kunyomi: うえ, あ, のぼ, うわ, かみ
meaning_story: There's a toe above ground. Look at it.
meaning_hint: Why is this important? There's another kanji with the toe below the ground, and I bet you can guess the meaning of that kanji. So, where's the toe? It's above the ground. Remember, the toe is what's important here (and its location, because you have to find it otherwise they won't be able to sew it back on).
reading_story: The toe sticking up above the ground is just a little thing... You go up to poke it and then you realize that the toe actually belongs to Joseph (じょう) Stalin. Joe doesn't like people messing with his toes, so you slowly back away.
reading_hint: Joseph Stalin, if you didn't know, has very sensitive toes. He's also very mean. Imagine yourself backing slowly away from Joe as to not incur his mighty wrath.

kunyomi: した, さが, くだ, お
meaning_story: There's a toe below ground.
meaning_hint: So, where is the toe now? It's below ground. Imagine yourself digging it out, and thinking... ugh, why does it have to be below ground like this? So irritating. Will I be able to sew it back on in time to save it?
reading_story: You keep digging for the toe below the ground, and instead of hitting a toe you hit something hard and metallic. You keep digging and digging around it, but it's huge. Turns out, you found yourself a car (か). Keep digging until you unearth the car. Inside, you find the toe you were looking for.
reading_hint: There's another useful on'yomi reading that just isn't useful enough for you to learn now. That reading is げ, but we're only going to worry about that much, much later when you have to learn one or two vocab words that read 下 as げ. That's the problem with really common kanji - too many readings.

meaning_story: The big radical and the big kanji are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well.
reading_story: There's this big guy (that's how you remember the radical, remember?), and he's wearing a huge Tie Dye (たい, だい) shirt. Because he's so huge, the tie dye shirt is also super huge. Everything about him is pretty big, but the tie dye stands out more than anything.
reading_hint: When you look at the big guy in your head, imagine him covered in tie dye head to toe. Think about how ridiculous it looks on him, especially since he's such a big guy. Shirt. Sweatpants. Hat. Shoes... it goes on and on.

meaning_story: This isn't exactly the same as the fins radical, but it's close. Sometimes this will happen (where we have to use a slightly 'modified radical' version of the original), so it's good to understand that now, early on. In this case, we have fins. How many fins? eight fins. How do you know that? Because you caught four fish with two fins each.
meaning_hint: Count the fins out in front of you, all the way from one to eight. It'll help if you actually do this. Now smell each fin, and think 'wow, I have to smell all eight of these?' Yes, you do.
reading_story: After you count and smell all eight of your fins, it's time to put them away. You open a large hatch (はち) and put them in. This is where you keep your fins, always putting in eight at a time because that's what the boss wants.
reading_hint: You've asked him why you can only put eight fins at a time in the hatch, but he never wants to answer. What could be down in the hole that the hatch covers? Why is there a hatch at all? What's with numbers and hatches being mysterious?

meaning_story: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for enter first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means enter as well.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
reading_story: Turns out, after you Enter the teepee (you'll remember that the radical is a teepee with a big entrance to it), you're given a new (にゅう) car!
reading_hint: Imagine lights turning on and flashing, and an entire audience inside. You're at a gameshow, and the announcer announces the neeeeew car in his announcey voice. Feel the surprise. Feel the happiness. Feel the excitement. Check the year on the car, too. It's this year! It really is new!

meaning_story: The radical is construction, which is part of the construction industry.
meaning_hint: Not to mention, construction of buildings and factories leads to all kinds of new industries as well. Think of all the new industries you could build with construction!
reading_story: To remember the sound こう we use the name こういち. Think of a construction worker. But, instead of thinking of a normal construction worker, think of one that's just wearing suspenders and a hard hat. No shirt. He's a sexy construction worker, in fact. Then, imagine this sexy construction worker as こういち, your favorite Japanese textbook writer, obviously. Boy is he looking sexy.
reading_hint: If you're somehow not attracted to the hunk of a man that this construction worker version of こういち is, that's okay. It's still ridiculous enough to hook a memory into that brain of yours. Make yourself mad over the fact that he's not following construction site regulations (where's his shirt, shoes, and pants?). That's dangerous! Even if you do look that sexy. Hey, put out that cigarette, it's bad for you! On the other hand, say you do really like what you see (you'll probably have to imagine a better looking version of Koichi's face, though). You two make eye contact. He nods as he puts out his cigarette and takes off his construction worker helmet, letting his long Fabio-esque locks flow. You beckon him over. What happens next is up to you and your own imagination. My guess is you have a conversation about kanji and the best ways to learn it.

meaning_story: The mountain radical and the mountain kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you are, then you're studying your kanji as well!
reading_story: Think about mountains talking to each other, calling each other by their names and adding the Japanese name-ender san (さん) to each of their names. 'Hello, Everest-san.' 'Oh hi, Fuji-san.'
reading_hint: Be sure to imagine this vividly. The more absurdly you can imagine it, the more likely you are to remember the reading, san.

meaning_story: The kanji and the radical that look like this are exactly the same. They are both mouth.
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical mouth you know the kanji mouth.
reading_story: Whenever we need to remember the sound こう we use the name こういち. You'll become familiar with this name after a while because the reading こう comes up a lot. Think of a mouth (that should be easy). Now, change it into the scariest mouth you can imagine. Perhaps the teeth are a foot long but just as skinny... or, the lips are bleeding and crispy... whatever scares you, think of it. Then, pan back away from the mouth to see whose mouth it is. Turns out it's こういち's mouth. See こういち there with a terrifying mouth. How scary!
reading_hint: Make sure to vividly imagine that disgusting mouth on こういち. He needs some facial upkeep, I think. The scarier you make it for yourself, and the more ridiculous it is, the more likely you're going to remember this reading. So, imagine away!

meaning_story: Nice! This kanji is the same as the radical that looks just like it (down to the meaning, even!). The radical is Nine and the kanji is Nine making the meaning of this kanji really easy to remember as long as you know the radical first.
meaning_hint: If you know the radicals nice and well, you'll know this kanji's meaning nice and well too!
reading_story: Although this kanji has two on'yomi to learn, the pronunciations of those two on'yomi are very similar, and nearly the same thing (making it easier to remember). Let's use the meaning, Nine, to remember the on'yomi as well. Whenever you try to hit on some cute (きゅう, く) guy/girl (your choice) Nine out of ten times they just spit in your face.
reading_hint: Think of the cutest guy or girl you can. It's important to get it in your mind that these people are super cute, and not just 'somebody.' If you have to, think puppies and kittens instead, the ultimate-cute-machine. They just bite you nine out of ten times. And yes, you keep stats, so imagine yourself writing down stats of this every time you try.

meaning_story: Lying on the ground is something that looks just like the ground, the number One. Why is this One lying down? It's been shot by the number two. It's lying there, bleeding out and dying. The number One doesn't have long to live.
meaning_hint: To remember the meaning of One, imagine yourself there at the scene of the crime. You grab One in your arms, trying to prop it up, trying to hear its last words. Instead, it just splatters some blood on your face. 'Who did this to you?' you ask. The number One points weakly, and you see number Two running off into an alleyway. He's always been jealous of number One and knows he can be number one now that he's taken the real number one out.
reading_story: As you're sitting there next to One, holding him up, you start feeling a weird sensation all over your skin. From the wound comes a fine powder (obviously coming from the special bullet used to kill One) that causes the person it touches to get extremely itchy (いち).
reading_hint: Make sure you feel the ridiculously itchy sensation covering your body. It climbs from your hands, where you're holding the number One up, and then goes through your arms, crawls up your neck, goes down your body, and then covers everything. It becomes uncontrollable, and you're scratching everywhere, writhing on the ground. It's so itchy that it's the most painful thing you've ever experienced (you should imagine this vividly, so you remember the reading of this kanji).

meaning_story: Do you remember the radical version of this kanji, where you knocked a zombie down breaking it in half, only leaving its legs standing? Then it said 'Hey, I'm a Person too?' Well, that radical is a kanji too, and that kanji is Person.
meaning_hint: Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.
reading_story: Only one Person at Nintendo (にん) complained about the new Jeans (じん) policy, and that person was you.
reading_hint: Imagine how angry you were about the policy. You'll have to come up with something to be angry about yourself (pick something that would actually make you angry, like maybe you're only allowed to wear cut off short-shorts jeans at Nintendo now), but if you pick something good, you'll definitely remember the two readings for this. Just remember you're working at Nintendo, and the policy has to be something about jeans. Then, imagine yourself as the only person complaining and everyone else in their dumb jeans (or lack-thereof) shaking their head at you because you're being a fool.

meaning_story: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are the same. Both are Power.
meaning_hint: If you know the radicals, you should be feeling fine... No, you should feel powerful!
reading_story: Who has the most Power of anyone? It's the Power Rangers. Who are they battling? Ricky the Rock (りき, りょく) Monster.
reading_hint: Know anyone named Ricky (りき), even a famous person like Ricky Ricardo or Ricky Gervais? Put his face on the monster the Power Rangers are fighting. Also, imagine him throwing rocks (りょく) and hitting people with them. You should imagine it as more gruesome than Power Rangers was on the show. This is real, yo (and gruesome will help you to remember).

meaning_story: The river radical and the river kanji are the same as each other!
meaning_hint: So, if you know the radical you know the kanji as well.
reading_story: So you're in a river. As you're floating down, enjoying yourself, you bump into something. It says 'moo' to you. You look around. There are hundreds of cows (かわ) surrounding you.
reading_hint: Touch them as you float by. Smell them. Is the river filled with cow poop? Probably. Use that to help you to remember that you run into cows when you're in the river.

meaning_story: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is seven and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also seven. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!
reading_story: You know this kanji means Seven, so let's use that to remember the reading too. Seven is a lucky number, usually, but this time it wasn't so good. Seven percent is all she got on her test after she cheated (しち) on it.
reading_hint: How unbelievable is it that someone got seven percent on a test, especially if you try to cheat? Imagine the girl you loathe the most from school, and imagine her cheating on the test (it's important it's a girl, because of the 'she' part in she cheated (しち). Then, imagine your happiness when she's super upset about getting seven percent on it. Serves her right, obviously.

meaning_story: When you think of crosses, you think of certain religions (Christianity). Instead of thinking about Christianity, though, let's think about where the Christians came from, namely the Jewish faith. How many commandments did they have? They had ten of them.
meaning_hint: This kanji is made up entirely of the cross radical, which might be a little confusing since you have to remember two different meanings. If you make a progression of the story in your mind, though, it should be a lot better. So, as long as you think 'Okay, I have a cross ... what have I associated with this cross? Why, the Ten Commandments.' If you do this, you should be alright and you should be able to remember both!
reading_story: So, now that you have the Ten Commandments in your head, think 'who held up these Ten Commandments?' Why it was Moses, who was a Jew (じゅう).
reading_hint: See how the progression of everything works? If you know the radicals, you can remember the meaning. If you know the meaning, you can remember the reading. It's all about connecting these things to each other in your head, because the more connections you have, the more likely you are to remember! It's just how the brain works.

meaning_story: This one uses the ground radical (which also happens to be the kanji for 'one') and the radical 'two.' Let's combine those ones together. What do you get? You get three.
meaning_hint: This one should be pretty self explanatory! Even easier, you can look at this kanji and see it has three straight lines. You know what one looks like. You know what two looks like. So... this is three! (Four is not like this, though).
reading_story: I'm going to count to three, then I'm going to whack you with these three sticks, son (さん).
reading_hint: I think a Southern accent goes well with this meaning mnemonic. You'll want to imagine that you're a boy and your dad has three sticks, ready for some thwacking. Feel a little afraid by this, and sad about three times the pain. The more emotions you can input (like fear) into this mnemonic, the more likely you are to remember it!

meaning_story: The kanji two and the radical two are the exact same things. Therefore, you know the kanji for two already!
meaning_hint: More simply put, you can just know that this kanji is the double of One. It's two lines, that's not all that hard to remember!
reading_story: Think of all the things you have Two of. What is the most important? Some would say eyes, some would say ears. I would say the knee (に) because if you didn't have them, it'd be really hard to go up stairs.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself without two knees, and see what it would be like. What would give you trouble? What couldn't you do? Just imagining this for a minute or two will help you to remember the reading of this kanji more effectively.

meaning_story: The radical for woman and the kanji for woman are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: That means if you know your radicals well, you know the meaning of this kanji as well! How swell.
reading_story: When you imagine this woman, she has a jo (じょ) weapon. She's standing in a battle stance, and yelling "I'm the mighty jo fighter woman!"
reading_hint: Be sure to think "Huh, what a weird lady... Wait, she's gonna hit me with that jo of hers, crap!!"

meaning_story: You're sitting on your stool again!!?
meaning_hint: There's someone you know who carries a stool around with her all the time. Why? Because she's super pregnant and can't walk too far. You're walking with her, but she has to stop every few feet and sit on her stool, again and again. Feel irritated about this, because it will help you to remember the meaning of this kanji better. Imagine this scene taking place several times as you're trying to walk to your destination together, but she's too slow and it's super-duper irritating.
reading_story: So, she's really pregnant, and carrying a stool, sitting on it again and again. Where are you two going? Where would a super preggers person go? Well, she needs to go to the matanity (また) store to get new clothes for her giant baby stomach.
reading_hint: I know 'mata' and 'maternity' are a bit of a stretch, but the goal is to get you to the memory of また in your head, so they don't necessarily need to be exactly the same. If this can get you to the correct memory in your head, then it does the right thing, and that's good. So, make that your goal and you'll probably remember the reading for this kanji!

meaning_story: The king has something in his hand that he's dropping... but it bounces too! He's bouncing a ball.
meaning_hint: This kanji looks just like a king bouncing a ball, no? If not, imagine the kanji itself bouncing the drop (the ball) over and over again, then laying some hoops like a pro.
reading_story: Think of someone curled up in a ball. It is someone you know / someone famous named “Tom” (たま).
reading_hint: So, who's in a ball? Which 'Tom' did you choose?

meaning_story: The real radical and the book kanji are the same in looks, but different in meaning. Still, what's the most real thing in the world, besides real life? That would be a book. People put their heart and soul into books, making them as real as they can... that is, unless you read Twilight. There's nothing real about glittery vampires. Take note that the second, third, and fourth meanings of this kanji are origin, real, and main. You can figure this out by thinking about how books almost always have their origin in real life. This in fact is the main source of book materials (real life).
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself reading various books... and have them have crazy contents. Constantly think... 'Is it real?' And then decide. Focus in on the fact you're reading a book, especially.
reading_story: Books are one of the best ways to hone (ほん) your intellect, you know?
reading_hint: A bit weak in the memory department, I know, but run it through your mind a few times. Luckily, you’ll see this on’yomi so much it’ll end up being hard not remembering it, good memory technique or not.

meaning_story: The child radical and the child kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: So, if you know your radicals, you know your kanji as well! This won't last forever (where radicals are exactly the same as the kanji) so enjoy it while the kanji are still small and simple!
reading_story: To remember the sounds し and す we'll use these mnemonics: There's a child. He's walking around, having a good time. Then, all of a sudden out of nowhere, Charlie Sheen (し) jumps out and grabs the child, then runs away with him. That child's parents are definitely going to sue (す) Charlie Sheen (し).
reading_hint: You give chase after him - make sure you zero in on the child, thinking about how you need to save said child. The child is what's important here, because that's the kanji you're learning. Oh, and Charlie Sheen as well, since you have to remember the reading, too. Of course, think about the ridiculousness of the situation. First of all, it's Charlie Sheen. Second of all, he's abducting a child. Third, if he gets away, he's totally getting sued. That's crazy... well... maybe not that crazy.

meaning_story: What's something with nine sides? Just add a drop and you'll have something that's almost a circle.
meaning_hint: It's not quite a circle though. You just need to add a drop of liquid to the edges to smooth it out to become a full circle.
reading_story: Do you know about the adorable cat Maru? If not, you should check it out. May seem like a distraction, but if you come back knowing the reading for this kanji, then it's totally worth while. When you think about a circle, think about Maru all rolled up in a little circle, being super adorable. Don't tell me it doesn't melt your heart just thinking about it.Alternatively, you could also look at this kanji and think of Maru inside of a box, with her little tail sticking out of it. Whatever works best for you, just get yourself to 'Maru.'
reading_hint: Obviously if you 'don't know this reading' well enough, you should watch some more Maru videos. I'll understand... just make sure you come back someday, okay?

meaning_story: What ground to a stop, so to speak? You're working on grading tests. But, you run into a question that is wrong, which made you stop. Why? Because you have to correct it.
meaning_hint: Go ahead and correct several answers. Feel like you suddenly have to stop whenever you have to correct something. Ugh, how time consuming.
reading_story: To remember the reading せい we use 'Hard Gay,' because he likes to say 'SEI SEI SEI!' Of course, if you don't know who this Japanese comedian is, you should check him out (literally or figuratively, whatever you want to do is your own business). Here he is helping out a ramen shop. As you're correcting these test answers, someone grabs your pencil and throws your desk to the side. And then they start humping your leg. It's Hard Gay (せい). He tells you that the test you are grading is the shogun's (しょう)! You can't give the shogun a bad grade, he'll have you executed!
reading_hint: Imagine Hard Gay shouting that you can't give the shogun a bad grade. Why is Hard Gay telling you this? You can't seem to figure out why, but with Hard Gay humping your leg it's hard to really concentrate on anything else.

meaning_story: The dog radical and dog kanji are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Soon there will be very few kanji/radical-same combos ... so enjoy it while you can.
reading_story: You see an emu running towards you from off in the distance (strange to see an emu in these parts...). As it gets closer, you realize that it's not an emu at all, it's something that sounds the same, or similar... an inu!
reading_hint: There's a good chance you know the word for dog in Japanese already too. If so, you're ahead of the game. If not, do your best to learn the reading before moving on.

meaning_story: The evening radical and the evening kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of this kanji as well. Make sure you know your radicals - they're the building block of everything you learn here!
reading_story: The evening is when it's time for YOU (ゆう).
reading_hint: Think about the day, and how it's all about doing things for other people... school, work, etc. But, in the evening, you do what you want, nothing else. Think about what those things might be. Say out loud 'This is for YOU.'

meaning_story: There are two mountains in front of you... and probably a bunch more around you too. You are in a pass, and don't know how to get out. You are frantically looking for the exit before you freeze to death. The most important thing is to find the exit from this mountain range - your life depends on it.
meaning_hint: In your imagination, really feel like your life depends on getting out. The important part is the feeling of 'needing to get out of the mountain pass.' If you have this feeling, you'll be more likely to remember that this kanji means exit, because that's what you want to do when you see this kanji.
reading_story: As you're trying to exit this mountain range, you suddenly realize that someone is actually hunting you. What? Make sure to feel that sudden realization. It's crazy. Then, you find the exit and run towards it. Sadly, the hunter is waiting there, and he shoots you (しゅつ) through the leg, knocking you down.
reading_hint: Focus on the surprise of realizing you're being hunted while trying to find the exit to the mountain range, then focus on the next part, where you get shot. View it in your head as the hunter shooting you. Powww!

meaning_story: The eye radical and eye kanji are the same as each other, so now you know them both.
meaning_hint: Well... you'll know them both as long as you studied your radicals, young grasshopper. If you didn't, then you're just a young grasshopper who needs to study his/her radicals.
reading_story: Your eyes are important to you, right? Sadly, one of your eyes is missing right now, because a sheep grabbed it and pulled it out, and is now running away from you, yelling his sheep call.... 'Mehhhhhh (め)!'
reading_hint: Of course, feel the pain of your eye being gone... and struggle to get it back. You eventually give up because the sheep is too fast, but then you come up with an idea. What if I call out back to the sheep in its own language? Go ahead and cover one eye and start making 'MEHHH' noises to see if you can get the sheep to come back to you and give you your eye. It's up to you whether it works or not, but be sure to feel frustrated by its reaction, or happy by it. Either one works.

meaning_story: Think about it this way. There is a famous fishing lure inventor, working on his best work ever. He’s old, and he’s been trying to make the best fishing lure for the last 50 years, and knows this will be his last invention. Then he figures it out. He takes one barb, and connects the end of it to the top of another barb. When he does this, he knows his work is finally finished.
meaning_hint: Make sure you look at this amazing fishing lure too - hold it in your hand, see the two barbs fused together. Think about how strange this lure is. Is this really the best in the world? Will this really finish all other fishing lures?
reading_story: How does the fish lure maker test his newly finished lure out? The one he just finished? He gets in a row (りょう) boat and rows out into the sea.
reading_hint: Make him think that he can’t just use his new lure on the side of the lake / ocean / whatever. He has to get out there, but unfortunately all he has is a crappy row boat. Imagine the row boat being terrible, leaky, and dangerous, which is why you’re surprised when he goes for it. That’s a terrible row boat to use! If you do this, you'll focus your mind on the rowboat part of things, which will help you to remember the reading of this kanji.

meaning_story: The fire and the fire kanji are the same as each other.
meaning_hint: If you know the radicals then this one is EZPZ.
reading_story: Whenever we need to remember か, we use the word car. For this kanji, when we think fire, we ought to think of something on fire. What is it on fire? It's obviously your very own car (か)! Oh Goddd NOOO!
reading_hint: Oh no... Oh no!! If you don't have a car, imagine what it'd feel like if your car just exploded and burned down. If you do have a car, imagine your own car in this situation. It should be a terrible feeling, if you imagine it well enough. So, when you think fire, remember the fear you had when your car was given to the flames. Now you have to walk everywhere, sad :(

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji are the same, so make sure you know the radical to know the meaning of this kanji as well (five).
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, friend-o.
reading_story: What do you have five of? The thing that comes to most people's minds is fingers (or toes). With these five fingers, you can do anything. Most notably, though, you can play the game 'go' (ご)- a game popular strategy board game in Japan.
reading_hint: When you think of your five fingers, imagine yourself playing the game go. If you don't know the game, look it up and watch some videos - you'll be able to imagine yourself playing it enough to remember the reading if you do. Focus on the hands while watching. See what the players do with their five fingers.

meaning_story: Imagine contorting yourself in such a way that your legs end up inside your mouth. You have bent your body in all the wrong ways in order to achieve this. In fact, if you look at yourself, you look like a square now... You're just a person with four sides.
meaning_hint: If you can get to square, you should be able to get to four as well, since squares always have four sides.
reading_story: Despite how amazing this feat you just completed is, the audience watching you is really bored. 'Yawn' (よん) they say, politely covering their mouth.
reading_hint: Try to be a little upset about this. You did something crazy, but nobody is reacting. They are bored? What the heck? Zoom your imagination in on their yawns, especially. How can they be that tired by your four-sides trick?

meaning_story: You have a cross. Why is there a slide / stroke going through the cross? Why, because religion really was a 'stroke of genius.' Oh, and see that little hook at the bottom? That's because once they hook onto you, they never let go. More genius!
meaning_hint: When you think about crosses and religion, it's hard to help but think of how it's changed and affected history. Someone was pretty genius at some point.
reading_story: Who do you know who's a genius? You don't even have to know them personally. Just think of them, and *sigh* (さい) when you do. Ugh, look at that genius over there. *Sigh*
reading_hint: The important part for remembering this kanji's reading is the feeling. You're so exasperated by how genius this person is, and how jealous you are about it. Do the sigh for real, too, if it will help. Just be sure to have that sighing feeling when you think about this person. The more realistic the (imagined) feeling, the more likely you are to remember this kanji's reading, too!

meaning_story: The hand radical and the hand kanji are identical in looks and meaning! That should make things easy!
meaning_hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. It won't be forever that radicals and kanji overlap so nicely like this!
reading_story: To remember the reading て we will use the word 'Television.' You have great hands. Go ahead and look at them. OH MY GOD. You have little televisions (て) on your hands. They are playing the dumbest show you can think of, too, both hands at the same time.
reading_hint: You try to shake your hands off, but it's no good. The televisions are stuck, and the volume won't go down. You have no idea how you got these televisions on your hands. All you know is that you want them off right this instant.

meaning_story: The radical heaven is the same as the kanji heaven, making this an easy kanji to memorize.
meaning_hint: If you know your radicals well (and you should!) you know the meaning of this kanji well, as well!
reading_story: Heaven... nowadays, people aren't all that good. Things have gotten bad. That's why the acceptance rate to get into heaven is only ten (てん) percent!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in line to get into heaven. You're super worried, because you're not sure if you'll get in. You heard there was a one in ten chance... those aren't good odds. Feel nervous in your imagination. Feel worried. Feel the pressure as you get closer and closer to the gate... will you make it?? Ten percent!

meaning_story: The radical and the meaning of this kanji are almost the same, but not quite. It's very easy, though - the radical is sword. We're learning Japanese, so can you name a Japanese sword. That's right, the most common is a katana, which happens to be the meaning of this kanji as well.
meaning_hint: The progression on this one is important. When you think sword you have to think 'what kinds of swords do Japanese people have?' Then, you'll reach the meaning of this kanji on your own.
reading_story: So now you have this sweet katana in your hands and you're swinging it around like an idiot. Feel free to make 'whooshing' noises as you swing it around. To become a master katana wielder, you decide to travel to Tokyo (とう). Tokyo has the best katana schools in the world, so it makes sense to travel to Tokyo.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself trying to travel to Tokyo with your katana. Airport security is not happy with you trying to take a katana on the plane, so you get a full cavity search. How awful.

meaning_story: The king kanji and the king radical are the same!
meaning_hint: Hopefully you're a king of radicals... because if you are, this kanji meaning was super easy for you!
reading_story: Oh (おう) Great KING… Please don’t kill me… Oh Great KING.
reading_hint: Unfortunately, there isn’t a really good way to learn this one using mnemonics, just because the “oh” sound is so common. If you can get used to thinking “Oh King” as something natural when it comes to thinking of the word “king” you should be alright. I’m not saying it’ll be totally easy, but try and think “king” then think “oh king” then “king” then “oh king” a few times (or more) and it should create a connection strong enough to help you remember the on’yomi. If that doesn’t work, there’s always common vocab – and luckily there’s no kun’yomi to confuse you.

meaning_story: The Narwhal construction group wants to build houses for narwhals. Instead of speaking for the narwhals like the right (右) does, they take action and build houses for narwhals that need homes. These people are members of the left, liberal political party. Of course, they're using lots of high taxes to pay for these houses, which the right doesn't like. That's how you know the left is involved in the construction.
meaning_hint: Imagine a bunch of hippies building the houses. That's how you'll know they're the liberal group, and on the left.
reading_story: This is a long reading to learn compared to normal (because this kanji primarily uses kun'yomi for its reading). Imagine all the construction workers with a funny accent. Whenever they walk by, they say "Hi Da'ri" (ひだり) which is supposed to be "Hi There," or "Hi Dearie." You're not sure which, but he's definitely saying "Hidari" at you.
reading_hint: I don't know what country these people are from, but imagine the phrase in a silly way in order to help your self to remember it.

meaning_story: The radical Middle and the kanji Middle are both the same. So if you know one, you know the other.
meaning_hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise you might find yourself in the middle of a kanji-learning problem.
reading_story: To remember the reading for this kanji, we use the word chewbacca to pull up ちゅう in our memory. If you remember back to the radical 中, the middle of your mouth was stabbed with a stick. You look up to see who did it. There stands Chewbacca over you, doing his Chewbacca yell. He has another stick too, and this time he plants it right in the middle of your head.
reading_hint: Imagine the fear and shock you'd feel after finding out it was Chewbacca who stabbed the middle of your mouth (and head). Give him a touch and smell too - it'll help you to remember this reading.

meaning_story: The moon kanji is made up of the moon radical.
meaning_hint: This should be EZPZ as long as you know the radicals already!
reading_story: Since げつ and がつ are quite similar, we'll use one mnemonic to cover both of them. I expect your experience learning Japanese throughout the future will help you to memorize and differentiate between the two. When the moon goes down and goes away, everyone in the world gets (げつ) up, because that means it's going to be daytime soon!
reading_hint: This one might not be as memorable at first, but if you think of the moon, and think about what people do when the moon is up, you'll come to sleeping. Then naturally you can think about what happens when the moon goes down... people gets up!

meaning_story: This is a strange kanji because it doesn't really mean anything at all. In fact, what it does is it repeats the kanji that comes before it. For example: 人々 is actually 人人. This kanji shows up whenever there's a repeating kanji, because it's often easier to write than writing a more complicated kanji twice. That's why this kanji is the repeater. It repeats what comes before it. To remember that this kanji is the repeater, though, think of a drop going into an enclosure. Drip drop drip drop. It does that over and over again even after it fills up. The dropping of the drops is the repeater portion.
meaning_hint: Since this kanji doesn't really have a meaning as much as it does a function, try to change the way you think about it when you're memorizing it.
reading_story: In Japanese, this symbol is often called the のま because it looks like the katakana characters ノ and マ put together. If you know katakana then this will be easy to read. If you don't, think of it this way: Your mom is the repeater. She is trying to force feed you over and over again until you explode (literally). You keep yelling 'No ma!' (のま) but she doesn't stop. She's on a repeating track, never stopping, repeating forever.
reading_hint: If you feel like you're so full you're about to burst, and if you imagine your mom doing this to you (how could you, ma?) you should be able to remember the reading of this kanji. That being said, the reading is mostly only useful in the event that you have to identify a 々 - otherwise, you won't see it much.

meaning_story: The rice paddy radical and the rice paddy kanji are the same, making this one super easy to remember, at least meaning-wise.
meaning_hint: Just know your radicals, and you will know your kanji as well.
reading_story: To remember the reading た, we use the word 'taco.' You're in the rice field... but when you lean down to examine the rice more closely, you see that it's not rice that's growing, it's a bunch of little tacos, blossoming out of the ground.
reading_hint: Smell the tacos. Touch the tacos. Taste the tacos. This is definitely a very strange rice field.

meaning_story: The Narwhal mouths. These are a group of people who speak on behalf of the narwhals. Strangely, though, in terms of political party, it's the right that's representing these majestic animals.
meaning_hint: The right are protesting gun rights and lower taxes for narwhals. Make sure you think it's strange that the right would even ask for these things for narwhals, let alone try to represent the narwhals... something's fishy here.
reading_story: This far-right narwhal group is getting militaristic, too. They're buying MIG (みぎ) fighter jets from the Russians to protect their Narwhal Friends.
reading_hint: See lines and lines of MIGS on the ice where the Narwhal's live. I hope you have a little fear of this. They are scary, these jets.

meaning_story: Just imagine a beast with a lid for a head and fins for feet, running around looking as insane as possible (really imagine it!). When it runs up to you, it shows you the top of its lid-head. On it is written the numbers 666. Why? Because it's a spawn of the devil, and the number six is the devil's number.
meaning_hint: Imagine this beast doing various crazy things, the crazier the better (to help you remember). Make sure all these things are associated with the devil and the devil's number (six), so you can remember the meaning of this kanji.
reading_story: Whenever we need to remember the reading ろく we just use the word rock. So, think about the devil and the devil's number. What is often associated with those things? Why, rock (ろく) and roll is. Imagine the lid-head fin-legged beast suddenly blasting out rock music in the middle of his destructive mayhem.
reading_hint: Sing along with the monster, if it helps you to remember the reading of this kanji.

meaning_story: The small radical and the small kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: So, know the radicals and you'll know the kanji. Nice how that works out.
reading_story: This small kanji would be a terrible gift to give to the shogun. This is the shogun's least favorite kanji since it's so small. The shogun's wife really likes it though, so the shogun gives it to her.
reading_hint: Imagine something really really small... so small you can barely even see it. That thing is this kanji. As such, the shogun really dislikes it since it doesn't look powerful. The shogun's wife thinks it's super cute though. Imagine the shogun's wife giggling and squealing over how cute it is.

meaning_story: The radical grave makes up the entirety of this kanji. In a grave, it's filled in with one thing, soil.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself filling up a grave, shoveling in shovelfuls of soil. It's sad business, especially since you're burying someone/something really important to you :( In your imagination, smell the soil that you're scooping in. Touch it and feel it too. Using more of your senses (even in your imagination) will help you to remember the meaning of this kanji (and any kanji) more effectively.
reading_story: To remember the reading ど, we will use the word 'dog'. As you're burying this important thing with soil, a dog (ど) runs up and starts unburying it, very frantically. You try to stop it, but it snarls and snaps at you and tries to get you to back up. Turns out, the dog keeps digging past your buried object, and unburies a ghost dog, which jumps out and takes over your body. Feel what a dog feels, because you've just been taken over by a dead dog.
reading_hint: Make sure you remember all the mnemonics in order as sort of a progression of one story. They connect to each other because it's easier to remember things that connect / continue. So if you remember the pieces as a whole you're more likely to remember all the things you need to remember!

meaning_story: The radical stand and the kanji stand are the same thing, so now you know them both.
meaning_hint: If you're keeping up with your radical studies, you're also keeping up with your kanji studies!
reading_story: Think of someone who has to stand up straight for you. These people are pros in hospitality. These are the doormen at the Ritz (りつ).
reading_hint: Imagine the doormen being extra straight… too straight in their standing. On their uniform is “The Ritz” written in fine lettering, and as you walk past them, they stand up straight and say “Welcome to the Ritz!” Whatever you do, while you’re thinking about it, make sure you think about how they stand up so straight, and associate it with these doormen, who work, specifically, at the Ritz. If you effectively imagine all this, you should be able to remember this on’yomi. Go through it like it’s a movie in your head!

meaning_story: The stone radical and stone kanji are the same thing!
meaning_hint: Know your radicals and therefore know your kanji. It's just that simple.
reading_story: You throw a stone through a window... that was surprisingly easy (いし).
reading_hint: Reading's a bit of a stretch, but the goal is to get you to the correct reading, so do your best to make sure it does just that!

meaning_story: This kanji is made up of the nail radical. Where would you hate to see nails? The worst place to scatter nails would be the street because of all the cars driving by.
meaning_hint: Imagine someone spreading nails out all over the street and watching cars hitting them and popping all the tires. Who would do such a terrible thing?
reading_story: Who is spreading these nails on the street? That is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), who will be popping up from time to time in the future as well (so be sure to get a good image of her in your head).
reading_hint: Might be sort of racist, but we gotta do this for memory's sake, right? Mrs. Chou is an evil little Asian lady. She hates everyone and does bad things to others for her enjoyment. Her laugh even sounds like her name. Imagine her laughing, saying 'Chou chou chou chou,' she says while spreading nails all over the street. She's like some evil Asian Santa Claus, or something.

meaning_story: The sun radical and sun kanji are the same, huzzah! Also, if you want to remember day as well, you can just think about how a day is the time it takes for the sun to cross the sky.
meaning_hint: The radical for this one is easy too, making the meaning for this kanji super easy as well!
reading_story: There are so many on'yomi for this kanji, but since this kanji is so important and common, you'll end up learning them all eventually whether you want to or not. For now, you're only going to have to learn one of the readings, and that one is にち. The sun is so hot. It focused its rays to take out one man... and that man is Friedrich Nietzsche (にち), famous philosopher. He philosophized one too many things about the sun, so the sun decided it was time he paid.
reading_hint: This reading will be easier to remember if you know of Friedrich Nietzsche... so do your research and learn about him if you don't. He's a pretty historical dude. Imagine the sun totally pissed off, too. It makes a grunting noise as it builds up a sun beam to blast him off the face of the earth. Also note that there's another reading worth learning as well: じつ. The reading can be remembered by thinking 'Gee! Two readings?' Because, seriously, two readings? Too many...

meaning_story: This kanji looks like and means the same thing as the radical, which makes it particularly easy to remember.
meaning_hint: As long as you know the radical thousand then you know the kanji thousand as well!
reading_story: Remember the thousand crosses you got stuck under while learning the radical 千? You're still under it. Then, suddenly, someone pops his head over you and says 'hey, I'll save you... but only for a thousand cents (せん). Go ahead and try to calculate what that would come out to. It's not that expensive, actually
reading_hint: But, the problem is even though you have a thousand cents in your pocket, you can't get them out. You're stuck under all these crosses. So, your savior just shrugs and runs off, he won't help you anymore. Feel the desperateness of the situation to help yourself remember the kanji better. Hear the coins falling on the ground.

meaning_story: This is another kanji that is the same as the radical. Both tree and tree are the same in looks and meaning.
meaning_hint: So, how are those radicals doing? Do you know them well?
reading_story: You’re walking through the trees, looking at them. They look ominous. Then, your foot gets stuck in the muck (もく) and you try to pull your leg out, but can’t. Then the trees next to you beginning to mock you. Even the mocking birds mock you. It’s terrible. It’s painful. You’re being mocked while you’re stuck in the muck.
reading_hint: Feel the shame, feel the irritation. Make yourself want to break free just so you can go attack those dumb trees making fun of you and mocking you.

meaning_story: The water radical and the water kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: So as long as you know the radicals, you know the kanji.
reading_story: Imagine a lake (i.e. a a whole bunch of water). When you think of water, you should try to think of this beautiful lake. It’s sunny, the trees smell nice (imagine a tree smell if you can – the more senses you use the better!) and on that tree there is an awesome tire swing (すい). You get onto the tire swing and you swinging back and forth. The water is right in front of you, and you are able to use the swing to throw yourself into the water. It’s a lot colder than you expected, and you come back to the surface, gasping for breath. The water gets into your mouth and you taste it. How strange, it’s very, very sweet. Imagine the sweetness of the water and how weird it is (really really sweet, this water is).
reading_hint: I know that was a long one, but try to imagine all the different bits. Try to feel the feelings (cold, smell, etc) too. The more you create in this fake memory (which you’re using to remember and associate water with すい (swing)) the more likely you are to end up remembering enough to make it happen. Especially when it comes to the senses part, the more vividly you imagined it, the more likely you are to remember the on’yomi.

meaning_story: The radical white and the kanji white are the same.
meaning_hint: Study your radicals hard! Most important thing!
reading_story: The white team was the first to be able to hack (はく) the white iPhone.
reading_hint: Imagine two teams (black and white), wearing their team colors, working really hard on hacking the iPhone. It is a huge contest, and people are watching with a lot of tensions, to see who will hack the white iPhone first. Feel that tension, and see the colors separating them so vividly. The colors are important, and the excitement of the winner holding up the hacked iPhone is too.

meaning_story: The doll means writing. This is one of those rare instances where the kanji and the radical meanings don't match (even though they look the same). To remember this one, Imagine a doll walking around. It's evil, obviously. You don't see it walking around, but you know it is. You keep finding nasty notes... writing that she has done while you're asleep, telling you nasty things and threatening you.
meaning_hint: Feel the fear of this as if it were actually happening. Writing? From a doll?? Imagine the things she could write to you and be afraid. Dolls really are terrifying.
reading_story: This is one of the unfortunate situations where the kanji has multiple important readings to learn... The doll's writing states a couple of demands. First, the doll demands that you give her more bread buns (ぶん). Second, she demands you stop calling her a monster. She does not appreciate this. She is a little girl.
reading_hint: Make sure you read these demands out slowly in your mind. Think about each demand she has, and think about how ridiculous they are. First of all, dolls don't eat buns. Second, she's totally a monster. You better make a decision, though, and act it out in your head. Dolls don't like to be kept waiting.

meaning_story: The combination of radicals for this kanji may not be obvious at first, but if you look carefully you'll see it. The lid is inside the head for this kanji because it's holding something in. Imagine the top of someone's head being closed by a lid. Open that lid up and peer inside... it's full of yen coins, the Japanese money system.
meaning_hint: Another thing that will help is to associate the word round to this kanji, because it has both of these meanings. Both are right, and if you learn one that's better than not learning either, but maybe if you think about how round the coins themselves are inside this person's head, you'll remember this one too.
reading_story: What does the word yen sound like? It sounds like えん. Why? because back in the day, Japanese used to have a 'ye' sound, but now it doesn't. Instead, it's an 'e' sound, which is why yen = えん. Alternatively, you can pull one of these yen coins out of this guy's head and examine it closely. Upon inspection, you find out they're knockoffs. They're not yen. They're En (えん)!
reading_hint: Feel disappointed that this huge money stash is worthless. En are not as good as yen, that's for sure.

meaning_story: The arrow radical and the arrow kanji are the same. Sort of a 'straight' shot to memorizing this kanji, you know?
meaning_hint: Just know your radicals and you'll know this kanji!
reading_story: To remember the reading や we use the word “Yankees” (like the evil baseball team, go M’s!). What is this arrow doing? It’s following around all the Yankee (や) baseball players, stalking them, waiting to make its move (I’ll let you decide what it’s “move” is).
reading_hint: Imagine the arrow as a human-sized living thing with legs, arms, and clothes, though. Strangely, it’s able to walk around even though its an arrow. It has some kind of agenda. Make it a bit evil, if you can. What a strange thing…

meaning_story: That mean guy Two-face is trying to hide from Batman by wearing a lid over his face. The problem is, everyone in the whole city recognizes him. No one else would even try wearing a lid.
meaning_hint: Picture the big city so full of people and, oh, nope that's definitely Two-face wearing a lid. He's so obvious even in a city this big. Go get him, Batman.
reading_story: Batman is the protector of this city but you can't seem to find him. Someone has to stop Two-face, right? You search and search and oh no, there he is. It's Batman but his secret identity is... Charlie Sheen! He looks deeply into your eyes and you know your city will be safe. He's got this.
reading_hint: You walk up to Charlie Sheen and realize you should have known all along. Of course no one loves your city as much as he does.

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji for cow are exactly the same! That makes it easy to remember, so long as you know your radicals well enough.
meaning_hint: The radicals are important to know, so make sure you're studying them. They'll come back again, you know!
reading_story: Have you ever heard of わぎゅう beef? That ぎゅう is this ぎゅう.
reading_hint: I hope you know what わぎゅう beef is, otherwise this will be a difficult one to learn.

meaning_story: If you have seven swords, there's only so much you can do with them. The main thing? Probably using them to cut something.
meaning_hint: Take these seven swords and swing them around. Cut everything in your path, including yourself. Then, think about how dumb it was to try to use seven swords at once, and then feel the pain of the cut you gave yourself. Ouch, ouch ouch.
reading_story: Because having seven swords for yourself is too much, you decide to take the swords and divide them up amongst pairs of people. You cut them into pairs, and give sets (せつ) to everyone who needs them in the village.
reading_hint: Just make sure you think about how you need to give them away in sets, and not anything else. This is the most important thing to think about in your head as you're trying to establish the mnemonic for your kanji reading memory. It's gotta be sets.

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji for direction are the same! Huzzah! There is also another meaning too, though. This can also mean way as well. Think of it this way: When you move in one direction in your life, you are developing your own way. 'The way of [your name here].'
meaning_hint: The only direction you need to go in is forward, as long as you know the radicals enough to know the meaning of this kanji, too.
reading_story: You need direction, but you don't know how to get it. So, you decide to choose via some way that would be somewhat random. You find a hedge cutter (かた) on the ground, and throw it up into the air. You'll go in the direction in which it falls. Imagine it coming down almost hitting you in the face too, how that would have hurt!
reading_hint: Feel the cutter in your hand. Look at the tip of it... think about the possibilities that one side of the cutter will cause it to favor one direction over another. Wonder if that's really random, or not. Feel the weight of it as you throw it in the air. Whatever you do, just know that it's a cutter, and not any other tool.

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji for door are the same!
meaning_hint: Time to open the door to the reading part of this mnemonic.
reading_story: You open the door and immediately get it closed back on your toe (と), literally causing your toe to explode.
reading_hint: Feel the pain of your toe going away. Think about the other side of the door, where your toe is probably rolling around after it blasted off your foot.

meaning_story: You have a big guy here, with an extra drop of something below his thigh, hanging down. That's fat right there. He's so fat he has things of fat hanging off his fat.
meaning_hint: Maybe you should touch the fat below his leg just to see what it is... feel it, and squeeze it. It'll help you to remember that this kanji means 'fat.'
reading_story: This poor fat guy has trouble with a lot of things. One of the things he has the most trouble with is tying a tie (たい).
reading_hint: Imagine him trying to tie the tie but he can't lift his hands around to do it. You have to help him out. Another thing that might help you to remember this kanji's reading is that it's the same reading as 大 (or, one of the same readings). Similar kanji often have similar readings, which is a good thing to know when you have to guess (it's true with this one, anyways!).

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji for father are the same.
meaning_hint: No, I am not your father... but this kanji / radical set is!
reading_story: Imagine your father is Cheech (ちち) from Cheech and Chong.
reading_hint: Hopefully you know who they are. If not, think about your father laughing like this: ちちちちちちちち〜！

meaning_story: You have a small slide. The thing about small slides is that they can only fit a few people at a time.
meaning_hint: Imagine a small slide (how could you not, after you see the radicals?) with only a few people on it, trying to move forward. Only a few people are required to create a slide traffic jam, though :(
reading_story: Why is there a little traffic jam on the slide? Because the shogun (しょう) is using the slide, causing everyone to stop and watch, even though there are people backed up behind him. How inconsiderate.
reading_hint: Imagine this in your head. A traffic jam on the slide, all because the shogun is using it. Picture some caution tape, orange cones, and Japanese secret service members all making sure no one gets close to the shogun while he slides.

meaning_story: The narwhal is sitting on a stool. Why is he sitting there? You told all the people you thought were your friends to stay sitting on the stools if they were indeed still your friend. When you come back to see who's still left, it turns out only the narwhal is there for you. Narwhals make the greatest of friends.
meaning_hint: Imagine the narwhal saying 'Hey buddy, I'm still your friend,' and then jumping over to you to give you a nice narwhal hug. You cry, because you're relieved you have at least one friend left, even if it is a narwhal.
reading_story: You (ゆう) are my friend, Narwhal prince, you say. 'Only you.'
reading_hint: To remember this reading, you'll have to focus in on the ゆう part. It's only you, narwhal friend. Nobody else.

meaning_story: Fur and fur are the same as each other, so the meaning of this kanji should be simple. This can also mean hair, too, though more like furry hair.
meaning_hint: Just make sure you're studying your radicals, otherwise it won't be as simple as I'd hoped.
reading_story: With fur, wisp your imagination to a land where there are stalks of fur all around, just like a big tall grassy field (except instead of grass, it’s fur). You’re surrounded by the black fur, the wind is blowing. Imagine yourself touching the long fur and smelling it. What does it feel / smell like? Now it’s time to get rid of it. There’s just too much hair! To get rid of it, you’ll need to mow (もう) it down with a lawn mower. Imagine yourself starting up the lawn mower, and taking it around, mowing down the hair. Hear the sound of the mower in your head (they’re loud and distinct). The important thing is to imagine yourself mowing everything. Key is to think “fur → In the fur → getting rid of the fur → mow the fur,” in that order. That’ll get you to mow, which will help you to remember the on’yomi.
reading_hint: Smell the fur as you mow it down. Feel it flying everywhere. It's giant, so it must be pretty intense. Make it more intense to help yourself to remember the reading of this kanji better.

meaning_story: There's a triceratops on top of the antenna... which is a problem, because when he's there, you only get half of the channels on your TV.
meaning_hint: Be irritated as you go through your channels. Literally every other one (half of them) are just static. CHSHHHHH! Maybe you go up to your roof and push the triceratops off the antenna to fix it. When you come back down, strangely the other half of the channels work, but the original half are broken, now... Be a little angry about this, and mostly focus your anger on the half thing, not the triceratops thing.
reading_story: One of the channels you do get has Star Wars on it, though. Feel a little happy about that. It's the scene with the carbonite and Han Solo. Half of Han's body is sticking out of the carbonite.
reading_hint: Hopefully you’ve seen Star Wars, and you know what Han Solo looks like coming out of the carbonite. Half of him is sticking out in that expression everyone knows and loves. It's a very vivid picture, and focusing on it should help you to memorize the reading better as well. 'Half of Han Solo.'

meaning_story: The radical heart and the kanji heart are the same. Rejoice and let your heart be free!
meaning_hint: Also, make sure you know the radicals by heart, it'll help you to learn more effectively, just like with this kanji.
reading_story: The heart, where is it stored in your body? Most people thought it was in the chest, but in reality, your heart is stored in your shin (しん).
reading_hint: This is when I start kicking you in the shin and you imagine feeling the pain of getting kicked there. As I kick you in the shin, you grab your chest... all this stress is giving you a heart attack (though your shin hurts a ton too).

meaning_story: There's a person inside your head.
meaning_hint: And, you have no idea how to get them out. They're inside for good, and it's freaking you out. As in, there's a little person in there, running around, controlling your brain. People think you're crazy, but you know better... He's inside there, doing evil things.
reading_story: You know this kanji means inside, so you can keep thinking about the person that’s inside you, running around. You finally discover him, and try to take him out, but before you can, he pulls out a knife (ない) and threatens to cut you if you do anything irrational.
reading_hint: Imagine him holding the knife out, threatening to stab your brain. You’re in a conundrum here. If you don’t take him out, you’re in trouble, but if you do try to take him out, he might stab you in the brain with his knife. Try to think a way around this situation, focusing mainly on his knife.

kunyomi: い, う, なま, は, き
meaning_story: The life radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
meaning_hint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.
reading_story: Whenever we need to remember せい, we use the character 'Hard Gay' because he always says 'SEI SEI SEI!' If anyone out there is full of life, it's got to be Hard Gay, especially when he's shouting 'Sei (せい), sei, sei!' He's so excited about everything, and has a great time with other people. What an awesome life.
reading_hint: If you don't know Hard Gay, you should definitely search Hard Gay on YouTube... I promise it won't be as bad as it sounds... and, it'll help you to learn your kanji better, strangely. Just be sure to come back here when you're done, because you have kanji to study!

meaning_story: The raptor cage is a reinforced enclosure, so it will hold those raptors in for a really long time.
meaning_hint: You've seen Jurassic Park, though. You know this isn't true... Be suspicious of whoever's telling you this.
reading_story: Turns out, the person telling you is a big idiot. It's Jar Jar Binks. 'Heesa (ひさ) very scary raptor!' he yells before running off.
reading_hint: Add a few more instances of Jar Jar saying 'Heesa' instead of 'He's a' in your mind.

meaning_story: There's a pile of stuff that's going to be put inside your mouth... and it is terrible stuff. There's cars, microwave ovens, televisions, and more, and somehow you have to put them all in your mouth. This is some kind of torture, so feel the fear of what you're about to go through. The reason you want to imagine these things going into your mouth in particular is because these things are machines, and this is the machine counter kanji that you're learning.
meaning_hint: If you need extra help remembering, you'll have to imagine these big machines being put into your mouth, stretching your cheeks out huge and filling it up. This is the most painful thing ever, but somehow you're able to put this pile of machines in your mouth... you'll live another day.
reading_story: Finally, you're in luck. The police and emergency services have found you and saved you (feel the relief of that!). But, because you're full of cars and microwave ovens, they can't fit you in the ambulance (feel the disappointment at that). They do everything they can to get you out of there and back to the hospital but you're too big. You just die (だい) right there while they try to shove you into various emergency vehicles.
reading_hint: Imagine the conversation the emergency people would have... 'we can fit him in...' 'If we don't get him in, he'll die!' 'Well, I guess he's going to die then...' Wait, they're going to let me die???

meaning_story: The drawer radical looks like the mother kanji, though their meanings are different. Still, this isn't too far of a stretch. Who's the nice person that folds and puts your clothes in your drawer? That's your mother.
meaning_hint: On the other hand, you can imagine your mother yelling at you to put your clothes away in your drawers as well. Either way, just make sure your mother is involved in this mnemonic.
reading_story: Whenever your mother tells you to put away your own clothes in your drawer though, you just laugh. 'Ha ha!' you say.
reading_hint: HAHA this!! your mother might reply, slapping you across the head.

meaning_story: The antenna picks up your favorite show about slides every day at noon.
meaning_hint: You know this because at noon you're always busy eating lunch, and you can't watch the awesome reality slide television show that you so want to watch more than anything! Make sure you feel this way in your heart (at least in your imagination) because it will help you to remember that this kanji means noon, because noon is when your 'slides-show' comes on the TV via the antenna.
reading_story: Because you can't watch TV at noon, you find you have to watch TV at another time. That time is Five (ご) o'clock, and it's a TV show about the game of go (ご).
reading_hint: It's so boring, though, and you hate it. Feel the boredom and the frustration of having to watch a stupid show about go when you could be watching a show about slides at noon. I guess go will have to do :(

meaning_story: The nailbat and spoon are your weapons (what else would you do with a nailbat and spoon combination? Prolly nothing). What will you do with these things? You're going up to the North Pole to take out that two-timing, scheming bearded elf slave-driver named Santa.
meaning_hint: If you need help, think that you'll use the nailbat to take out Santa, and the spoon to dig a grave and bury him. Things might get kinda graphic in your head, but just know that it's for the sake of memorization, and even Santa has to make sacrifices some time. Also, focus on the location as well. You know that Santa is at the North Pole. Think about how that's where you need to go to finish your job.
reading_story: You find Santa and hit him with your nailbat and spoon. Because you hit him in the stomach, he hocks (ほく) up an elf.
reading_hint: The elf falls out of Santa's mouth all slimy and covered with nasty Santa-throat things. Then, Santa hocks up a hairball. Too much beard grooming, I guess.

meaning_story: We theoretically have the Egyptian God Ra wearing a hat to help us to remember this kanji. Just think about this God, wearing a silly hat... maybe one of those ones with a propeller. He takes off his hat and wants someone to take it from him right NOW.
meaning_hint: He is an incredibly impatient God. That is something you'll have to remember when thinking about this, because impatient gods want things done right NOW!
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading こん, we'll use the word 'Condor.' When Ra gets his hat taken off his head, the servant runs off with it to put it away someplace safe. Suddenly, a Condor (こん) swoops down grabbing the hat, tearing it away from the servant. Ra is pissed, and shoots the condor down, burning his hat and the condor.
reading_hint: Imagine the surprise of a condor going for a hat like that, especially a god like Ra's hat. Must have been really cool for a condor to do that.

meaning_story: The old radical and the old kanji are one and the same, which means you know them both.
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, and you will know your kanji.
reading_story: To remember the reading こ, we will use 子 (ko/child). A child is the opposite of someone really really old, so use this disparity to remember the reading here.
reading_hint: Imagine a really old man writing this content and next to him there is also a child. Use these two contrasting images to remember that this kanji shares the same reading as 子, こ.

meaning_story: Who's someone who's just a mouth with legs? That's your know-it-all older brother, who won't shut up about anything.
meaning_hint: To help this mnemonic along, literally imagine your older brother as someone that's just a giant mouth with a pair of legs walking it around. It talks and talks and talks, too, irritating you. Feel the irritation specifically at your older brother. He's older than you, so you can't beat him up... yet.
reading_story: The strange thing about your older brother is that he has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's Ani (あに), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?
reading_hint: Be sure to be surprised to find out your older brother is actually the future Darth Vader. Now imagine your mouth-legs older brother wielding a light saber, coming at you... 'Ani!!!' you yell... but it's no good, because mouths don't have ears.

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji are the same! You're in luck, today.
meaning_hint: As long as you know your radicals, you'll be good to move on to the reading, which isn't as easy, unfortunately.
reading_story: What is your origin, in the grand scheme of things? What generation were you? I was Gen-Y (げん), for example. You might be Gen-X, or something else.
reading_hint: Important thing is to think about your origin in terms of your generation, because that will help you to remember the reading of this kanji. Of course, the word 'generation' and げん have a different 'G' sound, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain to pull out the actual memory of the correct reading, not to use the exact same sounds. If you get close enough to the spot where げん=元 is stored, you'll be able to retrieve it a lot more easily.

meaning_story: You're known to get the ailment evening toe, which is when your toe catches on fire after getting really, really hot (imagine this happening, ouch!). The only way to fix it is to cool your toe down, and the best way to do that is to go outside.
meaning_hint: After imagining your evening toe overheating, rush outside to fix it. It's the best way to prevent fire toe, which is way worse. In the evening it's nice and cold outside too, so feel this on your skin, and feel the cold air on your toe, which is starting to get some relief.
reading_story: You go outside (you’re not supposed to be out there at night!) and you’re accosted by a couple of guys. Then, all of a sudden, Guy Fawkes jumps from the roof above you and takes them out, then starts running. “Guy Fawkes!” you yell after him!
reading_hint: If you don’t know Guy Fawkes, you should do a little reading up on him to make this mnemonic make sense. Also, Anonymous People wear a Guy Fawkes mask, if that helps any.

meaning_story: The fins that fell onto my sword were sliced into two parts.
meaning_hint: The logic of this story makes a lot of sense - even in the kanji itself the fins are falling onto the sword from above. What happens to things that fall onto swords? They become more than one part.
reading_story: Now that you've cut the fish, it's time to cut something else into parts. Next on your list is the buns (ぶん) which need to be split up amongst the people. If you'd like to learn the second reading, just think about how fun (ふん) it will be to do this task.
reading_hint: Think about the buns (ぶん) as absolutely delicious things you want to eat really bad. If you want to eat the buns, and you taste the buns in your imagination, you'll surely remember that the reading for this kanji is ぶん as well.

meaning_story: The pile of fins left on the ground was for anyone. It was left there for the public.
meaning_hint: Imagine someone dumping these fins, and the public just waiting greedily. When they're dumped, they bum rush the pile and get as many fins as they can. The public loves their fins.
reading_story: When we need to remember こう, we'll think of こういち, the person who writes all these things. Hopefully I'm not too abstract in your mind - if I am, take a second to memorize my name, so that way you can memorize a lot of kanji that use the reading こう as well! So, who's the greediest member of the public knocking people out of the way, stealing fins from children and old ladies? Of course, that's the horrible こういち. I'm so, so evil when it comes to getting my fins.
reading_hint: Make sure you make こういち appalling in your mind. How can someone even act like this? How can someone be so terrible? These questions should come to mind while you're imagining me throwing babies to the side to get closer to the pile of fins.

meaning_story: If you put a stick on a spring, and then pull it, what would happen?
meaning_hint: Go ahead and imagine the result, but be sure to pull on it really hard because the spring you have is thick and good quality. When you let go, what happens? Does it hit someone? Does it cause some kind of weird disaster? I'll leave that up to you - the important thing is you're pulling on the stick against the spring to do something interesting with it.
reading_story: Amazingly, your spring propelled stick flies right into the heel of Achilles. You know what happens when he gets hit in the heel, don't you?
reading_hint: Imagine him grabbing his heel, screaming like a little baby. That's his weakness after all (that's why they call it the Achilles Heel and not something else). He falls to the ground and slowly groans himself to death, all because of your little stick.

meaning_story: The radical and the kanji for stop are the same, so hopefully it shouldn't be any trouble for you.
meaning_hint: If this kanji meaning is giving you trouble, it just means you need to study your radicals more... so... do that, okay?
reading_story: When we need to remember the sound し, we use the word 'Charlie Sheen.' - When you think stop, do you also think 'stop sign'? I hope you do. You're coming up to a stop sign, and on top of it, standing straight up and down, you see Charlie Sheen, saluting the sky. Even before you come to a stop, Sheen starts yelling 'STOPP! STOPPP!!' and jumps down onto the hood of your car, breaking the windshield in.
reading_hint: Make sure to feel the curiosity of someone standing like that on a stop sign. Then, feel the surprise when you figure out it's a celebrity standing up there. Lastly, feel the fear as he jumps onto your car and busts your windshield. See his face on the glass, looking in on you, all crazy like.

meaning_story: The elephant is a large animal. It's huge, and can accomplish any task. You are able to use this elephant to finish your task, as well.
meaning_hint: Look at your elephant... now think 'what can this sucker do?' Then, look at your task list. Come up with some ridiculous tasks for it to do and imagine them out in your head. Focus on the task list as you go through. Oh, also, 'task' sounds like 'tusk' and elephants have tusks... just a little extra juice to help you to remember.
reading_story: To remember the reading よう, we use the word 'yogurt.' - Unfortunately, your elephant (which can achieve any task) runs out of power. The elephant collapses, and you have to pull off a big jug of yogurt (よう) off its back, and put its trunk in it to recharge him.
reading_hint: Imagine the smell of the yogurt (it's getting kind of gross because you're in the sun). Also, listen to the elephant sucking down the yogurt, recharging itself. Be sure to think that it's a bit odd an elephant would run on yogurt, but you won't question what has to be done.

meaning_story: He cut the leaf with his sword at 10,000 miles per hour (or kilometers, if you're from one of those countries).
meaning_hint: When you see these two radicals, you should think, what would I do to a leaf with a sword? You'd cut it as fast as you could. At 10,000 mph.
reading_story: When you cut the leaf in half with your sword at ten thousand mph, it falls into the ocean. The ripples in the water attract ten thousand manatees (まん). They jump out of the water and swarm you, and you can feel their little manatee mouths all over you, tearing you apart.
reading_hint: Whenever we need to remember the reading まん we'll use the word 'manatee' - it's better than something generic like 'man.' Be sure to feel the manatees all over your body, chomping and biting you. The pain will help you to remember the reading. Keep thinking how you wish you hadn't let the leaf fall in the ocean, because it's what attracted them in the first place.

meaning_story: A disgusting pile of mullets. But, you're intrigued, so you pick up a mullet and try it on. Unfortunately, it's way too wide for your head.
meaning_hint: When you put on the mullet, imagine it being super flappy on the sides because it's way too big. It's like there's wings on the sides, though from back to front it fits well. It's really just too wide.
reading_story: When you put the wide mullet on, though, you feel like a different person. The disguise gives you strength. Soon, they will call you a hero (ひろ).
reading_hint: Imagine yourself running around with the mullet on, stopping crime. The mullet gives you a superpower too - to become really, really wide, whenever you want. This is good for blocking people from going down alleyways. You are the Hero this city deserves, Mulletman/woman.

meaning_story: We have the winter radical and the two radical (though it's sort of slanted). What's two times the winter radical, if radicals are just a part of a kanji? Two times would be enough to create the entire kanji, which is also winter.
meaning_hint: You could also think, 'Winter too' instead of 'two.' Because, this kanji is in fact 'winter too.'
reading_story: This kanji is a little different from the radical 夂 though has the same meaning… but don’t let that fool you (ふゆ).
reading_hint: Try to spend a little extra time with this one - the mnemonic isn't as strong as it could be, so you'll need to add a little extra old-fashioned memorization to this soup if you want to remember it later. ふゆ ふゆ ふゆ...

meaning_story: The bamboo radical and the bamboo kanji are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Just make sure you know your radicals!
reading_story: There's a little bamboo shrub sitting there, holding onto a lollipop. Because you're bigger than the bamboo shrub, you just take (たけ) it from the bamboo, causing it to cry.
reading_hint: Of course, focus on the absurdity of a bamboo shrub that can cry and eat a lollipop. Also, think about how mean you are to take the lollipop away from a defenseless bamboo shrub in the first place!

meaning_story: The radical car and the kanji car are exactly the same.
