meaning_hint: Make sure you study your radicals... though don't do it while driving.
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading しゃ, we use 'shaman'. There's a car. It's the nicest car you've ever seen. Exquisite, beautiful. Wouldn't you be surprised to learn it belongs to a shaman (しゃ)? Well it does. This shaman charges a premium for his shaman services so he can afford fancy cars like this.
reading_hint: The more fantastic you make this car, the better. Also, feel the surprise of a shaman getting out of this car. What a cool dude that shaman is.

meaning_story: If a guy has a big head you need to try to focus on the center of it when you meet and talk to them. You don't want to get caught with your eyes wandering all over their big head. Stare right at the center and pretend everything is normal.
meaning_hint: Picture a big headed person. Now stare directly at the center of their face. Ah geez, their eyes are kinda far away from here. You can really only take in this dude's nose...
reading_story: If you look at his head harder, you'll notice that his head is shaped like a huge letter 'O.'
reading_hint: Envision the letter O over his head. It's a perfect match, and giant.

meaning_story: The beggar is pointing his forehead up at you, his feet trapped in the ground. What diabolical scheme are you planning with this poor beggar you trapped? Turns out, you're planning to copy him to have your own version of him.
meaning_hint: You can imagine the whole story - him walking along, you setting a trap... and then whamo! You catch him. Then, come up with some crazy way / invention you're going to copy him. Are you cloning? Are you just taking his skin? Are you removing his forehead to grab his brain? Up to you - just make sure you make it ridiculous enough to remember.
reading_story: To remember the reading しゃ, we use the word 'shaman'. You finally decide on how you're going to copy him. You hire a shaman (しゃ) and have the shaman perform a sacred shaman cloning ritual.
reading_hint: The shaman runs around for a bit, doing ridiculous things. Imagine it dancing about and mumbling shamanic chants as the beggar is copied.

meaning_story: The leader samurai didn't become leader by sitting around not taking action. He got to where he is by doing.
meaning_hint: Think through all the doing he may have done in this past. Not all of it was easy, but it was actions, not sitting that moved him forward in life... just like with you! Learning kanji is about action, not about waiting. Learn a bit every day and good things will happen.
reading_story: When remembering the reading し we use Charlie 'Sheen.' - You go to visit the leader samurai who's known for doing rather than waiting. You walk into his room, and he's facing away from you. When he turns to face you, it's Charlie Sheen (し) sitting there. He's the samurai leader... what the!
reading_hint: You!? YOU are the samurai leader? Charlie Sheen!?? Be awe struck. This is worse than Tom Cruise being the last samurai.

meaning_story: The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
meaning_hint: Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!
reading_story: Put your hand to your ear and sing... 'Mimimimimimiiiii!' (みみ) and listen to your tone with your ear.
reading_hint: This is sort of a stereotypical singer sort of image. Make sure you concentrate a lot when you're listening to your mimimimiiii tone. In fact, why don't you do it out loud right now - make a little fool of yourself. It's fun, and it'll help you to remember!

meaning_story: When the sun is over the cross it's time to go to church... which is so darn early. This kanji can also mean fast too. Because, if you're early, you're probably pretty fast.
meaning_hint: Imagine the sun coming up slowly, over the horizon. It then lines up with the cross, and at that moment, your alarm goes off, waking you up. You check the alarm clock, and instead of displaying the time, it just says early on it, flashing in big red letters.
reading_story: To remember そう we use the word 'sew' - You wake up really early to go to church. When you arrive and go inside, the doors slam behind you, and a couple of armed guards grab you and throw you forward to a desk with a sewing machine on it. They then yell at you 'SEW!!' (そう) and you're forced to start sewing. Church tricked you... it's actually a sweat shop where you sew clothes for no pay, and now you're stuck here.
reading_hint: Make sure to follow the whole story along (starting at the meaning) and make your way to the church. Open the door and go inside, and look around (probably all tired-like, because it's early). When you just start to figure out what's going on, you get the shock of being grabbed and thrown into a chair, and then you start sewing and keep sewing, until you feel your fingers numbing up.

meaning_story: You're looking for a treasure, but no normal treasure... a treasure that's a stash of energy. Not gold, money, or anything like that. Imagine yourself finding it, and opening up a treasure chest. Out bursts a spirit ball of energy like you've never seen.
meaning_hint: Try to touch the energy spirit, it's pretty amazing. Is it solid? Does it shock you? What does it feel like? Be sure to imagine it out.
reading_story: As you reach inside the energy spirit, you feel something hard inside. It's a large key (き) that gives you access to another treasure.
reading_hint: You take the key and open another treasure that's nearby. Open it up and see what's inside. Imagine something spectacular.

onyomi: へい, ひょう, びょう
meaning_story: You put horns on your antenna to make your TV signal better. Instead, the horns combined with the antenna create something that attracts all horned animals for miles around. The animals all come running, knock everything over (including your house) causing everything to be flat.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself, your house, your cat, your everything... all completely flat... ridiculously so (the more ridiculous the better). This kanji also means peace. Why? Because flat things are nice and peaceful. They aren't bumpy. They aren't uneven. They're just flat. So much peace in flatness.
reading_story: Then, after destroying everything of yours, they walk over to your pastures and eat all of your hay, because they're quite hungry.
reading_hint: Feel angry about this too, because you were about to sell all that hay to make a living... good thing you're probably not living anymore.

meaning_story: A leader with a spoon is planting flowers so that one day this place may be full of beautiful flowers.
meaning_hint: It's kind of weird that the flowers radical is only a part of the flower kanji, but you'll make do. Just focus on the fact that the leader is planting all these flowers for a bigger picture thing (that's what leaders do). He wants there to be flowers for future generations as well, because he's a nice dude like that.
reading_story: The leader can't stop planting flowers though. He's going crazy. Maybe it's the pollen? He comes up to someone named Hannah (はな) and starts planting flowers in her face, probably killing her in the process.
reading_hint: Do you know anyone named Hannah? Any famous people, perhaps? Try to come up with someone you know of named Hannah that you can imagine to be in this mnemonic, to help you remember it better.

meaning_story: The radical for foot and the kanji for foot are exactly the same. That being said, there's also another meaning you should keep in mind, which is sufficient. If you think about it, one foot should be sufficient enough to walk around with if you jump.
meaning_hint: Same kanjis and radicals make Jack a happy boy. You should also learn the other meaning as well, though, if you can.
reading_story: What do you wear on your foot? You wear a sock (そく).
reading_hint: Just think about your bare feet. Think about them too much. Feel how cold it is on your feet. Now, put on a sock to make it feel better. Ahhh, so nice!

meaning_story: The generation radical and the generation kanji are the same.
meaning_hint: The same can't be said for different generations of people... they are not the same. Count your lucky stars that radicals and kanji can be, though.
reading_story: For the reading, when we need to remember せい, we think Hard Gay, because he says 'SEI SEI SEI' a lot. Think of multiple generations of people - what would the older generations hate more than anything? Of course, it would have to be Hard Gay shouting 'Sei (せい), sei, sei!'
reading_hint: Just imagine someone of an older generation watching Hard Gay. Imagine their disgusted looks and their confusion. Hopefully you can get some joy out of their reactions, too, to help you remember the reading. Maybe they try to imitate Hard Gay's catch phrase, and only say 'Se, se, se' instead of 'Sei, sei, sei' - that way you have both readings in your mnemonic!

meaning_story: You have a nailbat but you want to add an extra nail to it. How do you do it? You set the nail upright, and hit the nailbat into the nail as hard as you can.
meaning_hint: The nail flies out and hits you in the eye. You have a nail in your eye now, and you're freaking out. What do you do? How does it feel? Can you feel the metal on eyeball feeling?
reading_story: To remember the reading う we use the word うに (sea urchin). You have a nail that hit you in your eye. You're flailing around, trying to recover from this terrible situation. As you're moving around you step back on some uni (う) which stabs your foot. Now you have uni in your foot and a nail in your eye. This can't get any worse.
reading_hint: Of course, think about the feeling of these things hurting you. Also think of the absurdity of the uni part - where are you that there's uni on the ground anyways? Feel it cracking under your foot, getting all its spines up in there. It's really painful, probably because of the poison.

meaning_story: There is a leaf growing out of the sun! You fly out into space to check it out and when you get closer you see that it isn't just one leaf, it's a hundred! That makes sense, you wouldn't be able to see just one leaf on the sun from where you were on earth.
meaning_hint: Imagine flying toward the sun to see a hundred leaves growing together in the shape of one big leaf. You want to go closer!
reading_story: You fly closer, counting all one hundred leaves when you hear a strange sound. You take off your space helmet and hear, "GUH HYUCK (ひゃく)!" You know that laugh... it's Goofy! On top of the hundredth leaf is Goofy laughing and waving around. He must have built this leaf tower to get your attention.
reading_hint: Imaging hearing Goofy guh-hyuck over and over after you save him from being stranded on the sun. How would you feel being stuck in a cramped ship with laughing Goofy and his hundred leaves? Oh, you thought he would leave those behind? Nope, they saved him so you have to take them back too. Happy travels!

meaning_story: You have water already... and it's pretty cold. All it takes is one cold drop of liquid nitrogen added to it to turn it into one big block of ice, just like that.
meaning_hint: Go ahead and touch it... wow, it's really cold - and only from one drop, too. Feel the burn on your finger from where you touched the ice.
reading_story: When you think of ice, I want you to think of someone frozen with ice. Do you know anyone named Corey (こおり)? Anyone famous named Corey, perhaps Corey Feldman? Imagine this Corey person frozen solid with ice.
reading_hint: How did this happen? Was it your fault? Imagine the situation that would get Corey frozen like this.

meaning_story: The insect radical and insect are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: It's times like these when you gotta hope you're studying your radicals!
reading_story: It's an insect! Get it! You squish it with your foot - what sound does it make? A mush (むし) sound.
reading_hint: Imagine little words that say 'mush' flying out from under your foot as you mush the poor thing. What does a 'mush' sound sound like? You'll have to come up with something unique to yourself, and focus on it to remember this reading.

meaning_story: You walk up to a child wearing a helmet on his head. As you come closer, you see what he's working on. He has hundreds of letters (of the alphabet) in front of him, and he's rearranging them into different equations. Absolutely crazy, this one is. He's wearing a helmet because he doesn't want the aliens to know his thoughts, and know the secret codes and equations he's creating with the letters. A character also works, though this is like a 'letter character' not a character in a movie, even if it is Steve Buscemi.
meaning_hint: Build up the tension as you walk up to the helmeted kid. You're walking towards him from behind, so you can't see what he has in front of him. You just see the helmet on his head, which is made of tin foil and obviously for a crazy person. Then, as you get closer, hear the clack of wooden block letters being moved around, frantically.
reading_story: As you're watching the kid arrange all his letters around, you see one letter in particular standing out... 'A-B-C-D-E-F-G...' he says, as he puts the G (じ) aside. You ask him why he doesn't like the letter 'G.' He replies: 'G is for God. And God is actually aliens from the past... we must hide this letter from him.'
reading_hint: Imagine an alien God looking down on the kid, shaking his head either in approval or disappointment. You choose - whichever you think would be more interesting and memorable to you. The alien version of God should be pretty memorable enough to remember G is for God, though.

meaning_story: You have rice paddy power (or you need power for your rice field). If you want precision in your rice paddy, go ask a woman. If you want power in your rice field, you need a man.
meaning_hint: P.S. Sorry for being totally sexist there – use your possible upsetedness to remember the meaning of this kanji, though, and it will be all worthwhile
reading_story: Who da man? Dan's (だん) the man.
reading_hint: Say this over and over in a chanty fashion, preferably with a super manly voice, if you can swing it (out loud, now). Also, if you can think of someone named Dan that you know to imagine with this, it will help you out a lot.

meaning_story: The radical master and the kanji master have the same meanings! How lucky for you.
reading_story: Do you remember back to the radical mnemonic, where the master is balancing a water drop on his head? Imagine back to there. Once you do, the most amazing thing happens. The master takes off a shoe (しゅ) and places it gently on top of the water drop, where it balances on top, not breaking the water.
reading_hint: Seriously, this ought to not be allowed, at least when it comes to the physics we know and love on this earth. This is so amazing, so feel amazed by it in your imagination as well. Also, it might help if his shoe is something ridiculous... like a clown shoe, or something. You choose!

meaning_story: What is the evening mouth? Imagine a mouth that’s up in the night sky. It’s just there, talking, and only comes out at night. It only appears in one area of the world (what area would you choose? Imagine yourself going to that place to see the “night mouth.”), and appears only one month out of the year (more on this in a second). The “evening mouth” is the most famous thing in the _____ area (this is the area you choose). He’s so famous that everybody knows his name (“Evening Mouth.”).
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself going to the area you chose, and watching “Evening Mouth” speak. There are thousands of others there, wanting to see the giant floating mouth in the night sky. “Evening Mouth” then says “Everyone, what’s my name!?” and everyone shouts back “Evening Mouth!” in unison. “Evening Mouth” has certainly gotten really famous.
reading_story: So, when does “Evening Mouth” appear? Turns out, “Evening Mouth” only comes out to talk in May (めい). You know this because it’s just starting to be spring, and when you look around (you’re watching “Evening Mouth” again) you see some spring flowers come up.
reading_hint: You know what they say. April showers bring May Flowers. What do May Flowers bring? They bring “Evening Mouth,” baby.

meaning_story: The not and the kanji not are the same thing! That makes it easy... Not!
meaning_hint: Actually, it does make it easy - the radicals make kanji wayyy easier, no?
reading_story: To remember ふ we'll use the word 'fool.' Think of those jokes, where someone says something, then ends with a loud 'NOTTTT!' Someone is doing that to you, over and over. What is that person? That person is a fool (ふ).
reading_hint: Be sure to feel irritated at that person. Think in your head as they're telling these dumb 'not' jokes how much of a fool they are... and how much of a fool you are for sitting here and listening to them.

meaning_story: There's a mouth in the ground (in our case, it's a hatch), and inside is some kind of enclosure you can't quite get to. If you've ever seen Lost, this will sound familiar... on the hatch, there's actually a series of numbers that you don't understand.
meaning_hint: What are these numbers? What do they mean? Think over it for a while, get frustrated, and try to figure it out. You can't, though, so you probably won't ever get inside.
reading_story: When remembering the reading ごう, we use 'Grandpa Koichi.' こう is こういち, so ごう is ごういち, aka 'Grandpa Koichi' (ごう). So to help you figure out these numbers, you go and contact ごういち because he is so old and wise.
reading_hint: Like I said, ごういち is very old and wise, so just imagine こういち, but much older. Imagine sitting with ごういち and concentrating very hard to try and figure out these numbers.

meaning_story: The leader of alligators... he's no ordinary leader, that's for sure. He's not a politician.. he's not a king... He's one of the Other Ones, a group of strange, eccentric people who become leaders of animals.
meaning_hint: Imagine different groups of leaders - they're all dressed nice and normal. Then, off to the side are the leaders who are leaders of bears, cats, alligators, and narwhals... they're the other ones, no matter how you look at it. They are in their own group, and they are considered 'others' because society won't accept them :(
reading_story: To remember the reading た, we use the word 'Taco' Then there's the others of the others. These are the taco (た) worshipers. They're really strange.
reading_hint: Just imagine the 'others' shaking their heads at these taco worshipers. Seriously, what the heck?

meaning_story: A pile of graves has a whole lot of past associated with it, and not much future.
meaning_hint: Look at all the years and tombstones... all of it is from so long ago. All of it is from the past.
reading_story: To remember the reading きょ, we'll use 'Little Kyoto'. This will differentiate きょ from きょう, which is regular sized Kyoto. Get it? Okay, so all these tombstones from the past are located in Little Kyoto (きょ). Each grave pile represents a Japanese immigrant that came to Little Kyoto and died :( Alternatively, the reading can be こ as well. Just like Little Kyoto is a little Kyoto, it is also a child kyoto, like a 子 Kyoto, making it こ as well.
reading_hint: Come up with some kind of emotion along with this grave. It's probably a sad emotion as death is usually pretty sad. Feel sad about these dead people in Little Kyoto. They're no longer around to do fun things or play with their families.

meaning_story: The plate kanji and the plate are exactly the same, like two matching pieces of china.
meaning_hint: If you know your radicals, you know your kanji too.
reading_story: The person washing all the dishes was named Sarah (さら). She was named that because of her large head, which was shaped like Sarah Jessica Parker’s head (very big).
reading_hint: Imagine someone with a huge head, washing dishes. When I say huge, I mean huge. She turns towards you with her big head and says “Hi, I’m Sarah” and you see her name tag, which also says Sarah. She is Sarah, the dish washer. The plates she holds up next to her head pale in comparison, even though they're the biggest pieces.

meaning_story: You’re about to go down a grave slide. This time you won’t make the same mistake you made with the previous grave slide you tried. In the previous slide, you went down so fast your legs got stuck in the grave. You could feel the bones and rotting flesh touching your shoe-less feet. That previous grave-slide was faulty.
meaning_hint: Emphasize thinking back to the previous slide (not the one you’re on, unless you’re thinking about how much better this one will be compared to the previous one). Imagine the previous slide, and all its nastiness (when it comes to sliding down so hard your feet are stuck in someone’s grave, you’ll have plenty of nastiness to go around).
reading_story: To remember せん we use the word centaur. At the bottom of the previous grave slide, there was also a centaur as well. He started slapping you around with his hooves as your legs are stuck in the ground, and all you can do is take the beating.
reading_hint: Feel the scratchiness of the hooves on your face. He's not hitting you hard, but it's plenty enough to be irritating. Imagine him clopping around you in circles too, and make sure to vividly see the centaur, since that's important to the reading. Also make sure to think he's a real bastard, that centaur...

meaning_story: The radical for red and the kanji for red are the same thing!
meaning_hint: What a lucky ducky - as long as you know your radicals, you'll know this kanji's meaning as well!
reading_story: Think of Fozzie Bear. He says 'Wakka wakka wakka' a lot. Now, think of an evil, red (and I mean totally red) Fozzie Bear. He drops the 'w' and just says 'Aka Aka Aka,' because he's totally evil.
reading_hint: You'll have to think of him as really, really red, though. Like, a glowing, searing kind of red. Red enough for you to associate red with this evil Fozzie Bear. If you do, then you'll be good to go (as long as you know his catch phrase as well).

meaning_story: The leader is next to the tree. What is he doing? He's leaning against it, resting.
meaning_hint: One of the best things you can do under a tree is rest. Just lean your head against it and close your eyes. The leader of your outfit has been working hard, and he really, really needed that rest.
reading_story: To remember きゅう we use the word 'cute' - The leader who's resting under the tree suddenly gets surrounded by all the animals living in the tree... but, they're not evil, they're very, very cute (きゅう), adorable things. Squirrels with big eyes, funny birds, and so on. Everything is just so amazingly cute.
reading_hint: Make sure you imagine really cute things and get the 'awww' factor going in your heart. It'll help you to remember this kanji's reading.

meaning_story: There’s a cross in your mouth, so the things you say are very pious. Everything you say you say humbly.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself with a cross in your mouth, saying all kinds of humble things. 'Oh no, I'm not that good.' 'Oh no, my mustache doesn't look that great.'
reading_story: When you think of saying humble things, think of the humblest man in the world. His name is Moe (もう).
reading_hint: Imagine this character in your head. If it helps, you can take a Moe you already know of (Simpsons, perhaps?) and pretend he's extremely humble - ridiculously so. Just remember to make it crazy so you can remember it better.

meaning_story: The radical see and the kanji see are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Make sure you're studying your radicals. If you do, you'll know a lot of kanji as well, almost magically!
reading_story: You see something. It's walking towards you, but you need to see better. When the person comes close, you realize 'That person is me (み)!'
reading_hint: The struggling to see bit is pretty important - make sure that you slowly see a little better and better as the person comes closer, but it's difficult the whole time (struggles are good for memory). Then, it starts to become more and more clear, and you start saying 'that can't be me. No way it's me...' When the person comes up to you (the person, being you) you learn about parallel universes and other fabulous things. Still, the whole time you can't stop thinking about how 'this person looks just like me... no, this person is me!'

meaning_story: The radical, clam, is a type of shellfish. Also, we'll allow clam here too, because sometimes clams are referred to as 貝 and it's the same as the radical. I'd focus on learning the 'shellfish' version of the vocab if you can, though.
meaning_hint: Be sure to try and differentiate 'clam' and 'shellfish' before moving on to the reading.
reading_story: To remember the reading かい we use the word “coyote” (which is pronounced kai-oh-tee) Imagine a coyote (かい) with a huge shell making up its back area. You try to punch it, but the coyote shell skin is too strong and the coyote comes at you to devour you. Suddenly, someone with a sledge hammer comes in and smashes the coyote's shell, bursting shellfish all over you.
reading_hint: Taste the shellfish juice, smell it, and feel it. When you think this shell, you should think of this shell coyote that tried to eat you. If you're afraid enough in your imagination, there's a good chance you'll remember this reading quite easily.

meaning_story: A frog decides to jump down a slide... the problem is that it's not a water slide (which is another radical). This is a regular slide he jumps down, and as a frog, his skin gets dry easily. As he slides down, his skin gets torn off him, and so he's a naked, skinless frog when he reaches the bottom.
meaning_hint: Pick up the skin and feel it... Does it feel odd? Weird? Rubbery? Really touch it in your mind and remember how it felt. Make sure it's just the skin, too.
reading_story: The frog makes it to the bottom of the slide, with no skin. He flies into a 川 (かわ), which is full of skin from all the other animals and frogs that thought it would be a good idea to use this evil slide. So, the frog has to swim through a 川 of skin to get out. Ugh, disgusting.
reading_hint: Now imagine this happening to you, too. How disgusting.

meaning_story: The leader for the ceremony wasn't available, so they had to find a substitute. It also has another meaning. A leader only missed the ceremony if he forgot what period of time it was. If he thinks he's in the wrong age, he won't come because he's trying to lead some monkeys in the ceremony instead.
meaning_hint: First, come up with a really weird ceremony. Then, be someone who's coordinating this weird ceremony. Much to your surprise, the leader of the ceremony itself didn't show up. You have to figure something out... you have to find (and imagine yourself doing this) the substitute leader. Also, the sub does terribly - what a disaster, and it's all your fault, because you're coordinating.
reading_story: Turns out you were being kind of mean. The original (who got replaced by the substitute) leader actually died (だい), and you were all pissed at them. They tried to joust a train, thinking it was a medieval age dragon. How do you feel now? That wasn't very nice.
reading_hint: Imagine how you'd feel if this happened. Hopefully will teach you not to think bad things about people, because maybe it could cause them to die, you know?

meaning_story: The pelican with an umbrella is standing there in the rain, staying dry. You on the other hand, are not. But, this pelican is super nice. She sees you looking all pathetic and holds the umbrella over your head to keep you dry. What do you say when this happens? You say 'thanks.'
meaning_hint: Feel really thankful about this. You're all wet (feel the cold wetness) and you're getting wetter. Then, this pelican comes out of the blue to keep you dry. You probably feel really really thankful about it, right?
reading_story: Then you notice something else... The pelican is also holding a gun and pointing at you, and it's demanding all your money. Well, first of all, no more thanks for this pelican. Second, the gun is a bit crazy. It's a futuristic ray (れい) gun - one that looks different from any other gun you've seen.
reading_hint: Then, the pelican shoots a ray out of the ray gun, to show you she's not messing around. It melts the wall behind you, causing you to be totally frightened.

meaning_story: The thread radical and thread are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: This is why it's good to make sure you know your radicals.
reading_story: You have some thread... what's the first thing you do with it? You take it and put it in your mouth, and start sucking it down like spaghetti. You have decided to eat (いと) the thread.
reading_hint: Think about how it tastes. Think about how it feels in your throat. Let it get caught on your teeth and around your tongue. It's a weird feeling having thread in your mouth, and you want to use that weird feeling to remember you're going to eat it.

meaning_story: The rice paddy is full of nails. That sucks. Why is the rice field full of nails? It’s part of a town that’s known for making nails, and they dump their nails in the rice field (because rice is worth nothing to this town).
meaning_hint: Try to feel some anger towards the town as a whole. Rice is awesome. They can’t be throwing nails in there. Jerks.
reading_story: Do you remember the kanji 丁? The on’yomi is also ちょう, and the kanji means “street.” The mnemonic for that one had to do with Mrs. Chou who was scattering nails all over the street. Oh, and guess what town that street is in? So who does that mean lives here? Yeah, it’s Mrs. Chou (ちょう).
reading_hint: Do you remember Mrs. Chou? She’s notorious, by now.

meaning_story: Someone’s taking measurements of the trees… Why is someone taking measurements of trees? These people are planning to take the trees and cut them down to make their village.
meaning_hint: There is a whole group of people out there who are measuring these trees. Imagine them asking each other “do you think this will be a good tree for our village center?” and other people nodding in agreement or disagreement as they measure.
reading_story: They take all the wood back to where they're building their village and once they construct the village center they paint a mural (むら) on the side of it. The mural is of the forest where they got the tree from so they remember the building's origins.
reading_hint: Look at the mural on the side of this newly constructed village center. So many trees! Visualize the whole process as the tree becomes a building as you gaze and reflect on the message of the mural.

meaning_story: The cow part of this kanji is slightly altered, but I think you can see where it is. The gun looks just fine, though. Think back to a fake memory you have living on the farm. You have your gun, and you gotta use it on a cow (ruh roh). Once a year on New Year's, you have to go out and shoot one of the cows. It's only a yearly shooting, though, so at least there's that respite.
meaning_hint: You'll have to imagine yourself doing this to remember the meaning of the kanji. Focus on the thought that 'okay... it's only once a year... I only have to do this once a year...'
reading_story: It is New Years, though, so when you bring the dead cow back home, it’s time to celebrate. Using the cow’s organs and bones, you and your siblings construct a nendoroid (ねん). Nendoroids are Japanese toys - little plastic figurines (Google it if need be). You make a little cow nendoroid holding a gun. How cute.
reading_hint: How funny that you use dead cow parts to make a miniature cow holding a gun much like the one you murdered earlier. Imagine yourself playing with this nendoroid as you think about how weird it was to make a cow nendoroid out of a dead cow.

meaning_story: You have an enclosure trying to enclose the elephant. But, as you can see already, the elephant is way too big for it. No matter what angle you turn the elephant, you're unable to get it inside the enclosure.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself turning the elephant in all different directions. You turn it at a 90 degree angle. A 60 degree angle. A 20 degree angle... nothing works - no matter what angle you turn it at, the elephant won't fit in.
reading_story: You finally figure out the right angle to get the elephant into the enclosure. Wow, this is great! But, the moment you start squeezing it in, you hear a big squawk. The enclosure is already filled with cocks (かく), and they're all flying around fighting with each other, and scratching the elephant too.
reading_hint: This causes the elephant to freak out, destroying the enclosure in the process. Thousands of these roosters (cocks) stream out and fly everywhere, darkening the sky with how many there are.

meaning_story: The blue radical and the blue kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: Don't feel blue, you should know this kanji automagically!
reading_story: When we need to remember the on'yomi せい we think of Hard Gay (because he says "sei sei sei." When we need to remember the on'yomi しょう we think of a shogun. Remembering both of these readings is the real challenge here! Start by thinking of something that's very blue. What's the bluest thing you can think of? For me, it's the Blue Man Group. Imagine the Blue Man Group, but instead of the regular members, you have Hard Gay (sei) and a Shogun (shou), both painted from head to toe in blue paint. They are playing for you an amazing concert. It's fantastic! It's blue!
reading_hint: You'll want to imagine Hard Gay and the Shogun doing things that you would imagine them to do. Something crazy, something wild, and something memorable. Preferably, they do something together. Whatever it is, make sure it's crazy enough for you to be shocked into remembering it.

meaning_story: The real leader's body is here... so who's the other leader? Is he a fake?
meaning_hint: Just imagine finding your leader's body somewhere, even though you saw him just a moment before in the other room. That means the other one is a fake, and this body is the real leader.
reading_story: How do you know this is the real leader's body though, and not someone else's body? Because the real leader always would wear a tie (たい) with monkeys on it, and this body has a tie with monkeys on it. Now you know the facts.
reading_hint: Spend some time analyzing the situation. You're a detective here. The telling item is the tie, so focus in on that as grounds for knowing.

meaning_story: The color radical and color are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: Color me pink! This kanji's super easy if you know your radicals.
reading_story: You already have color on the mind because you know the meaning of this kanji, so think of something colorful about yourself. Imagine your ear (いろ) being a weird color... green, purple, red, whatever. Just make it really bright and standing out.
reading_hint: You can even have someone ask you about your ear... 'Is your ear okay? I think it's the color blue...'

meaning_story: There's rice spread out all over the ground. This will cause the Predator to come because he loves kome (rice). Then once he's gone, the next Predator will come to eat. Also imagine everyone else coming to the rice next. When rice spills, people come from all around to line up and grab a handful of it to take home. Who's next? Come forward!
reading_story: When they come, though, everyone is disappointed. It turns out it's rye (らい) grains, and rye grains taste terrible. Yuck.
reading_hint: If you love rye grains, on the other hand, imagine everyone being really happy that they came to get the rice. They're so lucky it's rye!

meaning_story: There's this mass pelican grave. Who on earth would kill all the pelicans? You look around, and see a giant building. It's a local pelican hunting company. They're obviously responsible for all these pelican graves.
meaning_hint: What a terrible company, though. Just think about all the companies you don't like, and add them to your metaphorical list.
reading_story: To remember the reading しゃ we use the word 'shaman'. The company hired a shaman (しゃ) to help them kill all the pelicans. The shaman does a shaman ritual that lulls the pelicans into a false sense of security and then the company kills them.
reading_hint: Imagine you're one of the people working at the company. Watch the shaman doing his shaman dance as the pelicans all become blissfully unaware. Now shoot the pelican! BLAM!

meaning_story: The treasures are in the mouth where there’s ice. How cryptic! You want to find the treasure, that’s for sure (treasure is great!). It is somewhere where there is ice, so maybe the arctic? What you are looking at is a diagram which will guide you there.
meaning_hint: Imagine looking at a diagram or map – and it has pictures of treasure in an area where ice is. This is where you will find the mystical treasure. This diagram will show the way. You're so excited that you found this map!
reading_story: What will you do when you find these treasures that are shown on the diagram? Well, you get there, and you find that the treasure is actually a wooly mammoth! What will you do with this wooly mammoth? You grab it and put it in your zoo (ず).
reading_hint: Imagine dragging a wooly mammoth back with you to the town or city you live in, then throwing it in a zoo to be kept. People are quite amazed by this mystical creature you’ve found, though, which is pretty cool.

meaning_story: You see some windows... you have a gun. What do you think you're going to do with this gun? Of course, you're going to shoot the windows... every single one of them.
meaning_hint: Make a point to make sure you get every one, and don't miss any of them. Actually search around in your imagination for any more windows, because you want to stress it's important you hit every one.
reading_story: Now that every single window is broken you feel pretty stupid because a bunch of mice (まい) come pouring in through them. You've made a way for them to get into your house. That wasn't smart.
reading_hint: Now you need to shoot every one of the mice that came through those broken windows. You can't let any survive. You have to get every last one out of here!!

meaning_story: The feather radical and feather are the same in looks as well as in meaning.
meaning_hint: Have you been studying your radicals? If so, this'll be easy!
reading_story: All these feathers. You're a bird man / woman, and you're getting ready to fly. Just as you're about to take off, someone dumps you with honey はね and you're all goopy, unable to go anywhere.
reading_hint: Taste the honey, feel it all over your feathers. Go ahead and plummet towards the ground (because you were jumping off a building to fly when someone doused you with honey). At least it's a tasty way to go, no?

meaning_story: You have a tree and another tree. You basically have yourself a forest!
meaning_hint: Follow the logic of this one and you should be okay.
reading_story: So, now you have this forest and you want to cut it down (so much money!). But, you don't have any tools, only your hands. You think... I've done karate for a while, so I can probably chop it down that way. You get in a chopping stance, then do your battle cry and hit: 'HAYA ... .SHI******!'
reading_hint: Obviously that didn't work well - you'll want to focus on your battle cry plus indecent swearing right afterwards to remember this reading.

meaning_story: The go radical and go kanji are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: Go study your radicals if you didn't know the 'Go' radical, okay?
reading_story: Knowing the kanji's meaning, you know you have to go somewhere. So, where will you go? You will go to こういち's house.
reading_hint: Come up with a good story that involves you going to こういち's house. Perhaps something crazy, weird, or interesting happens when you get there.

meaning_story: The radical gold and the kanji gold are the same, making this an easy kanji to learn.
meaning_hint: Just know your radicals and you'll be golden, so to speak.
reading_story: If you have a lot of gold your long lost kin will start appearing out of nowhere, pretending to be friendly.
reading_hint: I always associate the word 'kin' with a American Southern sort of thing. So, perhaps your long lost kin are coming from Texas or somewhere like that.

meaning_story: Instead of a 'cross' let's say that 十 is 'ten' for this time. You expose your flowers to ten suns. They are instantly burned up, and all that remains is grass.
meaning_hint: Think of how disappointed you are. You thought ten suns would make the flowers grow better, but instead it just burned up all the sensitive flowers, leaving only the grass behind :(
reading_story: We're going to combine a couple things here. When you need to remember く we use 'cooties.' When you need to remember さ we use 'saw.' So, くさ is a 'cooties saw.' You have plenty of grass in front of you, but you want to get rid of it. You take your cooties saw (くさ), which is a saw made out of cooties, and cut out a huge chunk of the grass and tear it up so that you can replant and get those flowers back again.
reading_hint: The reason you're using a cooties saw is because it actually eats up the grass (because it's made up of a million little bugs) - that way there isn't a big pile of grass to throw away afterwards.

meaning_story: Turns out, your home village is known for all its beautiful sunflowers.
meaning_hint: You might have to make up this part of your past, but the village you were born in is just beautiful during the summer. Sunflowers everywhere. You always like going back to visit your parents at your home village just to see them. They're so nice.
reading_story: You were so excited to visit your home village this year that when you got home you put a saddle (さと) on your horse and rode around in the middle of the sunflower field and took in the smells. The saddle prevents unnecessary chafing. Good choice.
reading_hint: Smell those sunflowers and enjoy it. They're so nice! Also feel that cozy saddle beneath your butt as you ride around.

meaning_story: The leader's key is the key that makes all the other keys. It's sort of like the one ring to rule them all, the one ring to bind them... except with keys.
meaning_hint: Imagine the leader taking his key to open up a safe that has a button to make other keys for the underlings. No key is as great as this key, though.
reading_story: You make a key for an underling, and he looks at it disapprovingly (even though you're their leader!). He simply says, 'this key sucks' (さく) and then walks off. How could this be?
reading_hint: Feel angry about this. Maybe you should kick your foot in his mouth and make him suck on that. Also keep in mind that there's another reading that pops up too that's さ. It's similar to さく, though, and I think you'll be able to learn both the readings via the vocabulary.

meaning_story: How many evenings are there? There are many.
meaning_hint: If you accidentally think 'a lot' or something similar, that's okay too. It's the basic meaning that counts, and all these things are pretty close, though eventually you want to get to the point where you know that this kanji does in fact mean many.
reading_story: To remember the reading た we use the word 'Taco' Let's start with the kanji meaning: many. You go outside in the evening (because that's what this kanji is made up of) and are surprised when you're hit by many tacos flying from the sky. For some reason it's raining tacos, and of course you have no idea why.
reading_hint: The tacos pelt you and knock you off your feet. Hard shell, soft shell, meat, lettuce, tomatoes, cheese... it's terrible. And there are so many of them, flying from the sky to drown you in tacos. This is absolutely absurd (and you should think that too, so you remember the reading).

meaning_story: The meat radical and meat are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: Study those radicals, and perhaps we'll eat some meat tonight.
reading_story: You know there's people-eating going on here, with this kanji. So, when you think of this meat, you'll have to think about who's meat it is. In this case, it's Nick's (にく) meat.
reading_hint: Do you know someone named Nick you can imagine? There's celebrities too, if you don't have someone. Someone like Nick Cage would do the trick.

meaning_story: The radical meet and the kanji meet are exactly the same!
reading_story: To remember the reading かい we use the word coyote. Do you remember how you remembered the radical? You had two hat piles meeting each other. You think it'll be love. Finally, the date is set, and they are about to meet for the first time. You have a good feeling about this. Just as they begin to meet each other, things are looking good... until a coyote (かい) jumps out from nowhere, grabs one of the hat piles, shakes it around, then runs off with it.
reading_hint: This is a disaster. This meet was your idea, and now you've gotten a pile of hats killed. How terrible. You probably shouldn't have chosen to let them meet in a coyote sanctuary.

meaning_story: Your father is in a kettle with a lid on top. This is a horrible situation. To make things worse, someone is forcing you to mix him with a big spoon. As you mix him, he tells you to mix harder, so that at least your life can be saved. 'Mix me, child! Mix me!!'
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself having to mix your father in a kettle, then put the lid on. This is a terrible thing... but also a terrible thing you'll probably remember, helping you to remember the kanji's meaning as well.
reading_story: Just before your father dies from you mixing him in a pot of boiling water, he has to tell you something. 'I'm not your father! Your father is... こういち!
reading_hint: Oh my God! Quite the bomb. Feel the shock, anger, and then forgiveness. You killed the person who you thought was your father because crazy people made you do it... but then you find out that こういち is your real father?? Such a mix of emotions to draw on to remember this reading! Think on this a bit. What will your next actions be? Will you seek out your real father?

meaning_story: The water slide with axes flowing down it instead of water is near your house!
meaning_hint: Imagine it right next to your house. People are lining up to use it, but to you it's just an eyesore because you have to look at the dumb thing everyday. It's so near, too! Literally the next lot over.
reading_story: The problem with how near the axe water slide is to your home is that your kin (きん) are always wanting to come over to your house so they can go ride it - they don't actually want to see you, they just want to ride the awesome axe water slide.
reading_hint: Imagine your 'kin' as a bunch of stereotypical hillbillies. At least, that's what I think when I think of the word 'kin.'

meaning_story: The poor alligator was taken far inland by a tsunami. His only source of water is a tiny pond that barely fits his body, and doesn't even provide much food.
meaning_hint: Imagine the alligator riding the tsunami in. When he hits the ground, and the water recedes, he's all alone in a field. He doesn't like it... it's not his environment. So, he looks around and finally finds a little pond, but it doesn't provide much for him. Imagine him looking for food in the little, shallow pond. Imagine him trying to stay wet... it's just not a great situation to be in, unfortunately.
reading_story: Eventually, the alligator dies. You come upon it and think it's alive. You shriek 'EEEEK!' (いけ) when you see it.
reading_hint: Actually scream 'EEEK' wherever you are as you imagine yourself coming across this alligator. Then think about how weird it was that you screamed 'EEEK.' Be sure to feel the surprise and fear from seeing the alligator as well.

meaning_story: The radical for rain and the kanji for rain are the same thing.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know your radicals!
reading_story: What if the rain actually tried to aim (あめ) for you? As in, drops would move out of their normal flight path just to hit you on your head? You'd be a lot wetter, that's for sure.
reading_hint: Imagine a world where each rain drop had to choose a target to aim for. How strange would rainfall be? Also, あめ and 'aim' don't really sound too much alike, but the goal is to use 'aim' to get to あめ, so make sure to take note of that in your mind as you learn the reading.

meaning_story: The rice radical and rice are the same in looks as well as and meaning. This also refers to 'America,' maybe because America is covered in rice or fields or something?
meaning_hint: Aren't radicals nice? They make things so much easier... if you've been studying them.
reading_story: You've got tons of dry grains of rice. You have no idea what you're going to do with it. Then, you come up with a solution. All this dry rice could go towards filling up the bay (べい), so you have more land to farm on!
reading_hint: In your mind, bulldoze the rice into the bay, watching it fill it up, then pile high. It's not particularly good looking land, but it'll do, and it's already full of seeds, so that's pretty good. The important thing is that you think you have way too much of the stuff, so the only way to get rid of it is to dump it in a large body of water, and that large body of water is a bay.

meaning_story: The 'right' for this kanji is like 'correct' or something along those lines. It's like when you get a question correct. 'You're Right!' You could also say it's a success. There's a triceratops and a wolverine. What are they doing together? You'd think they'd fight, but they took their battle to another venue... they're competing in Jeopardy! One of them answers a question, and the host says 'You're right!'
meaning_hint: Feel free to think through several questions and answers, but make sure they're all right, because that's what we're focusing on. Also make sure to focus on the triceratops and the wolverine themselves. You want to make sure that when you see these two radicals you automatically know they're playing Jeopardy, not doing anything else, like fighting or racing or playing or something.
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading とう, we use the Japanese city, Tokyo. The last question in the Jeopardy match is the following: 'The capital of Japan.' The triceratops answers first. 'What is... Tokyo (とう)?' Right again!
reading_hint: What a ridiculously easy question to ask. Think of it from the poor wolverine's perspective... he could have won if he had hit the buzzer more quickly. Ugh!

meaning_story: The radical run and the kanji run are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Make sure you know those radicals!
reading_story: To remember the reading そう we use the word 'sew.' You're running and running and running. You can't stop. In fact, you run so hard, your leg just falls clean off from overuse. You stop and grab it, then try to sew (そう) it back on again.
reading_hint: Of course, imagine yourself sewing on your leg. How much would it hurt? Would it stay on or be floppy? Maybe if you used a sewing machine?

meaning_story: There's a mustache on the ground. Upon closer inspection, you see that the mustache on the ground is exactly the same as yours!
meaning_hint: Pick up the mustache, hold it up next to your face in front of a mirror. It's unbelievable, but it's the same in every way, down to the last hair.
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading どう, we use the word 'doughnut'. While this is already strange enough, you notice something stranger. Over a couple feet away is a doughnut (どう) who also has the same mustache as you (and the one that fell on the ground). The doughnut looks at you for a moment, then scampers off. This doughnut must be a mutant because normally doughnuts don't move.
reading_hint: If it helps, imagine hundreds or thousands of doughnuts all around you with the same exact mustache. First of all, it's terrifying to be surrounded by thousands of mutant doughnuts. Secondly, it's really weird they all have the same mustache as you.

meaning_story: The radical say is the same as the kanji say!
meaning_hint: If, say, you learn your radicals, you'll know a lot of your kanji as well!
reading_story: I want you to say this out loud. Really say it. What generation are you from? Gen Y? Gen X? Please say it out loud.
reading_hint: You'll have to really focus in on this set of requests and connect them to the meaning of this kanji. Meaning of the kanji is easy to get to, but connecting it to remember the reading is a little more difficult. Spend a little time thinking about how they relate before moving on.

meaning_story: The self radical and self are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: Radicals have self. Kanji has self. Kanji and radicals can sometimes be the same thing... so do they really have 'self'? Only way to find out is to study both of them hard!
reading_story: When we need to remember じ we use the word 'Jesus.' Who said you should always look at your self before tossing stones (or whatever) at others? Jesus (じ) did. So, make sure you look at your own self before being a jerk.
reading_hint: You can feel free to do some introspection here.

meaning_story: There’s a samurai with (just) his forehead and legs. Everything in between is missing. What happened to everything in between? He was low on money, so he had to sell it all, leaving him only the top and the bottom.
meaning_hint: Imagine this terrifying samurai. You have legs… okay, that’s normal. But, then you have just a giant forehead on the top of everything else, walking around. That’s pretty scary that someone would sell such important parts of their body.
reading_story: To remember the reading う we use the word うに (sea urchin). After he’s sold half of his body, the Samurai starts trying to sell uni (う) as well. He keeps pushing the uni at you, trying to get you to buy it.
reading_hint: It’s up to you what you imagine after this (whether you buy it or not). Maybe you can take and sample some of it first (and taste the uni). Whatever you do, come up with a continuation for this story, and be sure to imagine the samurai as only a forehead on top of some legs. What is he talking out of? Why is he selling uni?

meaning_story: You discover something strange about a lantern. It's totally covered in hair which is arranged in a very strange shape.
meaning_hint: I want you to come up with a really strange shape this hair lantern should be in. Something startling, something surprising...
reading_story: The lantern also has a weird shaped marking on it under all the hair. It turns out the KKK (けい) have been here, and they left their sign (a big "K") on the lantern. Someone covered it up with their hair because they didn't like seeing it.
reading_hint: Carefully put the hair back over the lantern and the shape of the big K. Never look under it again.

meaning_story: You're doing some construction under your legs, and you're even wearing a helmet on top of that. Why do you need to build something under you and put something on top of you? You want to be able to reach the sky.
meaning_hint: So that explains why you're doing so many things to make yourself taller... too bad the sky is really high. Imagine what you'd need to construct / wear to get up that high.
reading_story: To remember the reading くう we'll use the word 'cooties.' You finally make yourself taller. But once you reach the sky, you find it's full of nasty cooties (くう) that knock you over and make you fall down.
reading_hint: You'll have to come up with something interesting for cooties in terms of what they look like. Are they like small bugs to you? Millions of small bugs running into you while you're up in the sky, knocking you down?

meaning_story: For some reason, you are standing on the sun. It's obviously very hot, but the thing you notice most is the sound of you burning up. It sizzles so much.
meaning_hint: Imagine a super loud sizzling sound, drowning everything else out. It's ridiculously loud, and hurts your ears more than the sun's heat hurts your skin.
reading_story: This sound is ridiculously loud. To counteract this, you turn on (おん) your noise canceling headphones.
reading_hint: You could turn on many other things too, to help out... maybe a fan to cool you off. Maybe the AC. Think of a bunch of things you turn on, and imagine yourself switching the 'on' switch to 'on' as well, to help bring home the point.

meaning_story: You have a wild viking child you have to take care of. He won't do anything but study, surprisingly. You can't get him to eat, use the bathroom, or anything else. He just wants to study.
meaning_hint: Of course, this isn't what you'd expect of a little viking child. It's the opposite. That's why it's so surprising! He loves to study!
reading_story: This crazy viking child who prefers study over pillaging (and other viking activities)... the other vikings just stop and gawk (がく) at him when they walk by.
reading_hint: You should tell the other vikings to stop gawking at this child. Just because he likes to study doesn't mean he's a bad viking...

meaning_story: You see a triceratops in the distance... but notice something odd about it. It's perfectly pi shaped (circular) It's the pitriceratops! But the shape isn't the strange thing about the pitriceratops. The weird part is that these creatures are made 100% out of sunlight. This kanji can also simply just mean light as well, if you like.
meaning_hint: Imagine it absorbing sunlight to become stronger. Then, it turns and sees you, nearly blinding you. Feel the pain in your eyes from all the sunlight emanating off the pitriceratops.
reading_story: Then you see it's actually fighting someone (that's what pitriceratops do best). He's fighting こういち, shooting him with bolts of sunlight, melting him where he stands.
reading_hint: Imagine this sight and make it somewhat traumatic. It will help you to remember that this kanji's reading is こう.

meaning_story: We have a coffin and a beggar. How do these things go together? The person begging is in the coffin. He's begging for his life, of course, but that's not going to do him any good. So, after he realizes that, he just begins to think. What could I have done better in my life? Why am I in this situation? How will I get out? Think, damnit, think!!
meaning_hint: Imagine him going down the slide thinking really, really hard. Maybe his head begins visibly throbbing from all of it. His hands are on his chin, allowing him to contemplate harder. Important thing is to focus in on the beggar’s thinking and perhaps a bit about what he’s thinking of.
reading_story: As he's being lowered into the grave in his coffin, conga (かんが) music begins to play. It interrupts his thinking, and he's unable to think clearly anymore.
reading_hint: Imagine his frustration (or, imagine it's you and your thinking is getting interrupted). This conga music is really irritating.

meaning_story: There's a mouth inside a mouth. But, if you look even closer (not actually, but we're pretending) you can see another mouth inside that mouth... and another one inside of that one! It keeps going and going. Can you count the number of times there's a mouth inside a mouth? This kanji also means revolve, too. Think of each 'time' a thing happens, it loops back around and comes back to the beginning, revolving around again for another time.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself counting and counting smaller and smaller mouths inside of each other, recording the number of times you can find a mouth inside another mouth. Dig deeper and deeper until it feels ridiculous how small the mouths are getting. Be sure to focus on the counting and the number of times you find one. Now, how many mouths is this times two, because your mouth is like this too.
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading かい we use the word 'coyote' At the very end... at the very last mouth... there's a big surprise for you there, which causes you to fall back. There's a tiny coyote (かい) that jumps out of the tiny little mouth and then gets bigger as it flies out at you, grabbing onto your face.
reading_hint: During all this, do you remember the number of times you had to count mouths in order to get to the coyote? Also, don't forget to feel surprised by the coyote jumping out at you. That surprise will help you to remember the reading!

meaning_story: There's a hat decorated with fins and (presumably fish) mouths on it. Who wears strange hats like this? Turns out, the valley people are the ones who wear these. I'm talking about the 'Valley Girls' of California, Hollywood / LA. They're into the crazy fashion, and they'll wear anything if it's deemed 'cool' or something like that.
meaning_hint: Imagine a bunch of Valley Girls walking around with these strange hats. Fins and fish mouths... what a strange new fad.
reading_story: Hanging around with all the Valley Girls in the sunny area of LA is also a robot. It's WALL-E's distant (and lazy, lounging relative), TAN-E (たに). He sits around getting a tan in LA with the Valley Girls while his cousin picks up trash.
reading_hint: What a jerk he is. Imagine the deep tan lines on TAN-E as well. He's the epitome of robot laziness.

meaning_story: You have a samurai with a flag on a stick. On his flag is this symbol, the kanji for voice. Why does he have that there? He feels like his Shogun isn't giving him and his fellow Samurai a voice, so he's brought a flag with the word 'voice' written on it to protest.
meaning_hint: Imagine him and other samurai with their flags on sticks waving them around shouting things like 'we want a voice in politics!' etc., etc.
reading_story: Once you start asking the samurai more specific questions about how he wants more voice he starts playing coy (こえ) with you. He doesn't really know what he wants, he's just here for the sake of protesting.
reading_hint: Then you ask him out on a date. He still plays coy with you... one of those samurai, I guess.

meaning_story: The west radical and west are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know all those radicals, will make your life more pleasant.
reading_story: To remember the reading せい we use 'Hard Gay' because he always says 'sei sei sei!!!' What's to your West? Think about the globe, and just keep going West until you hit Japan. Imagine Hard Gay (せい) standing on top of the image of Japan, thrusting his hips and saying 'SEI SEI SEI!!'
reading_hint: Make it as odd as possible. It's already pretty odd, thinking of a guy standing on a country on a globe, not to mention a weird guy like the character Hard Gay, but the stranger you make it in your mind, the more likely you are to remember it later!

meaning_story: Our leader has a lip ring. Wait, our leader has a lip ring? WHAT??
meaning_hint: Think of our president (or your prime minister, or dictator, or whatever) and imagine this person appearing on television one morning with a big ol' lip ring. Feel surprised by it. Just say 'What??' over and over again. You want to have the feeling of 'what' in you when you imagine this - that'll help you to remember this kanji's meaning.
reading_story: The leader with his lip ring is now eating some nan (なん) and curry. It's delicious, of course... but then he gets it caught on his lip ring, and tears half his lip off. He screams: 'Nannnnn eeeeeeeeeehhh!!' (なに) in anger at the nan and curry.
reading_hint: Make this one vivid and scary. He's eating the nan (that's your なん), and then he screams at the nan but gets overwhelmed with pain (that's the なに). Smell the nan (you're there) and see the blood gushing out of his/her lip. It's terrifying. How did the nan even catch on his lip ring anyways.

meaning_story: The life radical is without the slide (as it sometimes is), but when you combine that with the winter you have life during winter. What gives you life during the winter? It's the wheat you store away.
meaning_hint: Imagine you're starving. It's cold and you've run out of food. You don't know what you're going to do. If you don't find something, you'll lose your life. Then, you break open a barrel, and wheat pours out. It's beautiful. You just found some life in the middle of winter.
reading_story: You found your wheat. Thank God. You'll survive. You have to take the wheat back to your house, though. On your way, you get mugged (むぎ).
reading_hint: Imagine the disappointment. You go from finding life to losing it all... now you have no hope for the winter :( Also, keep in mind that むぎ and mug aren't super-alike, so you'll have to use it to get close enough to remember the actual reading, むぎ.

meaning_story: You have someone with horns, springs (on his feet), a stick, and is going down a slide. What type of person do you imagine? I'd say someone who's an immature boy. That would be your younger brother.
meaning_hint: Just pretend you have a younger brother for now, if you don't. Also be sure to imagine this person really vividly. They look ridiculous. He is a stereotypical little kid (horns because horns are awesome, springs on his feet, and a stick - plus he's going down a slide). Everything about someone like this screams 'little brother.'
reading_story: Unfortunately he goes down this slide too fast, bounces off the bottom with his spring shoes, and then falls right on his stick. It goes through him, causing your younger brother to die (だい). That's right, he's dead (で) now.
reading_hint: Be sure to feel bad about your younger brother. He was your younger brother, after all… just not a very careful younger brother. Very tragic. Just think about all the things you could have done to prevent this from happening. Was there anything? Was it kind of your fault?

meaning_story: Kings with hats. Did you know that all kings wear hats?
meaning_hint: Think of as many kings as you can think of. Guess what, every single one of them (aka all of them) wear hats! Think of strange hats, funny hats, and normal hats. Just make sure you're amazed by the fact they all are wearing them.
reading_story: But, as you're going through all the kings, it turns out not all them have hats after all. The last one you come to does not have a hat. He is the king of Zen (ぜん) Buddhism. He has simple clothes and a shaved head, unlike all the other fancy kings standing around nearby.
reading_hint: To add to this story and make it more memorable, you can imagine the other kings getting upset, saying things like 'All kings must wear hats! You are no king!' The king of Zen Buddhism just ignores them and begins to meditate.

kunyomi: うし, あと, のち
meaning_story: In the winter, poop loiters behind you (aka on your butt) because it freezes so fast. It lasts a long time after it's been dropped. Really it's anything that's behind you... which includes rear and back as well.
meaning_hint: Well, this is already really gross, but it can't be helped. It's so cold that your poop freezes to your butt cheeks and loiters there for a long time. Imagine the feeling of it frozen and stuck to you, and you know that if you try to rip it off, it'll take your skin with it. So, you're stuck with it behind you until you can get home.
reading_story: To pass the time while you wait for your poop to thaw from your rear/behind/back, you play a rousing game of go (ご) with your good pal こういち. After the game of go is done, your poop has finally thawed out. Finally.
reading_hint: Imagine playing this game of go with こういち. He's very talented, so the game is exciting. However, as your poop begins to thaw, the room smells more and more like poop. Smell the terrible poopy smell as it fills the room.

meaning_story: The blood radical and blood are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: There'll be some bad blood between us if you're not studying your radicals, especially when they're the same like this kanji!
reading_story: To remember the reading けつ, we use the word "ketsup." The perfect mix of ketchup and catsup! The radical is technically blood, but you know that radical is just a drop (of blood) on a plate. So, you ask yourself... Is that really blood on the plate? Could it be? You decide to take a gamble and lick it off. When you taste it, it's definitely not blood. No, it's ketsup (けつ).
reading_hint: Feel the relief that you didn't just lick up someone's blood. Taste the ketsup taste, too. It's pretty good. Not quite ketchup, but not quite catsup. Yum!

meaning_story: Under the ground, which you dug into, you found two great finds. You found both a mountain and a head, two strange things to find underground.
meaning_hint: You'll want to focus on the part where you find both, not so much the things themselves. Think about how you can't believe you did so good finding both things at once. Usually you only find one or the other when you're searching.
reading_story: But, you dig too deep and water flows into where you are. Your only hope is a row (りょう) boat floating off in the distance.
reading_hint: Also think... 'What's that row boat doing here?' But, it's your only hope, so you have to focus on it really hard.

meaning_story: The sun AND the moon are out? With both their light-powers combined, it's incredibly bright outside.
meaning_hint: Look up at both of them, hanging out in the sky together. Make them super bright, so bright you have to shield your eyes.
reading_story: When do things start to get bright outside? I'd say when things start getting sunny, and that is the month of May (めい).
reading_hint: If your months don't match up with this too well (if you're down in the southern hemisphere, for example) then you'll have to imagine all this up in the Northern Hemisphere. Sorry about that, South Hemisphere ladies and gents.

meaning_story: Someone is trying to put a lid on the small mouths. This is oppression. The small people are trying to speak out their opinions on the government but they cannot. Where would it be most important to squelch this sort of uprising? In the capital.
meaning_hint: Just imagine all these people yelling for change out of their mouths. They are the little people, the peasants, the regular Joes. Imagine them at the capital (imagine your capital building, whatever it is, in your country). P.S. This kanji looks very similar to the radical 束 but it's a little different. The line doesn't cross through the middle all the way. Be careful of this.
reading_story: To remember the reading きょう we use the Japanese city, Kyoto. Remember how there's a revolution brewing in the capital (via the radical?). It is drawing near. The people will take the capital soon. They've already taken Kyoto (きょう), and they took it with ease. If they can take Kyoto this easily, the capital will be no problem.
reading_hint: See the revolution. Be the revolution. Feel the swarm of people all around you as you overtake Kyoto and move on to take the capital city as well!

meaning_story: A leader with a spoon is a powerful thing. Even something like a spoon when given to the right man or woman can make great change in the world.
meaning_hint: Imagine your leader-hero holding a spoon out, then doing something awesome with it to totally change everything for the better. It's amazing the change this person can do with such a blunt, small, device!
reading_story: Then, this hero of yours takes their spoon and says some magic words into it, changing it into a car (か).
reading_hint: Of course, doing something like this is utterly amazing. Feel amazed in your imagination, because if you don't, then it'll be hard to remember the reading for this kanji. If you are amazed, you'll know that spoons going to cars = the reading is か, so make sure you take the time to be amazed.

meaning_story: The mouth of the king extends all the way around him (like in this kanji). Where his mouth reaches, that is his country, give or take a few drops.
meaning_hint: Imagine his talking taking physical form. As he talks, waves extend out from him, and stop right at the border of his country before getting to the next one.
reading_story: Turns out the king of this country loves drinking Coke (こく). Every morning that big mouth of his swallows a whole 2-liter bottle of Coke for breakfast.
reading_hint: Would you drink that much soda for breakfast? Now this king says he wants to pass a law requiring everyone in the country to drink nothing but Coke! That's crazy!

meaning_story: You'll have to stretch the top of bad out a bit, but it's there. You have a bad spoon, though you don't know that. When you use it to take a bite of something, your throat seizes up. You can't breathe. There was poison on that bad spoon, and now you're about to experience death.
meaning_hint: Imagine Death coming up behind you with his black cloak and scythe. He says 'aw, you had a bad spoon, sorry. I'm here to take you now.' You try to plead with death, saying his name over and over ('Death, but... Death, no, please!') to no avail. He takes you to his death kingdom.
reading_story: To remember し we use the word 'Charlie Sheen.' - You're taken to the Death Kingdom, where you are put in a waiting room. There next to you is Charlie Sheen (し). He says 'what's up?' and you two talk for a bit.
reading_hint: Imagine the whole conversation play out. What do you talk to Sheen about? Do you talk about how you both died? Something like that?

meaning_story: The meaning of the radical death and the kanji deceased are pretty similar which should make it easier to remember the meaning of this kanji.
meaning_hint: It's not just death though, it's a more polite version of the word death. You know how you say 'he's deceased' instead of 'he's dead' because it sounds nicer? It's kind of like that.
reading_story: When you think of deceased people, and possibly hanging out with deceased people, you can't help but think that they really are pretty boring.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself sitting with a deceased person. Are you having fun? Probably not. Feel the boredom. Take out your phone to do something, only to realize you've done everything there is to do on your phone. So boring. So, so boring... ugh.

meaning_story: There's a nice little leaf coming out of a rice paddy in a little box. So, everything is really tiny. Why? Because actually this is a drawing. Most likely some kind of modern art.
meaning_hint: What does this drawing mean? You're looking at it in the museum, examining it closely. Imagine this scene as a drawing to hit home the point that this kanji means drawing as well.
reading_story: Now you get it! Someone created this rice paddy in this box. The drawing is trying to depict a god (が) that is creating the earth. It's like his little sandbox for creation experiments. Putting the rice field in the box and watching it grow is one of those experiments. Then he fills it with cocks (かく)... the bird kind, you sicko.
reading_hint: Imagine the gods in the corner of the picture, looking down, commenting on the creation and adding feedback. What a strange drawing indeed.

meaning_story: You're digging a grave and you find an alligator's skull. You're excited about this find. So, you keep digging and digging, hoping to find more. Soon you find yourself surrounded by the earth itself! You can also think of this word as ground too, because that's kind of what the earth is made out of, at least the hard part.
meaning_hint: To make things even more memorable, you can imagine the alligator skull being hundreds of feet wide / tall. Imagine yourself digging the whole thing out, by hand, for years and years. Think of all the earth that would get in your fingernails. Think of the huge mounds of earth you'd create. Epic!
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading ち we use the word 'cheese' - You keep digging until you're surrounded by earth. You are digging down into the giant alligator's throat now, and in its throat you find a huge, rotting chunk of cheese (ち).
reading_hint: This is what killed the giant alligator! Dig into the cheese a little bit, smell it... even taste it! Anything to help you to remember that the reading for 地 is 'cheese' (aka ち).

meaning_story: There are some holy cross rice paddys with religiously important fish fins in them for some reason. You want to collect these fins, but you don't know where to go. You survey around. All you know is that these cross-shaped fin-filled rice paddys are to the east.
meaning_hint: So, turn to the east and make your way over there. Did you find all the fins you were looking for? Actually figure out in your imagination which direction east is though. If you struggle a bit at figuring it out (maybe you check moss on trees or check the wind or check the sun...) you'll likely remember this kanji's meaning better.
reading_story: You walk to what you think is east and test the rice paddy waters out. Eventually you find yourself in Tokyo (とう), which is about as far east as you can get. Once in Tokyo, you reach into the water and pull out some fish fins.
reading_hint: Feel these scaly, webbed fins in your hands. You're very tired from walking all the way to Tokyo, but these fins were worth it. Hold them up to the sky as you collapse into the rice paddy exhausted.

meaning_story: The radical for eat and the kanji for eat are the same! Lucky you.
meaning_hint: If you know the radical, you basically know the meaning(s) of this kanji. There is a second meaning added to it, though, and that is meal. Just think about the things you eat? What are they? In the simplest form, they are just meals. So, if you know 'eat' you should be able to remember 'meal' as well.
reading_story: Thank goodness, you finally get to eat your meal. You're so hungry. Someone has been starving you and now they've finally given you food. Unfortunately, though, every time you take a bite, you get a shock (しょく) from somewhere.
reading_hint: So, do you keep eating and keep getting shocked? Or do you not eat and continue to starve? What is worse? Obviously you're in one of the Saw movies, or something, too, so feel the fear. What will you choose? Life with shocks or death from hunger?

meaning_story: You accidentally stab your cross into the eye of a lion. Of course, this is a terrible thing you've done, because it's Mike Tyson's Lion. You have to fix your mistake. Mike Tyson is very direct when he tells you that you gotta fix your mistake.
meaning_hint: How will you fix this mistake, though? Maybe if you build a time machine you can go back and stop yourself from throwing your cross around so carelessly. Whatever you do, focus on how important it is to fix the mistake, more than anything. This kanji also means direct, so just imagine Mike Tyson being very direct when he speaks to you.
reading_story: Of course, there's not much you can do to fix this issue, and eventually Tyson finds out. In his rage, he grabs you around the neck and chokes (ちょく) you. As he rattles you, you make a 'jikijikijiki' (じき) noise as well. How's that for taking the direct approach?
reading_hint: Imagine Tyson grabbing your neck choking you out. You can't breath. You stop struggling. Then everything goes black. In your last moment, think about the mistake you made, wishing you could have fixed it.

meaning_story: You find some horns, some ribs, and some moon rock on the ground in front of you. When you try to move, they always rotate around with you, staying right in front. You can't escape these objects, for some reason. This kanji also means before, too. Something that's in front of you is before you, after all.
meaning_hint: Perhaps it's some kind of magic, but you don't care. Why are these strange objects always in front of me? Why won't they stay put? This will get pretty freaky after a while. Try to run.
