Try to hide. Spin around. Do whatever you need to do. No matter what, these objects are always in front.
reading_story: You're going crazy with these things in front of you all the time. You finally seek the help of a Zen master, who tells you that meditation will save you from this curse. You try it out, and sure enough, the objects are gone! It worked!
reading_hint: Go ahead and do some Zen Buddhist meditation. Maybe it'll help you to remember this kanji's reading better (and calm your mind so you're ready for the next kanji!).

meaning_story: A narwhal and a moon. Two great, majestic things. You really want to have both of them, more than anything.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself holding both, one in each arm, so happy because you have what you want. What a lucky kid you are, getting everything!
reading_story: Who wants these things? Duh, that's you (ゆう).
reading_hint: Who else could it be that'd want something so strange as this combination?

meaning_story: Just before saying something important, you take an arrow to the mouth which seals your lips together, making it so you can't talk. Someone doesn't want you to share what you know with something else.
meaning_hint: Imagine being so surprised by this arrow. Then, think of all the things you know that need to be said and told to everyone. Maybe you have information about nuke codes. Maybe you have information that will save the President. Whatever it is, make sure you know important things that need to be said (but also things that people want to prevent you from saying, even if it means shooting you in the mouth with an arrow).
reading_story: To remember the reading ち we use the word 'cheese.' - One of the things you know is actually very strange but very important. The president's cheese has been poisoned and only you know. If you could just say something then maybe you could save him... but... you have an arrow in your mouth.
reading_hint: Try saying the words 'cheese' with an arrow in your mouth. What would that sound like? Go ahead and pretend out loud.

meaning_story: A tsunami of a thousand mouths sweeps over your city, enveloping everything in its path. As you're being swallowed up, the one thing you notice is how lively the mouths are. They're talking, they're having a good time, and they're laughing. So lively.
meaning_hint: Imagine the mouths doing all kinds of things that you'd personally associate with being 'lively.' This is more of a personal thing, so fit the mnemonic to your own tastes!
reading_story: After the lively mouth tsunami is over, the town is infested by thousands of cats (かつ) who enjoy feeding on mouths.
reading_hint: Nom nom nom nom. There's just as many cats as there are mouths, making for a really crazy scene. Imagine a standing room only cat fest.

meaning_story: The radical for long and the kanji for long are the same! There is also another meaning to learn, though, which is leader. You can remember this by thinking about how the leader has a long staff, showing he's the leader.
meaning_hint: Make sure you know your radicals!
reading_story: Its been a long time, Mrs. Chou (ちょう), but we meet again.'
reading_hint: Remember your arch nemesis, Mrs. Chou? She's the one who spread all those nails around in the town. Well, she's back, and it's time for vengeance (even though it's been such a long time). Say the phrase in the mnemonic out loud a few times, doing a cool voice, and you'll be more likely to remember it.

meaning_story: Twenty mouths are together. That's a lot of mouths. What do they do? They sing beautiful music together.
meaning_hint: Listen to the twenty mouths. They sound great. Have them sing your favorite music. Also note that this kanji also means 'bend.' Imagine the music coming out at you bending all around in strange shapes through the air.
reading_story: The twenty mouths make so much music that they literally cloak you (きょく) with it. They cloak you with the music.
reading_hint: Imagine how you feel as they cloak you with music. Feel the music all around you, enveloping you. Become the music itself.

meaning_story: The radical neck and the kanji neck are exactly the same!
reading_story: You find this alien with the strange neck (remember how the radical is an alien with a strange neck?). You poke it. It wakes up and starts yelling things it's seen on American television (you know, to try to fit in, though it's pretty obvious it's an alien). 'Kooby (くび) Dooby Doo!' it yells, trying to say 'Scooby Dooby Doo!' and failing.
reading_hint: Kooby Dooby Doo? you ask? Then, like a broken record, the alien with the weird neck just keeps going and going and going, nonstop, until you break its neck. Then it stops.

meaning_story: You lack ice. So you go to the store and see if they have any. Nope, no ice. So, now you go to the next store. Is there ice here? Nope. Next!
meaning_hint: Feel a little frustrated you can't find ice. Have the words 'next next next' echoing through your head as you go from store to store, irritated.
reading_story: To remember the reading じ, we used the word 'Jesus' - Finally, when you're at the last store in existence, you decide it's time to pray to Jesus (じ), asking for a miracle. He comes down from the heavens with ice in his hands.
reading_hint: Imagine him coming down. Imagine your surprise. He hands you the ice, and it's cold. You thank him, and he flies away.

meaning_story: A leader is wearing a lid and is standing outside in winter. Plus it's raining and he's covered in drops of water. On top of all this, it's night.
meaning_hint: If it helps, you can come up with a reason why he's outside in the winter at night. Also, why is he wearing a lid on his head? Probably because he's protecting his people from something that comes at night.
reading_story: Question is, what is he protecting them from during the night? Turns out, it's the Yankees (や) baseball team. They're out for blood, and only the leader can protect us.
reading_hint: Imagine the Yankees stomping towards the leader, baseball bats in hand, blood on their faces. They're here to eat, and nobody will stop them. Feel the fear of their approach. Will you survive another night with them on the prowl?

meaning_story: There's a woman standing with two face who has a lid on his head. You look carefully at the woman. Who would be with Two Face not to mention crazy version of him (with a lid on his head!)? To your surprise, this woman is your older sister!
meaning_hint: You're very protective of your older sister so be sure to feel the shock and disgust that she's with crazy Two Face. You go up to him and yell at him about trying to be with your older sister.
reading_story: Two Face looks at you and your older sister. 'HA!' he yells. I'm not Two Face, I'm Charlie Sheen! He tears off a mask and sure enough it's Charlie Sheen. And guess who this two face good for nothing older sister is marrying? What a good match. She's marrying Charlie Sheen.
reading_hint: This is actually worse than Two Face. Feel the rage build up inside of you. Give Charlie Sheen a push away from your older sister. He's not the kind of guy your older sister should be dating. Urgh!

meaning_story: The fortune teller is telling your fortune and takes a look at a fish tail for a moment, then writes down a number based off that. It's the number 100. 'This is how many more years you'll live, so the fish tail says.' You look. That's not too bad. 'Wait,' she says. 'I made a mistake.' She grabs her pen and adds a point to the number. The point is a decimal right after the 1. 'Sorry, bad math. One more year to live.'
meaning_hint: You can't believe it. Just one decimal point takes your life from 100 extra years to only 1 more year. Of course, you'll feel really frustrated at the fortune teller for forgetting her decimals. You were so happy one minute, and now you're really upset. All because of one measly decimal...
reading_story: The decimal is still fiery in your mind. 'Wait!' she says again. 'I messed up again. I should move this decimal to the ten spot. There you go. You have ten years to live.'
reading_hint: This is getting ridiculous. You start with 100. Then go down to one. Now you're at ten?? What is it going to be next? Actually, it turns out to be ten. Imagine yourself 10 years later - how do you die? The fortune teller was absolutely right on the last fortune - exactly ten years, down to the second.

meaning_story: You walk up to a woman with a helmet on her head. 'Why are you wearing a helmet on your head?' you ask. 'Because it helps me to stay relaxed,' she replies. 'Oh, and it was super cheap, too.' You can see the price tag. It was only $1. That is cheap.
meaning_hint: You can imagine her super relaxed right now. But, if you take off the helmet she flips out and starts attacking you, screaming. Put the helmet back on, and she falls over limp, super-duper relaxed.
reading_story: When she falls over again, super relaxed, you pull out her wallet and open it up (because obviously, this lady needs help). You find her name, it's Anne (あん).
reading_hint: Say her name over and over as you're trying to revive her (without pulling the helmet off, of course!). 'Anne! Hey, you okay. Anne!?'

meaning_story: You find a pile of helmets on the ground. You move them aside to reveal a grave. When you open up the grave and go inside, you find yourself in your room.
meaning_hint: It's your room, exactly. Imagine yourself in your room, but it's underground hidden beneath a grave that was below a pile of helmets. Obviously, you should feel unnerved.
reading_story: You think "this can't be my room!" So you walk to the corner, where you keep a box filled with your shit (しつ) *sorry kids and moms.
reading_hint: When you look in the box, there it is, just how you left it. This is definitely your room. Or at least a perfect replica.

meaning_story: Using some chopsticks, you carefully pick away at a pine tree, taking some important specimens for it. Why are you doing this? For science, obviously.
meaning_hint: Take the specimens back to your lab and study them. What are they? Make them something very strange, and focus on the fact that you have a laboratory, a lab coat, and all sorts of science-related things to make you remember the word 'science.'
reading_story: Using all your science skills, you take the things you harvested and add a couple of scientific drops of something else to it. You step back, and watch it grow rapidly into a car (か).
reading_hint: This isn't at all what you expected. Why did it turn into a car? You should be terribly surprised by it. Check it out. It's a weird looking car, based off whatever you harvested from the pine tree earlier (you decided that part, remember?).

meaning_story: You can see the tsunami coming from your window, so you point your gun at it. 'You better turn away, sea, or I'll shoot!' The sea decides it doesn't want to die today, so it turns its tsunami around and goes the other way.
meaning_hint: You'll have to think of the 'sea' as its own entity, controlling the tsunami, otherwise you might confuse and combine the two. So, when you point your gun out the window, aim it at the 'sea,' not the 'tsunami,' if that makes any sense.
reading_story: Once the sea starts running, you sic your pack of coyotes (かい) on it, and they go and chase down the sea.
reading_hint: Watch the pack of coyotes bringing the sea down, and have them drag the sea back to you. 'Well well well. What do we have here.'

meaning_story: The sheep radical and sheep are the same in looks as well as and meaning.
meaning_hint: You are no sheep - you study your radicals, unlike most Japanese learners. You'll learn sooo much faster!
reading_story: To remember よう, we use the word 'Yogurt.' - The sheep are after you. There are too many of them, and they're chasing you down, stalking you... waiting for you to get tired. You are so hungry, and all you have in your pocket is some sheep's milk yogurt (よう). You eat it, and recharge.
reading_hint: Imagine the taste of this yogurt. You're so hungry and it tastes so good!

meaning_story: You go get your fortune told by a dude with a mullet. He says that you will go to a shop full of mullets, and buy him a new mullet.
meaning_hint: You're suspicious at first, but then you look up. You're right in front of a mullet shop. You feel the allure of mullets, and so you go in ready to buy.
reading_story: How many do you buy? The allure must have been strong, because you just bought ten (てん) mullets! TEN! Wow. Way to spend.
reading_hint: Seriously, though. What's up with the fortune teller with the mullet? How did he know you'd go into this shop, let alone buy ten mullets? Some sort of conspiracy is going on, obviously.

meaning_story: Where are you, right this very moment? Once you've got that, imagine people with sheep heads carrying crosses living to the south of you.
meaning_hint: So, where is that place? Is it France? Is it Brazil? Is it some city, maybe? Wherever it is, imagine the people of that place to have sheep heads with crosses. Imagine yourself driving down there and seeing all of them, walking around like it's normal. What's up with these southern people?
reading_story: When you go down to the south you have to stop in somewhere to eat. Of course, a sheep-headed cross-wearing person serves you and asks you what you want. Tell the sheep what you want. He says, 'sorry, the only thing we serve in this city is naan (なん). Would you like naan?'
reading_hint: Only nan? That's pretty odd. Go around to a bunch of other places as well. Turns out the sheep was telling the truth. They only eat nan here. Time to go back north, I think.

meaning_story: The sun that gives life is our very own star (which we happen to call the sun). Of course, all the other stars are probably giving life to other planets as well.
meaning_hint: Imagine all sorts of stars all around the universe giving life to planets as suns. These are all the stars you see in the sky, and there are billions of them. I hope you feel overwhelmed by how minuscule we really are when you look up at all of them.
reading_story: On one of the planets that has gotten life from a distant star, there is a particularly strange life form. They look like hoes with the faces of Charlie Sheen. They are known as the Ho-Sheen (ほし) race of beings.
reading_hint: Imagine these beings as vividly as you can. Make them strange so you remember them. Watch them go about their daily lives and come up with habits these creatures have. Are they intelligent? Are they like humans? Are they totally different? That's all up to you - just make sure to make it strange.

meaning_story: Think about Japan. Japan is a country made up of islands. Those islands are kind of like states in a way. These three drops in the huge river that makes up the Pacific Ocean are just Japanese states in the water.
meaning_hint: Also, another way to think of this is that the river radical is actually just three rivers, separating drops, which are capitals of various states. Rivers are usually great ways to divide up a country, and states are one way to do it!
reading_story: Each state is known for something in particular, right? Let's take the United States. Think through the ones you know in your head, asking each one what they're known for. Strangely, every single state says they're known for their shooters (しゅう). Well, the United States does love their guns, after all.
reading_hint: Each state representative even shows you their shooter. These shooters are very proud of themselves and their guns and they even put on a shooting demonstration for you. Hear the guns shoot all around you. It's overwhelming.

meaning_story: You come across an angel wearing a hat that's covered in flowers. So, you do the only natural thing. You take this angel, chop him up into tiny pieces, and dry him out. Then, you make tea out of all the dried up angel bits. You wear the hat, though.
meaning_hint: How does this angel-flower tea taste? Be sure to imagine it. Probably heavenly *rimshot.*
reading_story: In your tea you find a little metal button. I guess you missed it while you turned the angel into tea. You look at the button - on the back it says 'To Chad, you'll make an awesome angel.' Looks like you're drinking Chad the Angel.
reading_hint: It gets kind of weird when you know their names... Usually you just make them into tea without knowing who they are (easier that way). This one... this one is Chad, and you remember it vividly, because now you feel kind of bad.

meaning_story: In the rice paddy, you come across a beating heart. Of course, you do the most logical thing you can think of and pick it up and start eating it. After you're done eating it, you realize what you've done. It's Einstein's heart, and by eating it, it gives you the power to think like him.
meaning_hint: Now, sit in the middle of the rice paddy and think like the master of thinkers. Think about the universe. Think about space time. Think about the speed of light. What have you figured out? Of course, in this mnemonic, think about thinking. It's where you should arrive and where you should narrow into.
reading_story: Then, you see another heart in the rice field. Since the first heart did so well, and made you a great thinker, you go for it again. You eat the heart, but this one is Charlie Sheen's heart, and it dumbs you right back down to where you started.
reading_hint: If only you had thought a little harder, maybe you would have realized that the only direction you could have gone is down. Now you have the power of Charlie Sheen and Einstein in you, but they cancel each other out, leaving you where you started.

meaning_story: You stop at a small slide. What were you doing before you stopped here? You were walking.
meaning_hint: Question is, what made you stop? Imagine yourself walking at a nice casual pace... then imagine something that would make you stop that's incredibly interesting and strange. Maybe an alien is going down the slide? He would say 'keep walking, friend.'
reading_story: So, you're walking around, minding your own business, when suddenly something flips up and whacks you in the face. You stepped on the head of a hoe (ほ) and it caused it to swing up from the ground and hit you.
reading_hint: Of course, imagine the pain of your face. Did your nose break? After bringing yourself together, look down at what hit you. It's a hoe! How did you manage to step on just the right spot to flip it up on you like that? Examine the hoe. Pay close attention to it. Who's hoe is this? etc.

meaning_story: The cyclops only has one eye, so it really likes to look off into the distance with it. He's like the tower of Sauron, he thinks, with his one big eye. He's facing yonder, his large eye seeing all.
meaning_hint: Maybe the cyclops hears something behind him, so he swings around, and looks yonder again.
reading_story: As the cyclops is looking yonder he sees something moving (finally!). Turns out it's こういち, who's trying to get rid of the one ring! 'Oh crap,' thinks the cyclops. 'I better go take him out.'
reading_hint: Now you can imagine the cyclops and こういち battling it out. It's an epic fight, but you decide who wins.

meaning_story: A woman who is as speedy as a jet is definitely your younger sister. She's got seemingly unlimited energy and all she seems to do is run around. You, the older sister, on the other hand, are slow.
meaning_hint: Imagine a little girl (your younger sister) running around with her arms out, pretending to be a jet, too. Prwoooooo!
reading_story: Wait now your younger sister seems to be running even faster and she doesn't look happy anymore. Oh, it's because there are some mice (まい) on the floor and now they're chasing her. They seem to want a ride on your younger sister. They probably think she's a real jet.
reading_hint: Watch at your younger sister screams, running away from a bunch of little mice. They're all over her now. Your little sister is covered in mice.

meaning_story: Think of the coolest water slide in the world (so amazing!). Now, think of your disappointment when you hear about the swords that have been sliding down the slides and getting stuck, making it uber-dangerous for you to use this slide. In fact, it’s so dangerous, they’ve had to block off the entire area. You can’t even come close, that’s how bad the whole sword-water slide situation is.
meaning_hint: You'll want to imagine swords everywhere... on the slide, around the slide, everywhere. Then, as you walk up to go in (because you love water slides!) a police officer comes up and stops you, saying 'sorry, this area is blocked off.' Feel the disappointment, you really wanted to go in there!
reading_story: As you’re looking in on the blocked off area (all sad and stuff), you see something flapping around coming your way. It’s a hen (へん)… a female chicken, flying around avoiding flying swords, trying not to get hit. The hen looks like it’s flying around all crazy, but it’s really avoiding everything quite well. It’s very ninja-like.
reading_hint: Feel impressed by how good the hen is at avoiding things. Feel concerned for this hen as well. The more you feel for the hen, the more likely you are to remember it when you need to!

meaning_story: You have the measurement of a leader. Imagine yourself measuring said leader (his/her height) and then coming up short. This is not good, you think. Leaders need to be at least six feet tall. So, to make the leader tall enough, you attach another head to the top of his/her head.
meaning_hint: Make sure you really feel like the person can’t be a leader because they’re too short when you measure them (I know this isn’t true, but we’re remembering kanji here, anything goes!). As long as you feel disconcerted that the leader isn’t tall enough, you should be able to remember that you need to attach something to the leader to make him/her tall enough. The fact that you’re attaching another head to the top of his/her head is pretty weird too, and should help you to remember the meaning.
reading_story: You have to remember the kun'yomi reading of this kanji, and the part you need to remember is つ. So, think of attaching something to something else. What would you need? You'd need two (つ) things to put together!
reading_hint: Just focus on how attaching requires two things to remember this reading.

meaning_story: The tree has an umbrella, and it's holding it over his head, which is strange, because trees normally like water... turns out, it's not water falling on him, but dollar bills floating down.
meaning_hint: The sick part of this is that those dollar bills were once this tree's friends. The tree is sobbing uncontrollably as pieces of his friends fall on him and all around him - which is why he's using the umbrella to protect himself.
reading_story: The tree couldn’t take the body parts of his friends falling down on him, so he sat (さつ) down, and began crying uncontrollably.
reading_hint: What else could he do? He couldn’t move, so he sat. It’s weird imagining a tree trying to sit…

meaning_story: The radical bird and the kanji bird are exactly the same!
reading_story: Do you remember evil Mrs. Chou? The one who likes dropping nails on streets in towns? She's going to make a reappearance now. You're looking at some pretty birds. Think of the prettiest bird you can think of. Enjoy this moment, because Mrs. Chou (ちょう) suddenly walks in, grabs your favorite bird, breaks its neck, then puts it in a bag to take home for supper.
reading_hint: Of course, feel the shock of this experience. You can't do anything because you can't believe what just happened. Zero in on Mrs. Chou (she's the important part, really) and think about how much you hate her. She's going to eat your favorite bird! Go ahead and yell out Darth-Vader style 'CHOOOOOOUUUUUU!' if you want to really remember this.

meaning_story: The radical black and the kanji black are exactly the same.
reading_story: You're in a completely black room. There's no way out, and you can't see. The room starts to fill with liquid. It gets in your mouth. You taste it. It's Coke (こく)! Mm, tasty Coke.
reading_hint: You need to drink all this Coke, otherwise you're going to drown. Drink this Coke and keep tasting its cold sweetness as you drink it all to survive.

meaning_story: If you have something with fins and a mouth, you can probably assume it's a fish. If you add a sail to this fish, you have yourself a nice little boat.
meaning_hint: Or a giant boat, perhaps? Imagine yourself riding a giant fish with a sail stuck in it. What an awesome boat you have. It can swallow up smaller ships whole for you, if you like.
reading_story: What do boats do? They send you across the ocean.
reading_hint: Also think about someone giving you some letters to send as well.

meaning_story: Lion-person-drop. Think of the 'drop' as 'dropping something' instead of the usual drop of water. Now, imagine the kind of air drop the army might do. Except this one is a lion on a rope, holding onto a person, and then dropping the person at the right place. So, how did you get to the drop zone? You got there by means of lion-person-drop technology.
meaning_hint: I know, this one is a long one. But, if you see these three radicals together, how can you not think of this strange transportation method? Once you're able to do that, just focus in on needing to remember 'By Means Of' and you should be all set. If it doesn't come to you the first time, I bet it will come to you the second or third time, so don't fret!
reading_story: To remember the reading い we use the word “Eagle.” You’re about to do a drop by means of a lion person drop. Everything goes to plan, but as you’re falling towards the ground an eagle (い) flies by and tears open your parachute.
reading_hint: Feel the fear of falling. Focus in on the eagle… how did the enemy know?? They used the direct counter to your lion person drop. Be angry. Yell at the eagle. How could it!??

meaning_story: The slide coming out of the patient's heart is there because a mad scientist is testing to see if it's a good way to drain the body of blood. The patient is alive now... but they are definitely slated for certain death.
meaning_hint: As you imagine the mad scientist drawing blood out of the patient's heart with a small slide, also imagine a little meter hooked up to him as well. On one end is 'SURVIVE!' on the other end is 'CERTAIN DEATH.' Right now the finger is pointing close to certain death, though :(
reading_story: As the beeping heart things starts to do one long continuous beeeeeeeeeeeeeep, the doctor puts his hands together and hits (ひつ) the dead patient over and over, attempting to bring him back.
reading_hint: Maybe imagine yourself running in there too, just trying to hit the patient back to life, because the patient was your friend.

meaning_story: This kanji uses a modified jet radical. The front area wing is wider than the middle area of the wing. This may seem counterintuitive, but by doing this they can fit so much more jet fuel. The jet zooms off and keeps going for a long, long time, until it reaches the end of the earth.
meaning_hint: Imagine the end of the earth being like how they imagined it pre-Columbus era. Just a big drop going off into space, giant waterfalls plummeting down. Your crazy jet has made it to the very end! Congratulations!
reading_story: When you get to the end of the world, you land your jet and put out a few mats (まつ) to sit on so you can view the sights.
reading_hint: It's surprisingly dirty down here, because all the water takes the garbage this way. That's why you sit on these mats you brought.

meaning_story: The only radical that makes up this kanji is duck. Even though it looks the same, the radical has a different name from the kanji (because the meaning of the kanji is such a bad mnemonic word). So what is 'Duck?' You have that piece from the radical. The word 'Duck' is your family name.
meaning_hint: Just imagine your last name being 'Duck.' Say your first name plus 'Duck' out loud. Think about your family and parents, and how their last names are 'Duck' as well. Say as many of your family's name plus Duck as you can to help solidify the meaning of this kanji. 'Duck' is a 'Family Name.'
reading_story: Who else is a part of your family and who else shares your family name now? Turns out that Charlie Sheen (し) married into your family, so now his last name is the same as yours: Charlie Duck.
reading_hint: Make sure you feel a bit angry about his joining your family and using your Family Name like that. A Sheen doesn't deserve to be a Duck! C'mon!

meaning_story: Your husband is going down a slide. That's nice. As he's going down, though, he snaps the slide in two, and it collapses on top of your family dog :'( Was it your husband's fault that the dog died?
meaning_hint: Think of this conversation, following the 'accident.' You yell at your husband: 'This is your fault,' you scream. 'My fault!?' he replies. 'The slide obviously wasn't built right!' This goes on and on, and as it goes on, make sure to focus in on the fault part, with both people blaming each other over and over.
reading_story: Remember the dog that got squished? The husband was really sad about this, because it turned out to really be his fault because he built the slide too, so to make it up to the kids, he buys a new puppy. That new puppy is a shitsu (しつ).
reading_hint: Imagine the kids holding up the new shitsu puppy, so happy! They've forgotten all about the dog that's under the slide in the backyard... how horrible. Shitsu dogs aren't that distracting, are they? I guess they're puppies.

meaning_story: The radical fish and the kanji fish are exactly the same!
meaning_hint: Nothing fishy about that, right?
reading_story: You catch a fish. As you pull it out of the water, it starts yelling and pointing: 'GO!' (ぎょ). 'GO GYO GYO GYO!' There's a huge cruise ship coming right towards your little fishing boat. No wonder the fish was yelling GO at you.
reading_hint: Have him continue to scream 'GO GYO GYO GYO!' as you try to get your engine started and attempt to flee your impending doom. The fish helps too, because he's pretty worried as well.

meaning_story: Sew thread through your top hat and to the top hats of other people you know and you'll turn into a group of top hat wearing people. You're all connected by the thread now, so everyone will assume you're a group, even if that's all you guys have going for yourselves.
meaning_hint: Picture a group of people threaded together by their top hats. Don't you want to be part of a cool group like that? Your own top hat team.
reading_story: Even though the thread is connecting your top hats, the group itself is just so-so (そ). Being a group doesn't make you great. And none of you were that great to begin with, so you're just a bunch of so-so people in a so-so group now.
reading_hint: Imagine explaining your group to someone who isn't in it. When they ask how it is you shrug and say, "Eh, it's so-so."

meaning_story: You have a pig with a helmet. Now why in the world would you need something like this? He exists to protect your house.
meaning_hint: Imagine the pig with a helmet on his head protecting your own home. He stands outside the door attacking anyone who comes near (except for you, of course, this is your house after all!). The helmet makes him stronger, which is why he wears it to protect your house. That'll do pig, that'll do.
reading_story: Not only does he protect your house, though, he also protects your car (か). What a great package!
reading_hint: Imagine someone trying to get next to your car. The helmeted pig b-lines it to that person and takes them out.

meaning_story: This kanji is the same as the radical it comes from. Lack becomes Lack!
meaning_hint: If you know the radical you know this.
reading_story: To remember けつ, we use the word "ketsup." It's the perfect blend of ketchup and catsup! You're lacking something in your fridge. You look around, trying to find the ketsup (けつ) you lack. You can't find it, because you lack it.
reading_hint: Imagine having to use regular, ordinary ketchup, or just old, boring catsup on your burger. Or even worse, an actual tomato. BLEH!

kunyomi: ま, いま, ひつじ
meaning_story: You're flying in a Jet. Even though it's one of the fastest things on earth, your child is sitting in the back asking, 'Are we there yet? Are we there yet?' You have to keep responding. 'Not yet! Not yet! NOT YET!'
meaning_hint: Feel the irritation of this. How irritating is this kid going to be the whole flight over? The jet is going as fast as it can!
reading_story: What a selfish kid, right? Well, all he thinks about is 'Me (み) me me me me me me me me me me.' Hate kids like that.
reading_hint: Go ahead and pretend to listen to the kid asking if we're there yet. Then in your mind go 'me me me me me me me' quietly.

meaning_story: There's this duck pooping out thread. It's really strange that it would do this, because it's being fed paper.
meaning_hint: Imagine a duck being fed paper and instantly pooping out thread. You need thread, so this is good, but it's really strange that paper becomes thread like this when you feed it to a duck, you know?
reading_story: Turns out this duck is like a shredder. You put in paper and it shreds the paper into one long line of really skinny paper (thread). What paper are you trying to shred so nobody can see them? All the papers that show you're a Commi (かみ), aka a communist.
reading_hint: This duck is your only hope to hide the information before someone catches you! So, keep feeding those Commi papers to the duck as fast as he'll let you!

meaning_story: Your mama was going down a water slide but she came to an elephant blocking her path. But, since the elephant is so big, she went right in the mouth and then out the *cough* other end. She was able to pass through with no problem at all.
meaning_hint: Imagine the fear you'd feel for your mama as she's going down the slide at high speeds. Then, imagine the relief and surprise as she just passes right through the elephant, barely slowing down. It's nothing short of a really disgusting miracle.
reading_story: How big was this elephant she needed to pass through? Too (つう) big. Too, too big. So big she just passed right through one end and out the other. Ewww.
reading_hint: Imagine being inside this too big elephant. How did it get to be this too big size? Ponder this a while longer as you pass through the elephant's rear.

meaning_story: Everyone around you in this village has a duck mouth. They are all one 'Duck People.'
meaning_hint: Imagine visiting a nation. The first thing you see is how they all have duck mouths. Imagine how strange this would feel. It's a genetic thing, so you know it's a group of people that are like this. Duck People. An entire nation of Duck People.
reading_story: Another feature of these duck mouthed people? They're all terribly mean (みん).
reading_hint: They all come at you with their duck mouths and start biting you with them. Also imagine them saying mean things to you. Maybe they're making fun of your hair, or something. Whatever happens, be sure you associate these peoples being mean to you, whatever 'mean' means to you.

meaning_story: The sunflower was the reason the king was king. He was able to pluck the magic sunflower from the ground to claim his throne!
meaning_hint: Imagine the king pulling on a sunflower with everyone gathered round. They want to see if he'll be able to become king or not. Turns out, he will be able to become king, because he just pulled the sunflower out. Focus in on the reason he's king (because he pulled a sunflower out of the ground) and think about how absurd that reason is. Note that there's another 'reason' kanji in this level. It is 由, and also means reason.
reading_story: You don't have reason without re (り).

meaning_story: There are ten crosses with mouths, telling you the reason you are here.
meaning_hint: Imagine these crosses with mouths surrounding you in a dark room. You can just see their outlines and the large mouths talking to you. You know why you're here. Have them give you some kind of reason as to why you're here. It's important, whatever it is. Are you on some epic quest? Are you receiving a punishment? Are they judging you? It's up to you, just be sure to focus on the 'reason' part, though. Note that there's another 'reason' kanji in this level. It is 理, and also means reason.
reading_story: Why me? you ask. 'Because only you (ゆう) can do this,' they reply.
reading_hint: Just like most things like this, there's always a specific person in mind. In this case, it's you.

meaning_story: You find your father with a lid on his head, up in a tree. He yells down at you. 'Hey! Welcome to your first day of school!'
meaning_hint: You are not happy about this, but you have to do what your father says. So, you climb the tree and sit in the school bench to listen to your father talk crazy talk about all sorts of weird things. This is the worst school in the world, you think.
reading_story: It's just you and one other student at this ridiculous school. Your other classmate is a big trouble maker. It is こういち, the class clown.
reading_hint: Imagine こういち doing dumb things and bothering you and your father, who is the teacher. He throws こういち from the tree and expels him from this ridiculous school.

meaning_story: The rain is being mixed up and slashed at by a sky wolverine. This is causing the rain to get very cold and turn into snow.
meaning_hint: Imagine the wolverine running around the clouds frantically, trying to cool the air down with his claws to make this snow. For some reason, it's very important to him - perhaps you could help him out in that imagination of yours?
reading_story: You ask the wolverine, 'Why do you want this snow so bad?' He replies quickly: 'Because the rain is yucky' (ゆき).
reading_hint: He keeps saying 'Yucky yucky yucky' over and over again. Imagine him doing this with an accent that would bring the word closer to ゆき.

meaning_story: There's a pile of insects on top of a spring. Because the pile is so big, you need to be extremely strong to push it down enough to launch the huge pile of insects.
meaning_hint: Look at this pile of insects on the giant spring. Try to pull the spring down. You absolutely can't. Now imagine a bodybuilder coming along and pulling it down, launching the insects into the air. He's a bodybuilder, so he's strong enough.
reading_story: To remember the reading for きょう we use the Japanese city, Kyoto. When the bodybuilder is watching you try to pull the spring down (you aren't strong enough, though), he gets impatient (must be all the steroids). He shoves you out of the way, pulls down the spring, and launches all the insects from here to Kyoto (きょう). Dang, he's strong.
reading_hint: How far away are you from Kyoto? Probably pretty far. Imagine someone being strong enough to launch this pile of insects off of the spring and all the way to Kyoto.

meaning_story: The eye leaf grows only in the winter. Every other leaf, however, will do the opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
meaning_hint: Just think of the eye leaf as weird (it is weird, after all). It grows in the winter. Now, think of any normal leaves. They do the exact opposite, which is to grow in the summer.
reading_story: Now it's summertime! What do you do during the summer? You just sit around with your favorite string tying knots (なつ) in it over and over again.
reading_hint: Think about summer. Now think about yourself tying knots. Now think about summer again. Now think about tying knots again. Now think about your mother getting upset at you because all you do is tie knots all summer long. Go play video games like a normal kid!

meaning_story: Someone who has a lid on their head, an extra mouth above their mustache (which also contains a mouth) has got to be really, really tall.
meaning_hint: Also, dental care must be quite expensive as well, because of the two mouths there.
reading_story: Who is this tall monster with two mouths, a lid on his head, and a mustache? It's your good buddy こういち!
reading_hint: Imagine こういち being really tall with this scary face setup, looking down at you with both mouths open. Rwaawwwrh!

meaning_story: A teacher in winter is happiest because they get to teach! The kids can't go out and play because it's too cold. They all have to come in and stay warm as the teacher teaches!
meaning_hint: Picture a teacher excitedly teaching, bundled up in the cold. Snow falling outside. Grumpy children being taught, inside.
reading_story: Teacher can teach the most about Japan in winter by going to Kyoto (きょう). Kyoto is where all the old temples and history of Japan is centered. And it's really gorgeous when it snows.
reading_hint: Imagine the teaching teacher teaching you about Japan in Kyoto in winter. You've always wanted to go to Kyoto!

meaning_story: The sun and graves. They are both good ways to make a measurement of time. This also can mean o' clock, as in 'five o'clock' It's used when measuring what time it is in Japanese.
meaning_hint: Think about the sun going around the earth over and over again. That measures days going by. Think about graves. They have dates on them, and show generations of people. Both of these things have to do with one thing, and that is time and its passing.
reading_story: When we need to remember the reading for じ, we use the word 'Jesus.' One thing people think about when they think about time is the ability to do time travel. Now imagine Jesus (じ) being able to perform time travel magic. He performs an incantation, and goes back to the dinosaur ages, where he wrestles down a T-rex. Then, he goes to WWII era and punches Hitler in the mouth.
reading_hint: Imagine him going to all kinds of different times (since the word 'time' is important to our mnemonic) and also make sure you're specifically imagining Jesus doing all these things. Put these two together and you'll remember the reading in no time.

meaning_story: The springs are covered in ice. This has made them very weak.
meaning_hint: What else would ice do to springs? I'm pretty sure getting ice in springs is a bad idea for any machine. Those springs need to move, and moving frozen things breaks said frozen things. These springs are so weak.
reading_story: You are driving your truck over a frozen lake in a blizzard and one of your tires gets a flat. All you have in the car is a spring but it's covered in ice. You put it under your car and try to use it as a jack (じゃく), but it breaks because the ice made it so weak. Now you're stranded on this lake with your truck and this broken, weak jack.
reading_hint: This makeshift jack is so weak that it broke the moment you tried to shove it under your truck. The weakest jack you've ever seen, why even bother using such a weak jack?

meaning_story: A ghost is going down the water slide. The ghost goes down the water slide only one day of the week.
meaning_hint: You have to imagine the ghost thinking... 'Oh, what day of the week is it?' then realizing it's that special day of the week. At this point, he drags himself to the water slide where he has to go down it again. He's been alive forever, so now he's getting a bit tired of this weekly ritual.
reading_story: As the ghost goes down the water slide this week, he thinks everything is going fine, when suddenly a shooter (しゅう) shoots him and the ghost flies off and goes over the edge into the bushes under the slide. Ughh, how irritating!
reading_hint: Pretend that you're the ghost - think of how irritating it would be to get shot by a shooter. The shooter is also a ghost, so that's how he is able to hit you. Ghost shooters are the worst. This happens like every week, too!

meaning_story: There is an insect sliding around under your table from the wind. You try to grab the insect but it keeps sliding past your hand because the wind is so strong. It’s going to start blowing you around under the table too!
meaning_hint: Picture an insect, on it’s back, being blown around under a table. Feel the wind pushing you as you try to save the poor thing. This kanji also means style too. You can think of the wind blowing one style in fashion one moment and then another the next. It blows your clothes off and blows new style clothes onto you, over and over again. Imagine this happening. Are you embarrassed when all the clothes are off? Pleased when you get new style clothes on?
reading_story: The only way you can distract yourself from the wind and the insect sliding around under your table is by eating lots of food (ふう). That’s why you were at the table in the first place. It’s your dining room table and it’s dinner time!
reading_hint: Try to stuff food in your mouth in the wind. Food tastes even better when you have to fight for it!

meaning_story: You say to the cobra (because now you're talking to cobras): 'Hey cobra, I want you to write down what I'm about to say. The cobra pulls out a pen and paper to get ready to write down and record your important message.
meaning_hint: Imagine what it is you say to the cobra. Make sure to remind the cobra to write down what you're saying (because sometimes cobras can be slackers). 'Hey, you writing that down cobra? I want you to record my words accurately, now.'
reading_story: At least one thing you want the cobra to write down is the location of a key (き) that will lead to untold treasures.
reading_hint: You think about this for a moment, realizing that now the cobra knows the location of this key. You'll have to take care of him later.

meaning_story: The radical yellow and the kanji yellow are exactly the same!
reading_story: You're in a room, surrounded completely by yellow. You can't get out. Somewhere in the room is a yellow key (き) but you can't find it, because everything looks the same. You crawl around trying to find this tiny thing so that you can escape.
reading_hint: The Walls are coming in closer, too. Make sure you feel a bit of peril as you look for this key. The walls have a slight opening at the bottom too, so if you don't find it before the wall goes over it, the key will be lost forever, and you'll be smushed!

meaning_story: "Does the bamboo shirt suit me?" you ask... but nobody will answer.
meaning_hint: Shout 'PLEASE ANSWER ME!' a few times to get the idea of 'answer' in your head. What you really want is an answer, whether it's bad or good, but nobody's willing to say anything because you look so terrible.
reading_story: So, instead of a shirt now, you try something else. Maybe a coat (こた) will get you an answer.
reading_hint: You put on this weird bamboo coat. Smell it and feel the texture. How is it? Probably a bit bulky.

meaning_story: The stool is in the cliff. If someone has a stool deep inside a cliff, they are most likely pretty anti society, hiding away like that.
meaning_hint: Imagine someone who looks super antisocial (and a little feral). Ask them why they're sitting on this stool inside a cliff... they reply because they hate people. They are anti people!
reading_story: Turns out, when you go to this guy and pull off his beard, he's Han (はん) Solo, the anti-hero from Star Wars! What is Han doing here, so hidden away? He's obviously hiding from Jabba because he doesn't want to get frozen in carbonite again.
reading_hint: Make sure you get to the point where you pull this anti-social guy's beard off, to reveal Han Solo beneath. Be surprised... not just because he's Han Solo, but because he's real, too! Maybe you can yell out 'Han! Your people need you!'

meaning_story: A wolverine is going down a slide into your mouth. Why is he going into your mouth, though? You're opening it really wide, because you're screaming 'BUDDY!!! You're so excited to see your wolverine buddy-pal again. You thought he was dead.
meaning_hint: Make sure you feel super happy. Even yell 'Buddy' out loud while imagining this wolverine coming at you, if you're not in a quiet-zone.
reading_story: As you're about to embrace your buddy wolverine, a raccoon tackles the wolverine off the slide, preventing your mouth embrace.
reading_hint: RaCCOON! you yell. 'THIS IS NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS. Get out of here.' Feel some hate for the raccoon. He ruined everything.

meaning_story: There’s your nation's flag on top of the cloaked mouth. Why would there be a flag on this cloaked mouth? Because it's the symbol for the 'Bureau of Secret Things.'
meaning_hint: The cloaked mouth represents how this bureau never talks about their secrets. The flag represents your country. Think about all the cool secret things the Bureau of Secret Things must have. Aliens, maybe?
reading_story: The best bit of secret tech they have is the cloaking device. It can cloak you (きょく) with the press of a button.
reading_hint: Now, this mnemonic isn’t perfectly close, but the goal is to get you close enough in your brain so that you can remember きょく later. If you can get to CLOAK YOU, then you can get to きょく much easier than just trying to get there from scratch. So, imagine yourself getting cloaked. What would you do with this power?

meaning_story: Sauron is looking at some clams to buy.
meaning_hint: Have him go through various questions. 'How much are these?' 'Can you go lower on your prices? I have a lot of orcs to feed.' 'Are these ones on sale?' etc. Always make it focused on the buying, though.
reading_story: Some how Sauron goes from trying to buy clams to buying an entire car (か). He drives away in it, forgetting about the clams. Come up with a story about how he ended up buying this car from the clam salesman. Should be ridiculous to help you to remember that the kun'yomi reading for this kanji is か.
reading_hint: The on'yomi for this kanji (which you're not learning with the mnemonic, because it's not as common) just sounds like the word 'buy,' which makes it pretty easy to remember later on, when you need to.

meaning_story: What are rain boobs? They're things that create, produce, and emit rain. I would say those things are the big fluffy things in the sky, also known as clouds.
meaning_hint: Makes sense, if you think about it. Boobs produce milk, clouds produce rain! Kind of a weird comparison, admittedly, but it'll probably help you to remember this kanji pretty well!
reading_story: Let's imagine something besides rain coming out of these clouds though. Imagine a cool mom (くも) falling through the sky towards the earth (or a lot of them). They're all doing things that cool moms do.
reading_hint: Such a strange mnemonic, but くも doesn't lend itself well to mnemonics. Come up with cool things that the cool moms are doing while they fly towards the earth from their clouds. Depending on you, those things will be different, so I want you to make something up here that will help you to remember that these are cool moms (and not anything else!).

meaning_story: The white ice tree is a magical tree. When you eat its ice flowers it gives you incredible amounts of comfort, ease, and pleasure.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself picking the white ice flowers off the tree. Then, put it in your mouth. Make it taste comforting... It puts you at ease. Then, swallow it. Feel your head go nuts with comfort. This is the greatest drug in the world when it comes to comfort. So much pleasure!
reading_story: You want more of this, You gather as much as you can, and create an entire rack (らく) at your store with this tree. You sell out immediately, and have to refill your rack.
reading_hint: Imagine setting up the rack. Make it look beautiful. Shift around the flowers. Fill up the entire rack. Of course, your focus should be on the rack portion.

meaning_story: In the winter, the woman has to go through all the rice and count each individual grain. When you've counted all of them, you'll have an amount / number so that you can split them up accordingly.
meaning_hint: She has to count each grain out in order to divvy up the supply to last through the winter. Imagine yourself getting just a few grains today for food. It's not a good time for you guys :(
reading_story: Why are you so low on rice? It's because someone sued your farm and took everything you owned. So, you had barely enough rice (or not enough).
reading_hint: Come up with a story about why your farm got sued for everything. Go to the court case. Listen to the judge come up with your verdict. Be angry. This has ruined everything.

meaning_story: You have at your disposal a tsunami and a hook to assassinate this person. Which weapon will you choose. Decide now!
meaning_hint: Have trouble with the decision. Which one? Tsunami will be big and cool, but a hook will be more discreet. How can you decide? Can you think of a neat way to decide this, like Two-Face on Batman?
reading_story: To remember the reading けつ we always use the word 'catsup.' You finally decide. You're going to go with the tsunami... but not just any tsunami. You'll kill him with a tsunami of ketsup (けつ).
reading_hint: Get everything ready to take your target down. How will you plan this? Where will you put it? Go ahead and watch your plan unfurl, too.

meaning_story: Using just thread meeting the paper (with a little ink on the end) you create a masterpiece of a drawing (or a painting).
meaning_hint: It's unbelievable the kind of drawing you're able to draw with just the tip of a thread. So much detail. So artistic. If it helps, imagine that you drew the Mona Lisa, better than the original, only using this floppy thread tool.
reading_story: You tell someone that you drew this drawing only using a a thread. Their response? 'EH?!?!?' (え)
reading_hint: Tell a few more people how you drew this. Have them all do the same 'Eh!!??' reaction.

meaning_story: The leader, of course, is a master at something. He's the best of the best, but because he's so good, nobody can find him. Everyone wants to know where he lives. Because of that, you're searching for his dwelling.
meaning_hint: Think about what this leader is a master in. Come up with something crazy but also something that interests you. Also make yourself believe that you want to know where his dwelling is (aka where he lives) more than anything else in the world. Where is his dwelling?
reading_story: You are lucky. You finally find the dwelling of this leader master, and it's not at all what you expected. He lives in a Jewish (じゅう) synagogue. It's quite splendid, too.
reading_hint: Be sure to imagine this place totally over the top. Your master leader is living in a small dorm room somewhere in the basement, which also surprises you.

meaning_story: You're standing in the middle of a rice paddy in the rain with an umbrella. You're standing here because there's nothing else that's very tall around you. You want to get hit by electricity (aka lightning) to show that it exists.
meaning_hint: Get hit by the electricity. How does it feel?
reading_story: After the electricity hits you, you feel your face. In it is a huge dent.
reading_hint: Feel the indent in your face. It doesn't hurt, strangely, but it is pretty huge. Panic about this dent a bit.

meaning_story: This kanji is just the tree radical three times. Just based off this, you should be able to figure it out. This kanji means 'forest.'
meaning_hint: Makes sense, because a bunch of individual trees is what makes up a forest!
reading_story: One tree? No. Two trees? Not enough. I want more (もり) trees, please!
reading_hint: Keep repeating this pattern over and over, continually focusing in on how you need 'more' trees to make this forest. For some reason the person working with you only goes up by one at a time, though, so you have to say it a lot (it'll help you to remember, anyways!).

meaning_story: If you wear a top hat with power it will give YOU the power to help people. You put it on your head and the power it has surges through you, making you a bit of a super hero. And all super heroes help people!
meaning_hint: Imagine a top hat giving you the power to help your family, your next door neighbor, the world!
reading_story: With your newfound helping powers you materialize a jo (じょ) fighting stick in your hands to help get rid of bad guys. You're a helpful super hero with a top hat and a jo!
reading_hint: Imagine helping the townspeople with your jo! Smack the evildoers away!

meaning_story: The horse radical and the horse kanji are exactly the same! Huzzah!
reading_story: You are looking at a horse. It's looking at you. You try making horse noises at it, to get a reaction. Instead of reacting with a normal horse noise, it just makes sheep noises: 'Baaa,' (ば) it says. 'Baaaaa.'
reading_hint: Feel the shock of this. It sounds just like a sheep, it's strange.

meaning_story: Think of a gate that the sun has to go through every time it revolves around in the sky (I know, the sun doesn't move, but let's pretend it's ancient China, okay?). Someone at the gate checks the time, and makes sure the interval is correct, then waves it through the gate for another circling, where it creates its next interval of time.
meaning_hint: Interval is a weird word to remember, but just think of the sun going around the earth and through the gate just like clockwork. Every 24 hours it passes through the gate, and each interval is exactly the same.
reading_story: The interval is perfect... at least, until now. Genghis Khan and his Mongol horde come down on the gate and destroy it, delaying the sun by several hours. Now the interval is all messed up due to the Khans. Time to build a great wall, or something, to protect.
reading_hint: It's not too out there to assume a Khan attacked something Chinese (remember, we're pretending this interval sun gate is Chinese!). That's what Genghis, Kublai, and all the other Khans were known for, after all - attacks on China!

meaning_story: There is a great gravity at this grave. It pulls us in towards it... It obviously wants us to go to a specific location (aka the location where it is).
meaning_hint: This is a really, really general kanji meaning which makes it harder to remember via a mnemonic. Spend a few extra seconds trying to sort this one out in your head before moving on.
reading_story: The location you're being pulled towards is the secret sheep graveyard. You can hear the 'Baa (ば) baa baaaaaa!' noises more clearly the closer you get. It's scary!
reading_hint: The reading for this kanji is actually quite difficult to pinpoint. It uses both on'yomi and kun'yomi readings quite often, and there's no real good rules to figure out when to do which. The kun'yomi reading seems slightly more common, though, which is why we're going with that one. You will, however, have to work a little bit when you get to this kanji's vocab. Just a warning!

meaning_story: You're in a cage and you've been shot by an arrow. Obviously things are looking pretty bad. You need some medicine if you hope to live.
meaning_hint: More specifically, antibiotics. Your wound is festering pretty badly.
reading_story: When we need to remember the sound い we use the word 'Eagle.' You need your medicine really bad. Then, you look up. There's an eagle flying overhead. He has a package. It's medicine! You're saved!
reading_hint: Or, so you think. He just keeps circling and circling. Feel some hate for the eagle. Why isn't he dropping the medicine? You don't have long to live!

meaning_story: There's a cross on both sides of the sun, with the moon off to one side. That's because the religious folk are all about the morning (all those early church sessions!), and everyone else is all about the night (the moon).
meaning_hint: Just think about religious people waking up super early to do their rituals. That's why the crosses are on the sun. That's why they're associated with the morning.
reading_story: But, they're kind of grumpy because they have to wake up early in the morning. So, they're constantly cutting each other off, pushing each other, and being jerks. Imagine all of these people yelling back and forth at each other: 'You ass!' (あさ) a ridiculous amount, then all suddenly becoming quiet when they sit down in the church.
reading_hint: It might help if you think about them all being Italian too. At least when it comes to a stereotypical Italian accent, they'd say something like 'you ass-a hole-a!' If you're Italian, this is probably absolutely how you don't sound.

meaning_story: You have to sickle the rice paddy today because it's your turn. This kanji also means number in a series, which is a lot like a turn. For example, you're number 3, so your turn will be number 3.
meaning_hint: Go through in your mind the system your farm / village uses for deciding who has to sickle on any given day. It rotates, and it's a turn-based system. So, do you all stand in a line? Is there a calendar? Come up with something interesting, focusing on your turn in the process you come up with. It will be helpful to remember both the 'number in a series' and 'turn' meanings for the vocab coming up in the future.
reading_story: This turn-based rice sickle system is a contest as well! But, you are disappointed to find out that you have been banned from the game because of the performance enhancing steroids you've been taking.
reading_hint: Try to feel disappointed by this. Strange thing to feel disappointed by, but you were a great sickler. You were going to win the great prize, too (come up with something huge!), but now you're banned for the season.

meaning_story: You're taking an axe to a door. You're absolutely crazy. 'I HATE THIS PLACE!!' you keep yelling as you smash in the door.
meaning_hint: Why do you hate this place, in particular? Come up with a great reason why to help you to remember this very broad kanji meaning.
reading_story: You finally break through the door and jump in. Inside is a great circus show (しょ). There are elephants, tightrope walkers, bears on unicycles, and more! The greatest show on earth, but why is it here at this place?
reading_hint: Come up with a weird reason as to why the circus is at this place you hate so much. Why did you come here with your axe? Does it have something to do with the circus show?

meaning_story: You've already dug nine holes. You're doing this for your research which requires you to unbury bodies and take them back to your laboratory.
meaning_hint: What kind of research is this? Come up with something disgusting or ridiculous to help you to remember the meaning of this kanji.
reading_story: You dig up the ninth hole. You think you’ve found what you're looking for. Your research could finally be complete... but instead, you find the cutest (きゅう) animal in the world (what is your cutest animal?). It jumps out of the hole and gives you super adorable eyes.
reading_hint: D’awwwww. Go ahead and remember this animal that you use – we’ll use it later with other words that have きゅう as the on’yomi.

meaning_story: At the neck end of the water slide, it becomes a full on road.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself going down a water slide, getting to the neck of it (that's the end). It shoots you out onto pavement where you keep on sliding, except now you're surrounded by terrifying trucks and vehicles. You slide around, avoiding getting hit. It's so strange that you're even on a road in the first place, actually.
reading_story: To remember the reading どう we use the word 'doughnut'. You're going so fast on this road that you don't see the giant doughnut (どう) until the last minute. You crash into it, and both you and the doughnut go tumbling down.
reading_hint: Be sure to feel the last minute panic as you see the giant doughnut in the middle of the road. How did it get here? Also feel, smell, and taste the doughnut as you're tumbling along, crashing. Maybe steal a few bites while you're at it. Mmm, doughnuts.

meaning_story: You're loitering around in Ikea, just waiting for someone to help you. What's up with this terrible service? It's their duty to serve and they're failing terribly.
meaning_hint: While you're at it, imagine yourself writing a review about this Ikea on Yelp (or some other review site). Make the focus of this imaginary review be about the terrible service. Go ahead and make up your own story about how bad the service was, too.
reading_story: Why are you getting such bad service from people who supposedly have great service as their duty? It turns out the employees are all standing around just going 'yak (やく) yak yak yak yak' (that's the sound of people talking, by the way).
reading_hint: Go ahead and mock these employees by saying 'yak yak yak' over their talking. Feel a bit upset about this as well.

meaning_story: You've found yourself a stone lantern. You need a quick way to sharpen your blade so you use it, then catch your sword on fire. Time to go fight again!
meaning_hint: Try to feel the rush of the situation. People are chasing you to cut you down, but your blade is too dull. So, you sharpen it quickly on something normal, like a stone lantern, then rush back into the fight.
reading_story: When you've sharpened your sword, you turn around to do battle. What are you fighting? Several giant ken (けん) dolls.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself doing battle with these human-sized dolls. They're quite good at fighting, despite being made out of plastic. What gives?

meaning_story: The self radical is a bit modified, with things sticking out, but that’s because it’s falling down a slide. Sure, it’s yourself who’s tumbling down the slide… at least that’s how it feels to you. Who are you? What are you? All you know is you’re somebody, but you don’t know who that somebody is.
meaning_hint: Apparently, you’re having some kind of internal crisis. Come up with a rough one and you’ll remember this kanji better.
reading_story: You’re falling down this metaphorical slide… And then you hit something… and you hit it really hard. It’s your metaphorical shin (しん). You split it in half and it’s at a right angle. The pain is incredible (shins have a lot of nerves!). It may have been broken, and you may not be able to walk correctly again… metaphorically speaking, that is.
reading_hint: Just make the tumble and shin hit as painful as possible in your imagination and you’ll surely remember this kanji’s on’yomi.

meaning_story: A coffin has been left out in the sun for too long. When dead bodies are out in the sun like this, they really begin to decompose. You are wondering who this person is, though. You can't tell because it's fallen apart too much. You look on the coffin. There's a label, but it only says 'someone.'
meaning_hint: Smell the stench of the decomposing body. Also, feel really curious as to who this person is. It came from somewhere that gives you a reason to believe it's someone you know. Then, feel the disappointment as you read the label that says 'someone' instead of an actual name. 'Someone,' you repeat. 'Someone.'
reading_story: To remember the sound しゃ we use 'shaman.' It's time you open the coffin and check. Maybe there's more answers in there. There's no way this person could just be 'someone.' You lift the lid, and sure enough, you're able to figure out who it is. It's a shaman (しゃ), dressed in full shaman garb.
reading_hint: How strange that a shaman was delivered to you this way! Come up with a story explaining why this shaman's body is here at your door, rotting in the sun. Make it ridiculous and interesting so you remember it.

meaning_story: The radical suit and the kanji suit are exactly the same! This kanji can also mean join which makes sense. When something suits you well, like a hat or something, it joins together with you quite well too. Join me, my hat! You suit my head well. It just fits, you know?
meaning_hint: Just remember that this 'suit' means 'to suit you' - not the thing you wear, okay!
reading_story: You wear the hat you found out around the town (remember the strange hat with a mouth on it from when you learned the radical 合?). You think it suits you really well, but nobody else agrees. They start screaming. ああああああああ! Well I (あい) think it suits you. So, you know, there's that at least.
reading_hint: Imagine little あ characters coming out of their mouths while they scream to hit home the point that they're screaming あ and not something else. But あい am there too. あい think you look great.

meaning_story: The hard part about learning this kanji is that the radical looks the same but doesn't have the same meaning. So, let's make a story. The frog was all alone (just like in this kanji). Nobody else was there to help him. He had to support the weight of the building to make sure it didn't fall on the elementary school.
meaning_hint: When you think 'frog' you have to automatically think about this story. Embellish and add to it if you want. Make it more ridiculous. Make it more vivid. Whatever you need to do to remember that Frog = support.
reading_story: To remember the reading し, we use the name Charlie 'Sheen.' - Remember the frog from when you learned that this kanji means support? He's holding up an entire building to keep the children safe. Just when you think he's going to succeed, Charlie Sheen jumps on the building, pushing it down until it crushes the frog. He laughs maniacally as he runs off.
reading_hint: Make sure you're rooting for the frog! He's trying to support everything by himself, after all. True underdog story. Then, feel horrified when Sheen makes his appearance, ruining everything the frog ever worked for.

meaning_story: When you say something with your tongue you're obviously talking.
meaning_hint: The logic of this one is almost too good, so don't let that fool you!
reading_story: What (わ) are you talking about? You're talking about walruses.
reading_hint: Or, if you'd like, you can come up with some other 'wa' starting word to use to think about what you're talking about. Just be sure to actually imagine yourself talking about that thing.

meaning_story: You're hitting Ikea furniture with your nailbat, busting it apart. But, this isn't fun enough, so you ask your friend to start throwing it at you so you can hit it in the air.
meaning_hint: Feel the heaviness of the things you're hitting. It probably hurts your hands and arms just because of the mass of the items being thrown at you. Also wonder how your friend got so strong. He's able to throw this furniture as if it were nothing!
reading_story: Then an accident happens. Your friend throws a drawer set at you, and you smash it to bits... but, the drawer was full of nails (な) that fly out and hit you in the face.
reading_hint: Feel all the nails hitting you. There's so many of them and you try to pull them out. Why did your friend throw that ikea furniture at you?

meaning_story: You have this doll and you need to get a measurement of it. But, you have to get a measurement faster than your opponent. It's you versus that crazy lady over there.
meaning_hint: Imagine something like an advertisement for a cage match showing. The part that stands out big time is the word 'Vs.' in the center, between your faces. Also note how ridiculous this battle is. You're measuring dolls...
reading_story: Why are you measuring dolls versus this crazy lady? It's because you need to know how big to make the tie that you'll be putting on it.
reading_hint: Stick a little tie on that doll of yours. Is it pretty looking? Did you measure right? How is it versus your opponent's?

meaning_story: You’re sitting on a stool and someone cleats you in the forehead as part of an acceptance ritual. It’s for the most prestigious Spanish soccer club in the world. You got knocked off the stool, and the cleats really hurt your forehead, but you’re just glad to have been accepted. This kanji also means receive, which is quite similar in idea to accept. Shouldn't be too hard to remember because of the similarities.
meaning_hint: You’re dealing with a lot of mixed emotions right now. You feel the pain from being cleated in the forehead and knocked clean off your stool, but you’re also glad to have finally been accepted into the soccer club. Suppress your pain. Accept this honor like a man.
reading_story: After you got kicked, the club leader shouts “Uno (う) mas!” Knowing this means “one more” in Spanish, you now realize that they plan to cleat you in the forehead at least one more time as part of this demented acceptance ritual. Why couldn’t they have just stopped at uno?
reading_hint: Imagine the anxiety and fear you’d be feeling knowing you’re about to get cleated in the forehead again. Will they stop at dos? Tres? You pray to God they don’t say uno mas anymore.

meaning_story: You're brushing your mouth with a cross shaped thing. You're doing the action of this brushing over and over hoping to summon Jesus, who will help to solve the matter of your cavities.
meaning_hint: Imagine having this strange thing poking you in your gums, tongue, and cheeks. It’s not pleasant. That thing is spiky! What is this thing? How will this action summon Jesus to perform a miracle on your teeth?
reading_story: You try the special action out. You brush in a cross pattern, and *poof* Jesus (じ) appears in your mirror, blessing you and your teeth. 'Jesus, you're here!' you say through your toothpaste filled mouth.
reading_hint: Imagine Jesus touching your teeth and removing the cavities. What a swell dude.

meaning_story: A beast king with big horns marries a true beauty. The big horned king may look like a beast, but the beauty loves him for what’s inside. That is where true beauty lies.
meaning_hint: I’m sure you know of The Beauty and the Beast. Remember that movie? Think of the king and his big horns. And remember the beauty that loved him.
reading_story: Beauty and the who? Beauty and the Beast (び). The Beast. That’s right. Beauty and the Beast! How could you forget?
reading_hint: It’s a Disney movie. Everyone knows about it. How many times have you seen it? Remember the movie Beauty and the Beast.

meaning_story: This kanji uses the radicals mama (which you for sure know) and nail (though this nail radical is modified). Instead of being a regular nail, it's a nail made up of two barbs (that's twice as dangerous!). Your mama has this double-dangerous nail. She made sure to remove it from your play area beforehand, to prevent you from sticking it in your dirty little mouth.
meaning_hint: Basically, what you have to remember here is that mom was taking away nails in advance of something. You know, beforehand.
reading_story: She took away the barbed nail beforehand because she knew you'd hurt yourself. You were upset about losing this amazing looking toy, but she gives you a yo-yo (よ) to play with instead, making you very happy.
reading_hint: Compare the two things in your mind (the yo-yo and the nail). Which one is better? Weight it out. Think about it. Then, hopefully you come to the decision that the yo-yo is better. Go ahead and play with the yo-yo for a bit too. Should help you to remember it.

meaning_story: If you give a woman a machine she'll begin learning how to use it right away. She'll also get it to start before you or I could. Women are really good at starting up new machines!
meaning_hint: Picture a woman seeing a new machine and beginning work on it right away to see how she can start it up. It's so exciting!
reading_story: Actually, before the woman can begin she has to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Only then can her work with the machine begin. It's still really fast though!
reading_hint: Visualize this journey in your head. It is a great undertaking, but think of what great sights the woman will see on her journey to Mecca and imagine how proud she will feel upon arrival. She has to begin this journey before she can begin to tell you how to use this machine.

meaning_story: The Moon Stamp is laying on your stool. The giant moon reminds you of something... it reminds you that you have to take off all your clothes to moon the world, so you do it.
meaning_hint: Fake an epiphany in your imagination about this moon stamp sitting there. Compare the moon stamp to your butt, then realize in order to do this you have to take off your clothes.
reading_story: As you tear your clothes off to moon the world you scream 'F*#$ YOU ふく, WORLD!!! AHHHAHAHAHAH!'
reading_hint: Of course, if you're not familiar with the word that has all the symbols in it, you'll just have to remember the reading of this word straight up.

meaning_story: You see a hick sitting on a stool and go over to say hi. They don't respond. They're just propped up on the stool. You touch their forehead and realize they're like 105 degrees Fahrenheit! That'll kill a hick! This is a very strange occurrence, you think. Which is convenient since that's the second meaning for this kanji!
meaning_hint: Sitting on a stool is not what you should be doing when you have a fever of over 100 degrees! Even a hick should know that!
reading_story: As you stare at the 100 degrees Fahrenheit hick, a dog (ど) runs out of no where and bites them! It drags the sick hick out of your sight. You've never seen such an occurrence before!
reading_hint: Now you know that if your fever goes over 100 degrees a dog will come get you. Better keep an eye on those degrees next time you're sick.

meaning_story: Once you remove the lantern from the tent, we will be ready for departure. We can’t leave the lantern inside of the tent, that’s a fire hazard. We’d best take it with us before the departure. Don’t you agree?
meaning_hint: Feel the heat from the lantern. It’s not quite as comforting as being inside a tent, but it’s better than nothing. The lantern will light your way on your departure.
reading_story: Oh! Don’t forget your hats (はつ) either. Wouldn’t want to start a departure without hats or a lantern. That’d be a short journey.
reading_hint: How cold and unprotected would your head be without a hat? Very. Taking hats along with departures is integral to their success. Imagine how unsafe you would feel with no hats. That’s no departure I want to set out on.

meaning_story: If you see a helmet on a coat rack you have to determine who put it there. No one in your house looks like a soldier. So whose is it. You will determine whose it is by following the clues, of course!
meaning_hint: Imagine staring at a helmet on your coat rack and trying to determine how it got there and whose it is.
reading_story: You're determined to determine whose helmet this is! You pick it up and there's a tater (てい) tot inside it! Okay, you think you can determine whose helmet it is now. Probably the guy who brought the tater tots to your house.
reading_hint: You determined that this helmet belongs to no other than the guy who brought tater tots to your party! Now you don't have to keep staring at it!

meaning_story: If you say there’s a fire, but there really isn’t one, you’re going to have to discuss why you did such a thing once the fire department gets there. The chief fireman is not going to be happy with you.
meaning_hint: Why would you say there was a fire when there really wasn’t one? How shameful. You should feel ashamed about this. Feel bad for what you have done.
reading_story: The fireman chief has finally arrived to discuss your transgression. What is his name? Dan (だん). His name is Dan. And Dan is not happy with you.
reading_hint: Picture Dan’s screaming face. Feel the spittle spraying on your face as he screams at you for saying there was a fire when there really wasn’t. This isn’t so much a discussion as it is a good old fashioned tongue lashing. But hey, you deserve it.

meaning_story: A swift kick in the pants will damage your life and cause you to express much agony. Being kicked down there hurts, and one of the worst things in life. You can hardly express the pain you feel.
