To help mull things over, the narwhal busts out his xylophone (ざい) and starts playing a haunting melody. The xylophone notes waft eerily about the deserted graveyard.
reading_hint: Hear the plinky plink of the xylophone as you wander through the graveyard. The narwhal is playing the xylophone with the same stick he was using to poke the graves.

meaning_story: The fly radical and the fly kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!
reading_story: When you fly, you generate a lot of heat (ひ) because you’re moving so fast through the atmosphere. Normally this heat would be a nuisance, but you’re a superhero so it doesn’t bother you. This is actually the reason you’re able to fly – you’re a superhero and super resistant to heat.
reading_hint: You’re flying through the air super fast. Feel the air rushing past you as heat builds up all over your body from rocketing through the air so fast.

meaning_story: You stand on the Cliff of Life and give birth to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it!
meaning_hint: The baby is falling off the cliff! Imagine the sheer terror you feel as the baby plummets to the ground below.
reading_story: You give birth, and now this happens. Such bad luck. But wait! What's that sound? Sleigh bells? Could it be?! It's Santa-san (さん)! He caught your baby!
reading_hint: Oh Santa-san. You're always here for me when I need you most. Even when I'm giving birth to your child.

meaning_story: Sauron has performed many an injustice in his day and now he is starting to feel the guilt. Before, Sauron felt no guilt when committing an injustice, but now he’s starting to feel bad about the way he’s been behaving.
meaning_hint: See Sauron sulking and feeling guilty. He’s just moping about, consumed by guilt, looking for something he can do to make things right.
reading_story: Eventually, Sauron decides to erase his guilt by bringing joy to the world through music. As such, Sauron takes up the xylophone (ざい) and goes on a world-wide “Right the Injustice” tour. It’s a solo xylophone tour, but Sauron is actually a pretty mean xylophone player, so it works.
reading_hint: Now imagine Sauron on stage and playing a xylophone. He’s surprisingly lithe for a guy in full armor and he’s playing that xylophone beautifully. Hear the notes in your ears as he plays away.

meaning_story: The hole radical and the hole kanji are exactly the same! Spectacular!
reading_story: Ana (あな) fell into a hole. Laugh at Ana and her unfortunate misfortune of having fallen into a hole like a ninny. Haha, Ana – you’re stupid and clumsy!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself laughing at Ana while you point at her, continuing to jeer as Ana struggles to escape the hole. You’d help Ana out of the hole, but you’re too busy laughing at her.

meaning_story: If a pelican loses its skin, it could very well incur death. Having skin is pretty essential to living, especially for a pelican. A pelican with no skin will definitely incur a lot of pain, if not death.
meaning_hint: Picture this pelican with no skin. It’s just a pelican skeleton with its skin and feathers littering the ground beneath it. Its blood and guts are oozing out from between its little pelican ribs.
reading_story: But how did this pelican lose its skin in the first place? The pelican was shot with a heat (ひ) ray. The shooter just expected the pelican to incur minor burns, but instead the heat melted off all of the pelican’s skin.
reading_hint: Now smell the smell of the cooking pelican. The heat from the heat gun is roasting it. It smells like grilled chicken. Feel your mouth watering as the smell of cooked meat fills the air.

meaning_story: An old tribal leader has a mouth decorated with tiny gems encrusted on each individual tooth. Every year that he is leader, he gets a new mouth adornment. He’s very old and has been leader for quite some time, so each individual tooth in his mouth is quite well decorated.
meaning_hint: Picture this old leader. He looks pretty normal and unassuming. And then he smiles. His mouth shines so brightly with each individual gem catching the sunlight and reflecting it back into your eyes. Squint as you marvel at the sight of this shiny mouth of his.
reading_story: This old individual really wishes he could be a 子 (こ) again. Being old has taken a toll on his body, and he yearns to be a 子 once again.
reading_hint: Imagine you are this old individual, wishing to be a 子 again. Imagine your body feeling younger and more spry the more you think about it.

radicals: 人, 木, 幺, 戈
meaning_story: A drunkard is the kind of person who would poop two times under a tree before using a machine toilet. There’s a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.
meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard, squatting down under the tree to poop. You can smell the poop and a faint stench of alcohol in the air. How could he not have realized that there was a portable machine toilet right there?
reading_story: Oh, I see – the door to the outhouse with the machine toilet is locked, and the drunkard doesn’t have the key (き). If he had a machine like a jackhammer, or a circular saw, or some other heavy duty machine, he might be able to get in without a key, but since he has none of those or a key, he’s reduced to pooping under the tree instead.
reading_hint: Listen to the drunkard grumbling about the lack of a key as he poops under the tree. He doesn’t sound happy, and every time he stresses to push out the poop, his voice fluctuates. Imagine hearing this in your mind and being a wee bit disgusted.

meaning_story: A woman moving in one direction will obstruct any other women coming from the other direction. Women are very stubborn, so when a woman decides she is going one direction, she will obstruct anything from getting past her or changing her course.
meaning_hint: Picture this woman, obstructing your path. She’s fuming and furious and won’t let anyone past her. Imagine how angry she looks and how terrified you are of her. It’s scary.
reading_story: Since this woman decided to obstruct the path here, you need to figure out how to get past. Probably the best idea is to throw a bowling (ぼう) ball at her. Bowling balls are heavy, so that will be sure to get her out of the way. Just throw a bowling ball in her direction.
reading_hint: Now imagine that you are the woman. Feel the bowling ball hit you in the stomach as it crushes your ribs and knocks you back. Bowling balls hurt.

meaning_story: A leader gets put in a boob grave after shattering his ribs and dying in an attempt to overthrow the government. The leader wanted to go from a democracy to a dictatorship so he was trying to overthrow the other parts of government. However, he did not succeed, broke all his ribs, and was laid to rest in a boob grave (a grave for people who are boobs).
meaning_hint: Picture this leader trying to overthrow the rest of the government and failing miserably. Hear the sound of his ribs cracking and crunching as he is defeated.
reading_story: This leader was attempting to overthrow the government of Tokyo (とう). Little did he know that everyone in the Tokyo government was a ninja, so the leader was defeated.
reading_hint: Picture the fight. The leader busts into the government offices in Tokyo only to be taken down by these Tokyo ninja warriors. This leader deserves to be put in a boob grave. Everybody knows Tokyo's government officials are all ninjas.

meaning_story: Tying a thread to a tombstone each year will help you manage the passage of time. That way you’ll know how many years it has been since you’ll have one thread for each year. This will help you manage.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself tying a piece of thread to this tombstone each year. Whose tombstone is it? Imagine that person dead and you’re trying to manage their death.
reading_story: The tombstone is actually for your great uncle. He was a member of the KKK (けい). Through the passage of time, you got more and more accustomed to him being stuck in the racist ways of the KKK. Just when you thought you could finally manage having him over for dinner, he dropped dead. Now you’ll never get to learn about his KKK ways.
reading_hint: Picture your great uncle as a KKK member. Now he’s dead. What caused his death? Was it accidental, or murderous? Imagine what could have happened.

meaning_story: Sitting on the lid of a toilet, an explosion of poop erupts out, getting feces on your cross necklace and a large percent of your clothing. You were just trying to chill out, sitting on the lid of the toilet, and an explosion of poop just flew out the toilet bowl. Now you have poop all over you, like ninety-nine percent of your body is covered in poop. Even your cross necklace.
meaning_hint: This feels disgusting. Imagine yourself being covered in poop. Feel the warm smelly sludge covering your body as the abysmal aroma wafts up into your nostrils. You’re nearly one hundred percent covered in poop.
reading_story: You’re emotionally scarred, so you need to eat your comfort food in order to calm yourself down. Your comfort food is Ritz (りつ) crackers, so you clean one hundred percent of the poop off you so your body is now zero percent covered by poop, and you start to devour a box of Ritz crackers.
reading_hint: Now that the percent of your body covered in poop has reached zero, you can comfortably eat. Imagine yourself eating these Ritz crackers as you slowly start to feel better about life. Taste their buttery crispness as they crumble in your mouth.

meaning_story: Atop a cliff lie many grave stones which exert a lot of downward pressure on the cliff itself. There are tons and tons of grave stones on the cliff and the pressure is getting to be too much for the cliff to bear.
meaning_hint: Imagine how this cliff must feel. What if you had a whole bunch of grave stones piled up on top of you? Feel the pressure on top of you with all these grave stones pressing down.
reading_story: Near this cliff you see the lovable Star Wars character, R2-D2 (あつ). He’s just beep booping along when suddenly the cliff can’t take the pressure any longer and just blows up from the pressure. R2-D2 is caught in the cliff explosion and is smashed to pieces.
reading_hint: Picture R2-D2 getting blasted with rocks from the blast. Hear him beeping and booping in pain as he’s pelted with stones.

meaning_story: The butcher runs in your direction to prevent you from eating some bad meat. The butcher did not put his stamp of approval on what you are about to eat, and must prevent you from eating an inferior meal.
meaning_hint: See this butcher barreling in your direction. He’s wielding a butcher knife, so he appears scary, but he really just wants to prevent you from having a subpar dining experience.
reading_story: Actually, you’re dining at a fancy bowling (ぼう) alley. While the butcher is running your direction in an attempt to prevent you from eating that steak, he trips and falls, sliding down one of the lanes. He slides all the way down and crashes into the bowling pins, which prevent him from sliding any further.
reading_hint: Hear the crash of the bowling pins as they topple over from the butcher sliding into them. Poor guy, he was only trying to look out for you.

meaning_story: One should wash one’s self with a big bar of soap if they’re stinking up every place they go. If you find yourself stinking, do everyone a favor and wash yourself with a big loofa and some body wash.
meaning_hint: Smell yourself stinking up the room. Your acrid stench permeates everything around you. You stink, you stinking stinker.
reading_story: You are John Cusack (くさ), and you are stinking up the room. For such a famous actor as Mr. Cusack, you’d think you’d know when to wash up. But no, you are John Cusack and you are a stinking mess.
reading_hint: Imagine John Cusack in your mind. Now imagine him with stink lines coming off of him because he’s so stinky. Imagine how bad he smells.

meaning_story: Regardless of whether or not you wear a hat while you jackhammer, you’re going to have a surplus of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.
meaning_hint: The hat you’re wearing is ridiculous, giving you a surplus of bad style. Imagine a bunch of people scowling at you, not only because of your crazy hat, but because of the annoying sound of the jackhammer. Hear the obnoxious noise around you as the jackhammer rattles your bones.
reading_story: One of the people walking by is the owner of a push cart yo-yo (よ) stand. Having a surplus of yo-yos, he starts throwing them at you. This makes you stop using the jackhammer as you need both hands to fend off the yo-yo barrage.
reading_hint: Your hat is doing little to defend you from the onslaught of yo-yos being tossed at you. Feel the yo-yos hitting your body and listen to them roll away after striking you.

meaning_story: You see a flag stuck in the ground with a little bit of fur coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a tail. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.
meaning_hint: What kind of animal could it be? You start to feel the soft fur with your hand and then the stench of death hits your nostrils. Ew.
reading_story: You try to pull the flag out of the ground and hear a rumbling buzzing sound. At the end of the flagpole you see a huge beehive (び)! These bees made their home under the tail! Maybe that’s why the flag was sticking in it… to warn people. Oops.
reading_hint: See the bees swarming out from around the tail and toward your face. Run! Run before there’s nothing left of you but your own tail!

meaning_story: They say that a roof can hold over one bazillion books – it’s just a theory though. This theory hasn’t actually been tested, it’s just something they say. Can a roof really hold over one bazillion books? Is the roof strong enough to support that many books? We may never know.
meaning_hint: See yourself trying to prove this theory. You’ve gathered up one bazillion books and now you’re stacking them atop the roof. Feel the bindings as you stack them on the roof, breeze causing the pages to flap and flutter in the wind.
reading_story: Your name is Ron (ろん), Ron Weasley. Your friends at Hogwarts dared you to try and prove this theory, so now you’re putting the theory to the test. Ron Weasley never turns down a dare.
reading_hint: See yourself as Ron Weasley, atop the roof of Hogwarts, piling up over one bazillion books to see if the roof can support them. Hopefully the roof does support the books, otherwise you’re going to be in a lot of trouble, Ron.

meaning_story: Hanging off the edge of a cliff is a sun worshipping child with a thick unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries at the sun for cursing him to this cruel fate. Even the thickness of his unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to pull himself back up.
meaning_hint: I mean, this unibrow is really, really thick. So thick it doesn’t even look real. But it is. It’s really real and really thick.
reading_story: The child's thick unibrow can't wait any longer and gives up. It hops off the child's face and says, "Hey dude, I'll be at Sue's (あつ). She'll appreciate my thick, luxuriousness more than a weakling like you.
reading_hint: I guess if you want to go see that thick, beautiful unibrow you'll have to go see it at Sue's now. What's that? Oh, don't worry about the child. It uh. It's probably at Sue's too! Maybe... (or dead).

meaning_story: On the ground, holding a brush, is the woman who is your wife. You’re playing hide and seek with your wife and she chose to hide on the ground. Being a woman, she can’t go anywhere without her brush, so she’s taken that with her.
meaning_hint: Imagine your wife hiding on the ground outside. Also, she’s brushing her hair with that brush. This wife of yours sure cares about her looks.
reading_story: Your wife isn’t very good at the hiding part of hide and seek though. Wanna know why? She’s a Cyclops (さい). A really big one. She can’t hide anywhere. You easily spot your Cyclops wife hiding on the ground.
reading_hint: Now picture your wife again. She’s a Cyclops with long flowing hair. See her brushing it as her one eye darts around frantically.

meaning_story: The modified life of a clam is to blame for the current generation. Clams used to live normal lives, but once the young clams started to modify life and their way of living, the clam youth has turned to rubbish. This modified life of the clam is to blame for the downturn in clam society.
meaning_hint: Think of this modified life of the clams that is to be blamed for the downturn of society. Picture these clams wearing gang clothes like colored bandanas, tank-tops, and tattoos while they carry and shoot their guns. (Remember it’s a modified life as the life radical in this kanji is slightly modified.)
reading_story: These clams also go to clam strip clubs to ogle sexy (せき) clam girls. These sexy strip clubs are to blame for increased clam teen pregnancy because the clams get so sexually charged by the sexy clam girls at the sexy clam strip clubs that they can’t help but get sexy with each other.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in one of these sexy clam strip clubs. See the sexy clam girls as they twist around the sexy stripper poles. What are they wearing? What music is playing? Try and imagine this scene in your mind.

meaning_story: In winter, a tree writes up a governing clause for how the tree federation should behave in the winter. The clause states that all trees must be willing to be cut down for Christmas trees and firewood.
meaning_hint: This clause drafted by the tree is a very bold clause. Imagine you are a tree. How do you feel knowing that you could be cut down at a moment’s notice? It’s a scary thing to be a tree in winter.
reading_story: In reality, the tree that drafted this clause is actually Joseph (じょう) Stalin. Joseph Stalin drafted this clause disguised as a tree to make sure there were enough willing trees to become Christmas trees and firewood for all of Russia.
reading_hint: Imagine clever Joseph Stalin dressed up as a tree and drafting a clause. See him blending in with the other trees as he wears his costume and writes up the clause.

meaning_story: If you see a tsunami coming at you on stilts, you know the world is about to come to an end. A tsunami is tall enough as it is, put one on stilts though, and you know things are coming to an end. That tsunami is going to wreck everything.
meaning_hint: Imagine a tsunami. Now imagine one on stilts. It’s like, infinity times more frightening. Be afraid of this gigantic tsunami as it looks over you, dripping water down onto your face.
reading_story: Just when you thought the world was about to come to an end, a Cyclops (さい) on stilts runs into the picture and tackles the tsunami on stilts. The Cyclops has saved the day by defeating the tsunami!
reading_hint: So the world won’t come to an end after all. See the Cyclops charging at the tsunami, roaring all the way. Once it crashed into the wave, water droplets sprinkle down from the sky soaking you and everything around.

meaning_story: In a forest of pine trees, a woman starts a committee to preserve them. The pine trees in this particular forest are in danger of being cut down, so this woman must start a committee to save them.
meaning_hint: Imagine this woman sitting at a desk in the middle of a pine forest. She’s on the committee for saving them so she works right in the middle of them. Hear her typing on her keyboard and answering phone calls as birds chirp all around her.
reading_story: Speaking of birds, part of the reason she started this committee was to save the pines, but another was to save the eagles (い) that live in the pines. Eagles call this forest their home so it is important that the trees don’t get cut down.
reading_hint: Hear the sound of eagles screeching overhead as they fly about the pine forest. They have no idea that a committee is being formed for them. Look up at them as they fly. Oops, one just pooped in your eye.

meaning_story: Most people have a few, but you only have one eye and need to conserve it. In this world, most people have three eyes, but you only have one eye. Only a few other people like you have only one eye, but since it’s your last one, you need to conserve it to preserve your ability to see.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself with only one eye, being very careful to conserve its safety. You always wear protective eyewear wherever you go. Imagine what depth perception is like with only one eye as you feel the protective eyewear strapped to your head.
reading_story: You lost your eye when it was stabbed out by the shogun (しょう) himself. You foolishly challenged the shogun to a duel, and he beat you handily. In order to conserve some of your dignity, he stabbed out one of your eyes instead of killing you, so that one day you might redeem yourself.
reading_hint: Imagine walking around with your one eye. Curse the shogun for what he has done to you. You almost wish he had just killed you right then and there. The humiliation is almost too much to bear.

meaning_story: The slowly dying (which is why it's missing a line in the radical) life of two face is in your hands... literally. You hold his ribs in your hands. 'Please, please put them back,' he pleads. You could if you wanted to. You have complete control right now over him.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself thinking about this. Do you want to? Or do you not? Maybe you can use this control over him and get him to do something for you? Perhaps you can control him into killing the Batman? Hmm yessss....
reading_story: You decide to control Two Face and put his ribs back in. Instead of having him kill the Batman, though, you ask him to kill Hard Gay. Just before you can put the ribs back, Hard Gay jumps into the room you're in (as if he knew!) and thrusts his hips into your hands, knocking the ribs away. SEI (せい) SEI SEI!
reading_hint: Oh no! Thwarted again by that blasted Hard Gay! What a superhero.

meaning_story: A nailbat can be useful when you compare criticism to praise. Hitting a person in the face with a nailbat is something that will be met with criticism, not praise.
meaning_hint: Feel yourself smashing someone’s face with a nailbat. This person didn’t deserve what you did, so you’re sure to face fierce criticism for your acts. Hear the man’s scream as blood spews forth from his features.
reading_story: The blood from the nailbat wound sprays onto your body. It’s very warm and you can feel the heat (ひ) from the fresh blood. Feel this heat as the blood trickles down the length of your body. You’re insane, and you’re going to face a lot of criticism for doing what you done did.
reading_hint: Again, feel this blood moving down your body and feel the heat coming off of it.

meaning_story: A lion harvesting rice uses an axe to cut off the tops of the stalks. The lion is roaming the rice fields using his axe to harvest the rice. He does so by cutting off the part of the rice stalks he needs.
meaning_hint: Picture this lion on his hind legs, walking through a rice field. He’s holding an axe in one hand and acting like a human. See him cut off the plants and hear the whoosh of the axe as he cuts.
reading_story: This lion’s name is Dan (だん). He’s Dan the harvesting lion man. He swings his might axe to cut off the rice for harvest. Dan is the best lion farmer in the history of ever.
reading_hint: See Dan in his farmer’s uniform. He even has the name Dan embroidered on his jacket. See Dan frolick through the rice fields as he swings his axe about merrily.

meaning_story: Both a leader and a king have a duty to protect their people. A good leader always protects his followers, and a good king always protects his subjects. This is their duty.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself being protected by your king and leader. They don’t really like you, but it is their duty to protect you. See them fighting off evil doers and taking bullets for your sake.
reading_story: You’re the village nincompoop (にん), but the king and the leader still have a duty to protect you. Even a nincompoop is important to the kings and leaders of the world.
reading_hint: You’re a nincompoop. Even though you’re so nincompoopy, your king and leader still have a duty to protect you. Feel happy and content, despite your nincompoopery.

meaning_story: The life thread is an element essential to all living things. This thread of life joins all things together, providing an essential relationship between all life. This element is all that holds this world together.
meaning_hint: Visualize this invisible thread of life, interconnecting all living things. Without this element in our world, everything would fall apart and into chaos.
reading_story: But how do you feel about this thread? You think it's just so-so (そ). The element known as life isn't all that big of a deal. But what can you make out of this thread? You can create a suit (す) made exclusively from this thread. It’s the most impressive suit of all time. Far more impressive than that thread that was just so-so.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself wearing this exquisite suit. Feel the so-so thread in your hands. How could such a so-so thing like this thread turn into such an awesome suit? Skill.

meaning_story: Seeing a mohawk in the winter means the enemy is nearby. You are from the dreadlock tribe and the mohawk tribe is your enemy. You’re deep in the heart of battle and winter has fallen. Now is the time to take out the enemy.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself holed up in a winter encampment, waiting to strike at the mohawk wearing enemies. Feel the cold around you as you scan the horizon for mohawks.
reading_story: You’re kind of a techie (てき), so you have an advantage over your enemy. You’re armed with night vision goggles and other cool tech gear as well. Being a techie certainly has its advantages.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself all teched out like the techie you are. Hear the beeps and boops of all the technology you have at your disposal as you search for more mohawk enemies.

meaning_story: If you say "IKEA" an IKEA will be established in your neighborhood the next year.
meaning_hint: You try it out. You say "IKEA" and sure enough, an IKEA falls from the sky and establishes itself next to you.
reading_story: You go into the IKEA you've established. It's great, everything comes in sets (せつ). Chairs, tables, everything! Sets sets sets sets sets.
reading_hint: You say the word "IKEA" again, and it creates another IKEA. Now IKEA can come in sets.

meaning_story: You should say your peace before you evaluate a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say your peace before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand.
meaning_hint: What situation would you like to evaluate? Be sure to say your peace before doing so. Imagine yourself doing this out loud and think of what you would say.
reading_story: While you say your peace, you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “Heyo!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to evaluate who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!”once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself trying to explain a situation you’re about to evaluate and your audience keeps shouting “Heyo!” every other sentence. Imagine how frustrating that would be. Get angry at your rude audience and how much they shout “Heyo.”

meaning_story: A tree is something a squid will never examine. The squid lives in the ocean. The tree lives above water on land. Therefore, the squid will never get close enough to a tree to examine it.
meaning_hint: Examine this squid. See into his mind and experience his sadness at never being able to examine a tree in his life. How saddening.
reading_story: However, Ken (けん) from Street Fighter reaches into the sea and rips the squid out of the water, marches it over to a tree and throws the squid at it shouting “Hadoken!” Ken has brought this squid to a tree and now the squid is free to examine it.
reading_hint: Unfortunately the squid can’t live without water, so it soon dies. See Ken sobbing and crying once he realizes what a foolish thing he has done.

meaning_story: You have a scene going on inside your head. It is of a pair of horns on the ground atop a mountain. No. It is not just one pair of horns. It is many. So many that they create a giant hill atop the mountain, which is already pretty high.
meaning_hint: Imagine this hill of horns on top of this mountain. This hill of horns makes it possible for you to get just high enough to touch the top of the sky.
reading_story: How was standing atop this hill of horns on top of a mountain to touch the sky? Eh. It was okay (おか), but that's about it.
reading_hint: Feel indifferent about this hill of horns on top of the mountain. It's all in your head anyways.

meaning_story: Near a grave you put on a mask to increase the fear felt by others who see you. Graves are kind of scary as it is, but somebody with a mask on will only increase the fear felt.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing someone in a mask by a grave. Your feelings of unease would probably increase, right? Feel your anxiety increasing as you see this creepy guy in a mask hovering over a grave.
reading_story: To increase his zone (ぞう) of terror, this creepy dude puts on an even bigger mask which makes his zone of influence that much larger. How much can the terror increase?
reading_hint: Visualize this in your head. The mask he is wearing is increasing in size at an alarming rate, increasing the zone of horror as it grows. Feel fear as this terrifyingly large mask looms over you.

meaning_story: If a tree is growing out of a top hat you need to inspect it to find out why and how this happened. You should probably investigate the area too. I mean, how could a tree grow out of a top hat anyway? Seems suspicious.
meaning_hint: Inspect the tree. Inspect the top hat. Did you find anything?
reading_story: In the middle of your inspection you realize you need to saw (さ) the tree open to come to a good conclusion. This seems a bit unnecessary, but no! No! For the sake of this investigation you must saw the tree in half!
reading_hint: Imagine stopping to inspect the tree after each minute of sawing. You'll find out why it's growing out of a top hat! Eventually!

meaning_story: When half of your ribs are gone, I have the right to judge your addiction to bone amputations. One or two was okay, but removing half of your ribs? I’m going to judge you for that. You’re weird and strange and everybody is going to judge you.
meaning_hint: Imagine you had half your ribs removed for no reason. Everyone would judge you as there was no good reason for you doing so. Imagine how strange your body would feel if you were missing half your ribs.
reading_story: There’s perhaps only one way for people not to judge you for having half your ribs removed. That would be if you were Han (はん) Solo. Han Solo is so cool that nobody would ever judge him for doing anything. Also, keep in mind that this kanji contains 半, and also shares its reading. How helpful!
reading_hint: Picture Han Solo missing half his ribs. You feel the need to start judging him, but he’s just so cool you can’t bring yourself to do it. Imagine Han Solo awkwardly running around without half his ribs, shooting his gun and yelling at Chewbacca to fire up the engines on the Millennium Falcon.

meaning_story: A helmet with a number on it identifies which judge you are talking to. In this world, all judges have to wear special helmets with numbers on them while they judge you so they can be identified. The helmets protect their little judge heads and the numbers are to make sure no one mixes them up.
meaning_hint: See this judge wearing his judge helmet as he pounds his judicial gavel for order. Think of what you did to end up in this court of his.
reading_story: Apparently this judge is not happy with you. He decides to judge you with violence. He leaps out from behind his stand while clutching his gavel and smashes you in the shin (しん) with it. “Criminal!” he shouts as he knocks you in the other shin. “You deserve to die!”
reading_hint: Your shin really hurts. Why would this judge hit you in the shin? Did he go crazy? Feel how badly each of your shins hurt from being struck by this mad judge.

meaning_story: The leader of the cow tribe is too important to deal with small matters and trivial affairs. The cow leader had his underlings take care of such affairs and matters. The cow leader is above such things.
meaning_hint: Picture this hoity-toity cow leader who thinks he’s too good for small matters and affairs. See him acting all fancy like he’s better than everyone else. The cow even moos with a fake British accent. How pretentious.
reading_story: The latest affair that the cows have had to deal with is Ken (けん) the farmer. As a cow farmer, he obviously wants to slaughter all the cows to harvest their meat.
reading_hint: Imagine the cows getting together and trying to figure out a solution to this whole mess. Imagine drawings and diagrams of Ken the farmer. Also imagine the Cow leader sitting off to the side, thinking he's too important to help with these matters and affairs.

meaning_story: A butcher goes in his tent to get a jackhammer for the occasion. The occasion is that he has to butcher a rock animal. No butcher knife will butcher this rock beast, so the butcher must use a jackhammer from his tent.
meaning_hint: Watch as this butcher uses a jackhammer to butcher this animal on this special rock animal feast occasion. Hear the jackhammer rattling about as the butcher carves the beast.
reading_story: In this particular occasion, the butcher is a mighty Cyclops (さい). He actually slayed the rock beast himself, and now the Cyclops butcher is carving it up with his mighty jackhammer.
reading_hint: See this Cyclops butcher as he continues to carve the beast with his one eye. Continue to hear the jackhammer ringing in your ears as you watch the Cyclops butcher do his work.

meaning_story: The hat comes to a stop, thinking of a plan. The hat had been pacing around for a while, trying to think of how to get off the head he's resting upon and back into the house where it's nice and cozy, and came to the sudden realization of a plan. This caused the hat to stop.
meaning_hint: Imagine a hat walking about on your head, pacing back and forth deep in thought. See the hat stroke its chin in contemplation as it tries to think up a plan to get off your noggin and back inside.
reading_story: The plan that made this hat stop right in its tracks was very simple. First, obtain the key (き) to the house. Then, use the key to get in the front door. How simple!
reading_hint: Watch as the hat begins to grin. This plan is so simple it’s sure to work. Now watch as the hat obtains the key and enters the locked door. What sort of mischief will the hat get into once inside?

meaning_story: If there’s grass on the ground and fins in your hand, you need to raise that hand up to the sky. You’re in the middle of a fisherman’s ritual, which can only be performed on grassy ground. You take fish fins from the previous year, and raise them up to the sky in order to ensure a good fishing harvest.
meaning_hint: Feel the grass in your toes and the fins in your hand as you raise them up to the sky. See the sun glistening off the fins as you raise them up in the air.
reading_story: This ritual only works in one part of the world however. It absolutely must be performed in Little Kyoto (きょ). The way Little Kyoto lines up with the sun and the sky and all that astrological junk makes it the best place for you to raise fish fins up in the air.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself going through the same process as before, only this time imagine yourself in Little Kyoto. Little Kyoto is really little, so make sure you're in the right spot.

radicals: 丶, 刀, 心, 言
meaning_story: They say a sword will cause drop upon drops of blood to spill from your heart once you recognize you’ve been stabbed. Getting shanked in the heart by a sword will surely cause at least one drop of blood to spill from you, but first you must recognize that you’ve actually been stabbed.
meaning_hint: Look down at your chest. Recognize that you’ve been stabbed in the chest with a sword. It hurts a lot. See the first drop of blood eke out of your heart and down your chest.
reading_story: You nincompoop (にん), how did you not recognize that you were about to be stabbed? That guy came at you from like a mile away. And slowly! You had plenty of time to recognize they were going to stab you and you did nothing about it. You silly nincompoop.
reading_hint: You got stabbed in the heart with a sword for no good reason. It could have easily been avoided. Recognize that you are a huge nincompoop and you should feel bad.

meaning_story: The next clam will be yours, but this clam will be mine. These are the resources we have to share and distribute. If we don't distribute them this way (next one is yours, this one is mine) we may all starve to death. Would you want that?
meaning_hint: Imagine a pile of clams. Above them is a sign that says resources on it. You are thinking, why do I get the next one and not this current one? What's up with that? The guy distributing them is obviously corrupt and greedy, so feel upset about that and his way with resources.
reading_story: Now, who is the evil man distributing these resources? Imagine him to be Charlie Sheen (し), the terrible resources distributor. He is taking all the clams and tiger blood for himself!
reading_hint: Now imagine what happened in the meaning mnemonics again, this time with Charlie Sheen as the resources distributor.

meaning_story: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
meaning_hint: If you know the radical, you will know the kanji as well!
reading_story: Such righteousness! Well, at least according to the king who thinks he's being righteous. His version of righteousness is to send anyone who disagrees with him to the guillotine.
reading_hint: THIS IS NOT RIGHTEOUSNESS! you yell, just before the guillotine comes down on your neck.

meaning_story: Under the tree lays a turkey with a broken arrow in it. The police finally have stopped this evil turkey by shooting it with an arrow. Before it dies, the last thing they do is read it its rights.
meaning_hint: Picture the police officer reading this turkey its rights. In fact, say the rights out loud (make something up) to the turkey in your head. You are the police officer who shot this dying turkey, so you have to read it its rights.
reading_story: Whats your name, turkey?' you ask. You have to include the turkey's name in the rights or it's not official. The turkey responds: Ken (けん)... I am Ken the turkey.
reading_hint: Now re-read the rights to the turkey, using his name.

meaning_story: A tsunami hits the cliff on which the tofu sect is living. The sect chose to live on this cliff to be closer to the tofu deity in the sky, but now their lives are in danger from the tsunami.
meaning_hint: Picture this sect of tofu lovers up on their cliff. Smell the tofu in the air as you observe them worshipping the tofu as a tsunami crashes against the cliff. Hear the splash of the waters as water droplets rain down from overhead.
reading_story: Riding up along with the tsunami is a gigantic hammerhead (は) shark. The hammerhead has a taste for tofu and plans to eat all of it once it rides the tsunami up to the cliff. The sect won’t know what hit them.
reading_hint: It’s very strange for a hammerhead to have a taste for tofu, but this hammerhead does. Imagine the hammerhead thrashing around as it devours every crumbly block of tofu in sight.

meaning_story: A soldier in winter gains power when he completes a task. Each task he completes grants him experience points which in turn grant him power. Currently, the soldier is fighting a winter battle, so he can use all the power he can get.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as this soldier, running around doing task after task. You need all that experience to level up! Feel the cold winter air around you and hear the crunch of snow beneath your feet.
reading_story: Your next task is to kill a cow. Being a soldier, this is no problem for you. You sneak up on a cow and power-stab it to death. The cow shrieks in agony as it perishes, “Moo (む)… moooo~!”
reading_hint: See yourself stabbing this cow to death. Hear the sound of its flesh being stabbed as it moos out in pain. “Moo! Moo… moo…”

meaning_story: You're climbing a pine tree when a guard comes up and tells you that you have to pay a tax. You've climbed lots of trees and you've never been taxed for it before. This guard does look pretty serious though...
meaning_hint: What would you do if a guard told you there is a pine tree tax? Would you believe him? Would you pay it?
reading_story: You're thinking about this tax when you hear someone shout, "Vat did you zay (ぜい)?" German Hard Gay comes sliding down the tree. "Zer iz no tax! Don't listen to vat he zays!" He leaps over the guard and runs off. Without paying the tax.
reading_hint: Listen to Hard Gay say Zei Zei Zei in the distance as you pay the tax. He didn't have to, but the guard made you pay it.

meaning_story: Look at it from this angle – if we stick the sword in the cow, and untie the rope around the door, we’ll be able to solve this puzzle. You’re in a strange room and there is a cow blocking the exit. There’s a sword on the ground, and the handle on the door is tied shut with a rope. I think the only way to solve this problem is to kill the cow with the sword to get it out of the way, and then untie the rope holding the door shut.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself walking through the steps of this puzzle you must solve. Feel the cold steel of the sword as you plunge it into the cow’s heart to kills it. Feel the coarseness of the rope as you untie it from the door.
reading_story: When you make it through the door after you untie the rope and solve this room’s puzzle, you see a coyte (かい) on the other side. The coyote looks menacing and lunges out at you. Using the sword in your hand, you cut down the coyote. It falls over dead.
reading_hint: Good thing you were still carrying that sword, huh? That coyote almost got you. See yourself stabbing the coyote to death and listen to it yelp as its life leaves its body.

meaning_story: Taking out a thread in public, you sew a broken heart back up to make it whole. You’re a hero! Someone suffered a broken heart in the middle of a public gathering, and you’re the only doctor available. Taking action, you use a thread to sew the heart back up and make it whole once again.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself wrist deep in someone’s chest cavity as you sew their heart back up to make it whole. Feel the warmth of their open body as you do your work.
reading_story: What do you do to make this heart whole? That’s right, you sew (そう) it. You sew this heart to make it whole. It was busted, and now you sew it with thread to make it a whole heart once again.
reading_hint: Now you have to sew the chest back up to close the heart inside since it’s been made whole once again. Imagine the person you saved thanking you profusely as you sew his chest back up again.

meaning_story: Using a nailbat while you play football can aid in the assist of defending the ball carrier. Using the nailbat is like, super illegal as far as football rules go, but there’s no doubt that it would assist in tackling and knocking others to the ground.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself playing football with this nailbat. You hear the ball being hiked and feet scuffling all around. Wanting to aid your team and help assist a touchdown, you start cracking skulls with your nailbat. Hear the crunch as you bash other players with the nailbat. Hear their screams as they fall to the ground all around you.
reading_story: This nailbat was made from the wood of an ent (えん). Ents are composed of very strong wood. A nailbat made out of such a material is very strong. This proves a great aid in your defensive ability on the football field. You manage to assist in many touchdowns because of it.
reading_hint: Remember yourself crafting this nailbat out of an ent. You cut the branch from a live ent so he wasn’t too happy with you. Hear the leafy scream of the ent as you carve your nailbat out of one of his arms.

meaning_story: You have a great ability because your heart gives you the appearance of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition.
meaning_hint: See yourself in this ideal appearance. Everyone loves to look at you because you look so awesome. Your heart has given you many great abilities. Feel strong and powerful in this body of yours.
reading_story: While you may have the appearance of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to tie (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing.
reading_hint: Since you don’t know how to tie a tie or tie your shoes, you wear slip ons and clip ons. Hear the noise of Velcro being undone as you kick off your shoes and unclip your tie after a hard day’s work at the office.

meaning_story: They say Big Bird has always been correct since birth. Big Bird cannot tell a lie. Since birth, he’s been correct all the time they say.
meaning_hint: Picture Big Bird. Now imagine him saying “I cannot tell a lie.” Big Bird is always correct. He’s been that way since birth.
reading_story: Another thing Big Bird has been doing since birth is tan (たん). Big Bird loves to tan. He says it is good for his skin. If Big Bird says it, and Big Bird is always correct, then this must be true. Getting a tan is good for Big Bird.
reading_hint: Picture Big Bird lying out in the sun to get a tan. See him with sunglasses and a tanning mirror to reflect the rays. He’s been doing this since birth, so he’s a pretty accomplished tanner.

meaning_story: Using a nailbat to hit a sick dog will definitely worsen its condition. You take a nailbat in your hand, swing it, and hit your sick dog. The dog’s condition has just gone from bad to worse.
meaning_hint: Do you have a dog? Imagine hitting your dog with a nailbat. Even worse, your dog was sick and in bad condition, and now you’re hitting it with a nailbat. Hear your dog squeal in agony as you hit it with the nailbat, further worsening its already dire condition.
reading_story: You are actually Joseph (じょう) Stalin and you care not for the condition of this dog so you continue to beat the dog with your nailbat. Joseph Stalin isn't a very caring fellow.
reading_hint: The dog is already in terrible condition. Why are you still hitting it, Joseph Stalin? Imagine what the the dog possibly could have done to warrant such terrible behavior on your part. Perhaps you’ve gone insane, Joseph Stalin? Continue to hear the dog moaning in pain as you whack it again and again with the nailbat.

meaning_story: The power of the mouth of a clam deserves congratulations. I mean, have you ever tried to open a clam? They’re strong. That clam mouth has a lot of power. Definitely worthy of congratulations.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself trying to open a clam. You struggle to open its mouth but the clam’s power is too great. Congratulations clam, you’ve won.
reading_story: After you give the clam a hearty congratulations for his mighty power, you start to break down and cry like the little baby you are. “Goo goo… ga (が) ga…” It’s really embarrassing. Stop acting like a little baby, you baby. Go and goo goo ga ga somewhere else, you’re embarrassing the rest of us with your presence.
reading_hint: Since your friends have abandoned you, imagine yourself crying like a whiny little baby after your defeat. Actually pretend to wipe away tears as you say goo goo ga ga out loud. Go ahead – do it.

meaning_story: You kiss each of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine kissing each of your best friends on the mouth. Does this make you uncomfortable? Excited? Both? Feel that feeling.
reading_story: Actually, each of your best pals are of the cock (かく) variety. By that, I mean they are both roosters. Imagine kissing both of these cocks on their beaks.
reading_hint: Kissing the cock beak is kind of a strange experience. Feel the feathers in your hands as you steady the cock to kiss it. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

meaning_story: On a slinky rides a clam who spares no expense for travel. The slinky is the most high-end and sought after mode of transportation for clams. They get on one end and then slinky at breakneck speed to their destination. They’re also very expensive, but this particular clam spares no expense for travel.
meaning_hint: Visualize this opulent clam as he rides his slinky around town. Where is he going? How can he afford such an expense? Hear the sound of this slinky slinking around as you contemplate.
reading_story: Since the clam spared no expense and bought the best slinky clam money could buy, he is now the most famous and fastest clam in all the land. The slinky has turned him into a sort of clam superhero (ひ). Being a superhero has its downsides though. The clam has to always help people out and like, do good and stuff. The life of a superhero can be hard.
reading_hint: Now picture the clam in his superhero outfit. Imagine a clam with a mask and tights on as he speeds to the rescue on his super-fast slinky.

meaning_story: “Bring in the next woman so that I may examine her figure!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as a figure judge on this panel. You need to find a woman with the perfect figure to cast in your commercial.
reading_story: The next woman comes in. You examine her figure. She (し) is perfect. She is the one. She has the perfect figure and she shall be the star of the commercial.
reading_hint: Picture the most perfect figure a woman can have. She is perfect. Picture her. Now imagine her dancing about and showing off her figure for you.

meaning_story: The womb is a circle of power where a force of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in the womb. You’re being born into the world. Feel the force and energy of your mother around you. Hear the sound of water as you float about in the womb. Force yourself to breathe the fluid and imagine yourself doing so.
reading_story: Now pretend you are the pregnant woman. You need to force that baby out of you with such force that the baby comes flying out. Your favorite TV show is on and you need to get this baby out of your womb pronto. Suddenly the door busts open ad Dr. Hard Gay busts in. “Sei (せい), sei, sei! Who’s ready to birth a baby!?” he shouts. “Sei, sei, sei~!”
reading_hint: Your doctor is Hard Gay. Do you feel safe in his hands? Imagine Hard Gay with his hands down by your bits as you try and force a baby out of you. You feel very uncomfortable and he just will not stop shouting “Sei, sei, sei.” Worst pregnancy ever.

meaning_story: You can use a jackhammer to indicate and show someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go.
meaning_hint: Imagine using this jackhammer to show someone where the prize is buried. Feel the vibrations through your hands and the rest of your body.
reading_story: Actually, you're unearthing Jesus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to indicate to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to show you the way of the Lord? This guy.”
reading_hint: Picture Jesus getting all over the top and super preachy about his religious beliefs. He’s doing everything he can to indicate to the crowd that he’s the best, and show them how cool he is. Listen to Jesus preach to the crowd, desperate for their attention.

radicals: 又, 冖, 宀, ヨ
meaning_story: You’re wearing a helmet and wielding a modified nailbat, but Wolverine can still stab you in the forehead while sitting in a stool, causing you to lie down. Nothing can protect you from Wolverine, not even a helmet and a nailbat, not even a specially designed modified nailbat like this one. You think you might be safe because he’s sitting in a stool, but no, he still manages to stab you in the forehead. Now you have to lie down because you’re too wounded to stand.
meaning_hint: Feel the pain in your forehead as you lie down. Wolverine just stabbed you in the brain. It hurts. Feel the blood flow over your face as you lie down in agony. (Remember it’s a modified nailbat as the nailbat radical in this kanji is slightly modified.)
reading_story: You hear a horse neigh (ね) in the distance, followed by the sound of galloping approaching you. This can’t be good. All you want to do is lie down and nurse your wounds, but there appears to be a horse charging at you. Wolverine is riding it. You hear another neigh as the horse draws closer.
reading_hint: All you want to do is lie down, because you got stabbed in the forehead. Now imagine yourself getting trampled by a horse. Hear Wolverine laugh and the horse neigh as you get trampled by the mad horse.

meaning_story: If a Viking is in a bathtub, there’s no way you’ll manage to get him out. That Viking is in the bathtub and that’s where he aims to stay. There’s no way you’re ever going to manage to move this stubborn Viking.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself standing on the edge of the bathtub, struggling to get this Viking out of the bathtub. It’s impossible. You’ll never manage to get him out of there! Make sure to really feel your muscles tense as you try with all your might to move this Viking. You need to really get into this one, so that you don’t get it screwed up with “Shinto Shrine” (宮). Imagine the three lines on the top of this kanji representing sweat and stress lines from how hard you’re working to pull this Viking out of the bathtub.
reading_story: Since you’ll never manage to move this Viking out of the bathtub, you decide to play cards with him instead. You’re playing poker, and you manage to be dealt one ace (えい) after another. Then, the rest of the cards are laid out, and there’s another ace, and another ace. You have 4 aces! Surely you will manage to win this hand.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself playing cards against this Viking. You’re pretty sure you’ll manage to win this hand with your aces, but you’re also afraid that if you beat the Viking, he’ll tear you in half. Yikes.

meaning_story: The grave is in the same direction as the monk. If you’re looking for the grave, just follow the monk, they’re in the same direction.
meaning_hint: Monks are religious people, and graves usually stir up some spiritual feelings. This monk watches over the graves, so picture yourself following him to such a grave.
reading_story: You’re following this monk to the grave when all of a sudden he turns around and shoots you with a bow (ぼう). You’re not sure where he got that bow from, but now you’re dying from the arrow wound. The monk then proceeds to take your body and put it into the grave.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself getting shot by a monk holding a bow. See his face and hear the twang of the bowstring as the arrow enters your chest and pierces your heart.

meaning_story: One day, Sauron will say that he wants to remove your ribs as a penalty. I’m not sure what you’re going to do to earn this penalty, but you’ll do it eventually. When you do, Sauron will come to you and say that he needs to remove all of your ribs as penalty.
meaning_hint: Imagine Sauron removing all of your ribs. It’s very painful having them all ripped out of you. What could you have done to earn such a penalty?
reading_story: The way Sauron is removing your ribs is a two step process. First, he breaks your ribs with some baseball bats (ばつ), then he tears the ribs out of you. This is a penalty, so the process is not pleasant. It hurts enough being hit with the bats, but then after getting hit with the bats you get torn open for your broken ribs to be removed.
reading_hint: Feel your ribs being hit with these bats. Imagine the wind being knocked out of you multiple times as you continue to suffer many blows from bats.

meaning_story: The cheap tree has a plan. A plan to reduce the budget deficit. The cheap tree lives cheap and has led a life of cheapness so it knows how to make a cheap plan. The cheap tree is going to reduce spending and improve life. What a great plan.
meaning_hint: Picture this tree in a TV advertisement. Hear the tree detailing its cheap plan and how its plan is the best plan.
reading_story: This cheap tree is a woman. She is a woman with a plan and her name is Ann (あん). Ann is the cheap tree with a plan, man.
reading_hint: Look at Ann on the TV screen detailing her plan. Hear Ann’s leaves rustling in the soft breeze as she continues to detail her cheap plan. *Extra Hint: Same reading as 安 which is in the kanji. Convenient!

meaning_story: With a bamboo tree resting atop your head, you devise a plan. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it.
meaning_hint: Imagine being trapped under this bamboo tree that is resting on your head. You’re stuck. Feel the weight of the bamboo tree pressing on your head as you try and devise a plan to get out from under it.
reading_story: But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a sack (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a plan to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape!
reading_hint: Bamboo is usually kind of light, but this bamboo has a sack of rocks tied to each end making it heavy. Imagine yourself trying to remove this bamboo tree by pushing it up and away from you. It’s like doing a bench-press, bamboo style.

meaning_story: Launching a nailbat at the sun with a catapult is not exactly the correct way to present a gift and submit it to the sun. You wish to appease the sun, so you want to submit a gift to gain its approval. As such, you present it with this nailbat, but do so in a manner which isn’t quite correct.
meaning_hint: See yourself loading this nailbat into this catapult. Hear the twang as the nailbat gets launched into the air and towards the sun. This is not quite the correct way to submit a gift to the sun, so remember that the radical for correct in this kanji is modified, not quite correct.
reading_story: You really want to present the sun with something awesome. So you decided to submit your favorite nailbat. But in reality, all the sun wants is some tater (てい) tots. The sun really loves tater tots, but no one knows this. Poor sun. Just wants some taters.
reading_hint: Pretend you are the sun. Imagine these tater tots that you just cannot get your hands on. No one will submit them to you. All you do all day is imagine what the tater tots taste like in your mouth. All tatery and tottery. Mmm… tater tots.

meaning_story: Sauron became a pope in order to have a lion put in the Vatican. Sauron loves lions and always believed that at least one lion belonged inside the Vatican. However, in order to have one put in, he had to first become a pope.
meaning_hint: Imagine Sauron all decked out in pope garb as his sits in his mighty pope chair and pets the lion he put in the Vatican. Pope Sauron sure is one bad dude.
reading_story: Every day, Pope Sauron will put out cheese (ち) for his lion to eat. Most lions are not so fond of cheese, but this papal lion is quite fond of it.
reading_hint: Imagine this lion eating cheese. See it holding a huge wedge of cheese in its mighty paws as it nibbles on the cheese.

radicals: 一, 口, 土, 戈
meaning_story: Under a grave in the ground is a drunkard with something in his mouth from a region in North America. He died from whatever it is that’s in his mouth. That’s how this drunkard ended up in this grave in the ground. His whole face region is disfigured from whatever he ate. I wonder what region of North America the strange object came from.
meaning_hint: Try and imagine yourself unearthing this dead drunkard and trying to figure out what’s in his mouth. Smell the decay of flesh as you poke around in his mouth, trying to figure out what this thing is in his drunkard mouth. Think of an object and what region of North America it comes from.
reading_story: In an attempt to identify what region of North America the thing in the drunkard’s mouth came from, you touch it and try to remove it with your bare hands. Upon touching whatever it is, you find it to be all icky (いき) and gooey. Like, super icky. So icky that you barf in the region immediately adjacent to the grave you’re in.
reading_hint: Imagine touching this super icky substance from the drunkard’s mouth. It’s really icky. Feel yourself throwing up as you feel the icky goo between your fingers.

meaning_story: If you have a mullet, regardless of how good a heart you have, I’m not going to respond to anything you say. I don’t respond to mullet wearers, no matter how good a heart they have.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are this good hearted mullet wearer. No one will respond to anything you say because of your mullet. It feels bad to be ignored by everyone. Feel sad as you stroke your mullet for comfort.
reading_story: Every time you try and talk to someone, they start to respond as they turn around, but then they see you and they’re all like, “Oh (おう). You have a mullet. Nevermind.” You’re getting really tired of hearing “Oh. You have a mullet.” Like, “Oh. You’re inferior to us so we’re not going to respond. You mullet wearing freak you.” It feels bad to be treated this way.
reading_hint: Oh. Oh. Oh. You have a mullet. Oh. Ok. I have nothing to say to you. Go away.

meaning_story: Wearing a helmet in the bathtub of a Shinto Shrine is nothing strange. Shinto Shrines are home to many odd things, and the ritual of wearing a helmet in the Shinto Shrine bathtub in one such event. So don’t be afraid to take your helmet the next time you get in the bathtub at a Shinto Shrine.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself wearing this helmet as you soak in the warm waters of the bathtub, hearing the chanting all around you in the Shinto Shrine. Make sure to really feel the hot water of the bathtub, the helmet on your head, and the sounds of the Shinto Shrine around you. You need to really get into this one, so that you don’t get it screwed up with “manage” (営). Imagine the helmet as a German war helmet from World War I - the ones that have a single spike coming out of the top. Vividly use that image to remember this kanji.
reading_story: But wait, who is it that is bathing in this bathtub in the Shinto Shrine whilst wearing a German War helmet? Why, it’s none other than Mario himself! “It’s-a me-a (みや), Mario!” he shouts, jumping out of the bathtub and bouncing about the Shinto Shrine. “It’s-a me-a… It’s-a me-a, Mario!!”
reading_hint: See Mario jumping around the Shinto Shrine and imagine him shouting “It’s-a me-a, Mario!” as he hops around. Why is he wearing a helmet? Well, Mario’s a little… special, and with all that hapless bouncing around he’s doing, the helmet is just a precaution.

meaning_story: In your mouth you take an escalator and suck and inhale it into your body. You’re incredibly hungry so you’re eating everything in sight. The first thing that your mouth finds to eat is an escalator. You suck it down, practically inhaling it in your feeding frenzy.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as you inhale a whole escalator. Think of how wide your mouth would have to open for you to suck it down. Feel your cheeks spreading apart and stretching as you devour the escalator.
reading_story: It looks like something is riding the escalator as you inhale it. It’s a cute (きゅう) rabbit, just hopping along the escalator stairs. Unfazed, you suck down the cute rabbit along with the rest of the escalator. Cute or not, food is food.
reading_hint: Imagine the cute rabbit running away from your mouth as you suck and inhale the escalator out from under the cute rabbit’s feet. Hear it squeal and shriek in fear as you get closer and closer and finally inhale the cute rabbit into your mouth.

meaning_story: To be top dog of the water slide, you must grow a mustache on top of a mustache in order to surpass your peers. You go down a water slide in your bathing suit, so you really need to show off your stuff by using facial hair. The mustache is the most manly thing you can wear on your face, so to be the most manly, it makes sense to grow two of them. You’ll easily surpass all others using this strategy.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself with two mustaches, one over the other. Feel the pride and confidence as you surpass all others in manliness. Feel the bushiness of your two mustaches on your upper lip.
reading_story: The only one challenging you now is a little girl sitting in an amazing car (か). It's on the next water slide over, revving its engines, then blasts down the slide, surpassing you in manliness and speed.
reading_hint: Feel so surpassed by this car, surpassing you in every way.

meaning_story: Taking orders from a geoduck will place you into enemy territory. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared.
meaning_hint: Imagine this geoduck shouting orders at you to march into enemy territory. See its gross body as a mouth forms and starts shouting out orders.
reading_story: Not wanting to end up dead in enemy territory, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a row (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away.
reading_hint: Feel yourself in the row boat as you imagine rowing away to safe territory. Hear the geoduck in the background shouting at you from shore, ordering you to return to land.

meaning_story: The light of the moon is shining on a guard who's been on duty all night. The moon light makes him so warm and comfortable that he forgets where he is and starts to undress. He thinks he's home! Everyone is going to see him take off his clothes!
meaning_hint: Picture a sleepy guard, bathed in moonlight, starting to undress. No! Keep your uniform on guard! Don't undress outside in the middle of the night!
reading_story: You can't seem to get the guard to stop undressing so you throw some darts (だつ) at him. You figure that even if the guard doesn't snap out of this weird sleepy trance, at least you can use the darts to stick his clothes to his body. Then maybe he won't be able to undress anymore.
reading_hint: Imagine throwing darts at a guard who's undressing himself. Imagine trying to aim for his pants so they'll be nailed to his body.

meaning_story: A thread leads you to an outhouse where you can unite with the toilet. It’s really dark outside at night, so the thread runs from your campsite to the outhouse, allowing you to navigate there with ease. You really have to pee, so you follow the thread over to the outhouse. The campsite you’re at is united with the outhouse by this piece of thread.
meaning_hint: You really have to pee. Your desire to unite with the toilet is so strong that it wakes you from your slumber. Feel the thread moving through your hands as you use it to navigate your way to be united with the outhouse.
reading_story: Since you’re still kind of drowsy, you don’t realize how close you are to the outhouse and you unite your face with the outhouse door. It really hurts and you stumble over backwards and fall down a hill leading to downtown Tokyo (とう). You end up in a Tokyo street with your pants down, urinating on the sidewalk. The Tokyo Police will arrest you for sure.
reading_hint: How embarrassing. It's bad enough that you fell down a hill and wet yourself, and now you're going to be arrested for indecent exposure. Yikes.

meaning_story: The helicopter the leader is in has the most value! He would only choose to fly the very best one, after all. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter he flies goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader.
meaning_hint: Can you understand the value of this helicopter? The leader flew it to war and back! So of course it's worth a lot!
reading_story: To further increase the helicopter's value, the leader bought himself a car (か) and then tied them together. Now it has the value of a helicopter AND a car! Wow!
reading_hint: Imagine driving a valuable car with the leader's helicopter on top. Yeah!

meaning_story: As a leader of a lion, the pope has great value. Not many can lead a lion as the pope does, so this grants him a higher value than most people. It’s part of the reason he was made pope, actually. Note: By the way, this word is also used for the other type of "value" - the mathematical kind (a value). You may not come across this definition as often, but keep it in mind!
meaning_hint: See this pope, leader of lions. To show everyone how much value he has, the pope parades around leading a lion. See him walking through the streets with the lion behind him. Hear the lion roar as he parades throughout the town.
reading_story: Turning the corner, the pope and his lion come across a horse. While not having as much value as a lion, a horse is still an important animal to the town. However, the horse is afraid of the lion and lets out a shrill neigh (ね). The neigh in turn startles the lion, and now we have two animals that are scared.
reading_hint: Hear the neigh of the horse in your head. Do you value your life? If so, imagine yourself getting far away from these startled and dangerous animals as you continue to hear the horse neigh in the distance.

meaning_story: A creeper who lives in a rice paddy sells his ribs to the vice president as a side business. The creeper’s main business is working the rice paddy, but when the creeper needs some extra cash on the side, he sells his (and others’) ribs to the vice president.
meaning_hint: Imagine these shady side dealings. The vice president is buying ribs on the black market. Imagine him and the creeper in a dark alley, doing the exchange. Smell the faint smell of rotted flesh that still hangs on the bones.
reading_story: To feed the vice president’s need for more ribs, the creeper must acquire them from multiple sources. You really need some extra cash on the side so you go and find a target to obtain some ribs. As you’re pulling ribs out of their body, they shout at you, “F*** (ふく) you, rib thief! F*** you!”
reading_hint: Imagine you are the one having your ribs torn out. You’re in a lot of pain and probably pretty angry, so it’s no surprise that you’re swearing at this guy. Imagine yourself cussing him out and dropping f-bombs left and right as he tears ribs out of your body.

meaning_story: A broken arrow is sticking out of a turkey and you can see a crowd of people gathering around to view it. The turkey was just shot for Thanksgiving dinner and you see a hungry crowd gathering around to view the turkey getting skinned and feathered and prepared for dinner. Remember that the arrow is broken, because the arrow radical in this kanji is modified, or broken.
meaning_hint: View this turkey in your brain. Really picture it vividly as view the people viewing the turkey gathered around to view its preparation.
reading_story: After you view the turkey being prepared, there is some left over. The remains are put into a can (かん) and each person who came to view the preparation gets to take home a can of turkey for later.
reading_hint: Since you came to view the turkey being prepared, you also get a can. Feel the cold metal of the can in your hands as you view the label. It says, “Turkey.” Imagine what the turkey tastes like as you hold the can in your hands. Is your mouth watering?

meaning_story: Flowers from the moon adorned with horns riding a train over water are known as wisteria flowers. Wisteria includes ten species of woody climbing vines native to the Eastern United States and to China, Korea, and Japan. They are an aquatic flowering plant, so they got a snack when they rode that train over the water. Their petals look like little purple horns and they look kind of strange too so they must be from the moon.
meaning_hint: Google this flower if you don’t know what it is. Now that you have the image or a wisteria in your mind. Picture it and its journey from the moon riding a train in water. It’s a very strange journey, but this is a strange flower. This kanji is most commonly used in names, so you can remember that by keeping in mind that it’s not a very commonly known flower, and people want to have unique names so they use this kanji in them or something.
reading_story: So where does the wisteria arrive after its journey from the moon? Well, it arrives at Mt. Fuji (ふじ). Mt. Fuji is the best spot for a wisteria to arrive on planet earth. Fuji loves wisteria flowers and wisteria flowers love Fuji.
reading_hint: Picture this beam of water connecting the moon to Mt. Fuji and see the train traveling over it, carrying the wisteria. Imagine yourself standing on Mt. Fuji as you watch the wisteria train approaching. Hear the chug of the train engine as it gets closer and closer to Mt. Fuji.

meaning_story: Armed with nothing but a mullet and a nail, you command an agency of the highest regard in the government office. Everyone respects your mullet, and to let everyone know you’re tough as nails, you carry a nail around with you everywhere you go. This respect has earned you a position in a highly regarded government office where you command an agency of agents.
meaning_hint: See yourself as the leader of this agency, the commander of this government office. Feel the mullet on the back of your neck and the cold metal nail in your hands. Truly, what a majestic sight you are.
reading_story: The only person posing a threat to your agency and the whole government office is the notorious Ms. Chou (ちょう). She totally disrespects your mullet and cares not for your symbolic nail. Ms. Chou is an angry Asian woman and she is not to be trifled with.
reading_hint: Now see Ms. Chou facing off against this guy with a mullet holding a nail. They’re fighting in front of a government office and the whole agency is watching their battle. Hear Ms. Chou screaming as the mullet wearing agent jabs her with his nail. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 町 and 丁.

meaning_story: This word has three really important meanings. It's probably best if you remember them all. Let's do this! When you're a guest somewhere it's important to bring geoducks. But more than that, the amount of geoducks you bring is really what matters. If you don't have any live geoducks go ahead and bring any amount of framed pictures of geoducks instead. If you can't even do that, well, then you're going to have to tattoo geoducks on your forehead.
meaning_hint: If you're a guest you either have to have the right amount of geoducks, geoducks in framed pictures, or geoducks on your forehead. Otherwise you're a jerk.
reading_story: Unfortunately, if you mess up any of these things, (the amount, the framed pictures, or the forehead tattoo) every other guest will gawk (がく) at you.
reading_hint: Feel the feel of hundreds of gawks. Feel ashamed as they gawk at you. How could you!?

radicals: 夕, 月, 宀, 巳
meaning_story: The moon reflects on your helmet in the evening as you beat a snake to death with your arm. You were just minding your own business, wearing a helmet in the early evening, when this snake just came out of nowhere and attacked you. You use your strong arm to subdue and defeat this violent snake.
meaning_hint: Imagine using your arm to defeat a snake. Feel the scaly exterior of the snake as it wriggles and writhes about in your hand, hissing all the way.
reading_story: Your arm is tired from fighting the snake. You feel a chill. Where are your clothes? You’re nude, eh (うで)! Also, you’re Canadian, eh. But more importantly, you’re nude, eh!
reading_hint: Fighting a snake naked would be scary. But other than your helmet, you’re nude, eh. Feel the chill all around you as you massage your sore arm.

meaning_story: Near a grave, you can stand and see the boundary surrounding it. There is a boundary around this grave, drawn into the ground, but to see it, you need to stand next to the grave.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself standing next to this grave. See the boundary around you and the grave and feel the chilling air around you because graves are creepy.
reading_story: This grave is located in Kyoto (きょう), only the boundary around the grave represents a new country. The area within the boundary is actually a country belonging to the guy buried in the grave. He was tired of Kyoto and decided to start his own country.
reading_hint: Now see yourself hopping in and out of the boundary, switching what country you are in. One moment you’re in Kyoto, Japan, the next you’re somewhere else. What a silly boundary.

meaning_story: Fire in nature will burn down everything in its path. In nature, there are no firefighters or anyone to contain the fire, so the fire will burn and burn until it has no fuel left to consume.
meaning_hint: Feel the fire all around you as it burns. You’re out in nature – the middle of a forest fire. Hear the woods burn and crackle as you feel the heat around you.
reading_story: What is the worst thing that could burn in this fire? Your nendoroid (ねん) collection. You've spent a lot of time and money collecting all these cool and rare and unique nendoroids and now they've all burned in the fire.
reading_hint: Cry your eyes out as you smell the smell of burning plastic from the nendoroids. Worst. Day. Ever.

meaning_story: You hold a nailbat and watch the sunrise. The sunrise indicates that you've had to bear this nailbat all night long. It is a long time to have to carry a weight such as this.
meaning_hint: Carry the nailbat. Bear its weight. Feel it pressing down on your body as the sun rises in the distance.
reading_story: But, it doesn't end there. This nailbat you bear is not something you can give up easily. You have to continue to carry it all day long too. Good thing about the day is that the sun will give you a nice tan (たん).
reading_hint: Now that you've done this for one night and one day, you can put down the nailbat. It's all over. Feel the relief. Even something that's not so heavy like a nailbat will be heavy if you carry it this whole time.
