meaning_story: A pelican and your older brother get together to celebrate. You know when these two get together it's going to be a crazy celebration.
meaning_hint: Indeed, these two throw a wild party. Imagine the craziest celebration you can, thrown by your older brother and this pelican. They're cheering, drinking, and jumping into pools from the roof.
reading_story: But, if you celebrate too much you go a little crazy. The pelican grabbed your brother and shook (しゅく) him so hard that his head flew off.
reading_hint: You'll have to imagine a pelican shaking your older brother so hard with its wings that his head falls off. "You shook him too hard!" you yell.

meaning_story: The American flag is the reason you need to deliver this package. The flag is inside the package, and you need to deliver it to the president. He lost his old flag, so now it’s up to you to deliver this new one to him. What more of a reason do you need?
meaning_hint: You need to deliver this flag to the president. Imagine yourself running as fast as you can while carrying the parcel in order to get it to him. Your lungs are tired and your legs burn, but you must deliver the flag as soon as possible!
reading_story: To deliver this flag is something you just have to do (とど). Need to do. Want to do. There is no one else to do it. This is something only you are equipped to do.
reading_hint: The world depends on you to do this delivery. If you fail, the United States will be ruined. You have to do it! Deliver that flag now! Run! Run!

meaning_story: A water slide and a cow god are two completely different things. While both are fun to ride, a cow god and a water slide are very different and should not be confused with one another.
meaning_hint: Imagine sliding down a water slide. Now imagine riding around the world on a cow god. Both experiences are fun. But they’re also different. Think about what makes each experience different.
reading_story: Also different from the water slide and the cow god is Tigger (ちが), the tiger from Winnie the Pooh. Tigger bounces all about, and is almost just as fun to ride around on as a water slide or a cow god. The ride is just a bit more bouncy when it’s with Tigger.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself riding on Tigger’s back. Feel yourself shoot up into the air as Tigger jumps and feel yourself bounce off the ground as Tigger lands and jumps again. It’s pretty fun, but a different kind of fun than a water slide or cow god.

meaning_story: A sheep with no legs that goes down a slide with any knowledge of construction lacks the distinction necessary to get new legs. This sheep is missing its bottom half, so it often gets to places by using slides. However, the sheep doesn’t know anything about construction, so it’s pretty clueless how to make slides or even how they work. Lacking distinction, no one really cares about this sheep enough to get it that leg transplant it so desperately wants.
meaning_hint: The sheep radical is missing its bottom, so keep that in mind as to why this sheep has no legs. See this legless sheep zooming around town in the slides, baa-baa-ing all the way.
reading_story: The way this sheep lost its legs was due to a saw (さ). A saw cut off the sheep’s legs. With the loss of its legs, the sheep lost its distinction as well. All because of some stupid saw.
reading_hint: Picture this sheep getting its legs sawed off with a saw. It’s brutal. See the saw slicing through the sheep’s flesh and bone as blood spatters everywhere. Hear the sheep screaming as each leg is slowly sawed off.

meaning_story: If you make too many excuses around a pig it will turn into an elephant. All those excuses build up in the pigs body and it transforms. Elephants remember everything, you know? And now it’s stuck remembering all the excuses you made. It exists to remind you of them. This is a special phenomenon that only happens when you make excuses around pigs. You can lie around other animals and pigs that have already turned into elephants. I can’t say they won’t judge you though.
meaning_hint: Picture it in your mind. Make a bunch of excuses in front of your pet pig. About how you don’t have time to study your kanji. You have previous plans, you can’t go out. You have to wash your hair, so you can’t clean the pig’s pen this week. WOMWOMWOMWOM - what’s the sound?! YOUR PIG IS AN ELEPHANT NOW!
reading_story: This special elephant phenomenon was actually started by the shogun (しょう). He was sick of people making excuses about why they couldn’t pay their taxes, go to war for him, or come to his birthday party. Now all he has to do is walk around town and find the people with elephants in their yards. Then he can punish them!
reading_hint: Imagine getting an invitation to the shogun’s birthday party. This is the third one this month! You’re pretty sure it’s not even his birthday. You’re about to make an excuse when… you notice your pig staring at you. Hmm… you don’t want your pig to become an elephant. It wouldn’t fit in your house anymore. I guess you have to go.

meaning_story: There’s a flag under the blackjack table that you can kick in order to expand the table. Sometimes you only have a few people playing blackjack so you don’t need to kick the flag at all, and sometimes there are many people playing blackjack so you need to kick the flag many times in order to expand it to a proper size.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself kicking this flag to see the blackjack table expand. Feel your foot kicking the flag. You’ve kicked it so many times that your leg is sore, but you need to expand the table some more so you keep kicking it. Imagine the blackjack table making that sound Mario makes whenever he gets a mushroom and expands in size.
reading_story: The blackjack table does have a limit though of how many times it will expand, and that limit is ten (てん). You can only kick the flag to get the table to expand ten times.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself kicking the flag ten times. Count it off in your head and imagine each instance up to ten. Any more kicks after ten don’t cause the table to do anything, but it does cause your leg to get sore.

meaning_story: Behind the flag lies a mask – yet another layer of secrecy. You’re standing in front of a crowd, giving a rousing speech. Hiding your face is the flag of your country, and behind that flag you’re also wearing a mask, just in case the flag falls down. The extra layer of secrecy is just to be safe. You don’t want your identity to be revealed.
meaning_hint: Behind the flag is a mask, and underneath that mask is another layer. It’s another mask. Picture yourself removing mask after mask – it’s a never-ending stream of masks. Layer after layer, you can’t be unmasked.
reading_story: Every layer is a layer of protection to maintain your anonymity. However, an angry protester throws something at the flag, damaging it. This is unacceptable, so you get out a needle and thread and sew (そう) the flag back up. It’s not too difficult for you to sew things, so you sew the flag back to working order in no time.
reading_hint: See yourself in your mask, working on this flag. You’ve got the needle in one hand and the thread in the other. Now sew. Sew sew sew until the flag is repaired.

meaning_story: A pelican can see you are nothing to look at. The pelican might look at you, and you can see that the pelican is looking at you, but the pelican asserts that you aren’t much to look at.
meaning_hint: Look at the pelican looking at you. See its beady pelican eyes and wonder what’s going on in that head of its.
reading_story: You know who doesn’t like to look at pelicans? Charlie Sheen (し ). Pelicans freak him the heck out. But can you really blame Charlie Sheen? Pelicans are creepy, especially under the influence. I see how Charlie Sheen would be wary to look at a pelican.
reading_hint: See Charlie Sheen staring down a pelican. Since Mr. Sheen doesn’t want to look at the pelican, he’s really freaking out. See him sweating bullets as he slowly starts to lose his mind looking at the pelican.

meaning_story: King Sauron raises from the ground zombie after zombie in an infinite loop. Sauron, king of all the lands, has decided to raise an army of zombies from the ground to keep everything in order. However, he’s gotten stuck in a loop and can’t stop raising zombies from the ground.
meaning_hint: Picture King Sauron raising zombies from the ground. He can’t stop, no matter how much he wants to. No time for eating or sleeping, King Sauron is all gaunt and sickly looking. He also smells pretty foul.
reading_story: In an attempt to knock King sauron out of his zombie raising loop, you toss a can (かん) at his head. The can smacks into him, knocking him out of the loop. Normally, King Sauron would kill you for throwing a can at him, but in this case, he is overjoyed.
reading_hint: Picture yourself throwing this can at Sauron. Feel the weight of the can as you heft and throw it, and then hear the clink of the can on Sauron’s helmet as it strikes him.

meaning_story: In an attempt to control your clothes, you manufacture a mind control device. This mind control device will allow you to control the mind of your clothes and all that they do. You just need to manufacture it.
meaning_hint: Imagine being able to control your clothes with your mind. What would you have them do? Imagine what you would do with your clothes if you could manufacture something to control them and move them around at will with your mind.
reading_story: Upon doing some internet research, it appears that the only man with the capability to manufacture such a clothing mind control device is none other than Hard Gay. You call him up and are greeted with a loud, “Sei (せい), sei, sei!” on the other end of the line.
reading_hint: Picture Hard Gay in a scientist’s outfit, working to manufacture this mind control device for your clothes. See him violently thrust as he does science and shouts “Sei, sei, sei~!”

meaning_story: After sliding down a water slide, an angel steps in a drop of blood, because I forgot to mention that he’s gravely wounded. Since I forgot to mention it earlier, I’ll tell you now. On the water slide, the angel got stabbed in the gut, so the drop of blood on the ground that he stepped in actually came from his own body.
meaning_hint: See the angel slide down the water slide all filled with joy and such, only to get to the bottom and realize he’s been stabbed, standing in a big drop of blood. Did I mention he’s screaming? Listen to the angel scream as he continues to bleed.
reading_story: I also forgot to mention that this angel has been trained in the ancient art of ninjutsu (じゅつ). Unfortunately, the angel’s ninjutsu training did him no good on this water slide. No amount of ninjutsu training could have prepared him for this day.
reading_hint: Since the angel is a trained ninjutsu practitioner, imagine the angel in a ninja outfit as he slides down the water slide. Hear him screaming out martial art yells as he slides down and then gets stabbed in the gut.

meaning_story: The ground stopping ceremony is one that's performed by the military. They stop the ground from moving forward and taking over the lands. As the military they have to protect the people, and that involves stopping the ground.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in this military as well, stopping the ground.
reading_story: What does the military all wear? They wear nice military boots (ぶ).
reading_hint: Put on the boots and see how it feels. These military boots are so nice.

meaning_story: If you get hit with a lantern in the ribs and end up in a grave, you’re the model image of the type of person who is very unlucky. Getting hit in the ribs with a lantern is usually not enough to kill you, but you ended up in a grave. You’re an unfortunate type of person.
meaning_hint: Dying from a lantern blow to the ribs is not model behavior. Feel the lantern crashing into your body and snapping your ribs on impact. Hear the crack of bone as you fall into the grave where you die.
reading_story: You were a member of the KKK (けい). Definitely not a model citizen. KKK members are not the type who are widely liked by the general public. They might actually be glad to hear that a member of the KKK was put in a grave due to a lantern injury.
reading_hint: Picture this KKK member falling into a grave after being hit in the ribs with a lantern. The lantern has set the KKK’s outfit on fire, so watch him flail around hopelessly as the flames consume him.

meaning_story: You have an animal for a husband with horns that are narrow. This animal husband of yours is a goat. A goat with narrow horns. Why is this animal your husband? You’re weird, that’s why.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself married to this animal husband with horns that are narrow. It’s a strange marriage. Listen to the goat making its goat noises as it clomps around your home. Now hug your goat husband and feel its soft fluffy coat against your skin.
reading_story: I’m not even going to get into the semantics (せま) of how this weird relationship of yours works. Nope, this reading explanation is on the straight and narrow. Need to know basis. Classified. All that junk. There will be no discussion of the semantics between you and your goat lover.
reading_hint: But that doesn’t mean you can’t imagine the semantics. The finer points of the relationship. Go ahead, imagine all the weird stuff that comes with the territory for having a goat as a husband. Use all that weird stuff to remember this kanji and its reading. Want an example? Just imagine the goat doing dishes! Goats don’t have hands! Hahahahaha!!

meaning_story: A bamboo helmet protects the head of a bear as he travels through a large pipe. This bear is going on a dangerous expedition through this pipe, so it needs a helmet for safety. The only helmet available in the bear’s size was a bamboo one, so that is what the bear wears as it traverses the pipe.
meaning_hint: See this bear in his bamboo helmet, bumbling along through the pipe. Hear the bear’s claws clink on the pipe as he walks through, roaring and growling all the way.
reading_story: The bear is almost to the other side of the pipe when he stumbles across a soda can (かん). Being a bear, he stops to play with the can, batting it around and forgetting his mission.
reading_hint: See the bear in his bamboo helmet, playing with the can inside of the pipe. It’s very noisy. Hear the can rattling around and the bear making a huge commotion banging into the sides of the pipe and stomping all around.

meaning_story: If a holy cross is hanging in the car of a drunkard, they’ll still publish the details of his accident if he gets in one. Not even a holy cross can protect a drunkard from having the details of his unsafe car driving published.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself as the drunkard driving this car. You just got into an accident. Hold the cross in your hand and pray that your accident won’t get published in the newspaper. You don’t want everyone to know what a drunkard you are, so really imagine yourself praying and holding the cross while you do so.
reading_story: The next day, you examine the news to see if they had the audacity to publish your car accident. Letting out a big sigh (さい), you discover the article detailing your life as a drunkard and a full write-up of the accident. How embarrassing. Sigh.
reading_hint: Let out a big sigh. Your secret drunkard life has been exposed to the world, and now everyone knows about your problems. Let out another sigh for good measure. Sigh.

meaning_story: You have to use two axes to open a clam. That seems like overkill, but it is necessary. This clam is of very high quality meaning it won't open so easily.
meaning_hint: Imagine the highest quality clam you've ever seen. It is hard, smooth, and basically impenetrable.
reading_story: You finally open the clam of quality. You can't believe your luck! It opened! When you look inside, expecting to see some high quality clam meat you see... shit (しつ). This clam is filled with poo.
reading_hint: You even put the clam in your mouth before looking and taste it. Shit (しつ) is all over your mouth. Taste it, and think how disappointed you are in this clam that looked to be of such high quality. You broke two axes to open it, after all!

meaning_story: When the sunrise touches a sunflower field, it will increase their quantity. A sunflower needs the sun to grow, so when a sunflower is exposed to the sunrise and all the sun thereafter, the quantity of sunflowers in the area will surely increase.
meaning_hint: See the sunrise coming over the horizon, causing you to squint your eyes. See the sunflowers sprouting up all around you. Smell the vast quantity of flowers, breathing in their sunflowery smell.
reading_story: Eventually, the quantity of sunflowers becomes too great for you to walk through. As such, you must use a row (りょう) boat and row your way through this sea of sunflowers. Row, row, row!
reading_hint: Feel the row boat oars in your hands as you row your boat back to safety. Feel the breeze as you skim along over the sea of sunflowers as the sunrise crests over the horizon.

meaning_story: The clam devil. All he talks about is how he wants you to sell your soul to him.
meaning_hint: Imagine a clam devil being really obnoxious about your soul. "Hey, sell me your soul, friend!" Over and over and over again. Make sure you feel irritated at it in your mind's eye.
reading_story: The devil clam won't stop asking you to sell your soul to it, and you're getting really upset. Suddenly, Han (はん) Solo bursts through the door, fills the devil clam full of lasers, and then runs off.
reading_hint: Han Solo saved you from this pushy clam devil! You feel relief, but you also wonder what this clam devil did to Han Solo to make him do this. Maybe Han Solo sold his soul to the clam devil?

meaning_story: A leader plays together with his servant. Since they play together all the time, the leader has no time to fetch his own food but makes his servant get it for him. The leader also really likes shark fins, so that’s what he’s eating.
meaning_hint: Picture this leader playing while the servant brings him a big bowl of shark fins. You can smell their fishy smell from all the way across the room.
reading_story: The leader takes the fins from his servant and smells them. Suddenly he throws the bowl to the floor, shattering it. 'I can’t eat these fins! They expire 今日 (きょう)! They’re no good! Today is too close! You trying to kill me?'
reading_hint: See the leader smashing this bowl of fins onto the ground and hear the pieces of the bowl shatter and fly around along with the fishy smelling fins as you hear the leader shouting, “今日!?!? Ugh!” What a mess.

meaning_story: The door leading to the moon can be broken down with one’s shoulder. It’s not a very sturdy door to the moon, so it’s quite easy to drop your shoulder and ram down the door to the moon.
meaning_hint: See yourself smashing through this door using your shoulder and seeing the moon on the other side. Hear the splintering of wood as your shoulder crashes through the door and feel the impact with your body.
reading_story: To get through the door, you could have used a wood cutter (かた), but you’re a man so you used your shoulder. Wood cutters are for women and babies. Men are much too macho to use something like a wood cutter.
reading_hint: Scoff at the puny wood cutter as you stand on the other side of the door you just busted through using your shoulder. Wood cutters are useless to you. Imagine breaking one over your shoulder to show your superiority.

meaning_story: What might cause a tree to slide down a jet would be if its stocks and shares took a dive in the market. This tree was on a jet for an important investor meeting when it got the news that its stocks and shares had just plummeted. Being very upset, the tree got up and got on the emergency slide out of the jet and plummeted into the ground just like his stocks and shares.
meaning_hint: Visualize this tree sliding out of the jet and falling to his doom. As he falls, visualize red lines falling alongside him to represent the stocks and shares. Hear the shrill whistle of them speeding through the air to the ground.
reading_story: Once the tree hits the ground with his stocks and his shares, the impact creates a large KABOOM (かぶ)! Stocks hit the ground - KABOOM! Shares! KABOOM! Tree! KABOOOOOOM~!
reading_hint: Listen to each of these things impact the ground and see each individual mushroom cloud appear around them. KABOOM! KABOOM! KABOOM!

meaning_story: If, at a certain angle, you approach an insect, you’ll be able to touch it without it noticing. Most of the time, insects will run away from you when you try and touch them, but if you do so from the right angle, the insect will have no idea.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself approaching this insect from a sneaky and stealthy angle. Now touch it. What does it feel like? Smooth? Hard? Fuzzy? Feel the insect in your mind as you touch it.
reading_story: Uh oh, looks like this particular insect is a lightning bug so when you touch it you get a shock (しょく). Did you know that lightening bugs contain bazillions of volts inside them? Well they do, and it you touch one, you get a shock. A very big shock.
reading_hint: Feel this electrical shock to your system as you touch the lightening bug. This discourages you from ever touching another insect again. You don’t enjoy the shock.

meaning_story: A car pales in comparison to the Death Star as far as transport goes. Do you think you would look cooler driving a car, or the Death Star? The Death Star, obviously. The Death Star is the best means of transport. Far superior to a car.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself using the Death Star in lieu of a car as your means of transport. Imagine how cool you feel rolling up somewhere in your Death Star. See yourself plowing through rush hour traffic and attending drive-in movies.
reading_story: In order to obtain the Death Star as your own personal means of transport, you had to usurp (ゆ) Darth Vader as its commander. It wasn’t easy to usurp him, but you managed to do it with the power of lots of money and a big gun. You’ve usurped the Death Star and now it is yours.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself usurping Darth Vader as the owner of the Death Star. It belongs to you now and you can do with it as you please. You didn’t expect the usurping process to go so smoothly, but you’re glad it did. Visualize it happening in your brain.

meaning_story: You're flying a helicopter and you see a woman in the moon light touching her waist. She has both hands on her waist, like she's Wonder Woman or something. But it's the middle of the night. What is she doing?
meaning_hint: Imagine flying your helicopter closer to the woman, it's not so hard because you have lots of moon light to see in, and try to see why she's touching her waist.
reading_story: As you get closer you realize her waist looks weird and... puffy? You bring the helicopter down and see that the woman's waist looks incredibly cozy (こし)! She has a blanket balled up and tied around her waist, she's holding it there with her hand, probably because it's cold out at night. But even with just her waist covered, she looks so warm and cozy!
reading_hint: Imagine how cozy your waist would be if you tried a nice warm blanket around it.

meaning_story: There’s a fish stick in the rice paddy, but the clam is accustomed to this sort of disorganization. The clam is the owner of the rice paddy, and his workers are prone to leaving fish sticks out in it. Therefore, the clam is accustomed to there being fish sticks out in his rice paddy.
meaning_hint: Most clams would be upset to find a fish stick in their rice paddy. This clam is accustomed to it though, so it’s not as big of a deal to him. Imagine the clam looking at the fish stick and shaking his head while he tsk tsks at it.
reading_story: Even though the clam is accustomed to this, he still needs to remove the fish stick from the rice paddy. Therefore, the clam takes the fish stick and places it in a can (かん) to dispose of later. At the end of the day, there are quite a few fish sticks in the can, and then the clam throws them all out.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as the clam collecting these fish sticks in the can. Pick them up one by one and hear them clink into the can as you gather them.

meaning_story: The flag is old but that doesn't mean it's not still alive. This is a living flag, and it gets old just like other living things.
meaning_hint: Imagine the old flag with a face and mouth and eyes and nose... it talks and listens and everything else. It's a flag that's alive D:
reading_story: The flag that is old and alive is actually a Buddhist relic (that's why it's alive, in fact ... and old!). But, it's a really dumb relic, so it's put in little kyoto (きょ).
reading_hint: Not as cool as a real relic, it's put in this dumb Little Kyoto shrine that's basically just a tourist attraction. Eh, whatever.

meaning_story: Atop a water slide, you use a shortened brush and some water to apprehend a criminal. The criminal you’re about to apprehend has been sabotaging water slides all over the nation and you’ve just caught him red handed. Taking your shortened brush (shortened for maneuverability), you splash him in the eyes with water and stab him into submission.
meaning_hint: See yourself about to apprehend this villain. Feel the splash from the water you just tossed on him and hear him shriek as you jab him with the short brush. It’s a shortened brush, because the brush radical is shortened in the kanji. Remember that.
reading_story: To make matters worse, this rogue you’re about to apprehend is an imperial fighter pilot. As such, he manages to escape in his tie (たい) fighter before you can apprehend him. Where did that tie fighter even come from? Lucky guy.
reading_hint: Imagine standing atop the water slide as the tie fighter speeds off into the distance. The force from the propulsion almost knocks you off the slide. Hear the engines roar as the villain makes his escape.

meaning_story: You have to fly in a helicopter and use a jackhammer to punch your ballot. The helicopter gets you far away from prying eyes, and the jackhammer makes you really try for whoever you're voting for on that thing. It's foolproof!
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to fill out your ballot while flying in a helicopter and using only a jackhammer to do it. Do you think you could do it? Do you think you could do it AND vote for the right person?
reading_story: While using the jackhammer on the ballot, the helicopter pilot keeps yelling “Heyo (ひょう), don't mess up! Heyo! Watch out, don't let me see!” as he flies the helicopter all over the place.
reading_hint: You're starting to think this method of filling out ballots is rigged.

meaning_story: You see a mantis sitting on a flag and you know for a fact that it does not belong there. Insects should be in trees and on the ground. Not on flags. Insects belong in the wild!
meaning_hint: Look at that mantis, pretending it belongs here. What are you gonna do about it?
reading_story: Luckily for you, and unluckily for this mantis who doesn't belong on your flag, you're a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang member, and you don't take crap from nobody. You climb the flagpole, punch the mantis and yell, "YOU DONT' BELONG HERE!"
reading_hint: Your Bosozoku life has prepared you for this moment. Those who don't belong, shall be punished, you think to yourself.

meaning_story: You throw a nailbat at a wedding in the hope that someone will catch it. You’re evil, and you love ruining weddings. What better way than to throw a nailbat and hope someone catches it with their face?
meaning_hint: Imagine throwing this nailbat at someone, or even having the nailbat thrown at you. You’re at a wedding, so you’re not expecting a nailbat to come flying at you. It’s a natural reflex to catch things thrown at you, so you catch the nailbat and the nails pierce your hands. It really hurts.
reading_story: After you catch the nailbat and get it stuck in your hands, most likely you’ll want to get it out of there. To do so, your friends hold you down and use a garden hoe (ほ) to pry the nails out of your palms. The hoe isn’t very graceful, but it is effective. And also painful.
reading_hint: Now you’re having those nails pried out of your hands with a hoe. It really smarts. Imagine this sensation and how awful it would feel. Your poor hands.

meaning_story: A leader with a stick, a hook, and an arrow can create the perfect climate to determine a candidate to be his successor. The stick, hook, and arrow are all weapons to be used in a battle royal. Many will fight to the death with these tools to be considered as candidates for the next leader.
meaning_hint: See all of the people fighting with these weapons to become candidates for leader. Hear the screams and grunts as they fight bitterly to the death.
reading_story: The current leader who created this climate of competitive bloodlust is none other than こういち himself. こういち has been looking for a replacement candidate for a long time, and this is what his search has come to. こういち thinks this method will finally net him a suitable candidate.
reading_hint: Picture こういち the leader watching his people fight to become a candidate for leader. See こういち smiling and clapping as people fight to the death with sticks, hooks, and arrows.

meaning_story: You’ve just committed an injustice to a car that belongs to your comrade. You accidently hit your comrade’s car with your own car and now your comrade is reconsidering if he still wants to be your comrade or not after such an injustice.
meaning_hint: Imagine hitting the car of a comrade with your own car. Hear the screech of the tires and the crash of metal. You feel really bad about this injustice you’ve committed.
reading_story: Since you feel so bad for your comrade and his car, you decide to write an apology in the form of a haiku (はい). Haikus are perfect for every situation, especially patching things up with a comrade.
reading_hint: Think of a good haiku for your comrade. It has to include stuff about his car as well as the injustice of you hitting it. What do you think a good haiku would be?

meaning_story: There’s a tsunami coming and your older brother is in no condition to escape. Your older brother has brittle bone syndrome so there’s no way he’ll be able to escape the tsunami in time in his condition.
meaning_hint: Imagine your poor brother and the condition he is in. His brittle bones make it impossible for him to move very fast at all. Imagine the sad face he makes when he realizes his fate.
reading_story: Your older brother lives in Kyoto (きょう), Japan and this is where the tsunami will be hitting worst. In your older brother’s condition, his best bet is to find a stronghold and wait out the tsunami instead of trying to outrun it. Since Kyoto is in Japan where they get a lot of tsunamis, your older brother should be able to find somewhere safe to hunker down.
reading_hint: Now that you know your older brother should be able to wait out the tsunami somewhere safe, you feel very relieved. You’re still anxious though, so you watch Japanese news for any updates on the tsunami situation in Kyoto though.

meaning_story: If you poop next to a good butcher, the sound will echo and he will know that you have pooped in his presence. This butcher is very in tune with poop, especially if the sound is echoing.
meaning_hint: Hear the poop echo. You know what a poop usually sounds like, now imagine that sound again, but with an echo. How could anyone not notice?
reading_story: This poop is really big. I mean, it’s so big, it’s as big as Kyoto (きょう). Yes, the entire city of Kyoto. No wonder there was an echo.
reading_hint: Imagine a poop the size of Kyoto. It’s massive. It must smell pretty bad too. Smell the smell of this huge poop as the echo continues to sound all around you.

meaning_story: If you mix power into your fighting style, you will be very effective in combat. Power is very effective for killing people, so if you throw power into the mix, you’ll be unstoppable.
meaning_hint: Power is very effective in battle. Imagine yourself flexing and swinging your arms around. Feel the weight of them and hear the sound of your powerful arms whooshing and cutting through the air.
reading_story: You punch こういち with your fists of power. It’s super effective! こういち dies. Why would you do such a thing!? You know punches are こういち’s only weakness! They’re super effective against him!
reading_hint: Imagine power punching こういち. Do you feel bad? You should. Hear こういち scream as you punch him over and over again. He cries for mercy but you do not relent.

onyomi: ばつ, はつ, はい
meaning_story: Taking a nailbat and hitting your friend with it will surely extract blood from their body. It’s not nice to hit your friend with a nailbat, but if you choose to do so, you will definitely extract blood. And pain. Lots and lots of pain.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself hitting your friend with a nailbat. What could your friend have done to make you so angry? Hear the bat bashing into your friend’s body as the blood splashes onto your face.
reading_story: To make matters worse, your friend is completely nude (ぬ). So not only are you extracting pain and blood from your friend’s body, but also copious amounts of embarrassment. Why would you hit a nude? That’s just rude, dude.
reading_hint: Imagine your nude friend. Sear this image into your mind. Now beat it with a nailbat.

meaning_story: The fish and sheep are very fresh here. This is a great place to get fresh fish and fresh sheep. I kid you not.
meaning_hint: Imagine eating this fresh fish and fresh sheep. It’s the freshest you’ve ever tasted. Taste it on your tongue and experience how fresh it is.
reading_story: This place also serves fresh centaur (せん), but that’s just weird. Centaur is endangered and you don’t believe in eating endangered things. Even if they are incredibly fresh.
reading_hint: Can you imagine eating a fresh centaur? How weird would that be? Half of it is human-like, so you’d be like, a half cannibal. Weird, huh?

meaning_story: A tsunami hitting a bed of flowers will cause both the flowers and their leaves to become full of water. Tsunamis bring lots of water anywhere they go, so this tsunami will be sure to soak both the flowers and their leaves.
meaning_hint: Imagine being one of these flowers. You’re a bit thirsty so at first you’re excited about the tsunami. You can’t wait to be full of water. Imagine soaking up all the water you want until you’re full.
reading_story: Soon after you’re full of the water from the tsunami, you see a manatee (まん) floating over towards you and your flower friends. The tsunami must have carried him over here, and he looks hungry. The manatee starts to munch on you and your flower friends. Oh the humanity!
reading_hint: Just like you got full on the water, this manatee is now becoming full on you and the other flowers. Imagine being eaten alive by this manatee. Chomp chomp chomp. What a way to go.

meaning_story: A beggar lies sprawled on the ground so you give him some money. You feel bad for the beggar on the ground, so that’s why you decided to give him something.
meaning_hint: See the beggar on the ground. He’s writing in agony and moaning for help. Imagine how sad and pitiful he looks.
reading_story: When you set the money down next to the beggar he shouts, “No! I want a yo-yo (よ)!” so you go to the corner store and buy him a yo-yo with the money instead. You give the yo-yo to the beggar and he looks very happy.
reading_hint: Now watch as the beggar plays with the yo-yo you just gave him. He’s actually pretty good with it. See the beggar doing insane tricks with his new yo-yo as passersby give him change for his impressive yo-yo performance.

meaning_story: Taking a nailbat, you decide to create one grave and another grave, take two people by the toe, and hang them upside-down to beat them to death. Once the two people are dead, you can put them in the new graves you just made.
meaning_hint: Imagine hanging two people up by their toes and beating them with a nailbat. Hear their screams and pleas for mercy as you beat them over and over again.
reading_story: After, you hang them up by their toes and then run into them with your car (か). No mercy.
reading_hint: Why are you such a mean guy? Most guys wouldn’t beat people to death with their car. Why you gotta be like that?

meaning_story: A butcher wearing cleats wants to stab Wolverine in the heart, but Wolverine decided to hide instead of fight. Wolverine doesn’t usually hide, so you can imagine how scary this cleat wearing butcher is. The butcher has a bloodlust for Wolverine’s heart.
meaning_hint: Picture this butcher and his cleats searching for Wolverine so he can carve out his heart. Hear the cleats clack on the floor as he searches.
reading_story: The butcher thinks that Wolverine has committed a terrible crime that he must pay dearly for, but actually wolverine is innocent (いん). He’s innocent, so he decided to hide instead of fight. Fighting would just make the situation worse.
reading_hint: Wolverine is innocent. Picture Wolverine hiding and cowering in a corner, being all sad that someone doesn’t believe he’s innocent. It’s very strange to see Wolverine this way.

meaning_story: A tree grows next to a greenhouse enclosing an imitation of the tree. The imitation greenhouse tree wants to be big and impressive like the tree outside, so it does its very best imitation of a real tree.
meaning_hint: Look at this greenhouse tree struggle to grow big and strong like the wild tree outside. Hear its leaves shake and timber creak. How cute.
reading_story: The greenhouse tree realizes that its imitation will never be as good as the real thing. When it realizes this, the tree moans (も) aloud. The tree is still kinda tiny, so the moan isn’t very loud, but it is still pretty strange to witness. Speaking of witnesses, Bobo (ぼ) the clown sees this greenhouse tree moaning and decides to take it for his next clown show. Surely this miniature moaning tree can be worked into Bobo's next clown act.
reading_hint: Hear the little tree moaning at its pitiful imitation of a real tree. The greenhouse tree sounds very sad and you actually start to feel bad for it. Moan along with the tree in sympathy.

meaning_story: Now your mouth can include more words than ever before! With our new and improved “Mouth Now!” program, your mouth will include more words than you ever thought possible!
meaning_hint: Imagine how your repertoire of new words will impress all your friends and family. Don’t include them on your secret that you used the Mouth Now! program, just feel super smart with all the words you now know.
reading_story: If you buy now, we’ll also include a handful of books by Gandhi (がん) himself. Gandhi didn’t use our program, but we’re sure if he’d had the opportunity to, he would have used it. So buy now, and get the words of Gandhi in your hands as well as your mouth!
reading_hint: Since you bought the program, you also got the Gandhi books included with your order. Imagine yourself reading them and learning all about non-violent resistance. Fascinating.

meaning_story: Be careful what you say in public, otherwise you might face a lawsuit. People will sue you for just about anything these days, so you really need to watch what you say in public, otherwise you might find yourself with a lawsuit on your hands.
meaning_hint: What could you say in public that would get a lawsuit brought on against you? Think of something really offensive you could say and imagine yourself saying this in public and getting slapped with a lawsuit as consequence.
reading_story: With how easy it is to get a lawsuit brought on against you, you need to be extra careful what you say around the shogun (しょう) especially. This shogun is infamous for bringing lawsuits against people that just look at him the wrong way.
reading_hint: Imagine looking at the shogun and having him immediately slapping a lawsuit on you. This shogun kind of sucks, doesn't he?

meaning_story: A butcher who is good knows no limit. A butcher who is not good will have a limit – a point at which they can butcher no longer. However, a good butcher knows no such things, and has no limits.
meaning_hint: Witness this good butcher doing his thing endlessly and without limit. He can butcher for years and never feel fatigue. Hear his knives slicing and chopping on the cutting board with expert precision.
reading_story: This butcher is the product of generation (げん) after generation of good butchers, each of them without limit. Butchering is in his blood.
reading_hint: See this butcher standing proud as the spirits of butchers from every past generation circle around his, giving him strength. Every generation produces better and better butchers.

meaning_story: A moon who stays in bed all day every day will soon become obese. A healthy moon needs movement and exercise to stay fit and not become obese. If a moon stays in bed all day, they’ll be sure to grow obese over time.
meaning_hint: Imagine this moon in bed, slowly getting bigger and bigger, becoming more obese every day. Hear the sound of the bed creaking and cracking as the moon grows larger and larger.
reading_story: But once the moon gets obese enough, he turns into a super hero (ひ)! He is, super obese moon! The most obese hero in all of history.
reading_hint: Imagine super obese moon the super hero. His powers are rolling and sitting on things. See super obese moon in his little cape and marvel at the fact that he’s even capable of movement.

meaning_story: Music and beans are very plentiful here. The beans make you want to dance to the music and the music makes you want to eat beans. It’s a vicious cycle, so the beans and music must both be plentiful.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself dancing to the music while you gorge on beans. Both are so plentiful, how could you not enjoy them? Hear the music as you taste every variety of bean on your tongue.
reading_story: With the beans and music being so plentiful, you can’t see how this party could ever end. However, Harry Hou-dini (ほう) appears and takes all your beans and music before disappearing into thin air. Darn you and your tricks, Hou-dini!!
reading_hint: Hou-dini always ruins all of your fun. While you are quite impressed with his disappearing act, you are sad that your beans and music are gone. Feel bad that they are no longer plentiful.

meaning_story: A husband marries a husband while the sun goes down and the men replace their solitary lives with one of everlasting companionship. Instead of one husband and one wife, we have two husbands here. They shed their lives of bachelorhood and replace it with one of monogamy.
meaning_hint: See these two husbands as the sun sets under them. Listen to them each saying their vows, expressing how they could never replace one another.
reading_story: After the ceremony, the husband and his husband get in a car (か) and drive off into the sunset. They’ll never be able to replace this memory with anything. Truly it is the happiest day of these husbands’ lives.
reading_hint: See the husbands driving off into the sunset in their car. Hear the engine rumble as the car speeds off into the distance.

meaning_story: The sun rises over the capital building, creating a breathtaking scene. The sun is so bright and warm as it crests over the capital building. It’s quite the scene to behold.
meaning_hint: Picture this scene in your mind. Squint as the sun shines in your eyes and feel its warmth as it rises up and over the capital building.
reading_story: As the sun continues to rise, you see some silhouettes coming out of the capital building and heading your way. Upon closer inspection you see that they are all KKK (けい) members and they look angry. Not wanting to cause a scene or get caught up in anything unfortunate, you flee the scene.
reading_hint: It’s usually not a good idea to be associated with the KKK, so leave the scene. Imagine their white sheets casting a silhouette on the horizon.

meaning_story: A cobra with horns on a train coils around a sacred scroll, protecting it. This cobra has horns so it looks pretty intimidating. The scroll it's protecting is in transit on the train, and the cobra is doing a good job of safeguarding it so far.
meaning_hint: Imagine this horned cobra coiled around the scroll. It certainly acts as a deterrent to thievery. Hear the cobra hiss as you walk past the scroll.
reading_story: Really it's not the scroll the cobra is protecting though, it's what the scroll is wrapped around. When you knock the cobra away and open the scroll, three or four cans (かん) roll out. They were used to support the scroll so it wouldn't get squished.
reading_hint: You're crazy thirsty, though, so you go in and drink the cans of juice that the scroll was wrapped around.

meaning_story: While holding a nailbat you say humbly, “Stool, I don’t know where you are, but I’m going to search for you and I am going to kill you. I’m not doing it for fame or fortune and I do not think I am better than you. All I want is to murder you with this nailbat.”
meaning_hint: This stool has wronged you, so say the previous statement aloud. Imagine yourself holding a nailbat and visualize what you will do to this stool once you find it.
reading_story: You begin your search for the stool and soon after you find it. You smash its legs with your nailbat and then you sew (そう) its legs back on so you can bash them off again. It’s hard to sew wood back together but you think it’s worth the trouble.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself bashing the legs off the stool only to sew them back on again. Hear the crack and splinter of wood over and over again as you repeat this process.

meaning_story: Up in a tree you start your very own circus and you set up and care for everything all by yourself. This tree top circus is quite impressive, even more so since you set up all the tents and stuff all yourself. Also, you care for all the circus animals all on your own as well.
meaning_hint: Imagine this grandiose circus in the trees. See the bright colors and circus music and sounds way up in the tree as you admire your handiwork.
reading_story: Who are you to have created such an amazing piece of work? You are こういち, master of all things. こういち knows how to set up and care for a circus, even one as high tech and demanding as this tree top circus. こういち doesn’t mess around.
reading_hint: See こういち working on the set up for this circus in the trees. See こういち riding one of the elephants he cares for as the animal boots こういち up to put the finishing touches on the circus decorations.

meaning_story: The sun rises over the capital, shining down on you and your long hair, casting a large shadow on the ground behind you. You’re standing in front of your capital city, watching the sunrise. You have very long hair, so the shadow you cast is pretty impressive.
meaning_hint: Feel the sun shining down on you, warming your body as you turn around to view your shadow. Picture yourself dancing about and waving your long hair around and watching your shadow do as you do.
reading_story: Your capital city is really big on poker, so the top of the capital building has a huge sculpture of an ace (えい) on it. As the sun continues to rise you see the shadow of the large ace as well.
reading_hint: Now you have your shadow as well as the ace’s shadow to enjoy. Go over to the ace’s shadow and make strange shapes by combining the shadow of the ace with your own. How fun.

meaning_story: If you toss a thread into the mix, someone is bound to get strangled. Mix a few threads in with a few people and that thread is going to wrap itself around someone’s neck and strangle them. For sure.
meaning_hint: Imagine using a thread to strangle someone. It’s not pleasant. Imagine yourself getting strangled by a thread. Feel it wrapped around your windpipe. You’re dying slowly.
reading_story: Who would be so cruel as to use a piece of thread to strangle you? Well, こういち, that’s who. As we all know, こういち is a diabolical mastermind who also loves thread. Therefore you are getting strangled by こういち with a piece of thread. Lucky you.
reading_hint: Imagine looking at こういち as you get strangled with the thread. What kind of faces is he making? What is he saying to you? Picture this in your mind as you struggle to get free.

meaning_story: Say, if you have an axe with a drop of blood on it, you probably hit someone with it, which probably means someone is going to sue you for this heinous act. No one wants to be hit with an axe, and it would probably cause a lot of harm. I really wouldn’t be surprised if they say they want to sue you.
meaning_hint: Imagine being hit with an axe. Feel the splitting pain in your skull from such an injury. You’re going to sue them for all of their money! And more!
reading_story: You want to sue, but your lawyer is really so-so (そ). You're not sure if you'll be able to win with just a so-so lawyer, but he's all you can afford.
reading_hint: Imagine this so-so lawyer in court. Imagine him fumbling the case and causing your attempt at suing to be unsuccessful. This so-so lawyer just cost you a lot of money.

meaning_story: There is a pelican at your wedding. He is there as a supplement to the guests because not enough people came.
meaning_hint: It's weird that you didn't hire more people to supplement as extra guests, but pelicans are much cheaper.
reading_story: Along with pelicans to supplement your wedding guests, you also bought a ton of hoes (ほ). They are all around your wedding, standing there.
reading_hint: Imagine your wedding. A few people, and then twenty pelicans and twenty hoes. They supplement your lack of guests. You feel sad you don't have more friends, but luckily they don't know that because you have so many pelicans and hoes at your wedding.

meaning_story: A tsunami carries a hick and a stool atop it. In fact, the hick is sitting on the stool like it's a seat in a subway. This is his form of transit.
meaning_hint: The hick is sitting on a stool just like he's on a form of mass transit. What a weird image to have in your mind.
reading_story: What kind of transit is he riding on? Water (わた) transit.
reading_hint: Maybe when the tsunami stops at the next station you'll take the water transit for a ride yourself.

meaning_story: Next to a nailbat stand, there is a woman who hopes to adjoin herself with a nailbat. This woman wants to defend herself from attacks at any time and thinks that having a nailbat permanently adjoined to her is the obvious solution.
meaning_hint: Pretend you are this woman eyeing up this nailbat stand. Picture what it would be like having a nailbat adjoined to you. Like, having a nailbat instead of an arm or something.
reading_story: Unfortunately, it seems like this clinic will only adjoin things in sets (せつ). So, the woman has to get two nailbats, or none at all. The woman has never been a big fan of sets, and would like to keep both her arms, but she decides to go through with the procedure anyway.
reading_hint: Imagine having a set of nailbats instead of a set of arms. How terrible would that be? Not only would you not be able to pick anything up, but you’d probably also accidently hurt yourself and others with the nailbats like all the time. Not a good choice.

meaning_story: Uh oh, looks like a leaf injured the accident prone elephant again. This elephant has had really bad luck with leaves lately, it’s been getting cut left and right these past few weeks. This time, it was really bad though – the elephant got one of his legs cut off.
meaning_hint: Imagine what crazy thing this elephant would have had to have done to get its leg cut off by a leaf. Something ridiculous, no doubt. And that’s why this elephant radical is slightly modified – he’s missing a leg.
reading_story: Oh, dear – looks like the elephant has done it again. He’s just cut his other leg off. Wait, this time he did it himself. He used a saw (さ) to saw it off! Man, we need to watch this elephant more carefully. Sigh (さい). There goes my zookeeper bonus this year.
reading_hint: Imagine this elephant sawing off his own leg. What is wrong with this elephant? Now sigh out loud. This elephant is really difficult to take care of. Sigh, sigh, sigh.

meaning_story: There once was an animal with an insect friend who felt very alone unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other.
meaning_hint: Imagine this animal and this insect. Let’s say it’s a flea and a dog. Imagine them going everywhere together. To the park, getting ice cream, even the drive in movie theater. They’re inseparable.
reading_story: One activity that the animal can never do alone is solve Sudoku (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team.
reading_hint: Picture this animal with the insect on his head doing a Sudoku. See the insect hopping around on the animals head shouting answers and suggestions into the animal’s ear. How cute.

meaning_story: On the grass near a rice paddy sits a creeper that is some sort of a dog beast, a vicious animal. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet. Also it’s a creeper.
meaning_hint: This dog beast animal thing is really creeping you out. It’s smiling at you all weird and making sensual groaning and moaning sounds. Eww.
reading_story: Probably the strangest thing about this animal beast creeper is that he only creeps on you if you’re a Jew (じゅう). The dog really likes to creep on Jews. If you’re not a Jew, he’ll probably leave you alone. If you are a Jew, be prepared to get creeped on by this dog beast.
reading_hint: Why does this animal have a Jewish person fetish? I’m not sure, but it makes me uncomfortable. Imagine it makes you uncomfortable as well. Just imagine the dirty thoughts this Jew loving beast creeper has while it hides in the grass near the rice paddy.

meaning_story: You take some flowers and some fruit and you make a cake out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations.
meaning_hint: Look at this cake you have made. It’s majestic. Now taste some of it. It is one great tasting cake. Imagine yourself eating the best cake in all of ever.
reading_story: You’re standing back, admiring your cake when you hear a car (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car!
reading_hint: Hear the roar of the car engine as you get splattered in the face with the cake. Wipe it off of your face just in time to see the car speeding off into the distance. Also, recall that this kanji shares a reading with the similar kanji, 果.

meaning_story: They say using measurement device (like a ruler) is a good way to chastise someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anywhere! They say the uses for measurement devices are pretty much unlimited when it comes to chastising people.
meaning_hint: Imagine being chastised with a measurement device. Think how horrible it would be getting hit on your knuckles, your nose, or your eyes. It would be awful. Imagine this experience.
reading_story: The reason you are being chastised this time is because you traveled to Tokyo (とう) without permission. To chastise you, you’ve been slapped on the knuckles with the measurement device in front of Tokyo Tower. Hopefully this will teach you a lesson.
reading_hint: Imagine being slapped in front of Tokyo Tower. The view is pretty awesome, but your knuckles really hurt.

meaning_story: You become old in the winter due to circumstance. In the winter, your body gets cold and your joints get all stiff and rickety. This is also what happens when you get old. Due to circumstance, your body gets old in the winter.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself standing outside in winter time. You’re very cold so your movement is stiff and awkward and your joints hurt. It’s just like being old.
reading_story: This particular circumstance takes you back to when you were a 子 (こ). When you were a little 子, you never thought you’d get old, even in the circumstance of winter. Your joints were young and limber and the cold of winter had little effect on you. A circumstance is also a reason we're in this situation.
reading_hint: But as you get older, the effects of winter make you feel older and older, very far removed from feeling like a 子 again. Imagine yourself as a rickety old dude out in the cold, reminiscing about the days when you were a 子.

meaning_story: Your new car doesn’t mix well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark contrast to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast.
meaning_hint: Imagine this garage of yours with a sea of white cars. Now there is a new car that really sticks out like a sore thumb. Imagine yourself looking out over your cars and seeing this wacky car practically jumping out at you.
reading_story: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a peacock (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark contrast to like, every other car out there.
reading_hint: See yourself driving around in this peacock car. Hear the engine purr as strangers jeer and yell at you. This car sure does get a lot of attention, doesn’t it?

meaning_story: Atop your water slide, you announce your plans to create a waterpark around it. This water slide was the first thing you created, and now you plan to create a waterpark all around it.
meaning_hint: See yourself standing on top of this super tall water slide, making your announcement. Look at how far up you are! Announce your plans as you try not to look down for fear of falling.
reading_story: Before you create this park for your water slide, you need to come up with a name. You decide on The Splash Zone (ぞう). Not surprisingly, Splash Zone has already been taken, but you really want the name to include “zone” in it, so you try and think of something else.
reading_hint: What would be a good name for a waterpark that includes the word “zone”? Try and think of a good one to help you remember the reading for this kanji.

meaning_story: On a roof, while holding a flag in your mouth, you crack your ribs trying to create a majestic looking house. You crack your ribs by falling off the roof. You want to stick the flag on top of your house to make it look all cool like, but you need to hold the flag in your mouth while climbing.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself trying to create this wondrous, patriotic roof scene. Taste the metal flag pole in your mouth as you feel yourself falling off of the roof and cracking your ribs on impact. You’re in a lot of pain. The flag radical is sort of a double flag, so just think of it as the flag breaking on impact along with your ribs.
reading_story: Even though you fell down and broke everything, you’re still determined to create your masterpiece. Since the flag got ruined in the fall, you need to sew (そう) it back together before you continue on.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself sewing the flag back together. Picture your country’s flag, and imagine yourself sewing it back into one piece.

meaning_story: You loiter around, waiting for your master to depart. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself loitering around your master’s fancy mansion. You’re pretending to dust things off, but actually you’re just loitering about waiting for him to depart. Imagine carrying a feather duster around as you wait.
reading_story: It’s time for your master to depart. OHHHHHHHHH (おう) YEAAAAAHHHH!!! Party time! Oh yeah!
reading_hint: Say “oh yeah” out loud. Really get excited about it because now that your master has departed you can do whatever you want!

meaning_story: On the edge of a cliff, ten thousand people use their power of persuasion and encourage you to jump off. The power of ten thousand voices is pretty encouraging, even if you’re being encouraged to hop off a cliff.
meaning_hint: However, you have a parachute, so it’s not that bad. Imagine jumping off of this cliff, feeling the rush as the ten thousand people encourage and cheer you on.
reading_story: However, one of the ten thousand people actually wants you to die so he whips out a death ray (れい) and shoots at you with it. He misses, and the other people encourage him to stop shooting at you, but he continues to fire his death ray at you again and again.
reading_hint: You’re floating to the ground and death ray rays are firing past you left and right. Hear the crowd of people shouting and trying to encourage the shooter to stop as you continue to dodge the rays.

meaning_story: A tsunami that is white, traveling in the direction of winter is a fierce and violent force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white – it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence.
meaning_hint: Imagine this white tsunami, more violent and fierce than any other tsunami you’ve ever seen. It’s very frightening. Feel the cold wetness it brings to your skin.
reading_story: You know the musician Beck, right? Well he has a grandfather named Geck (げき), and Geck is the only man who can stop this great white tsunami and save the world from its fierce and violent ways. In Geck we trust!
reading_hint: Imagine Geck, the old musician, getting right up next to the violent tsunami and taming it with his music. Hear the soothing but powerful melodies Geck is conjuring out of thin air. Impressive.

meaning_story: The fortune radical and the fortune kanji are exactly the same! But it also means occupy as well, so don’t forget that. Fortune and occupy both occupy the same radical.
meaning_hint: Just remember that his kanji also means occupy and you’ll be just fine.
reading_story: To occupy some free time you have, you go and get your fortune told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a centaur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true!
reading_hint: Imagine getting your fortune told by a centaur fortune teller. Do you trust this mythical beast to know your future? Watch him manipulate his crystal ball as his hooves stomp the ground beneath him.

meaning_story: A butcher who tries to stand too early will hinder his ability to stay standing. You know how sometimes when you stand up too fast you get light headed and woozy? That’s what’s happening to this butcher here.
meaning_hint: Stand up real fast. Did you feel dizzy? Maybe, maybe not. Either way, focus on this action and this feeling of dizziness and how it can hinder your ability to function. Also imagine you’re a butcher.
reading_story: Being a butcher is just this guy’s side job though. His main gig is being a shogun (しょう). The real reason he is having trouble standing is because someone poisoned him to hinder his ability to walk. The shogun has been poisoned and now he looks dizzy whenever he walks.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as this shogun/butcher. You feel dizzy all the time and your ability to walk is always hindered. Imagine trying to walk places, always being afraid that you’re going to fall over. It would be lousy.

meaning_story: Your ego... it's totally out of control. I mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's me. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego.
meaning_hint: Just keep going with this sentence about the ego. You can't stop, because really it's your ego that's out of control. That's I when you're saying it.
reading_story: I am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says 'ga (が) ga ga ga!'
reading_hint: You're just destroying the ego of that other guy. 'Why?' you ask? 'Because I am the boss here. And you are the baby. Ego things.'

radicals: 山, 王, 夂, 彳
meaning_story: If you loiter on a mountain with a king in the winter, it’s a good indication that this is a sign he favors you. The king doesn’t let just anyone loiter around with him atop a mountain in winter. You should be proud.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself atop this mountain with the king in winter. It’s very cold and windy, but you feel very happy as this is the first sign of affection the king has shown you.
reading_story: Truly this is a sign, an indication sent from above that you have finally made it in life, that you are cool enough to get in good with the king, you’re so happy you could die! And then evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) comes along and pushes you off the mountain. You die. Dammit, Mrs. Chou! Why you gotta ruin everything like that?
reading_hint: Imagine falling off a mountain like this. It’s really steep and the fall will surely kill you. Visualize yourself falling to your doom, cursing Mrs. Chou all the way.

meaning_story: Holding a bloody nailbat, you accept it as a means to instruct students. The nailbat is very effective at disciplining students that aren’t paying attention when you instruct.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as an instructor, attempting to instruct and enlighten your students. One of them is being a nuisance and distracting all the others. So, you take your nailbat and beat the crap out of him until he behaves. Imagine yourself doing this.
reading_story: While you're smashing your student with the nailbat, you hear a strange sipping sound. You look away from the crumpled mass of student you were beating, and see a student sipping on a small juice (じゅ) box. The nerve. You are meant to instruct these students, not let them sip juice loudly. You turn towards him, nailbat raised, "Do you have enough for everyone?" Still sipping, the student opens his bag to reveal it's full of little juice boxes.
reading_hint: Picture yourself beating the snot out of your student and being interrupted by the sound of another student sipping on a tiny juice box. But he had plenty of juice for the rest of your class. You decided to forgo the nailbat, accepted a juice box from the student, and you're sipping it while instructing the rest of the class on proper straw usage.

meaning_story: You hold gold fins in your mouth while shopping for pencil lead at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, and your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine having these gold fins in your mouth. Taste the metal as your tongue runs over them. At least you don’t have lead in your mouth – wouldn’t wanna get lead poisoning.
reading_story: The lead you’re buying isn’t for you, actually. It’s for your ent (えん) friends. They sent you to this special ent shop, and that’s why the payment system is all messed up.
reading_hint: Imagine what this ent shop would look like. It’s probably all tree-like and earthy, like being inside a forest indoors. Imagine what this would be like as you continue to shop for the lead.

meaning_story: A car had to go to the butcher so it could be sent in the mail. The car was too big for the shipping box, so the butcher had to chop it up so it was shorter on the tips. Now it can fit in the mail.
meaning_hint: Pretend you are the butcher chopping this car up for the mail. Feel the cleaver in your hand and hear the sound of metal being butchered away. Keep in mind that the car radical in this kanji is shorter on the tips, and that’s because you butchered it for the mail.
reading_story: Who is the butcher? You (ゆう) are. You are the butcher. And you need to mail this car to your friend in Japan. You are a good friend.
reading_hint: You are very kind to send your friend the car, even if it is butchered a bit. Continue butchering the car, but concentrate on thinking about you and how great you are.

meaning_story: In a gold cross, you see a needle sticking out of it. Right in the middle of the gold cross, there’s a needle. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest.
meaning_hint: Picture this golden cross in your head. Why do you suppose there’s this needle stuck in it. You try to pull it out but you can’t. Envision yourself straining and stressing trying to get the thing out.
reading_story: Just when you’re about to give up on trying to remove the needle, Harry (はり) Potter shows up and works some magic to remove the needle from the cross. Thanks, Harry! You’re like, super helpful.
reading_hint: That was really nice of Harry to help us out with removing that needle. Picture Harry Potter in your head and imagine him yelling a spell incantation to remove the needle from the cross. Harry takes the gold as a reward.

meaning_story: If you loiter around a demon lord with horns, the demon would be correct to assume that you’ll obey his every command. This horned creature is the devil and he wants you to obey him.
meaning_hint: Entranced by the devil’s power, you’ve been loitering around him for a while. Now you are completely under his spell and have no choice to obey him. Imagine yourself being forced to carry out the commands of the devil whether you like it or not. What do you think he’d have you do?
reading_story: Unfortunately for the devil, you are actually a Jew (じゅう) with super demon fighting powers. Using your Jew superpowers, you turn the tables and force the devil to obey you! You force the devil to sing and dance for your entertainment.
reading_hint: Even if you're not actually a Jew, imagine that you are, and feel the yarmulka atop your head as you command the devil to obey you. Think what else you should have him do as he sings and dances.

meaning_story: On the moon, it’s easy to turn a pig into pork. The low gravity of the moon makes the whole process much easier and cost efficient. Soon, all the pig farming will be done on the moon and there will never be a pork shortage ever again.
meaning_hint: Imagine going to a pig farm/restaurant on the moon. You’re in a space suit, eating some space pork. It’s delicious. Imagine the best pork you’ve ever had. This is better than that.
reading_story: At this particular pig restaurant, they have a secret ingredient that goes onto their pork. Lots and lots of butter (ぶた). Okay, so it’s not that big of a secret. But boy is it delicious. Mmm, butter.
reading_hint: Butter and pork. A match made in heaven! Imagine yourself scarfing down this buttered pork by the pound. You’re stuffed, but you have to eat more. It’s soooo gooood.

meaning_story: You loiter around a black hole. You're waiting for the black hole to finish its process of sucking everything up, because when it's done, you'll hit a button and the black hole will shoot all its sucked in data back out and you'll be able to restore everything to the way it was before.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself waiting and waiting. You want to hurry up and restore things to the way they were before because it's really boring when there's nothing but a black hole.
reading_story: When the black hole is done sucking everything in it's time. You hit the restore button but nothing happens. You were lied to. 'F@#$ YOOOOU (ふく)!' you yell.
reading_hint: Now you're left with nothing. This is why you feel so angry at everything.

meaning_story: During a tsunami, your lip ring is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a river. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring.
meaning_hint: Imagine how painful this would be, having your lip ring ripped from your lip. It would hurt a lot. Touch your lip and imagine missing half of it. Yikes.
reading_story: But why were you trying to cross this river anyway? Well your car (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself fording the river, all wet and cold from the water. Keeping your eyes on your car, you move slowly across. Look at the car. Look at it!

meaning_story: A clam takes a helmet and by hammer and nail, fastens it over his life savings. The helmet acts as a makeshift safe for the savings, protecting them from any would be thieves. The nails aren’t totally immovable, but it’s better than nothing.
meaning_hint: Picture this miserly clam, putting all his savings in a helmet and nailing it to the ground. Hear the tink of hammer on nail as he secures his savings.
reading_story: After he’s secured his savings, the clam realizes he accidently left the keys to his car under the helmet as well. Oh no! Also, the clam doesn’t have any power tools so he ends up trying to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pry each nail out of the helmet to regain access to his things.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as the clam, trying to pry out nails with chopsticks. It’d be practically impossible. See yourself trying to do it and getting very frustrated in the process.

meaning_story: Taking an egg, you stamp your official seal of approval onto the document. Your seal is like a normal seal, but with an egg. It’s kind of a messy stamping process, actually.
meaning_hint: Imagine you have an envelope that you need to seal. Now get an egg, put it down and take a wax stamp and press it into the egg and onto the envelope. Sealed! Except now you have egg and wax all over your hands. Sticky.
reading_story: Your sister accuses you of using her bathroom towel, you claim you are innocent (いん), but she shows you the towel where there is wax and egg residue. Since you are the only one who uses a seal consisting of those things, there is no way you can claim innocence.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself wiping your gooey hands on your sister’s towel. You thought you could get away with it, that you’d be seen as innocent, but you didn’t think ahead, now did you.

meaning_story: You take a nailbat and you hit Superman with it, causing the ground to shake while you wave goodbye to Superman. The nailbat that you have is actually made out of kryptonite, so hitting Superman with it causes his body to shake, in turn causing the ground to rumble and shake. Wave bye-bye Superman, bye-bye.
meaning_hint: Feel the ground shake beneath you as you wave goodbye to Superman. Hear him screaming out in pain as his body falls apart in front of you.
reading_story: As you continue to wave goodbye and the ground continues to shake, you decide that this isn’t going quickly enough. So you take your nailbat and hit Superman in the shin (しん). And then the other shin. That’ll speed things up.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself cracking Superman in the shins with the nailbat. Superman howls in pain once again. “Not my shin! Ohhh, the pain!”

meaning_story: A tree with a human head wants to find some ribs to stab. This tree is a deranged serial killer with a human head for a disguise. He kills his victims by stabbing them in the ribs and taking their heads.
meaning_hint: This tree is after you. Imagine him chasing you and holding you down right before he stabs you between the ribs. Ohh, the pain.
reading_story: While the tree is trying to stab you again, you flail around trying to get him off of you. While thrashing about, you knock the tree over and realize that the tree is actually a costume and it’s Charlie Sheen (し) inside of it! Charlie Sheen was disguised as a tree disguised as a human! But why is he stabbing people?
reading_hint: Why would Charlie Sheen feel such a desire to stab people in the ribs? Perhaps he’s all cracked out on drugs. Picture Charlie Sheen and how crazy he is.

meaning_story: In a hole, you see a big guy who looks like he wants to stab you. You don’t want him to stab you, so you make sure not to fall into the big hole that houses the big guy that wants to stab you big time.
meaning_hint: Look at this hole – it’s like, super big. The guy is really big. They’re terrifying enough on their own, but put them together and you’ve got a big problem. You feel very afraid of this hole and getting stabbed. Just don’t fall in, okay?
reading_story: You fall in the big hole. What did I just tell you not to do!? He’s totes (とつ) going to stab you for sure. Totes.
reading_hint: This big guy inside the big hole is totes going to stab you. Why did you fall in?? Feel the big guy press you up against the wall of the hole as he begins to stab you repeatedly.

meaning_story: You see a fish stick poking out of a tombstone looking suspicious. How did this fish stick get here? What does it have to do with this tombstone? Very suspicious indeed.
meaning_hint: Ponder over this fish stick sticking out of the tombstone and how suspicious it is. Why would someone stick it there? Maybe it was aliens.
reading_story: Even more suspicious is a coyote (かい) lurking behind the tombstone, in the coyote’s mouth, you see half of a KKK member. I guess you could call him K-point-five (け). Short K? Mini K? I dunno, there’s a joke in here somewhere.
reading_hint: Think of a funny name for this half of a KKK member incorporating the letter K for certain ease in remembering how to read this kanji. And then think of that ex-KKK member in the mouth of the coyote looking suspicious.

meaning_story: During a tsunami, your antenna start to sweat you’re so nervous. You’re just a little tiny bug with antenna, how are you supposed to escape with your life when a tsunami is headed right for you. You’re sweating all over, even your antenna.
meaning_hint: Imagine being so nervous that you’re sweating profusely. Now imagine what it would be like to have antenna. Those are sweating too.
reading_story: Sweat. Sweat everywhere. From your antenna to the crack of your ass (あせ), there is sweat. Eww, ass sweat. Sorry you had to imagine that.
reading_hint: But imagine it again! Embrace the sweaty ass. Press your mind firmly into it so you remember how to read this kanji!

meaning_story: Out of bamboo, you make a brush – a writing brush. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself using this bamboo writing brush. Do you know many kanji? Of course you do! Imagine yourself writing them all with this nice writing brush. It’s actually fun to write things with it!
reading_story: Once the writing brush hits (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on!
reading_hint: Imagine the sound the brush makes when it hits the paper. It’s a bit of a plop, and then kind of a scratching sound as the brush bristles move around. Really focus on this sound that the brush makes when it hits the paper.

meaning_story: A woman sitting on a stool with a broken heart is very angry. She had her heart broken by some jerk and now she’s sitting on the stool, just stewing over the guy and how angry she is with him.
