meaning_hint: This woman is so angry! Pretend you are the woman. Sit on your stool and feel your heart, painful in your chest, as you fume and think about how angry you are.
reading_story: They guy who broke your heart and made you so angry was such a dog (ど). He cheated on you multiple times, with your mother and your sister! What a dog!
reading_hint: You’re so angry! Imagine your ex as being an actual dog and picture yourself hitting it right in the face with your stool. Hear the dog whimpering in pain as you demolish it.

meaning_story: In the summer sun, you slide down twenty stories only to ascend stairs back up and do it all over again. The sun is pretty hot, so sliding down twenty stories on the slide feels really good with the fresh air and everything. Ascending the twenty stories back up? Not as much fun.
meaning_hint: Feel the air blowing against your body, cooling you down as you slide on the slide. What a fun ride. Now imagine climbing up twenty floors or stairs in the hot sun. Is it worth it?
reading_story: Who would ever build a slide this tall? Who would want to ascend it again and again, just to slide back down? Well, the shogun (しょう) built it for his kids. And since the shogun is so rich, they have an exclusive elevator only available for use by the shogun and his family. That way they don’t have to ascend stairs, they can just take the lift.
reading_hint: Imagine again climbing up the stairs, only this time you see the shogun’s elevator zoom past you. Hear the shogun and his family making fun of you for having to ascend the building like a peasant.

meaning_story: If you go down a water slide filled with rice, all the kernels are going to be thrown astray. If you go flying down that water slide and run into that rice, it’s definitely going to fly out of the water slide from the impact. Rice will be flying astray all over the place.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself rocketing down this water slide and running into a pile of rice. Bam! Rice flies everywhere.
reading_story: This water slide is on a boat called the Mayflower (めい), and by knocking all the rice astray, you just destroyed a large percentage of the Mayflower’s food supply. Uh oh.
reading_hint: The captain of the Mayflower is not happy with you. All of the rice is now in the ocean because of you. Imagine the Mayflower’s captain shouting at you and cussing you out for this irresponsible thing you have done.

meaning_story: Threatening to hit you with a nailbat and a sword in the mouth, the shogun and his council beckon you. You’d better come when they beckon, or else you’re going to get hit in the mouth with a nailbat and a sword.
meaning_hint: Imagine what would happen if you don’t come when they beckon you. Bam! Nailbat to the mouth! Bam! Sword to the mouth! You’re dead, man.
reading_story: Wait, who was the one who wanted to beckon you? Oh yeah, the shogun (しょう). The shogun is beckoning you and you better come if you don’t want to die.
reading_hint: Imagine the shogun as he beckons you see him all dressed up in his court garb as he waves his big hands in a motion to beckon you to him.

meaning_story: Next to the moon is a black hole about to suck the moon into its belly, its abdomen of despair and nothingness. The black hole is hungry and wants the moon inside its abdomen. “Get in my belly!” the black hole shouts.
meaning_hint: Picture this black hole as a self-aware, hungry creature. The black hole is really hungry for that moon and wants it in his belly. See the black hole smacking and licking his lips as he rubs his abdomen in anticipation.
reading_story: When the moon sees the black hole rubbing its abdomen and telling the moon to get in its belly, the moon shouts, "F@#$ (ふく) you!!!" No one tells the moon to do anything it doesn't want to do!
reading_hint: Picture this black hole trying to suck the moon into its belly as the moon shouts "F@#$ YOU F@#$ YOU!" Over and over.

meaning_story: Your eyes start to close as you drive your car because you’re getting drowsy. This is a very dangerous way to drive your car, especially since your car is missing its top and its bottom. This is no time to be getting drowsy. Keep your eyes open and drive for your life!
meaning_hint: Feel yourself getting drowsy as you drive this goofy car. You’re so tired. Struggle to keep your eyes open. Also visualize this car missing its top and its bottom because the car radical is modified.
reading_story: The reason you’re so drowsy, and also the reason your car is missing part of its bottom, is because you took one of the car’s tires and made a tire swing (すい) out of it. You’d been swinging on the tire swing all day and now you’re super drowsy and worn out.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself swinging on this tire swing. You’ve been swinging for a while and you’re getting really drowsy.

meaning_story: Setting up a stand on the top of a mountain, you rake all the rocks to the edge of it. You want to clear the area around your stand, so you get your rake out and you rake all the stones and debris away from the stand and toward the edge of the mountain top. It also creates a small barrier around the edge as well.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself at the top of the mountain, holding the rake in your hands. Look over the edge. Feel the sinking feeling in your stomach as you realize how high up you really are.
reading_story: You set up this stand at the top of the mountain so you could give a speech to the world. But you need to look your best, so you decide to get a tan (たん). You lay next to the edge of the mountain, and prepare to tan. Everyone likes a person with a healthy tan.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself at the edge of this mountain getting your tan on. Feel the sun beating down on you and feel the fresh mountain breeze blowing over your body. It’s very relaxing.

radicals: 一, 口, 木, 又
meaning_story: A tree with a mouth eats a beggar and his stool, which were on the ground next to him, which seems to be a bit extreme, don't you think?
meaning_hint: The beggar was just sitting there on a stool! Why so extreme?
reading_story: Unfortunately we still haven’t come up with a good reading for きょく, but just try and remember this reading as Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z and his strange step brother Kyoku (きょく). Goku and Kyoku are the beggars in this story, the ones performing all the extremes. First Goku gets eaten by the tree with the mouth, and then Kyoku gets eaten as well.
reading_hint: You know Goku from Dragon Ball, right? Imagine him doing all sorts of extreme things. Then imagine his less impressive brother, Kyoku, also doing extremes. And then they get eaten by the tree.

meaning_story: Every good butcher is a guy. Guys make the best butchers. A guy butcher is a good butcher.
meaning_hint: Is this sexist? Maybe. Use that to remember this kanji.
reading_story: Also, compared to a girl, a guy can eat way more roe (ろう). I mean, I don’t like roe and that’s why I don’t eat a lot, but guys can definitely eat more roe than girls.
reading_hint: Picture a bunch of guys trying to prove that they can eat more roe than their girlfriends. Watch the girls roll their eyes and walk away. Watch the guys eat the roe anyway because it’s delicious.

meaning_story: Having a mullet, you take a brush and stroke it with water for your health. Mullets take lots of care to remain healthy, so it is important to brush it every day and keep it moisturized with water.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself with a mullet. Take your brush and brush your luxurious mane and then splash some water on it. You are the epitome of health.
reading_story: Who do you know that is the perfect example of health? Well, that’s こういち. こういち has grown a mullet for his health, and now he’s the healthiest man you know.
reading_hint: Imagine こういち with a mullet. To imagine him being healthy, picture him and his mullet lifting weights and drinking protein shakes. So much health!

meaning_story: The leader you know as Big Bird uses a brush to make sure his feathers stay healthy. Big Bird is your leader, and Big Bird wants to look his best for his followers so he uses a brush to keep his feathers healthy and shiny.
meaning_hint: Picture your leader Big Bird brushing his body with a brush. Hear the sound of the brush running over his yellow feathers and see them gleam with shine.
reading_story: While Big Bird is the current leader, he also has a rival. Big Bird’s rival is Ken (けん) from Street Fighter. Ken doesn’t like when Big Bird appears so healthy because then Big Bird gets more support, so Ken decides to get in a fight with Big Bird and beat him up so he no longer appears healthy.
reading_hint: Imagine Ken busting into Big Bird’s room, taking his brush, and beating him senseless with it. Imagine what Bid Bird would look like after this beating. He certainly does not look so healthy anymore.

meaning_story: They say pine stairs like to invite people to walk on them. They say that pine stairs enjoy being stepped on, so it makes sense that the pine stairs would invite people to do so.
meaning_hint: Imagine hearing a set of pine stairs invite you to walk on them. They coax you over in haunting voices that you can’t resist. Feel the pine under your feet as you ascend the stairs.
reading_story: Who are the pine stairs trying to invite? You (ゆう). They want you. You and no one else. You are the only one fit to walk on the pine stairs so that is why you are being invited.
reading_hint: Hear the pine stairs chanting at you, “We want you! We want you!”

meaning_story: You substitute a clam for collateral so your friend will lend you some money. Normally he would ask for something more valuable, but you’ve convinced him to substitute a clam for what he would normally take as collateral when lending to people.
meaning_hint: Imagine this exchange. Your friend is going to lend you money in exchange for a clam. Hand your friend the clam and take the money he’s lending you. Feel the clam and the lent money in your hands.
reading_story: You want your friend to lend you some money so you can buy yourself a car (か). You need money and a car a lot more than you need this clam, so you’re happy to put it up as collateral for the loan.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in this new car that you got with the money your friend lent you. Hear the roar of the engine and feel the wind in your hair.

meaning_story: A drunkard creeper has a heart that is terribly misguided. To make matters worse, the creeper is upside down. This creeper is also a drunkard, and his heart has a misguided love for alcohol. He’s so drunk right now that he thinks down is up and up is down and that’s why he is upside down.
meaning_hint: Imagine this creeper creeping on some alcohol. See him stroking a bottle of alcohol as he expresses his misguided love for it.
reading_story: This creepy misguided drunkard really likes to listen to the American rapper Waka (わく) Flocka. If you don’t know who Waka is, take the time to YouTube a song of his to get the Waka beat flowin’ through your body.
reading_hint: Now imagine the drunkard creeping on his bottle of alcohol while he listens to some Waka Flocka. Hear the song in your head as you observe the drunkard’s misguided behavior.

meaning_story: A sick mama needs an elephant doctor to treat her pain. The sick mama has a strange sickness that had been forgotten by most doctors, but not the elephant doctors, because elephants never forget. This elephant doctor will know how to alleviate the sick mama’s pain.
meaning_hint: Imagine this elephant treating the sick mama and getting rid of the pain that ails her. See the elephant in a little doctor outfit with like a stethoscope and everything. Hear the elephant trumpet his trunk as he treats the sick mama’s pain.
reading_story: The mama’s pain was too (つう) much for a human doctor to heal but not too big for an elephant doctor. Nothing is too big for an elephant.
reading_hint: See the elephant treating the pain of the sick mama. Imagine the human doctors shaking their head in shame as the pain was just too much for them to contain.

kunyomi: しりぞ, ひ, ど, の
meaning_story: A water slide is a good way to retreat. It’s fast, efficient, and super fun. What better way to retreat from anything than by using a good ol’ water slide?
meaning_hint: Imagine using this water slide to retreat. See yourself speeding down the wet water slide as you shout, “See ya, suckers!”
reading_story: Just when you thought you’d made a safe retreat, you see a tie (たい) fighter flying overhead. A tie fighter?? Really? Where did that come from?
reading_hint: Now you’re going to have to make another retreat. I dunno if a water slide is going to cut it this time. Imagine sliding away as the tie fighter speeds after you, shooting lasers all the way.

meaning_story: You can use a water slide when you have a surplus of water and need a route to travel. Having a surplus of water allows you to use the water slide since you don’t have to feel bad about wasting any, and a water slide is a fast and fun route to get where you’re going.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself taking this water slide route. Where are you going? Imagine your destination and the scenery you’ll see along the route as you feel the surplus of water all around you.
reading_story: You’re really enjoying this scenic route when all of a sudden you stub your toe (と) on a protruding portion of the water slide. It really hurts. Your toe is bleeding. Worst. Trip. Ever.
reading_hint: Feel your toe’s pain. It really smarts. Hold your toe in your hands and feel it throbbing painfully.

meaning_story: Platinum thread will suit you well if you have an exorbitant salary. Having a salary this high means you can afford the most expensive thread in the world. This thread suits you well since you’re so wealthy.
meaning_hint: Imagine how much something sewn out of this expensive thread would cost. Now imagine wearing that expensive thing. Would it suit you? Of course it would, your salary is outrageous.
reading_story: Like I said, your large salary allows for you to have garments sewn from pricey thread. The fabric however, is made from the hides of cute (きゅう) rabbits. I know cute rabbit hide clothing may sound kind of messed up, but this is high fashion – you wouldn’t understand.
reading_hint: Take a look at this outfit sewn from platinum thread and cute rabbit hide. Does it suit you? Would you wear it? Imagine what It must feel like. Touch the smooth hide and fuzzy fur from the cute rabbits.

meaning_story: In the capital city, a broken dog begins to settle in. This dog used to live in the country, but he kept getting caught in bear and fox traps which busted the poor dog up. The dog didn’t want to live like this, so he decided to settle in the capital city where there aren’t pesky animal traps to get caught in.
meaning_hint: Imagine this dog going to the capital and settling in. The poor dog looks pretty messed up though. The radical for dog in this kanji is a bit modified, so just remember that the dog in this story is all messed up.
reading_story: Just when the dog was about to settle in, it gets shot by a shooter (しゅう). The shooter is from animal control, and this dog was a stray, so the shooter put him down. Most of the time, the dog will get caught and caged first, but this shooter thinks that takes too much time.
reading_hint: Imagine this poor dog looking happy about being in the capital and finally settling in. And then the dog gets shot by a shooter. This is a really sad story.

meaning_story: Take your leather and change it in to shoes.
meaning_hint: You start with a sheet of leather. Now imagine yourself going through the process of changing them to shoes. Smell the leather and feel it, too.
reading_story: Some shoes aren’t made from leather anymore these days, but you know who always wears shoes made of leather? Old coots (くつ). Old coots are so old that the only shoes they wore growing up were made from leather so they refuse to wear any shoes that aren’t made from leather. Crazy old coots.
reading_hint: Imagine some of these old coots busting into a modern shoe store and kicking over all the display stands and setting everything on fire because they hate non leather shoes so much. Hear the old coots screaming and babbling nonsense as they destroy the store.

meaning_story: Closing each eye is something that the peoples do before they sleep. The peoples can’t sleep with both eyes open and they can’t sleep with just one eye open either. Peoples have to close each eye before they can sleep.
meaning_hint: You are one of these peoples, so imagine yourself closing your eyes and sleeping. Go ahead and do it right now. Close one eye, and then the other. Now imagine yourself sleeping.
reading_story: The reason you want to sleep is because all the other peoples were mean (みん) to you. They were so mean that the only way you could get over it was to close your eyes and sleep. You just want to sleep.
reading_hint: Those other peoples were really mean to you. Imagine all the mean things they were saying to you. What did they say? Think about all these mean things as you close your eyes and drift off to sleep. Also keep in mind that this kanji has the same reading as 民, which is included in this kanji.

meaning_story: In the sun while holding a comb in a cage and sitting on a stool, you comb your hair in your spare time. Since you’re in a cage, you actually fashioned this comb yourself, so it’s a little messed up, missing a prong. You’re working on improving it in your spare time, and you also use it to style your mop.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in your spare time, sitting on this stool in a cage in the sun. Feel the warmth of the sun on your body and feel the metal bars of the cage holding you in. You try to forget about your situation by combing your hair with the comb. The comb radical is a little modified, so be sure to remember that you made this comb yourself and it’s a little wonky.
reading_story: So how did you get in this cage? Well, before you used to comb your hair in your spare time, you used to steal cars (か). You’d stolen may a car in your day, but you finally got caught in the act of stealing a car, and now you’re spending all of your spare time in that cage, just combing your hair.
reading_hint: Picture yourself in this cage. You’re going to be there for life because you’d stolen too many cars. Feel the tears run down your face as you continue to comb your hair. You’re going to die in this cage.

meaning_story: After buying a comb from IKEA, you take the steps up the stairs to your bathroom. The stairs lead up to the only mirror in your house, and you need to see yourself when you use the comb from IKEA, so you run up those steps as soon as you get home.
meaning_hint: Imagine carrying this IKEA comb in your hand as you run up the stairs. Hear the steps creak under your foot as you climb. And then imagine having to put together the comb you just bought because it’s from IKEA.
reading_story: The stairs are pretty long, but after you finish climbing all the steps, you finally get to the mirror. Only, the mirror is smashed, and there’s a note next to it. It says, “My bad. Dan (だん).” Dangit Dan!
reading_hint: Imagine seeing this broken mirror that Dan broke. You climbed up all those steps for nothing. Throw the comb down in frustration. DAAAAAAAAANNNNNNN!!!

meaning_story: If you eat a rice paddy the size of the moon, your stomach is going to hurt. All the rice in a rice paddy the size of the moon is way too much rice for anyone to consume. If you do, your stomach is going to ache like crazy.
meaning_hint: Imagine having a whole rice paddy in your stomach. A rice paddy the size of the moon. Your stomach hurts a lot. You feel like you’re going to throw up.
reading_story: From the sky, an eagle swoops down and flies right into your distended stomach. Bam! The eagle (い) hits your stomach and you vomit up the entire moon sized rice paddy.
reading_hint: This eagle saw your stomach distress and decided to help by making you barf. Hear the screech of the eagle as it swoops down and rams you in the stomach.

meaning_story: You say you’re sick and you’re correct because you’re displaying the number one symptom. That symptom is vomiting. The number one symptom of being sick is vomiting. That is correct.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself with this BLEEARRGHGGHH symptom. You can’t stop BLUUAUHAHGHHH vomiting all over the BLEUUARGH place. It’s disgusting.
reading_story: The only way to cure yourself of this symptom and cure yourself from being sick is to pay homage to the shogun (しょう) and he will use his magical shogun powers to relieve you of your symptoms. The shogun is a magical man indeed.
reading_hint: Pay homage to the shogun. Try not to vomit while you do so. Imagine what you would say to the shogun to try and convince him to cure you.

meaning_story: A tsunami can make farming difficult, even with thick clothing on. You have thick boots, thick clothes, and thick gloves on – even a thick hat. Tsunamis are very hard though, so even with all this thick gear on, farming will still be much more difficult than usual.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself all bundled up in this thick outfit. Imagine yourself trying to farm or even just move in these clothes. You’re like the Michelin Man. Also imagine yourself in the wet rain as well because there’s a tsunami afoot.
reading_story: Since you spent all that time putting your thick outfit on, you forgot to do anything to protect your crops. The tsunami washes them all away and your farm is ruined. NooOOOOOoOooOoOO (のう)!!!
reading_hint: Say it out loud this time: NooooOOOOOooOOoO!! All that effort wasted. Watch as your crops and farming tools get washed away in the tsunami.

meaning_story: A piece of thread tied to a stand is looped around Two Face’s neck so you throw the stand out the window which causes the thread to tighten around Two Face’s neck. The stand looks a little messed up, but that’s probably due to how many times you’ve thrown it out the window.
meaning_hint: Imagine Two Face with this thread tightening around his neck. See his struggle as he tries to escape. He’s screaming. The stand radical in this kanji is a bit weird, so just remember it as being a bit beat up from being thrown out the window so much.
reading_story: The reason you wanted to tighten this thread around Two Face to incapacitate him was because you wanted to steal Two face’s tater (てい) tots. Tater tots are awesome, so you can’t resist. Like I said, you’ve done this before with the stand and all, but only when Two Face has tater tots. You think he’d have learned by now.
reading_hint: Continue to listen to Two Face’s cries for help as he tries to escape the thread around his neck. Now imagine yourself eating the scrumptious tater tots. Mmm, potatoey.

meaning_story: Atop a water slide flowing with rapid white water, I feel the urge to slide down. I mean, what else would you do on a water slide? Everyone who gets to the top of a water slide has the urge to go down it. Duh.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself at the top of this water slide. See the white water foaming at the top and hear it gushing and splashing. You wanna go down it don’t you? Feel the overwhelming urge to go down this awesome water slide.
reading_story: Actually, this water doesn’t look nearly white and foamy enough. You feel the urge to make the water flow more violently. Therefore, you hack (はく) the control panel to up the power on the water jets. The hack is easy, and soon the water is flowing stronger than ever.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself hacking the control panel that controls the water. Look at the electronics and imagine yourself crossing wires and typing in computer code as you hack your way to victory. Keep in mind that this kanji also shares its reading with 白 which is a part of this kanji. How useful.

meaning_story: I say, that direction looks like the perfect place to visit. Let us visit that direction. It’s much better than that other direction. I say, if I had to pick which direction I would rather visit, I would visit that direction.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself looking at two different directions and hearing someone say the above. Which direction looks like a better place to visit?
reading_story: The person you are traveling with is none other than Harry Hou-dini (ほう) himself. You trust Hou-dini’s judgement, so you visit the same direction that he does, only when you get there, Hou-dini disappears and you are visiting there alone.
reading_hint: Imagine getting there and Hou-dini vanishing. It’s what he’s known for. Now call out for Hou-dini trying to get him to come back because he promised you’d visit this place together. Hou-didni! Hou-diiiiiniiiiii!!!

meaning_story: Taking a thread and moving to the sound of the music, a drunkard makes a weave through some fabric. He’s using the thread to weave his clothes back together after he damaged them in a fall down the stairs. You know, because he’s a drunkard.
meaning_hint: Imagine this drunkard bipping and bopping to the sound of the music as he weaves this thread through his clothes to repair them.
reading_story: This drunkard is actually a Sheikh (しき) (an Arabic leader), but he’s just fallen on hard times and has been hitting the bottle pretty hard lately. The piece of clothing he is using the thread to weave back together is one of his fancy formal robes.
reading_hint: Imagine this drunken Sheikh again, only this time he is moving to the sound of some Arabic music. You know what that sounds like, right?

meaning_story: If you see a fish stick and some grass in with your treasure, you should worry. Fish sticks and grass are not treasures, so they do not belong with the treasure! Someone has been messing with your stuff! This is a great cause for worry!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself taking inventory of all your treasure. You find a fish stick, and then you find some grass. Hold them in your hands and crush them as you become filled with worry and dread.
reading_story: Do you need to worry about remembering how to read this kanji? Nah, yah (なや) don’t need to worry about it doncha know. You’ll be fine. Nah, yah don’t need to worry about it one bit.
reading_hint: Don’t worry about it! You’ll remember this one for sure. Just repeat the reading mnemonic a few times out loud and just remember the “nah yah” bit and you’ll be fine.

meaning_story: You see a flag by the exit letting you know to yield. There’s cross traffic just outside the exit, and the flag lets you know that you need to yield to them.
meaning_hint: Look at this flag telling you to yield. Now look through the exit right by the flag. You can see a bunch of people out there walking. Imagine standing by the exit, yielding to the other people until you have an opening. Hear the hustle and bustle of the people as you wait.
reading_story: Even though the flag told you to yield, you’re starting to lose your patience. The people walking outside the exit are all a bunch of crazy old coots (くつ)! These crazy coots keep walking right in front of the door, getting in the way. The old coots aren’t even going anywhere, they just keep looping around to obstruct the way!
reading_hint: Darn coots! Forget the yield flag, it’s time to exit. Imagine busting out of the exit, punching and pushing your way through the old coots. Hear them scream and shout “Augh! My hip!” as you plow through them.

meaning_story: In construction in the winter there is a lot of aggression. Lots of power tools and sharp things, destruction everywhere, construction is pretty violent to start with. Then add in the snow and cold weather, and people are even more angry than ever. People with a lot of aggression make for good construction workers.
meaning_hint: Imagine these construction workers in the winter. Imagine them all doing their jobs, but as violently as possible. Hear them all screaming loudly while they work. It’s actually pretty frightening.
reading_story: By far the construction worker with the most aggression is none other than こういち. こういち is so full of aggression that you almost don’t even need other construction workers.
reading_hint: Picture こういち doing construction. Now hear him scream violently as veins bulge on his neck and forehead.

meaning_story: A car from IKEA sees your hand and wants to attack it. This car is a vicious attack car with an appetite for human hands.
meaning_hint: Look at this IKEA car poised to attack your hand. Imagine it jumping out and attacking your hand viciously, hear the roar of the car’s engine as you scream out in terror.
reading_story: You remember Beck’s grandfather, Geck (げき), right? Well, once again, Geck is the only man who can stop this IKEA car’s attack on your hand. Go Geck, go!
reading_hint: Picture Geck valiantly defending your honor and warding off the IKEA car’s attack on your hand. Geck is your hero!

meaning_story: After a tsunami, you find an axe on the ground next to some fins on the beach. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach.
meaning_hint: See these things on the beach. It makes sense to see fins, as fins are usually in the ocean, so seeing them on the beach is logical. Pick up the stuff you find as you feel the beach sand between your toes.
reading_story: Walking down the beach a bit more, you also find a hammer (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer.
reading_hint: Pick up the hammer in your hand. It’s pretty heavy. The tsunami must have been very strong to pick up such a heavy hammer.

meaning_story: Take this thread and put it through your big lip ring. We're going to pull that lip ring out so that you can once again look beautiful. That big lip ring is covering up your face, so, you know, gotta get it out.
meaning_hint: Obviously I'm a crazy person who's about to pull out your lip ring with a thread, so don't feel too beautiful about that. This is a horrible situation you're in, and you need to get out of it, because this guy obsessed with 'beautiful' non-lip ring faces is nuts.
reading_story: Anyways, he pulls your lip ring out, because you were tied to a chair this whole time. Then, out of your bleeding lip he removes a key. 'This is what I was searching for the whole time. The real beautiful thing was the key.
reading_hint: Muwawhahahahahahahaha!

meaning_story: There are horns on the ground next to some fins and a plate that benefit the horns. The fins and the plate on the ground benefit the horns, because the fins and the plate make the horns look better by comparison. Why would you want a stupid fin or a fragile plate when you can have awesome and powerful horns? These horns are much cooler than those fins.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing some fins and a plate next to some horns on the ground. Which looks cooler? Which would benefit you more? Definitely the horns. Imagine picking them up and inspecting them.
reading_story: On the horn that you pick up, you notice a key (えき) shaped slot. Hmm, perhaps something is inside the horn that would benefit you. Need to find a key first though.
reading_hint: You need to find a key so you can get inside this horn and find something that might benefit you. Imagine taking a key and jamming it in the hole, trying to open the horn.

meaning_story: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing stick at the sun, you attain the legs of a child. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself getting new legs. Legs that belong to a child. They’re limber and young and full of energy! Feel your legs of a child underneath you!
reading_story: As you delight in your new legs, Jesus (じ) descends from the sky. “My child,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.”
reading_hint: Say back to Jesus, “I’m not your child Jesus! And you’re just jealous of my new legs! You wish you had the legs of a child, Jesus! Your legs are like super old!” Actually say this out loud, and remember how Jesus wishes he could be a child again too.

meaning_story: A helmet saves your life because Sauron didn’t have the heart to destroy the Constitution. You thought Sauron was going to destroy the Constitution, so you put on your helmet and went off to stop him. When you reached Sauron, he didn’t have it in him to destroy such an important document, and he got really upset, so he tried to destroy you instead. Luckily, your helmet saved your life.
meaning_hint: See Sauron looking at the Constitution before he finally yells in frustration and then throws you across the room. You hit your head on the wall, but your helmet saves you. Feel the impact as you hear the crack from the helmet that saves your life.
reading_story: You’re not done though, you still need to take the Constitution back to where it belongs. Luckily, Ken (けん) from Street Fighter shows up and starts fighting with Sauron, giving you some time to collect the constitution and get out of there. Thanks, Ken!
reading_hint: Watch Ken fighting off Sauron with his Street Fighter moves. Hear him shouting “SHORYUKEN! SHORYUKEN!” as you scurry off with the Constitution.

meaning_story: The ice's orders are to be cool and cold. That's cool, baby!
meaning_hint: Imagine being ice and getting your orders to be nice and cold. Alright, you were born for this!
reading_story: You're ordered to be cold because there is a death ray (れい) coming and it's going to be focused on you and all the other ice! If you aren't cold enough the ray will melt you! Get cooler now!
reading_hint: Imagine being shot with a death ray. Think cool, cold thoughts. Resist it!

meaning_story: A winter table would be an odd thing to deal with. Winter on its own can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst!
meaning_hint: Look at this winter table. How are you ever going to deal with it? Just think of your favorite warm food and then imagine it getting cold. Deal with it, dog.
reading_story: This winter table is something you have to deal with, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus show (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this.
reading_hint: Feel the relief of getting rid of this table. No more having to deal with it anymore. The circus show can have it.

meaning_story: You loiter on the mountain, reading off the numbers of pi on this winter morning. Everything is so perfect, so mathematical here. You view it as delicate. Not in the sense that it will break apart at any moment, more in the sense that there are smaller, more subtle things to be enjoyed on this mountain, which is why you loiter here doing math.
meaning_hint: You'll have to imagine the things you consider to be 'delicate.' Is that the snow falling on the branches? Is it the breeze? Is it something else? That's for you to decide, but imagine it vividly whatever it is.
reading_story: Ah! Of course! The delicate bumble bee (び), that is your epitome of delicate. It lands upon your finger, and you look at its every fiber of being.
reading_hint: Picture yourself looking at the bee, thinking how each hair on its body is so delicate. Maybe it has a delicate aroma to go with it. A faint smell of honey?

meaning_story: A leader uses a stick in the winter made of hair to enforce discipline. The leader uses the stick made of hair to discipline his followers. He hits them with it.
meaning_hint: Imagine the leader disciplining his people with the hair stick in the winter. Imagine him yelling “DISCIPLINE!!” with each hit of the stick as you feel the cold winter air around you.
reading_story: If the leader uses a stick to discipline his followers, then to discipline the leader himself, we need a shooter (しゅう). If the leader ever needs discipline himself, a shooter will shoot him with a gun.
reading_hint: Pretty harsh isn’t it? There’s no room for error here with the leader. The shooter will shoot him if he ever needs discipline.

meaning_story: You wear a great big cross on your chest and you attend a specialty exhibition for gambling. The big cross on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross, and everyone is gambling.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself at this specialty exhibition. Feel the weight of the cross shaped badge on your chest as you continue gambling at the exhibition.
reading_story: You’re not very good at gambling, but you are pretty good at cheating. You hack (はく) the specialty exhibition gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system.
reading_hint: Hack the gambling machines. Imagine the sounds of the expedition around you as you work to hack the machines. Look at the computer parts and cables as you work.

meaning_story: In a pine tree, the mouth of the king opens to the extent of ridiculousness. The king has a big mouth. The extent that it can open to is astounding. However, the king only has this power when he is near his magical pine tree.
meaning_hint: This is probably why he’s king. Having a mouth that can open to the extent that it could house all other potential king candidates will win you the crown for sure. Imagine the big mouthed king doing this while holding a branch of his magical pine tree.
reading_story: The king’s favorite food is tater (てい) tots. He likes to open his mouth to the extent of near disbelief, and then shovel in all the tater tots he can get his royal hands on. The country is currently experiencing a terrible tater tot shortage.
reading_hint: Do you like tater tots? Imagine you are the king. Open your mouth as wide as you can and imagine shoving tater tot after tater tot inside. How many would you be able to fit?

meaning_story: Sometime in the future, thread of every color will be faced with extinction. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction.
meaning_hint: Imagine what the world would be like without thread. No thread of any color. How would you fix tears in clothes or make new ones? It would be a strange world where thread is extinct.
reading_story: The extinction of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly zits (ぜつ). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits.
reading_hint: Pretend you have deadly zits. They’re everywhere, not just your face. You can’t pop them or you’ll die, but they’re all bulging and extremely painful. Now you’re facing extinction. Lousy.

meaning_story: Ice from the east is frozen. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen.
meaning_hint: Imagine this super frozen ice from the east. You’ve never seen anything quite like it before. It’s so frozen, it’s like it was frozen once and then frozen again. Twice frozen. Feel the ice and how freezing cold it is. It’s like, really super cold, man.
reading_story: Japan is a country of the east, and this ice was frozen in Tokyo (とう), Japan. Tokyo is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there.
reading_hint: Imagine being in Tokyo and seeing all this frozen ice. Hear people speaking Japanese all around you as you touch and feel the freezing frozen ice.

meaning_story: The giant radical and the giant kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
reading_story: Just recently, a giant rampaged through Little Kyoto (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto.
reading_hint: See Little Kyoto after the giant rampaged through it. It looks even smaller and more pathetic than ever. Look at all the smoldering rubble and smell the smoke with your nose.

meaning_story: A pine tree that trips a turkey is immature. This pine tree likes to use its roots to trip each turkey that walks past it. The pine tree is pretty immature, so it thinks watching a turkey trip and fall is hilarious.
meaning_hint: Picture this pine tree moving its roots about to trip this turkey. See the turkey trip and fall to the ground as it squawks. Feathers go flying everywhere.
reading_story: To make it worse, the turkey falls into a pile of fetid cheese (ち). The immature pine tree placed the cheese there for the turkey to fall in. It was bad enough that the turkey fell down, but now he has a face full of old, rotten cheese.
reading_hint: Picture the turkey falling down again, only this time his face splats into a pile of yucky cheese. Hear the squishing sound and smell the fragrant smell wafting off the cheese.

meaning_story: Super poop is a super power you have in infancy. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power!
meaning_hint: Infants poop a lot. There's poop everywhere. The powerful aroma overwhelms you. Eww. Also refers to child, which kind of makes sense because infants are also children, right?
reading_story: In infancy, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as yogurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power.
reading_hint: See this infant gobbling up all the yogurt he can get his grubby little hands on. Soon, he begins to poop all over the place. Hear the infant screaming, 'Goo-goo! Yogurt poop power! I'm a baby! Wahhhh!!'

meaning_story: You stick horns in the ground using them as spikes and you line up the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself lining up these horns in the ground. The spikes are sharp and you poke yourself with one. Ouch. Need to be more careful as you line these up.
reading_story: As you line up these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on hay (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty.
reading_hint: Imagine the hay in that bull's mouth as it chomps angrily, watching you line up horns in the ground. It probably wishes you were the hay.

meaning_story: The lovely radical and the lovely kanji are exactly the same! Lovely!
reading_story: It is a lovely ray (れい) of sunshine shooting out from the sun and hitting you in the face. What a lovely ray!
reading_hint: See this lovely ray coming down from the heavens and striking you in the eyes. Feel its lovely warmth and see its lovely brightness.

meaning_story: A big lip ring is a pretty odd thing to have. If it's big, it'll stretch your lip out, which is odd.
meaning_hint: Imagine a huge lip ring pulling on your lip. You think... 'man, it's odd I bought this...'
reading_story: And, to make things even more odd it seems like your big lip ring is a giant key (き), and you use it to open your house door.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself bending over and using this big odd lip ring key in your door to unlock it. Click! Ouch!

meaning_story: There’s blood and hair in the tofu and the populace is in outrage. Someone has put their blood and hair into all the tofu in the world, claiming to be the messiah, and they are distributing their holy body to all eaters of tofu. Needless to say, the populace is not pleased.
meaning_hint: Imagine eating some tofu with blood and hair in it. It’s disgusting. Most pieces of tofu have three hairs in it – yours has two, but this doesn’t make it any less displeasing. Imagine yourself along with the whole populace vomiting after eating this gross tofu. Also remember that your piece of tofu only has two hairs in it because the hair radical in this kanji is one hair short.
reading_story: The guy who angered the populace by putting his blood and hair into the tofu is on the run, so the populace hires a shooter (しゅう) to track him down and shoot him. This jerk needs to die, so a shooter is the right guy for the job.
reading_hint: Imagine the shooter hunting the guy who ruined all the tofu. See the shooter lining up his shot before he shoots the crazy tofu ruiner. BAM!

meaning_story: A tsunami hits hercules straight on, but he takes it like the buff dude he is. This is how he takes a bath, washing away all the blood and suffering he has caused. The only way to become pure is to get his guilt washed away with a tsunami.
meaning_hint: Imagine the huge tsunami hitting Hercules straight on. When he sets up to get hit, he is dirty, nasty, and impure. When the tsunami hits him and recedes, he is shiny, sparkly, and pure.
reading_story: After the tsunami pulls away, and Hercules is there all pure, he looks down. He is completely naked, save for his pure white Keds (けつ).
reading_hint: Just imagine a buff naked Hercules wearing a pair of Keds. They are as pure as he is.

onyomi: せい, しょう, しん
meaning_story: A tsunami is blue and pure. A pure blue tsunami is the purest tsunami you’ll ever see. So blue! So pure! Tsunami!
meaning_hint: Imagine this pure blue tsunami. Marvel at how pure and blue it is.
reading_story: Seeing this tsunami being so pure, Hard Gay feels the strong desire to defile it. Therefore, Hard Gay runs up to the tsunami and starts humping it violently. “Sei (せい), sei, sei!” he yells.
reading_hint: Imagine this pure blue tsunami again in your mind. Now imagine Hard Gay humping the crap out of it, thrusting his hips deep within its pure blue water while he shrieks “Sei, sei, sei!” at the top of his lungs.

meaning_story: A gold Wolverine swam in the water while his father made a record of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine.
meaning_hint: See this gold Wolverine holding his gold medal after getting out of the water. His dad doesn’t want to forget anything about this precious moment so he makes a record of it. Imagine him scribbling furiously in his notebook.
reading_story: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a record of this also. One angry fan threw a rock (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records.
reading_hint: Imagine a pitiful Wolverine crying on the ground as each rock hits him. All he wanted was some recognition from his father. Poor guy. Imagine poor Wolverine like this as his dad just looks on and writes in his notebook.

meaning_story: On a water slide, there is a thorn that will only poke you if you ride in reverse. Going down a water slide in reverse is dangerous, so there is a thorn in place to prick you if you do. The thorn is in place to deter people from going down the water slide in reverse.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself going down this water slide in reverse. For whatever reason, you’ve ignored the warnings about going down in reverse, and before you know it there’s a thorn jabbing you in the butt. Feel the pain as it stabs you.
reading_story: Being the nice guy that you are, you take some Gak (ぎゃく) and put it over the thorn to cover it. If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial and you’ll see. The Gak will protect people going in reverse from taking damage on the thorn. They might get a bit sticky though.
reading_hint: Imagine running into this Gak while going in reverse on the water slide. Feel the Gak on your body as it sticks to you, all slimy like. It’s kinda gross. Oh well, better than getting stabbed by the thorn I guess.

meaning_story: A pine is there one evening, and then the next evening, it experiences a shift. After two evenings, the pine tree is shifted from one location to another. This phenomenon is known as a Double Evening Pine Shift.
meaning_hint: Picture this phenomenon in your head. Imagine it all dramatic in like a time-lapse video sort of thing with dramatic music too. See the pine tree one evening, and then the next evening – it shifts!
reading_story: So what causes this fine tree to shift, anyway? Well if you look closely, you’ll be able to see that an eagle (い) actually picks up the pine to shift it to its new location. That’s one strong eagle.
reading_hint: See the eagle picking up and shifting the pine tree in the evening. Hear the eagle screech as it shifts the tree in the evening.

meaning_story: Rice that is blue has a lot of team spirit. The rice is on the blue team, so the rice has painted themselves blue as a show of team spirit.
meaning_hint: Look at all the blue rice. They’re so full of spirit, you can’t imagine eating them. That would just be mean.
reading_story: Even though the blue rice has lots of team spirit on their side, they’re still going to have a tough match against their opponent – Hard Gay. “Sei (せい), sei sei!!” he shouts as he charges at them. Hard Gay is about to lay the smack down on team blue rice.
reading_hint: Imagine Hard Gay humping the spirit out of the blue rice. Hear Hard Gay shouting “Sei, sei sei!!” as he humps them into submission.

meaning_story: You’re a butcher and you see a pair of horns on a pig in the back of a squad car. The police squad arrested the pig for impersonating a bull, hence the horns. The pig put on the horns to escape you, since you are a butcher, and butchers like to butcher pigs.
meaning_hint: Imagine this pig with horns, pretending to be a bull. He looks ridiculous. Now imagine him in a squad car, with the squad standing outside guarding it.
reading_story: The squad has to call in the chief inspector, who differentiates himself from the rest of the squad by wearing a tie (たい). The chief inspector is really proud of his tie, so his displays it with joy.
reading_hint: Imagine the chief inspector striding up to the pig with horns, proudly displaying his tie. Look and him grin wildly as he approached the squad.

meaning_story: If you have a mullet, you should put your car in storage if you aren’t using it. Since you have a mullet, people will hate you and want to destroy your car. The best way to keep it safe is to have it in storage while you’re not using it.
meaning_hint: Imagine you have a mullet and a car. Now imagine yourself putting the car into storage after you drive it. Look around the area as the storage door closes to make sure no one sneaks in to bash it.
reading_story: Look around. Where is your 子? Oh, crap! You put your 子 in storage along with your car! How forgetful of you.
reading_hint: Imagine that you locked your 子 away in storage. You’re the worst parent ever. Feel bad about putting your 子 into storage.

meaning_story: A woman is one of the few strange things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few strange things in this world, with woman being one of them.
meaning_hint: Imagine saying this to a woman. Try and imagine her face as you tell her how strange she is.
reading_story: But when you think about it, we're all a little strange. Me, you, myou (みょう) everybody!
reading_hint: Who's strange? Me and you. Me, you - we are strange! Strange, strange, strange!

meaning_story: There are horns on the train and you’ve got a sword and a ticket to ride. This horned train is on its way to hell and you’ve got a one way ticket. Lucky you. The sword is just for protection.
meaning_hint: Visualize this evil hell train with horns. You’re riding on it because you have a ticket. Picture how evil this train looks and feels with its fiendish hellfire, horns, and other junk. Feel your sword in one hand and your ticket in the other.
reading_story: Another person who has a ticket on this train with horns is Ken (けん) from Street Fighter. Ken got his ticket to hell for beating up so many people. Ken never thought it was a big deal, but apparently that’s enough to get you a one way ticket to the underworld.
reading_hint: Look at poor Ken just sitting there on the train. He’s too sad to do any of his special moves or anything. Go over and put your arm around Ken’s shoulder to try and console him.

meaning_story: As a hat, four people holding a cross use an umbrella. The umbrella is big enough to be a hat for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that’s why they’re holding the cross.
meaning_hint: See these four people all under one umbrella. No one is carrying the umbrella, it’s just resting on all of their heads like a hat. Their hands are busy holding that cross, anyway.
reading_story: You know the Spanish phrase “Mi casa (かさ) es su casa”? Well this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is an umbrella. Mi casa es yours too, because it’s an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me.
reading_hint: Imagine the four people in the umbrella hat again, only this time imagine them skipping along singing “Mi casa es su casa”. It’ll help you remember.

radicals: 女, 冖, 巾, ヨ
meaning_story: A woman dressed as Wolverine uses her forehead to beat up Two Face and his wife. This woman is really angry with Two Face and his wife, but she doesn’t want anyone to know who she is. Therefore she disguises herself as Wolverine and goes on a headbutting rampage, hitting Two Face and his wife.
meaning_hint: What a crazy thing to witness. Just picture it. A woman dressed as Wolverine, screaming and bashing two people with her forehead. The wife got it worst though. Look at her crying in the corner as sticky red blood runs down her face, mixing with the tears.
reading_story: Unfortunately, the woman’s costume doesn’t fool (ふ) anyone. They all know who she is because of her voice and because she’s the only one who would want to hurt Two Face and his wife. You’re not fooling anyone, lady!
reading_hint: What a foolish move by this lady. She should have known this costume wouldn’t fool anyone. Imagine her thinking about what a fool she is as she gets arrested by the police.

meaning_story: You see a rice paddy and you give it a kiss before granting it the abbreviation, RP. The rice paddy isn’t too fond of this abbreviation, so you kiss it again to soothe it.
meaning_hint: As you imagine yourself giving a kiss to a rice paddy, think about whether or not the abbreviation RP would ever catch on. Do you think it would?
reading_story: The rice paddy still refuses to accept this abbreviation despite your kisses. Therefore, you are forced to take the rice paddy and hang it from a torture rack (りゃく) until it agrees to accept the abbreviation.
reading_hint: Imagine the rice paddy on the rack, squealing for mercy. Turn the handle to turn the rack, causing the rice paddy even more discomfort.

meaning_story: You can't blame your pine trees for the amount of pine needles they accumulate. They're just trying to live. They accumulate pine needles and pine cones and it's just natural. Don't be a jerk and blame them for that!
meaning_hint: All pine trees know is how to accumulate more needles and pine cones. Please don't blame them!
reading_story: If you think about it, the more of these things a pine tree accumulates, the more sexy (せき) it will be to other pine trees. So if you try to blame it and make it feel bad, it won't get any other pine tree lovers!
reading_hint: How many pine needles has your tree accumulated? OH! That's so many! IT'S SO SEXY!

meaning_story: There’s a tsunami in heaven and you take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability.
meaning_hint: Take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Feel the drop of water on your finger and visualize yourself flicking it at the tsunami as it races towards heaven.
reading_story: Just after you append the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows ten (てん) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall.
reading_hint: Look up at this ten story tall tsunami. It looks big and powerful. Feel the water spray from the tsunami as it towers over you.

meaning_story: If you are wearing a helmet, it might be odd to approach the queen, not to mention rude. Most would think it odd for you to approach the queen with your helmet still on – you’re supposed to remove all headgear before approaching her. What are you thinking?
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself wearing a helmet and approaching royalty. You’re so dumbstruck by seeing such a powerful figure that you totally forget to remove your helmet.
reading_story: The reason for your approach is that you’re asking for the key (き) to the city. You think you deserve it, so that’s why you ask for the key. However, you are denied the key and your request as you forgot to remove your helmet. Rats.
reading_hint: You really wanted that key. Imagine yourself going home, embarrassed and defeated, while you try to think of another way to get the key. Maybe you could just knock the queen out with your helmet and then steal the key. Hmm…

meaning_story: Putting on a helmet to protect her from the sun, a woman attends an outdoor banquet. Not wanting to burn her fair skin at the banquet, the woman made sure to wear a wide brimmed helmet for optimal sun blocking protection.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing this woman as you eat food at the banquet. Taste the food in your mouth as you see her wander about in her oversized helmet.
reading_story: This banquet is being put on by the ent (えん) lord. That’s why it’s outside. An ent always prefers to be outdoors rather than in.
reading_hint: While at the banquet observing the woman in the helmet, also see the ents wandering about and mingling with all the other ent guests.

meaning_story: A tree devil is a devil that isn't nice to trees. Trees that go to tree hell see the tree devil, and his favorite punishment is to turn these sinning trees into a single processed board.
meaning_hint: Imagine the tree getting sent to tree hell to see the tree devil. He laughs, then starts sawing.
reading_story: By making boards from these trees, the devil has to cut the tree in 半 (はん) over and over again until they're board sized.
reading_hint: Half and half and half again. These poor trees have to be cut in half for a long time, until they're at a molecular level, unable to be cut in half again (or are they? Only the devil can try to cut molecules in 半).

meaning_story: While observing a grave and a cross that Sauron is making while wearing the clothes of a gravedigger, you break the branch you were sitting on. Crap, now Sauron is going to know you were spying on him. Dangit, why did that branch have to break?
meaning_hint: Imagine sitting as your seat breaks out from underneath you. You land at Saurons feet and he doesn’t look happy about you ruining the cross that you landed on. Feel the cross break beneath you as well and feel fear at Sauron’s impending wrath.
reading_story: Before Sauron can get a hold of you and break all your bones for breaking his precious cross he was making for the grave, a coyote (かい) comes out of nowhere and attacks Sauron, knocking him down. You have no idea where the coyote came from, but you don’t pause to think. You get right up and hightail it outta there.
reading_hint: Hear the coyote snarl as it attacks Sauron. Hear Sauron scream in agony as the coyote clamps down on his arm. Where did that coyote come from anyway?

radicals: 目, 小, 又, 上
meaning_story: Above a small stool with an eye stands your coach. Your coach is coaching you in wizardry, and while trying to turn the small stool into a dog, you turned it into a small stool with an eye. You’ll need some more coaching from your coach on this one.
meaning_hint: Look at your coach trying to coach you on this magic spell. Hear his words of encouragement as you continue to fumble with the incantation.
reading_story: That was a really hard lesson and by the end of it your coach wasn’t too happy with your progress. To relieve some stress, you go out behind the classroom and toke (とく) up. You hardly ever toke up, but this sort of situation really calls for it.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself toking up behind the school. Feel the smoke enter your lungs as you toke up. What would your coach think if he saw you now?

meaning_story: Your leader is an ox and you are his colleague. You’re colleagues, but the ox is definitely the leader of your group. The ox is a great leader, and both you and your other colleagues look up to him.
meaning_hint: Imagine this ox as your colleague. What would it be like working with him? Probably a little odd, right?
reading_story: As your colleague, the ox likes to suggest things to do with the rest of your colleagues to build teamwork. He suggests you rent a row (りょう) boat and row around some on your lunch break.
reading_hint: Imagine an ox in a row boat. That row boat won’t hold him! Silly ox, what were you thinking?

meaning: cup of liquid, counter for cups
meaning_story: A tree is not a cup of liquid or a counter for cups. Don’t get them mixed up. I mean really, who counts on trees? A cup of liquid could be a counter for cups because that makes sense, but definitely not a tree.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself kicking a tree out of the way to start counting off cups by using cups of liquid. Count the cups of liquid in your mind until you feel confident you’ll remember this meaning.
reading_story: Another way to remember the counter for cups using a cup of liquid would be by creating and memorizing a haiku (はい) about them. Aren’t haikus useful?
reading_hint: Think of a haiku about a cup of liquid and a counter for cups. Use that haiku to help remember this kanji.

meaning_story: A woman who is good is my daughter. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it.
meaning_hint: Look at how good this woman is! She’s my daughter! She’s good! You wish your daughter was as good a woman!
reading_story: Your daughter is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a moose who may (むすめ) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things.
reading_hint: Think about how your daughter is basically a moose who may do dumb things. How ashamed you feel. How very very ashamed.

meaning_story: They say if you use a hat to cover the area your hair used to be, chances are you had a doctor diagnose you with cancer. Sometimes after you get diagnosed with cancer, the process makes you lose your hair, and you have to wear a hat. It’s sad, but true.
meaning_hint: Imagine the doctor diagnosing you with cancer. All of your hair falls out just thinking about it. Now put on your hat.
reading_story: You just had the doctor diagnose you with cancer. How terrible. You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention you bang your shin (しん) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day.
reading_hint: Hold your shin as you feel the throbbing pain in it. Even though the pain is so extreme, you can’t help but still think about the diagnosis you got from the doctor.

meaning_story: In the morning, you use a gun on your nose to make it dry.
meaning_hint: You have this terrible problem with runny noses in the morning, and the only way to get it nice and dry is to shoot your nose with a gun. Unfortunately, other problems go along with this technique as well.
reading_story: Immediately you throw the gun in the trash can (かん) and start crying. After you collect yourself and your nose, you vow never to use your gun to dry your nose again. It will stay in that trash can.
reading_hint: Hear the gun clunk into the trash can as you throw it. The can is made out of metal, so it makes a loud clinking noise.

meaning_story: There is a district with a severe lack of class located in Europe. It’s a district filled with low lives, thieves, and beggars. The district lacks many favorable things. Europe’s reputation suffers because of it.
meaning_hint: Were you thinking of a particular area of Europe? If so, use that place to remember this kanji. If not, think of a back district in Europe that lacks class and use it to remember this kanji.
reading_story: Actually, you live in Europe and you just realized the district in question is where you live! OOOOOOHHHHHHH (おう) NOOOOOOOOOOO!! :(
reading_hint: Oh no! The shame. You are the reason Europe has lost its good name. Feel great woe as you sob yourself to sleep at night. Ohhh, ohhhh noooo…

meaning_story: A saw cuts into your heart and you are filled with fear. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart, too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever.
meaning_hint: Try and imagine this saw slicing into your heart. Are you filled with fear? You should be. Think of how terrifying this would be.
reading_story: Even more so than your fear of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in Kyoto (きょう). You always wanted to take a trip to Kyoto, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go.
reading_hint: How sad. I fear you’ll never make it to Kyoto. Think of Kyoto and how you long for it as you slowly die from that saw wound to the heart.

meaning_story: An animal eats a child from a plate in a very fierce manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style.
meaning_hint: See the fierce animal fiercely eating the child from the plate. It’s very gruesome. See blood and body parts flying everywhere as the animal devours the child.
reading_story: The reason this fierce animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to mow (もう) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him.
reading_hint: That child really shouldn’t have forgotten to mow the lawn. Imagine you are the child, being eaten by the fierce animal and wishing that you would have just mowed the lawn like you said you would.

meaning_story: A tsunami rolls in and destroys all the construction that was being done on the inlet and the bay. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer.
meaning_hint: Picture all the construction on the bay and the inlet getting destroyed by the tsunami. Look at all of it fall apart and crash to the ground as the tsunami knocks it down. Imagine yourself right near the action, feeling the water spray from the tsunami.
reading_story: Imagine the Japanese people standing on the bay and the inlet as the tsunami approaches. “Eh (え)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!”
reading_hint: EH? A tsunami you say? Those construction areas are screwed, man. Again, imagine the tsunami demolishing the area. Then be all like, “Eh? A tsunami? Aw, man.”

meaning_story: In the morning, Cow God will destroy Korea. Cow God has become angry with Korea for it has not been paying homage to Cow God. Cow God angry. Cow God smash. In the morning.
meaning_hint: Imagine the sun rising over Korea as Cow God approaches to destroy everything. Hear the screams of all the Koreans as Cow God ravages the country.
reading_story: Once Cow God destroys Korea, he puts what’s left of Korea into a large can (かん) for storage. This way Cow God can remember this day fondly whenever he wants to. The can full of Korea is like a memento for Cow God.
reading_hint: Imagine Korea doesn’t exist anymore and what’s left of it is in a can owned by Cow God. What a strange world. Try and picture Cow God scraping the remains of Korea into the can.

meaning_story: A narwhal stands next to his pile of belongings, trying to protect them from a turkey who is both male and brave. This brave male turkey wants to take all of the narwhal’s goods away from him. The narwhal has put all his stuff into a pile so it is easier to guard.
meaning_hint: Imagine this brave male turkey sizing up the situation. Imagine him circling around the narwhal and the pile of goods, just waiting for an opening to steal all the narwhal’s stuff.
reading_story: The brave male turkey has a reason for wanting all the narwhal’s junk though. “You (ゆう)!” the turkey yells, “You killed my family and left me for dead! You and your horn are to blame for my terrible life, so now I’m going to take your pile of things, you filthy animal!”
reading_hint: Listen to the turkey as he talks, he really emphasizes “you” each time he says it. Read it aloud if you have to – get a feel for how angry the turkey is.

meaning_story: You set sail and go off on your sea journey with a lid on the table to assist in your navigation. You’re a strange navigator, but somehow having a lid on the table with your maps and charts helps in your navigation.
meaning_hint: Imagine conducting your navigation with this lid on the table. Move the lid around and mark the maps and check your compass. Feel the lid in your hand as you navigate some more.
reading_story: But who are you? Who is this master navigator? You are こういち, Master of Navigation. Nothing in the world is un-navigatable for the great こういち and his lid.
reading_hint: See こういち, Master of Navigation as he performs his navigation maneuvers. See こういち spin the lid around and make a big show out of his intricate navigation practices.

meaning_story: A servant puts a gun on the ground next to a plate so his master can oversee his work. The servant is supposed to disassemble the gun and place the parts on the plate on the ground. He’s been doing a poor job lately, so the master decided to oversee his work this time.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as this master. Oversee your servant working on this gun. Hear the clicks and snaps as it comes apart and hear the pieces clink and clatter on the plate.
reading_story: You continue to oversee the procedure and soon the deed is done. You take the gun from the servant and slide all the parts from the plate into a can (かん). You seal the can and then put it into storage. You’re demilitarizing, so all the guns need to be put into cans.
reading_hint: Picture yourself putting a gun into a can. See all the pieces fall into the can and clink around. Now imagine sealing on the lid for the can. Good job.

meaning_story: Wearing a helmet, you jackhammer your religion into others. This jackhammer is a holy one, and you use it to crack open the skulls of the people and force your religion into their brains. The helmet helps protect you from anyone else who might try to do the same to you.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in your helmet, using your jackhammer to get religion into people. Feel the jackhammer rumble as the skulls crack. Imagine yourself shoving religion into them by stuffing Bibles, scripture, and hymnals into their brains.
reading_story: Eventually, someone notices that you are forcing religion on people, even those who don’t want any religion. This person is a shooter (しゅう), so he takes out his gun and shoots you, stopping your religious oppression.
reading_hint: See this shooter just before he shoots you. The sound of the jackhammer drones in your ears as you hear the crack from his gun. You’re dead.

onyomi: せい, しん, しょう
meaning_story: They say blue is the best color anyone could request. When you request a color, if it’s not blue, it might as well not even be a thing. Blue is the best color, they say.
meaning_hint: What things would you request in the color blue? Imagine the things you might request that you would want to be blue. Think of these things when you see this kanji.
reading_story: You know what else they say? “Sei (せい), sei, sei!” Oh wait, that’s not what everyone says, just Hard Gay. Hard Gay loves the color blue and he makes request after request that they let him wear a blue outfit, but they say it’s not allowed.
reading_hint: Imagine Hard Gay in his current black outfit. Now imagine it in blue. Hard Gay wants to wear blue, so he makes a request to wear blue, but he is shot down. Too bad.

meaning_story: A fishstick gets caught in a battle between a narwhal and Two Face – how scary. This situation is very scary for the fishstick. The narwhal and Two Face are fighting over who gets to eat the fishstick, and it’s a very scary thing to be caught in the middle of.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are this fishstick. This is very scary for you. The battle itself is scary enough, but you know that no matter who wins you’re still getting eaten.
reading_story: But wait! What a fool (ふ) you’ve been. While the narwhal fights Two Face, you can just escape. They’re distracted and won’t even notice. And you thought this was a scary situation. Pshaw!
reading_hint: How foolish you feel as you walk away from the battle. Hear the sounds of the two fighting get softer and softer as you walk away.

meaning_story: There is a cross in your forehead with a thread attached to it, forcing you to search where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on.
meaning_hint: It hurts to have this cross stuck in your forehead, but try to ignore that as you search for where the thread leads. Imagine gathering the thread in your hands as you move along.
reading_story: Your search is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a sack (さく). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?!
reading_hint: Why are there more crosses and threads in the sack? Are you supposed to take them from the sack and throw them at other people’s foreheads? Maybe. Imagine yourself reaching into the sack and throwing the crosses at other people.

meaning_story: The servant radical and the servant kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means retainer and you’ll be fine.
meaning_hint: Retainer and servant are basically the same thing, so remembering this one shouldn’t be too hard for you.
reading_story: Your servant, also known as your retainer, bangs his shins (しん) all the time so you make him wear jeans (じん) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants.
reading_hint: Imagine your servant banging his shins on everything in your house. Hand him a pair of jeans and tell him to put them on to soften the blows.

meaning_story: The leader of a mountain expedition had a turkey as their sponsor. The turkey is pretty wealthy and seems to enjoy being the sponsor for risky mountain expeditions like the one this leader is leading.
meaning_hint: Imagine this opulent turkey sponsoring this mountain climbing leader and his team. See yourself as one of the mountain climbers. Look at the jackets of the others and see a huge turkey logo emblazoned on them.
reading_story: Since the logo is so gaudy and ridiculous, you let out a large sigh (さい). Siiiigh. These logos are really embarrassing, but you needed a sponsor, and there’s no one around making fun of you, so you can deal with it.
reading_hint: Sigh out loud as you imagine looking at this turkey logo. It’s super cheesy and tacky, but hey – a sponsor is a sponsor.

meaning_story: If you want to go from one grave to another grave you need to walk along the street. Streets are there to connect two places. Like these two graves. That's literally the only reason to have streets.
meaning_hint: Imagine going from one grave to another by street. This street makes traveling so easy!
reading_story: In the street, a truck rockets towards you before screeching to a halt. “Hey guy (がい) – get outta the road! Move it, guy! I got places to be! Guy! Guy? GUY!!”
reading_hint: You don't know what this guy's problem is, but streets are for everyone, not just cars! Ignore his, "GUY?!" shouts and keep going!

meaning_story: They say longcat is actually many cats, all stuffed into one. That’s why longcat is so long, they say. Many cats stuffed into one makes for one very long cat.
meaning_hint: Picture taking a cat and stuffing other cats down its throat until the cat is longcat. Hear the cats hiss and growl as you stuff them into one another.
reading_story: Once you start this process of getting a cat stuffed with more cats, you realize that you can’t really stuff more than two (つ) cats inside of another. Two cats is really the limit. How longcat got so long seems to be a mystery after all.
reading_hint: So if longcat isn’t actually stuffed with other cats, how did longcat get so long? Ponder this question as you remove the two cats from the other cat.

meaning_story: The servant sits on the stool, holding a piece of thread, looking very tense. He’s sitting on the stool to chill out because the servant is feeling stress over the fact that his master ordered him to strangle someone with that piece of thread.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are this servant. Feel very tense that you have to murder someone with this thread. Imagine sitting on a stool to calm down.
reading_story: The servant feels even more tense because he’s supposed to use the thread to kill his next of kin (きん). He loves his kin very much and this is really stressing him out.
reading_hint: Imagine having to use a piece of thread to strangle your next of kin. This is a sad thing to think about. Use that sadness to remember this kanji.

meaning_story: At the gate, you kiss the cabinet members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual.
meaning_hint: Imagine kissing all the members of the cabinet. A lot of them are old men. Imagine kissing all of them at the gate. Eww.
reading_story: You need to kiss each member of the cabinet to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your cock (かく). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself sneaking past the cabinet members, finding your cock, grabbing it, and getting out of there. You’ve recovered your rooster! The day is won.

meaning_story: A leader with one bare foot has the overwhelming urge to put a sock on it. The leader’s foot is really cold, so he really wants to cover it. The urge is overpowering.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as this leader with one bare foot. Feel the incredible urge to cover it with something warm and fuzzy.
reading_story: Finally you have to give into your urge. You put a sock (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock.
reading_hint: Feel this sock on your foot. It feels great. Wiggle your toes around inside the sock as you think about how glad you are that you gave into that urge of yours. Note that this kanji also has the same reading as 足, so keep that in mind too!

meaning_story: You got bad ribs from a fish tail that was too violent and intense to handle. You were out catching fish with your bare hands and you found a fish that was so violent and intense in its thrashing that it broke all your ribs. The fish tail smacked you in the ribs so hard that it made all of them bad.
