meaning_hint: Try and hold this fish tail even though it’s so violent and intense. Imagine holding this fish as it thrashes around and feel your ribs breaking one by one.
reading_story: That violent fish left you with some pretty intense rib damage, huh? Let’s (れつ) go to the hospital! C’mon, let’s go! We need to get those bad ribs looked at.
reading_hint: What are you waiting for? No time for hints – let’s go to the hospital!

meaning_story: In the ground under the rice paddy, someone buried treasure again. There was treasure in the ground under the rice paddy before, but now there’s treasure there again.
meaning_hint: Dig this treasure out of the ground again. Who keeps burying it there? Feel yourself digging the ground up as you remember how many times you’ve had to do this again and again.
reading_story: Once you dig up the treasure, you find a note signed “こういち”. こういち says that he’ll keep burying treasure here again and again until the day he dies. こういち is a diabolical fiend!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself reading this note from こういち. Why would he keep burying treasure here? Where is he getting it all from anyway?

meaning_story: A demon on a jet is pretty alluring. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring.
meaning_hint: See this demon flying around in his jet. Do you feel allured? You should. Hear the roar of the jet engine as the demon cackles.
reading_story: This alluring demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. Meat (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat.
reading_hint: The demon won’t be so alluring once you see him scarfing down humans, tearing the meat from their bones. How gross.

meaning_story: You fly north to the moon and break your back when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact.
meaning_hint: Imagine flying north to the moon. Feel the force of being rocketed through space on your journey. Now feel your spine telescope and your back break. It really smarts.
reading_story: Your back hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in haiku (はい) form. I flew to the moon. It is there I broke my back. My back hurts real bad.
reading_hint: Say this haiku out loud. Memorize is and use this haiku to remember this kanji.

meaning_story: A horse gets trapped in a small room with a stool and a giant insect creating a very boisterous situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place.
meaning_hint: Imagine the boisterous sounds coming from this small roof. Hear the horse neigh and stomp his hooves, hear the insect buzzing loudly, and hear the wooden stool rattle around as the horse and insect try to escape the room.
reading_story: Soon the insect and the horse escape the room. Even so, they’re still being quite boisterous. I guess they don’t get along. To teach them a lesson, you sew (そう) the two of them together, forcing them to work out their differences. You sew really fast, and before they know it, they’re trapped together. You won’t un-sew them until they manage to not be so boisterous anymore.
reading_hint: Imagine having to sew a giant insect to a horse. Hear them both protesting boisterously as you sew them and flail around afterwards.

meaning_story: You threaten to eat a gun unless Two Face starts to decorate the house. You and Two Face are throwing a party, and one of you needs to decorate. You really don’t want to decorate, so you threaten to eat a gun unless Two Face does all of the work.
meaning_hint: Imagine this gun in your mouth. Taste the metal. Imagine shouting “DECORATE!” at Two Face to get him to start decorating. Pretty drastic move if you ask me.
reading_story: This is a pretty big shock (しょく) to Two Face. He never expected this behavior out of you. He never knew you hated to decorate so much. What a shock, indeed.
reading_hint: Imagine Two Face’s shocked face when you stick the gun in your mouth. Hear his scream in terror as he quickly begins to decorate.

meaning_story: If you want to buy a geoduck you have to go to the bank beforehand to deposit enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy even one! They're expensive, after all.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself depositing your money beforehand. Imagine the delicious geoduck you'll be able to buy now that the money has been deposited into your account!
reading_story: You go to the bank to make the deposit and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a yo-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo! Now you can't see! Now you can't make the deposit!
reading_hint: Imagine trying to make a deposit to your bank after getting hit in the face with a yo-yo. You can hardly see what you're shoving your money into. You hope it isn't the hands of the kid that hit you!

meaning_story: They say sheep are detailed creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say.
meaning_hint: So sheep are detailed you say? Imagine how accurate and precise there detailed creatures are. See the sheep working on their sheep stuff in a very detailed manner. Feel their soft wool as you do so.
reading_story: The reason these sheep are so detailed is that they are trying to impress the shogun (しょう). If they make enough of an impression on the shogun, perhaps the shogun won’t kill them for their meat and make their carcasses into clothing.
reading_hint: Imagine you are one of these detailed sheep trying to impress the shogun. What detailed tasks would you perform to show the shogun you aren’t worth killing?

meaning_story: The waiter interviewed the devil on the latest edition of the book he is publishing. The waiter has a part time job as a journalist, so that’s why he’s interviewing the devil on the latest edition of his book. The waiter needs the story for the magazine he works for.
meaning_hint: Imagine the waiter all dressed up in his waiter garb, sitting down with the devil and interviewing him on the latest edition of his book. What kind of book do you think the devil wrote?
reading_story: Actually, this edition of the devil’s book is a fan fiction about Han (はん) Solo with a foreword by Harrison Ford. The previous editions didn’t have the foreword, so this edition is special. The devil really likes Han Solo, so that’s why he wrote this fan fiction.
reading_hint: Imagine reading this book about Han solo written by the devil. This new edition has a foreword by Harrison Ford, but is it really worth buying the book over again? Probably not.

meaning_story: Traveling in the direction of the ocean, you take a gun and shoot a crab, then stick a flag in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to.
meaning_hint: Look at your flag and hear it flapping in the wind. Also hear your ears ringing a bit from when you shot that crab. Look at all the bits of exploded crab strewn around the area. Yowza.
reading_story: To make sure that no one removes your flag, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the key (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it.
reading_hint: Picture yourself locking this flag up with your key. Imagine turning the key in the lock and hearing the click when it is secured.

meaning_story: A tsunami knocks a cleat off a child and the shoe begins to float away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami.
meaning_hint: Your cleat is floating away but you’re floating too. The water is really deep now, but you try and float towards your cleat to retrieve it. Imagine floating in this wet water reaching for your lost cleat.
reading_story: While you float in the water, an uni (う) jabs into your foot. “Uwaaa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~”
reading_hint: Say “Uwaaa~” out loud a few times while you imagine an うに stabbing you as you float along with the tsunami water. What a day you’ve had.

meaning_story: You run every day and soon you become a human that can go beyond the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast.
meaning_hint: Run fast! Go beyond the limits imposed upon you by nature! Imagine yourself running faster than any human has ever run ever. Feel yourself cutting through the air, wind breaking across you as you break the sound barrier. Boom!
reading_story: To solidify your ability to go beyond the abilities of other humans, you etch (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate.
reading_hint: Etch these runes into your legs. Go ahead and run a finger over your legs and pretend to etch runes into them. These runes you etch will allow you to run fast forever.

meaning_story: Using the light from the sun, the Joker is trying to use the scales from a fish tail to illuminate a dark cave. The Joker is taking the light from the sun, reflecting it off the fish tail, and using that reflected sunlight to illuminate the cave.
meaning_hint: Picture the Joker doing this. See the cave illuminate before your eyes. See it sparkle with light. What do you see inside?
reading_story: The sunlight from the fishtail begins to illuminate the cave and then you see it – the lost tomb of the shogun (しょう). This is what you were searching for. The shogun was buried in a secret tomb and at last you have illuminated it!
reading_hint: You are so filled with excitement! Picture what the shogun’s tomb looks like as you think about how rich and famous you will be with this discovery.

meaning_story: A tsunami rips a flag off your house in the rain, causing a leak where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home.
meaning_hint: Look at this leak in your house and see the rain water coming in. Hear it drip drip dripping down the wall.
reading_story: The leak is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of roe (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm!
reading_hint: Did you know that roe can plug any leak? It’s true. If you don’t mind wasting some, you should break a leak into your own house and then try to plug it back up again with some salmon roe.

meaning_story: The lineage radical and the lineage kanji are exactly the same! Brilliant!
reading_story: Lineage describes a family background and your lineage is that of the KKK (けい). This is where you come from. You can trace your lineage back to many KKK members.
reading_hint: Imagine how you would feel if you found out about your lineage like this. How would you feel if most of your ancestors had been KKK members?

meaning_story: A servant holding a gun sits on the ground to see if he can find something to look at. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers.
meaning_hint: Look at this servant. He’s doing a great job. Oops, look like he sees you. Yup, he’s pointing his gun at you. Imagine staring down the barrel of his gun as you slowly back away.
reading_story: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man Randy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, look at this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him.
reading_hint: Pretend you are Macho Man Randy Savage. Run at this servant guy, take his gun away, and beat him up. Ohhh yeaaahhh!

meaning_story: A woman and a duck are in the sun preparing for marriage. Marriage to each other, that is. This woman is marrying a duck out in the sun. How odd.
meaning_hint: Imagine this marriage. Why would a woman marry a duck? Imagine the woman in her wedding gown and the duck in a little tuxedo, quacking up a storm.
reading_story: Once they get to the part in the marriage ceremony where they ask if anyone objects, a condor (こん) swoops down from the sky and gets into a fight with the duck. Apparently the condor thinks that he should be with the woman and that the duck stole his love away. Yikes.
reading_hint: Imagine the condor fighting the duck as the woman looks on from the sidelines, weeping into her dress. What a sight.

meaning_story: Seeing a fish stick, a cross, a Sauron action figure, and some old clothes brings up a great feeling of nostalgia. Fish sticks were your favorite food as a child, you were raised very Christian, and you used to love Lord of the Rings. Oh the nostalgia.
meaning_hint: Imagine all these things from your childhood. Pick them up and feel what they feel like. Imagine yourself all nostalgic as you examine them.
reading_story: Another thing you used to love doing as a child was to tie knots (なつ). To further increase the feeling of nostalgia you’re experiencing, you grab some rope and start trying knots in it. It’s almost like you’re a kid again!
reading_hint: Feel nostalgia as you continue tying knots in this rope. Feel the weight of the rope in your hand as you continue to tie it in knots.

meaning_story: Holding a nailbat on the sun, you put your ear to a stool while someone takes a photograph of you then hands you the photo. You took the nailbat to the sun to defeat monsters there, and you put your ear to the stool because you thought you heard it say something. When you did so, one of the sun monsters you came to defeat snapped a photo of you, then handed you the photograph.
meaning_hint: Imagine doing all this. Feel the weight of the nailbat in your hand and the heat from the sun. Feel the wood of the stool on your face as you press your ear to it. Hear and see the flash of the camera as the photograph is taken of you.
reading_story: When the sun monster took the photograph and handed you the photo, you couldn’t even see the photo because you’d been blinded by the flash. Not being able to see, you sat (さつ) down on the stool and tried to regain your sight. The sun monster sat down too, waiting to give you the photograph.
reading_hint: You sat down on the stool. Feel the wood under your butt as you sit. It’s not a comfortable stool. Rub your eyes until you regain your sight.

meaning_story: That tree is big, but it looks like it needs to rest its head on a pillow or something. See, the tree, while big, looked really messed up, kind of smushed a bit. Something must be wrong with the tree. I think it needs a rest. Somebody get this tree a pillow to rest on.
meaning_hint: Look at this big messed up tree. Now imagine the tree falling down, creaking all the way as it rests on the big pillow. Be sure to remember that the tree is big in a messed up way as the radical for big is also kind of messed up and mushed.
reading_story: While the big tree is sleeping on the pillow, you sneak past him and steal his Mac Cooler (まくら) (the cooler where he stores all his Big Macs). This Mac Cooler will feed you and all your friends for years!
reading_hint: Imagine lugging this Mac Cooler away from the tree as he snores into the pillow. Feel how heavy the Mac Cooler is as you drag it along the ground.

meaning_story: If you point a loaded gun in the direction of a child on a water slide, things will quickly turn from play time to potential jail time. You should never point a gun in anyone’s direction, let alone a helpless child on a water slide. He’s just trying to play and have a good time.
meaning_hint: Pretend you’re the child on the waterslide and you see someone pointing a gun in your direction. How terrifying would that be? It’s not like you can run, or get off the water slide. You just have to hope the guy with the gun is a bad shot. You’re just trying to play, and here’s this guy pointing a gun in your direction. Rude!
reading_story: Who points a gun in the direction of a helpless child? Nobody. This guy’s a real a**hole (あそ). He deserves to be punished. Pointing a gun in the direction of a child while he’s trying to play on a waterslide is just terrible. What an a**hole.
reading_hint: I mean really – what sort of person would do this? He’s a real jerk. Get mad at this a**hole and use that anger to remember this kanji.

meaning_story: You catch a fish stick with a hook in order to give it to a person and make them pleasant. This person wasn’t pleasant before, so in order to make them pleasant, you gave them their favorite food – fish sticks.
meaning_hint: Imagine catching this fish stick with a hook and then feeding it to this person. See their expression change drastically until they look incredibly pleasant. See them smiling and laughing and looking so very pleasant.
reading_story: Unfortunately, coyotes (かい) also find fish sticks to be pleasant, and soon you attract some of them. The coyotes surround you and the other person, eying up your fish sticks. You’d better give up the fish stick, these coyotes don’t look very pleasant.
reading_hint: You toss the fish stick at the coyote. Hear the coyote scarfing up the fish stick, smacking its lips, as you back slowly away and make your escape.

meaning_story: Every part of a clam must be eaten by those who are poor, even the shell. Poor people can’t afford to waste anything, so they eat every single part of the clam.
meaning_hint: Imagine being poor and eating a whole clam. Imagine eating the good part, and then imagine crunching and cracking your teeth on the shell as you grind it up in your mouth. It’s wretched.
reading_story: Since you’re poor, you always need to forage for new food. After finishing every part of the clam, you forage around in a nearby trash bin (びん) for discarded clam shells to munch on. Rummaging through the bin, you find some more clam shells.
reading_hint: Picture yourself digging through the bin. Feel the trash between your fingers as you search for more clams. Smell the terrible odor of trash as you search.

meaning_story: If Big Bird makes a mistake and you try to correct him you’re only going to prolong things. Big Bird is very stubborn and always believes he is correct. Arguing with him over it will only prolong the situation.
meaning_hint: Imagine what Big Bird could have done wrong. He believes he is correct. Imagine yourself yelling and arguing at Big Bird over it.
reading_story: Actually, you are an Ent (えん), and as everyone knows, Ents take a long time to say things. Being an Ent, you prolong pretty much everything that requires words, so this argument with Big Bird here is going to take forever.
reading_hint: Silly Ent, why prolong this argument any longer than it needs to be? Imagine yourself as a tree, arguing over things with Big Bird for an eternity. Prolonged forever. Neverending.

meaning_story: You take a nailbat to a turtle shell and push the nails into it. You want the turtle to come out of his turtle shell but you don’t want to damage the turtle shell too much, so you just push the nailbat into it instead of just smashing it.
meaning_hint: Imagine this poor little turtle in his turtle shell as you place the nailbat atop him and start pushing down. Hear the turtle screaming for mercy as you continue to push.
reading_story: Push down harder… A little harder… Push… CRACK! Oh (お) no, the turtle shell split into a million pieces. It’s worthless now. Oh no.
reading_hint: Oh no. Say it out loud a few times as you imagine smashing the turtle shell with your nailbat. Oh no.

meaning_story: If you look for a leaf among the hills you will notice they are scarce. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills.
meaning_hint: Imagine being on the hills. You want a leaf to find and take back as a souvenir but there are none. Imagine looking feverishly for a leaf even though you don’t really expect to find one.
reading_story: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too scarce to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a bow (ぼう). You were looking for a leaf, but instead you found a bow. No one else is around, so you take the bow as your own.
reading_hint: Hold the bow in your hand, pulling the bowstring back taut. Pluck the bowstring with your fingers making it hum as you think of that scarce leaf you never did find.

meaning_story: The next plate is the one you will steal. The last plate would have been too obvious. This next one will be the best plate to steal.
meaning_hint: Wait for this next plate. Here it is – now steal it! Imagine yourself stealing this plate and making off with it.
reading_story: You steal this plate from a Tokyo (とう) restaurant so after you steal it, imagine yourself running through the streets of Tokyo as you lose your pursuers.
reading_hint: Be careful not to drop that plate! Wouldn’t want to steal something just to break it. Imagine yourself running through the streets of Tokyo. See all the sights and hear all the sounds. Just don’t get too distracted, you gotta get to a safe place and stash your plate away.

meaning_story: This clam has a circus subscription. The clam subscribes to the circus, in every way. The clam has a circus magazine subscription, season tickets to the circus, the whole works.
meaning_hint: Imagine this clam decked out in its circus gear. It has peanuts, popcorn, face paint, and a stack of magazine subscriptions. Hear the sounds of a circus in the background, elephants and tigers and bears, oh my!
reading_story: こういち sees this clam with his magazine subscription and こういち doesn’t want to be left out of the fad so こういち gets a magazine subscription too. Then every week, こういち and the clam get together with the magazines from their subscriptions and read about the circus together.
reading_hint: Look at こういち and the clam reading their magazine subscriptions together. Listen to them chuckle and chat about circus stuff.

meaning_story: On a water slide, a mohawk is a most suitable hairstyle. The mohawk is very aerodynamic, so it is highly suitable for a water slide where speed is important. Truly, a mohawk is the most suitable hairstyle for a water slide.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself with a Mohawk speeding down a water slide faster than ever before. Think how suitable this hairstyle is as you rocket down the wet slide, water splashing all around.
reading_story: Being a techie (てき), you design something even more suitable for the water slide. You design a mechanical mohawk that is even more suitable for reaching maximum speeds on this water slide. Being a techie comes in handy sometimes.
reading_hint: Imagine this techy mohawk and what it would look like on your head. Imagine it with jet airplane wings and little boosters on the side. Hear your mohawk engines roar as you speed down the water slide.

meaning_story: There are some feathers resting on a stand and you and the following of the feathers are following the feathers. The feathers have a following, and you are one member of the following. You and your fellow followers follow the feathers wherever they may go.
meaning_hint: Imagine you and the following following the feathers all around. Following the feathers isn’t always easy, but you do it anyway. Imagine touching one of the feathers and feeling the smooth texture on your skin.
reading_story: While you and the following are following the feathers from their departure from the stand, one of the members of the following drops an egg and yolk (よく) spills everywhere. What a mess! Being a quick thinker, you use one of the feathers to soak up the yolk and clean up the mess.
reading_hint: Imagine cleaning up egg yolk with a feather. The rest of the following follows your example and takes the other feathers, helping you clean up the yolk.

meaning_story: A tsunami is heated by the sun inside an enclosure where you use a spoon to quench your thirst. This tsunami is inside an enclosure, and you are spooning the hot water out of it to drink. For whatever reason, hot tsunami water heated by the sun relieves your thirst the most.
meaning_hint: Imagine this thirst of yours. You’re super thirsty so you grab your spoon and start spooning the hot tsunami water into your thirsty mouth. Feel the hot water on your tongue as your thirst in quenched.
reading_story: What do you say when your thirst is quenched? Cowabunga (かわ), dude! Y’know, like the Ninja Turtles? Cowabunga, your thirst has been quenched!
reading_hint: Say cowabunga out loud a few times. Imagine spooning some hot water into your mouth while you do so. Cowabunga!

meaning_story: You take some bamboo and glue it into a figurine as a token of appreciation for your friend. You glue the bamboo together and make a cute little figurine. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself gluing this bamboo together. You get wood splinters and glue all over your hands but you know your friend will appreciate this token so you carry on.
reading_story: You hand your friend this token of appreciation and your friend tells you they’re actually allergic to bamboo! You fool (ふ)! How could you forget? What a foolish thing to do. You wasted so much time and effort on this token of friendship. You foolish fool.
reading_hint: Imagine the embarrassment you feel, forgetting they were allergic to bamboo. Oh well, it’s the thought that counts. You’re still a fool, though.

radicals: 一, 山, 冖, 巾
meaning_story: On the ground at the base of a mountain you hit the forehead of Two Face with your belt. You pushed Two Face down the mountain first, and when he hit the ground at the bottom, you proceeded to bash him in the forehead with your belt.
meaning_hint: What could Two Face have done to deserve so much punishment? Imagine what he could have done to get you so angry as you continue to smack him in the forehead with your belt. Smack, smack, smack!
reading_story: Turns out that Two Face stole your favorite tie (たい). He’s not giving you your tie back, so you just gotta keep beating him up until he gives it up. Shoving him down the mountain didn’t work, so now you’re hitting him with your belt in the hopes that will work. You really want that tie back!
reading_hint: See your tie around Two Face’s neck as you continue beating him with the belt. “Gimme back my tie, you jerk!” SMACK! “That tie is mine, you thief!” SMACK! “I’m going to strangle you to death with that tie if you don’t give it back right this instant!” SMACK SMACK SMACK!

meaning_story: You see a mullet on a good butcher as he stands in a corridor. He’s in the corridor because he needs to get him mullet into his hair net before he starts butchering. Since he’s such a good butcher, he never forgets to tie up his mullet.
meaning_hint: See this good butcher standing in the corridor, tying up his epic mullet. Really focus on the corridor he’s in, imagining what the walls look like as you touch them.
reading_story: As you walk down the corridor, you trip and drop the bucket of salmon roe (ろう) you were bringing to sell him. The good butcher dives and manages to save every last roe from splatting all over the corridor’s ground.
reading_hint: This corridor won’t claim another roe life thanks to the good butcher and his trusty fast reflexes (and mulleted head)!

meaning_story: You shoot a rocket at a turkey to detach its head from its body. The rocket hits the turkey, and its head becomes detached from its body. The turkey is now dead.
meaning_hint: You really want to dismember this turkey with a rocket. Visualize the rocket detach its head from its body, detach the legs and detach the wings in your mind. See it all happening as the rocket explodes. Boom.
reading_story: The reason you want to detach the limbs from this turkey is that the turkey is actually a piñata and inside him are a ton of Reese’s (り) Pieces. You love Reese’s Pieces so you just gotta blow up this turkey.
reading_hint: Imagine seeing the limbs of the turkey detach from its body as the rocket explodes him open and Reese’s Pieces go flying everywhere. Open your mouth and catch them, letting the peanut buttery chocolate goodness melt in your mouth.

meaning_story: You loiter around a tombstone and measure its diameter. You’re doing this to each tombstone, and if you loiter around long enough, you’ll soon know the diameter of every tombstone.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself loitering about, measuring the diameter of each tombstone. Picture yourself measuring them, your hands running over the smooth carved stone.
reading_story: You’re measuring the diameter of the last tombstone when you realize it belongs to a KKK (けい) member. You know they were a KKK member because it says “KKK” right on the tombstone. You grimace as you finish measuring the diameter.
reading_hint: Run your fingers around the diameter of this last tombstone. Feel the etchings where it says “KKK” as you imagine what this person’s life must have been like.

meaning_story: Chester the Molester takes an insect and proceeds to dissolve it in some acid. Chester is pretty messed up in the brain, so he likes to do things like dissolve insects in his spare time.
meaning_hint: See Chester the Molester dropping drops of acid onto this insect, dissolving pieces one by one. Look at the insect squirm in pain as its limbs get dissolved.
reading_story: Just when the last bit of the insect begins to dissolve, you finally work up the courage to confront Chester. “YOU (ゆう)! You… you… JERK!”
reading_hint: Okay so maybe you’re not the best with words, but the important part is that you called Chester out. Good job, you.

meaning_story: This grave is filled with a pool of ice which will equal death for anyone who falls into it. If you fell into this grave filled with ice, you would certainly die. Ice grave equals death.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself falling into this ice pool inside the grave. Remember that the pool radical is full of ice and not water since it has two drops which equal ice. Feel the cold embrace of the ice grave as you fall in.
reading_story: Now you’re dead. You equal death. Someone is going to have to notify your next of kin (きん). You’re already in a grave, so your kin won’t have to bury you, but it’s still sad regardless.
reading_hint: Imagine your kin finding you in this grave. Their sadness is all equal, no on kin member is more sad than the other, but they are all very sad. Imagine them all weeping while they stand around your grave.

meaning_story: A butcher has a surplus of meat and if you exclude last year, this is the most meat he’s ever had. It’s not often that this butcher has a surplus, but these last two years have been years of surplus. If you exclude last year, this year is the largest surplus of meat this butcher has ever had.
meaning_hint: Look at all the meat! Exclude last year, don’t even think about it. Just look at all the surplus this year! Smell and see all the meat around. There’s so much of it.
reading_story: Someone brings up the surplus you had last year, so you hit him with a jo (じょ). You specifically told people to exclude last year, and this guy didn’t listen. Hit him and anyone else with your jo should they bring up the forbidden subject.
reading_hint: Imagine smacking people with your jo each time they bring up last year, the thing you specifically told them to exclude. Smack!

meaning_story: You change your attitude about a clam being precious freight after you realize how expensive it is. This particular clam is incredibly valuable. It’s worth a lot of money. Before you didn’t think it was freight worthy of such a fuss, but you’ve changed your mind.
meaning_hint: Imagine what would make this clam so luxurious that it would be considered precious freight. Perhaps it’s made out of solid gold. Maybe it’s jewel encrusted. Who knows?
reading_story: The best way to transport freight like this is in your very own car (か). When it’s in your car, you can keep an eye on it and know that it is safe. Just don’t crash your car, okay?
reading_hint: Imagine driving your car with the precious freight sitting in the seat next to you. Keep glancing over at it as you drive your car, just to make sure the freight is still safe.

meaning_story: A child shares his lineage with a grandchild. The child passes his lineage down to his child and then that child’s child is the grandchild and between them all a lineage is shared.
meaning_hint: Look at this family tree. See the child, and then the grandchild. Trace the lineage with your finger as you observe.
reading_story: The son (そん) of a son is a grandchild. In this case, a grandson. Easy.
reading_hint: Just remember that a son is all you really want. You need a son to carry on the family name and the lineage. So make sure that your child and your grandchild are both sons.

meaning_story: A greenhouse being used as a grave is still a grave, though it's kind of a crappy one.
meaning_hint: Go into the greenhouse grave. It reeks of dead bodies because you didn't bury anything, plus, it's really warm. This was the worst idea ever.
reading_story: You have buried in this greenhouse grave Bobo (ぼ) the clown.
reading_hint: You look down to see his half decomposed body. His nose is still bright red, and a lot of his makeup remains on top of his withering face. To say the least, it's really gross.

meaning_story: You poop twice on a sleeping drunkard person and you find yourself wondering how many more times you can poop on them and wonder how much they can take before they realize what’s going on.
meaning_hint: You’ve already pooped twice on this drunkard, how many more times can you do it? How much do you think this person can take? Just imagine yourself doing this.
reading_story: As you continue thinking about how much poop this drunkard can take and how many more poops you can drop on him, he begins to wake up. Quickly, you eke (いく) out one last poop before you scurry away. You eke that poop out just in time to make your escape.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as you eke out that last poop. Really concentrate on eking it out so you can get away in time. Flex your butt muscles for added effect.

radicals: 工, 口, 寸, ヨ
meaning_story: Wolverine is doing a construction job and he’s using his mouth to measure so he knows how many folks he needs to inquire about helping him with the job. Using one’s mouth is a strange way to measure something, but that’s just how Wolverine does things. Once he measures it all out, he’ll know how many construction workers he needs to inquire about working for him.
meaning_hint: Imagine Wolverine going around, measuring the construction site with his mouth. Look at him with his mouth wide open, wandering around the site deep in thought. What a weirdo.
reading_story: You decide to inquire as to why Wolverine is using his mouth to measure out this construction site. As you get closer you notice his cool ripped jeans (じん). Instead you inquire how he got such a fresh style. He looks you up and down, pulls out his claws, and tears yours up to match his. You’ve completely forgotten what it was you were asking, but who cares! Look how great you look!
reading_hint: Look down at your ripped up jeans. You’re so fashionable now! Just like good old ‘90s Wolvie.

meaning_story: Taking some thread and sitting by a bookshelf, you begin to knit. You knit by this bookshelf because you don’t know how to knit, and the bookshelf is filled with books on how to knit.
meaning_hint: Imagine reading these how to knit books as you attempt to knit with this thread. It’s not easy, and the going is slow. Feel frustrated with your progress.
reading_story: You’re trying to knit because your pet hen (へん) gets cold in the winter. To warm up your hen, you want to knit a small little hen sweater for it to wear.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to knit this hen sweater for your hen. Imagine what it will look like once it’s finished as you feel the thread and the knitting needles in your hands.

meaning_story: A butcher butchers the womb of a woman and her baby falls to the land below. The woman needs a C-section, so the butcher cuts open her womb and her child falls down to the land beneath her.
meaning_hint: This is kind of gruesome to picture, but that’ll help you remember. Hear the woman scream as her womb is cut open and head the baby cry once he’s on land.
reading_story: Once on land, the baby covers his nose. Something begins to reek (りく). What is that smell? It reeks!
reading_hint: It’s the woman’s womb that starts to reek. Her womb is getting infected and the smell is overwhelming. Cover your nose to protect yourself from the stench as you fall to the land under you because your knees go weak from the reeking stench.

meaning_story: You take a nailbat measuring pi feet in length, and hit a tree with it while you look for valuables. This is a special nailbat, measuring the length of pi in feet. It’s pretty impressive, when you look for stuff, this nailbat is indispensable.
meaning_hint: While you imagine yourself as you look for valuables, also marvel at this amazing nailbat you have. Feel the weight in your hands as you smack the tree with it.
reading_story: In order to cover all your bases while you look for valuables in this tree, you have to smash the whole thing open. This tree is huge, so you’re outside all day hitting it with your nailbat. Since you’re out in the sun all day, you get a deep tan (たん). This tan is so dark you almost look like a different person.
reading_hint: Feel the sun on your back as you get tan. You’re more tan than you’ve ever been before. Look in a mirror and check out that nice tan of yours.

radicals: 亠, 口, 冖, 豕
meaning_story: There is a lid in your mouth and on your forehead there’s a pig who is feeling very luxurious. You are this pig’s servant and he has commanded you to carry around a lid in your mouth while he rides around on your forehead. This luxurious pig pays you very well, so you put up with it.
meaning_hint: Feel the pig’s weight on your forehead as you taste the metal from the lid in your mouth. You don’t feel very luxurious, but the pig sure does.
reading_story: You are ごういち. In your old age, you’ve been finding it hard to make ends meet, but this luxurious pig has taken you in. This pig has a soft spot for people like you, ごういち, so that’s why he employed you, even though you’re so old.
reading_hint: Picture ごういち with a pig riding on his forehead and a lid in his mouth. Poor ごういち. How did it come to this?

meaning_story: You are given some gold to oversee a model. You are a famous architect, so you get a lot of gold for overseeing the construction of models like this one.
meaning_hint: Feel the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you oversee this model being built. Observe it and watch as it grows under your watchful eye.
reading_story: When the model nears completion, you accidentally drop a can (かん) of coffee right on top of it. Oh snap. The can spills and coffee gets all up in the model’s business. That model has been ruined.
reading_hint: Imagine dropping this can. See it fall in slow motion before the can finally spills all over, ruining the model.

meaning_story: A tsunami came in and buried your flag so now you have to use a spoon and dig it out of the mud. The tsunami knocked your flag over and then covered it in mud, so you gotta use your spoon to dig it out.
meaning_hint: Imagine using a spoon to dig your flag outta all this mud. So much mud! Feel its col soiled wetness on your hands as you dig away.
reading_story: The time of day (でい) is high noon, so the sun soon dries the mud and makes it harder to dig through. It just might take you all day to spoon your way through this mud.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself out in the day, continuing to dig through the now hardened mud. Feel your arm getting tired as day slowly turns to night.

meaning_story: A witch doctor takes some fins and makes a nest out of them to ensure a good fishing season for the village. The reason it's a nest is because it represents many fish being born, and if there are many fish, then it'll be a good fishing season for all
meaning_hint: Imagine building this nest from fish fins. It’s not the same as a normal nest, but it gets the job done. Also it smells really fishy.
reading_story: But, the nest doesn’t help at all with this year's fishing. In fact, this year's fishing was the worst. All the villagers get together to sue (す) the witch doctor.
reading_hint: Imagine the court case and the proceedings. This witch doctor is going to lose everything for the nest that didn't work.

meaning_story: You line up your body with the sun and everything looks normal. The sun is lined up behind you, and you’re looking at all the things the sun has lit up. Everything looks normal.
meaning_hint: Gaze out in a line from the sun as you observe the world. Everything is very normal looking and comforting.
reading_story: Soon you see something that doesn’t look so normal. It’s a fool (ふ), a jester. Dressed all in fool’s garb, this fool is dancing up towards you with a ridiculously unsettling grin on his face.
reading_hint: Imagine this creepy looking fool as he approaches. He’s kind of freaking you out. Feel very uncomfortable as you continue looking at this fool.

meaning_story: A tree next to a train gets hit with antenna and then a pole. The antenna and pole are sticking out of the train, so when the train goes past the tree, the tree gets hit.
meaning_hint: Hear the train choo-choo along and listen to the snap and crack as the tree gets hit with both the train’s antenna and pole.
reading_story: After the train’s pole runs into the tree, it snaps off and lands in the train car you’re in. Taking the opportunity, you bend and fashion the pole into a bow (ぼう). You find some arrows, and spend the rest of the train ride shooting targets with your bow and arrow.
reading_hint: Imagine bending this pole into the curve of a bow and then shooting things from a moving train. Hear the twang of the bow each time you loose an arrow.

meaning_story: If you grind rice, every part of it, eventually it will become a fine powder. You can then use this rice powder as a part to create some other dish. Some kind of cake, perhaps.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself grinding this rice into a powder. Hear the scrape of the rice on stone as you grind it down to the finest powder.
reading_story: Actually, grinding the rice down to a powder is super fun (ふん). It’s so fun you don’t want to stop! AH HAHAHAHA! RICE POWDER! SO FUN!
reading_hint: Okay, we got a little carried away there. Just keep in mind how fun this is. Make sure you say fun with a little bit of a Scottish accent. You know what they say, Scotts have more fun!

meaning_story: You had a good fang previously, but now that fang is worthless. Previously, when you were young, all of your fangs were good. Now that you are old, your fangs are dull and worn.
meaning_hint: Think back to this good fang that you had previously. Imagine feeling the fang with your tongue and reminiscing over what a good fang it was.
reading_story: To remember your old but good fang and other things that happened previously, you keep a diary in a locked box. You hide the key (き) for it around your neck on a chain. That way the key is always with you and you’ll never lose it.
reading_hint: Previously you didn’t have a key, but now you do. Feel the cold metal of the key on your skin as the necklace moves about on your neck.

meaning_story: You request that winter rescue you from the warmth. It's summer but you want it to be winter. You request that winter rescue you from the summer weather.
meaning_hint: It's so hot. You need a rescue. Imagine the cool of winter rescuing you from this hot, hot heat.
reading_story: If you don’t receive a rescue soon, your cute (きゅう) rabbit pet is going to melt. Winter needs o get here soon or your cute rabbit is going to die from the heat.
reading_hint: Imagine your poor cute rabbit melting in the heat. If only winter had come to rescue him sooner. Oh, such woe!

meaning_story: A leader of (odd looking) lions puts a drop of magic liquid on his face to look like a person who might resemble someone else. The leader of lions is going incognito, so he needs to resemble a person who is not himself. He takes this drop of powerful face paint and transforms.
meaning_hint: Watch this leader as the transformation takes place. Now he doesn’t resemble anything like the leader he used to be. He doesn’t look like the same person. Watch him morph in your head.
reading_story: The reason he doesn’t resemble the same person anymore is because he actually resembles a horse now. The leader is now a horse! Listen to him neigh (ね) and stamp his feet. Woah, easy there boy!
reading_hint: Listen to this horse who used to be a leader neigh and stomp around. Hear the neigh in your ears as you try and calm the horse down.

meaning_story: Wearing a helmet, a creeper sneaks into a rice paddy, steals all the rice, and becomes rich from selling it all. The creeper is so good at getting into the rice paddy because he is so accomplished at creeping. Plus, the helmet helps his stealth as well. He sells the rice on the black market and turns a sweet profit, getting filthy rich.
meaning_hint: Imagine this creeper creeping into the rice paddy. He’s very creepy, but also very sneaky. Now imagine him rolling in all the yen he made from selling all of the rice. He’s rich, but he’s the disgusting kind of rich. Yuck.
reading_story: Once the owner of the rice paddy discovers that all his rice has been taken, he realizes what a fool (ふ) he’s been to not implement some sort of security measure against thieving creepers. Now the rice paddy owner will never get rich. He has no rice to sell! Oh, what a fool he is.
reading_hint: Imagine the rich creeper and imagine the fool rice paddy owner. There’s quite a big difference between their attitudes and moods. Juxtapose these in your mind and think of what a lousy situation it is for the rice paddy owner. Pool fool.

meaning_story: If you play blackjack on the moon in the winter, your cards will scatter everywhere. The cards scatter because the gravity is so weak on the moon, so the blackjack game is prone to disaster.
meaning_hint: Imagine playing blackjack on the moon where even the slightest move causes the cards to scatter about. Watch them float along. It’s very frustrating to play this way.
reading_story: You are playing blackjack with Santa-san (さん). Santa-san is doing his best to use his Christmas magic to prevent the scatter of cards, but it’s not working out so well. Good effort, Santa-san.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself next to Santa-san as he tries to prevent the cards from scattering. Look at the expression of concentration on Santa-san’s face as he tries to prevent the scatter.

meaning_story: The flowers next to the potato are a little showy, don’t you think? I don’t believe the flowers are needed. The flowers are too showy. Just the potatoes are fine.
meaning_hint: Imagine the flowers next to the potatoes. Sure they smell nice, but they’re a bit showy, gaudy, and unnecessary.
reading_story: The flowers are too showy so you get in a car (か) and drive the flowers over to your friend’s house to give them the flowers. They don’t need to know where the flowers came from, it’s the thought that counts. So get in your car and drive on over!
reading_hint: See the showy flowers on the seat next to you as you drive over to your friend’s house. Visualize which friend you’re going to see as you hear the car engine roar.

meaning_story: You use your mouth when you see a Chinese person and you sigh. You sigh so loud that it’s practically a roar coming out of your mouth. Chinese people and Chinese things make you sigh because it reminds you of when you stayed in China and it brings up memories. The sigh is a sigh of nostalgia.
meaning_hint: Let out a long sigh as you recall memories from China and all the Chinese things you saw and did. Oh, sigh.
reading_story: Your favorite Chinese thing to do is tan (たん). You can wander around without your shirt on and tan all day. No one will sigh or scoff at you, it’s perfectly acceptable. The Chinese just love to get their tan on.
reading_hint: Sigh again as you remember how nice it was to tan everywhere. Picture yourself wandering around some Chinese streets with your shirt off as you soak in the rays and get a tan.

meaning_story: Your leader sticks his toe into a clam to spy on it. There’s a hidden camera on his toe and the leader wants to have plenty of secret spy footage to review later.
meaning_hint: Imagine having your toe as a spy. Wiggle your toe around, pretending like you’re using it to spy on that suspicious clam, just like your leader does.
reading_story: While you and your leader spy on the clam, you realize that the clam is smuggling tater (てい) tots. Use the camera to watch the clam smuggle these tater tots. The clam eats a few tater tots in the process.
reading_hint: Boy you wish you had some tater tots. Tater tots are good. Imagine how good a tater tot would taste in your mouth as you continue to spy on this devious clam.

meaning_story: If you can write an interesting poem about winter while riding on a horse, I’ll be pretty surprised. It’s hard enough to write a poem as it is, let alone an interesting one. And then you’re riding on a horse and the poem has to be about winter? Heck, I’d be surprised if you didn’t fall off the horse and injure yourself, let alone write a poem.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to write a poem while riding a horse. It’d be really hard to do. I bet you’d be surprised if you managed to do it as well.
reading_story: You might also be surprised to learn that you are to ride this horse all across Kyoto (きょう). That gives you a time limit. You have until you traverse Kyoto to write this poem about winter.
reading_hint: Imagine riding through Kyoto on a horse. As if that wasn’t difficult enough for poem writing, now you have all the sights and sounds of Kyoto to distract you as well.

meaning_story: Taking a nailbat, Wolverine smashes the forehead of Two Face and proceeds to sweep up the mess afterwards. Once Wolverine is done smashing Two Face’s forehead with that nailbat, there’s quite a mess to clean up. Wolverine then takes a broom and uses it to sweep up the mess he made.
meaning_hint: Watch Wolverine sweep up the mess he made. Hear the sweep-sweep sound as he cleans up all the bloodied remains from his nailbat rampage.
reading_story: Wolverine finishes his sweep, then notices he’s missing an ear. He must have accidentally knocked it off during his rage. Wolverine then finds his ear, and begins to sew (そう) it back onto his head. Wolverine has done this before so he knows how to sew body parts back on.
reading_hint: Look at Wolverine as he sews his ear back on. He really does know how to sew, so the job is done pretty quickly. Imagine what it would feel like to sew your own ear back on as you watch.

meaning_story: Holding a bouquet of flowers, you take a cleat to a tree in an attempt to collect a vegetable from it. You have cleats on your feet, and you’re kicking the tree so it will drop any vegetables it might be carrying. The flowers are for your sweetheart, and you want to get them a vegetable too.
meaning_hint: Imagine kicking this tree with your cleated foot. You don’t expect it to be harboring any vegetables, but you’re desperate. Feel the vibration run up your let as you kick the tree once more.
reading_story: Once you realize that the tree doesn’t have even a single vegetable, you let out a deep long sigh (さい). You’re depressed. No vegetable for you or your sweetie. Sigh.
reading_hint: Sigh out loud a few times while you think about your lack of vegetable. It’s really depressing you. Sigh sigh sigh.

meaning_story: Under the moon while you sit on a cliff, you inject a syringe of tofu right into your vein. Ahh, tofu. You’re addicted to it. You sneak out to the cliff at night to get your tofu fix, injecting it straight into your vein.
meaning_hint: Feel the tofu running through your veins. Feel the tofu goodness spreading all over your body. It’s so intense you can even taste a little tofu in your mouth.
reading_story: Eventually, your friends and family find you at the cliff, tripping on tofu. Each and every vein on your body is engorged, pulsating with the effects of tofu. Your friends try and take you home. “You cyan’t myake (みゃく) me!” You slur, suffering from the effects of the tofu. “None of you cyan myake me go home! You cyan’t myake me! Nyah!”
reading_hint: Say this out loud, it’ll help you remember. Really focus on the “myake” be sure to say it like you’re all bugged out from tofu overdose.

meaning_story: You loiter about carrying a cross to protect you from Sauron claiming your heart of virtue. Sauron wants your heart because it is filled with virtue and Sauron needs a virtuous heart to complete his latest scheme. Luckily, this enchanted cross you have protects you from Sauron.
meaning_hint: Feel your heart of virtue in your chest. It’s a good heart, full of virtue. Feel the weight of the cross in your hand as Sauron tries to approach you but can’t. The cross protects you.
reading_story: Sauron tries to tempt your virtue by encouraging you to light a cigar and toke (とく) up. Smoking is not viewed as virtuous in this land, so Sauron is trying to play a trick on you by getting you to drop your guard and toke up. It will taint your virtue a bit, but not enough to deter Sauron from taking your heart anyway.
reading_hint: Imagine Sauron trying to coax you into taking a toke of his cigar. “C’mon, guy – all the cool kids are doing it. You want to be cool, don’t you?” Continue to imagine Sauron trying to peer pressure you into taking a toke as you loiter about some more, still carrying your cross.

meaning_story: On the roof are two flags above the mouth to the warehouse. The double flag marks the entrance to the warehouse, and they are located on the roof right above it.
meaning_hint: Look at this warehouse. See the double flags above the mouth to the warehouse and hear them flapping in the wind as you approach.
reading_story: As you get closer to the warehouse, one of the flags falls off. This is unacceptable, so you climb up there and sew (そう) the flag back on. This double flag needs to stay intact, so you sew it back together right away.
reading_hint: Picture yourself atop the roof of this warehouse as you sew the flags back together. Feel the needle and thread in your hands as you work.

meaning_story: Mix spiders into alcohol to make acid. Spiders have a little bit in them already, but if you really want to make it potent, smash them in some whiskey to make a deadly acid that will rip through anything.
meaning_hint: Imagine crushing up some spiders into alcohol. Watch it turn green. It's going to eat through the beaker! Quick, do something!
reading_story: You're trying to find a container for this acid when Santa-san (さん) bursts through your wall. He frowns down at you. You're on the naughty list now. You killed spiders AND made dangerous acid? Ooooh you're in trouble.
reading_hint: It’s Christmas morning. Instead of gifts, Santa-san just throws a piece of charcoal at your face. Feel the charcoal smash into your face and explode into acid, burning you. Santa-san runs away laughing. Ho ho ho!

meaning_story: A husband and another husband find a clam and agree to share it between them. They agree to share, so each husband gets a part of the clam to themselves.
meaning_hint: How nice that they were able to agree here. Look at each husband having half of the clam. Boy, sharing sure is caring.
reading_story: Since the husbands were able to agree, Santa-san (さん) believes they’re both good husbands and belong on the good list. Therefore, Santa-san gives them each lots and lots of clams for Christmas.
reading_hint: Imagine Santa-san flying over the husbands in his sleigh, raining clams down upon them from the sky. It warms the heart, wouldn’t you agree?

meaning_story: You come across a pelican wearing a top hat and it claims to be one of your ancestors reborn. Normally you wouldn't believe any old pelican that claimed to be a dead ancestor, but this one is wearing a top hat... so it must be telling the truth!
meaning_hint: Imagine meeting a long dead ancestor in the form of a top hat wearing pelican! Quick, ask him if there are any health conditions in your family you should know about.
reading_story: You ask your ancestor pelican how life is now that he's, well you know, a pelican.The pelican shrugs and says, "Eh, it's so-so (そ)." Now that you think about it, he must have had a so-so life to be reborn as a so-so pelican.
reading_hint: Your ancestor had a so-so life when he was a human and now he's having a so-so life as a pelican. At least he looks dapper in that hat!

meaning_story: A gold bar can be turned into a coin. Well, more than one coin, probably. But you know for sure that you can make at least one coin out of this gold bar.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking this gold bar and punching a coin out of it. Imagine yourself pulling a lever to press a coin out of the gold bar. Feel the lever going down as you hear the sound of a gold coin being punched out.
reading_story: You need this coin to give to a centaur (せん). The centaur is your bodyguard and he only accepts gold coins as payment.
reading_hint: Imagine paying this centaur with your gold coin. Hear the centaur thank you in his gruff voice before he gallops away.

meaning_story: Into the water slide you enter, and upon arrival you realize how crowded it is. It’s more like a people slide than a water slide, really.
meaning_hint: Feel the people slithering around as you go down the crowded water slide of people. They’re all damp and squirmy. Yuck.
reading_story: Back when I was a 子 (こ), these water slides weren’t nearly as crowded. 子 these days have it rough.
reading_hint: With wistful nostalgia, think back to when you were a 子. Remember the simpler times when slides weren’t this crowded. Ah, to be a 子 again.

meaning_story: You should only go to the cow god if you need defense. Like, your castle is being ripped apart by barbarians, defense, not, your basketball team has poor defense and now you need more, defense.
meaning_hint: I mean, you could go ask the cow god to help you with the bad defensive skills of your basketball team, but he'll probably kill you all with his laser eyes because that isn't a real emergency.
reading_story: When the cow god comes to help you with your defense (for a good reason), you notice a symbol on its back. It's a large ace (えい), like a playing card. It's the ace of spades. I wonder why.
reading_hint: Maybe the cow god is going to ace your enemies in your defense! That would be pretty cool!

meaning_story: A tree combines with a table to make a desk. When you think about it, a desk is just a table with more stuff. To make this more stuff, like drawers and such, you need more wood, and wood comes from trees. Add materials from the tree to the table and you have a desk.
meaning_hint: Chop this tree into pieces to transform this table into a desk. Hear the sounds of construction in your head as you make this desk with your bare hands.
reading_story: When you finish the desk you turn to your friend and say, “It’s cool, eh (つくえ)?” Your friend looks at you and says, “S’coo’ eh? What?” “This desk, it’s cool. It’s cool, eh?” “Aw, yeah man. S’coo’ eh.”
reading_hint: Okay, so this is a pretty tricky one to make a reading mnemonic out of, if you can think of a better one, please email us. Until then, just imagine someone slurring “It’s cool, eh?” While you think about how cool this desk really is. Run your hands over the finished project as you say it.

kunyomi: よご, きたな, けが
meaning_story: A tsunami hits the ground, expelling all the water at a poor beggar, making him very dirty. Even more dirty than he was before. When the tsunami hits the ground, it forces water up from under the ground which is very dirty. This dirty water hits the beggar, and now he is dirty too.
meaning_hint: Look at this dirty beggar. He looks absolutely dumbfounded. He was not expecting to get this dirty today. Man, he’s dirty. He's been dirty before but never this dirty. Imagine him touching you and rubbing his dirty limbs all over your body.
reading_story: Once the beggar realizes how dirty he is, he becomes sad. “Oh (お), no.” he says. “Oh no! My clothes!! They’re so… DIRTY!”
reading_hint: Hear the beggar shouting “Oh no!” over and over again as he examines how dirty his outfit is.

meaning_story: You eat part of a director to domesticate him. This director has been going around kicking cameramen and punching actors and it’s really ruining his reputation. You need to domesticate him. The only way to do this is to shock him into submission. His ego is so big from two blockbusters that you have to eat part of him to get him to calm down.
meaning_hint: Which part of the director did you choose to eat in order to domesticate him? Think about eating that part of the director and imagine its taste in your mouth as you chew. Eww.
reading_story: While you did succeed in your attempt to domesticate the director, he is now bleeding profusely from the bite wound. All over the script! You gotta get your car (か) and drive him to the hospital like right away. Get to the car! Hurry!
reading_hint: You’re proud that you managed to domesticate the director, but now you feel kind of bad for having injured him. Okay, you really just feel bad because he’s probably going to sue you and he definitely has a lot of money. Oh, and he’s bleeding all over your car.

meaning_story: You throw a pelican into a black hole and a duplicate comes out. The duplicate is just like the pelican you threw into the black hole. How strange.
meaning_hint: Examine the duplicate. Is it really exactly the same? Touch the pelican and feel his feathers to make sure it’s all real.
reading_story: Suddenly, the duplicate pelican starts yelling, “Why did you throw me into that black hole?? F@#$ you (ふく) man, f@#$ you.”
reading_hint: You feel pretty bad after this duplicate says this. Just hear his words echoing over and over again in your mind. “F@#$ you... you... you...”

meaning_story: A tsunami runs into nine trees and produces a dye the color of the forest. The tsunami water mixes with each tree, nine of them actually, and the resulting liquid is a forest green dye.
meaning_hint: Imagine this happening in front of you. See the tsunami turn from the color of water to the color of a forest. The dye washes over you and now you’re forest green as well.
reading_story: The dye continues to pass through the forest and hits a group of centaurs (せん). Now each centaur is dyed with the forest green dye. They don’t look happy.
reading_hint: Hear each centaur shouting about how he hates that dye for changing his color. They look kind of funny, so you laugh at them a bit, but not too loud – they might hear you and get even more angry.

meaning_story: Two pools, both altered and not quite like a pool you’ve seen before are put together and flipped around – this is an egg. One pool is the egg white, the other pool is the egg yolk. They’re different, but similar.
meaning_hint: Separate the two pools from one another. Now the pools look like the kanji. The kanji is one white pool and one yellow pool. Neat, huh?
reading_story: You remember Tamagotchi (たまご), right? Well, Tamagotchi is an egg, and the toy looks like an egg, so it’s pretty easy to remember that tamago means egg.
reading_hint: Just think Tamagotchi whenever you see this kanji. Tamagotchi = tamago = egg. Easy!

meaning_story: Water will drop for eternity. A drop of water will always fall down. There is a water drop, and it is dropping down for eternity.
meaning_hint: Imagine this water dropping for eternity. Drop. Drop. Drop. It’s kind of driving you insane. Imagine this water drop sound continuing on for eternity and how much it’s starting to annoy you.
reading_story: Actually, you’re an ace (えい) fighter pilot that’s been captured and now you’re being subjected to water drop torture. They will let the water drop for eternity or until you give up the information you have. Being an ace fighter pilot isn’t always fame and glory.
reading_hint: As the water crop continues to sound for eternity, imagine the good old days of being an ace fighter pilot, flying about in the sky. It’s hard to concentrate for long though with that incessant drip dripping though. Ugh.

meaning_story: Taking a piece of thread you blame the exploits of your past on poor judgment. You tie this thread around your finger to remind you of all the exploits you accomplished in your day. Most of them weren’t actually on purpose, so you blame them on poor judgment and accident.
meaning_hint: Think up what exploits you accomplished. What sort of things might you have done, but not quite on purpose? Think about how it feels to be exalted for such exploits that were but mere accidents.
reading_story: One of your exploits was when you got dressed in the dark and were wearing funny clothes and everyone thought that it was sexy (せき). The newspapers and fashion agencies couldn’t get enough of your sexy style.
reading_hint: Imagine setting this sexy fashion trend on accident. Imagine what you were wearing when you got dressed in the dark. Probably a pretty strange, mismatched outfit.

meaning_story: An eye is a good thing to have for an eyeball. It wouldn’t make sense to use anything else as an eyeball. Even a good marble won’t do the trick. A good eye is the best eye for an eyeball.
meaning_hint: Feel your eyeball in your head. Go ahead, poke one of your eyeballs through your eyelid. Does it feel good? How does it feel?
reading_story: You know who else had a good eyeball? Gandhi (がん). Gandhi had at least one good eyeball. I mean, each eye of his was probably good, but at least one eyeball was. Gandhi was a great guy so it only makes sense for his eyeball to be good too.
reading_hint: Look at Gandhi’s eyeball with your eyeball. It looks good, doesn’t it? Pull up a picture of Gandhi on Google or something and stare deep into his good eyeball once you determine which one is the good one.

meaning_story: A tsunami, even at night, is composed of a lot of fluid. When you think of a tsunami, you think of water, and water is a fluid. Even at night when you can’t see the tsunami that well, it’s still made up of lots and lots of fluid.
meaning_hint: Imagine hearing this tsunami coming at you during the night. You can hear the fluid rushing and crashing towards you. Feel the fluid soak your body once the tsunami finally passes over you.
reading_story: Since you are now drenched with fluid, you want to go inside and dry off. Unfortunately the door is locked and you don’t have a key (えき). Wait, you don’t have a key? What did you do with it? Why don’t you have a key?
reading_hint: Well it looks like the fluid from the tsunami washed away that key you had. You had a key in your pocket, but the fluid from the tsunami must have washed it away. Bummer dude.

meaning_story: With both a nailbat and a cleat, you scrape a tree until you gather enough wood shavings. By scraping the tree with your nailbat and the cleat, you are shaving wood from the tree. After you gather it, you will use it as kindle for your fire.
meaning_hint: Hear the sound of your nailbat and cleat scraping against the tree as you gather up the crunchy wood shavings. Scrape, scrape, scrape.
reading_story: Now to gather all of the shavings. *CRACK* *BOOM* Oh no. It’s raining. Looks like you won’t be able to start that fire. Sigh (さい). So lousy. Sigh, sigh, sigh.
reading_hint: Let out a nice big sigh as you feel the rain fall down onto you. You just spent all this time gathering the wood shavings with your nailbat and cleat and now it doesn’t even matter anymore. Sigh!

meaning_story: A Viking and his older brother join a group. They can raid and pillage better in a group, so it makes sense that the Viking and his older brother would join a group with other Vikings.
meaning_hint: Look at this big group that contains the Viking and his older brother. Hear them shouting as a group and imagine their Viking battle cry.
reading_story: This group has decided to raid Tokyo (とう). It’s a large undertaking, but they have a large group of Vikings on the job. Tokyo doesn’t stand a chance.
reading_hint: Imagine this group of Vikings rampaging through Tokyo. See all the Japanese people running away and screaming as the group of Vikings comes busting in swinging their axes and shouting loudly.

meaning_story: A samurai with a kind heart has every intention of protecting you. This samurai has the intention to protect everyone in his village from harm. What a good heart this samurai has.
meaning_hint: Imagine this samurai going around town saying “I intend to protect you. I intend to protect you. I intend to…” He’s just letting everyone know his good intentions.
reading_story: This samurai is actually Charlie Sheen (し). Most people think that his intention is to get drugs and women, but ever since he became a samurai, Charlie Sheen has really shaped up and shown that he has a kind heart.
reading_hint: Look at Charlie Sheen in his samurai outfit. He has every intention of turning his image around and being a samurai with a good heart is really helping him out.

meaning_story: There’s a comb and another comb that are exactly the same and you found them on the ground next to some fins you showed interest in. At first, the shiny fins on the ground caught your interest, but once you got closer to the fins you also noticed a pair of combs that looked exactly the same.
meaning_hint: Pick up these fins and the two combs. Feel their weight in each hand as you examine them with interest. Smell the fish smell and feel the teeth on the comb.
reading_story: Since the combs interest you more than the fins, you examine the combs more closely. Taking interest in where they were made, you discover they were made in Kyoto (きょう). Dang, Kyoto sure does make some nice combs.
reading_hint: Now you’re interested in getting more combs. You gotta go to Kyoto though. Imagine getting on a plane to Kyoto while holding this pair of combs and thinking about all the other combs you’ll be able to get once you arrive in Kyoto. How exciting.

meaning_story: If you have a big mouth but a good heart, people will recognize your kindness. Even if you blabber on with your big mouth, as long as everyone knows that your heart is filled with kindness, they will love and accept you.
meaning_hint: Share your kindness with the world. Use your big mouth to let people know what you’re doing. “I’M TAKING OUT THE TRASH AND NOBODY EVEN ASKED ME!” Y’know, that sort of thing. Go ahead and say that out loud a few times.
reading_story: To further show your kindness, you chop up some onions (おん) for a friend who always cries when they chop onions. The onions make you cry too, so it’s a nice act of kindness that you’re toughing it out for your pal.
reading_hint: Imagine chopping up these onions. Smell the onion smell in the air as your eyes begin to sting from the onions. Your friend had better appreciate this kindness.

meaning_story: You put on a mullet beforehand to preface the statement you’re about to make about rednecks. Putting on the mullet beforehand lets people know a bit about what’s coming. It’s a nice preface to ease them into the redneck subject.
meaning_hint: Imagine putting on this mullet wig as a preface to your hillbilly statement. Feel the hair dangling down on your neck as you do.
reading_story: Even though you put the mullet on to preface the comment, hoping that it would be taken as humorous, someone in the audience gets offended. They run up to you and smack you with a jo (じょ). They dare you to say it again as they hit you over and over with the jo.
reading_hint: What could you have said that was so offensive to this guy? You even prefaced the statement with a funny mullet wig. Think of what you might have said to make this guy so angry.

meaning_story: You count nine of them in the tree, each turkey holding something random or miscellaneous. There are nine turkeys in the tree and they’re all holding random, miscellaneous things. How odd.
meaning_hint: Look at the turkeys in the tree. There are nine of them and they are all gobbling up a storm. Hear them gobble as you imagine what random, miscellaneous things they are holding.
reading_story: As if things couldn’t get any more random, Zazu (ざつ) from the Lion King flies into the tree and starts asking the nine turkeys miscellaneous trivia. Zazu always did have a thirst for knowledge, but this is kind of strange.
reading_hint: Look at Zazu asking the turkeys random questions about miscellaneous trivia. You’ve seen the Lion King, right? Zazu should be pretty easy to visualize here.

meaning_story: Under a tree sitting on the grass is a woman who loves sakura, or cherry tree, if you’re an English speaker. This woman really likes to just chill out in the grass under these cherry trees and watch the sakura blossoms. It’s very pretty.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself siting under the tree in the grass with the woman. Smell the cherries and see the sakura blossoms falling down all around you. How whimsical.
reading_story: How do you say cherry tree in Japanese? Sakura (さくら). Sakura is Japanese for cherry tree. I’m sure you’ve probably heard this before, so it shouldn’t be too hard to remember.
reading_hint: Sakura means cherry tree and sakura is the way to pronounce this kanji. Easy!

meaning_story: As I put on my mining helmet, I was certain that mountain was filled with secrecy. Therefore, I decided to dig into the mountain and make a mine. The helmet is for protection. I shall discover what secrecy lies beneath. I’m certain there’s something there, I just don’t know what.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in a helmet digging into this mountain. What sort of secrecy do you think it holds? You’re certain there is something there, it’s just a matter of what.
reading_story: At last, you can finally get your mitts (みつ) on the secrecy that has eluded you for so long. You reach into the depths of the mountain and your mitts find lots and lots of treasure. Aw yiss.
reading_hint: This secrecy isn’t so secret anymore! Look at all this junk you got your mitts on. Hold the treasure in your mitts, feeling its weight as you make an inventory of all the cool things you found.

meaning_story: A pine tree is certain to keep a secret if you promise to shower it with water. The pine tree needs water to live on, so you give it some water in exchange for it keeping your secret.
meaning_hint: What is the secret? I can’t tell you! It’s a secret. I bet you wonder what it is though. Try and coax the pine into telling you what the secret is. Go ahead – try.
reading_story: To try and get the secret out of the pine, you heat (ひ) it up with a lighter. The pine does not appreciate heat and is afraid of getting burned down so the pine spills the secret.
reading_hint: Ooh, finally the secret comes out. Wait, oops – it looks like the heat from the lighter was too great and the pine burst into flames. He’s dead now. Guess you’ll never learn that secret after all. Imagine the pine drowning in flames as he screams. Look what you did.

meaning_story: If you see an elf standing on a grassy cliff in winter, you know their elf parents are super strict. When elf kids misbehave they're supposed to go stand on grassy cliffs to think about what they've done. But only really really strict parents make their kids do that in the middle of winter.
meaning_hint: Picture the elf shivering on the grassy cliff, the winter air freezing their pointy ears. You're glad your parents aren't that strict!
reading_story: Elf parents are really strict but maybe the next generation (げん) won't be so strict! Well, I mean, they live for a really long time, so the next generation won't happen for a while, but let's all hope that they will learn from their parents and be less strict to their own little ones!
reading_hint: Usually the next generation will be less strict. Don't you think?

meaning_story: Taking a nailbat, you hit a hat, a grave, and someone’s mouth before you throw away the bat. You hit someone’s hat when you bash their head in with the nailbat, and you hit the grave with the nailbat to pack the dirt over their corpse. You hit the mouth of someone who got suspicious and asked too many questions, and then you throw away the nailbat to get rid of the evidence.
meaning_hint: Imagine hitting all these things with your nailbat. Hit the hat, hit the grave, and hit the mouth. Feel the bat in your hands as you connect with all these things then finally throw the nailbat away.
reading_story: You also need to throw away your clothes to disguise yourself. Throw away your clothes. Now buy a suit (す). Put on the suit. Suits are cool.
reading_hint: You look darn good in that suit. Check yourself out in the mirror. Oh yeah, looking good. You’ll never throw away this outfit.

meaning_story: They say a shrimp who is bad with translation has no reason to live. Most shrimp make a living with their translation skills. They are the translators of the ocean. If they don’t know how to say something in all the languages of the sea, they have no reason to live. They might as well be dead.
meaning_hint: Imagine this one shrimp who is bad at translation. He’s trying to find a reason to live, but he’s having trouble. Look at him all alone, being shunned by the other shrimp.
reading_story: The translation this shrimp failed to make was for the word “yak” (やく). The shrimp found no reason to translate yak because there are no yak in the sea and then the shrimp just started questioning everything in his life and fell apart.
reading_hint: The translation of the word yak was the reason this shrimp fell in to despair and gave up the translation profession. Now everyone hates him. See this poor shrimp being harassed by others while they shout at him, “Yak! Yak! Yak!”

meaning_story: In the valley you feel a lack of want. You want for nothing in this valley. It is the valley of plenty.
meaning_hint: Think of how much you want to be in this valley. They have everything in there. You lack nothing. You want for nothing. Man, you wanna be in that valley so badly.
reading_story: Once you get to the valley, you want some protein. Egg yolk (よく) falls from the sky! It’s a miracle! You wanted protein, and egg yolk was presented. It falls right into your open mouth.
reading_hint: This was the yolk you wanted. Feel is slosh into your mouth from the sky. Taste the yolk on your tongue before swallowing it. Mmm, egg yolk.

meaning_story: When left in the sun, a football will become warm. If you leave your football out in the sun for a long time, it’s definitely going to get warm.
meaning_hint: Go out into the sun and touch this warm football. Ooh, it’s warm. Feel the warmth on your hand. Also keep in mind that this one has to do with warm places, 温かい can be used for warm things.
reading_story: Oh, wow – that football is really warm! We need to get Dan (だん) the fireman to cool this warm football off with the fire hose. Dan is the man for the job.
