reading_hint: Watch Dan cool down this warm football with the fire hose. Dan is an expert at this, so Dan gets the football un-warm in no time flat.

meaning_story: After you travel down a water slide, a cat pirate is there to welcome you. You’re having one of those dreams again, but you do feel welcome here. The cat pirate is standing at the base of the water slide, ready to welcome all new visitors to cat pirate land. You are one of those visitors. Welcome.
meaning_hint: Feel the water under your butt as you slide down the water slide only to be welcomed by the cutest little cat pirate. Look at him with his little cutlass and peg leg. How adorable!
reading_story: The cat pirate then launches into a speech about how they welcome all kinds of people. Even gay (げい) ones. He puts a certain emphasis on gay, so you figure that the cat pirate thinks you are gay.
reading_hint: Are you gay? Did the cat pirate guess correctly? How does this make you feel?

meaning_story: A leader takes a gun and uses gravity to cause a wound. The leader takes the gun and drops it onto your head. Gravity pulls the gun down, and it causes a wound on your ear where it hit you.
meaning_hint: Feel the gun being dropped on your head. Bonk. It really hurts. Rub the wound and feel the painful bump start to swell.
reading_story: The wound really hurts and you’re really angry, but you can’t do anything because the leader is the shogun (しょう) and you’re just a lowly peon. You can’t get angry or talk back to the shogun, so you just have to suffer your wound in silence.
reading_hint: That rotten shogun, thinking he can just wound people without consequence. Feel your blood boil with anger at the shogun as the wound on your head continues to throb.

meaning_story: On a cliff, a fire burns to ashes. The ashes then blow off the cliff, and follow the wind wherever it may go.
meaning_hint: See the light from the fire as the ashes fly off the cliff. The wind carries some of the ashes over to you. Feel the ashes as they strike your face and wipe the black ash with your hands.
reading_story: The ashes inspire you to write a haiku (はい). Using the ashes you write a haiku on a rock for everyone to enjoy.
reading_hint: Ashes on my face. Falling from the cliff of fire. Gives my life meaning. Or just come up with your own haiku. Whatever works for you.

meaning_story: A nailbat wearing samurai clothes is in strange attire. These clothes are for humans, not nailbats. This attire is strange for a nailbat.
meaning_hint: Check out this nailbat’s attire. I wonder why he’s dressed like a samurai. Watch him as he walks around in his human clothes.
reading_story: The nailbat tears his attire on one of the nails so he needs to sew (そう) it back up. The nailbat is very sad but he gets right to work on sewing up his attire.
reading_hint: Look at the nailbat on the ground as he begins to sew his attire back together. Hear him humming a little diddy as he does so. Hum hum hum, sew sew sew.

meaning_story: You give flowers to someone who just happens to be an author. The author loves flowers, so he is very happy that someone gave him some.
meaning_hint: You are the someone giving the flowers to the author. Smell the flowers in the air as you hand them off. See the author’s face light up upon receiving them.
reading_story: Unfortunately, the author is allergic to flowers. He’s only allergic to touching them though, so the author receives and manipulates the flowers with a pair of chopsticks (ちょ). Using the chopsticks, he can still enjoy the flowers without touching them.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to move and manipulate flowers with a pair of chopsticks. Are you skilled enough to do so? Imagine getting a cramp in your hand from using the chopsticks.

meaning_story: You put a lid over a sunflower before you kick it in the backside. The lid is to cover the sunflower’s eyes so it can’t see who kicked it in the backside.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself doing this. Hear the sunflower scream in surprise as you blind it and then kick it in the backside. Thump!
reading_story: The reason you’re kicking this sunflower in the backside is so that you can steal his uranium (うら). The sunflower has a uranium stockpile, so you blind it with the lid, kick it in the backside, and then steal its uranium.
reading_hint: At last! The uranium is yours. This of all the devious things you can achieve with the uranium as you hold it in your hands.

meaning_story: The gate to the genius is now closed. The genius’ visiting hours are over, so the gate is closed. This genius has been genetically modified to know more than any human could know, and his days are spent answering questions and advising. But now, his work day is over, so his gates are closed.
meaning_hint: See the genius sitting behind the gate as it creaks closed in front of you. Hear the gate slam closed as you keep in mind that this genius has been modified to have increased intelligence because the genius radical in this kanji is modified as well.
reading_story: On the other side of the closed gates there is still a line of people that want the genius's advice. They decide to keep waiting until morning and gather together some hay (へい) so that sleeping outside won't be so awful.
reading_hint: Picture a bunch of people in front of closed gates, sleeping in piles of hay. Super itchy hay.

meaning_story: This car is all weird because it looks like the side is going to dangle and drip off or something. The front bumper of the car is dangling off and the sides of the car look like they could drip off at any moment.
meaning_hint: Compare this kanji to the car kanji, 車. See how the sides and top are different? Use that to remember that this car looks like it’s falling apart. See the parts dangle, and hear the drip of car fluids falling out. This car is a wreck.
reading_story: You see the parts as they dangle off the car and you get an idea. You could probably swing (すい) on these dangling parts. The parts can probably take some weight still before they drip off the car, so you might as well swing around on them while you still can.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself swinging off these dangling car parts. Hear the car creak and groan as you swing around on it, causing more fluid to drip out of the car.

meaning_story: A tsunami hits the greenhouse, destroying the last remaining plant life in the area. The tsunami recedes, and there is nothing but sand, and the lands become a desert.
meaning_hint: The greenhouse was your only hope in turning the desert into a green forest. Now it's all washed away by salt water, meaning nothing will grow anyways. Feel disappointed about this.
reading_story: See the sun come up over the desert, then go back (ばく) down. Up, back down, back up, back down. You stand here for days watching because you're so depressed. Stop being so vague in your approach, sun! You’re weirding everyone out!
reading_hint: Up, back down, back up, back down. Move your head up and down to keep up with the sun’s movements. Will it ever rise like normal?

meaning_story: A rice paddy and the game of blackjack can both incorporate fins but they differ in many ways. For one, blackjack is a card game and a rice paddy is where you grow rice. They differ. There really aren’t any similarities here at all. Except that you can use fins to fertilize a rice paddy and can use fins as betting chips in blackjack, but other than that - nothing.
meaning_hint: Think of more ways that a rice paddy and blackjack differ. There are plenty of reasons, so pick your favorites.
reading_story: Okay, so we both know how the two things differ. That was the easy part. Now let’s think of a way they are similar. Well, they can both be ruined by an eagle (い). An eagle can easily ruin a game of blackjack by shredding and stealing the cards and scattering chips all over. The eagle can also ruin a rice paddy by stomping and eating all the rice.
reading_hint: Just imagine the eagle ruining both of these things. Hear the eagle screeching and flapping its wings as it does so.

meaning_story: The White King has become emperor. The White King is now the White Emperor. He likes the ring of emperor. He thinks it sounds more powerful than king.
meaning_hint: He’s called the White King/Emperor because all of his clothing and accessories are white. His white outfit makes him very bright. You need to squint to look at him.
reading_story: This White Emperor is actually こういち. こういち always wanted to be a king or an emperor, and now he’s been both. Good for you, こういち.
reading_hint: Look at こういち all dressed in white. He looks quite dashing in his white crown. He winks at you. Looking good こういち, looking good.

meaning_story: You have a nailbat and a mullet and you’re hitting a pile to extend it from one side of the yard to the other. You’re a rebel and you found a pile of leaves in someone’s yard. You take your nailbat and you extend the pile all over their yard. Looks like someone has some extra work to do.
meaning_hint: Feel your mullet brushing your next as you extend the pile with your nailbat. What a mischief maker you are.
reading_story: Before you can finish your mission to extend the pile all across the lawn, an angry cock (かく) comes running at you. Looks like you didn’t notice the “Beware of Cock” sign in the yard. This rooster is angry and it’s running right at you. Hurry and run away before the cock pecks and scratches you to death!
reading_hint: As you run you extend your nailbat behind you in hopes that is deters the cock from attacking. Imagine yourself running in this way as fast as you can as you hear the rooster clucking at you as it chases.

meaning_story: A greenhouse is already really good when it comes to a plant's livelihood. But add the sun into that equation and you have something really great for the plants. Their livelihood will be awesome, now!
meaning_hint: Just feel happy that your plants have such a nice livelihood now that the sun is out. They look so healthy and fresh!
reading_story: From out of nowhere, Bobo (ぼ) the notorious clown thief starts picking the plants, ending their livelihood. Bobo needs the flowers for his clown acts, so he uses the livelihood of the flowers to support his own livelihood.
reading_hint: Look at Bobo do what he needs to do to maintain his own livelihood. Hear the flowers screaming as they are plucked from their homes.

meaning_story: Those that are in the middle of your heart are the ones you have the most loyalty towards. The middle of your heart is the most sacred, special place for people, so it makes sense that those you keep in the middle of your heart are those you are most loyal to.
meaning_hint: Who do you feel the most loyalty towards? Imagine them in the middle of your heart. Feel them in your chest. Imagine them, literally inside the middle of your heart.
reading_story: You pictured Chewbacca (ちゅう), didn’t you? No? Well you should have. Chewbacca deserves everyone’s loyalty. Chewbacca is super loyal to you, so you deserve to give him your loyalty as well.
reading_hint: Chewbacca is very loyal. Focus on your loyalty to Chewbacca. Picture him right in the middle of your heart and hear his Chewbacca yell. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 中 which is also included in this kanji.

meaning_story: There is a moon and a city inside your lung. Inside of your lung there is a city and above that city lies a moon. It’s a pretty sight, but also very strange. Moons and cities don’t usually reside inside lungs.
meaning_hint: Imagine having a moon and a city inside your lung. Feel their presence as you breathe in and breathe out. Also, 月 often refers to internal organs as well, so remember that when you see this kanji.
reading_story: Having a moon and city inside your lung inspires you to write a haiku (はい). Perhaps the city and moon are just metaphorical. Either way, a haiku is the best way to go about things here.
reading_hint: The city and moon. Inside my lung, forgotten. Where is the answer? Or just think of your own haiku. Be creative!

meaning_story: They say that the samurai from this town once cut a heart out of a magazine and gave it to the princess. They say the samurai was just trying to express his feelings so he cut a heart shape out of a magazine with pretty pictures on it. He then gave that magazine heart to the princess in an attempt to win her over.
meaning_hint: Look at this samurai. He’s pretty shy. Look at him bashfully cutting out the heart from the magazine. Snip, snip, snip.
reading_story: Unfortunately, the samurai did not notice what was on the backside of the heart that he cut out of the magazine. It was a very unflattering picture of Charlie Sheen (し). When the princess got the heart, she was very confused. Is this samurai trying to say he is in love with Charlie Sheen?
reading_hint: The samurai can’t believe he forgot to check the other side of the magazine. He doesn’t love Charlie Sheen! Aw, man – how embarrassing! Imagine how embarrassed you would be if this happened to you.

meaning_story: A nailbat, along with some other products, work together with a tree to manipulate your chastity. You’ve always believed in chastity, but this nailbat, tree, and assorted products are trying to manipulate your values.
meaning_hint: Imagine what this tree and nailbat could be doing in an attempt to manipulate your chastity. Be very imaginative and vivid here, it’ll help.
reading_story: The nailbat and tree manipulate and manipulate and finally they have compromised your chastity. Now you need to sew (そう) your chastity back together. Figuratively, of course.
reading_hint: Your chastity needs to be mended so you take a mental thread and sew your chastity back together. Feel the thread running through your body as you sew yourself back up.

meaning_story: Bamboo from the moon is very powerful and can easily destroy a muscle or a tendon with one hit. This moon bamboo grows on the moon and is specifically cultivated for its muscle and tendon destroying abilities. The moon bamboo is made into weapons specifically designed for this purpose.
meaning_hint: Pick up one of these moon bamboo weapons. Be careful not to hit yourself with it. If you hit something with it, the muscles and tendons hit would instantly be rendered useless.
reading_story: If someone attacks you with one of these moon bamboo weapons, every muscle and tendon in your body will be obliterated. Someone will have to notify your next of kin (きん) to come pick up your pathetic remains. Your kin will have to see you in your weak state, close to death. How sad.
reading_hint: Picture yourself as a pile of flesh and bones with no remaining muscles or tendons. See your kin standing around you as they gasp and recoil in horror. You’re not going to live much longer, but this is a horrible image to leave with.

meaning_story: The Not Mouth says “no”. What else would you expect from something named the “Not Mouth”? The Not Mouth will always say “no”, regardless of the question.
meaning_hint: Imagine encountering this Not Mouth. Ask it a question. It answers, “No”. Imagine doing this over and over until you believe that the Not Mouth always says “no”.
reading_story: You ask the Not Mouth if it is afraid of heat (ひ). The Not Mouth says, “no”. So you set the Not Mouth on fire. The Not Mouth then screams, “NONONONONONONONONONOOOOOO~!” Looks like someone can’t handle the heat.
reading_hint: Listen as the Not Mouth continues to scream in bloodcurdling agony. Hear the flames flicker as they lick across the Not Mouth’s being. Seems as though the heat was too much for the Not Mouth.

meaning_story: You become a plate pile, heaps and heaps of plates. You’ve been turned into a pile of plates by an evil wizard. Heaps of plates make up your form now. You have become a pile of plates.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself becoming a pile of plates. Feel your arms and legs become nothing more than heaps of dinnerware. Hear the plates clinking about as you struggle.
reading_story: The evil wizard responsible for turning you into nothing more than heaps of plates is Hard Gay! “Sei (せい), sei, sei!” he shouts. Every time he says “sei” another part of your body becomes a pile of plates. When your head is the only part not transformed, Joseph (じょう) Stalin busts into the room and knocks out Hard Gay. Wow, thanks Joseph Stalin!
reading_hint: Imagine Joseph Stalin beating up Hard Gay and then coming over to you. Every time Joseph Stalin says “comrade” to you, another pile of plates turns back into its normal body part. Just imagine this all taking place.

meaning_story: Over a helmet on the ground, a sunrise arrives to proclaim a new day’s beginning! You took off your helmet and put it on the ground when you went to sleep, and now that the sunrise is showing, you know that the morning has arrived. The sun will proclaim the arrival of the new day with its bright and shiny rays!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself being awakened by the sunrise. Pick up your helmet and proclaim to the skies that a new day has arrived. Proclaim it aloud! Be very animated as you do so.
reading_story: Out of the nearby forest appears a centaur (せん). The centaur wants to join in and proclaim the arrival of a new day along with you. You’re a bit surprised, but hey – who doesn’t like to proclaim the arrival of a new day?
reading_hint: Continue proclaiming your joy for the sunrise and the start of a new day. Only this time you have a centaur with you. Run your fingers along his furry back. He’s quite soft.

meaning_story: The leader who is king of every clam sets the rent for everyone. If you rent a home in King Clam’s kingdom, the rent will be set by the great clam leader himself.
meaning_hint: King Clam loves when people rent from him. Imagine him rolling in all of the rent money he collected from all the clams who rent from him. Hear his shell clattering about as he frolics in his money pile.
reading_story: With all the rent money the clam king makes from all the other clams who rent from him, he has quite a big pile of rent money. One day the Clam King falls off his rent money pile and lands right on his chin (ちん). BAM! The clam king just broke his chin. How embarrassing.
reading_hint: Imagine the Clam King with his broken chin. See him crying and sniffling at the pain he has suffered. That’s what you get for being so greedy!

meaning_story: Writing a poem in winter is the only way to gain the respect of other poets. Rumor has it that you’re not considered a true writer of poems until you write a poem in the dead cold of winter. Only then will you gain the respect of the community.
meaning_hint: You have to do this to gain respect. Imagine yourself out in the cold of winter, trying to write a poem. Feel the cold around you as your hand, shivering, grasps the pen.
reading_story: Soon the cold makes you a bit delirious. With all the white around with it being winter and all, you end up writing a poem about the KKK (けい). A poem about the KKK is definitely not the way to gain the respect of other poets.
reading_hint: Imagine what this poem of yours must be like. What kind of things do you think it says about the KKK? Think about what you could have written.

meaning_story: The horns of the creatures who drink alcohol have a measurement so large that they are revered the world over. The horns are revered both for their size and potency. The horns can be used in medicine, so they are very valuable, those alcoholic monster horns.
meaning_hint: Look at one of these revered horns. Pick it up and feel its weight. It measures very large. Your arms are getting tired from the weight.
reading_story: The reason you are interested in these revered horns so much is that your son (そん) is sick and you need one of these revered horns to make a medicine for your son. Only with the revered power of the horns will you be able to save your son’s life.
reading_hint: Good thing you already have one of these revered horns. Now imagine yourself grinding it up into a powder to mix into a potion for your son to drink. Hear the horn grinding away as you physically break the horn up into millions of tiny pieces.

meaning_story: A sock that's become a circle from being stuffed with the remnants of many a fish tail begins to ripen, giving off an awful odor. Every time you find a fish tail you put it in this sock. You find a lot so this sock has become pretty circular. The fish tails start to rot and ripen, and now the sock smells absolutely foul.
meaning_hint: Smell the smelly smell of each fish tail as it begins to ripen. It’s like breathing in the worst parts of the ocean all at once.
reading_story: Since the fish tail filled sock began to ripen, you decide to play a joke and throw it at someone. You toss it at your worst enemy, and they juke (じゅく), getting out of the way just in time. Ah, the juke! Their expertly timed juke totally ruined your plans.
reading_hint: How did this guy get so good at juking? That was like, the best juke you’ve ever seen. Replay that juke over and over in your head, seeing the guy expertly dodge that circular sock filled with fish tails.

meaning_story: If you grind a stone down to more than just a few pieces, it will become sand. Stones that get broken up enough will become sand, and you pick up a few grains in your hand.
meaning_hint: Feel these few grains of sand between your fingertips. Imagine the stones that they originally came from. Nature is crazy.
reading_story: What’s in your hand? A few grains of sand (さ)! Sand, sand, sand!
reading_hint: Just remember that stones become sand and if you remember that this kanji means sand you’ll remember how to pronounce it as well.

meaning_story: Bamboo spaced at a particular interval is something evoking simplicity. You don’t need anything fancy, just bamboo spaced at a certain interval. Bamboo is very simple, but also very elegant. Simplicity is beautiful.
meaning_hint: Imagine this bamboo and its precise interval spacing. The simplicity is apparent. That’s really all it is, just bamboo spaced at intervals. Look at it and feel the bamboo with your fingers as you focus on the intervals of space between the pieces.
reading_story: Furthering the simplicity is how the bamboo was spaced. The designer just took a soda can (かん) and used the length of the can to measure the interval of space between each piece of bamboo. Simplicity at its finest.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as the one laying the bamboo down. Feel the can in your hand as you space out the bamboo. Feel the aluminum can with your fingers. Squeeze it a little so the can flexes and pops. This really is simple.

meaning_story: You give flowers to a shark and it literally starts to steam with anger. This shark hates flowers so steam starts shooting out of the shark’s head.
meaning_hint: Look at this shark with the steam coming out of his head. Hear the steam shooting out like in cartoons. This shark hates flowers and now he’s steaming mad.
reading_story: The reason steam is shooting out of the shark is because of a bad memory it has with Joseph (じょう) Stalin. Joseph Stalin used to give the shark flowers all the time, but then Joseph Stalin betrayed the shark so flowers remind him of the betrayal. So now whenever the shark sees flowers, he steams with anger.
reading_hint: Imagine what Joseph Stalin could have done to get this shark so steaming angry. Probably something pretty lousy.

meaning_story: The storehouse radical and the storehouse kanji are exactly the same! Stupendous!
reading_story: A storehouse is a storage zone (ぞう). It’s the zone where you store things. That’s why it is called a storehouse.
reading_hint: Get in the zone, the storehouse zone. Imagine yourself inside the storehouse. You feel safe here. The storehouse is a safe zone.

radicals: 口, 广, 米, 聿
meaning_story: There’s rice in your mullet and a brush in your mouth that tastes like sugar. Man, what a crazy night you must have had. You didn’t even have a mullet yesterday and now you have one with a bunch of rice stuck in it. Where did this brush come from and why is it in your mouth? And why does it taste like sugar?
meaning_hint: Taste the sugar in your mouth as you try to piece together your evening. Everything is foggy so you have to concentrate really hard to remember.
reading_story: You remember traveling to Tokyo (とう) by train, and meeting a strange gentleman in downtown Tokyo. He must have drugged you or something. You’re pretty sure you’re still in Tokyo now, you just don’t know where. Even though you took the brush out of your mouth, the taste of sugar still lingers on your tongue.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself bumbling around the streets of Tokyo looking for a landmark or something that will help guide your way back home. Your mouth still tastes of sugar, so imagine that sugary taste in your mouth as you continue to try and find your way home.

meaning_story: The thread inside is running short on supply. The supply of thread is running low. We’re keeping some reserves inside, but the supply won’t last us long.
meaning_hint: Imagine this meager supply of thread inside the building. It has to be guarded because it’s in such short supply. You really want to get the last bit of thread, so devise a plan to steal that thread. Go ahead, do it.
reading_story: You steal the last supply of thread from inside. Now you are the sole supply of thread. When the others check the supply and discover it’s been stolen they all shout out in unison, “NOOOoooOOOOoooOOOoo!!” (のう)
reading_hint: Hear their shouts ringing in your ears as you run your fingers through your newfound thread. Muahaha.

meaning_story: A helmet wearing king finds a drop of water containing a valuable treasure. Inside the drop of water is a precious stone. Truly, a great treasure. This king is very happy.
meaning_hint: Look at this helmet wearing king. He’s so happy to find this drop of water with a gem in it. Look at it sparkling so bright.
reading_story: When he tries to remove the gem, he realizes that he can’t penetrate the drop of water. It’s stuck inside the drop which is stuck to the ground. Just then Hou-dini (ほう) shows up and snatches the treasure away. “Ta~da!” Hou-dini shouts.
reading_hint: Dang it Hou-dini! He always ruins this king’s treasure conquests. This is the fourth time this week! Hou-diiiiniiiii!!

meaning_story: They say someone with various talents is important. Various talents can include speaking various languages so if you are someone who knows various languages you can say things that various peoples will comprehend.
meaning_hint: You are someone who can say things in various languages. Speak some of these various languages now. You are someone who is good at saying things. Nice job.
reading_story: You’re so good at speaking various languages that you decide to put on a show (しょ). At the show, you say a lot of things in various languages and everyone is impressed.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself at this show. The spotlight is on and all eyes are watching. You feel kind of nervous, but you speak the various languages with ease.

meaning_story: There is a hole in the pile of flesh that is my body where my heart used to be as I stare out the window… I feel so lost. I’m looking out the window for answers. First there was a hole in my heart and now there is a hole where my heart used to be. I’m just a pile of suffering.
meaning_hint: How emo is that? Read that out loud in the most emo, depressed voice you can muster. Really imagine yourself staring out a window as you wallow in your own self-pity.
reading_story: As I stare out the window, you don't just get sad, you also get really mad (まど). So, so, mad.
reading_hint: Maybe you're mad that the window was made in China, and it's broken. Or maybe you're mad about the hole in your body. Whatever it is, get mad.

meaning_story: The beans radical and the beans kanji are exactly the same! Fancy!
reading_story: These beans are from Tokyo (とう). Everybody knows Tokyo has the best beans. What?! You didn’t know that? Tokyo’s beans are the best beans!
reading_hint: Imagine eating these beans from Tokyo. They’re the best beans you’ve ever had. Even if you don’t like beans, you love Tokyo beans. Mmm… beans beans beans.

meaning_story: There is a tree frog on the branch. In the tree there is a frog. It is a tree frog. The tree frog is on a branch in the tree.
meaning_hint: See the tree frog on the branch of the tree. Hear the tree frog ribbit as he hops from branch to branch.
reading_story: What’s this? Something else is on the branch. Hey, look! It’s Charlie Sheen (し). Charlie Sheen is licking the tree frog on the branch to get high. Oh Charlie Sheen, you crazy guy.
reading_hint: Watch Charlie Sheen on the branch as he licks the tree frog. See his eyes glaze over as he gets all messed up from licking it.

meaning_story: Balancing a nailbat on your forehead while standing on a car, you brandish your nailbat menacingly. It’s hard to brandish a nailbat that is on your forehead, but somehow you are doing it.
meaning_hint: Concentrate really hard on this nailbat on your forehead. You gotta keep it balanced, but you also have to brandish it in a way that will intimidate others. It’s difficult.
reading_story: You decided to brandish this nailbat because you want the key (き) to this car you are standing on. It’s much nicer that your car, so you’re trying to intimidate the owner into giving you the key.
reading_hint: Yell at the car owner as you continue to brandish the nailbat from your forehead. “The key! Gimme the KEY!”

meaning_story: You slice some ribs and carve the meat from them. You have a big knife and you’re using it to carve the meat from the ribs. Slice slice, carve carve.
meaning_hint: Hear the sound of the knife blade scraping on the rib bones as you carve and slice up the meat. Your mouth starts to water.
reading_story: After you carve the rib meat, you’re really thirsty. You’re parched. Grab yourself a Coke (こく). You like Coke. It’ll go perfect with these ribs you just carved. Hot ribs and ice cold Coke. Nice.
reading_hint: Imagine washing down your ribs with the ice cold Coke you just got. Taste the tasty ribs first, then feel the sweet bubbly goodness of the Coke afterwards.

meaning_story: The claw radical and the claw kanji are exactly the same! Ravishing!
reading_story: You’ve got not one tumor (つま), but too many (つめ) tumors and you need to claw them out with your sharp claw. One tumor is one tumor too many. Cut them out with your claw!
reading_hint: Imagine you have too many tumors. Feel the claw digging into your flesh and removing the tumors. It really hurts, but it is necessary.

meaning_story: The child is in the water because he gave his consent. You asked the child if he wanted to be thrown in the water and he said yes. He gave you verbal consent. When he lands in the water, he lands on top of a pile of sticks and the water breaks around him.
meaning_hint: Imagine the child telling you he consents to being tossed in the water. Now toss the child into the water and feel the water spray on you as he splashes about. Also, he’s screaming because he landed on a pile of sticks.
reading_story: You’re in trouble. Even if this kid gave you his consent, he’s been impaled on sticks and now he might drown. The shogun (しょう) is not going to be happy with you. This child is the shogun’s child. Dang. You’re in trouble.
reading_hint: Hear the shogun’s child screaming and splashing in the water. Feel your heart sink and your stomach turn. What should you do? Should you run away or try and help the child?

meaning_story: Inside the greenhouse is two face. He is concocting something nasty for Batman, and doesn't want you to see. Because greenhouses tend to be kind of see through, he puts up a thick curtain to keep you from peeping.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to look through this curtain to see what he's doing (so you can report to Batman). You can't, and it's very frustrating.
reading_story: You finally do manage to find a crack in the curtain, though, and look in. In front of you is the weapon he's been building... a poisoned Big mac (まく), which everyone knows Batman is really into. He will eat this and die for sure! You have to warn him!
reading_hint: If you'd like, imagine taking a bite of this poisoned big mac after Two Face leaves. Uh oh... yep... it's poisoned.

meaning_story: You use a piece of thread in a construction project making a deep red quilt. The thread is a deep red color, so it’s a perfect addition to the deep red quilt. The entire thing is deep red. Deep red is your favorite color.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself all wrapped up in this deep red quilt after its construction is done. Feel all warm and cozy as you marvel at how deep and red it is.
reading_story: This deep red quilt is actually a present for your best friend こういち. こういち’s favorite color is also deep red, so you’re sure that こういち will just love this gift you got him.
reading_hint: Now imagine こういち all wrapped up in this deep red quilt. Look at his happy face and hear him cooing with pleasure as he wraps himself up all tight and cozy.

meaning_story: A broken arrow fired at a turkey will lack the ability to injure it, much to the delight of the turkey. The arrow is broken, so it’s no longer a threat to the turkey. The turkey is delighted.
meaning_hint: Imagine the look of delight on this turkey’s face as you fail to hit it with this broken arrow of yours. Hear the turkey gobbling in joy as it prances about unharmed.
reading_story: You need to wipe that look of delight off the turkey’s face. It’s embarrassing. So you pick up a can (かん) and toss it at the turkey. Bam! The can connects. You knocked out the turkey with the can.
reading_hint: Imagine hurling this can as hard as you can at the turkey. Hear the loud smack as the can connects, knocking out the turkey. Now you are the one who feels delight.

meaning_story: A butcher, in the winter, takes a cow to descend with him into the killing room. They descend there by taking an elevator. This is where the butcher will slaughter the cow for dinner.
meaning_hint: The reason the butcher does this stuff in a place he needs to descend to is so he doesn’t bother anyone. Imagine hearing the cow being slaughtered here. Hear the cow scream moo in agony as the butcher’s blade carves it up.
reading_story: The killing room’s elevator begins to descend again. It’s こういち! He’s here to help the butcher. The cow shudders in fear as the butcher and こういち approach.
reading_hint: See こういち and the butcher wielding knives as they approach the cow. Their knives are ready to descend into the cow’s tender flesh. See their blades glinting in the fluorescent lights as こういち and the butcher cackle maniacally.

meaning_story: A tiger kills a pig, eating the meat from its ribs at the climax of a drama about the animal kingdom. The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger but the tiger grew up and his ferocious instincts kicked in and he ate the pig, ribs and all. What a drama.
meaning_hint: Imagine watching this and hearing the tiger gobbling up the pig, slurping the meat from the ribs. This drama is so moving that you find yourself shedding a tear. How touching.
reading_story: You remember Beck’s grandfather, Geck (げき), right? Well, Geck did all the music featured in this drama. Geck’s pretty talented. You’re impressed.
reading_hint: Imagine what song Geck composed for the scene in the drama where the tiger eats the pig. Play that song in your head as you imagine the scene once again.

meaning_story: The woman sitting on that stool is actually a dude. Oh oops! You thought he was a woman because of his long hair and the way he was sitting. Maybe you shouldn't be judging people based on their looks!
meaning_hint: Dude, I can't believe you called that dude a woman. What's wrong with you?!
reading_story: You only found out this dude wasn't a woman when a dog ど ran up and the dude stood up. He started rubbing the dogs face saying, "Who's a good boy? Who's a good boy? Not you! Me! I'm the best boy of them all. Because I am a dude, the best of all boys! HAHAHAHA!"
reading_hint: Look at the poor dog. He's not a dude and now he doesn't think he's a good boy, all because of this other dude. Was he sitting on the stool this whole time, waiting to make this dog feel bad? I guess you'll never know...

meaning_story: The ear and the mouth of a king are holy. The king has holy hearing and holy eating abilities. This king is divine.
meaning_hint: See the holy ear and mouth of this king. They glisten and glitter and people write hymnals about their holy prowess. Imagine a song playing as you witness their holy majesty.
reading_story: This king is actually Hard Gay. “Sei (せい), sei, sei!” he shouts with his holy mouth. Since his mouth is so holy, when he shouts, “Sei, sei, sei!” the whole area shakes and shimmers.
reading_hint: Hear the holy reverb ringing in your ears as you witness Hard Gay’s mouth and the surrounding area glimmer with fantastical holy magic. “Sei… sei… sei…!”

meaning_story: Seeing a nailbat in the hands of a turkey, you infer that he wants revenge. This turkey knows you killed his brother for dinner last night, and now he’s going to make you pay. You infer that this turkey is going to take this nailbat and beat you to death.
meaning_hint: Look at this turkey. See the nailbat. Fear the nailbat. Infer what will happen next.
reading_story: It’s easy to infer what this turkey plans to do. He plans to murder you with the nailbat. You run to a nearby canyon, grab a vine and swing (すい) across to safety. The turkey is unable to swing across so you’re safe. For now.
reading_hint: Feel the wind in your hair as you swing to safety. Now look back across the drop you just swung over, seeing the turkey standing there fuming, malice in his eyes.

meaning_story: A storehouse moons (remember, sometimes the moon radical indicates an internal organ!) is your internal organs. They are storehouses for various bodily functions.
meaning_hint: Alternatively, think about storehouses on the moon, filled to the brim with internal organs. You open the door, and they kind of slowly bounce out (because of less gravity) and get all over your pretty white space suit.
reading_story: Your internal organs are encased in a zone (ぞう) bordered by your rib cage. The flowers and the moon are both encased in the zone known as your stomach. This is the zone where all the action happens.
reading_hint: The zone where your internal organs are housed is also a zone you don’t want damaged. Imagine navigating you and your internal organ zone around as you feel the flowers and the moon sloshing around inside of you.

meaning_story: If you take a nailbat and hit a member of your company with it, you will suffer a financial loss when you get sued. Hitting a company member with a nailbat is not something you can just do without some sort of loss or punishment, ya know?
meaning_hint: Imagine hitting your fellow company member with this nailbat. Hear it thunk as it strikes flesh. I hope this is worth the loss you’re going to incur later.
reading_story: Unfortunately for you, the person in charge of determining your financial loss to make up for the nailbat incident is the victim’s son (そん). He wants you to incur a huge loss and even take some of your property as well. That’s too much of a loss. You start hitting the son with the nailbat too.
reading_hint: Okay so now you’re hitting the son with the nailbat. Thunk thunk thunk. He’s screaming and pleading for help, but when his father comes over you smack him with the nailbat again too. Thunk.

meaning_story: Seeing a stone and some horns on the ground next to a piece of poop and another piece of poop, you try and pick each of them up with a magnet. The magnet fails to pick up either piece of poop. The magnet doesn’t pick up the horns either. But wait! The magnet picks up the stone!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself trying to pick each object up off the ground with your magnet. Hear the clink of the stone against metal as the magnet lifts it off the ground. Must be some iron in it or something.
reading_story: You’re pretty excited that you lifted something up with your magnet. Science is cool! But then you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Jesus (じ)! Jesus was using his magic to levitate the stone all along, it wasn’t your magnet. Darn it Jesus! You’ve fooled me for the last time!
reading_hint: Imagine Jesus snickering behind you as the stone falls to the ground once again. Imagine running after Jesus so you can catch him and give him a piece of your mind. He’s always playing tricks on you.

meaning_story: They say accidentally firing a catapult is an unforgivable mistake. They say you shot the catapult at your own castle. Even though it was an accident, it’s still a mistake you will never be forgiven for.
meaning_hint: Imagine shooting the catapult on your own people by mistake. Hear the catapult whoosh as your heart drops into your stomach. Oh, what a terrible mistake you’ve just made.
reading_story: To pay for your mistake, you have to spend many years locked up in prison with other people who have made mistakes. There, you learn to play the Japanese game, Go (ご). Playing Go helps the time pass more speedily, and you soon forget about your mistake.
reading_hint: Have you played Go before? Imagine playing it inside of a prison while you slowly forget about the mistake you made. Hear the black and white pieces click and clack on the board as you play.

meaning_story: A tsunami produces a diamond at its origin. The pressure is so great in the area where a tsunami forms, so a diamond is formed there, at its origin.
meaning_hint: Look at the origin of this tsunami. See everything compressing greatly under the pressure. Pop! Out comes a diamond. So shiny.
reading_story: Every generation sees a tsunami and every generation (げん) wants to get their hands on that origin diamond. The diamonds at the origins of tsunamis are the most precious and pure diamonds ever, so each generation of people tries to snatch them up.
reading_hint: Imagine you are one of the people from this generation. Swim under the tsunami water and try to grab the diamond at its origin before anyone else. You’re all wet and the water pressure is very great, but that diamond is worth it.

meaning_story: There are antenna and some flowers next to the potato. The potato got the flowers for his wife, and the antenna are from the bug he killed to get the flowers. The bug with the antenna was guarding the flowers, but the potato ripped off his antenna and killed him.
meaning_hint: Imagine the potato engaging in combat with this bug. Hear the bug scream in agony as the potato rips off his antenna and claims the flowers.
reading_story: This potato is an emo (いも). After he tore off the antenna, he started to feel really emo so he broke down and cried for a while. His black makeup is running from the tears.
reading_hint: Look at this emo potato as he weeps next to the dead body of the bug he just murdered. Imagine some emo music playing in the background while you watch.

meaning_story: The thread running through this thorn is pure. It’s a thread necklace with a thorn attached to it and both the thread and the thorn are pure, 100% natural.
meaning_hint: Pick up this pure thorn on the thread necklace. The thorn pricks your finger and draws blood. It stings. Yup, that’s a pure thorn alright.
reading_story: These pure thorn necklaces made from thread can only be manufactured in the month of June (じゅん). Any other month means that they aren’t pure. Only in June are all the conditions proper for a pure thorn thread necklace to be made.
reading_hint: Imagine making one of these pure necklaces in June. Feel the June weather around you outside as you string the thread through the pure thorn.

meaning_story: Next to some flowers is a mullet wearing bird trying to recommend which flowers you should buy. This bird is weird looking. It’s wearing a mullet wig. And it’s trying to tell you what flowers to buy. Why would a bird try to recommend flowers?
meaning_hint: Hear this mullet bird squawking about what flowers you should buy. It’s trying to recommend the tulips. Squawwwwk! Tulips! Rawwwk!
reading_story: The owner of the flower shop is a centaur (せん). Upon hearing the mullet bird trying to recommend you a flower to buy, the centaur owner comes over and chases away the bird. Apparently the bird does this often and is a great nuisance to the centaur business owner.
reading_hint: Listen to the centaur’s hooves clicking and clacking as he chases the bird away. He’s very angry and yelling as well. It’s quite the scene.

meaning_story: Into a well, a drop of rice falls from your rice bowl. You were eating out of your rice bowl on the side of a well, and some rice fell out of your rice bowl and this drop of rice proceeded to fall all the way down.
meaning_hint: You lost a drop of rice from your rice bowl. Feel sorrow for the lost rice as you watch it fall down the well and hear it splat into the water below.
reading_story: Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up, steals your rice bowl, and shoves you into the well. You’d gotten on the don’s bad side, so he came to teach you a lesson. The don steals your rice bowl and shoves you into the well.
reading_hint: Hear the don shout, “See ya, sucker!” as he pushes you into the well. You’ve just lost a drop of rice, now your rice bowl, and now you’re all wet in a well. Worst day ever.

meaning_story: You have a mullet and you huffed some glue so you passed out before you could put the meat in the refrigerator and now it’s starting to rot.
meaning_hint: Once you wake up from your glue induced delirium, you smell the rot of the meat. Ew. It’s disgusting. You start dry heaving at the smell of it.
reading_story: What a fool (ふ) you were to huff all that glue and pass out. You even look like a fool with your silly mullet. You need to get the smell of rot out of your house so you throw the meat away. You throw the glue away too. “No more!” you say.
reading_hint: Not wanting to look like a fool anymore, you clean up your place. Imagine yourself throwing out the rotting meat and the glue. Smell their smells intermix as you toss them out. It’s not a nice smell.

meaning_story: There’s a tsunami approaching your fins and your mouth and all you can do is run alongside it. You're a fish which is why you have fins (and a mouth). The tsunami is approaching you, but that's okay because you are a fish and you can swim. So you just run alongside this tsunami like it's no problem.
meaning_hint: Run alongside this tsunami. Feel the water rush past you, your fins, and your mouth.
reading_story: As you continue to run alongside the raging tsunami you spot a helpful ent (えん). This ent wants to save you so he tells you to climb up into his branches and hold on! why he is trying to save a fish from the water, you do not know.
reading_hint: Feel the ent bark on your fins as he snatches you out of the water. You can't breathe up here! *GASP* *WHEEZE*

meaning_story: You need somebody to make a measurement before you can shoot. You know how snipers have spotters? The spotter makes a measurement with his equipment and advises the sniper when to shoot and where to aim. He is a very important somebody.
meaning_hint: Imagine being next to this somebody as he makes his measurements and tells you how to adjust your aim. “SHOOT!” he yells, right in your ear, “SHOOT! SHOOT! SHOOT!”
reading_story: The target you are trying to shoot is an evil shaman. The shaman (しゃ) has brainwashed his entire village and is building an evil empire. This shaman needs to be taken down, so you shoot him.
reading_hint: Visualize the shaman in your sights. After your spotter tells you to shoot, feel your finger slowly squeeze the trigger of your gun. BOOM!

meaning_story: The one hundred magic threads that make up the leader's helmet make him shrink in size. Somebody wanted to embarrass the leader so they knit him helmet out of one hundred magic threads and it causes him to shrink everytime he puts it on. He's not very happy about it.
meaning_hint: See the helmet made of one hundred threads slowly lower onto the leader's head, and then he himself lowers to the ground as he shrinks. Watch him get smaller and smaller until you can't even see him anymore under that helmet.
reading_story: As the leader began to shrink, he shook (しゅく). He shook and he shook and then he shook some more. He shook so violently as he shrank that the room actually rumbled.
reading_hint: As the leader shook, so did you. The vibrations ran through the room. Feel your body shake as you continue to watch the leader shrink.

radicals: 水, 士, 聿, 示
meaning_story: A samurai with a jackhammer drips his brush in some water before he paints his slave. There was some paint on the brush, but the jackhammer wielding samurai needed to thin it down with some water before he painted his identifying markings on his slave.
meaning_hint: Look at this samurai with the jackhammer hefted over one shoulder as he uses the water to wet his brush. He then begins to paint a design on his slave. Look at the slave, he looks sad.
reading_story: The slave slowly reaches behind him and grabs a death ray (れい). He shoots the jackhammer samurai right in the face! BAM! The death ray has killed him. Then the slave takes the jackhammer and runs away! Escape!
reading_hint: This slave is now free. He has a death ray and a jackhammer, so he feels pretty safe. Look at the smile on his face as he shoots the death ray into the air and revs up the jackhammer in celebration.

meaning_story: There’s some rice in the shape of a nine on a cross and this Is stylish. The rice grains are arranged to form the number nine. This number nine is prominently displayed on the cross, and it’s stylish to carry it around and be seen with it.
meaning_hint: Imagine hefting this cross with the rice in the shape of a nine on it. You don’t feel stylish, but society tells you that you are. You’re stylish.
reading_story: It’s also stylish to swing (すい) the cross around while you wait for things. You’re waiting at a bus stop so you swing the cross around violently. You swing it so violently that the rice comes flying off!
reading_hint: See the rice fly through the air from you swinging the cross. Hear it as it clatters to the ground. This cross just isn’t as stylish anymore now.

meaning_story: Out of your mouth and onto a grave comes some throw up and then some spit. The sight of a grave makes you have to throw up, so as soon as you see this grave, throw up comes out of your mouth. After you throw up, you spit to get the taste out of your mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself throwing up. Vomit all over this grave. Now spit until you can’t taste the throw up in your mouth anymore.
reading_story: Apparently you find throw up to be funny because you start laughing manically. “HAHAHAHAHA (は)!” You spit on the ground and continue to laugh. “HAHA! HAHAHAHAHA!!!”
reading_hint: Spit on the ground and keep laughing. Throw up some more. Just spew everything out of your mouth while you laugh. You’ve gone insane.

meaning_story: In the middle of the ground is a clam that is very valuable. Inside of this valuable clam is a priceless treasure, and it’s just lying there in the middle of the ground.
meaning_hint: Look at this valuable clam. What could be inside? Pick it up and shake it about, trying to guess what valuable thing is enclosed.
reading_story: To get to the valuable object inside, you need to open the clam. The valuable clam is locked, so you need to find a key (き). Search for the key.
reading_hint: Finally, you found the key with which to open the valuable clam. Take the key and stick it into the clam, hearing the click as its shell opens. What do you see inside?

meaning_story: You see a thread that wants to loiter from some horns and you would be correct to assume that it would hang vertical. The thread wants to loiter and hang from one of the horns. When things hang from things, they usually hang vertical, so that’s what this thread is going to do.
meaning_hint: Look at this vertical thread as it hangs from the horns. Take hold of it and pull on the vertical thread. Feel it in your hand.
reading_story: For some reason, Channing Tatum (たて) is strangely attracted to vertical pieces of hanging thread. Channing Tatum starts batting at the vertical thread like a cat.
reading_hint: Look at Channing Tatum playing with this thread. He’s like a cat playing with a piece of yarn. Look at Mr. Tatum bouncing around batting at the thread like some silly feline.

meaning_story: Give a kiln power and it will work. Simple!
meaning_hint: Power up your kiln and watch it working all day long hardening your pots and statues.
reading_story: Just remember that if you want it to keep working you have to put enough kindling (きん) in there to keep it going. Otherwise it won't have enough power to work. It will shut off and your pots will stay soft and doey.
reading_hint: People are just like kilns. If you want to work hard for a long time you need your own human kindling to keep going. (It's snacks.)

meaning_story: The nailbat antenna are things deserving of worship. These two antenna are both shaped like nailbats, and that is miraculous. Therefore, you worship them.
meaning_hint: Look at these nailbat antenna. Worship them in all their might. Imagine yourself kneeling down and bowing your head before their majesty.
reading_story: What better way to worship these nailbat antenna than with a haiku (はい)? Let’s think up a good one and use it to worship the best we can.
reading_hint: Mighty antenna. I worship thee forever. Thank you for your grace. Or come up with one of your own – haikus are fun!

meaning_story: You use your ability to fish tail to avoid a bear. You are a fish and you have a fish tail and you use your fish tail to maneuver away from the bear that wants to eat you.
meaning_hint: Imagine you’re a fish in the water. Feel the water around you as you hear the bear roar in hunger. You gotta use your fish tail to fish tail and escape his grasp!
reading_story: This bear is actually Kumar (くま), from the Harold &, Kumar movies. Kumar is so high he thinks he’s a bear.
reading_hint: Imagine Kumar from Harold &, Kumar splashing around in the river, screaming about how he’s a bear and needs to eat a fish.

meaning_story: Your mouth wears a mask to hide the fact that it’s boisterous. With the mask on, the mouth figures people won’t know who it is that’s being boisterous.
meaning_hint: Hear your mouth being boisterous behind its mask. It’s saying all sorts of things. Noisily. And with energy. Say a few things out loud yourself in this boisterous fashion.
reading_story: Your boisterous mouth is just so-so (そ). It's annoying as all get out, but it is also capable of intimidating people which can be used to your advantage. Your so-so mouth has its upsides.
reading_hint: Using your boisterous mouth, state aloud 'MY SO-SO MOUTH IS SO-SO AND IT IS ALSO BOISTEROUS~!'

meaning_story: A ghost takes your hair and uses it to carve its name in things. For whatever reason, this ghost can use pieces of your hair to interact with the physical realm. Therefore it steals strands of your hair to carve out its name in things and really freak you out.
meaning_hint: Watch this ghost as it approaches you, plucks out your hair, then carves its name into a table. Feel the pinching pain as the hair leaves your head and hear the sound of the carve on the table.
reading_story: This is the ghost of the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! You watch her carve her name and you become very nervous. Hopefully she doesn’t decide to start carving her name in your skin while you sleep. Dang, that’s creepy.
reading_hint: Okay, you’re really freaked out now. Mrs. Chou is scary. Imagine her plucking out your hair and then carving her name into your flesh as you sleep. Yikes.

meaning_story: There’s a tree in your hair, I think it’s a cedar. How did that cedar tree get in your hair?
meaning_hint: Imagine having a cedar tree in your hair. It’s just a little tree, a sapling, but it’s pretty strange and awkward. It does smell nice though. Mmm… cedar.
reading_story: Once the cedar is fully grown, you use the cedar wood to make a guitar for Sue. A Sue guitar (すぎ), if you will. This Sue guitar was made just for Sue. She’ll love it.
reading_hint: Give Sue her Sue guitar. Hear Sue squeal with glee as she receives her Sue guitar.

meaning_story: Gold is not the same as copper. They are two different metals. Gold is not the same as copper.
meaning_hint: Take a piece of gold in one hand and a piece of copper in the other. Bang them together furiously as you shout. “GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER! GOLD IS NOT THE SAME AS COPPER!”
reading_story: Smashing the copper against the gold has made you tired. You should eat a doughnut (どう). Go get yourself a doughnut.
reading_hint: Mmm… doughnuts. Eat the doughnut and taste its yummy flavor as you look at the piece of copper. It’s shiny.

meaning_story: There is a hat on top of the grave in your mouth next to the cottage. You’re standing next to a cottage. You have a grave in your mouth. Why? You were hungry. You’re eating the grave. The grave has a hat on it because it’s sensitive to the sun.
meaning_hint: You’re next to the cottage so look at it. Picture that cottage. Now taste the cold stone of the grave on your tongue as you begin to chew it up, hat and all.
reading_story: A shaman (しゃ) lives in this cottage and when he sees you outside eating the grave, the shaman comes out to yell at you. The shaman thinks it is very disrespectful to eat a grave, so he shoos you away from his cottage.
reading_hint: Continue to taste the grave and hat in your mouth as the shaman chases you away from the cottage. Hear him yelling and screaming as he chases you off.

meaning_story: You have an alcohol nine times stronger than any other drink in a bottle shaped like a cross and you drink it all and become drunk. You’re like, so drunk right now from all that alcohol. Nine times more drunk than ever before.
meaning_hint: Feel how drunk you are as you look at the cross shaped bottle that once held the alcohol. See the cross start to blur in front of you from how drunk you are.
reading_story: If you drink so much that you become drunk, then your alcohol will begin to taste like water. What is the reading of 水? It's すい, which is the reading for this kanji.
reading_hint: Speaking of 水, you need to drink some. You need to rehydrate and 水 is the best way to do it. Drink a lot of 水. Go. Now.

meaning_story: Fire, fire, flame! There’s fire and flame everywhere! And more fire! RUNNNN!!!
meaning_hint: Feel the fire all around you, the flame licking at your body. It’s really hot!
reading_story: To make matters worse, you’re an ent (えん). Being made of wood is bad when you’re around the flame of a fire. You’re gonna burn, ent.
reading_hint: Hear the crackling and popping of your ent body as the fire and flame burns you away. It’s really hot and painful.

meaning_story: If you loiter around my skin, he will get angry at you. He is my boyfriend and he is very protective of me. So don’t loiter around my skin for too long or he will beat you up.
meaning_hint: He is a jealous guy. He will beat you down if you loiter around my skin for too long. Imagine he is beating you up right now. He is screaming at you as he does so.
reading_story: He says the only way he will stop beating you up is if you give him some curry (かれ). You give him some curry.
reading_hint: He accepts the curry you give him. Smell the curry smell as he eats it right in front of you. He is eating very loudly.

meaning_story: You tie a thread to the Joker to introduce him. Without the thread attached, the Joker would be likely to escape, and you can’t introduce what’s not there! Therefore, the thread is necessary.
meaning_hint: Imagine walking around as you introduce the Joker to everyone. Feel him pulling against the thread and groaning and moaning about how he can’t escape.
reading_story: You want to introduce the Joker to the shogun (しょう) but it looks like the Joker has cut the thread and made a break for it. Dang. You really wanted to introduce him to the shogun. The shogun is going to be disappointed.
reading_hint: Imagine the shogun yelling at you. He thought you were going to introduce him to the famous Joker. He’s angry that you failed to deliver. Hear him yelling and scolding you as he makes you feel shame.

meaning_story: A hut is jammed in a development. There's barely any room for this hut in the community but they jammed in the hut anyway.
meaning_hint: Imagine jamming in this hut. Pick up the hut and jam it in between the other homes in the area.
reading_story: The reason you jammed in the hut is because a coyote (かい) is in the area. The coyote is dangerous, but since your hut is now jammed in with a bunch of other homes, you feel more safe.
reading_hint: Hear the coyote howl and snarl as he watches you jam in your hut in the safety of the community. He's not happy.

meaning_story: A tsunami, old and powerful, takes the moon and dunks it into a lake. The tsunami is so old that it’s had plenty of time to grow massive enough to reach the moon. The old tsunami smashes into the moon, dragging it down into a nearby lake.
meaning_hint: See and hear the tsunami as it roars into the sky, knocking the moon out of it. Hear the moon as it careens towards earth before splashing loudly into the lake. The ground rumbles all around you upon impact.
reading_story: The lake splashes everywhere. The lake is now dry. But where did all that water go? Oh no! It splashed on all of the little 子s (こ). The water must have headed straight for that daycare.
reading_hint: Picture the little 子s crying, covered in lake water. At least you think they’re crying. It’s hard to tell what’s lake water and what’s tears.

meaning_story: They say if you go to the circus you will hear a lecture. They don’t have as many circus animals as they used to, so they’ve had to fill a lot of time with lectures.
meaning_hint: Imagine going to a circus all excited to see animals. Instead, there’s just a guy giving a lecture. You start to zone out and don’t listen to what he says.
reading_story: But wait, who is this fellow giving the lecture? Why it’s none other than こういち himself! こういち is giving a lecture on Japan and their circus animals. こういち’s speech is kind of interesting, but you still wish there were animals.
reading_hint: Listen to こういち drone on and on about stuff in his lecture. You respect こういち, but this lecture is really boring. You fight the urge to take a nap.

meaning_story: You use a train to measure your lifespan. However, your particular train is missing its right side rail, so your lifespan looks like it will be cut short.
meaning_hint: What terrible news. Your lifespan is not long at all. Stupid train. Imagine a train with a missing rail driving off a cliff. This represents the end of your lifespan.
reading_story: You're so sad about the results of the train measurement that you decide to look online for some methods to live longer. You find out that if you drink small juice (じゅ) boxes, once a day, everyday, you might be able to extend your lifespan.
reading_hint: Picture yourself filling your cart at the grocery store with a bunch of small juice boxes, hoping that each one will give you a slightly longer life.

meaning_story: A tsunami and a clam work together to break your ribs beyond measure. The clam rides the tsunami and barrels into your ribs at full speed, breaking them. You can’t even measure the damage done to you – it’s way too severe.
meaning_hint: You try and measure your pain, but you can’t. Feel this unlimited pain from all your broken ribs. It really hurts.
reading_story: While you’re still trying to measure the damage done to your ribs, a friend of yours decides that he needs to reset all your rib bones back into place. To stifle your screams, he sticks a sock (そく) in your mouth.
reading_hint: Taste the stinky sock in your mouth as you feel your ribs crack back into place. Bite down on the sock as you try not to concentrate on the excruciating, absolutely beyond measure, terrible, terrible pain you feel.

meaning_story: The ground and a shuriken have mutual respect for one another. The shuriken respects the ground because of how solid and stable it is, and the ground respects the shuriken for how pointy it is. They have great mutual respect here.
meaning_hint: Pick up the shuriken and throw it into the ground. Hear it whizz through the air and then plunk into the ground. This act of aggression causes their mutual respect to waver.
reading_story: Since you made the shuriken attack the ground, the mutual respect is out of balance. To restore the balance, they play a game of Go (ご). This is a very harmonious game. Go will restore their mutual respect, no matter who wins.
reading_hint: Imagine the ground and the shuriken playing Go. Try and imagine how each of them would go about moving the pieces. Hear them clack on the board as they do so.

meaning_story: This tsunami is the reason we have so much oil now. The tsunami moved a bunch of earth out of the way, so now it’s really easy to dig for oil. The tsunami is the reason we get oil so easily now.
meaning_hint: Watch as this tsunami crashed over the land, pushing earth out of the way. Once the tsunami passes, hear the spewing geysers of oil as they erupt out of the ground.
reading_story: Where is all this oil buried? On the Yucatán (ゆ) Peninsula. That’s where you are right now. You’re vacationing on the Yucatán Peninsula.
reading_hint: Look at all the oil on the Yucatán Peninsula! It’s everywhere. Splash around in the dark and wet oil that now covers the entire Yucatán Peninsula.

meaning_story: One can use a cobra to protect oneself. Cobras are scary. They are good guard animals. It’s very easy to use a cobra to protect oneself.
meaning_hint: Look at this cobra in front of you. Hear it hissing and making snake noises. Truly the cobra is the best way to protect oneself from others.
reading_story: Only problem is, this cobra is just a 子. It’s a little 子 cobra. Not intimidating yet. To protect oneself, you really need an adult cobra. 子 cobras just aren’t as effective.
reading_hint: Aww, look at the little 子 cobra. How cute! Pick it up and feel the little thing slither between your fingers.

meaning_story: Taking a nailbat from the pile of weapons, you set out to make someone pay. A nailbat is the most effective weapon to make someone pay. That’s why you chose the nailbat from your pile of weapons. They owe you money and they need to pay up!
meaning_hint: “You’re gonna pay!” Imagine smacking someone with a nailbat while yelling this phrase over and over.
reading_story: Your victim screams out, “Sekuhara (はら)! Sekuhara!” Sekuhara is short for sexual harassment in Japan. “Now you’re gonna pay for giving me sekuhara!” Your victim shouts. Dang. He’s turned the tables.
reading_hint: Now imagine running away from this guy while he chases you shouting “Sekuhara! Sekuhara!” Man, he’s gonna pay for this…

meaning_story: A gold man has one mustache above his lip and one mustache below his lip and keeps all his extra mustaches safely tucked away in a pot. This man is made of gold and has a lot of money. That’s how he can afford to groom two mustaches at the same time. If anything should happen to one, he has plenty of back up mustaches in his mustache storage pot.
meaning_hint: Picture this double mustachioed gold man as he rifles through his pot of mustaches. Imagine how ticklish they must be.
reading_story: The mustachioed man’s wife asks if he loves his pot of mustaches more than he loves her. “Nah babe (なべ),” he says. “Nah, babe. Nah.”
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as this golden man with the mustache (and another mustache). Say “Nah, babe” over and over again like you’re trying to convince your wife that you actually love her more than your pot of luxurious mustaches.

meaning_story: You have an animal and you say it’s a dog to prevent it from going to prison. Dogs are the only animals that don’t have to go to prison. Your animal is not a dog, but you say it is to prevent it from going to prison.
meaning_hint: Imagine any animal that’s not a dog. Now imagine dressing it up like a dog so it doesn’t have to go to prison. Practice throwing your voice by saying “woof woof” aloud to help convince people that your animal is actually a dog.
reading_story: What is the name of your animal? Your animal is named Goku (ごく). Yeah, like Goku from Dragon Ball Z. You don’t want your little Goku to go to prison, so you say that he’s a dog.
reading_hint: Poor little Goku doesn’t want to go to prison either so Goku does his best to act like a dog even though he isn’t. How adorable.

meaning_story: The sake radical and the sake kanji are exactly the same! Sweet.
reading_story: In the future, for the sake of alcoholics, they will have booze home delivery. Eagles (い) will deliver the booze right to your door. Just put in an order, and it'll be at your doorstep in no time flat. Eagles are like, super fast at delivery.
reading_hint: See this eagle as it comes to deliver the alcohol just for your sake. Scree! Hear its wings flag and the glass bottle clink down on your porch as it's delivered.

meaning_story: Your ear listens to your heart and feels shame. Your heart is full of shame for how you’ve lived your life and when your ear hears all the things you’ve done, your ear feels shame too.
meaning_hint: Feel the shame. Feel the shame in both your ear and your heart. Imagine the things you’ve done to make you feel so much shame.
reading_story: You must cleanse your spirit of this shame. You decide to complete Haj (はじ). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja). Upon arrival in Mecca, you think of a funny joke and bust out laughing. “HAHAHAHAHAHA!! (は) HAHAHAHAHA!!!” Oh man, you’re in a temple and that was completely inappropriate. You feel even more shame than before.
reading_hint: You’re super embarrassed for bringing so much shame on yourself again. But then you think of another joke. “Hahaha!” Better luck with the next Haj, I guess.

meaning_story: Next to a water slide there is a flag warning the sheep to slow down. The sheep like to go down the water slide extra fast and dangerously, so there are flags periodically spaced alongside the water slide warning the sheep to slow down. They always go too fast.
meaning_hint: Imagine these sheep flying down the water slide as you hear the flags flapping in the wind. Shout at the sheep, “SLOWWWW DOWWWWN!”
reading_story: The sheep refuse to slow down. To get them to slow down, you come up with another idea. All the sheep that go down slow enough will be rewarded with cheese (ち). Sheep love cheese. Cheese will be good motivation to cause them to slow down.
reading_hint: Now watch the sheep go down the water slide. They’re all going down at a slow pace because they want that cheese reward. Good job.

meaning_story: A tsunami carries a cross into your soup. Hey tsunami, I was eating that soup. Why you gotta be like that and throw a cross in it? My soup is ruined!
meaning_hint: Dang it. You really wanted to eat this soup. Hear the crashing waters of the tsunami as you smell the delectable soup smell. Your mouth waters. Too bad the soup is now contaminated by that cross.
reading_story: To make matters worse, you’re a Jew (じゅう) and you don’t like any Christian things like crosses. This soup is now terribly offensive to you.
reading_hint: You’re a Jew and you think Christianity is silly. The cross in your soup is dirty and represents a religion you aren’t very fond of. Feel your stomach churn as you lose your appetite for this soup.

meaning_story: Using a nailbat and a cleat, you measure out alcohol to add to your soy sauce. You want to drink alcohol, but covertly, so you measure out some in a convoluted manner by using a cleat and nailbat and then sneakily add it to your soy sauce.
meaning_hint: Imagine how you would go about doing this. It’s not easy to get the alcohol into the soy sauce using just a nailbat and a cleat, but you’ve done it.
reading_story: Uh oh, looks like the shogun (しょう) wants some soy sauce. He takes your bottle of soy sauce and puts it on his food. The shogun is going to get tipsy and it’s all your fault.
reading_hint: Imagine the shogun after he’s finished his meal. He’s being all silly and uninhibited. He’s going to be really embarrassed later.

meaning_story: A tsunami, once stopped by a belt, will begin to stagnate. This belt is a belt of water resistance, so the belt stops the tsunami. The belt has caused the tsunami to stagnate.
meaning_hint: Watch this belt as it stagnated the tsunami. See the belt glow as its enchantment activates, immediately stagnating the tsunami water.
reading_story: While you watch the tsunami stagnate, you get ready for work. While you were watching this whole thing happening, you were tying your tie (たい). Once the tsunami stagnated, you were all done tying your tie. And since the tsunami is no longer a threat, you’re ready to go to work.
reading_hint: Look in the mirror at you in your tie. Put the finishing touches on your outfit and imagine going out into the world with your tie on, no longer afraid of any tsunamis. They’re all stagnant now thanks to that magical belt.

meaning_story: A squid had its ribs removed by a sword. This is actually why squids don’t have ribs today. The very first squid had his ribs removed by a sharp sword and all the squid descendants were born without ribs from that point on.
meaning_hint: Imagine removing the ribs of this squid with a sword. Hear the rubbery flesh squish as it separates. The squid is also screaming in agony. Reach in and pull out the ribs with your bare hands.
reading_story: You set down your sword as you attempt to pull out the ribs with your hand. Like Ken (けん) from Street Fighter, you shout “Shoryuken!” and rip the ribs out. Yeah, you’re just like Ken from Street Fighter.
reading_hint: Imagine doing a Shoryuken to rip the ribs out of this squid. It’s incredibly gruesome, but Ken from Street Fighter is cool, so that makes it okay.

meaning_story: If you scrape a sharp stone against your skin, it will tear. The sharp stone will tear your skin. That’s not comfortable.
meaning_hint: Imagine this sharp stone. Feel its weight in your hand. Now drag the sharp stone against your skin. Feel your skin as it begins to tear. The pain is agonizing.
reading_story: You’ve snapped. You’ve gone insane. Continue to violently tear up your skin with the stone as you laugh maniacally. “HAHAHAHAHAHA! (は) HAHAHAHA!! HAHAHA?!?!”
reading_hint: Continue laughing as you examine your wounds. Dang. They really hurt. Haha, you need to get to a hospital.

meaning_story: The turtle radical and the turtle kanji are exactly the same! Nice!
reading_story: You know Dragon Ball Z, right? Imagine this turtle doing a Kamehameha (かめ). The turtle charges up his energy and releases a might Kamehameha blast. Shwooom!
reading_hint: See this turtle as he gathers energy, shaking the earth around him, gathering chi for his Kamehameha blast. He releases it in a mighty blast of energy. Kamehameha!!

meaning_story: If you’re on the edge of a cliff with a snake, you’re unlucky. You’re hanging off the edge of this cliff and you can’t pull yourself back up when you notice a snake approaching your fingers. The snake looks like it’s gonna bite you. How unlucky.
meaning_hint: What will you do? You can either let do and fall off the cliff, or get bit by the snake if you keep holding on. Man, you’re unlucky.
reading_story: Even though you’re so unlucky, you decide to take your chances and let go of the cliff. Amazingly, a yak (やく) runs below you and catches you as you fall. Saved by the yak!
reading_hint: What a nice yak this is. Perhaps your luck has turned around. Perhaps you aren’t as unlucky as you thought. Your butt sure does hurt from that fall though…

meaning_story: To make alcohol the key is to ferment it. But, if you ferment it a certain way, it will become vinegar.
meaning_hint: Imagine making a bunch of vinegar. You use a key to change it from alcohol to vinegar, yum!
reading_story: You are demonstrating this practice in front of an audience. You want them to take you seriously so you wear a suit (す). A very nice suit. Surely they will now believe that you can turn alcohol into vinegar.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself doing the same thing as before but you are now wearing a suit. Dang, you look good.

meaning_story: You say something and the flowers are right in agreement. The flowers see where you are coming from when you say what you say. You and the flowers are in complete agreement.
meaning_hint: What did you say to the flowers that you are so in agreement about? Think about what you said.
reading_story: You and the flowers are in agreement on the fact that neither of you like when a duck (だく) walks across the flowers. You don’t like having a duck walk on the flowers because the duck will poo in the flowers and then you have to worry about stepping in it. And the flowers just don’t like having duck poo in their face.
reading_hint: Imagine you are the flowers. There’s a duck. It’s making a poo. On you. Ew, man, that’s disgusting. Bleh.

meaning_story: I’ll give you this bright plate if you agree to an alliance with me. I know you like things that are bright, and I know you like plates too. Therefore, this bright plate should be more than enough to convince you to enter into an alliance with me.
meaning_hint: Look at this bright plate. Look at it. It’s awesome. It’s blinding. Hold it in your hands. Marvel at it. Wow. This plate is sweet.
reading_story: The person you are trying to get in an alliance with you is the captain of the Mayflower (めい). You want to be in an alliance with the captain of the Mayflower because you really like boats. You want to ride on the Mayflower like, so bad.
reading_hint: This Mayflower boat is the best boat you ever did see. Hear the ocean around it as it bobs in the water, full sails billowing in the wind. Boats are cool.

meaning_story: A nailbat and a cleat measure the mettle of your commander. Your commander’s nailbat and cleat are the best in the service so you know your commander measures as one of the best in the world.
meaning_hint: Check out the commander’s nailbat and his cleat shoes. They’re awesome. Heft the bat in your hands and put your feet in the cleats.
reading_story: Who do you think is the supreme commander? It’s the shogun (しょう), obviously. Duh. The shogun is the supreme commander of everything.
reading_hint: Check out the shogun with his cleated shoes and nailbat. He’s awesome. What a great commander he is.

meaning_story: Nothing can stop a protester from starting to dance! Protesters love to dance. They're probably protesting because someone told them they weren't supposed to dance in the first place.
meaning_hint: Picture the streets filled with protesters dancing! It looks like a flash mob, except they have signs and the cops don't seem very pleased.
reading_story: As they dance you hear this sound coming out of the crowd. "Boo (ぶ) boo!" they say, as they dance. You look closer and see that they're all protesting ghosts! And they're booing as they dance!
reading_hint: Imagine hearing the ghosts boo as they dance. They dance for the future of dancing in this world. So that, one day, no one will have to die and become a ghost to dance freely.

meaning_story: A leader is someone you can blame the problem of debt on. The leader is the person who got us all into debt. Blame the debt on the leader.
meaning_hint: Who is the leader that brought all this debt? Focus on that person and how angry you are at all the debt there is.
