reading_story: With all this debt, the most you can do is sigh (さい). SIGH. You can blame the leader all you want but it’s not going to change the debt problem. Sigh, sigh, sigh.
reading_hint: Sigh out loud a few times while you think of how lousy the debt situation is. Sigh!

meaning_story: To become leader of the frog kingdom you must achieve a great deed. No particular deed, just something of epic proportions. Epic by frog standards anyway.
meaning_hint: Imagine you were a frog and you wanted to become the leader. What sort of deed do you think would make you worthy to become leader? Imagine yourself doing this deed.
reading_story: You decide that your deed will be finding the lost key (き) of the ancient frog kingdom. The key has been missing for hundreds of years, but you decide to set out and retrieve it.
reading_hint: Imagine searching for this key and then finding it! You’ve done a great deed. Now imagine yourself opening the ancient treasure chest with that key. Hear the key click in the lock as you do so.

meaning_story: You decide to compare people's mullets by helicopter when you see the most luxurious mullet you've ever seen! You bring the helicopter down and as you get closer you realize this mullet isn't on a person. It's on a deer! A deer with a beautiful, flowing mullet.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the deer's mullet up close. It's even prettier than you thought from the air.
reading_story: As you're admiring and comparing the deer's mullet to all the mullets you've ever seen, it gets hit by a car (か).
reading_hint: Deer get hit by cars all the time, but it was still really shocking . I mean it was right in front of you. The car could have hit you too.

radicals: 大, 勹, 冂, 儿
meaning_story: There’s a nailbat outside an enclosure with a head and legs inside it because big dudes decided to exchange the death of the others for their freedom. There is only one nailbat and the last guy left alive gets to be set free. The winner will exchange the blood of the other big dudes for his freedom.
meaning_hint: Imagine the big guys inside the enclosure beating the crap out of each other with the nailbat, hacking of heads and legs. Is this exchange really worth it?
reading_story: One of the big guys finds a can (かん) on the ground and uses that as a weapon. He and the guy with the nailbat exchange blows, but the can is no match for the nailbat. The guy with the can is struck down.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to wield a can as a weapon against a nailbat. It’s not a fair exchange. Feel the nailbat strike you down violently.

meaning_story: The fang radical and the fang kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means tusk. It means fang and tusk.
meaning_hint: Since the fang radical is the same as the fang kanji, that should be easy to remember. Tusks aren’t too different from fangs, so that shouldn’t be too hard to remember either.
reading_story: Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (げ)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.
reading_hint: Picture a gecko with cute little fangs. You can keep thinking they're cute as long as one never bites you. They may be little, but gecko fangs are no joke!

meaning_story: There’s a stick next to the sun reflecting on its former glory. The stick used to be a great tree and the stick thinks that if it stays by the sun long enough it might return to its former form as a towering tree.
meaning_hint: Pretend you are the stick. Really focus on your former self as you feel the sun warm you with its rays. Imagine yourself growing, larger and larger.
reading_story: Just when you feel like you’re about to start becoming like your former self, a cute (きゅう) rabbit dashes out of the woods and snatches you up in its mouth before running off with you. Dang it! This cute rabbit needs to let you down right now!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself being carried off by this cute rabbit as you struggle and try to get away. Shout at the cute rabbit to let you go.

meaning_story: If you set sail for IKEA, generally you will end up purchasing many things. The sail on your boat is billowing. Onward to IKEA! They generally have nice things!
meaning_hint: Imagine setting sail in your ship and seeing an IKEA in the distance. Generally this would be a happy sight.
reading_story: Generally you wouldn’t have any problems getting to IKEA. However, Han (はん) Solo flies in from the sky and purchases everything in the store before you can get to shopping. Han! How rude of him to so such a thing.
reading_hint: Imagine Han Solo running about picking up and purchasing everything in IKEA. Now imagine him trying to put all that furniture together. It’s not easy.

meaning_story: When a tsunami comes, the brush makes a good safe haven. Thick brush is a haven from tsunamis because the brush will break the tsunami water and keep you safe and dry.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in the haven of a brush while a tsunami strikes. Hear the water crash and rush all around you while you remain safe in your haven.
reading_story: The only downside about this haven is that there’s only room for two (つ) people in the brush. The brush isn’t big enough for more than two people, so unless you have a lot of brushes, you won’t be saving many people from the tsunami.
reading_hint: Since there is room for two people in the brush, imagine yourself in the haven with one other person. They and you make two. The other person is a real whiner though - imagine them crying the whole time.

meaning_story: A sick ox is in need of a heal. Please! Someone heal this sick ox!
meaning_hint: You are a healer. It is your job to heal. Heal this sick ox by placing your hand on the ox. Feel the ox fur as you begin to heal its sickness.
reading_story: To fully heal this sick ox you need to cleanse him in water. Therefore you row (りょう) the ox out in the middle of a lake, dunk him in the water, and then row back to shore.
reading_hint: Imagine being in a row boat with the ox you need to heal. He doesn’t like the water and he’s not helping you row either. Lousy ox.

meaning_story: Taking a piece of thread, a lion ties it to a piece of rice he will inherit from his parents. The lion ties the thread to the rice so he can be sure not to lose it. He wants to inherit it very badly and does not want it to become lost.
meaning_hint: Imagine this lion with one end of the thread tied to his claw and one end tied to the rice. The lion looks at the rice gleefully. He can’t wait to inherit it.
reading_story: Suddenly the KKK (けい) busts in and murders the lion’s parents! Oh no! Blood everywhere. The KKK is a murdering bunch of ravenous ravels! Well, now the lion can inherit his piece of rice I guess.
reading_hint: Imagine the lion’s face as he sees his parents being brutally slaughtered by the KKK. Once the KKK leaves and the lion realizes he now owns the piece of rice, the lion becomes happy again.

meaning_story: A water slide is a valuable thing that you cannot leave behind. Well, normally. However you have been forced to leave behind your water slide. You’re moving, and the water slide is just too big to take with you. You gotta leave behind that water slide, regardless of how valuable it is.
meaning_hint: Imagine going down the water slide one last time as you think of how much it sucks that you gotta leave it behind. Man, you’re gonna miss this waterslide. Feel the water under you as you feel the sorrow in your heart.
reading_story: You leave behind the water slide and return to it many years later. You’re surprised to find that eagles (い) have made a nest at the top of the slide. Yes, eagles. Now you feel good about your decision to leave behind the slide. A family of eagles now has a home thanks to you.
reading_hint: See the eagles as they circle over the water slide. Hear the flap of their wings as they screech their eagle screeches.

meaning_story: You tie a piece of thread to your turkey in order to maintain proximity to it. The turkey likes to run away, so you tie a thread to it. This way you can hold the other end and maintain your turkey.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding onto a thread that is attached to a turkey. Feel the turkey tug against the thread as you struggle to maintain control.
reading_story: The reason the turkey is struggling is because there’s an eagle (い) swooping down to attack the turkey. You try to maintain control, but once you see the eagle as well, you let go of the thread.
reading_hint: Now you and the turkey and the eagle are all bumbling about in pandemonium. You try to maintain order but it’s not possible. What a kerfuffle.

meaning_story: There is a big jackhammer in Nara. That jackhammer is the biggest in all the land and is on display in Nara, Japan.
meaning_hint: Look at this big jackhammer. Look at it. It’s so big. Also it’s in Nara. Imagine being in Nara and looking at this big jackhammer. You’re all like, dang – that’s a big jackhammer.
reading_story: What’s the first part of Nara? Na (な). Well that’s easy.
reading_hint: Just keep in mind what the first part of Nara is. The first part of Nara is “na” so you’ll have no trouble remembering this one.

meaning_story: You take a tree and slice it until you reach its nucleus. To get to the nucleus of the tree you have to make many a slice, but it’s possible.
meaning_hint: Imagine slicing this tree smaller and smaller until you finally get to the nucleus of it. It’s super tiny so you have to view it in a microscope. What does it look like?
reading_story: It looks like a cock (かく). And by cock I mean a male chicken – a rooster. Why does the nucleus of a tree look like a cock? Science is weird.
reading_hint: Look at this tree nucleus that looks like a cock. While you’re watching it, the nucleus goes “Cock-a-doodle-doo!”

meaning_story: If you have a mullet you must make a departure for your hairstyle is obsolete. Of all the obsolete hairstyles, the mullet is the worst. Therefore you must make a speedy departure.
meaning_hint: Look at your mullet. It’s disgraceful. What an obsolete hairstyle that is. Feel shame for being so behind the times.
reading_story: Let’s come up with a haiku (はい) in memory of this obsolete hairstyle. A haiku is the best way to remember something that is obsolete, especially if it’s something hilarious like a mullet.
reading_hint: Are you ready for the obsolete mullet haiku? Here goes. What’s that on your head? / The mullet is obsolete. / Make your departure.

meaning_story: In the south, a dog will offer you help. The dogs in the south are very friendly. Southern hospitality. The dogs from the south will offer you lots and lots of assistance.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in the south and seeing a dog. What does the dog offer to do for you? Imagine the dog making the offer and how nice the dog is for doing so.
reading_story: You’re Ken (けん) from Street Fighter and you’re looking for Ryu. The dog decides to offer to help you in your search. Ken is lonely without Ryu, so it makes sense that Ken is looking for him.
reading_hint: Imagine going around with this dog looking for Ryu. Since you’re Ken, feel free to do some hadokens for fun while you search.

meaning_story: There is a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Luckily there are no ships around, so the tsunami in the middle of the open sea is not damaging to anyone.
meaning_hint: Look at this tsunami in the middle of the open sea. When the tsunami isn’t destroying things and is just out there in the open sea it looks really majestic and pretty.
reading_story: Someone dares you to go out to the open sea and surf on the middle of the tsunami. “Oki (おき) doki,” you reply. You can’t refuse a dare. Every time someone dares you to do something, you always respond with “oki doki”.
reading_hint: You really regret saying oki doki this time. You don’t want to surf on a tsunami in the middle of the open sea. Imagine doing so. It’s terrifying and wet and you don’t even know how to surf. You’re going to die.

meaning_story: Taking a nailbat to a mohawk, you pluck the hairs off one by one. With the nails from the nailbat, you get them caught on the hairs making up the mohawk. Once the hairs catch, you pluck them off!
meaning_hint: Imagine plucking each one of these hairs out as the guy with the mohawk squeals in pain each time. Pluck. Ow! Pluck! OW!!
reading_story: The guy with the mohawk is a self-proclaimed techie (てき) but he managed to screw up your computer beyond repair. You decide to pluck out his mohawk with a nailbat as punishment. Some techie this guy is.
reading_hint: Now you have motivation for torturing this techie with a mohawk. Continue to pluck each hair, thinking about how this lousy “techie” screwed up your computer. Also note that this kanji has the same reading as the similar 敵.

meaning_story: Using an escalator you reach the conclusion that it is much more convenient than stairs. If you want to reach the top of something, an escalator is the way to go.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself on an escalator. What is up above that you’re trying to reach? Feel the escalator move beneath you as you envision what it is you’re about to reach.
reading_story: The thing you’re trying to reach is a cute (きゅう) rabbit! The escalator is taking you up to the pet store. Once you reach the pet store you can obtain a cute rabbit.
reading_hint: Imagine getting off the escalator and seeing a big cute fuzzy rabbit there waiting for you. How cute!

meaning_story: A leader has clothes that he is quite reliant on. The leader needs his clothes to make him look like a leader. The leader has become more reliant on his clothes than he is on his actual skills as a leader!
meaning_hint: Imagine this leader in his clothes. Look how reliant he is on them. Imagine what he would be without his clothes – nothing! And also, naked.
reading_story: The leader has become so reliant on his clothes that his judgment has been clouded. His kingdom has become infested with eagles (い) but the leader does nothing, trusting that his clothes will rout out the eagles if it is something that needs to be done. He’s become so reliant on his clothes that he’s started to become not so good a leader anymore.
reading_hint: Look at the leader as he shouts at his clothes he’s become so reliant on to do something. Hear the countless eagles screeching around as they terrorize the neighborhood. People scream and weep in the streets.

meaning_story: Give some thread to a turtle and he will turn it into a rope. This turtle likes to weave thread together and make ropes. Give him some thread and the turtle will give you a rope in return.
meaning_hint: Look at this turtle fervently working on making his rope. See his little arms weave the thread together as he concentrates intently on the task.
reading_story: This turtle has been hired by Joseph (じょう) Stalin to make a rope for every soldier in his army. Joseph Stalin is running short on workers so he’s recruited this turtle to help with the war effort.
reading_hint: Imagine Joseph Stalin barking orders at the turtle, telling him to make the rope faster, faster, FASTER!

meaning_story: You soak each foot in water before approaching the sun and taking your first step. Oh, GOD! The water didn’t help at all – dang the sun is hot! Why would you ever step on the sun!?!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself going through this process. Stick your foot in some water. Then step on the sun. The water doesn’t really help. The sun is like, really hot, man.
reading_story: The reason you took a step on the sun was to win a trip to Tokyo (とう). There was a contest going on that said if you were brave enough to step on the sun they would give you a paid vacation to Tokyo. You won!
reading_hint: Too bad your foot got burned off. And too bad they’re only paying for a vacation to Tokyo and not your medical bills. Think about it – was that step really worth it?

meaning_story: An honest leader can say humbly that he does not stretch the truth. This leader refuses to stretch the truth and always tells things like it is. This is something he can say humbly, he’s not trying to brag about how he doesn’t stretch the truth, he just wants you to know. He tells you the only thing he does stretch is his body.
meaning_hint: Imagine this leader telling you about how he doesn’t stretch the truth. While he does so, imagine him doing the splits and stretching his arms and neck all about as well.
reading_story: While in the middle of his explanation, the leader realizes he is thirsty so he begins to stretch towards a glass of egg nog (の). Apparently this guy really likes the nog.
reading_hint: Watch him stretch towards the nog in desperation. You could help him, but you’re kind of enjoying watching him stretch, you weirdo.

meaning_story: That special woman in your life will eventually take your surname and make it her family name too. Traditionally, a woman will change her last name when she gets married and keep that name for the rest of her life. Her husband’s family name becomes her family name too.
meaning_hint: Imagine having your surname changed for the rest of your life. How do you feel about having a different family name? Is it a big deal to you or does it not matter much?
reading_story: There is a special woman in the life of Hard Gay. She’s changing her surname to Gay. Yes, Hard Gay’s family name is Gay. “Sei (せい), sei, sei! Another Gay is on the way!”
reading_hint: Imagine Hard Gay chanting this at his wedding as Mrs. Gay officially takes on Hard Gay’s family name. I’m sure they’ll live a long and happy life together.

meaning_story: The sweet radical and the sweet kanji are exactly the same! Double sweet.
reading_story: The sweet, sweet sensation is almost overwhelming. You gotta put on some sweet resistant armor (あま) to protect you from all that sweetness. The armor will prevent you from having a sweet, sweet sweetness overload.
reading_hint: Put on the armor! Feel its weight on your body. Now taste the sweet flavor on your tongue. It’s sweet, but not too sweet.

meaning_story: You have a big pile of crap including a sword and a clam and you’re trying to trade it in for money. The pile is a bit weird though. I mean, besides containing random junk like a sword and a clam, the weird pile smells kind of funny and I think it might be moving. I’m not sure if you’ll be able to trade this in.
meaning_hint: Look at this pile you want to trade. Did it just move? Hmm… maybe. The pile radical is a bit weird in this kanji, so just remember that. Since the pile is weird, it’s a bit hard to trade.
reading_story: The pile you’re trying to trade shifts around a bit and you see a bow (ぼう) and arrow. Looks like the previous owner of the pile was going hunting for clams what with the sword and the bow and arrows and all.
reading_hint: Maybe you don’t want to trade this pile after all. There might be some other cool weapons in this pile. Even though it’s weird, that sword and bow are pretty cool looking so maybe you won’t trade this pile after all.

meaning_story: An ent and a geoduck trust each other. They are both strange and misunderstood creatures, so they have developed a trust. They have lots of trust and understanding between the two of them.
meaning_hint: Imagine the geoduck and the ent holding hands, dancing around together, and performing trust falls. It’s a ridiculous sight.
reading_story: “I need you to find me some rye (らい) grain,” said the ent to the geoduck. “I trust you won’t fail me?” “Your trust is not misplaced!” says the geoduck.
reading_hint: Imagine the geoduck out searching for rye grain. He’s chanting the word rye over and over so he doesn’t forget what he’s been entrusted to retrieve.

meaning_story: You run from the Joker because you are Ultra Man. Ultra Man is only used to fighting big Japanese monsters. Ultra Man is not used to dealing with Western villains. Therefore, Ultra Man will run from the Joker.
meaning_hint: As you run, you realize you’re not being very Ultra. You’re being lame. Feel some shame why dontcha?
reading_story: Just as you start to think about fighting the Joker, the Evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) shows up and starts to run after you as well. Not Mrs. Chou! Mrs. Chou is ultra scary, dude. Run! Run away!
reading_hint: Run faster than you’ve ever run before, Ultra Man! Mrs. Chou is running after you and screaming. The Joker is laughing. Don’t stop running until you’re safe!

meaning_story: Two Face is the creeper in the rice paddy who keeps measuring the width of workers’ butts. Two Face waits in the rice paddy until a worker comes by and then he measures the width of their butt. Apparently Two Face is a creeper with a butt fetish.
meaning_hint: Imagine having the width of your butt measured by Two Face in a rice paddy. Feel his creeper hands on your bum. You’re really uncomfortable.
reading_story: To punish Two Face for being such a creeper, you catch him and make him eat a habanero (はば) pepper for each butt width he measured. He measured the width of a lot of butts so he’s going to be eating a lot of habaneros.
reading_hint: Imagine Two Face crying as he eats the spicy habanero peppers. Hopefully this will teach him a lesson and he will no longer feel the desire to measure the width of your butt.

meaning_story: A skewer to the heart has afflicted your health. You’ve been afflicted with a disease from the skewer to your heart. Your affliction is death. You’re dying.
meaning_hint: You did not wish to be afflicted as such. Feel the skewer in your heart and the great pain it gives you. You know you’re dying.
reading_story: Since you’re afflicted with the death, you cry out a last request. You want a can (かん) of beer. If you have just one can of beer, you think you can die happy.
reading_hint: If you’ve never had beer before, just imagine it’s your favorite soda. Hear the can hiss as you open it. Feel the metal of the can touch your lips as you try to ignore the afflicted area from the skewer wound to your heart. Taste the liquid from the can as you slowly fade away.

meaning_story: If you see an animal in a top hat while you're hunting make sure you aim at it! Even if you don't actually shoot it, you should at least aim so you can see it better. Top hat wearing animals go for the most money and they're super rare! Aim right at it!
meaning_hint: Imagine aiming through your scope at a top hat wearing animal. You aren't sure what kind of animal it is, but you know you want it, so aim carefully.
reading_story: Ready, aim, fire! You attempt to shoot the animal but your aim is just so-so (そ) and you end up shooting the top hat off it's head. Unfortunately for you, top hats are really tall and the animal got away fine. Now you're left with a top hat with a hole in it.
reading_hint: If your aim is so-so you aren't going to hit anything well enough to kill it. That's lucky for the once top hat wearing animal though!

meaning_story: A butcher takes a car to the army base. Why? The army base needs a butcher to chop their meat and prepare it.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are the butcher riding in the car to the army base. See the army base approach, planes flying, guns shooting, and commanding officers shouting.
reading_story: You’d never know it was an army base though because all the soldiers are wearing jeans (じん). Is it their day off or something? You thought soldiers were supposed to wear uniforms when they were on the base.
reading_hint: Picture all the soldiers wandering around the army base wearing jeans instead of their uniform pants. Some of them have the rest of their uniforms on, and one guy over there only has jeans on and nothing else.

meaning_story: In a rice paddy there is an explosion under a grave where a base is buried. The grave is of a famous baseball player who was buried with a baseball base. His grave is in a rice paddy because he loved rice and the explosion is from him busting out of his grave. He’s a zombie.
meaning_hint: Imagine this zombie baseball player exploding out of his grave in the rice paddy. Hear him moaning and lurching about as he holds a base in one hand and a baseball in the other.
reading_story: Unfortunately his base is ruined (るい). Being buried in the grave all that time rotted them. The baseball and base are both ruined.
reading_hint: Since his prized possession is now ruined, the baseball zombie man is now very sad. See him as he falls to his knees in the rice paddy and cries his little zombie eyes out.

meaning_story: A spring-loaded firearm shoots at a witch doctor and hits him with a bullet. The spring isn’t very powerful though, so while the bullet hits the witch doctor, it does not damage him.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are shooting this bullet at the witch doctor. Feel the spring compress and then release as you pull the trigger.
reading_story: The reason you shot at the witch doctor with the spring bullet is because he is named Dan (だん). Dan is your name and you don’t like there being more than one Dan. You’re the only Dan! The witch doctor is not happy that you hit him with that bullet though.
reading_hint: Scream at Dan the witch doctor. “I’m Dan and I’m the man! You’re not Dan, I am! I’m Dan!” Throw the spring at the witch doctor along with your spare bullets to really drive your point home.

radicals: 一, ヒ, 廾, 歹
meaning_story: You present flowers from the ground and a bad spoon to your twenty year old friend at his burial. There are twenty flowers for each of the twenty years of his life. The bad spoon was his favorite spoon, even though it was a bad one. His death was very sudden and tragic and you are overwhelmed with emotion at his burial.
meaning_hint: Imagine being at this burial. You’re very sad and crying a little bit. Feel the flowers in your one hand while holding the bad spoon in the other. Smell the flowers' aroma as the wind whisks the smell up to your nose.
reading_story: Your twenty year old friend was in a bad accident and they had to sew (そう) most of his body back together. Since they had to sew everything up, his body was pretty messed up and they decided to go with a closed casket ceremony before the burial.
reading_hint: Actually, you were the one who had to sew your friend back together. Imagine yourself sewing your friends appendages back onto his mangled body. Sew away as you reflect on the twenty years of his young life.

meaning_story: Taking a nailbat and a lid from the table, you confront your enemy. The nailbat is your weapon and the lid is your shield. You are ready to confront anything.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking the nailbat and the lid from the table. You feel like a mighty warrior with a club and a shield. Imagine confronting your greatest enemy with confidence!
reading_story: Who is it that you wish to confront? It’s こういち. こういち is the one you wish to confront because he’s been making fun of how slowly you’re progressing in WaniKani. Now he’s going to pay.
reading_hint: Imagine taking the nailbat and bopping こういち on the head with it. You’ve finally confronted him about how rude he’s been concerning your Japanese studies and now you’re following through with it. Hear こういち scream in pain as you punch the lid into his tummy.

meaning_story: Above a mountain, a moon and another moon crash into each other and crumble to pieces. The two moons smash into one another and crumble, their pieces falling onto the mountain and making it bigger.
meaning_hint: Hear the crack as the moons collide and hear them as they begin to crumble. Imagine them over this huge mountain. It’s an amazing sight.
reading_story: As you see each moon continue to crumble to the ground and wonder what this will do to the balance of gravity on your planet, you hear someone laughing behind you. It’s Hou-dini (ほう)! Turns out this was all an illusion by the great Hou-dini himself. There was never one moon, let alone two. Nothing’s even crumbling. It’s all an elaborate ruse by Hou-dini.
reading_hint: Oh Hou-dini you rascal. I really thought that was a real crumble. Hou-dini is so clever.

meaning_story: On a water slide there was an insect who got mauled by a bear shortly after his dispatch. The insect’s superior officer was told to dispatch the insect out to the water slide but the insect was attacked by the bear and the insect lost its leg.
meaning_hint: Since the insect radical is missing a little piece, keep in mind that it got mauled by that bear. Imagine you are the insect and you got your leg ripped off as you hear the bear roaring beside you.
reading_story: You’d like to dispatch the bear yourself but you are injured and unable. Luckily your insect commander makes the executive decision to dispatch Ken (けん) from Street Fighter out to help you. Ken unleashes a hadoken at the bear and blasts him into oblivion.
reading_hint: Hear Ken screaming out as he dispatches the bear with a mighty hadoken. HADOKEN!

meaning_story: A nailbat lies in the sun in an enclosure next to a spoon on display. The nailbat is in an enclosure because you don’t want it to take away from your spoon display. The sun glints off the spoon magnificently.
meaning_hint: Look at your spoon display in the sun. It’s very impressive. The sun glints of the spoon and stings your eyes, but you don’t even care.
reading_story: The spoon is on display for a local KKK (けい) rally. For whatever reason the KKK really likes spoons so you made this display to display to the KKK your spoon.
reading_hint: Imagine the KKK looking at your spoon that is on display. Tell them to ignore the nailbat in the enclosure as you notice how bright their white robes look in the sun. Almost as bright as your spoon. Almost.

meaning_story: If you combine fire with violence, it will explode! A fire, once full of violence, will surely explode. The fire can’t handle all that violence so the fire just rumbles and shakes and then finally explodes. BOOM!
meaning_hint: Imagine the fire explode. Feel the heat of the fire and the explosion. It’s very violent. BOOM BOOM BA-BOOM!
reading_story: As you watch the fire explode, you start to back (ばく) away. I don’t blame you. You need to back away or else you’ll get caught in the violent explosion. Back away a little more just to be safe.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as you back away from the explosion. As you back away, see the fire dance and feel the heat of the explosion on your face.

meaning_story: You carry a cross across a rice paddy with a heart on it to return a favor for your friend. The heart needs to be purified so that’s why you have it on the cross and your friend lives on a rice paddy farm so that’s why you’re running through that. The favor you are paying your friend back with is getting him this heart. He needs a new one and you’re providing it.
meaning_hint: This is a pretty big favor. Imagine running through a rice paddy carrying a cross with a warm beating heart on it. Thump thump. Thump thump.
reading_story: You arrive at your friend’s place and you can finally return the favor you owe him by presenting him with the heart. “Eh (え)? What’s this? I didn’t ask for this!” “Eh!?!?” you reply. Apparently he didn’t want a real heart, he wanted a candy one. He wanted a Valentine!
reading_hint: Imagine how dumb you feel at this miscommunication. Eh? You don’t feel dumb? Well you should!

meaning_story: A tsunami pushes all the fish closer to land, making for some easy fishing. The tsunami starts out in the middle of the ocean and pushes all the fish towards the coast where everyone does their fishing. With all the fish pushed closer to land and closer together, it’s very easy for people to go fishing in one spot and catch a lot of fish.
meaning_hint: Imagine going fishing for fish in a fishing spot after a tsunami. There are SO many fish here. Your hook barely touches the water and there’s already a fish on it. Man, fishing like this is easy! Smell the smell of fish and sea air around you.
reading_story: To get to the best fishing spot you need to go (ぎょ) row (りょう) out to the middle of the ocean. You go by means of rowing. To get to the fish and do the fishing, you need to go and row out to sea.
reading_hint: Go! Go row! Go and row for the fishing! How do you go? You row! The row part should be pretty easy to remember since you gotta row your boat out to sea, but if you’re having trouble with the go part, just remember that it has the same reading as 魚.

meaning_story: Pine warms in the sun, giving off a fragrance. The pine has been out in the sun all day and the warmth of the sun makes the pine smell very strongly. The fragrance is very apparent.
meaning_hint: Smell the pine smell in your nose. The fragrance is overwhelming. Pine fragrance everywhere!
reading_story: You’re about to feint. You need to get out of here. You and your best bud こういち hop in the car to get away from the pine fragrance. You let こういち drive since he’s older and wiser.
reading_hint: Imagine riding in the car with こういち. The pine fragrance is still on your clothes so you roll down the windows to air out. You notice こういち is no longer wearing his shirt. You don’t mind.

meaning_story: A tsunami blows a bouncy off-red spring into the gulf. The tsunami was very violent so this off-red spring got blown all the way from across the ocean into this gulf here.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are the spring getting blown away by this tsunami. Feel the wind and water carry you into the gulf and hear the water crash and wind blow. Also remember that the spring is an off-red color since the red radical is altered here.
reading_story: Wait, how many springs were there? One (わん). There was one spring that got blown into the gulf. Just one spring. That’s you.
reading_hint: You are the one! You alone traveled across the sea to the gulf. You are the only one!

meaning_story: Your foot senses an omen foretelling that it will soon hop. Your foot is sensitive to omens and soon your foot begins to hop, just like your foot predicted.
meaning_hint: Imagine a dark cloud gathering around your foot, the mark of an omen. As the cloud swirls about your foot begins to hop… hop… HOP!
reading_story: The ominous omen was conjured upon your foot by none other than the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) herself! You actually saw a foreboding omen predicting Mrs. Chou’s arrival as well, but that’s besides the point. The evil Mrs. Chou is the reason your foot can’t help but hop.
reading_hint: Feel your foot continue to hop as Mrs. Chou cackles in the background, laughing her evil little head off. “Hop! Hop! Yes… muahaha!”

meaning_story: A nailbat enclosure with a cobra on the outside will prevent anyone from giving you a hug. All you want is a hug, but you can’t get a hug because you are in an enclosure made of nailbats with a vicious cobra attached. If anyone tries to get close enough to hug you, the cobra will bite them.
meaning_hint: Dang you want a hug. Think intently about how much you want a hug as you grip the nailbats making up your enclosure. Your hands start to bleed.
reading_story: The person you want a hug from the most is your daddy (だ), your dada. You cry out, “Dada! Hug me! I just want a hug! Wahhh… dada…”
reading_hint: Say that last bit out loud. Really get emotional at it. Maybe wrap your arms around yourself in a self-hug to attempt to alleviate some of the pain.

meaning_story: In an enclosure sits the sun which determines when something is in season and what time of month it is. Depending on how much sun leaks out of the enclosure, it affects what clothes are in season. Also, the sun determines the time of month as well. How does it do it? Magic, of course.
meaning_hint: Imagine the sun as it leaks more and more light out of the enclosure. You start off cold then start to feel warmer. Shorts are in season now! Put on shorts! The time of the month has changed! Pay your rent! So many things to do!
reading_story: Looks like it’s that time of month again. Wait, what month? The one that’s coming soon (しゅん), of course. Soon, yes… Shorts are in season in this month. Shorts! Coming soon. Ah, I get it now. It’s that time of month, that month that’s soon arriving, and shorts are in season. Yes, it all comes together.
reading_hint: Imagine being out and about soon as you wear your in season shorts. Ah, what a great time of month this is. But soon it will be over. Too soon.

meaning_story: You press your ear to the cross on the chest of Sauron and to his heart you listen. Sauron has been having chest pains lately and he’s also found God, hence the cross. You press your ear to his chest to listen to his heart to see if he’s healthy.
meaning_hint: Listen to the heart of Sauron. Thump. Thump thump… thump. Thump!
reading_story: As you continue to listen, you feel like there’s something wrong. That doesn’t sound like a regular heartbeat at all. All at once you realize that he’s been cursed by the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! You can hear her cackling in the background. Darn you Mrs. Chou! What’d Sauron ever do to you?
reading_hint: Listen to the evil Mrs. Chou cackle away as she takes great pleasure in having cured the great Sauron. Sauron starts to cry and Mrs. Chou continues to laugh and laugh.

meaning_story: You give your servant a gun along with some other products to look to. You can’t look to them yourself since you are very busy. You allow your servant to look to your gun and the other products.
meaning_hint: Imagine your servant as he looks to your gun and products. You can always look to him to take care of your menial tasks. You feel smug.
reading_story: After your servant is done with your gun and other products you want him to look to your car’s o-ring (りん). There’s something wrong with the o-ring so you want your servant to look to that as well.
reading_hint: Imagine your servant as he looks to your car’s o-ring. Hear him clinking and clanking around in the garage as he does so.

meaning_story: The omen radical and the omen kanji are exactly the same! Ominous!
reading_story: Evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) is the bringer of every bad omen. If you see a bad omen, you know it’s the work of the Evil Mrs. Chou. No doubt.
reading_hint: Imagine seeing a bad omen. Any bad omen of your choosing. Now imagine the Evil Mrs. Chou cackling away in the background at the bad omen she has conjured. Muahahaha!

meaning_story: A master with a sword makes a big pledge to protect the entire city from harm. This sword master is a pretty big guy, but his pledge to protect the entire city might be too big even for him. It’s a mighty big pledge.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are this sword master making this big pledge. Say aloud, “I, the sword master, pledge to defend this big city!”
reading_story: To keep your pledge you must defend the big city against its worst enemy. The KKK (けい). The KKK try to invade the big city daily so it’s up to you to fend them off with your master sword skills.
reading_hint: Imagine fighting the KKK with your sword in order to keep your pledge. Imagine them rushing at you in their bright white robes. Can you defeat them all?

meaning_story: A lantern smashes into your ribs to punish your crime. It’s punishment for stealing the lantern. You stole the lantern so they take the lantern and smash it into your ribs to punish you for your crime.
meaning_hint: Feel your ribs crack and splinter as the lantern collides with your body. This punishment really hurts. How could they punish you like this? It’s so cruel!
reading_story: Who is it that wants to punish you? Why it’s the KKK (けい) of course. You stole a lantern from the KKK and now they’ve begun to punish you by smashing the KKK lantern into your ribs.
reading_hint: As the KKK members punish you for stealing the lantern, imagine them in their bright white robes and KKK hoods. And don’t forget about your broken ribs. Those still hurt a lot.

meaning_story: A greenhouse is the newest power of the city you decided to recruit. You’re trying to recruit all the buildings in town and the greenhouse was the next on your list. It adds just a little but of power to the town, but it's important nonetheless.
meaning_hint: Imagine what you had to do to recruit this greenhouse. Imagine schmoozing with the previous greenhouse owners to recruit them to your cause and sell you the greenhouse.
reading_story: After you recruit the greenhouse, you recruit Bobo (ぼ) the clown to guard it for you. Bobo the clown has a terrifying amount of power so he’ll make an excellent guard for the greenhouse.
reading_hint: Recruit Bobo the clown. Look at him. He’s terrifying. Bobo will make for a great deterrent for entry to your greenhouse.

meaning_story: The leader presents you with a prize as reparation for his past deeds. This leader wronged you in the past and wishes to make amends. Therefore the leader presents you with a reparation in the form of a glittering prize.
meaning_hint: Imagine receiving your reparation prize. Feel the prize in your hand. It’s all wrapped up but it’s heavy and feels expensive. What could it be?
reading_story: The leader who presented you with this reparation is the shogun (しょう) of Japan. The shogun unjustly wronged you terribly in the past, so that’s why he’s awarding you this prize. At least the shogun is making an effort to atone for his past ways.
reading_hint: Imagine receiving your reparation prize from the shogun himself. You feel angry at the shogun for what he did to you in the past but you feel excited about the reparation prize itself. Feel this internal conflict of emotions as you accept the prize.

meaning_story: Carrying a nailbat, you see a duck on the ground and must resist smashing it. You hate ducks and love smashing them with nailbats. However there are old people and small children around so you must resist smashing this duck into the ground with your nailbat.
meaning_hint: Must… resist… smashing… Imagine holding the nailbat. You really wanna smash that duck. Resist the temptation!
reading_story: Since you managed to resist smashing the duck, you decide to treat yourself with some tater (てい) tots. Tasting fresh tater tots is almost as satisfying as smashing a duck into the ground with a nailbat.
reading_hint: Taste the hot fluffy tater tots on your tongue as you pat yourself on the back for being able to resist the temptation of public animal slaughter. Good job.

meaning_story: This door is big and you need to return it to its rightful owner. This door is too big and important looking to not belong to someone. You need to find its owner and return it to them.
meaning_hint: Heft this big door in your arms. It’s very heavy. Feel your arms tire as you look for who to return the door to.
reading_story: You are in return mode (もど). When you enter this mode, you concentrate only on returning something. Nothing else matters in this mode. You’re in full on return mode.
reading_hint: You’re obsessed with returning this big door. Once you enter this mode, the only way to get out is to return the thing you have.

meaning_story: Both the sun and the Joker are shining. The sun is shining because it’s the sun and the sun is always shining. The Joker is shining because he has this big wicked grin on his face. The sun and the Joker are having a competition to see who is shining the brightest.
meaning_hint: Imagine both the sun and the Joker shining bright. What looks brighter in your mind? The shining glare of the sun or the shining grin of the Joker?
reading_story: The shogun (しょう) is the judge of this shining contest between the sun and the Joker. The shogun ends up giving the victory to the Joker because the Joker threatened to murder the shogun’s family if he wasn’t declared the winner.
reading_hint: Imagine you are the shogun. You’d probably award the shining trophy to the Joker too if he threatened your family. Imagine handing the shining trophy to the Joker as you think of your shogun family’s safety.

meaning_story: Next to a gate there is a bean trying to measure out the best way to struggle past the guards and gain access to the private community. The gate is the entrance to a gated community and the bean wants to get outside. However, there are guards and the bean would have to struggle past to get in.
meaning_hint: Pretend you are this bean. You want to get past that gate so bad. You go for it. Imagine the struggle you have with the guards. Struggle! Struggle harder!
reading_story: You continue to struggle because you need to get to the other side of the gate. On the other side lies the city of Tokyo (とう) and it’s been your dream since forever to visit Tokyo. This is what you struggle for: entrance to Tokyo!
reading_hint: Vividly imagine Tokyo in your mind. Think of the city, the lights, the people! Continue to struggle with the guards and don’t stop struggling until you break free and enter Tokyo.

meaning_story: Happiness is a circle and tenacious. Happiness is a circle because it’s meant to be shared, shared all around! Happiness is tenacious because happiness doesn’t like to let go. Happiness latches onto you and tenaciously holds on.
meaning_hint: Envision happiness as a circular thing that’s latched onto you. It’s super tenacious. Imagine happiness screaming at you, “WHY WON’T YOU ACCEPT ME?”
reading_story: This circular blob of happiness is so tenacious that it’s starting to get on your nerves. You were happy before but this particular bundle of literal happiness is more annoying than anything so you hire a shooter (しゅう) to snipe the happiness out of your life. Unfortunately the shooter misinterprets your instructions and just shoots you dead instead. Oh, and what was that little happiness ball of tenacious love? Your shitzu (しつ). Wait, you hired a shooter to shoot your shitzu? Wow. Cold.
reading_hint: Hear the crack of the sniper rifle as the shooter shoots you with his gun. BAM! Feel the shooter’s bullet hit you. The happiness is fading from your life. Your shitzu is licking that face. Good bye cruel, tenacious world.

meaning_story: Your foot is an off-red color and you see traces of ink on it. What happened? Why is your foot this reddish color? What do these traces of red ink mean? Where are you?
meaning_hint: As you look at your foot and examine the traces of off-red ink, try and think of what could have happened to cause this strange occurrence. Also remember that the red is an off-red color because the red radical in this kanji is slightly altered.
reading_story: Turns out the traces of red ink were from a foot fetishist who thinks that red feet are sexy (せき). You were drugged at the bar and taken back to the fetishist’s lair where he dyed your foot red. That’s creepy. Why would anyone think that red feet were sexy?
reading_hint: You certainly don’t feel sexy. You feel violated. Try not to think about what the fetishist might have done to your sexy feet as you try and think how to get out of here.

meaning_story: A triceratops attacks the moon with his own ribs in an attempt to whittle down the moon. The triceratops is not the smartest dinosaur so that is why it tore out its own ribs to attack the moon. It uses its ribs to whittle down the moon, both physically and emotionally.
meaning_hint: Hear the scraping sound as the triceratops continues to whittle down the moon with its ribs. Scrape, scrape, scrape.
reading_story: The triceratops continues to whittle down the moon with his ribs until there is almost no moon left. A sack (さく) of coins falls out from the moon. Did you know that if you whittle down the moon enough you’ll receive a sack of coins? Apparently this triceratops knew.
reading_hint: Hear the clink of the sack as it falls out of the moon. Imagine hefting the moon sack in your hand as you look at the whittled remains of the moon.

meaning_story: A leader asks half of his men to accompany him on a secret mission. The leader’s mission is volunteer only, so it’s impressive that he got half of his men to accompany him.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are one of the leader’s men who volunteered. What made you want to accompany him? Imagine the good qualities of this leader and how he inspired you to accompany him on this mission.
reading_story: The leader you decided to accompany is none other than Han (はん) Solo. Who could be more inspiring? I’m surprised not more than half decided to accompany him. Han Solo is awesome.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself as you accompany Han Solo. You try to stay calm, but you’re just so excited to be around Han Solo.

meaning_story: You have to stop the tooth that orders you to age. The tooth that wants you to age is your wisdom tooth. Everyone knows that with age comes wisdom, but you don’t want to age so you stop your tooth from aging you by removing it.
meaning_hint: Imagine having your tooth removed. No anesthetic. This is incredibly painful at any age.
reading_story: As soon as the tooth is removed, you cease to age. Your age has stopped. A ray (れい) of sunlight shines on you and an orchestra sounds and it’s all dramatic and stuff. The ray of light shining on you adds to the dramatics as well.
reading_hint: Imagine being forever the age that you are now as you feel the ray of light envelop you. It’s very bright and very warm, but it feels pretty good.

meaning_story: You wear a helmet on top of your top hat if you want to give someone your best regards before you go off to war. You can't just wear one or the other. The top hat makes it polite, but the helmet helps people know that you're leaving. You need both for them to understand that you're offering your absolute best regards.
meaning_hint: Imagine giving someone your best regards while wearing a helmet and a top hat. Try to say it fast because wearing them both is a bit hard.
reading_story: Do you know the saying YOLO (よろ)? It means You Only Live Once. This is why you're giving your best regards now. You don't know what's going to happen to you in the war, and you only live once, right? So you say, "YOLO! Best regards!"
reading_hint: Imagine thinking about the phrase YOLO and how it totally fits into why you're giving your best regards before going off to the war.

meaning_story: You take a clam and kiss it on a bribe. Someone gave you a bribe of $1,000 to kiss this clam. Who wouldn’t take that bribe?
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself kissing a clam. Feel its cold shell on your lips as you smell the salty ocean. It’s all worth it though, so just keep your eyes on that $1,000 prize.
reading_story: After you kiss the clam, you take your bribe money and run off down the road (ろ) to the nearest shopping center. Fortunately there is one just down the road, so you’ll get there in no time.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself running down the road, feet slapping on the pavement. Hold your bribe money tightly in your fists as you dash down the road.

meaning_story: A clam shouldn’t have bribe money, but he does. That clam is bad news. He shouldn’t have all that bribe money because such activities are frowned upon in clam society, but this clam is just rolling in bribe money.
meaning_hint: See this clam literally rolling in bribe money. Hear the clam shell shattering as you see him diving into the money screaming, “LOOK AT ALL THE MONEY I HAVE!”
reading_story: Do you know what happens when somebody doesn’t pay the clam his bribe money? The clam shoots off their kneecaps. They always scream, “Why?? (わい) WHYYYYYY!?! WHY WHY WHY!!?!?” But it matters not. This clam has no room in his heart for pity.
reading_hint: Listen to these clams screaming “WHY?!” as they get their kneecaps blown off. Wait, do clams even have kneecaps?

meaning_story: The door in that direction is among a cluster of doors. You run in the direction of the cluster and one door stands out to you. You enter it.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing all these doors, this cluster of doors. You feel confused at which one to enter but finally pick one. Hear the door creak as you open it.
reading_story: After you make it through the door, you come across another cluster of doors. Which one to choose? You see a bow (ぼう) and arrow etched over one of the doors. You enter that door. Another cluster appears. You see another door with a bow and arrow over it. You repeat the process until you finally escape the cluster of doors maze.
reading_hint: Good thing you noticed that bow and arrow clue. Imagine going through each cluster of doors looking for that bow and arrow symbol to guide you outside.

kunyomi: おもんぱく, おもんぱか
meaning_story: A tiger needs to think and consider its actions before it attacks. Tigers are smart hunters, so they need to consider all options and really think through a situation.
meaning_hint: Look at this tiger as it approaches you. Think what things it has to consider. It has to consider how big of a threat you are and so on. You need to consider how you’re going to escape from this tiger.
reading_story: It's considering you for so long that it takes out a robe (りょ), a pipe, and an armchair and starts puffing away, staring intently at you. You didn't even know tigers could wear robes, but this one seems to use it to help itself think.
reading_hint: Consider this! Tigers look great in robes.

meaning_story: They say if you put things on a slide, seven things to be exact, that’s the best way to consign good to someone. They say if you consign seven things to someone, you should send them over on a slide. Slide ‘em on down. All seven of ‘em.
meaning_hint: Imagine what seven things you consign over to this other person for safekeeping. Visualize them in your head as you slide each one down the slide.
reading_story: One of the seven things you consign over to this guy is a tack (たく). It’s the sharpest tack you’ve ever seen. You slide the tack down the slide. Good thing no one is on the slide now, sitting on that tack would hurt.
reading_hint: Let’s imagine what it would be like to hit this tack while sliding on the slide. It would hurt. Good thing you are consigning it over to someone. Probably safer for everyone that way.

meaning_story: In a cemetery you stick a stamp, something very contrary to your relative, on their grave. Your relative hated stamps and didn’t want anything to do with them. That’s why you sticking a stamp on their headstone in the cemetery is very contrary to their beliefs.
meaning_hint: Imagine what could have happened to your relative to make them have such an aversion to stamps. Some sort of accident? Stamp abuse? Something contrary to popular belief?
reading_story: As you think about what caused their aversion to stamps, contrary to popular belief or not, you snack on some Kia cookies (きゃく). What, did you forget about Kia Cookies? Yes, they’re a real thing.
reading_hint: Munch on your Kia Cookies as you dwell on everything contrary. They taste like Korea and Starcraft.

meaning_story: In the rain I take my rake and shake it, making a demand that the rain stop! I demand this rain stop right now! Don’t make me shake my rake more violently than I am currently shaking it!
meaning_hint: Go out into the rain and shake your rake. Imagine shouting your demand at the sky as the rain pelts you from above.
reading_story: Now imagine the rain changing. Wait a second, this isn't rain, it's juice (じゅ)! You shake your rake harder, and demand that the juice rain continues. It doesn't listen to your demands and stops as soon as you start bottling it. Well, at least you have enough for one, really small juice box.
reading_hint: Picture yourself demanding more rain from the sky, trying to fill up your tiny juice box with what little juice rain you were able to get.

meaning_story: Building a boob grave in winter is an easy thing to do. It’s so easy to do that boob graves are the only kind of graves that people make in winter. The boob grave is very soft and pliable and easy to work with, even in the winter.
meaning_hint: Imagine what you do as you do what you do. Take the boob grave in your hands and feel its likeness to an actual boob. As you do this, also feel the chill of winter around you.
reading_story: While you do the boob grave stuff, you get hungry. You decide to do some cheese (ち). Cheese is a good thing to do. Eat some cheese.
reading_hint: Eating cheese is the next thing you do after setting up the boob grave. Taste the cheese in your mouth as you gaze upon the boob grave and continue to feel the brisk winter breeze blowing over you.

meaning_story: You’re going down a water slide when some propaganda comes flying at you but you dodge out of the way at the last second. You don’t like getting misled by propaganda, so it’s a good thing you managed to dodge it. The water slide will now carry you further away from the propaganda and off to safety.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself careening down the wet water slide, wind in your hair. See the propaganda coming at you. Visualize it as a big flaming poster, TV, magazine, whatever. Now dodge! Jerk your body out of the way violently! Do it! Hear the flaming propaganda whoosh by you.
reading_story: As the flaming ball of propaganda zips past you, you can feel the heat (ひ) coming off it. Man, it would suck to get hit with a big ball of propaganda heat like that. Good thing you managed to dodge it.
reading_hint: Feel the heat of the propaganda move past your head as you dodge. The heat is very strong. It even singed some of your hair. Smell the smell of burnt hair as you continue to zip down the water slide.

meaning_story: You see a nailbat and some flowers in a rice paddy so you draw a picture of it. The scene is just too beautiful not to draw. You draw the rice paddy first, then the flowers, and lastly the nailbat.
meaning_hint: Imagine this scene as you draw it. Feel your feet in the damp rice paddy, smell the flowers, swing the nailbat. Really experience the scene as you draw it.
reading_story: You continue to draw throughout the day in the hot and muggy weather. You draw for so long that you begin to sweat and get really bad B.O. (びょう). Did you forget to put on deodorant today? Your B.O. is terrible!
reading_hint: Try and continue to draw as your B.O. attacks your nose. Your B.O. is really bad. You try not to black out from the stench as you draw some more.

meaning_story: There are antenna attached to your ribs because they are the latest edition. These new edition ribs of yours have an antenna attached to them because they are electronic. They get a signal from space and your new edition can play music, get weather reports, and so much more!
meaning_hint: Imagine having antenna sticking out of your ribs. At first it’s uncomfortable but soon you realize how useful these new edition ribs are. Super useful.
reading_story: To make the most of these latest edition ribs of yours, you hold a can (かん) up to your ribs. The can amplifies the sound coming from them and makes it easier to hear. It can be any old can too. Soda can, coffee can, you name it.
reading_hint: Imagine holding a can up to your ribs and hearing the sound louder and clearer. Now remove the can. Put it back. Remove it. Keep doing this over and over until you get bored.

meaning_story: Seeing a water slide is a bad omen so you should escape this situation. Every time you see a water slide, something bad happens, so water slides have become sort of a bad omen for you. Upon seeing a water slide, you need to escape or else something bad will happen to you.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the water slide omen and being filled with fear and anxiety of what might happen to you. You need to escape. Run! Run away from the water slide!
reading_story: The water slide you are trying to escape from is in Tokyo (とう). You’re new here, so you’re not too familiar with the Tokyo streets. Your escape is hindered by your lack of navigational ability. To make matters worse, the water slide has become sentient and is chasing after you, knocking down buildings as it chases you.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to escape the water slide through the streets of Tokyo. Hear the water slide smashing buildings behind you, much like Godzilla. You need to escape faster!

meaning_story: You use a nailbat on the escalator to handle any obstacles. People, pets, luggage, all of that is easy to handle when you’ve a nailbat.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself riding up the escalator with a nailbat in your hand. Imagine smacking every obstacle out of the way as you ride, hearing the screams from those around you as you handle them.
reading_story: All this nailbat swinging is hard to handle and you start to work up a real sweat. Someone comes up to you and asks “暑か?” (あつか). He wants to know if you’re hot. You don’t like being asked questions so you get all up in his face and start shouting, “暑か?!? 暑か?!?! 暑か?!?!?!?!?!?”
reading_hint: This really freaks the guy out. Looks like you handled that situation well. Just imagine yourself shouting “暑か!?” like a maniac as the guy runs away from you.

radicals: 大, 丶, 冂, 米
meaning_story: If there’s a drop on your head and the rice is big, you know you’re in the interior. And by interior, I mean you’re actually inside someone. The rice is big because you’ve shrunk to a tiny size and are inside someone’s stomach. The drop on your head is actually digestive fluid.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in the interior of someone’s tummy. See the big pieces of rice all around you as drops of stomach fluid continue to drop down on your head.
reading_story: While you’re in the interior of this guy, you hear him break out in song. He starts singing “Oklahoma” (おく) at the top of his lungs. The big pieces of rice slosh around as he sings and dances. “OOOOk-lahoma, where the wind comes sweepin' down the plain!”
reading_hint: If you’re unfamiliar with this Oklahoma song, check it out on YouTube. Imagine being in the interior of someone’s belly as you hear this song booming all around you.

meaning_story: A leader with horns takes a lantern and searches for people to join him. He needs more people to join his cause so he can get his horns removed. He’s embarrassed of them which is why he only travels at night, hence the lantern.
meaning_hint: Imagine this shady leader approaching you in the night. The lantern light shines in your face. Would you join him?
reading_story: The leader guy approaches you out of the darkness, his lantern held high. Oh no, not that guy. You've heard about his horn problem and you don't want to join him. You look around and spot a large haystack (へい). You quickly jump into it and hide from him.
reading_hint: The last thing you wanted to do was join that guy so you hid in a haystack to avoid him.

meaning_story: You change the geoduck because it wants to lean to the left. You want a geoduck that is straight, not one with a propensity to lean one way or the other. If this geoduck continues to lean this way, you’re going to have to change it!
meaning_hint: Look at this geoduck lean. You try to change it by grabbing the geoduck to straighten it out. Feel the gooey creature in your hands as you attempt to get the lean out of its body.
reading_story: You got this geoduck that refuses to do anything but lean from the KKK (けい). Apparently the KKK has a surplus of geoducks that love to lean. You take the geoduck back to the KKK member who sold it to you and you hurl the geoduck in his face.
reading_hint: Hear the smack as the geoduck contacts with the KKK member’s face. SMACK! If he doesn’t want this to happen again, he’ll sell you a geoduck without any lean to it.

meaning_story: The thread on this football is loose. We need to tighten up the loose thread on this football or it’s gonna fall apart while we’re playing.
meaning_hint: Look at this football. The thread is loose on the football and needs to be tightened. Attempt to tighten the loose thread on the football as you hold it in your hands.
reading_story: You finally tighten the loose thread and all of your friends cheer, “You rule!” (ゆる) You rule because you fixed the loose thread on the football and now you can play again. Yeah! You rule, man!
reading_hint: Listen to your friends shouting “You rule!” and hear their cheers echo in your ears as you toss the football around again.

meaning_story: On the train to heaven they play music. Everyone knows that the only way to get to heaven is by train, but not everyone knows that they play music. What song? Stairway to Heaven of course.
meaning_hint: Imagine being on this train to heaven as it plays music. Listen to Stairway to Heaven as you imagine yourself riding on the train. Choo choo!
reading_story: As they play music on the train to heaven, you decide to sew (そう) to pass the time. Sew some clothing and patch any holes you find. Sewing is a great way to pass the time.
reading_hint: Continue to listen to them play music as you concentrate on your sewing. Why anything needs to have someone sew it while you’re in heaven is beyond you, but just imagine doing it.

meaning_story: A woman sleeps with the king and becomes pregnant. Only the king wasn’t human and now the woman is pregnant with a hybrid alien baby!
meaning_hint: The king radical is slightly altered in this kanji, so just remember that the king is a strange alien and not human. Imagine being this woman and having this half-breed alien baby inside you. Feels weird.
reading_story: Being pregnant with this strange creature, you need to do something to calm you down. You should play Nintendo (にん). Nintendo really calms your nerves and makes being pregnant with some mutant baby not seem like that big of a deal anymore.
reading_hint: What game are you playing on the Nintendo? Maybe it’s a game where you kill alien invaders? That’s messed up.

meaning_story: Wonder Woman sleeps with Superman and becomes pregnant with his baby. Superman and Wonder Woman are very much in love and are happy to be pregnant.
meaning_hint: Imagine Wonder Woman and Superman together in a photo. Wonder Woman is all big and pregnant and Superman is just there looking super.
reading_story: Superman tells Wonder Woman that she looks fat when she’s pregnant so Wonder Woman kicks Superman in the shin (しん). This really hurts Superman’s shin and he goes hopping around the room holding his injured shin.
reading_hint: Imagine you are Superman and you get kicked in the shin by a pregnant Wonder Woman. Wonder Woman is strong so the kick to your shin really hurts. Imagine rubbing it as the pain slowly subsides.

meaning_story: A clam wears a mask to give you presents. The clam is a secret Santa so it wears a mask, that way you don’t know who gave you these presents.
meaning_hint: Look at this clam in a mask with a bunch of presents to give you. You don’t understand why this clam is acting as it is, but who cares? Presents!
reading_story: To get this mask, the clam had to go to the Mask Zone (ぞう), a store that sells only masks. Clam sized masks aren’t readily available, so before the clam distributed the presents, he had to go to the Mask Zone.
reading_hint: When the clam went to the Mask Zone to get masks for presents, he also got one for you. This mask is one of your presents. You enjoy it very much because you like masks from the Mask Zone.

meaning_story: You point your nailbat at a shrimp to select it. The waiter asked you which shrimp you wanted so you used your nailbat to point at your favorite shrimp.
meaning_hint: Imagine waving your nailbat around in a restaurant to select the shrimp you want. Feel its weight in your hand as you point and shout out which shrimp you select.
reading_story: After you select your shrimp, the chef skewers it with a long tack (たく). He jabs the tack into the shrimp while it’s still alive so the shrimp screams out in pain as the tack pierces his body.
reading_hint: Imagine this shrimp shrieking in pain and terror as the tack goes through his body. This is the shrimp you selected to die. You did this.

meaning_story: After going down a water slide, Sauron pulls from the ground a zombie and then decides to send back the creature. Sauron went down the water slide for fun, and when he got to the ground he thought it would be fun to summon a zombie. After he summons the zombie, he decides he doesn’t like it, so he decides to send back the zombie into the ground.
meaning_hint: Imagine how Sauron sends back the zombie. Imagine Sauron stomping on the zombie’s head as it tries to crawl out of the ground. Stomp stomp!
reading_story: In an effort to send back the zombie, Sauron continues to stomp on its head. When this doesn’t work, Sauron finds a can (かん) and throws that at the zombie too. And another can, and another. Can after can rain down on this zombie in an attempt to send back the abomination.
reading_hint: Now imagine Sauron throwing a can at the zombie trying to crawl out the ground. Will he be able to send back the zombie? Maybe. But for now just hear the sound of each can ricocheting off the zombie’s skull. Thunk!

meaning_story: You use some thread to tie some products to a tree and then spin them around, winding them up along the trunk. This is your favorite way to spin thread. It’s not the most efficient, but it’s definitely the most exciting.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking some thread and tying it to an object. Now spin the tree around like you’re spinning a wheel on some game show. Zoooooom! Around and around it spins, winding up all the thread!
reading_story: One of the products you attached the thread to was a cookie (く). As you see the cookie spin around the tree, you start to want to eat it. In the middle of the spinning, you stop the tree and detach the cookie.
reading_hint: Eat the cookie. Mmm, cookie. It’s so good. Taste its crumbly goodness in your mouth. You don’t regret stopping the thread spinning process at all. So worth it.

meaning_story: You use a nailbat to hit a cat pirate and suppress him. The cat pirate was attacking you so you used the nailbat to suppress him.
meaning_hint: You need to suppress this cat pirate. Imagine him hissing at you as you smack him around with your nailbat.
reading_story: The reason you need to suppress this cat pirate is because he’s trying to steal your egg yolk (よく). You’re making breakfast with every egg yolk in the house and the cat pirate is trying to suppress you so it can take the egg yolks for itself.
reading_hint: Defend the egg yolk! Smell the smell of eggs in the air as you continue to suppress the cat pirate with blows from your nailbat.

meaning_story: In a prefecture with a long lineage, they take your heart and suspend it over the gates. This is the tradition of the prefecture. Your ancestor started this prefecture and the tradition of his lineage is as follows. When one of them dies, their heart is taken and preserved to suspend over the entry gates to remind everyone of the lineage surrounding the prefecture.
meaning_hint: Take a look as they suspend your heart over the entrance to the prefecture. You are seeing this because you are dead. You feel sad that you are dead but also glad that they are honoring you in such a way by suspending your heart for all to see.
reading_story: Your prefecture is being invaded by the characters from Street Fighter. Ken (けん) thinks it’s dumb that they decided to suspend your heart over the entrance to the prefecture so he shoots a hadoken at it. Ken knocks your suspended heart out of the air and it splats onto the ground below.
reading_hint: Dangit Ken, that was my heart! Why’d you have to go and hadoken it like that? Imagine Ken shouting “HADOKEN” at your suspended heart. Splat! Also keep in mind that the reading is the same as 県 which is a radical.

kunyomi: とな, たた, ほめ
meaning_story: You take a pine and fashion it into a gun that is small, earning the title of Small Wooden Arms Dealer, or SWAD. You’ve earned the title SWAD for this small pine gun you’ve crafted.
meaning_hint: What is your name? Is it Peter? Well now that you’ve earned the title SWAD, your name is SWAD Peter! Or whatever your name is. Just imagine your new title as you run about holding your small pine gun. Pew pew!
reading_story: There is only one person cool enough to bestow such an awesome title upon you, and that is the shogun (しょう). The shogun has deemed you worthy of the SWAD title. Congratulations.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in front of the shogun, your small pine gun held out in front of you in display. Now the shogun bellows out his approval and bestows upon you the title of SWAD. Hear everyone in the audience erupt in celebratory applause.

meaning_story: You thread someone together with thread. Someone is falling apart so you use thread to put them back together.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking some thread and putting someone back together with it. It’s awfully messy. I hope you’re good with blood.
reading_story: You’re threading this someone back together as part of a show (しょ). The show is a demonstration to show med students how to thread someone’s skin together after they have an accident. You’re the most experienced, so you’re leading the show.
reading_hint: Imagine threading someone back together again, but this time you have an audience. Hear them “ooh” and “aah” as you put on a riveting show.

meaning_story: You sail to IKEA with a plate on your tray. The plate on your tray is empty, so you rail each sail on your boat and sail to IKEA for their food.
meaning_hint: Yes, IKEA sells food. Imagine putting the food on your play on top of your tray and carrying your heavy tray back to the ship. Careful not to spill!
reading_story: When you get the tray back to your ship, the sun is shining pretty bright so you put on your Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. Ray-Ban sunglasses are the best defense against things that are too bright. Your Ray-Bans allow you to carry your tray around the ship with safety.
reading_hint: You sit down to eat the food from your tray. See all the food through your tinted Ray-Ban sunglasses. You look pretty cool. Look at your reflection in the metal tray as you eat.

meaning_story: The great nailbat in the sky must abstain from hitting people unless they really deserve it. Sometimes it’s hard for this nailbat to abstain from hitting people because people are real idiots sometimes, but the great nailbat in the sky must abstain from striking people unless they really deserve it.
meaning_hint: Look at this nailbat in the sky. Imagine the restraint it must employ to avoid bopping all the idiots in the world. Imagine the person you’d most want to hit with a nailbat and think how hard it would be to abstain from hitting them.
reading_story: One group of people you definitely do not abstain from hitting with your nailbat is the people who exploit the hicatee ひか. The hicatee is a Central American river turtle hunted for its mean, eggs, and shell. Therefore, the poor hicatee is endangered. This great nailbait in the sky shall not abstain from ridding the world of these evil hicatee poachers.
reading_hint: Imagine someone about to cut open a hicatee turtle when the nailbait in the sky crashes down and kills them. Hear the nailbat whoosh through the air and then squish into the poacher. You’re free, Mr. Hikatee! Safe and free!

meaning_story: You have a dilapidated outhouse you need to allocate some glue on to get it all patched up. This outhouse is in bad shape and you only have so much glue left so you need to allocate it carefully.
meaning_hint: Imagine being inside this hot and stinky outhouse as you allocate the glue in the spots that need the most repairs. Feel your fingers get sticky with glue as the smell invades your nostrils.
reading_story: You don’t want to allocate the glue for these repairs alone so you get your Jewish (じゅう) friend to help you out. Your Jewish friend is a really great guy and isn’t so wimpy when it comes to bad smells so he has no trouble helping you out.
reading_hint: Your Jewish friend is pretty great. He also has really good ideas about how to properly allocate the glue to get the best repair on your outhouse. What a good pal he is.

meaning_story: A tsunami can’t stop the explosion from tasting bitter. The explosion happens, and you get some bitter explosion dust and debris in your mouth. You want to stop this bitter flavor and get rid of it so you rinse your mouth out with a tsunami but even that is not enough to stop the bitter taste.
meaning_hint: Imagine how bitter this taste must be that a tsunami isn’t enough to wash it away. That’s really bitter.
reading_story: It looks like this bitter taste is permanently in your mouth now which is too bad because you’re eating at your Jewish (じゅう) friend’s house tonight and you just love Jewish cuisine. You love Jewish bagels, Jewish brisket, blintz, gefilte fish, schnitzel, and macaroons. All your Jewish favorites will never be the same now that your mouth is forever bitter.
reading_hint: Imagine eating all of these Jewish foods but imagine them all being really bitter and totally unpalatable. It’s really sad. All these Jewish foods used to be your favorite but now you can hardly stand them.

meaning_story: A mountain frog decides to branch off. The mountain frog used to be a tree frog climbing trees, but then he decided to branch off and climb mountains.
meaning_hint: Imagine this frog in the act of branching off. Imagine him soaring through the air, flying from a tree to a mountain. Whee!~
reading_story: The reason the frog decided to branch off from the tree and climb the mountain is because he found a key (き) to a mountain treasure chest. The frog wants to use this key to open the chest and become rich beyond imagination.
reading_hint: Look at the little frog on the mountain in front of a treasure chest with a key. Hear the click of the key in the lock as the chest opens and the frog’s face lights up with joy upon seeing all the riches contained in the chest.

meaning_story: You go to a grave with a sunflower and you bury it. The person whose grave you are visiting loved sunflowers, so you bury it next to his grave in memorandum.
meaning_hint: Imagine going to this grave and burying this sunflower. Smell the sunflower smell as you dug up the cold wet earth with your hands.
reading_story: Before you can bury the sunflower, you prick your hand on something in the midst of digging. It’s an uni う! Who would bury an uni next to your friend’s grave? Someone fiendish, no doubt.
reading_hint: Your uni injury really smarts. Feel it painfully pulsate as you think about how maybe next time you decide to bury something you’ll use a tool.

meaning_story: You take gold in exchange for executing orders to construct a buzzer. You are a buzzer maker and someone orders you to make one in exchange for some gold. This is how you make a living.
meaning_hint: Imagine the gold, heavy in your pockets, as you construct this buzzer with your bare hands. Feel the cool metal clink around in your hands as you put the buzzer together.
reading_story: Finally the buzzer is done. You’ve earned your gold. You test the buzzer and it goes ring りん! Ring! Ring! Ring! Ring ring ring ring ring! Man, that ringing is annoying but hey, that’s what buzzers do.
reading_hint: Wait, should this buzzer be buzzing or ringing? Oh well, you got your gold. It’s the client’s problem now.

meaning_story: 'This grave is so odd!' you think. The thing that makes it so odd, more than anything, is that it's placed out on a cape (you know, the kinds that jut out into the sea). It's also HUGE. There's no other graves out here, and you'd think family members would be worried about some wash out.
meaning_hint: Walk along the cape - the grave stands out and looks odd to you.
reading_story: You walk up to the huge grave to read it. Turns out, a cyclops (さい) was buried here. That explains the location and size. Cyclops always bury their dead on capes. Also, they are big.
reading_hint: The other odd thing about this situation is that the cyclops is still alive. It bursts forth from the grave, destroying the ground around it. Water flows in, and the cyclops comes after you.
