meaning_hint: Picture yourself hoisting this nailbat against the pull of gravity. You’re pretty strong, so this is an easy task. You are really good at hoisting things.
reading_story: After you hoist up the nailbat against gravity, you hoist up a cup of yogurt (よう) as well. Hoisting the nailbat made you hungry, so you hoist up some yogurt to eat afterwards.
reading_hint: Hoist up this yogurt and imagine yourself eating it. Such a sweet reward after all that nailbat hoisting you did today. Good job.

meaning_story: You hit a tsunami with a grenade. Boom! A piece of tsunami flies off the main body and lands somewhere inland, creating a wing of the tsunami. This tsunami wing turns into a lagoon, where it exists even today.
meaning_hint: Kind of like a 'hospital wing' this 'tsunami wing' is just part of the main tsunami, though now it's classified as a lagoon.
reading_story: This 'tsunami wing' thing was so successful (with the lagoon and all) that you decide to make more tsunami sections. You take out your cutter (かた) and begin cutting off pieces of the tsunami more carefully this time. You create lakes, ponds, rivers, and more, all with a box cutter.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself cutting out pieces of a frozen tsunami. You're very careful how you cut things out, too. You want perfect shapes, unlike that lagoon you blasted out with a grenade.

meaning_story: There are flowers and hills in your front lawn. Your lawn is pretty big and it is covered with both flowers and hills. It’s very pretty.
meaning_hint: Imagine walking through your lawn and smelling all the flowers as you travel over the rolling hills. What a delightful lawn this is.
reading_story: You are the proud owner of a Shiba (しば) Inu, y’know, the Japanese dog? Well, this Shiba Inu of yours loves to run around in your lawn and through the flowers and over the hills. This is the perfect lawn for your Shiba.
reading_hint: Look at your little Shiba running through the lawn all happy and elated. Hear him barking as he zooms up and down each hill.

meaning_story: The moon has an antenna on it that sends a signal directly to your liver to tell you whether or not your liver is doing okay.
meaning_hint: Go ahead and have a drink. Your liver has to process that. When you drink, the moon antenna signal sends you an alert. When you don't, it is all fine and dandy.
reading_story: Now, when you drink a whole can (かん) of beer, then the signal goes off the charts. You're drinking too much. Your liver can't handle it! No more cans of beer, please.
reading_hint: Drink multiple cans and watch the signal go crazy. Doctors are rushed to your location. Your liver is weak, it can't handle this!

meaning_story: You have a cross in your mouth, and also in your mouth you have some clothes to muffle the sounds of your mourning. You’re mourning your Christian grandmother’s death. That’s why you have a cross. The reason you have all these things in your mouth is because you had been mourning so loudly and for so long, your family was getting annoyed. These things are in your mouth to keep your mourning noises to a minimum.
meaning_hint: Imagine having a cross in your mouth and also some clothes. Taste the wood of the cross and the cloth of the clothes as you feel a strong sense of mourning for having lost your grandma.
reading_story: To help yourself through the mourning process you sew (そう) a little doll that looks like your granny. You sew pretty often, so making a little granny is no problem for you. You sew one up in no time.
reading_hint: Imagine this little stuffed granny that you sew. It looks just like granny, only in plushie form. This brings a smile to your face and you are more confident about making it through the mourning process.

meaning_story: You have a thread hill, but the hill is a bit weird looking (take a look at the hill radical in this kanji). It's not any normal hill, it's a weird lumpy hill that isn't quite right. That's because it is a thread hill of netting, and parts of the nets have caught things, like fish and cats, so there's weird abnormal lumps in them.
meaning_hint: You'll need to differentiate this from 綱, which uses the same radicals (though 綱 has a real hill radical). Just remember that the weird 'hill' has stuff caught in it because it is netting.
reading_story: There's so much netting that it's out of control. You decide to take your lawn mower to mow (もう) it all down.
reading_hint: When you do this, it destroys your lawn mower, because who thought it was a good idea to use a lawn mower on netting? Your dumb idea. C'mon!

meaning_story: Even though you’ve old legs, you overcome your disability. These old legs of yours don’t work very well, but you overcome the odds and you run a marathon!
meaning_hint: Imagine running a marathon with your old legs to prove you can overcome anything. Feel your old legs cramping up as you try to overcome the marathon and finish the race.
reading_story: When you pass the finish line and finally overcome the limits of your old legs, someone hands you an ice cold Coke (こく) as a reward. Mmm, such a refreshing Coke.
reading_hint: Filled with the jubilation of achievement from overcoming all odds, imagine the flavor of this cold Coke in your mouth. Fizzy and Coke flavored, it runs down your throat and into your tummy. Yum.

meaning_story: The tsunami that is white is the most scary tsunami of all. It doesn't come in and destroy everything. No, it comes in, goes inside your door, then stays at your place overnight, without even asking!
meaning_hint: Imagine the white tsunami knocking on your door, walking into your house, and then just laying down on your bed. You try to tell it to leave, but it's a tsunami, and it says it will be staying overnight thank you very much.
reading_story: Your cat walks up to the white tsunami that's staying overnight and decides it doesn't like it, so it hacks (はく) up a hairball on it. Even that doesn't get the tsunami to leave.
reading_hint: See the hairball slowly sinking into the tsunami. The cat hacks up another one.

meaning_story: If you have one stool and another stool, you have a pair of stools. Look at this pair of stools. Look at it.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in front of this pair of stools. Picture yourself sitting on one stool, getting up, then sitting on the other. Repeat this process forever and ever.
reading_story: To make sure you don’t lose one or the other, you sew (そう) the pair of stools together. After you sew them together, you’ll never lose one.
reading_hint: Imagine sewing this pair of stools together with needle and thread. It’s not easy to sew wood together, so concentrate on how difficult a task this is.

meaning_story: You walk up to a tree and put dynamite on it. Then you set it off. BOOM. It explodes, but doesn't do what you'd expect. Instead of blowing the tree up, it blasts a very beautiful pattern into the side of it as well as the ground around it.
meaning_hint: Think about what pattern it might be. Is it a checkered pattern? Something more complicated and beautiful? Whatever it is, think of something that really impresses you.
reading_story: The pattern is so beautiful that you want to put it on your garage (がら). So, you do.
reading_hint: Imagine painting your garage with the pattern you imagined earlier.

meaning_story: You get hit with a nailbat and an axe in the mouth for expressing your philosophy. Your philosophy conflicts directly with everyone else’s philosophies so you get hit in the mouth with an axe and a nailbat.
meaning_hint: Imagine expressing your philosophy. Your deepest thoughts and feelings. And then you get hit in the mouth with an axe and a nailbat. Oh man, that hurts really bad. Blood’s everywhere.
reading_story: The person leading the charge for beating you up for your thoughts and philosophy is Tetsuo (てつ) the Iron Man. You know, from the movie. Tetsuo is hitting you with a nailbat and an axe, holding one in each hand.
reading_hint: You know what Tetsuo looks like, so imagine him going to town on your face with these weapons. Your mouth is taking a lot of punishment. It hurts very badly. You should have kept your philosophy to yourself.

meaning_story: You have a pair of stilts that are missing the middle part that normally makes them steady. Instead, there is a jackhammer in between your stilts, making you jump up and down. This is all part of the purification ritual you have to perform, though by 'purification' they mean destroying everything below your stilts and you try not to fall.
meaning_hint: Think about how weird of a purification ritual this is. You're destroying stuff, which I guess is kind of like purification if you're a crazy bad guy on an 80s movie, but other than that, it's pretty odd.
reading_story: After you finish the purification ritual, they say you didn't do it well enough so you have to do it again. All you can do is sigh (さい).
reading_hint: Go ahead and sigh right where you are while thinking about having to do that purification ritual again. *sigh*

meaning_story: You keep your substitute clothes in a sack. The clothes in the sack are just substitute clothes, so they only come out in emergencies.
meaning_hint: Look at this sack of substitute clothes. Imagine it filled with all the clothes you hardly ever wear. What kind of clothes would be inside this sack?
reading_story: You need your substitute clothes so you take our your substitute clothes sack. You open it up to grab your substitute clothes, only to find out that there is a ton of salmon roe inside your sack. Oh man, you forgot all about putting that in there. You yell: F**K ROE (ふくろ) because that roe destroyed all your clothes and made it nasty.
reading_hint: Imagine how nasty it is in there. Also imagine how smelly it is. Feel angry about putting roe in your sack. Why would you even do that? Why would the roe do this to you, as well.

meaning_story: If you hit a satellite with a nailbat it will shake! It won't break or anything, they're pretty well put together, but it will definitely shake violently.
meaning_hint: Imagine hitting a satellite with a nailbat and watching it shake around in space.
reading_story: You want it to shake because there is a bunch of yogurt (よう) in there. And you only like yogurt that's been well shook. And who can resist space yogurt? Huh? Anyone?
reading_hint: Imagine shaking yogurt. Shake it!

meaning_story: A tsunami breaks your bone, but not from hitting you head on. No, you're walking around where the tsunami had originally hit, then you stepped on some slippery water, which caused you to fall and break said bone.
meaning_hint: Somehow you managed to not get hurt when the tsunami hit you head on, but after when you were walking around. What a dope.
reading_story: You not only broke your bone when you fell on the slippery ground, you also got a bunch of cuts (かつ) from where you landed on some glass, so that's something else to worry about.
reading_hint: Just imagine the whole process. You fall from something slippery. Then you break your bone (feel that pain). Then you notice all the glass cuts in your arm (feel the pain). What a bad day, though to be fair, you did survive getting hit by a tsunami.

meaning_story: A servant combines one stool with the dirt from a grave to make a very solid seating device. This solid seat made from a stool and the dark power of a grave is capable of holding even the heaviest of things.
meaning_hint: This solid stool has been made by combining a stool with the dirt from a grave. Imagine you are the servant that made this solid new stool. Now sit on it. Wow, that’s solid.
reading_story: While this stool is solid, you need to keep it away from the dreadful Cutter (かた). The Cutter likes to find solid things and cut them to pieces. Oh no! The Cutter is already here and he’s cutting the solid stool!
reading_hint: Hear the Cutter cackling as he cuts the stool into two pieces. Hear the wood crack as it breaks away. Also keep in mind that the 堅い reading is like 固い, which has a similar meaning.

meaning_story: To your car you take an axe. The sun has broken your car for good this time (you think). You're so angry at your car. You think this is permanent. Turns out, though, that it's not permanent. It's just temporary. You did make it permanent by taking an axe to your car, though.
meaning_hint: Feel sad that you were the one to destroy your car for good, even though the sun problem was just temporary (it just needed to cool down!).
reading_story: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when this happened, too, so now you're stuck in Zanzibar, a foreign place, and you have no idea what to do next.
reading_hint: You should probably be worried about this situation.

meaning_story: Take a thread and turn it four times in order to twist it up really good.
meaning_hint: Four times is as much as you can twist it before the pressure pushes back at you so hard you can't deal with it.
reading_story: You look at the twisted thread and think that it is the cutest (きゅう) thing you've ever seen.
reading_hint: It's going to be a challenge, but imagine a twisted piece of thread being super, duper cute.

meaning_story: Flowers find their death in a river out in the wild. Flowers live on water, but this river drowns the flowers to death. The wild is a dangerous place.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself out in the wild wilderness as you hear the flowers screaming until death takes them. The river is raging, there’s nothing you can do to help the flowers. The wild has claimed them.
reading_story: Ah (あ), the flowers in the wild have been claimed à la (あら) the great flood. Ah, you don’t think so? Well I do.
reading_hint: Imagine this scene again, only imagine it like the wild flowers are experiencing their own great flood. Ah, those flowers are drowning to death à la everything that died in the Biblical flood.

meaning_story: Imperial clothes allow you to perform an ancient attack that cannot be repelled.
meaning_hint: IMPERIAL ATTACK, GO! Imagine what this imperial attack might look like and imagine yourself in some swanky imperial clothes while you perform it.
reading_story: The attack is so strong because it doesn't involve normal clothes. No, your attack actually shoots (しゅう) energy from your imperial clothes like a powerful force field.
reading_hint: This attack is very strong, to say the least. IMPERIAL FORCE FIELD CLOTHES ATTACK, HOO-HAH!

meaning_story: A tsunami hits Joker and he's dragged through the land. When he wakes up, he finds he's in a bog.
meaning_hint: The soft landing of the bog saved him. He can't believe it. Time to go kill Batman.
reading_story: The Joker gets up out of the bog and looks down. There is a body. It's the Numa (ぬま) Numa guy.
reading_hint: So that's what happened to him.

meaning_story: A good moon is one that's nice and big and bright.
meaning_hint: The better the moon is the brighter it will be. i.e. if it's a full moon it's a good moon and it's a bright moon.
reading_story: It’s so bright that you can see all the roe (ろう) in the sea glowing and reflecting the light like stars. It’s so pretty! You had no idea the moon could be so bright that the roe in the sea would be bright right back at it!
reading_hint: Picture the bright moon. Now picture the roe on your sushi glowing brightly too. Now eat it and maybe you’ll be bright!

meaning_story: A mullet with tree hands stands before you. Then, he takes his tree hands and chafes them all over you. AHGHHHGHHH.
meaning_hint: It hurts so much, too! So much chafing!
reading_story: You can't believe the pain. It's so bad you scream out for your mama.
reading_hint: MAMAAAAAA. THE chafe hurst sooo BAAADDDD.

radicals: 山, 王, 心, 夂, 彳
meaning_story: The loitering mountain king likes to loiter around your house during the winter, probably because of your soft heart. But this time you won't take it. This time you are going to chastise him for loitering in your house, even if he is a king of the mountain!
meaning_hint: Dumb king. So irritating he's loitering around. What would you say to him if you chastised him?
reading_story: You can't do any of the chastising though, because you're a wuss. So, you instead hire evil Mrs. Cho (ちょう) to do it, because she's always up for being mean.
reading_hint: Imagine her chastising the poor cold mountain king. He is so sad he has to leave, and you kind of feel bad.

radicals: 尸, 心, 寸, 示
meaning_story: We put a flag to remember where we tried to use a jackhammer to measure your friend's heart. Granted, it was a terrible idea, but hopefully that flag of remembrance is some kind of consolation?
meaning_hint: Obviously it's not good enough consolation. Be furious about this.
reading_story: Even though you weren't happy with the flag, you were even more frustrated to watch an eagle swoop down and grab the flag and fly away with it.
reading_hint: Now you have absolutely nothing. Not even an consolation flag.

meaning_story: A badger has a good heart. A badger is courteous to others, always.
meaning_hint: Just imagine talking to a badger with a good heart. Everything he does is so courteous and nice.
reading_story: While a badger is courteous, a condor (こん) is not. The condor swoops down and punches the badger's good heart. What a jerk! Condors are the worst.
reading_hint: Imagine how discourteous the condors are, even to the courteous badgers.

meaning_story: A bamboo stalk looks the same as a big ol' cylinder.
meaning_hint: Compare the two things in your mind and make them the same.
reading_story: Think of a cylinder shaped Tokyo (とう). All the buildings are cylinders. The city itself is cylinder shaped too.
reading_hint: It's a really weird city now that they passed the cylinder law. Imagine it so deeply that it weirds you out.

radicals: 一, 丿, 火, 戈
meaning_story: Hit by a tsunami the drunkard is propelled down a slide where he hits the ground which is covered in fire. He is immediately destroyed.
meaning_hint: Even if he wasn't saved by the slide (to avoid the tsunami) he would be in trouble. Seems like the world just wanted to destroy this drunkard.
reading_story: One could say this drunkard met (めつ) his fate.
reading_hint: Strangely, he just came from a Mets (めつ) game, so maybe that's why he had such bad luck.

meaning_story: A foot on a giant is a pretty long distance for a normal person to walk. Giants have big feet and can travel large distances very quickly.
meaning_hint: Compare the distance you can travel with one step compared to a giant. It's a considerable difference in distance.
reading_story: Going to Little Kyoto (きょ) is a short distance for a giant but a long distance for you.
reading_hint: Imagine walking the distance between where you are and the (possibly made up) Little Kyoto. Think about the distance.

meaning_story: A bamboo redwood from long ago has been found. Not too often you see a bamboo redwood. You're super interested in studying it, in fact, so you try to enroll in the group that gets to study it.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself going to the research lab that is involved with studying this anomaly. Imagine the enrolling process.
reading_story: When you finally get in, you see the bamboo redwood. Waow, it's pretty sexy (せき).
reading_hint: Do your best to imagine a sexy bamboo redwood. Whatever is sexy to you, I guess.

meaning_story: If the rain touches your foot and gives it a little rain kiss, you know that part of your foot is exposed to the elements. You can also see some dew forming on your exposed foot. So that's what rain kisses are!
meaning_hint: Ugh, you shouldn't have bought these open toed shoes, at least not during rainy season!
reading_story: You run along the road (ろ), trying to get out of the rain, but the road keeps going and going, with walls on both sides.
reading_hint: You wonder how long this road will go. With exposed toes, your feet are going to get all wet if you can't get off this blasted road.

meaning_story: A fire door is a door that leads to something full of fire. That thing is a furnace.
meaning_hint: Open the fire door and feel the heat of the furnace. Hot!
reading_story: You're using the furnace to melt tar to put on the road (ろ).
reading_hint: Smell the tar baking from the furnace. Feel the heat from the furnace. Fix the road, while you're at it.

meaning_story: When a soldier comes up to a tree, he is very gentle.
meaning_hint: Around other humans, the soldier is very violent. Trees make him gentle, though.
reading_story: The soldier hangs around the tree, being nice and gentle. He hangs out with all his Jewish (じゅう) friends under the tree too, taking a break from the war.
reading_hint: Imagine all the fun things he and his Jewish friends will do under the tree. They have a good time not fighting.

meaning_story: You have to run, put your ear on the stool, then run back. That's the gist of this game.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself asking how this game works, then getting the above response.
reading_story: Then, after you do that, you have to take off your shoe (しゅ) and put it on your head while repeating the first step. That's the real gist of the game.
reading_hint: Which one was the gist? Seems like there keeps being new rules added. This isn't Calvinball, man.

meaning_story: You wield a nailbat and wear a helmet. You stand before the tent with a jackhammer in it. The jackhammer has been in there grate(ing) on something, making a terrible noise, even worse than a normal jackhammer noise.
meaning_hint: Just imagine the grating sound the jackhammer makes when rubbed on something. Metal on metal, anyone? Grate grate grate...
reading_story: You open the tent and see the jackhammer on top of another jackhammer. EUgHHWW! You can believe what you've just saw. You saw two (さつ) jackhammers doing it, and it will scar you for life.
reading_hint: If you can manage, imagine the two jackhammers before you were able to look away. NO WONDER they were making such a grating noise.

meaning_story: Two kings are here right now! We need to entertain them otherwise who knows what they're do. Get out the harp, or something.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself playing a harp even though you probably don't know how to. Entertain these kings to the best of your ability, right now. That's why you're doing it and not someone who knows what they're doing. They want it now.
reading_story: You don't even know how to do the 事 (action) of playing the harp, yet you're doing it.
reading_hint: Just say to yourself: 'This 事 I don't understand. I don't understand this 事 at all omg what am I going to do?'

meaning_story: You can see the grave in the distance. It's on the ground out in front of you. Coming up from the ground is a sunrise, really accentuating the grave. You enjoy looking at it, but then you notice something in the way of your view. A hedge is blocking the perfect view you so yearn for.
meaning_hint: Be really irritated about the hedge blocking your view. Stupid hedge... This kanji also means fence, too, so keep that in mind. A hedge can act as a fence, right? In fact, they often do.
reading_story: You were so cocky (かき) you'd have a great view, then that hedge got in your way.
reading_hint: That should teach you not to be so cocky about things.

meaning_story: A good stamp is a stamp that will stamp in an instant.
meaning_hint: Imagine a stamp that will stamp all the things that need stamping instantaneously. In an instant!
reading_story: What are you stamping over and over in instants? You are stamping socks (そく) that need stamp designs on them.
reading_hint: Go ahead and pretend to stamp stocks in front of you as fast as you possibly can. Stamp stamp stamp. Instant!

radicals: 一, 丿, 女, 戈
meaning_story: A drunkard goes down a slide, hits the ground and bumps into a woman. Who is that woman? It's none other than her majesty.
meaning_hint: The problem is that you don't want to run into her majesty. That's a grave offense. Feel the fear that you're going to get your head lopped off from running into her.
reading_story: After you run into her majesty, her guardian eagle (い) swoops on you and pulls you off of her.
reading_hint: Then it starts pecking at your eyes. Imagine fighting off an eagle trying to get at you.

meaning_story: A (fresh water) tsunami. Some horns. The ground. A bunch of poop. Combine these together and let them decompose a while. You'll have yourself some very nourishing soil.
meaning_hint: Bones are great for fertilizer. So is poop. So is water (as long as it's fresh water). So nourishing!
reading_story: This is the kind of nourishing soil that Jesus (じ) would make if he was into making soil, probably.
reading_hint: Imagine him making soil made out of those things. Jesus approves of this nourishing soil.

meaning_story: A cow in the winter doesn't like to leave the barn to go to the pasture. It has to, though, because a cow's gotta eat.
meaning_hint: It's cold outside (it's winter after all). Imagine you having to herd all the cows out to pasture even though they don't wan to leave the warm barn.
reading_story: ぼく is one of the common ways to say 'I' in Japanese (tends to be more for boys, you'll learn the kanji soon). In this case, you're a boy... a cowboy, and you say 'ぼく will take these cows out to pasture!'
reading_hint: Actually say that phrase out loud while thinking about bringing your cows to pasture.

meaning_story: Picture a train moving across water and feel at peace. It's not normal water, obviously, trains can't float. But it looks like water, and there is something incredibly peaceful about watching the ripples from a moving train slide across the surface of the water.
meaning_hint: Picture the train on the water. Feel the peace ripple through your body.
reading_story: This peace, like the train, is bringing you somewhere ... it's... it's... Thailand (たい)! Thailand is so beautiful and peaceful. Yes. This is where you shall find inner and outer peace!
reading_hint: Close your eyes. Now picture Thailand and feel at peace.

meaning_story: An axe is sticking in the ground on top of a mountain. It's sticking into the very peak. Because why would you bother to stick your axe anywhere else on the mountain to prove you climbed it?
meaning_hint: Picture that axe, jammed into the mountain's peak. The person who did that must have been really cool to get all the way up there.
reading_story: You can't help but gawk (がく) at the peak. Somehow it looks even higher now.
reading_hint: Go ahead, imagine this peak with an axe in it and actually gawk a bit at how far you have to go to get that high.

meaning_story: Take your spoon to the sun to be able to take a bite. It's delicious, you hear. That's the point of the spoon.
meaning_hint: Taste that delicious sun. It doesn't even burn! It just tastes like the best thing you've ever eaten.
reading_story: You got this recommendation to eat the delicious sun by Charlie Sheen. What a smart frood.
reading_hint: You and Charlie Sheen eat the sun together. Delicious!

meaning_story: There is a flag with Two Face on it, with criss crossed ribs. This flag isn't for some weird Two Face pirate ship. It's for his printing shop, 'Two Face Printing.'
meaning_hint: Think about how it's a really weird flag to have on a shop for printing. Super weird. Maybe talk to him about it and tell him it's not very effective.
reading_story: When you tell him his printing shop flag is dumb, he asks you how many faces you saw on it. You say 'I saw two (さつ) faces on there.' 'Hmm,' he replies. 'That's the right amount of faces you saw.'
reading_hint: You really saw two faces? I think if you saw the two faces, you'd get it.

meaning_story: The king's hat, not to mention the hair stuck to said hat, is incredibly rare. If you have your hands on either of these things, you'll be a rich duck.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself holding a king's hat covered in his hair. Who will you sell it to? This is such a rare item!
reading_story: Then you look closer at the hat. It's about to get even rarer. Attached to the hair is the king's chin (ちん).
reading_hint: Not sure how it got there, but you'll make a pretty penny from this. The king only had one chin, so that's about as rare as they come.

meaning_story: You need two graves, so you make a measurement for the two graves. You need some graves that are big enough to fit one giant demon which you plan to seal in to the graves.
meaning_hint: Imagine you have to seal in a huge demon. Go through the sealing in process in your mind to do it.
reading_story: The only way you can seal in that demon is to lure it in with lots of food (ふう). The more food you have, the easier sealing it in there will be. By the way, this has another reading you should probably know. It’s ほう. You need to use a hoe (ほう) to make the graves in the first place. A shovel would be better, but you like hoes more.
reading_hint: Mmmmmm. Foooood. Seal that demon in and then get some food for yourself. Dealing with demons is hungry business.

meaning_story: If you use stilts you are using two sticks to walk on simultaneously.
meaning_hint: You can't use one, you have to use two, and you have to use them at the same time.
reading_story: Who is using the stilts simultaneous to you? He's hugging you from behind, using your stilts with you, and he is the Japanese comedian Hard Gay (せい).
reading_hint: He yells out SEI SEI SEI while doing his famous thrust motion, throwing off your balance.

meaning_story: If a tsunami hits a pirate they are going to sink no matter how good of a pirate captain they are.
meaning_hint: Tsunamis are big. Pirates are small. Simple as that.
reading_story: As the tsunami comes to sink the pirate, the pirate holds his chin (ちん) up high. He will die with dignity.
reading_hint: Imagine this dignified chin-holding-up-high pirate. Nod your head, because you know he got what he deserves.

meaning_story: A nailbat business is a pretty tough business to run. The employees, especially are pretty dumb, since their only job is to put nails into bats. You can't stand how dumb they are, so you spend a lot of time slapping them.
meaning_hint: Slap those nailbat business employees of yours. Do you enjoy it? You're sick.
reading_story: ぼく is one way to say 'I' in Japanese, usually used by dudes. But, you are going to use it here, because you always want to remind your nailbat business staff that 'ぼく am the boss, here. Not you. ぼく (ぼく).
reading_hint: Say that phrase out loud with the ぼく. You're the boss, now.

meaning_story: If you have bad ribs, they are going to come out of your body and out of your clothes, causing your clothes and body to split in half.
meaning_hint: That's about as bad as ribs come, seriously. Ribs that try to split you in half? That's crazy. Imagine it happening to you.
reading_story: As they split your body and clothes in half, your ribs scream: 'LET'S (れつ) GET OUT OF HEREEEEE!'
reading_hint: They fly out of your splitting body yelling that phrase. You can't believe it.

meaning_story: A tsunami in the morning then some other watery action, all caused by the moon. All this watery action caused by the moon is known as the tide.
meaning_hint: Imagine the moon doing something to make the water go up and down, causing the tides to take place.
reading_story: You're looking at the tide charts, thinking the moon will be all reliable, only to learn that Mrs. Cho (ちょう) is actually on the moon in her evil villain base, controlling the tides.
reading_hint: Everyone thought it was the moon's gravity. Instead, it's just Mrs. Cho. She causes all the tsunamis! What an evil lady.

meaning_story: The construction of a giant clam statue was made in tribute to the giant clam people who will eat us if we do not provide good enough tribute.
meaning_hint: Imagine this giant statue. It's pretty amazingly big. What a great tribute.
reading_story: Next to it is another tribute statue. Even more terrifying than the giant clam people is こういち (こう).
reading_hint: Be in fear of this powerful god. You must provide more tribute!

meaning_story: Who will say turkey? Who? WHO???
meaning_hint: Say 'who' over and over again, demanding someone says 'turkey,' for some reason.
reading_story: Then, someone says turkey. 'Who said turkey? You? How dare (だれ) you.'
reading_hint: You're so mad at that person even though you demanded someone say turkey.

meaning_story: The chopsticks were not enough, they could not grab the soup from the bowl. You'll need a ladle to do that.
meaning_hint: You can't use chopsticks for this, you need something that can hold liquid, like a ladle.
reading_story: As you use the ladle to distribute your soup, you find that there's something odd in this soup... it is a toe (と) soup, full of people's toes!
reading_hint: Imagine the horror! Then, try eating a toe. How does it taste?

meaning_story: The radical blade and the kanji blade are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: Just know your radicals!
reading_story: You have a blade, your enemy does not. This is going to end well for you. You're so happy you laugh out loud: 'HA (は) HA HA HA! I WIN!'
reading_hint: Imagine yourself holding a blade and laughing. Go ahead and pretend to do it right now, wherever you are. Give it a good, evil laugh. Now put down that blade and stop laughing or the police will get the wrong idea!

meaning_story: You put a stone into a wrap of some kind. This wrap happens to be a cannon, and you're shooting off the stone, just like I used to do to boats with the cannon we had growing up for some reason.
meaning_hint: This makes a lot of sense when you think about it, right? The muzzle of the cannon wraps around the rock, then you shoot the rock. Boom!
reading_story: You want to do a trick with your cannon, though. You want to shoot someone out of it, so of course you use Houdini to do the trick.
reading_hint: You shoot houdini out of the cannon, but when you look, he's gone! What an amazing magician, able to disappear like that. Oh wait, that's because you shot him out of the cannon.

meaning_story: A bamboo thing you put on your head to stand taller would probably be a hat. A bamboo hat is probably one of those hats you think of when you think of rice farmers, a conical hat.
meaning_hint: You know the ones I'm talking about? They're cone-shaped, sort of, and they go on your head, keeping the sun off your face.
reading_story: A conical hat is kind of like an umbrella on your head. What's the reading for 'umbrella' in Japanese? Why, it's kasa (かさ)!
reading_hint: Think about a bamboo umbrella on your head. They're pretty similar in shape, after all.

meaning_story: The dragon radical is the same as this kanji, which is dragon.
meaning_hint: Not to dragon with it, but make sure you know your radicals so you know your kanji!
reading_story: Imagine a dragon. You are talking to it, which is already pretty strange, but as you're talking, he turns into the Street Fighter Character Ryuu (りゅう).
reading_hint: Then imagine after his transformation he attacks you using his Street Fighter moves. 'Hadouken!'

meaning_story: A thread is holding a wolverine and a pig to the ground, prevening them from going over the edge.
meaning_hint: You'd think someone would use a rope or something to prevent their prize animals from jumping over the edge, but this farmer doesn't seem to care.
reading_story: The thread is on a spool, too, which makes it even worse, because as they run off towards the edge, they'll eventually reach the end of the spool, which means it won't be holding them anywhere.
reading_hint: As they're running towards the cliff, yell to them: 'NO! You will reach the end of your spool! Stopppppp!' Then watch them reach the end of their spool and fly off the edge.

meaning_story: If someone puts a blade to your heart, you're going to have a rough time. They leave it there, for a long long time. They aren't going to cut you, but you can't move. You have to endure the pain and uncomfortableness of the situation.
meaning_hint: Imagine your chest and ribs are open. There's a blade on your heart. Now try not to move, or your heart will be cut!
reading_story: This is all a part of your ninja (にん) training. You must learn to stay totally still, without breathing. This is how they train you. If you can endure this you can endure anything, plus you can stay really still, which is good for ninjas.
reading_hint: Just think about how much you want to become a ninja. You'll do anything, even endure this.

meaning_story: A gold pool is where you're going to go fishing. Because, if the pool is gold, hopefully the fish are too.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself fishing in a gold pool, catching golden fish. What a great fishing spot this is.
reading_story: You caught a couple of gold fish. Two (つ) gold fish, actually!
reading_hint: Count your golden fish. They're so nice! They're also worth their weight in gold, because, well, they are gold.

meaning_story: A longcat will bring you good luck.
meaning_hint: Imagine your longcat that you have hanging from your belt. People ask you why you have a long cat hanging from your belt. You say it's for good luck.
reading_story: This whole long cat for good luck thing is working so well for you! You decide to make some do it yourself kits (きつ) to make a good luck long cat and sell them to other people. It's so easy to make, you can make it in your kitchen (きち).
reading_hint: Put together these kits in your kitchen in your head. What would they include? Cats? Stretchers to stretch out not-long cats so that they become long? Imagine making one yourself, using a kit in your kitchen.

meaning_story: The part of rice that stands up tall in the air (at the end of the stalks) is the grains.
meaning_hint: If you think about this one it'll make good sense. Just imagine rice stalks standing up into the air.
reading_story: You have a box of grains. Ryuu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is doing training by punching the grains to strengthen his fingers.
reading_hint: He has his hands flat, and stabs his hands into the grains. Yah! Yah! Yah!

meaning_story: Your long hair is your friend. It's your hair and you're so proud of it.
meaning_hint: Just feel your hair, it's such a good friend, and you wish it was longer.
reading_story: Who gave you this hair? Probably the great 神 (かみ) of hair. You deserve this great hair.
reading_hint: Pretend to pray to the great hair 神. What is his reply? Does he give you more hair?

meaning_story: An axe lay in the ground, atop a hill.
meaning_hint: The axe in the ground on top of the hill really shines. The sun is coming up behind it, silhouetting the whole thing very nicely.
reading_story: Also up there is the cutest (きゅう) little animal you've ever seen. It scampers around on the hill, then runs into the axe, cutting itself in half.
reading_hint: The cutest thing in the world! What have you done!!? Why did you leave your very sharp axe there?

meaning_story: The leader of a big rice paddy is standing in the middle of said rice paddy with an umbrella. Who is this wacky leader? Why, it is I. It is me.
meaning_hint: Imagine that this leader is you. Be rough about it, because 俺 is the 'rougher' version of 'I.' You should only use it in casual situations or if you're a badass.
reading_story: Why am I standing in the middle of this rice paddy with an umbrella? I'm digging for ore (おれ).
reading_hint: More acurately, I'm standing here with an umbrella so I don't get wet. My minions are doing the ore digging, but I am watching to make sure they don't slack off.

meaning_story: A leader of business? Ha! That's me! That's I!
meaning_hint: This version of I is more boyish. It's a sort of young man / boy way of saying 'I,' though you'll hear women use it too sometimes (it's a teensy bit tomboyish though).
reading_story: ぼく is one of the more common ways to say 'I' in Japanese. If you're on level 44 of WaniKani, you probably already know that, so you know the reading for this as well.
reading_hint: Hopefully my assumption is correct. If it's not, learn it on your own! Good luck!

meaning_story: The measurement radical and the measurement kanji are exactly the same.
meaning_hint: If you make sure to know the radicals, you'll also make sure to know the kanji too, automagically.
reading_story: You want to measure something... something that will make you famous. You decide you'll measure the biggest mass in our solar system. We're talking about the sun (すん).
reading_hint: Imagine yourself deciding to do this. First step is to get a ridiculously long measuring tape. Then, you go up to the sun and start measuring. You immediately start getting burned. Feel the pain of the heat from the sun. Think about how this really probably wasn't a good idea. You still go forward, though, doing your best to measure the sun. Ouch, ouch, ouch.

meaning_story: The tree has an omen growing from it, one single peach that is the size of a house. Inside is a child who will save the village from demons.
meaning_hint: Of course, this tree omen of a peach refers to momotaro, the little boy who was born from a peach (you should look it up if you don't know this children's story).
reading_story: If momotaro (もも) wasn't enough, think about the peach growing larger and larger. You want it to grow bigger, so you yell at it: 'MORE! MORE!' (も).
reading_hint: It grows bigger everytime you say 'MORE MORE' twice. If you say it just once, it stays the same.

meaning_story: A pine tree with ribs on it that is a tree... well, of course it is a tree. That's pretty dumb. But, it is fascinating this pine tree has ribs. What is hidden in those ribs? Perhaps a tree's heart? You pull the ribs back and the tree screams in terror, but it can't go anywhere because it's a tree. Inside is a beating... not heart... but a pear. A beating pear.
meaning_hint: You grab the beating pear and take it out of the tree, which screams some more. Take a bite out of this pear-heart thing and think about how it tastes.
reading_story: It's so good. Sooo sooo good you gnash (なし) your teeth at the tree.
reading_hint: I want more pear hearts, you yell! So you go around pulling the ribs back from the trees all around you, taking their pear hearts and eating them raw.

meaning_story: The woman servant is the lower ranking princess. The queen is no servant. Hecks no. Just the princess, because she's a servant to what her parents tell her to do.
meaning_hint: Just imagine a princess saying 'UGH, I'm just like a servant, I have to do all the crap you tell me.' Then, all the servants roll their eyes, because, really, she's a princess, lucky duck.
reading_story: The princess goes on to do whatever she wants. She tells the real servants: 'don't tell my daddy the king I did this. He may (ひめ) not like it.'
reading_hint: The servants all know they should tell the king, because the princess is a servant to the king, just as they are, plus they don't want to lose their heads.

meaning_story: A woman loves her catapult for some good ol' fashioned recreation.
meaning_hint: You ask the woman what she does for fun... for recreation. She says, she goes out and shoots her catapult.
reading_story: Her favorite thing to shoot at with her catapult for recreation is Godzilla (ご).
reading_hint: Get out of here, Godzilla! I'm gonna shoot you.

meaning_story: Here's what I say: What's the difference between a water slide and rice? That is my riddle, and if you can figure it out you're pretty smart.
meaning_hint: Try to think of the riddle as a riddle, and then try to figure out the riddle (hint: I don't know the answer either).
reading_story: The only person who can answer this riddle are the Nazo (なぞ).
reading_hint: Go seek out the Nazo and see if you can figure out the answer of this riddle.

meaning_story: The leader of the temple isn't a monk like you'd expect. It's a samurai, who protects the monks in return for prayers that keep him safe.
meaning_hint: You walk up to a temple and you'er surprised to find that there's a samurai guarding it. Talk to him for a while so he can tell you why he has been doing this job. He's quite a nice guy, actually.
reading_story: The reading is samurai, which should be easy enough to remember.
reading_hint: If you know the meaning you know the reading as well! That doesn't happen too often with kanji, so consider yourself lucky!

meaning_story: From my mouth I have told you seven times not to do that. Now I have to scold you.
meaning_hint: SEVEN TIMES! You'd think you'd learn.
reading_story: What were you doing wrong that caused me to scold you? You were feeding the 鹿 (しか). If you feed them they'll never be able to feed themselves!
reading_hint: Imagine yourself feeding the deer, then getting scolded (or you doing the scolding to someone else feeding the deer, whichever works best).

meaning_story: A tree with two moons on either side, holding the tree up in a horizontal angle, is a shelf.
meaning_hint: So, your shelf is made up of a tree and two moons. Imagine this shelf and put things on it. The moons are kind of rolling around, making it hard to build your shelf.
reading_story: Your moon shelf is great. It's also huge, because moons are really big. That means you can store a ton-a-stuff (たな) on it.
reading_hint: Think about the ton-a-stuff you're going to put on there. Like, literally, measure out a ton of things and put them on there. It can hold it!

meaning_story: Take a mouth, now multiply it by four. Four mouths are so loud, and with four mouths you can really shout.
meaning_hint: Imagine four mouths shouting at you, all at once. HEY YOU. Also, this is different from the 'seven mouths' of scold (叱), because you need more mouths to scold someone, since the whole goal is to make them feel bad. Four is enough for a shout, though.
reading_story: They are shouting the word '今日!' (きょう). Why? Because they want something happening today.
reading_hint: If you imagine them as being irritating enough and loud enough, you'll probably remember the 今日 part too. Why are they yelling 今日 over and over again with their four mouths?

meaning_story: In the cage there are some legs. They are the legs attached to a small animal.
meaning_hint: You can only see the legs, though, because a cloth is covering the cage. What kind of small animal is it? Try to look.
reading_story: You look up through the cloth, and see a hairless cat. This small animal is hairless, but most surprisingly is covered in hickies (ひき).
reading_hint: Who is giving this cat all those hickies? Pretty gross, if you ask me.

meaning_story: The spicy radical and spicy kanji are exactly the same! Hot!
reading_story: Imagine eating this spicy food, becoming blinded by the spicy heat, and knocking your shin (しん) on something while you bumble around.
reading_hint: It's bleeding profusely and really hurts a lot. Plus your mouth is still burning from that spicy food you ate. It's pure agony.

meaning_story: A flowers fang is the bud that comes out of the ground. It's like a little fang, coming from the earth, and it will become a flower someday. This is a little sprout.
meaning_hint: Imagine a bunch of these. They look like big fangs poking out of the ground (that is, until they bloom and get into the air).
reading_story: When the sprout gets out of the ground and opens up, instead of a flower there is a human-looking 目, looking right at you.
reading_hint: You look at all the sprouts. They have all turned into 目s, looking straight at you. You're terrified.

meaning_story: The mountain wind coming down from the mountains is very fierce. It is so fierce it's a lot like a storm. Well, it is a storm, really.
meaning_hint: If you think about it makes sense. Those mountain winds that come down from the mountain are cold and windy and nasty. When they mix with warmer air down below, it creates a nasty storm.
reading_story: A storm is nothing to scoff at. If you get hit by the storm and get all wet and nasty and electrocuted, you're bound to get a rash (あらし).
reading_hint: The rash comes from being wet and not drying off when you get home. Your skin gets irritated by this moisture.

meaning_story: A tsunami goes through a little door, and plops down a big drop on your face. This tsunami is your tears inside your eye area. The door is your tear duct. The big drop is the teardrop coming down your eye.
meaning_hint: Imagine a teardrop going through this process to get out of your eye, though in a more miniature teardrop size.
reading_story: Your teardrops always come at the worst times, ruining (るい) serious and/or happy moments. You can't stop crying. it is ruining your life!
reading_hint: Think of several inappropriate situations to cry in. Put yourself in them. Think about how all this crying is ruining things, for real!

meaning_story: Rain on a rice paddy means only one thing... thunder! Get off the rice paddy! There's nothing but you to attract the thunder!
meaning_hint: Imagine hearing the thunder as you run. It is getting closer.
reading_story: You can't run fast enough to escape the thunder so you hitch a ride (らい) from someone driving by.
reading_hint: Thank goodness, that was a close one. The guy who picks you up is named Ryan, though he likes it if you call him Ry (らい).

meaning_story: While the radical is can, it refers to a tin can, which is almost the same thing.
meaning_hint: I'll also allow can, though I really prefer it if you answer tin can, because that's a better thing to have in your mind.
reading_story: The reading is unbelievably easy. A tin can is a can (かん).
reading_hint: I can't make this stuff up. It's too easy to remember, almost.

meaning_story: The grave of flowers really suits this spot. The flowers have replaced a tower which was here long ago, and the flowers look way better than the old tower that was once here.
meaning_hint: Imagine the tower that used to be here. Now imagine the flowers, looking much better. The grave for this tower is flowers, and it is nice.
reading_story: A tower starts with a とう, or at least kind of.
reading_hint: Imagine the long vowel sound for tower. TOoooower.

meaning_story: A slide to get off the jet. It's so beautiful. It's a brilliant vermillion color.
meaning_hint: Just imagine it this beautiful color. Look up the color in Google Image search if you don't know what it is.
reading_story: The vermillion slide also matches your shoe (しゅ), though only one of them.
reading_hint: Look down at your vermillion shoe. Looks so good.

meaning_story: A feather is on a rice paddy, and they are attached together. You put a feather on a rice paddy to create a giant airplane. Flawed, sure. But, this rice paddy + feather is going to be one wing of your amazing aircraft.
meaning_hint: Imagine a wing that is made of a rice paddy and a feather put together. Doesn't make sense, looks ugly, and probably will not fly. Imagine it anyways. It is your wing.
reading_story: To make the feather and rice paddy stick together you need some kind of sticking agent. This time we find the original bird that the feather came from and grab its eggs. We break the eggs open and use the yolk (よく). It's pretty sticky, but still probably not aircraft safe.
reading_hint: Imagine using the yolks to stick everything together. It's all over your hands, and things are pretty nasty.

meaning_story: A spoon to measure a geoduck is a very approximate measurement. Geoducks are big, spoons are small. Still, we'll get the approximation going, right?
meaning_hint: Do the comparison. A spoonful of geoduck aka a whole geoduck on a spoon. This is a spoonful, right? This is what the recipe wanted, I think...
reading_story: Maybe this is too much geoduck, even if we're going for an approximate. So, you take the core (ころ) of the geoduck and measure that instead.
reading_hint: That's a little better. Not too much geoduck. Still a lot, but more like an approximate.

meaning_story: I put flowers in my mouth and pine needles too. It's the only way I know how to get rid of the bacteria that's in there.
meaning_hint: Your mouth is pretty bacteria filled. It's pretty nasty, actually. Certain flowers and certain pine needles will help to kill the bacteria, though.
reading_story: You learned this bacteria killing trick from your kin (きん).
reading_hint: Sure, your kin is a bunch of hicks, but they sure know what flowers and such to chew on to get rid of the mouth bacteria.

meaning_story: On a gold stand is something that looks like a sunflower. It's so beautiful! You inspect it closer, though. It chimes. Looks like this sunflower looking thing on the gold stand is actually a bell.
meaning_hint: How did they make a bell in the shape of a sunflower? Amazing bell technology right there. Ring it a few times. It makes a pleasant sound.
reading_story: Ah, this makes sense. This fancy bell is a part of a fancy bell show (しょう). For some reason you're standing on the stage where it's being shown off, too, during this show.
reading_hint: Get off the stage, someone yells. You're blocking our view of that bell!

meaning_story: What has a sail? A boat has a sail.
meaning_hint: Not quite the same meaning as the radical, but the connection is clear.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the kanji 船, though there's an extra reading there as well, ふな. They're close, so you should be able to remember it based off of ふね.
reading_hint: Try to answer ふな a couple times when doing your reviews. It'll help when we get to the vocab part.

meaning_story: The woman who makes your house a home is your bride.
meaning_hint: She's in your house because you married her. Thus, she's your bride. Your house is now a home.
reading_story: Now that you have a bride in your house, you can get rid of your maid (よめ), since your bride will do all the cleaning.
reading_hint: Your bride is very upset at how sexist you're being right now, and makes you do all the cleaning instead. The maid still gets fired.

meaning_story: Looking up to the cliff, you see the trees, and the sun shining down on them. Using the sun and the trees (up there on the cliff), you've devised a method to tell what time of the year it is, based on where the shadow from the trees fall. After a while, you develop a bigger system. This system is a whole calendar.
meaning_hint: Look at the different shadow patterns. Know what they all mean. This is your very own calendar system.
reading_story: Remember the word 歴史, which means 'history'? Using a calendar, you too can remember history (otherwise, who knows when these things happened). So, the reading for this kanji is the same as the reading for 歴史's beginning, because they're related.
reading_hint: Make sure you make the connection between the word 歴史 and this kanji. If you do, it'll be much easier to remember the reading of this kanji.

meaning_story: The sun looks down on the rain boobs, which are just big white fluffy 'boobs' that create rain. When there's a lot of these, it's cloudy.
meaning_hint: What does that cloud look like? Kind of like a boob, actually... Hmmm, cloudy days...
reading_story: Remember 雲? It means 'cloud' and has the same reading as 'cloudy,' making them both くも.
reading_hint: Make sure you know both cloud words and you'll know their readings too.

meaning_story: An alligator is considerably dangerous. Considerably terrifying too. Considerably [put your scary adjective here].
meaning_hint: The radical meaning and the kanji meaning aren't the same, but we'll get through this together. Just put a considerable amount of effort into this and you'll learn considerably more quickly.
reading_story: Speaking of considerably terrifying, that place known as Narnia (なり) is pretty terrifying. Not sure why children want to go there.
reading_hint: Also, things that are 'considerably' anything start somewhere. They become (なり) whatever 'considerable' thing they are now from something smaller before.

meaning_story: A sock circle, around a grave. This is the symbol which tells you you're at cram school.
meaning_hint: Every day walking to cram school you look for this circle of socks around the grave. When you get to it, you know to turn left, and right there will be the cram school you attend.
reading_story: The sock circle around the grave moves around though, and tries to pull you in. So, to get to cram school you have to juke (じゅく) this thing and run past it.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself doing a juke to get past this weird monster of a grave. You've gotten pretty good at it, though you don't want to be careless. Looks like Carly was the latest victim. Poor Carly, didn't juke well enough.

meaning_story: From the mouth of your older brother comes... a curse!
meaning_hint: Imagine him cursing you. He's not a fan of you, since you are siblings, but to think he'd go so far as to put a curse on you? You can't believe it. What kind of curse did he put upon you?
reading_story: Turns out, he put the no road (のろ) curse on you, meaning you can never walk on roads.
reading_hint: In your mind, walk around the area where you live. Think about the places you can go that aren't roads. If you try to walk on a road, you can't. This is the no road curse, after all.

meaning_story: After the tsunami the sun comes up, and shines on the spikes. Imagine that scene. They were super wet, before, but maybe they're dry now because of the sun? Go ahead and touch the spikes. Nope, they're still damp.
meaning_hint: Can't use damp spikes, so you'll have to wait until they dry out. Keep touching them, though, just to be sure. Nope, they're still damp every time.
reading_story: As you're watching the spikes to see if they'll ever stop being damp, a shitzu (しつ) dog walks right into the spike trap.
reading_hint: Now they're even more damp compared to before. Feel the horror of accidentally killing that poor little puppy. How did you let this happen? You were right there, watching!

meaning_story: I built a pine house using my earnings. Before I could only buy a plastic house. But, this time I built a sturdy pine house, because I make so much earnings these days!
meaning_hint: Check out your awesome pine house. It really does look good. Nice and sturdy. Using all your earnings was totally worth it.
reading_story: Along with this nice pine house you bought a nice new car (か) as well.
reading_hint: Imagine your new car in front of your new pine house. They look good together! Also, this has the same reading as 家, and includes it on the side. Good little way to cheat and remember the reading, that is.

meaning_story: I have sick in my skin. Just look at it, it doesn't look too good. Whenever I have sickness in my skin, I know that I'm probably exhausted.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself being really, really exhausted. Then look at your skin. It's all sickly looking.
reading_story: When you're exhausted, your muscles are all probably worn out. Being this worn out, you can probably imagine that your body is all heated (ひ) up, from all the exercising.
reading_hint: Imagine exercising so much that your body gets all exhausted and heated (ひ) up.

meaning_story: A sheep with feathers (and presumably wings, too) is able to fly.
meaning_hint: Imagine the sheep with feathers taking off and flying around. It's an odd sight, but makes sense, kind of.
reading_story: Using this sheep that can fly, you're going to get rich! But there's a problem... you have to catch the sheep. So, you get some cake (かけ) and use it to lure the sheep to your trap, where you catch it!
reading_hint: Ha HA! Everyone knows sheep love cake. Works every time. Now this flying sheep is yours!

meaning_story: I'm putting all my clams on someone to win the race (clams = slang for money). If you do that, you are performing a gamble.
meaning_hint: Who are you betting on? Imagine it and bet on that someone. Now imagine the race playing out and imagine the excitement of your gambling.
reading_story: Best part is, if you win this gamble, you're going to take all your money and spend it on a new car (か).
reading_hint: You won! Be excited about that. Then, take all the money you won and think about what car you can buy. What would you get?

meaning_story: It was raining, and during the rain two spikes fell from the sky, smashing you completely, killing you instantly. But, you're not ready to die, so you come back as a ghost.
meaning_hint: Make sure you focus on getting killed by the spikes, then feeling enough regret to come back as a ghost. What does your ghost form look like?
reading_story: When you turn into a ghost, you discover a couple of new powers. First, you can shoot rays (れい) out of your eyes (awesome!). Also, you can row (りょう) a boat really fast. That one's not as cool, but still useful for going across rivers and lakes and such.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself using your two new powers, as a ghost.

meaning_story: The tsunami circus is a circus troop that uses the power of water to do all their tricks. Their most famous trick is when they send a tsunami down a gutter and all ride it around the circus tent.
meaning_hint: Imagine a huge gutter going everywhere, with clowns riding the tsunami wave inside the gutter, flying all around. Seems dangerous, but they're professionals.
reading_story: And, of course, the ring leader is こういち. He's controlling the water pressure and all that, sending people through the gutter and down to the ground, where there's another gutter to shoot them outside the tent.
reading_hint: You'll just want to imagine out this whole scene the best you can. Focus on the gutter and the ringleader.

meaning_story: A soldier carries a halberd.
meaning_hint: The radical and kanji aren't the same, but the connection makes sense here.
reading_story: Using that halberd, the soldier pierces a cow (む). It says 'MOOOO' as it gets stabbed.
reading_hint: This soldier will be eating well tonight. Yum yum cow.

meaning_story: I protect my own animals by going to hunt other animals... like wolves and cougars and such.
meaning_hint: My animals can't protect themselves, that's why I hunt other animals instead.
reading_story: I also do all my hunts using a car (か). I just run those animals down with my car. Kind of cheating, but vroom vroom anyways.
reading_hint: Imagine hunting down animals in a car.

meaning_story: Up on the moon cemetery you got a stamp, to prove you were there. You got this stamp on your leg, though, for some reason. Maybe because that way it wouldn't wash off when you wash your hands?
meaning_hint: Look at the moon cemetery stamp on your leg. Pretty cool stamp you got there, bro.
reading_story: Up on the moon, where you got your moon cemetery stamp on your leg, the only thing to eat was Kia cookies... cookies made by the car manufacturer Kia.
reading_hint: They aren't great cookies, but you'll eat them because you have to. Gotta get back to earth to show off that leg stamp you got.

meaning_story: A tsunami hitting a tent and some beans will destroy it completely. This is very easy to understand. If you agree with this and think this then you are showing lucidity in your thought.
meaning_hint: Everything makes sense. Everything is lucid.
reading_story: But, the thing that is not lucid... the thing you don't understand... is who would do such a thing. Who would destroy my tent and bean collection using a tsunami? Who is that evil? Of course, you know the answer, which is Mrs. Chou (ちょう).
reading_hint: If there's something evil going on, it's definitely Mrs. Chou.

meaning_story: The grave demon is one who hangs around graves. He's not your normal demon, though. He looks just like a little lump that sits there and does nothing. Then, when you get close he jumps on you, sucks your face off, and then lumps his way back to a grave to inject it into the dead underground body, which then reanimates and... you get the idea.
meaning_hint: The important thing is you know what it looks like, so you can avoid it when you're at a graveyard. It's a lump, okay?
reading_story: Have you ever heard of the game 'Katamari Damacy'? That game is about a little guy who rolls a ball around, turning it into a bigger and bigger lump. What do you think the Katamari (かたまり) part means? It of course means lump.
reading_hint: If you don't know the game and have never heard the music (especially) it's great stuff! If you have, this word will be really easy for you. If you haven't, look it up!

meaning_story: The animal king? He's just this guy who lives in the forest, and thinks he's king of all the animals. He's a lunatic, though.
meaning_hint: He's absolutely bat sh*t crazy, speaking of animals.
reading_story: The animal king is such a lunatic he has no idea what day it is today. 'WHAT IS TODAY (きょう)?' he yells.
reading_hint: WHAT IS TODAY WHAT IS TODAY? Imagine him yelling this over and over, then switch it to 'WHAT IS 今日???'

meaning_story: You call a nurse who's a woman miss. If you don't call her miss she might ignore you when you need help. Make sure to be polite and call your female nurse "miss!"
meaning_hint: Excuse me, Miss Nurse? I need to pee.
reading_story: Even terrible people are polite enough to call their nurse miss. Even Joseph (じょう) Stalin, who happens to be in the bed next to yours. In fact, that's all he'll call her. "Miss would you come over here and fluff my pillow?" "Miss could you bring me soup?"
reading_hint: "Miss! Joseph Stalin needs his achey tummy rubbed. Wait, Miss come back!"

meaning_story: A pelican has taken some fruit, and rubbed it all over your naked body. It's worrisome that a pelican is doing this, but what're you going to do, right? Pelicans are big and scary.
meaning_hint: Be a little afraid. Try not to move. The pelican is marking you with its fruit, and for some reason you're completely naked, too.
reading_story: Ah ha. He was marking you with fruit so that the Egyptian God Ra (ら) could find you. Ra comes over and says: 'Mmm, here's my little fruit friend.' Then he takes a bite out of you.
reading_hint: Not sure what's going on here to be honest, but let Ra take a few bites out of your fruity body before telling him to stop.

meaning_story: Take the mullet and wrap it around a couple of trees. Then, rub a stone with it. If you use these things to rub the stone for long enough, you'll be able to polish it!
meaning_hint: Look at the polished stone! It's so smooth, thanks to your mullet wrapped around a tree polisher.
reading_story: A polished stone isn't just for looks, though. You're eating these stones, because there's nothing else to eat. It's a meager (みが) living, but it's way better than a rough stone, that's for sure.
reading_hint: Imagine eating smooth polished stones. Then, rough ones. They're both meager, but at least one goes down easier.

meaning_story: The butcher now needs boobs, specifically cow boobs, to fill his next order. He has them, but he needs to keep them cool, but there's no room in the freezer. So, he puts them in the shade where they're (hopefully) stay cool enough.
meaning_hint: Look at the cow boob meat in the shade and wonder if it will stay good long enough there. It's pretty warm today, and the shade isn't all that cool.
reading_story: Where did he put the meat? He put them in (いん) the shade. Got that? IN the shade.
reading_hint: You might want to say that sentence a few times. There is shade, and things are in it.

meaning_story: The moon table is a table that's made entirely of skin. You thought the table was made of moon, with all those pours and such, but when you look more closely, you realize it's skin. Disgusting, porey, skin.
meaning_hint: Touch it and feel the 'moon table.' You know it's not made of moon. How ridiculous.
reading_story: But, when you go to touch this 'moon table' made of skin, you realize that it's harder (はだ) than you expected.
reading_hint: You'd think skin would be softer, but it's pretty hard. Much harder than you expected.

meaning_story: The boobs demon (imagine a demon covered in boobs, or something) is a soul / spirit from another world who comes to this world to surprise people with all the boobs he's covered with. Weird dude, this one.
meaning_hint: Imagine being visited by this spirit. It's not a great experience, to say the least.
reading_story: He comes to visit you a lot, this spirit. He's always rolling around a lump of boobs, saying he's the Katamari Tamashii (たましい), and rolls balls of things around just like the original (but only with boobs).
reading_hint: Imagine him rolling a thing of boobs around, singing the Katamari Damacy song, if you know it. If not, you're missing out.

meaning_story: An eye omen can be noticed when you are caught staring off into the distance, seeing visions and other omen-like things. That's why this kanji is stare.
meaning_hint: Go ahead and stare off into the distance. What omens do you see with your eyes?
reading_story: The future! You see the future with your stare. The future is that... oh God. No. Mrs. Chou (ちょう) is going to come and kill us all! She is tired of throwing nails down on the streets, and this time she's going to finish us for good!
reading_hint: Tell everyone of the omen you stared out. We must prepare the defenses!

meaning_story: Feeling like stone again (and again, and again?). If your body is feeling like a stone all the time, every time you touch it, you're probably feeling quite stiff.
meaning_hint: Touch your body again and again. Each time it's so stiff. What a pain.
reading_story: Now touch こういち's (こう) body. Once again, so stiff.
reading_hint: Don't get the wrong idea, sicko.

meaning_story: The toe is early. I hate it when the toes show up early. Well, if the toes are going to show up this early, I guess it's best to put them on the table.
meaning_hint: See all the toes lined up on the table. They are the ones who showed up early.
reading_story: What do all the early toes on the table do while they're waiting until it's the right time? They just sit around on their table, talking (たく).
reading_hint: Imagine the toes talking to each other. 'Hello Mr. Toe!' 'Oh hello other Mr. Toe!'

meaning_story: If there's a treasure chest, there's always a villain, too, trying to get to the treasure chest before the hero of the story.
meaning_hint: And, the villain always gets to the treasure chest first, often via nefarious means. That villain, so important when it comes to treasure chests.
reading_story: What day did the villain get to the treasure chest? He got to the treasure chest today (きょう), which is faster than the hero, who won't get here until tomorrow.
reading_hint: TODAY THIS TREASURE IS MINE! HAHAHAHA!

meaning_story: A tsunami in the shape of a dragon flies off the cliff, then comes crashing down to the ground. This skinny tsunami of water flying down to the ground is a waterfall.
meaning_hint: Can you see why a tsunami dragon (especially the Asian skinny snake-like kind) could be a waterfall? Try to imagine it.
reading_story: Despite how cool a dragon waterfall is, to be honest it's also pretty tacky (たき).
reading_hint: Now imagine it being a bit tacky. Dragons are alright but... you just don't want to overdo it, you know?

meaning_story: The meaning of this kanji is the same as the meaning of the radical that it comes from, making things easy. Just make sure you note that this 'well' is a water well. That's important.
meaning_hint: So long as you don't fall down a well, you should be able to remember both the radical and kanji meaning here.
reading_story: Oh, hey friend, let me show (しょう) you something that's in this well. *pushes friend down well.*
reading_hint: The 'Let me show you something in this well' trick is the oldest trick in the book. You've thrown a lot of friends down there.

meaning_story: The black grave is covered with ink, black ink. That’s why it’s black. The grave is covered with ink that is black so that’s why the grave is black. Because of the black ink.
meaning_hint: Imagine pouring this black ink over the grave. Hear it slop out and dribble all over the grave, turning it black.
reading_story: Yeah, I poured black ink on the grave and now it’s all covered in ink. So what? Sue me (すみ). Yeah, go ahead and sue me! I don’t even care!
reading_hint: Imagine saying this out loud to someone who was upset you poured black ink on to the grave. Sue me!

meaning_story: A protester kicks you in the forehead with cleats on and your eye blinks. Well, of course it did. You just got kicked in the head!
meaning_hint: Imagine getting kicked by someone in cleats, let alone in the forehead, and feel your eyes blink.
reading_story: You blink and blink and soon (しゅん) there are tears coming out of them too. You try to blink them away but it's not working. Soon you're crying and blinking and crying some more.
reading_hint: How soon do you think you would cry through your blinking after getting kicked in the head? I would cry pretty soon after.

meaning_story: If a tsunami wraps around itself, the resulting wave will create a lot of bubbles. You know how tsunamis wrap around once gravity kicks in, right? Well when that wave crashes, there are a whole lot of bubbles created.
meaning_hint: Imagine this tsunami wave wrapping itself around you. The rush of water creates a ton of bubbles. Feel them all tickling your skin.
reading_story: Normally this tsunami and the resulting bubbles would spell death, but luckily you are the great Hou-dini (ほう)! Since you are Hou-dini, you use the bubbles to your advantage and float atop them, escaping a death by drowning. Magical!
reading_hint: You’re Hou-dini so you’re always capable of death defying feats like this one. Imagine being Hou-dini and surfing along on the bubbles created by the tsunami. Pretty cool.

meaning_story: You scrape some pine with your cleat, causing Wolverine’s heart to calm. Wolverine needs to calm down, and for some reason the sound of a cleat scraping on pine wood does the trick for him. Wolverine’s heart begins to calm down rapidly.
meaning_hint: Imagine scraping a cleat against pine and hearing the scraping sound as you see Wolverine calm down. His heart rate is slowing and he looks very calm and peaceful.
reading_story: The reason Wolverine needs to calm down is because he accidentally ate some onions (おん) earlier. Onions really freak Wolverine out for some reason, so after eating them he needed your help to calm down.
reading_hint: Smell the smell of onions in the air as you continue to scrape the pine with your cleat and calm Wolverine down. I wonder why onions freak him out so much…

meaning_story: There's this child you really don't like. So you take an umbrella and stab the child, creating a cavity / hole in his body.
meaning_hint: Wow? Really!? You're a horrible person for doing that! At least you'll never forget about doing that, right?
reading_story: And you know who that child was? It was child version of kouichi (こう). Now WaniKani will never exist! You just went back in time to kill half the people who started WaniKani!
reading_hint: Imagine WaniKani disappearing because you screwed up space time. You should never have stabbed a hole into child Koichi using that umbrella.

meaning_story: This tree is very odd, to say the least. The shape is all crazy, like a lightning bolt stuck into the ground, or something. Oh wait, look at this. I can sit on it really nicely. It's just like a chair!
meaning_hint: Imagine this odd tree chair being the most comfortable chair you've ever sat on. It's shaped perfectly for you, and the moss makes it soft. Wow, what a chair.
reading_story: But, this odd tree chair is also home to an eagle (い). It swoops down upon you as you sit down, gouging your eyes out.
reading_hint: Feel the fear and regret. You should have known not to sit in this 'chair'. Mother nature never forgives, and now you don't have eyeballs.

meaning_story: The flowers in your enclosure with rice are chrysanthemum flowers. You’re trying to dry out the chrysanthemums, so that’s why they’re in the enclosure with the rice. The rice will absorb the moisture from the chrysanthemum.
meaning_hint: See the chrysanthemum in the enclosure with the rice. Imagine a time lapse of the chrysanthemum drying out. See it quickly shrivel up and dry from the rice.
reading_story: You’re walking around the house and you accidently kick (きく) the enclosure with the chrysanthemum and rice in it. Your kick sends the contents of the enclosure flying! Rice and chrysanthemum bits everywhere! You clumsy oaf! Why’d you have to go and kick this enclosure?
reading_hint: Imagine your kick connecting with this enclosure and the sounds of the rice scattering everywhere. The chrysanthemum doesn’t make much of a sound compared to the rice, but it does crumble apart since it’s so dry. Poor flower.

meaning_story: A tsunami causes the capital to become very cool. The capital was already a pretty cool temperature, but with the addition of the water from the tsunami, the capital is now very cool.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in the capital. The tsunami hits and now you are all wet. You are also very cool because the water is not warm. You are cool and wet. How sad.
reading_story: You don’t like how cool it is in the capital now so you decide to get in your row (りょう) boat and row away to some place that is not so cool. Get it your row boat and row away!
reading_hint: Imagine rowing in your row boat. The more you row, the less cool it gets. Feel your arms strain as you do so. It’s all worth it!

meaning_story: Using a thread that is white, Two Face makes some cotton pants. Two Face loves the feel of cotton, and he only uses white thread to make his clothes.
meaning_hint: Imagine Two Face making these cotton pants. See him sewing them up with white thread using a sewing machine. See the cotton go through as the sewing machine whirrs away.
reading_story: Two Face also believes that cotton is a fabric that should only be worn by men (めん). Men are the only ones who should be wearing cotton in his opinion.
reading_hint: Imagine Two Face and his posse of men, all wearing cotton. Now imagine them all marching around shouting “REAL MEN WEAR COTTON” or something.

meaning_story: You have a mullet and you are standing next to a tree while next to another tree is a demon that looks like the devil. That demon looks like the devil, because he is the devil. Uh oh. The devil doesn’t like mullets. Or trees for that matter. You might be in trouble here.
meaning_hint: Imagine standing next to this tree with your mullet as the devil leaves his tree and walks over towards you, fire in his eyes. Feel the hair on the back of your next stick up and the wind lazily blows your mullet about.
reading_story: Oh, crap – the devil is going to send you to hell for having a mullet. You cry for your mama (ま). “Mama, please!” you shout. “Ohh, mama save me!”
reading_hint: Imagine the devil scalping you and removing your mullet from your head as you continue to cry for your mama to save you. Why won’t your mama save you? Where is your mama when you need her??

meaning_story: You keep the helmet of your ox in the dormitory. You can’t keep the helmet anywhere else, because someone might steal it. You keep it with you in your dormitory to keep it safe.
meaning_hint: Imagine guarding this ox helmet in your dormitory. Hold it in your hands as you smell the musky ox smell wafting off of it as you sit in your dormitory.
reading_story: The main reason you keep the ox helmet with you in your dormitory is because you are afraid someone will steal it and row (りょう) down the river with it. Someone stole your last ox helmet and they did just that. You don’t want anyone to row away with your ox’s helmet ever again.
reading_hint: Imagine you stole the ox helmet. Row row row your boat away from the dormitory. See the dormitory fade away in the distance as you row towards your getaway hideout.

meaning_story: There are nine birds and one of them is a dove and another is a pigeon. These nine birds are a flock of all kinds, but the dove and the pigeon are the leaders.
