meaning_hint: Look at these nine birds strutting down the street like they own the place. The dove and pigeon are out in front because they are the most important. Hear them chirping and fluttering their feathers about.
reading_story: Take a look at the pigeon in front of you. Now, grab it, tear it in half, and grab the heart (はと) from its little body.
reading_hint: Devour it. You love pigeon hearts. Discard the rest, keep the heart.

meaning_story: Your gold thorn is making you dull. You’re so enamored with the gold thorn that you forego your studies and become dull, slow, and stupid.
meaning_hint: Imagine gazing at this gold thorn for hours upon hours. Feel the intelligence seeping out of you as you become more and more dull from doing nothing but admiring your gold thorn.
reading_story: Just then, the don (どん) of your local mafia shows up and steals your gold thorn, but you barely react as you’ve become too dull to notice. Once you realize that your thorn is gone, you become very confused. You’ll never catch the don because you don’t actually know the don was the one who did it.
reading_hint: Now you cry about your lost thorn. You’re so dull that you soon forget what you were crying about. Then you forget that you ever lost anything at all. Now you just feel dull. Hmph.

meaning_story: You bought a gold comb from IKEA that was made in a forge. This is a handmade gold comb. Did you know IKEA sold those? Well the ones that have a forge attached to them do. Man, I wish all IKEAs had forges. These gold combs are awesome!
meaning_hint: Examine this gold comb from the IKEA forge. It’s so cool. Turn it over in your hands. It’s still warm from the heat of the forge. Mmm, freshly made combs…
reading_story: You go stand over by the IKEA forge to check it out and you are there for so long that you actually start to get a tan (たん). Did you know you can tan by the heat of a forge? Well now you do. The forge is so hot and bright that you tan right up!
reading_hint: Feel the heat from the IKEA forge as you see your skin tan. Your skin is hot and tender from the forge. That’s the fastest tan you’ve ever received!

meaning_story: A crab moves a stone because he is playing the game Go. You know this game, right? You put black or white stones on a board until you win the game. This is the Japanese game known as Go. This crab is pretty good.
meaning_hint: Look at this crab placing stones on the Go board. Hear them click and clack as the crab places them with expert precision.
reading_story: Go is pronounced Go (ご) in Japanese, too. How convenient is that? Like, super convenient. So easy even a crab could remember!
reading_hint: Go is Go. Easy!

meaning_story: You’re sick, and government propaganda has gotten you in the habit of buying medicine to cure yourself. The propaganda is for highly ineffective and overpriced medication, but you’ve gotten into the habit of always buying it, so it’s what you always do when you get sick.
meaning_hint: Imagine getting sick and then immediately buying the medication due to the propaganda and the habit it has created in you. Feel the irresistible pull of your habit making you do this.
reading_story: Too bad your habit isn’t eating couscous (くせ), because that would cure your sickness in no time. Couscous is great for healing all sorts of things. Or is that just more propaganda? Hmm…
reading_hint: Imagine eating some couscous. Imagine making it a habit. You eat couscous every day and you never get sick. Mmm, couscous.

meaning_story: A pine tree wants you to do a favor for it in exchange for a head of plant, or ear of plant, depending how you look at it. The pine is willing to exchange a pine cone in exchange for this favor. The head or ear of a pine is its pine cone, right?
meaning_hint: Imagine what sort of strange favor this pine could want. And would it really be worth doing just for a head or an ear (of the plant)?
reading_story: The pine tree agrees to give you its head of plant/ear of plant (the pinecone) in exchange for destroying a hoe (ほ). The local farmer always smacks this pine tree with his hoe, so the pine tree wants you to break the farmer’s hoe so he can stop bothering the pine tree with it. You agree.
reading_hint: Imagine carrying your newfound head/ear of this plant ad you break the hoe over your knee, set it on fire, and cast the ashes into the wind. Good job.

meaning_story: I have five things in my mouth and I need them all for me. I own these five things, and I keep them in my mouth so people like you cannot take them from me.
meaning_hint: What five things would you keep in your mouth to protect them from me? Imagine these five things in your mouth and think of how important they are to you as you taste them on your tongue.
reading_story: Me, personally, I am quite thirsty so I ask for some “waga” (わが). I have five things in my mouth, so it is hard for me to pronounce the word “water”. So it sounds like “waga” when I ask for it. “Coulg I pweash hab sum waga?! I deed waga!!”
reading_hint: Imagine how you would sound asking for “waga” with your mouth full of five things. You can carry out this experiment in real life if you would like, just be careful not to choke, okay?

meaning_story: A gold loving Big Bird uses a brush to polish his key. The key leads to the vault where Big Bird keeps all his gold. Big Bird also likes to keep the key (which is also gold) nice and shiny so he uses the brush to keep it nice and clean and shiny.
meaning_hint: Look at Big Bird brushing the gold key with his brush. He is very focused. See the light glint off the gold key because of how clean and shiny it is.
reading_story: Having all of this gold behind lock and key has made Big Bird very cocky (かぎ). He’s so cocky that he sometimes doesn’t even lock the vault. Big Bird is so cocky that he lets everyone know exactly how rich he is with all his gold. This Big Bird sure is cocky.
reading_hint: Okay, so cocky is a little off from , but I think it’s close enough to help remember the reading. If you can think of anything better, let us know. Anyway, just imagine how cocky Big Bird is, bragging about all his gold and waving his shiny key all around.

meaning_story: I found part of a plate at the lantern festival. There is a legendary plate broken into three parts. One part of the plate I found was at the lantern festival. The lantern festival was pretty cool, but I’m really glad I found the part of that plate I was looking for.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding this part of the plate in your hands as the light from the lanterns glitters off it and dances around, illuminating the background. It’s enchanting.
reading_story: The plate part you found at the lantern festival is made out of bone (ぼん) china. How fancy. Is bone china made from real bones? Bones found in China? Probably not, huh.
reading_hint: Tap this bone china plate with your knuckle. Hear the pleasant tap as you continue to view all the fancy lanterns around you at the festival.

meaning_story: You dig a mullet grave behind your manor. Now that you own a manor, you’ve decided to cut your mullet in an attempt to look more respectable. You dig a grave for your mullet though as it means a lot to you. Put your mullet in the grave that you just dug behind your manor.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself cutting off your prize mullet and dropping it into the grave you just dug behind your manor. Feel the hair tickle the palm of your hand as you drop them into the grave below.
reading_story: The shogun (しょう) himself is coming to visit your manor soon, so that was the main reason you did away with your mullet. You don’t want the shogun to get a bad first impression of you or anything, so you cut off your mullet just to be safe.
reading_hint: Imagine showing the shogun your manor. He sees the grave, and you explain how you recently had to bury a close friend of yours. The shogun feels sorry for your loss. You feel very sad to have lost your mullet.

meaning_story: You see an animal by the grave with a mouth so you kick the monkey. The monkey is the animal by the grave. The monkey also has a mouth, a mouth that is screaming profanity at your dead relative in the grave. This is why you kick the monkey. You kick him right in the mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine this monkey yelling profanity at your poor dead relative in the grave. Now imagine kicking this foul monkey in the mouth. BAM!
reading_story: You kick the monkey over and over again until he finally straightens his act out and salutes (さる) your relative’s grave. It is a beautiful salute. A salute full of respect and regret.
reading_hint: Look at this monkey salute the grave. He is perfectly still and the form of his salute is impeccable. All because of you repeatedly kicking him in the mouth. Well done.

meaning_story: There’s a tree in the east that looks like a pillar. The tree is so tall and straight and does not have any leaves or branches. The tree is basically a big wooden pillar.
meaning_hint: Look at this big tree pillar over in the east. The sun rises in the east, so imagine the silhouette of the pillar as the sun rises behind it.
reading_story: Actually, this pillar is in Tokyo (とう). You know, in Japan – the Land of the Rising Sun? This pillar is an ancient relic that is held very dear to all the people living in Tokyo.
reading_hint: The sun rises in the east and Tokyo is in the Land of the Rising sun, so just keep that in mind as you watch the sun come up behind this majestic pillar in Tokyo.

meaning_story: They say that big guy on the ground is a beggar with a lot of pride. He’s a beggar, but he refuses to accept handouts because of his pride. He’s kind of a paradox. What kind of a beggar doesn’t accept handouts? That’s pretty odd, wouldn’t you say?
meaning_hint: Imagine this big guy sitting on the ground as people try to give him food and money. Hear him adamantly refusing as he turns his nose up at the would be donators. Pride can be a strange thing.
reading_story: This big beggar has had an overabundance of pride ever since he was a 子. He wouldn’t even let his parents make him lunches for school and he never accepted any allowance. It makes you wonder how a 子 with so much pride would end up on the streets as a beggar.
reading_hint: Look at this 子 compared to this beggar. What could have happened to this 子 in order for him to be brought to this point in his life? You feel bad and you want to help him, but his pride is preventing you from doing anything to help.

meaning_story: You see an eye on a stand with a sunflower growing out of the pupil. Looks like you’re having one of those dreams again. Why is there a sunflower coming out of the pupil of this eye? Who knows? This is a weird dream.
meaning_hint: Imagine what it would feel like to have a sunflower grow out of the pupil of your eye. Imagine the sunflower roots growing into your pupil and spreading out into your head.
reading_story: The only person who can remove this sunflower from your pupil in a man in Tokyo (とう). You must travel to Tokyo if you want to save your eye. You gotta get to Tokyo.
reading_hint: Imagine traveling to Tokyo with this sunflower growing out of your pupil. Imagine all the strange looks you get at the airport and while you’re on the plane to Tokyo. This sunflower can’t get removed soon enough.

meaning_story: You hold a helmet over your heart and Sauron has a nail over his rather than anything protective. You think he’s holding a nail over his heart rather than anything protective because Sauron is so confident in his abilities that he needs no protection like a helmet or anything and would rather just intimidate you with a nail.
meaning_hint: Look at Sauron holding this nail over his heart. Now you feel pretty silly for holding a helmet over yours rather than something cool like a nail.
reading_story: You shout as you charge at Sauron and rather than shouting back at you, Sauron neighs (ねい) like a horse! Why would Sauron neigh rather than shouting or something? Perhaps he is trying to confuse you so you let your guard down.
reading_hint: Hear Sauron neigh over and over again as he gallops at you like a horse. You ponder his reasons for doing this rather than something normal as he continues to neigh and close the distance between you.

meaning_story: The leader of your sad life aims a kick at the sack you are holding. This leader is in charge of making your life sad. The next step in the leader making your life suck is attempting to kick your sack out of your hands. Your sack holds all your valuables, so it’s not something you want to have kicked.
meaning_hint: See this leader’s kick coming at your sack. Hear the leader yelling as he aims his kick at your sack. Hiyahhh! Also keep in mind that the life radical is missing the little drop/slide thing on the side. It’s missing that because your life is lousy and sad.
reading_story: You manage to get your sack out of the way as you shout “Heyo (ひょう)! Look, you missed! Heyo!” Unfortunately your leader’s friend was standing behind you and he kicks your sack as you move it out of the way. “Heyo!” he shouts, mockingly.
reading_hint: You thought you were all cool saying “heyo” and moving your sack away from the kick, but they had this planned all along. Heyo…

meaning_story: Inside a mountain is poop and more poop from a secluded individual living there. The mountain itself is pretty secluded, being away from all civilization. The secluded man living inside this secluded mountain leaves his poop inside the mountain. All you see in there is poop, poop, and more poop.
meaning_hint: Imagine being secluded in this mountain with all of this poop. Poop mountain. Smell the awful stench permeate your very being. It’s absolutely dreadful.
reading_story: Who is secluded inside this poop filled mountain? Why it’s you (ゆう)! You are the secluded man inside this poop mountain. You’re disgusting.
reading_hint: Since you are the one inside this mountain, imagine yourself pooping inside of it. You poop, poop, and poop some more. All inside this secluded mountain. Do you feel good about what you did?

meaning_story: With the power of your mouth you command a tree to become a shelf. Most of the time one would have to use their hands and tools to turn a tree into a shelf, but you are capable of turning a tree into a shelf by using the power of your mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine using your mouth to turn a tree into a shelf. Yell at this tree and keep yelling at it until you see it become a shelf.
reading_story: Once you turn the tree into a shelf you put the shelf in your car (か) and sell it at a local pawn shop. You keep doing this over and over again until you are rich. You command the trees to turn into shelves and then you take the shelves in your car to sell them. Easy money.
reading_hint: Imagine transporting the shelves in your car. Over and over. Back and forth in your car. Vroom vroom.

meaning_story: A sunflower tells a dog with a fish tail to shut up. The fish tail dog is barking and barking because it has a fish tail. This is not normal so the dog is freaking out. The sunflower is really annoyed by this dog, so the sunflower tells the dog to shut up.
meaning_hint: Imagine the dog yelping around with its fish tail. Then a sunflower comes to life and yells “SHUT UP!!”
reading_story: The dog takes offense to this and starts to mock (もく) the sunflower, saying “Shut up~ Shut up~ Nyah~” and sticks its tongue out. The dog doesn’t like to be told to shut up, so he results to mocking the sunflower. The sunflower doesn’t like to be mocked.
reading_hint: You can mock the sunflower too. Just tell the sunflower to shut up in a mocking voice. Go ahead, try it.

meaning_story: You use your car and an axe to slice down a pedestrian. This innocent guy is just walking along the road when you drive up to him in your car and axe him to death with your axe. You’re all like, VROOM! AXE! Now this guy is dead because you sliced him down in cold blood.
meaning_hint: Imagine driving your car, waving your axe out the window and slicing this guy down. Hear his scream ring in your ears as you slice, slice, SLICE.
reading_story: You were driving around in Zanzibar (ざん) when you sliced down this man. Luckily, Zanzibar has no laws at all, so you won’t get arrested for slicing down this guy with your axe.
reading_hint: Zanzibar is a crazy place, huh? Continue to drive around Zanzibar as you wave your axe out your car window looking for another victim to slice.

meaning_story: The stand supports Two Face, the sovereign ruler of the universe. The stand has a couple extra legs holding it up higher than usual, but that makes sense since the sovereign ruler of the universe is held in higher regard than anyone else ever. Bow down before the sovereign and almighty Two Face!
meaning_hint: Two Face is your sovereign ruler. You must bow to him, so imagine bowing over and over again to your sovereign ruler, Two Face.
reading_story: Since you have shown such great respect towards your sovereign ruler, Two Face, he decides to bestow upon you a single tater (てい) tot. What graciousness! Your sovereign ruler has given you a tater tot! The highest of all honors!
reading_hint: Hold this tater tot in your hands. It is a precious gift from your sovereign ruler. You want to eat it and you can feel your mouth watering, but you must keep it as a reminder of this momentous day. Dang, it sure smells good though.

meaning_story: Someone in a top hat comes up to you and tells you that all the pine trees in your yard are going to be taxed from now on because of a new tariff that's been enacted. You can put a tariff on trees? Only pine trees? You didn't know that. But this guy does have a very official looking top hat. Top hatted people do seem like they're associated with tariffs.
meaning_hint: Imagine a top hat wearing man pointing at all of your pine trees and explaining how much the tariff will be. You have to pay it right away, he says. Darn.
reading_story: As he's telling you about the tariff, he happily tells you that your pine trees are just so-so (そ). That means you don't have to pay as much as people with really nice pine trees. That's a relief I guess. It's a good thing you never took care of your pine trees because they lowered how much of the tariff you have to pay now!
reading_hint: Imagine being happy that someone called your trees so-so because it means you don't have to deal with such a high tariff. Cool! I guess...

meaning_story: The gold from the east needs tempering before it can be sold. The gold from the east is good, it just needs some tempering before it’s entirely presentable. You know, tempering like you’d do in a forge.
meaning_hint: Imagine tempering this gold from the east. You’re heat treating the gold when you’re tempering it, so feel the heat from the fire on your face and arms.
reading_story: The smithy where you’re doing the tempering is pretty fancy, but it’s just a rental. You haven’t sold enough gold to own a smithy as nice as this one yet, so for now, you rent one. It is pretty swanky though, even for a rental.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in this rental smithy. It’s really nice. There’s like TVs and live music and free WiFi and everything. It’s a very nice rental in which to do tempering. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares its reading with 練, which has the same right side.

meaning_story: Beware if you see a butcher in a top hat wandering around. He'll try to thwart all your plans! I mean, just look at him over there. He's definitely up to something. Better get out of here before he tries to thwart your plans too!
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to go to dinner when a top hat wearing butcher jumps out and steals your wallet. He thwarted your dinner plans! Noooo!
reading_story: Your plans were thwarted, and now you're having a so-so (そ) night. It's not awful, because your date paid for dinner instead. But that wasn't your plan! Now the it feels so-so to you.
reading_hint: This so-so night could have been a so awesome night if your plans hadn't been thwarted.

meaning_story: You stop a drunkard from going down a slide with a jackhammer to ask him how many years old he is. Those are a lot of dangerous things he's doing. Jackhammering, being drunk, sliding down a slide, I mean, come on! So you better ask him how many years old he is. He might be too young (or too old!) to be doing these things!
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to stop a drunkard from sliding with a jackhammer to ask him how old he is. You're doing it for his own good!
reading_story: You manage to stop the drunkard to check how many years old he is and realize that he's a cyclops (さい). You have no idea how cyclops age! Even if you asked, you wouldn't know if that was enough to tell if he was breaking any laws. You better ask you old friend Hard Gay. He knows everything about cyclops lore. He sei (せい) sei sei's his way over and then sei sei sei's at the cyclops. But you don't know what they're sei-ing! You just wanted to know how many years old this guy was!
reading_hint: Imagine the cyclops sei sei seiing at Hard Gay and then Hard Gay sei sei seiing back at the cyclops. You have no idea how many years old either of them are. This didn't help at all!

meaning_story: The rain orders you to slow your speed to zero. You can’t be driving this fast in the rain. The rain is coming down so badly that you have to slow down your speed to zero. Your orders are to stop moving until the rain has let up.
meaning_hint: Imagine how bad the rain must be for you to be ordered to bring your speed down to zero. It’s really bad. Hear the pounding of the torrential rain and the thunder in the background.
reading_story: You have to keep your speed at zero until you see a ray (れい) of sunshine. Once you see that first ray, additional rays will be sure to follow and it will be safe to move faster than zero miles per hour once again.
reading_hint: Imagine the rain starting to let up and seeing that first ray of sunshine. It’s so beautiful. Envision this heavenly ray that signifies your being allowed to start moving again. Also keep in mind that this shares its reading with 令, the bottom part of this kanji.

meaning_story: A demolition man that Two Face is friends with (because he's also a demo man sometimes) team up to steal a bunch of cash! Cash is all these two think about! And they're gonna blow a hole in the bank to steal some!
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing demolition man and two face running away from a smoking hole in the bank with bags loaded with cash. It's almost too much cash for them to handle!
reading_story: They can't seem to carry all the cash they stole and the police are coming so they stash the cash in a hay (へい) stack. No one would think to look there! Once this blows over they'll come back and dig through the hay for their stolen cash!
reading_hint: Maybe they should change it to "Like looking for cash in a hay stack!" Except it's pretty easy. Just scratchy and annoying.

meaning_story: You give bamboo to someone and they make them into chopsticks. They are very talented at turning bamboo into bamboo chopsticks. This someone is an expert at their profession.
meaning_hint: Watch this person take ordinary bamboo and transform it into chopsticks right before your eyes. Hear the whooshing and whittling sounds as they form the bamboo into chopsticks with expert speed and precision.
reading_story: Now use those chopsticks to eat some delicious hash (はし) browns! That's what chopsticks were made for. That's what they're always made for.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to pick up hash browns with your chopsticks. They would be really hard to eat if you didn't have these handy eating tools!

meaning_story: The eye of an ox is clear. How would be able to see out of it if it wasn’t clear? Duh. The eye of an ox is clear.
meaning_hint: Look at this clear eye belonging to the ox. You can see right through it! Cool.
reading_story: You like the ox’s clear eye so much that you steal it and row (りょう) down the river with it. Everyone knows that ox can’t swim, so hopping in a row boat and rowing away is a good escape strategy.
reading_hint: Row, row, row your boat away from the ox who just realized you stole his clear eye. Look at him through the clear eye. Boy, he looks angry.

meaning_story: On a mountain cliff there is a grave and then another grave, and also another cliff! This is the mountain cliff of redundancy. Like, cliff-ception or something. There’s also two graves as well.
meaning_hint: Imagine standing next to these two graves and seeing the one cliff and then the other. You’re afraid of heights, so the double cliff is really freaking you out.
reading_story: As you’re peering over the cliff, somebody behind you shouts, “Hey, guy (がい)!” This startles you and you tumble down one cliff and then the other. The guy who shouted at you shouts again. “Hey guy! Are you okay? Guy? Guy!!!”
reading_hint: Imagine the pain you feel from tumbling down these cliffs. That guy shouting guy is getting pretty annoying too. He just keeps saying “guy” over and over again! Maybe those two graves are for people he killed with his annoying voice.

meaning_story: Without a fire, you will lack the ability to cook anything. You really need a fire to cook properly. Having a fire will make sure any cooking endeavors you attempt will not fail.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as you cook with a fire very confidently. Knowing you cannot fail, feel the heat and hear the crackling embers of the fire. Smell the delicious smell of whatever you are cooking as well.
reading_story: You cook your meal evenly by swinging (すい) it back and forth over the fire. You swing it left, you swing it right. You swing it to, you swing it fro. All this swinging ensures a properly cooked meal.
reading_hint: Imagine swinging this meal over the fire. Feel the flames licking at your fingertips as you cook this meal by swinging it back and forth over the fire.

meaning_story: Seeing rice and your mullet in a grave moves you to tears so you must reapply your cosmetics. You are very attached to both rice and your mullet, so seeing them both in a grave makes you very sad. You started the day off wearing a lot of cosmetics, and crying over the stuff in the grave makes your cosmetics run, so you must reapply them.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself trying to not cry over the rice and the mullet as you cake on more cosmetics in the mirror. Powder your nose and paint your lips!
reading_story: You need all your cosmetics to be in pristine condition because later you are visiting the shogun (しょう). The shogun invited you to his place to offer his condolences for your lost rice and mullet, and your cosmetics need to look perfect so you don’t embarrass yourself.
reading_hint: Imagine going to the shogun and feeling the weight of the cosmetics on your face. Keep trying not to cry. Ruining your finely applied cosmetics in front of the shogun would be a bad move.

meaning_story: A butcher uses horns to skin a pig before he throws it into a grave, hearing it crash into the earth. The horns the butcher has are very sharp. They cut through pig flesh with ease. The butcher just wants the pig skin, so he tosses the rest of the pig into a mass grave where they crash into the other pig carcasses there. What a waste of bacon.
meaning_hint: Listen to the sickening crash of pig meat and bones as the butcher tosses them into the grave. CRASH CRASH CRASH.
reading_story: Before they crash into the mass pig grave, the butcher has to call them over by yelling “SOOEY! (つい) Here pig pig pig. SOOEEEYYY!!” You are familiar with this pig call, no? Sooey!
reading_hint: Imagine you are calling these pigs and they all come at you at once and crash into you. Sooey! CRASH.

meaning_story: A crab will never lack deceit. Crabs are very deceitful creatures and will deceive you at every given opportunity.
meaning_hint: Imagine this crab, filled with deceit. He looks evil and conniving. Imagine him clicking his claws as he comes up with new deceitful ways to deceive you and everyone you love.
reading_story: The crab presents you with a guitar (ぎ). But it’s actually a lute. Deceit! The crab has fooled you again! HAHAHA! That’s not a guitar at all!
reading_hint: You thought you were getting a guitar, but it’s actually a lute. Man, you really wanted a guitar, too. Dang crab and all his deceit. Lousy.

meaning_story: A tsunami hits your mohawk and it begins to drip. The water from the tsunami continues to drip from your mohawk long after the tsunami has passed. There’s a lot of water in your hair now, so it’s probably going to drip for a while.
meaning_hint: Imagine having all this tsunami water in your hair. Hear it drip from your mohawk. Drip… drip… drip…
reading_story: Luckily, you’re a self-proclaimed techie (てき), so you develop a device to stop the drip drip dripping. This techie device of yours is like a hair dryer helmet. You put it over your mohawk, it does its thing, and your hair is dry! Being a techie sure does have its benefits.
reading_hint: Feel the weight of this dryer helmet on your head as you listen to it whirr away. The dripping has finally stopped! Success!

meaning_story: Next to a grave is a flag being stabbed with the horns of a lantern by a fence. You’re leaning over a fence and using the horns on the lantern to poke holes in the flag by the grave. You don’t like the person buried there, so you are defacing his grave by ruining the flag there. You can’t get inside, but you can lean over the fence to poke the flag.
meaning_hint: Imagine straining yourself over this fence to poke the flag with the lantern. Hear the fabric of the flag rip as you stab away at it.
reading_story: While you struggle to poke holes in the flag, you notice some hay (へい) bales on your side of the fence. You push, pull, and drag the bales and stack them up, using them to get over the fence. Awesome, now you can really do some damage.
reading_hint: Picture yourself piling up bales of hay so that you can climb over the fence to get to the grave of that guy you hate.

meaning_story: The rain takes the task of creating fog. You see, the rain water is needed to make fog. The fog has water droplets in it which come from the rain. So the rain has the very important task of creating fog.
meaning_hint: Imagine being out in the rain and the fog. Feel the cold rain striking you from above and getting you all wet as the fog swirls around you.
reading_story: With all the fog, it’s hard to find the right key from your key ring (きり). You’re trying to get into your house, but you can’t see your key ring because of all the fog. The fog is really thick so you just fumble around with y our key ring until you finally find the right one.
reading_hint: Imagine bumbling about with this key ring in the fog. Hear the keys jingle on the key ring as the fog continues to swirl about, obstructing your vision.

meaning_story: After passing through a door, you use a feather to put the finishing touches on a folding fan. The door leads to your folding fan workshop where you make all your folding fans. This folding fan is now complete that you’ve added a feather to it. How lovely it is.
meaning_hint: Use this folding fan to fan your face. Feel the refreshing breeze as you admire the gorgeous feather you just added. What a fashionista you’ve become.
reading_story: Your biggest folding fan customer is a centaur (せん). This centaur just loves your folding fans and this one you just made with the feather was for the centaur’s latest order. You go back out your door and deliver this folding fan to the centaur.
reading_hint: Imagine handing this newly made folding fan to the centaur. See his face light up with delight as he examines your fine craftsmanship and starts fanning himself with it. Another satisfied customer!

meaning_story: The door filled with injustice is the front door. Every front door is just filled with injustice. Don’t believe me? Look at a front door. Touch it. Feel it. Taste it. Tastes like injustice, doesn’t it?
meaning_hint: Imagine doing all these things to a front door. It would be strange to do, I suppose. But really, front doors are just filled with injustice – I swear.
reading_story: Since this front door is filled with such injustice, you decide to set it on fire and you can feel the heat (ひ) coming off it. The heat of the fire burns all the injustice away from the front door.
reading_hint: Imagine setting your front door on fire. Don’t actually do it though! Imagine the heat coming off the door. Feel it on your hands and face. Visualize all the injustice burning away in the flames.

meaning_story: This fish stick is so good, I’m going to hold a grudge against you. I’m holding this grudge, because the fist stick you made is way more good than the fish stick I made, so now I am jealous and salty. I will hold a grudge against you for being better at fish stick making.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding a grudge against someone and their good fish stick creation skills. Darn them for being so good at it. It’s unfair.
reading_story: To help alleviate some of the anger you’re feeling from this grudge, you sic your pet condor (こん) on the guy who made a better fish stick than you. The condor pecks both of his eyes out. Now he holds a grudge against you!
reading_hint: Imagine the condor plucking the guy’s eyes out. It’s gruesome. You start to not feel your grudge as much anymore, and you start to feel bad for what you’ve done. You took this too far, man – way too far.

meaning_story: Two Face has the sun in his eye, so he puts on a hat for shade. The hat shields both of his eyes, so Two Face is much happier when he wears his hat when he’s out in the sun.
meaning_hint: Imagine Two Face putting on this hat and standing defiantly in front of the sun. The sun shines brightly, but the hat he wears protects him!
reading_story: He especially needs this hat because he is shooting a bow (ぼう) and arrow at a target. Without the hat, he wouldn’t be able to see the target clearly and would point his bow in the wrong direction.
reading_hint: Imagine Two Face wearing his hat and shooting this bow. Hear the string stretch and twang with each shot.

meaning_story: You have a fish stick mask that you hate. And with good reason – this mask made from fish sticks is revolting. It’s gloppy and yucky and smelly. This fish stick mask is worthy of your hate. No doubt.
meaning_hint: You hate this mask. Feel the hate boiling inside you as you smell the rotten smell of old fish sticks. Bleh.
reading_story: You are in the hate zone (ぞう). In the zone of hate. Nothing can bring you out of this hate zone except for destroying this mask. Destroy the mask.
reading_hint: Imagine smashing the dish stick mask to smithereens. Hit it with your hate fist, kick it with your hate feet. Hate, hate, hate. You’re in the zone!

meaning_story: The leader of a narwhal construction crew needs all the help he can get. The narwhals are beginning construction on an underwater city. The leader knows the narwhals are hard construction workers, but they’ll need some help building this city.
meaning_hint: Imagine being the narwhal leader and asking others for help. Ask a shark for help. Ask a whale for help. Ask a shrimp for help. Go on, ask.
reading_story: Then you discover a saw (さ) who would be a great big help. This saw is very strong and would help you and your narwhal construction team out a lot. You should make use of this saw right away.
reading_hint: Imagine using this saw and realizing how big of a help it is. Hear the saw sawing away as you and your fellow narwhals get to work.

meaning_story: A nailbat with a thousand things should say humbly, “Please, take this insert”. The thousand things the nailbat has are inserts. He says humbly that he wants you to take one. Since he says it so humbly and he has like a thousand others, you happily take the insert from him.
meaning_hint: Imagine the nailbat offering you this insert. Feel the paper in your hands. Turn the insert over and fold the insert open.
reading_story: The insert is a promotion for teaching you how to sew (そう). The nailbat is in charge of handing out these inserts to people who want to learn how to sew. How did the nailbat know that you too wanted to learn how to sew?
reading_hint: Look at the sewing pictures in the insert. There’s a needle and a thread and people actually in process of sewing. You can’t wait to learn how to sew too!

meaning_story: A leader and Wolverine take a slide to Italy. Wolverine’s leader is Professor X, and they are both sliding down a big slide to Italy. How fun!
meaning_hint: Imagine Wolverine and his leader Professor X going down this slide to Italy. Hear them wooping and cheering as they ride down the slide. Whee~
reading_story: Before Professor X can get off the slide into Italy, a large eagle (い) swoops down and plucks him right out of his wheelchair. That eagle is very strong. Goodbye, Professor X!
reading_hint: Imagine this eagle carrying Professor X away from Italy and out over the ocean. You can also remember this reading easily because Italy starts with the letter I. Super simple stuff.

meaning_story: They say the key to telling a lie is to totally believe the lie yourself. They say that if you believe your own lie, others will believe it as well. This is key.
meaning_hint: Imagine an actual key going from you to another person. This key is the lie. You gotta believe in the lie for it to reach the other person and unlock their understanding. Visualize this visual lie.
reading_story: The lie you told was about not stealing your buddy’s saw (さ). You actually did steal his saw. He saw you steal his saw, but now you are trying to lie your way out of it. It’s not going well.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to lie your way out of this. He saw you steal his saw. He caught you red handed. What sort of lie can you spin to get yourself out of this situation?

meaning_story: A woman with a mouth bears likeness to all other women with mouths. Am I saying all women look the same? No. Just all women with mouths. They all bear a likeness to one another. Y’know, because they all have mouths.
meaning_hint: Look at a woman and another woman. See how they have a shared likeness. It’s most definitely because they each have a mouth.
reading_story: The woman takes offense at you comparing her likeness to all women just because of her mouth and hits you in the face with a jo (じょ). Can you guess where she hits you with the jo? That’s right. She hits you in the mouth.
reading_hint: Imagine getting hit in the mouth with a jo for saying that all women bear the same likeness because they all have mouths. What a silly thing for you to have said.

meaning_story: Superman has a mouth with lips. The lips on his mouth are super, just like him. Superman has some super lips on his mouth, doesn’t he?
meaning_hint: Look at superman move his mouth and pucker his lips. He’s making duckfaces at you. His lips are nice, but he’s getting kind of annoying with all this flaunting he’s doing.
reading_story: Superman’s favorite thing to touch to his lips is a nice cold Kuchi beer (くちびる). The Kuchi people are Afghan Pashtun nomads. They are lesser known for their amazing beer. Superman loves Kuchi beer! Kuchi beer is the best thing for Superman to touch to his lips. Mmm… Kuchi beer.
reading_hint: Imagine you are Superman drinking this Kuchi beer. It’s so good once it hits your lips.

meaning_story: A viking moves your mouth with his hand to manipulate it. He sticks his hand into your mouth. With the viking’s hand in your mouth, he can make you look like you’re saying anything he wants.
meaning_hint: Imagine the viking having his hand in your mouth. Taste his salty flesh on your tongue. Imagine him manipulating your mouth and your jaw and making it look like you are saying all sorts of funny things.
reading_story: The viking continues to manipulate your mouth even though he knows you are the shogun (しょう) of Japan. Yes, you are the shogun himself. The viking is manipulating your mouth to manipulate the people of Japan. The viking is manipulating and using you to control the country.
reading_hint: Imagine being in front of a huge crowd of Japanese people as the shogun of Japan. Feel the viking’s hand in your mouth as you address them, his words coming out of your mouth as he manipulates your every move.

meaning_story: A wave crashes into a woman, transforming her into an old woman! The wave washes away all of the woman’s makeup, revealing her to be an old woman. The makeup she had on made her appear to be a much younger woman, but once the wave washed away her makeup, she was revealed for the old woman she is.
meaning_hint: Imagine a gorgeous woman. Now see her get hit by a wave of water and turn into an old woman. The old woman could still be pretty too, she just looks way old now. Like ancient.
reading_story: In an attempt to distract you from the fact that she is actually an old woman, the old woman starts to baa (ば) and act like a sheep. The old woman goes “Baa! Baa!” and hops around on all fours like a sheep.
reading_hint: Imagine this old woman acting like a sheep, just saying “baa” over and over and over again. Baa! Baa! Baa!

meaning_story: With a lid, you hit yourself in the mouth and then kick it like a pathetic loser. You kick the lid, even though it is your fault that you hit yourself in the mouth with it. It’s not the lid’s fault. You don’t need to kick it. You’re being pathetic.
meaning_hint: Imagine kicking this lid and with each kick you feel a little bit more pathetic. Your mouth hurts a lot too.
reading_story: You kick the lid one last time and it bounces off the wall and hits you in the eye (あい). How pathetic. You are a pathetic mess. You should have never kicked the lid. Now both your eye and your mouth are in pain, you pathetic fool, you.
reading_hint: Hold your eye with one hand and your mouth with the other. Feel them pulse in pain as you reflect on how pathetic you are today.

meaning_story: An insect specializing in construction builds a rainbow. Did you ever wonder where rainbows come from? Construction insects build them. Construction insects build rainbows.
meaning_hint: Imagine this insect with a construction hat on, building a rainbow. He works very fast. The resulting rainbow is beautiful!
reading_story: This rainbow building insect is so needy (にじ). He is needy because he needs everyone to look at his rainbow and praise him for what he’s done. “Look at my rainbow! Look at how good it is and I am! I’m so needy! Needy for praise and recognition!”
reading_hint: Imagine this construction insect being all whiny and needy for attention and stuff. It’s pathetic. Hear him whine and whine because of how needy he is.

meaning_story: A big treasure treasure treasure treasure is refreshing! Sorry, I can’t say treasure treasure treasure treasure without saying it four times. See? I did it again. Anyway, this big treasure treasure treasure treasure is really refreshing. It’s been a long time since you found a treasure treasure treasure treasure, so finding this big one is really refreshing.
meaning_hint: Imagine finding this big treasure treasure treasure treasure and being really refreshed and relieved and happy. This treasure treasure treasure treasure is so big, you’ll be set for life!
reading_story: You’d had a sour (さわ) taste in your mouth for not being able to find any treasure treasure treasure treasure for such a long time, but now that you found this big one, the sour taste is totally gone and it’s sooooo refreshing!
reading_hint: Imagine the most sour taste you could ever imagine. So super-duper sour! Now imagine that sour taste instantly melting away once you discover this big refreshing treasure treasure treasure treasure. Jackpot!

meaning_story: You keep your tongue to your self to give your heart a rest. You’ve been talking and moving your tongue around all day expressing your feelings. This has tired both your tongue and your heart out, so you stop your tongue moving and decide that you need some self time, some time to rest.
meaning_hint: Stop moving your tongue. Put your hand over your heart. Breathe. Rest. Relax.
reading_story: You can’t rest for long though because the KKK (けい) are here! Oh crap! Your heart is beating out of your chest. Why are the KKK here? Are they going to set you on fire? I don’t know! Get out of there, man! Run!
reading_hint: You didn’t get to rest for long did you? But why did the KKK show up after you stopped expressing your feelings to give your heart some time to rest? It’s a mystery. Just imagine yourself running away from torch wielding KKK members. Scary.

meaning_story: This shrimp is the exact length of a shaku, or Japanese foot. That’s how they came up with this form of measurement. They measured the length of this shrimp and it was the length of a Japanese foot which they deemed the shaku. It’s equal to 30.3cm, very close to one imperial foot.
meaning_hint: Imagine this foot long shrimp. It’s pretty big. Imagine it squirming about making a “shaku shaku” sound as it worms about.
reading_story: How is shaku, the Japanese foot, pronounced by Shaq (しゃく) in Japanese? Why Shaq pronounces it shaku. It’s pronounced shaku both in English and Japanese.
reading_hint: Imagine Shaq dribbling the shrimp like a basketball, saying “shaku, shaku, shaku” every time he bounces the shrimp.

meaning_story: On a stone, every nine years, you take a cross and you smash it. You smash one cross every nine years on this stone to honor your ancestors. They did not like crosses because they were vampires. Actually you are a vampire too.
meaning_hint: Take this cross and smash it on the stone! Hear the wood break and splinter as you remember all your vampire family who went before you.
reading_story: The stone where you smash this cross is to commemorate all your ancestors who were killed by a cyclops (さい), the vampire’s mortal enemy. The cyclops would take a cross and smash it into the vampire’s heart, killing them dead.
reading_hint: Imagine being a vampire and having a cyclops smash a cross into your heart, killing you. See the malice and hate in the cyclops’ on eye as he drives the cross into your chest.

meaning_story: Your rice fortune is sticky. Rice is sticky. So is your rice fortune. Your fortune of rice is sticky because it is made up entirely of sticky rice.
meaning_hint: Look at this sticky rice fortune of yours. Run your hands through it and feel the sticky rice between your fingers. Hear the sticky sucking sounds and you stir the sticky rice about.
reading_story: This rice is so sticky that you are able to sculpt nendoroids (ねん) from it. Your rice fortune is worth even more now that you are hand making limited edition nendoroids from it.
reading_hint: Imagine sculpting these sticky rice nendoroids with y our bare hands. Feel the sticky rice between your fingers as you smush the rice into cure little nendoroids.

meaning_story: If you own your own rice paddy and you wear a top hat on your forehead, then you're the kind of person who has tatami mats in your home. They feel pretty fancy to non-Japanese people. So if you see someone wearing a top hat and working in a rice paddy, you can assume they have a nice big, tatami mat covered home too!
meaning_hint: Imagine being the type of person who has their own rice paddy, a top hat to put on their forehead, and tatami mats on their floors. You're so cool!
reading_story: You decide to visit one of these people to see their tatami mats and as you walk in, staring at the ground you hear a familiar voice. It's... it's... Joseph (じょう) Stalin? Darn! You should have known! But the top hat was covering his face... well at least these tatami mats are nice.
reading_hint: Imagine admiring Joseph Stalin's tatami mats. He has a lot because he has a big house. I guess it was worth it...

meaning_story: The moon is the same as your torso. Because you’re so FAT! AHHAHAHAHAHA. I’m sorry, that was mean. But really, if your torso was as big as the moon, you’d have one large torso, y’know?
meaning_hint: Imagine if your torso was as large as the moon. You’re a gigantic human. Imagine floating around in space like this. Wooooaaaahhh.
reading_story: Your torso got so big because of all the doughnuts (どう) you ate. You ate so many doughnuts that your torso got to be the size of the moon and then you floated away into space with your own gravitational pull and everything. Doughnuts are dangerous things.
reading_hint: Imagine how many doughnuts you would have to eat to get your torso this size. Now imagine eating all of those doughnuts. I hope you like doughnuts, because you’re going to be eating a lot of them.

meaning_story: Two Face has a towel. Good for him. Two Face always deserved his own towel, and now he has one.
meaning_hint: Imagine Two Face with his towel. He looks so happy holding his towel. You feel happy that he is happy.
reading_story: Two Face loves this towel so much that he plans to pass it on to his next of kin (きん). This towel will stay in his family for generations to come. He can’t wait to pass it on to his next of kin.
reading_hint: Imagine Two Face passing this towel on to his next of kin. It’s like a big ceremony. You hear music and see lights and all kinds of stuff. This is a bit over the top, dontcha think?

meaning_story: There are flowers growing around a heart with a wick sticking out of it. The heart is a sacrifice to the old gods and the life energy bleeds from the burning wick to feed the flowers. The wick burns, releasing the power of the heart which spreads into the ground around the heart causing the flowers to grow.
meaning_hint: See this morbid scene. As the wick burns you can smell the smell of burning organs. The flowers are pretty though.
reading_story: Sometimes the wick burning the heart isn’t enough for the flowers to grow properly and they get thirsty for the blood from your shin (しん). So, you slice open your shin with a sacrificial knife and drip your blood over the thirsty demon flowers.
reading_hint: Imagine slicing your shin with a knife, causing blood to drip on the flowers around the heart with a wick in it. Your shin really hurts from the injury, but the flowers are rejoicing as they’re showered in blood.

meaning_story: A tree that is stamped with one pattern, then stamped with another pattern, over and over, is the willow tree.
meaning_hint: A willow tree is a tree that looks like it's on repeat over and over again. It also looks nice on a stamp. Note that the first stamp is kind of an ugly looking backwards stamp, and the second stamp is the normal stamp radical.
reading_story: Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter really loves willow trees. Ryu loves them so much that he makes out with them. Ryu is open mouth kissing a willow tree. You are watching this. It is happening.
reading_hint: Watch Ryu as he French kisses this willow tree. Hear him slurping and moaning in ecstasy. Why are you watching this? This is gross. Wait – is this turning you on!? Ew.

meaning_story: Going down a water slide with horns is a pig who thinks he can accomplish anything. Because the pig has horns, this is why he thinks he can accomplish anything. The thing he is currently trying to accomplish is going down this water slide and surviving.
meaning_hint: Imagine this pig with horns flying down the water slide. Hear the pig squeal as it shoots down. SQUEEEEEEEE~!
reading_story: The next thing the pig wants to accomplish is learning how to swing (すい) on a swing. Immediately after getting off the water slide, the pig runs to swing on a swing.
reading_hint: Imagine the pig swinging on this swing. Hear him squeal as his swings closer to you and father away from you. SQUEE… squee… SQUEE… squee…

meaning_story: Flowers are mysteriously appearing in the rice paddy. No matter what you do to them, they continue to amass.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself spraying poison on these mysterious flowers, but they just double in size, and continue to amass.
reading_story: As the flowers amass it starts attracting wildlife. Soon thousands of baby chicks (ちく) are amassing in the rice paddy as well.
reading_hint: Feel the wetness of the rice paddy under your feet and the fluffiness of the chicks pressing in on you. Watch the looming, mysterious flowers above you as the chicks smother you.

meaning_story: The moon has a lot of power that is power it gets from the power of every armpit of every human on earth! Why does your armpit smell? It’s because the moon is draining the power from your armpit. The moon saps power from your armpit and that power is sucked up into the sky where the moon collects the power for its own devices.
meaning_hint: Imagine an aura of stinky power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Feel the power leaving you as the moon saps your power through your armpits.
reading_story: This is a pretty wacky (わき) armpit image isn’t it? Seeing lines of power traveling from your armpit to the moon. Definitely wacky. Have you ever seen something this wacky in real life?
reading_hint: Imagine this whole scene again but keep in mind how wacky it all really is. The moon sapping power from you through your armpits? So wacky.

meaning_story: In a cage there is a treasure from IKEA that you are planning to assault. You have to assault this cage to get to the treasure inside. The treasure is from IKEA, so you know it’s totally worth it.
meaning_hint: Imagine your assault on this cage. Imagine kicking, punching, and grappling with this cage in vicious assault. Hear the IKEA treasure clinking around in the cage as you do so.
reading_story: Oh (おう) yeah! Your assault worked. The cage busts open and the IKEA treasure comes pouring out. Oh yeah! OH YEAH!
reading_hint: Ohhhh shoot. Your assault was successful and the treasure is now yours. Say “oh yeah” over and over again as you fist pump in triumph.

meaning_story: Having a foul mouth and horns will prevent you from getting into Heaven where you would blossom into an angel. If you have horns, you are not meant for Heaven and not blossom there. To blossom in Heaven, you must not have horns or a foul mouth.
meaning_hint: Swear like a sailor as you imagine yourself with some horns. You’re not going to blossom in Heaven. You’re going to blossom in Hell and become a demon.
reading_story: You don’t want to blossom into a demon so you saw (さ) off your horns with a saw. If you saw off your horns, maybe you can beg for forgiveness and have your foul mouth forgiven.
reading_hint: Imagine taking a saw to your horns and sawing them off. Hear the reverberation of the saw in your skull as you painfully saw off your horns.

meaning_story: The gold is real in this bowl. When the gold is in the bowl, it’s real. When it is not in the bowl, it is imaginary. Keep the gold in the bowl and keep it real.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking the gold in and out of this bowl. It feels like cold metal while it’s in the bowl, but when you take it out, it’s not gold at all. This is a strange bowl.
reading_story: The bowl has a hatch (はち) attached to it, so you close the hatch to keep the gold inside and therefore keep it real. If the hatch is open, the gold can fall out and become unreal, so you keep the hatch closed to keep the gold inside and real.
reading_hint: Close the hatch on the bowl and hear the hatch snap shut. Shake the bowl about and hear your very real gold as it rattles around.

meaning_story: Your servant sits on a stool to open a clam because he is clever. Why stand when you can sit on a stool? This servant of yours is pretty clever to have thought of sitting on the stool.
meaning_hint: Imagine him sitting on the stool. He looks clever. He’s wearing a monocle. You can smell the fishy clam smell as he opens it.
reading_story: Your clever servant is actually Ken (けん) from Street Fighter. Ken opens the clam by shooting a hadoken at it. That’s a bit overboard, Ken.
reading_hint: Imagine Ken sitting on this stool as he hadokens this clam. Now we’ve reached the line between clever and dangerous. HADOKEN!

meaning_story: You use a cleat to climb a tree and your hair becomes the coloring of foliage because your hair is like a chameleon. The coloring of your hair changes to whatever the color is around you. So when you use the cleats on your feet to climb this tree, your hair becomes the coloring of the tree branches and leaves.
meaning_hint: Imagine climbing this tree and then looking at your hair coloring. See the color change to various shades of brown and green.
reading_story: Your hair coloring abilities come in handy because you are hiding from a cyclops (さい) who wants to murder you. The cleats you’re wearing are actually stolen from the cyclops, and now the cyclops is looking for you to get them back. Your hair coloring helps you stay hidden from the cyclops in this tree.
reading_hint: Wrapping your hair that is now the coloring of the tree around you, stay very still and quiet as you watch the cyclops walk around looking for you. Hold your breath and don’t make a peep!

meaning_story: A butcher that is small and a sun that is small both fit into a crevice. The crevice is pretty small too, but since the sun and butcher are small as well, they both fit into it too.
meaning_hint: Look into the crevice and see the small butcher and the small sun. Hear the butcher screaming for you to help him out of the crevice because the sun is way too hot and he’s late for vacation.
reading_story: The butcher wants out of the crevice so he can go ski (すき). He’s vacationing by going on a ski trip, but first he needs to get out of this crevice. He can’t do it without your help.
reading_hint: Imagine taking the small butcher out of the crevice and putting him on a small pile of snow. Watch as he skis down it. He sure does like to ski.

meaning_story: In a grave, you bury a clown and then cultivate crops atop it. The clown acts as a natural fertilizer and makes it super easy to cultivate crops on his grave. Nature is amazing!
meaning_hint: Imagine killing this clown and burying him in the grave. It’s all worth it when you cultivate the crops though. Look at how big and beautiful they are!
reading_story: Before you murder the clown and cultivate your crops, you have to say bye (ばい) to him. Say bye to the clown and then bash his head in and throw him in the grave.
reading_hint: Say bye bye! Bye bye to the clown. Now hear his head crunch and his skull crack as you bludgeon him to death. Crack! Snap!

meaning_story: You move your foot in time with the mama elephant to dance with her. The elephant mama is leading the dance, so you gotta move your foot to the beat and follow her lead.
meaning_hint: Imagine doing this dance with the mama elephant. Move your foot and imagine a mama elephant doing the same.
reading_story: You dance so much that you develop an odor (おど). The odor is so strong that the mama elephant faints mid-dance. Your odor is lethal.
reading_hint: Smell the odor under your arms. It reeks. Looks like you danced too hard this time.

meaning_story: This gate makes the sound of darkness. The gate looks like darkness, but it’s even more creepy that it sounds like darkness too.
meaning_hint: Imagine this gate making an ominous sound. The sound of darkness. Look deep into the darkness of the gate as you hear the sound it makes. Ouummmmm…
reading_story: You decide to taste the darkness and discover that it is so yummy (やみ)! Who knew that darkness was so yummy? Mmm… this darkness tastes so yummy!
reading_hint: Take the darkness in your hands. It’s like really dark cotton candy. Imagine eating it and how yummy it is. Keep hearing the sound it’s making as you eat. Yummy!

meaning_story: You have a surplus of chopsticks laid out diagonally in front of you. Why are they diagonal? And why do you have so many chopsticks? Why the surplus? Truly, this is a mystery for the ages.
meaning_hint: Look at all these chopsticks lying diagonally in front of you. Pick them up. Feel the wood grain. Wonder why you have so many.
reading_story: Then you remember that you are a shaman (しゃ) and the reason you have this surplus of chopsticks laid out diagonally is for a ritualistic shaman ritual you are performing. The chopsticks need to be placed diagonally in order for the ritual to work.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself being a shaman, dressed all in shaman garb. Run your hands over the diagonal chopsticks until you get a splinter. Yeowch!

meaning_story: You cover shrimp with ice to exhaust it. The ice makes the shrimp really tired. Give them enough ice, and they will soon become exhausted.
meaning_hint: Imagine the shrimp getting covered in ice and then being all like, “Man, I’m so exhausted. How did this human know that ice would exhaust me so?”
reading_story: After you exhaust the shrimp, you put some ice on your jeans (じん) to cool yourself down. Exhausting the shrimp exhausted you as well, and you’re really warm from all that work you just did so you put some ice in and on your jeans to cool down a bit.
reading_hint: Imagine putting ice in your jeans. Dang, that’s cold. You can still smell the fishy smell of shrimp in the air though.

meaning_story: Rain falls off a tree and lands in your eye where it turns to frost. It turns to frost because it’s super cold outside and your body is freezing. The rain that fell of the tree turns to frost as soon as it hits your eye.
meaning_hint: Feel the rain hit your eye and then crystalize into frost immediately. The rain in your eye is wet, and then very cold as it becomes frost.
reading_story: This whole description is pretty emo. You came up with this whole emo frost idea because you are a shemo (しも). An emo who goes by she pronouns.
reading_hint: Picture yourself walking proudly, casting your frost gaze at all who you pass. "Wow look at that frosty, cool shemo. She's sooooo cool!" you hear them whisper. (Haha cool, get it? Because you're frosty and also a little sad, which is totally in when you're a teen.)

meaning_story: The pine trees and flowers surround the turkey as he sits on a stool and begins to harvest. The turkey is going to harvest the pine tree sap and the flowers. The harvest will be used to make floral tea and syrup.
meaning_hint: Imagine the turkey sitting on this stool as he picks flowers and drains the pines of their sap. What a great harvest this will be!
reading_story: But the harvest is in jeopardy because an angry cock (かく) just showed up! This male rooster doesn’t want the turkey to harvest the pines or the flowers. The cock asserts that those things belong to him! The cock and the turkey begin to fight.
reading_hint: Imagine the turkey smashing the stool over the cock’s back. A brawl breaks out. Pine tree sap is knocked over and flowers are crushed. It’s brutal.

meaning_story: Your mullet is tied to one tree, and another tree, as you make hemp goods. Your mullet is very strong, so you are able to suspend yourself between two trees by tying your mullet to each tree. You like to take hemp and make stuff from it, so that’s what you do while you’re hanging from these trees by your mullet.
meaning_hint: Feel the weight of gravity pulling on you and your mullet as you make this hemp stuff. What are you making? Hemp clothes? Jewelry? Paper? Whatever it is, imagine making it and feel it in your hands as you hang.
reading_story: Once you finish your hemp creation, you call for your mama (ま) to get you down. Your mama is the one who tied you to the trees by your mullet in the first place, so it is up to your mama to get you back down again.
reading_hint: Still holding the hemp in your hands, imagine wiggling about while you yell for your mama to come get you down. Mama! MAMA! MAMAAAA!?!

meaning_story: An odd horse is still a horse. It may look a little funny, but that doesn't change what it is on the inside.
meaning_hint: Look at this odd horse. Hear it whinny and neigh like a normal horse. It's not so odd, after all.
reading_story: This horse is particularly odd because it knows how to use a key (き). It carries a key around it's neck and uses it to get in and out of it's stable.
reading_hint: Watch the horse take the key in it's mouth and open the stable doors. It may be odd, but it sure is resourceful.

meaning_story: Superman makes a measurement with intent to humiliate you. He makes a measurement of his biceps and then compares his numbers to yours. He does this just to humiliate you since your measurements are inferior to his. Scumbag Superman.
meaning_hint: Imagine Superman as he humiliates you. He’s waving the measurement numbers in your face and laughing at you and your puny arms.
reading_story: Superman loves to humiliate you and calls you a big joke (じょく). Your arms are a joke, your body is a joke, you’re just a big joke, says Superman. He is going to humiliate you as much as possible, it seems.
reading_hint: Imagine Superman continuing to humiliate you and call you a big joke. His face is so close to yours that you can smell his breath and feel his spit on your face as he shouts at you.

meaning_story: You use fire and a nail to make a lamp. The fire heats the nail to a glowing red which you can then use for light, just like a lamp.
meaning_hint: See this glowing red nail. Imagine moving it around in the darkness to illuminate things. See the soft red glow coming from the nail as you feel the heat emanating from it.
reading_story: Use this lamp to explore a dark area of Tokyo (とう). You’re in an abandoned warehouse, and you are using this lamp to explore. This is one of the largest abandoned warehouses in Tokyo and you are there alone with your lamp. It’s pretty creepy.
reading_hint: As you explore this building in Tokyo, imagine using your lamp to illuminate the graffiti that’s written all in Japanese. It’s pretty cool.

meaning_story: In the mysterious rice paddy there is some livestock. This livestock is also mysterious because no one knows where it came from. The mysterious livestock are only seen in the mysterious rice paddy. How mysterious indeed.
meaning_hint: Examine this mysterious livestock from a distance. Imagine them floating around the mysterious rice paddy like they aren’t even walking. Hear them moo and oink as well.
reading_story: Your favorite member of the mysterious livestock crew is a little chick (ちく). The chick is very cute and little. The chick is also very mysterious because it floats about without even flapping its little wings.
reading_hint: Look at this chick bobbling about in the air. It looks very ephemeral and other worldly. Still a very cute chick though. You want to pet it.

meaning_story: The tsunami hits your form and you begin to melt. You are a witch and water makes you melt. The tsunami is a lot of water, so once it touches your form, you begin to melt.
meaning_hint: Feel the water from the tsunami crashing into your form. Feel the water on your body as your form begins to melt. I’m melting! I’m mellltiinnnggg!
reading_story: The only way to reverse the melt process is to eat some yogurt (よう). The yogurt counteracts the melting from the water and your form will become whole again. Quick, eat some yogurt!
reading_hint: Feel the melt begin to reverse as you eat your yogurt. Taste the yogurt on your tongue as your form begins to solidify once again.

meaning_story: The insect on that doll is a mosquito. The mosquito thought that the doll was a real living thing, so it was disappointed when it couldn’t suck the doll’s blood. Mosquitos aren’t the brightest insects around.
meaning_hint: Hear the mosquito buzzing around the doll in frustration as it tries to suck blood from it. Buzz buzz buzz.
reading_story: All the buzzing this mosquito is doing is really bothering you so you run it over with your car (か). VROOM VROOM SQUISH. Using your car was a bit overkill, maybe – but that mosquito was being really annoying so it needed to die.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself using a car to squish a mosquito. Bzzzzz… SQUISH. That mosquito is dead for sure.

meaning_story: Two Face has a long notebook. He uses this notebook to record all the debts people owe him. The notebook is so long because a lot of people owe Two Face money.
meaning_hint: See Two Face studying this long notebook. Hear the long pages flip as he looks through all of the names written there.
reading_story: The name that shows up most often in Two Face’s long notebook is the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう). Mrs. Chou borrows a lot of money from Two Face and it’s time to collect. Two Face is gonna go smack her up with his long notebook. Oh yeah, it also doubles as a bludgeon.
reading_hint: Hear the long notebook cracking against Mrs. Chou’s face as Two Face repeatedly hits her with it. Hear him yelling “Where’s my money!?” as he continues to biff Mrs. Chou with the long notebook.

meaning_story: A tsunami surplus covers every grave with paint. The surplus of tsunamis first strike a paint factory which causes paint to spread everywhere. Then the tsunamis run into a graveyard and the every grave there gets coated with paint from the paint factory.
meaning_hint: Imagine this multicolored tsunami washing over every grave in the cemetery. After the tsunami subsides, every grave there looks like a rainbow.
reading_story: You touch the paint with your toe (と) to see if it’s still wet. It is. The paint is still very wet and now your toe looks like a rainbow. Both your toe and the graves in the graveyard look like rainbows now.
reading_hint: Look at the paint on your toe. You feel its cold wetness as you examine the rainbow paint coating it. It’s kind of pretty.

meaning_story: This clam made a fortune when he decided to paste himself to a banana. The clam made a fortune because many people viewed as daring modern art and paid him a lot. The clam just never wanted to be separated from his favorite fruit, so that’s why he decided to paste himself to it.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are this clam. Paste yourself to the banana. Feel the paste on your hands as you paste yourself to this yellow fruit.
reading_story: You’re a little crazy, which is why you decided to paste yourself to this banana in the first place. Now that you have a fortune, you’re both crazy and giddy. You laugh like a maniac. HAHAHAHAHA (は)! HAHA! HAHAHA!!
reading_hint: Laugh out loud and pretend that you are a clam. You also have a banana pasted to you. How strange and silly! HAHAHA!

meaning_story: The sunlight shines on your forehead in your car with a great radiance. The car you are in is a convertible, so the sunlight shines right onto your big bald forehead. The sun has a pretty powerful radiance as it is, but the sheen from the sunlight hitting your forehead is the most powerful radiance ever witnessed by man.
meaning_hint: Imagine this radiance emanating from your shiny dome. The radiance is blinding!
reading_story: This radiance is the key (き) to powering your car. Your car runs on reflected solar energy, and the radiance coming from your forehead is the most powerful source of radiant sunlight ever imagined. Your forehead is a perfect key for this car.
reading_hint: Point your shiny forehead, filled with radiance, at your car. Hear the engine start and jump to life as you power it with the reflected sunlight from your forehead.

meaning_story: This fish stick gives you an idea, a recollection if you will. You have a recollection of a great idea you had once before but had forgotten. Your great idea has to do with fish sticks. Thank goodness for this recollection you just had.
meaning_hint: Pick the fish stick up in your hands and feel its crispy fishy goodness. Take a bite of the fish stick and feel your mind become instantly active with the recollection you’re having.
reading_story: Your recollection was of your plans to travel to Oklahoma (おく). You want to go to Oklahoma because you’ve heard they have the best fish sticks there. You had this idea once before, but you forgot about it. Now that you’ve had this recollection, you decide that you absolutely must go to Oklahoma.
reading_hint: Now that you’re in Oklahoma, imagine having a fish stick there. See the Oklahoma scenery around you as you chow down on the best fish stick you’ve ever had in your entire life. Oklahoma! Woo!

meaning_story: Eating fish sticks fills you with every kind of regret. Regret for eating a poor fish, regret for eating unhealthily, and regret for having no one to share them with. Every regret enters your body as you eat these fish sticks.
meaning_hint: Imagine eating this fish stick. Taste its fishy regret taste. Feel your body become heavy with every regret imaginable. It’s not pleasant.
reading_story: You regret eating these fish sticks even more when a coyote (かい) shows up. Coyotes love fish sticks and will brutally murder any and every person who has fish sticks so they can steal them. This coyote is going to murder you for your fish sticks.
reading_hint: Feel yourself gaining even more regret as the coyote starts to tear you to pieces. The taste of fish sticks lingers on your tongue as your world slowly fades to black. Oh, regret.

meaning_story: You take a rake in for a measurement but it is resistant. The rake doesn’t want to have its measurements taken. The rake is resistant to have any measurement taken because it feels inferior to the other rakes and doesn’t want to be embarrassed if it ends up being smaller than the others.
meaning_hint: Try and move this rake over to the measurement table. It is resistant so you have a hard time moving it. Imagine the rake struggling and resisting endlessly.
reading_story: Because the rake is persistently resistant, you eventually tie it to the table with your neck tie (たい). The tie won’t hold for long, so you need to take each measurement quickly.
reading_hint: See yourself tying the tie around the rake and attaching it to the measurement table. The rake is still jostling around, but the tie keeps it from moving about too terribly much.

meaning_story: On a cliff, the pope is holding a shield. The pope is near the edge of the cliff and is using the shield to fend off demons. The demons want to shove the pope off the cliff, but the pope is using his holy shield of popery to fend them off.
meaning_hint: Imagine the shield glowing brightly as hymns play in the background. The demons try to get close to the pope to shove him off the cliff but the holy shield is too bright and popey.
reading_story: The light of the pope's shield begins to fade. The shield's holy power is waning! Just as the demons are about to push him off the cliff, the sun begins to rise. That's right! It's June (じゅん) and summer has just begun. The pope's shield reflects the power of June's bright sun into the eyes of the demons, casting them off the cliff behind him and back into hell!
reading_hint: This pope would have been in a lot of trouble if June's summer sun hadn't risen at just the right moment. His shield would have become useless and he might have been shoved off the cliff if it was a less sunny month.

meaning_story: There’s an insect in your helmet so you remove it with a spoon and a snake. You use the spoon to scoop the insect out of your helmet and then the snake eats the insect off the spoon.
meaning_hint: Hear the insect buzzing as you scoop it out with the spoon. The buzzing stops once the snake gobbles it up though.
reading_story: The spoon is really heavy (へび) though, so it takes a lot of strength to move it over to where the snake is. The spoon is made of some really heavy metal. You’re not sure what it is exactly, but it’s really heavy. You hope the snake appreciates this.
reading_hint: Hear the snake hissing as you continue to hold up this heavy spoon. Feel your arm muscles tire and strain as you continue holding it steady.

meaning_story: The king gets his ribs crushed playing with the king’s squad of football players. The king thought it would be fun to play football with the royal football squad. The king ended up getting his ribs crushed. He’s not a smart king.
meaning_hint: Imagine this king playing with the squad of football players. Since there are two king radicals, you can imagine that the king got his ribs crushed so bad that he’s seeing double from the trauma.
reading_story: The star member of the king’s football squad is Han (はん) Solo. Han Solo is actually the one who crushed the king’s ribs. Han Solo is going to get beheaded for this.
reading_hint: Imagine Han Solo and the rest of the squad at the beheading. Imagine Han Solo getting his head chopped off as the king cheers and then clutches his broken ribs in pain.

meaning_story: You’re so hungry that you eat a table so you won’t starve. If you don’t eat this table, you will most definitely starve, so you eat the table to stay alive.
meaning_hint: You don’t want to starve, do you? Feel your tummy gurgle in pain. You gotta eat this table. Taste the dry wood taste on your tongue as you eat the table and get splinters in your tongue and gums.
reading_story: After you finish the table, you still feel like you might starve so you decide to eat every key (き) off your key ring. One by one, you eat each and every key so you don’t starve.
reading_hint: Imagine eating every key. Taste the cold metal on your tongue. After you swallow each key, you hear it clink against the other keys already in your tummy. Clink!

meaning_story: If you have nothing to eat but your ego, you’ll starve. You ego won’t satiate you, so you can’t eat it. And if all you have it your ego to eat (which you can’t), you’re gonna starve for sure. Your ego is preventing you from accepting help from anyone.
meaning_hint: Imagine being so proud and egotistical that you would rather starve than accept help from others. Feel your stomach wasting away as you slowly starve.
reading_story: You continue to starve and when no one is around, you cry “goo-goo ga-ga” (が) like a little baby. Your ego is preventing you from accepting food from others, but it’s not preventing you from crying goo-goo ga-ga like a whiny little whiner.
reading_hint: Now you’re starving and you’re crying. Feel the hot tears on your face and the gurgling in your stomach as you continue to cry out your goo-goo ga-gas.

meaning_story: You go down a water slide off the edge of a cliff and fly over a cross at a swift speed. You almost don’t make it over the cross, but you are going swift enough that you make it.
meaning_hint: The cliff radical is flipped horizontally, but that doesn’t change the fact that you’re flying over it. So swift! Feel the wind on your face as you just barely make it over that cross.
reading_story: Because it was so swift, you don’t notice the hole in your jeans (じん) until after you land. Looks like you snagged your jeans on the cross as you flew over it. So swift was your speed that you didn’t even notice when it happened.
reading_hint: Imagine flying over the cross again but this time try and pay attention to your jeans tearing as it snags. Try to hear the rip of the jeans in your ears.

meaning_story: You have a power that fills you with power, power of the moon that allows you to threaten anyone and everyone. The power of the moon makes you three times as powerful as anyone else, so you are free to threaten everybody because you know you have the power to defeat them in combat.
meaning_hint: Imagine being three times more powerful than the strongest person you can imagine. You have so much power that you could even lift the moon if you wanted! Imagine threatening the moon as you flex your massive muscles.
reading_story: For your next challenge, you decide to threaten the entire city of Kyoto (きょう). You have heard that there are some pretty strong fellows in Kyoto, so you threaten them all with your muscles and challenge everyone to a fight.
