reading_hint: Imagine fighting everybody in Kyoto. You threatened them, and now they are fighting back. Imagine them yelling Japanese battle cries as you fight them off and continue to threaten them and their families with physical harm.

meaning_story: A tree and a good fang are a solid approximation of how much this trinket of yours is worth. That’s because your trinket is made from a tree and a good looking fang. Therefore, the approximation given for how valuable it is should be fairly accurate.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding this good fang tree thing in your hand. Make an approximation for how much it is worth. Turn it over in your hands as you concentrate intently.
reading_story: As you’re making your approximation, somebody comes up and shouts, “Hey guy (がい)! I’ll give you $10,000 for that trinket there, guy!” This guy must be crazy. That’s much more than your approximation of the value of this thing. But you sell it to the guy anyway.
reading_hint: Imagine selling this trinket to the guy and getting $10,000. You’re rich now! “Thanks guy!” he calls after you.

meaning_story: You take a nailbat and beat a paragraph to death with it and then you get placed under arrest. The reason for your arrest is that you beat that paragraph to death with the nailbat for no reason.
meaning_hint: Imagine beating a paragraph to death with a nailbat. Hear it screaming in pain as the life fades from it. Then imagine being placed under arrest for your crime.
reading_story: Who is it that’s being placed under arrest? It’s actually こういち. You are こういち. こういち is the one who has beat this paragraph to death with the nailbat and is getting arrested.
reading_hint: Imagine こういち going insane and beating the crap out of this paragraph with the nailbat. Hear him screaming at the top of his lungs, even as he’s being placed under arrest.

meaning_story: Someone has a fish tail and they begin to boil it. Actually that someone is me. I am the one who will boil this fish tail. I’m making it for you. I am boiling this fish tail to serve to you for a meal. Aren’t you excited?
meaning_hint: As the fish tail begins to boil, you smell the fishy aroma all around you. Hear the water boiling as the smell from the fish tail invades your nostrils.
reading_story: Once the pot reaches a rolling boil and the fish tail is ready, I ask you to get down on one knee (に) to receive your meal. While you’re on your knee, I pour the boiling water on you and then your skin begins to boil! Haha! What a funny joke I have played upon you.
reading_hint: Feel your skin blister and boil from the hot fish tail water. And then your blood begins to boil because you’re so pissed off that someone would actually pour boiling fish tail water on you. How rude.

meaning_story: If a helicopter loiters near a black hole then it's going to capsize. I mean, yeah, it's not a boat, but just look, that's what's happening! That helicopter is going down! If you want to save it you better cover up the black hole! The only way to save it from capsizing is to cover it right up!
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to cover up a black hole so that the helicopter doesn't capsize. It's one or the other, dude. Cover or capsize. You decide.
reading_story: You're doing your best to cover the black hole to stop the helicopter from capsizing but it's not working! “F@#$ you (ふく) black hole!" you shout. You just want to cover it up! You just want to do the right thing!
reading_hint: Man, f@#$ you, black hole. F@#$ you. Making that helicopter capsize and then refusing to be covered? What a d***!!!

meaning_story: The horse who can write a paragraph gets to be a chess piece. Only the most erudite of horses gets selected to be a chess piece. The knight’s chess piece is represented by a horse, and for a horse to earn this honor, they must first write a paragraph explaining why they deserve the honor.
meaning_hint: Imagine a horse trying to write a paragraph about why it deserves to be a chess piece. See the horse struggle with his hooves to write out a paragraph as he neighs in nervous frustration.
reading_story: Upon being told that he will never be a chess piece, the horse slips into a coma (こま). The horse will never awaken from this coma as he knows he will never fulfill his dream of becoming a chess piece, so he has nothing to live for.
reading_hint: See this horse in its coma. You feel bad that it will never be able to be a chess piece, but this is a bit dramatic.

meaning_story: You take fish sticks, five of them, and stick them all in your mouth for reasons beyond comprehension. It’s beyond my comprehension because you hate fish sticks and would never eat one, let alone five of them.
meaning_hint: This act is beyond my comprehension. It’s beyond your comprehension as well. Why are you doing this!? You don’t know!! Taste the fish fish stick taste in your mouth as you wonder in futility.
reading_story: Since this is beyond your comprehension, you decide to play a game of Go (ご) to get your mind off it. While you are focusing on the Go game, you hope your subconscious will gain comprehension of why you put those five fish sticks in your mouth.
reading_hint: Imagine playing Go while your subconscious works on the fish stick comprehension. Hear the Go stones click on the Go board as you play and think.

meaning_story: They say a sweet tree will never conspire against you. It will never conspire because it is so sweet. This is a sweet tree that will never conspire against you they say.
meaning_hint: But! You are suspicious of this sweet tree. It’s too sweet for its own good. You’re positive that this sweet tree is going to conspire against you, regardless of what others say.
reading_story: You’re pretty sure that the sweet tree will conspire to shoot you with a bow (ぼう) and arrow. Why? How am I supposed to know? I’m not a tree.
reading_hint: Imagine getting shot with a bow and arrow by this conspiring sweet tree. Oh! The pain! Hear the bow string twang as you get shot.

meaning_story: There’s a helmet next to a turkey, and a bird is sitting in it. The bird is a crane. The crane looks at the turkey, daring it to try and take it's helmet seat.
meaning_hint: The birds don't like each other. The turkey can't believe a crane is sitting in a helmet like a nest. The crane can't believe the turkey is here judging it.
reading_story: They are not nice to each other, these two birds. They say mean things to each other. They are two rude (つる) birds.
reading_hint: Imagine them saying nasty words at each other. Especially rude ones.

meaning_story: You take a nailbat and a stone and you begin the cultivation of the land. You use the nailbat to till the soil and you use the stone to flatten ground. After you are done with the cultivation you can start your farm business.
meaning_hint: Imagine practicing this cultivation with the nailbat and the stone. Use the nailbat to till the soil and use the heavy stone to smooth out the land.
reading_story: You’re so excited about your cultivation that you talking (たく) to everyone you meet about it. You talk to friends, family, and even strangers! You talk to them all about your cultivation project.
reading_hint: Imagine going to talk to all of these people about cultivation. Imagine going up to them and just saying, “Cultivation! Cultivation, cultivation. Cultivation? Cultivaton.”

meaning_story: You take a lid, and aiming it at the sun you kick it into the air and eventually it begins to decline and crashes into the sun, causing it to supernova. Imagine kicking this lid so hard that it flies into space. See it fly up to the peak of its arch, then watch as it begins the decline until it finally collides with the sun.
meaning_hint: As you watch the lid decline, keep in mind that the sun radical its middle line extending outside the box on both sides. This is because the sun is going supernova. Pew!
reading_story: As the lid begins to decline in the sky, you realize what’s going to happen so you attempt to swing (すい) to safety. Swing one some vines in the direction opposite of the sun. You know that once that lid finishes its decline and collides with the sun, there’s gonna be trouble.
reading_hint: Imagine swinging on these vines as you hear the sun explode and go supernova behind you. Swing faster! Swing faster!

meaning_story: You step on a nailbat with your cleat, whose measurement is pretty big, which is what encourages you to get new shoes. The nailbat’s nails go right through your cleat and into the soft flesh within. Even though your cleats are pretty big, the nailbat goes right in. This encourages you to get some new shoes because these cleats have been ruined by the nailbat.
meaning_hint: The nailbat’s nails are only sticking out one side in this radical, but that’s because the nails on the other side are stuck in your foot. I encourage you to remember this and the endless pain it provides.
reading_story: I especially encourage you to get new cleats before this afternoon when you have to meet the shogun (しょう). You can’t meet the shogun with ruined cleats, damaged by a nailbat. I encourage you to get some nice new shoes before you present yourself to the shogun.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in your shiny new shoes as you shake the shogun’s hand. Your foot still really hurts from the earlier nailbat injury, but I encourage you to suppress the pain as you converse with the shogun.

meaning_story: A tsunami and a couple fires run into each other. They cancel each other out completely, and the remainder left behind is a faint remnant of what was once there.
meaning_hint: You go to see if you can find any remainder of the fire + tsunami battle. You can, but it's so faint.
reading_story: Just like the tsunami and fire canceling each other out, leaving a faint remainder of what was, your tan (たん) is extremely faint as well.
reading_hint: Look at your skin. It has such a faint tint.

meaning_story: There’s a stone, a tree, another tree, and a coat rack. That stone and two trees will make the perfect foundation for a house to put that coat rack in! This stone is flat and heavy and both of the trees are flexible and durable.
meaning_hint: Imagine making a foundation with the stone and the two trees so you’ll have somewhere for your coat rack. Feel the wood grain and cold stone against your skin as you move them around to form the foundation.
reading_story: After you put the foundation together, you realize it is just so-so (そ). It is so-so because you have no idea how to make a foundation. Who were you kidding? Making a foundation with no prior experience? IDIOT!
reading_hint: Now imagine handing the foundation project over to someone who has a clue what they’re doing. Hand them the stone and the two trees. Within seconds the coat rack is standing on them, not falling over or anything. Wow, you really didn’t know what you were doing.

meaning_story: A butcher decides to compare a grave to his highness. The butcher says that both a grave and his highness are cold and deep, and if you fall into one, you’re already dead.
meaning_hint: Imagine how your highness would feel about this comparison. Imagine telling it to her face. Do you think your highness would think this comparison was amusing at all?
reading_story: Here comes her highness now! The butcher is getting ready to run into the streets and tell her about his grave comparison. You know that won't turn out well for him, so as he starts forward you push a hay (へい) bale in front of him with your foot and he trips over it, falling to the ground. Your highness moves on, and the butcher misses his chance. Phew.
reading_hint: Picture the butcher tripping over the hay bale right as her highness was making her way down the street. That hay bale probably saved his life.

meaning_story: In the event of a tsunami, Wolverine, your forehead, and a stool will all be immersed in it. You will become immersed in the tsunami after it hits because tsunamis are gigantic and bring a lot of water. Now you and your forehead are immersed in the tsunami along with Wolverine and a stool.
meaning_hint: Feel the water all around you as you become immersed in this tsunami. See Wolverine trying to swim his way to the top as you watch the stool floating about in the water.
reading_story: Still immersed, the stool floats over and hits you in the shin (しん). The tsunami gave the stool a good push and while it was fully immersed, it ran into your shin. It really hurts.
reading_hint: Hear the stool crack against your shin and feel the pain erupt through your leg. You try to scream but you’re under water so you just get a big mouthful or tsunami.

meaning_story: The few members of society without power suffer from severe inferiority complexes. Most people in this world have lots of power, so the few that do not feel quite inferior. It is this feeling of inferiority that fuels their inferiority complexes.
meaning_hint: Imagine you are one of the few without power. Feel the inferiority crushing down on you. It feels terrible and there is nothing you can do about it.
reading_story: Since you suffer from such extreme feelings of inferiority, when someone offers you and your friends the chance to gain power, you yell “Let’s (れつ) go!” without a second thought. “Let’s go, guys! Come on! Power awaits us!”
reading_hint: Let’s go, let’s go! Time’s a wastin’! I’m tired of this inferiority and want to gain some power!

meaning_story: This crab trap has the power of intuition. By the power of intuition, this crab trap can trap like, every crab. Through intuition, it knows where the crabs will go and how they will react, so it is much easier to trap them.
meaning_hint: Look at this crab trap and see it visibly glowing with intuition. Its powers of intuition are so strong that you can actually see it shimmering with intuition as it expertly traps all those crabs.
reading_story: But it looks like the crab trap’s intuition has failed it this time because it has trapped a can (かん), and not a crab this time. It seems as though an intuitive crab dressed up a can to look like a crab and fooled the crab trap with this can disguised as a crab. How clever.
reading_hint: Imagine this crab fashioning a can to look like another crab. The crab trap’s intuition fails it this time due to the crab’s can decoy being so lifelike and believable.

meaning_story: Chester the molester decides to become a butcher and decides to isolate himself from others. He doesn't want anyone to know his true calling isn't molesting, it's butchering. He's embarrassed to be seen so he isolates himself.
meaning_hint: Imagine Chester the molester learning to become a butcher alone in a dark room. He's decided to isolate himself and dedicate his time to his new craft.
reading_story: After he isolates himself, he butchers a cock (かく). He couldn’t find a chicken to butcher, so he settled on a cock instead. He isolates the cock from the other chickens and then chops off its head.
reading_hint: Imagine him isolating the cock on his chopping block and lopping off its head with his butcher's knife. Chop!

meaning_story: You take a stool, another stool, and yet another stool and stack them on top of a tree to make a mulberry bush. This is how mulberry bushes are made. You take three stools and you put them atop a tree.
meaning_hint: Imagine putting three stools on top of a tree and watching it transform into a mulberry. The science of nature!
reading_story: You then eat a mulberry because a mulberry with cure (くわ) any and all ailments. A mulberry is the cure-all of nature.
reading_hint: Have something you need to cure? Eat a mulberry. Taste the mulberry taste on your tongue as you become cured. Ahh, nice.

meaning_story: You give a flag and a spoon to a nun as an offering. You give her this flag and this spoon because they are very precious to you and you want to show the nun how serious you are about repenting for your evil deeds.
meaning_hint: Imagine handing the nun your country’s flag. And also a spoon that is very valuable to you. Imagine getting down on one knee as you do so.
reading_story: You’re getting down on one knee (に) as you present the flag and the spoon to the nun. The nun accepts your offer and takes your flag and spoon from you. Your soul is saved!
reading_hint: Feel your knee digging into the cold floor as you present your offerings to the nun. You feel slightly sad as she takes your precious belongings from you.

meaning_story: A king takes his slide into his private jet and is given a pearl as a gift. The pearl he receives is from his guest in the jet. That person is you. You see the king slide down his slide and into the jet where you present him with this pearl as tribute.
meaning_hint: Imagine giving this gorgeous white pearl to the king after he slides down his slide and boards the jet. See his king face light up as he sees the pretty pearl.
reading_story: You were carrying the pearl in your shoe (しゅ) before. You didn’t want to lose it, so you transported it in your shoe. That way the constant pain from it rubbing on your foot would assure you that it had not been lost. Hopefully the pearl doesn’t smell like a shoe.
reading_hint: Imagine walking around with the pearl in your shoe. That hurts a lot. It really agitates your foot. Ow. Ow. Ow.

meaning_story: A nailbat can give you a reason to pluck things. The reason is that you have nailbat nails stuck in your skin and you need to pluck them out.
meaning_hint: Imagine having to pluck out nailbat nails from your skin after being hit with it. It hurt badly enough that you got hit with the nailbat, but plucking out the nails hurts even more. Imagine plucking them out one by one.
reading_story: You can’t pluck another nail so you get your friend Chewbacca (ちゅう) to pluck them out for you. Chewbacca is very brave and strong, so he begins to pluck the rest of the nails out of you like a good friend.
reading_hint: Imagine Chewbacca plucking the rest of the nails out of you. Hear him make his Chewbacca noises as he continues to pluck.

radicals: 亠, 土, 旦, 回
meaning_story: On your grave there is a lid designed to prevent you from knowing how many times the sunrise crests over the podium. Someone buried you in this grave and put a lid over it. They didn’t want you to know how many days had passed since you were put in the grave. With the lid over the grave, you can’t see the sunrise and don’t know how many days have passed. Your captor is giving a speech from that nearby podium, but with the lid over you, you can’t quite make out what’s being said.
meaning_hint: Try to visualize this podium in your head from your location. See through the grave lid with your mind’s eye.
reading_story: The guy on the podium’s name is Dan (だん). Yes, you remember now. Dan is the one who has trapped you here in this grave and is now giving a speech from the podium.
reading_hint: Dan! The lout! How could he do this to you? And then give a speech from a podium like nothing happened? Unforgivable.

meaning_story: A butcher has an enclosure where he keeps his can of supplies that he uses to make pottery. The can holds all the things he needs to make pottery. The butcher butchers by day, and does pottery by night.
meaning_hint: Imagine this butcher making pottery. He makes butcher knives and slabs of meat from clay. They look so realistic!
reading_story: The butcher sells this pottery in Tokyo (とう). The Tokyo butcher shops and restaurants use his realistic looking pottery in their store displays to attract customers. The pottery looks so realistic that nobody can tell the difference!
reading_hint: Imagine seeing this pottery in Tokyo. You know how they have a lot of fake food in displays to advertise, right? This is just another one of those things.

meaning_story: That woman with the cobra is the princess. You can tell she is the princess because of the cobra she has. No one but the princess can command a cobra like that. The cobra is wrapped around her head and shoulder, ready to do her bidding.
meaning_hint: Look at the woman with the cobra. This is the princess. Hear the princess cobra hiss as it slithers about. Hisss. Also note that this word can also mean queen.
reading_story: The princess commands the cobra to bite you and you feel the heat (ひ) from its venom in your veins. The poison sends a terrible heat throughout your body. The heat is overwhelming. You are sweating and you feel like you’re gonna die.
reading_hint: Hear the princess laughing as the cobra continues to hiss at you while the heat from the venom spreads throughout your body. Feel the heat in your veins as the world begins to fade to black around you.

meaning_story: You’ll win a treasure if you take one of your ribs and prune it off. Naturally, you prune one of your ribs off to get this treasure.
meaning_hint: Imagine pruning one of your own ribs. Feel the flesh and bone separate as you prune off one of your ribs. But think of the treasure!
reading_story: Since you decided to prune off a rib, you now need to take your car (か) to the hospital. You are bleeding from where you pruned the rib off, so you need medical attention. You get in your car and drive to the hospital.
reading_hint: Imagine having this terrible wound on your ribs as you drive your car. Hear the engine roaring as you speed towards the hospital to have your self-inflicted wound treated.

meaning_story: You stop the spoon from moving by tying it down with some thread which is purple. The spoon wouldn’t stop moving around and it was really bothering you so you got some purple thread and you tied that spoon down.
meaning_hint: Imagine tying this spoon down with the purple thread. Feel the spoon struggle to get free as you tie it down with the very purple thread.
reading_story: The spoon being held down by the purple thread is actually Charlie Sheen (し). Charlie Sheen has done so many drugs that he actually became a spoon. Purple thread is his only weakness, so that’s why you used purple thread to stop and subdue him.
reading_hint: Imagine tying Charlie Sheen the spoon down with this purple thread. Hear him scream and watch him struggle as he tries to get free.

meaning_story: The mouth of that turkey is solely his. It’s very unique, so that mouth could belong to no other turkey but him. That mouth is solely his.
meaning_hint: Imagine what makes this turkey’s mouth so unique. This beak is solely his. It belongs to no other. This turkey is the only turkey with a mouth like his.
reading_story: You traveled a long way to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his but you missed your exit on the high way and you have to hang a U-ey (ゆい). You know what hand a U-ey means, right? It’s making a U-turn. Well, you have to hang a U-ey on the highway so you can get off at the right spot to see this turkey and the mouth that is solely his.
reading_hint: Imagine hanging a U-ey on the highway. Hear your tires screech as you turn around and get off where you’re supposed to.

meaning_story: This hill and your ribs are both very sturdy. You fall down the hill and your ribs hold up to the punishment as does the hill. Since they are both very sturdy, neither your ribs nor the hill take any damage as you fall down the hill.
meaning_hint: Imagine tumbling down this hill and bashing your ribs into the ground as you fall. Since your ribs are sturdy, this really isn’t a big deal.
reading_story: At the bottom of the hill you crash into ごういち, but it’s no matter because he is sturdy too. ごういち is a very sturdy man, so when you crash into him with your sturdy ribs after tumbling down the sturdy hill, ごういち doesn’t even bat an eye.
reading_hint: Feel your sturdy ribs crashing into the sturdy ごういち. He sure is sturdy for such an old dude. The impact is quite jarring.

meaning_story: If you loiter, you’d be correct to assume that you’d never subjugate anyone. If you want to subjugate, you have to not loiter. Loitering will prevent any subjugating from occurring. Stop loitering and get to subjugating!
meaning_hint: Fight the urge to loiter as you begin to subjugate people. You feel lazy and want to loiter about, but you need to meet your subjugation quota.
reading_story: You have one more person left to subjugate when you hear his shout, “SEI (せい) SEI SEI!” It’s Hard Gay! Man, Hard Gay might be tricky to subjugate.
reading_hint: SEI SEI SEI! Do your best to subjugate Hard Gay as you hear him chant his chant. Will you ever be able to subjugate someone so majestic? SEI!!

meaning_story: You take a nailbat and an axe and you say that you vow to avenge your father. You father was murdered and you vow to seek out the killer and then hit him with the axe and the nailbat. You take this vow very seriously.
meaning_hint: Repeat this vow over and over and focus on it intently as you feel the weight of the deadly axe and nailbat in your hands.
reading_story: You are about to fulfill your vow when you hear “SEI (せい) SEI SEI!” Your father was killed by Hard Gay! Hard Gay humped him to death. Ew.
reading_hint: SEI SEI SEI! Imagine Hard Gay humping your poor father to death as you remember the vow that brought you here. Hit Hard Gay with the nailbat and the axe until he stops shouting “SEI SEI SEI”.

meaning_story: The leader of this valley is very vulgar. The name of the valley is Vulgar Valley, so it makes sense for its leader to be very vulgar.
meaning_hint: Imagine meeting the leader of Vulgar Valley. Imagine all the vulgar things he says to prove he is worthy of being the leader of Vulgar Valley. He is so very, very vulgar.
reading_story: This vulgar leader leads his Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang through Vulgar Valley, patrolling the area and spreading vulgarity as he goes.
reading_hint: Hear the motorcycles rev and purr as they carouse the Vulgar Valley. Hear the leader screaming vulgar things as he and his Bosozoku bike gang ride all around.

meaning_story: A tsunami at the gate of the king makes sure all of his plants get watered. The gate prevents the tsunami from damaging anything inside the king’s home, and the plants around the gate get watered by the water of the tsunami.
meaning_hint: Hear the tsunami crash into the gate as you see the water slosh around and make sure that all of the king’s plants get good and watered.
reading_story: These plants are getting watered in June (じゅん), the month they need watering the most. June is a hot month, so it’s good that this tsunami came and got the king’s plants watered when it did.
reading_hint: Again, watch and hear the tsunami crashing into the gate and getting the plants watered. This time, remember that the month is June and it is very hot and sticky outside. You’re sweating and very hot.

meaning_story: The leader, Master Splinter (the rat from Ninja Turtles) isn't even supposed to exist. He exists because someone accidentally poured ooze on him.
meaning_hint: Imagine someone accidentally spilling ooze on a rat, then watch the rat turn into a sentient rat martial artist.
reading_story: But really, if you do something accidentally, it's probably a good (ぐう) thing in a way. You learn a bit about how you can improve yourself so you don't do it again, or in Splinter's case, it's just a good mistake!
reading_hint: However you look at it, try to make this accident be a good accident.

meaning_story: A construction beggar is a beggar who can construct anything. This beggar is very adept at construction.
meaning_hint: It's weird, though, because even though he's adept he doesn't like doing construction, which is why he's a beggar who doesn't have a job.
reading_story: This adept beggar is こういち. Imagine Koichi begging on the corner. You shake your head, because you know he could have a job, but he chooses not to do construction.
reading_hint: Maybe give him some change? He could use your help, if you are able.

meaning_story: A fish in its mouth and in the other mouth is half a beggar (the head is cut off). The other half is on the ground. The animal that has fishes and beggars in its mouth, is an alligator.
meaning_hint: Just imagine the blood and fishes and beggars everywhere. The alligator is having a good meal tonight.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the わに in 'Wanikani.' Ever heard of it?
reading_hint: So long as you've ever used WaniKani, you probably know the reading of the word alligator.

meaning_story: A nailbat bed is a bundle of nailbats in the form of a bed, but it's still a big old bundle nonetheless.
meaning_hint: Imagine a bed that's more in the shape of a bundle than a bed. Not particularly comfortable in this shape, but why did anyone think a bundle of nailbats would be comfortable as a bed anyways?
reading_story: What (わ)? You thought it would be comforatble? Ha (ha) ha ha ha ha. What? Hahaha.
reading_hint: Look at the bundle nailbat bed and just say: 'What? hahaha' over and over at it, because it's absurd.

meaning_story: A horse that is fat is a burdensome animal.
meaning_hint: A fat horse. So burdensome. Not to mention the burden on the horse on top of the fatness.
reading_story: But you have to be nice to the burdensome horse because this horse is your dad (だ).
reading_hint: Go visit your dad the burdensome horse because you have to visit your dad. It's weird because you're a human and he's a horse.

meaning_story: A tsunami is the same as a cave. Because, if a wave is big enough, it will curl over on itself, creating a sort of cave within the wave. That's why it's the same as a cave!
meaning_hint: Also, imagine a tsunami hitting a cave, becoming the same as the cave (since a cave will shape it).
reading_story: Best way to remember the reading for this kanji is to think about how the shape of a cave is the shape of a doughnut (どう).
reading_hint: Also note that the 同 part of this kanji gives away the reading as well. 同 and 洞 have the same readings!

meaning_story: The leader all in white is the chief. All the other leaders are wearing some other color, but that's who you tell the chief apart from the other leaders.
meaning_hint: Imagine all the leaders standing around, then the chief person standing there all in white.
reading_story: The reading is the same as 白, which is included in this kanji. The other reading is お, and it's like the honorific 御, in a way. You'd want to be polite to someone who is the chief ______, right? That's why it could be お, too.
reading_hint: You'll learn more about which reading to use when the vocabulary roll around. In the meantime, try to remember both of them the best you can!

meaning_story: The say next mouth is the next mouth next to you, that says things on your behalf. Who is this mouth? This mouth is your consult. It is your second mouth that tells you what to do.
meaning_hint: Imagine it as a floating mouth whispering in your ear, right next to you, saying the things you should say.
reading_story: This is the mouth (and maybe whole body, if you want) of Charlie Sheen (shi). His consult for you is that you should drink tiger blood.
reading_hint: If it helps imagine the whole of Charlie Sheen giving you consultation instead of just a mouth. Focus on the mouth part, though.

meaning_story: Big Bird, the king of all the lands! His favorite thing to do is hold courts in his King's court.
meaning_hint: Imagine Big Bird running his King's Court. You're there advising him.
reading_story: At all of Big Bird's King courts he serves tator (てい) tots to all his people.
reading_hint: Eat the tator tots being offered to you. This is a great king's court.

radicals: 牛, 刀, 虫, 角
meaning_story: This is an animal with an angled sword claw that's filled with cow meat but looks like an insect. What kind of animal is that? It's a crab.
meaning_hint: If you think about the different parts you can see why this is a crab. A delicious, delicious crab.
reading_story: The reading is the same as the かに in WaniKani.
reading_hint: If you've used WaniKani before, you probably know this reading, hopefully. All praise the great allicrab!

meaning_story: The sun hits this thing and then breaks into three suns. What can deflect the sun into three directions? A crystal!
meaning_hint: Crystals take light and deflect it around into many directions. That's why there are three suns in this kanji.
reading_story: Who is hoarding all the crystals, because he loves how they look? That would be the shougun (しょう).
reading_hint: Imagine the Shogun laying in his bed of crystals. He's rolling around on them, laughing and having a great time. All the crystals are his!

radicals: 日, 女, 土, 匚
meaning_story: A grave is a cage that holds both the sun and a woman. They're both sitting inside this grave cave, not knowing where they are. Pan outside of the grave cave to see that they are actually in a huge dam. But, they don't know this, they can't see outside.
meaning_hint: It's a really, really big dam. It's also dark outside, because the sun is inside the dam, cooking the water to make steam which makes electricity for the dam.
reading_story: The sun's job is obvious (heat up the water and create steam), but the woman's job is just as important. She has to be all sexy (せき) for the sun so the sun heats up enough to cook the water.
reading_hint: Imagine a lady being sexy for the sun, then imagine the sun heating up to steam up the water to create power for the dam.

meaning_story: If a tsunami hits your helicopter while you are jackhammering, it will drift out to sea. What were you doing with a jackhammer at a time like this? Now your helicopter is drifting away!
meaning_hint: Picture your helicopter as it drifts out to sea with the tsunami.
reading_story: As it drifts away you shout, "Heyooo! (ひょう)." You know the helicopter probably can't hear you (or understand you) but maybe it will turn on and stop drifting away if you shout it enough.
reading_hint: "Heyoooo stop drifting awaaaay!!"

meaning_story: A tsunami is about to hit, so you use your helmet to correct the issue. To reroute and block the tsunami, you use your helmet to dig out an eddy that will do just that.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself digging an eddy with your helmet. You're digging and digging, and it's hard work. Off in the distance you see the tsunami, and you dig more hurriedly.
reading_story: The thing about the eddy is that it probably won't help much, but either way, you do (よど) something about the problem, at least.
reading_hint: You do what you can with what you have.

meaning_story: The grave of the sun right there, but it was put in the wrong spot. Someone has to correct the placement of the sun's grave. It's right on the edge of the embankment, and that will surely wash away, washing the sun's dead body along with it.
meaning_hint: You can already see the sun sticking out of the embankment just a little bit. Ugh, gross. Gotta correct this.
reading_story: You dig up the sun's grave to get it out of the embankment, but as you dig, all you find is tater (てい) tots. Where did the sun's body go? Who took it? Did it come back to life? Why are there tater tots in its stead?
reading_hint: Try one of the tater tots... they taste vaguely sun-like.

meaning_story: If you look at the cliff and then look under the ground, you'll find a giant mouth. As you dig away the mouth, which is at least 20 meters in diameter and reeks of the worst breath you've ever had the honor of smelling, you see that this mouth belongs to the great empress.
meaning_hint: 'Empress,' you say. 'Why does your breath smell so bad?' 'It's because I've been buried under the ground of a cliff for all these years, of course.'
reading_story: As you look at the empress, who is still stuck inside the cliff, you see far off a giant こういち lumbering towards you. What is he doing here? you wonder. He spots you and the empress, then starts charging your position. When he gets there, he tears the cliff apart, throwing you off the cliff and sending you flying in the air. The last thing you see is Koichi devouring the empress (he is really that big).
reading_hint: Before you hit the ground, yell 'こういち, NOOOOO!' See the last moments of the empress being devoured, unable to move because she's so tiny compared to Koichi, and also because she's stuck in the cliff.

meaning_story: Everyone is sick in Ikea. The sickness has spread all throughout Ikea and everyone is getting it. This is an epidemic!
meaning_hint: Just watch the sickness jump from person to person in Ikea. They aren't allowed to leave since all of Ikea has become quarantined.
reading_story: The sickness that caused the Ikea epidemic actually came from the 駅 (えき) right next to Ikea. Someone brought it in from the station there... that must be it. It's the only way to get to Ikea.
reading_hint: Imagine the person getting off the train from the station, looking sick and such. They give the sickness to everyone else, causing the epidemic.

meaning_story: You have a numbered feather. Pick your favorite number and put it on the feather. Then, put the numbered feather on your head. When you put it on, you're able to flip and flip over and over.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself doing flips with this feather on your head. Flip flip flip.
reading_story: You're pretty good at your flip technique, but you're not that good. You really need to practice and hone (ほん) your skills and get better.
reading_hint: Or, maybe you get so good that you write a 本 (ほん) about doing a flip. Wow, you're good!

meaning_story: A tree can be a tree, but it can also be a psychopath. The tree goes from being a regular tree to being a psychopath. Such mood swings are so rough. Especially when the tree slips to gloom.
meaning_hint: Imagine all the mood swings of this tree. Psychopath tree! Also very gloomy sometimes.
reading_story: Then the tree switches from gloom to being super excited (these moodswings!). The super excited tree starts doing dubstep. Uts (うつ) uts uts uts uts ♬.
reading_hint: Sing along with the moody tree. Gloom to dubstep. Such a big change.

meaning_story: A tsunami is coming over the cliff with the graves on it. You can see this happening very far away. It's right on the horizon.
meaning_hint: Look way far off, right at the horizon, to watch this scene play out.
reading_story: Also standing on the horizon where the tsunami is hitting the cliff is some guy (がい). He just stands there, and this guy then deflects the tsunami out of the way.
reading_hint: Who is that guy who is deflecting the tsunami on the horizon? Just some guy, I guess. Just some guy.

meaning_story: A gold name on this piece of wood is the inscription that shows the artist's signature.
meaning_hint: This inscription refers to a signature or something similar. This is an artisan's signature in the form of an inscription.
reading_story: The inscription is a name written on something, right? Remember the kanji for 'name'? It is 名, and it shares the reading with this kanji as well, making both names めい.
reading_hint: If you need to review 名 go ahead and do that. It will help you to remember this kanji.

meaning_story: The leader cat pirate is the greatest cat pirate of them all. It leads all the cat pirate leaders, even! This is truly a cat pirate to look up to.
meaning_hint: Imagine this majestic cat pirate leader of leaders. Feel in your heart that you look up to this cat pirate, truly.
reading_story: Your job is to bring this leader of cat pirates (whom you look up to) its favorite food: gyoza (ぎょう).
reading_hint: Of course, the gyoza is filled with fish, because we're talking about cat pirates, here.

meaning_story: The tsunami hits the sun, causing sauron to turn into a stool... wait, this doesn't sound like a realistic situation at all. This sounds more like the plot of a manga.
meaning_hint: Imagine reading this manga, imagining out each frame in your head.
reading_story: The 'man' of manga is the man reading used here.
reading_hint: If you know the word 'manga' you will know the reading here too!

meaning_story: This gel will cause your hair to stand early in the morning (right when you wake up), so you don't have to do any styling. This invention is so amazing and useful that you patent it so nobody else can make money from it.
meaning_hint: Go to the patent office and fill out the forms to get your special early standing hair gel patented.
reading_story: When you go to get this patented, you find out that someone else already patented your miracle gel! 'Who did this?' you ask. Turns out, it's the Shougun (しょう).
reading_hint: You go right to the Shougun's office to talk to him about it. Have a nice conversation with him and figure out why he was able to get this patented before you. Turns out he can do what he wants because he's the Shougun.

meaning_story: A bamboo tsunami's specialty is to crush everything in front of it, smash down, and turn into multiple record books.
meaning_hint: The bamboo flattens as it hits the ground then turns into papers. The papers combine to become record books that show what happened here, this day.
reading_story: A record book is a book, when it comes down to it.
reading_hint: Bamboo can also become bo staffs too, if they don't turn into record books.

meaning_story: You're walking down the street when you find a building shaped like a huge nailgun. You decide to walk inside and find that it's a really nice restaurant. That's unexpected. Who would have thought a restaurant would want to make their building look like a nailgun?
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself seeing a giant nailgun shaped building and walking inside to find a beautiful restaurant. How weird!
reading_story: You look at the menu at this restaurant and all it serves are tater (てい) tots. You love tater tots! This place is way better than you thought when you first saw it.
reading_hint: Are you getting hungry? I'm getting hungry.

meaning_story: I'd like you to say nail. Wait, I'd like to revise that. Could you say screw now?
meaning_hint: Imagine you saying this to someone. Then, imagine someone telling this to you.
reading_story: Now revise the previous scenario to where they have you say nail first, but then revise you to say 'tater (てい) tots' instead.
reading_hint: Go through the scenario again in your head. Both sides.

meaning_story: A nailbat samurai is far more robust than compared to a regular samurai.
meaning_hint: Go ahead and compare the two types of samurai. Nailbat one is way more robust, don't you agree?
reading_story: When the robust samurai hits the other samurai in the face with his nailbat, the other samurai splits in half. Now someone has to sew (そう) that samurai back together.
reading_hint: That's your job. You have to swe the broken samurai back together. If only he were more robust, like nailbat samurai!

meaning_story: There are nine cars all driving in the same place. With so many cars driving in the same place, they create a rut.
meaning_hint: Imagine the cars spinning out in the rut. Spin spin spin. The rut gets bigger. Nine is too many cars.
reading_story: To get out of the rut you have to put in a second key (き) that turns on the thrusters. You put in the key and press the 'take off' button.
reading_hint: Imagine turning the thrusters key, then feeling the car lift off the ground. You'll finally get out of this rut!

meaning_story: A big turkey in the rice paddy is getting all stirred up. He's kicking up all the rice. Who stirred him up?
meaning_hint: He is a really big turkey too. Like, 12 feet tall, or something. Don't want to stir up a turkey that's that big.
reading_story: While the turkey is stirred up, it also looks like it's having a lot of fun (ふん).
reading_hint: Is it laughing? Oh no, this is bad, it's enjoying being stirred up, now we'll never stop it.

meaning_story: Your mullet gets a nice brushing, and you brush your long hairs into your mouth. This style is all the rage in China. China is up on all the latest hair trends.
meaning_hint: Imagine you're brushing your mullet hairs. Then imagine the first time you saw someone else brushing their mullet hairs into their mouth in China.
reading_story: And, believe it or not, you wear it outside and everyone sees it. Overnight, it's a huge fad in とうきょう (とう).
reading_hint: All the kids in Tokyo are wearing their mullets like this now.

meaning_story: On the mountain it is winter so there is a signpost to tell you that you have reached the summit.
meaning_hint: If the signpost wasn't there, you'd have no idea, due to the terrible conditions and the snow. But, the signpost tells you you're there, even though you can't see the view around the mountain.
reading_story: Why are you here on the summit of this mountain even though the conditions are so bad? You are houdini, and today your 'trick' involves you escaping from deadly mountain summit weather.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself trying to escape (and imagine yourself as houdini). Think about the advertisements everywhere for this trick too: 'Houdini! The great escape artist will escape from a... mountain summit!'

meaning_story: A grave with a cross and flowers over it that opens up like a clam. That's no normal grave, this is fancier. This is a tomb.
meaning_hint: Imagine the tomb door to be shaped like a clam, even, if it helps.
reading_story: When it comes to tombs, it's really fun to go inside of them. That's my idea of fun, anyways. What about you?
reading_hint: Try to convince yourself that tombs are fun and nothing else.

meaning_story: A nailbat with a sail attached to it with Ikea furniture are the base. It's a boat made out of the weirdest things, but it's still a form of transport.
meaning_hint: Imagine your weird transport. You jump onto it and sail off.
reading_story: This transport vessel is the preferred transport of Han (はん) Solo as well.
reading_hint: Imagine him riding on this Billy Bookcase with a nailbat and a sail. Him and Chewbacca are having a great time on there.

meaning_story: A fang butcher is a butcher who uses their fangs to butcher everyone. A person who does this is wicked.
meaning_hint: Imagine him running up to you and tearing you apart with his fangs. 'I AM WICKED!' he yells.
reading_story: The reason he's so wicked and devouring you is because he's an animal. He's a jaguar, so of course he's doing it.
reading_hint: Now imagine the creature coming at you but this time it's a jaguar. A wicked jaguar.

meaning_story: A mouth that wants peace can call for it. If you don’t have a mouth, you can’t call for peace. So use your mouth and call for peace when you can. Peace is great.
meaning_hint: Call for peace. Say it aloud. I’m using my mouth to call for peace!
reading_story: But before you call for peace, you must first placate the masses. To do so, you astound them with your yo-yo (よ) skills. Once they are so entranced by how talented you are with a yo-yo, you easily convince them to make peace.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself whirling this yo-yo about while you call for peace. Imagine yourself doing a variety of tricks with it as you slowly convince the people to agree to peace.

meaning_story: On top of a big mountain, wearing a lip ring, you see a cape jutting out into the ocean. You’re wearing a lip ring because you’re a cool and edgy guy who likes to climb big mountains. From the top of the big mountain, you see a cape.
meaning_hint: You’re tired from just climbing up the big mountain but the view is worth it. Feel the wind blustering around you as you take in the beautiful scenery, including the cape.
reading_story: Atop the big mountain overlooking the cape, you start to play what you call hacky sacky (さき). Most people say hacky sack, but you’re edgy and cool and have a lip ring so you say sacky instead.
reading_hint: See yourself doing your hacky sacky thing on top of this big mountain. Concentrate to keep the hacky sacky in the air as it’s a long way down.

meaning_story: Moving in the direction of a gun, an alligator can carry out a murder once it reaches it. This alligator wants to kill someone. The alligator wants to carry out their execution. The gun is across the room so the alligator has to move in its direction to obtain it.
meaning_hint: See the alligator shuffle across the floor in the direction of the gun. See the alligator as it prepares to carry out the murder. It’s scary.
reading_story: The alligator plans to murder Charlie Sheen (し) with that gun. The alligator has had just about enough of Charlie Sheen and all his antics and things. It’s time to carry out his demise.
reading_hint: Picture Charlie Sheen cowering in a corner as the alligator moves in his direction with the gun, ready to carry out his death at a moment’s notice. Hear Charlie Sheen scream and plead for mercy as the alligator approaches.

meaning_story: A grave can become a castle, under the right conditions. Normally, a grave is just a grave, but sometimes, a grave can become a castle. You just have to know what to do.
meaning_hint: Graves are pretty uninteresting. You can’t live in them. They’re not as big or cool as a castle. But imagine you could make them into castles. Imagine you have the power to make a grave become a castle.
reading_story: And so you turned a grave into a castle and that’s all she wrote (しろ). That’s it, end of story. The grave became a castle and that’s all she wrote.
reading_hint: When a grave turns into a castle, there’s really no turning back. So just remember that when a grave becomes a castle, that’s all she wrote.

meaning_story: They say that flowers held by a turkey on a stool are good to defend yourself with. Even better than a guard dog they say. People are so confused by the turkey sitting on a stool holding flowers that they just lose their will to fight. This turkey is great to defend yourself and your home.
meaning_hint: Picture this turkey holding its flowers while sitting on its stool. Hear it gobbling as it defends everything around it with its mere presence.
reading_story: The only thing this flower bearing turkey cannot defend against is Godzilla (ご). Godzilla is pretty much undefeatable, especially for a turkey. The turkey is totally unable to defend anything from the mighty Godzilla.
reading_hint: Imagine Godzilla approaching the flower turkey. Hear Godzilla roar as the turkey gobbles in fear before being crushed beneath the massive and scaly foot of Godzilla.

meaning_story: The demon radical and the demon kanji are exactly the same! Wicked!
reading_story: How do you keep a demon locked up? Use a key (き). Use a lock and key and keep that demon locked up safely behind bars so he can’t get out and do bad demon stuff.
reading_hint: Picture yourself locking up a demon with a special demon containing key. Hear the key click into the lock as the demon screams to be set free.

meaning_story: Wearing a helmet for safety, a master of the mouth and ribs begins to divide your body into pieces. This master of the mouth and ribs is a demented surgeon. He’s dividing your body into pieces, starting by removing your mouth and your ribs.
meaning_hint: Feel this master surgeon divide your body into multiple pieces. Feel him divide your mouth from your face and each of your ribs from your body. Hear the bones crack and flesh rip as he continues to divide you.
reading_story: This master surgeon is actually Wario (わり) from the Nintendo universe. Wario likes to divide people into pieces because he’s evil. An evil mastermind. And after he finishes dividing you, Wario likes to drink a gallon of water (わ). Wario really likes water, so he drinks a lot of it.
reading_hint: See Wario, all splattered with blood, guzzling down a whole gallon of water. Hear the water slosh about as Wario chugs it down.

meaning_story: Reaching your ear is the sound of a drunkard who can’t find employment. You hear him before you see him because he’s behind some trash cans. Being a drunkard, he’s like, super wasted and just kind of rambling to himself, making strange sounds. No wonder he can’t find employment.
meaning_hint: Hear the strange sounds this drunkard is making. Let his ramblings enter your ears and imagine what he could be trying to say.
reading_story: Since this guy is such a pathetic drunkard, it comes as no shock (しょく) that he can’t find employment. If he did find employment, I would be filled with both shock and awe.
reading_hint: Actually you find out that he does have employment. He’s a garbage man. Feel the shock of making this shocking discovery. How can this drunkard possibly hold down his job like this?

meaning_story: Pine stairs excel at supporting people. Every contractor knows that pine makes for the strongest stairs. Stairs made of pine excel in every aspect.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself as the one making these stairs out of pine. You excel at your job. Feel the pine wood in your hands and hear the saws sawing and hammers hammering as you assemble the stairs from the pine.
reading_story: You’re a shooter (しゅう). You’re a shooter and you excel at your job. You're so good at being a shooter that you constructed these pine stairs just to get to a better sniping position. Now that's dedication.
reading_hint: Imagine having a sniper rifle slung over your back as you work on building these stairs. Once they're finished, visualize yourself climbing them and looking through the sights of your gun, finding your next target to shoot.

meaning_story: A leader wishing to curb injustice will write a moving haiku. The power of a haiku is enough to stop all injustice in the world, and the leader knows this. Therefore, he writes such a haiku.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself as a great leader, out to stop injustice in the world. You gotta write a haiku to do it though. Think up a haiku now and use that to remember this kanji.
reading_story: What are you writing? You’re writing a haiku (はい). A haiku to end all injustice in the world!
reading_hint: The reading for this one is the same as the first syllable of the word. Haiku. Easy!

meaning_story: A leader wielding a nailgun can easily cause his followers to halt. How does the leader do so? He shoots one of them with his nailgun. The rest of them immediately come to a halt.
meaning_hint: Imagine following the leader with his nailgun. As soon as he turns around to get you all to halt, he shoots someone with his nailgun. He shoots you. You halt in your tracks and fall to the ground. Feel the pain of the nail in your body. It hurts really bad.
reading_story: To make matters worse, you drop the tater (てい) tots you were carrying. To cause you to come to a halt, the leader shot you right in the hand so you’ve dropped your tater tots to the ground. Your tater tots are ruined.
reading_hint: See your tater tots rolling away from you on the ground. You were really looking forward to eating them. Nurse your wounded hand as you see your tater tots roll off into the distance.

meaning_story: Wearing a helmet, you slide down your stairs seven times to make your house a home. This is your housewarming ritual, so before you can consider your house your home, you must slide down the stairs seven times. The helmet is just for safety.
meaning_hint: Imagine sliding down seven times while wearing your helmet. The helmet protects your head, but there’s nothing to protect your bottom. Imagine how sore your posterior will be after sliding down the stairs seven times. Your house is finally a home, but your butt sure smarts.
reading_story: On your seventh trip down the stairs to make your house a home, you land on a tack (たく) on the way down. Like I said, you have nothing on to protect your butt, so the tack sticks right in you, piercing your bottom. The tack stings really bad. It hurts.
reading_hint: Feel the pain from the tack sticking out of your butt. It’s bad enough that your butt hurts from sliding down the stairs but now you have a tack stuck in it too. Imagine how painful all of this would be.

meaning_story: Wearing a big cross over his clothes is a drunkard who's walking around the streets holding said cross yelling "YOU CANNOT JUDGE ME! I HAVE A CROSS. LET HE WHO SINNNNNED FIRST JUDGE ME? MMK??"
meaning_hint: Imagine running into this guy. All he talks about is judging.
reading_story: He also mentions how you can't judge him because he's a cyclops (さい). He pulls up his eyepatch to show you his cyclopsness. DON'T JUDGE CYCLOPS! he yells.
reading_hint: Imagine the shock of seeing this, because his eye is right in the middle of his forehead, like a cyclops would be.

meaning_story: Loitering around with a brush? Sorry, but you're breaking the law. If you have a brush, that's okay. If you're loitering, that's okay. If you combine the two? Well... watch your back.
meaning_hint: Imagine a police officer coming for you. He's yelling at you because you have a brush and you're loitering. He grabs you, throws you to the ground, telling you what you're doing wrong.
reading_story: Where were you loitering with your brush, breaking the law? Right outside the Ritz (りつ) Hotel. You'd think that it would be okay since you were staying there, but the law is the law.
reading_hint: Imagine the hotel staff watching as you get thrown to the ground. You yell "won't the Ritz do anything to help me??" They won't.

meaning_story: Take a measurement of the road. Hmm. It seems a bit too long. As you measure it, you continue down this road, wondering where it will lead you.
meaning_hint: Roads are really long, so I imagine it would take a long time to measure it (if you want to go from end to end). Imagine yourself pulling a tape measure along with you, all the while thinking, "where will this lead me?"
reading_story: Where does the road that you're measuring lead you? An awesome doughnut (どう) shop!
reading_hint: What a perfect way to end this road measuring. You're hungry. Nom nom nom. Imagine eating your fill, and taste the donuts in your mouth. You just walked a long ways!

meaning_story: The leather radical and the leather kanji are exactly the same! Cool!
reading_story: One way to get leather is to skin a male chicken, a cock (かく). You won’t get much leather from a cock, but you can definitely skin one in a pinch, should you need a little extra leather.
reading_hint: Imagine skinning a cock for its leather. See yourself cutting through the rooster’s skin as you pluck the feathers out so it can be tanned into leather.

meaning_story: A grave digger heading in the direction of a winter clam cannot afford the luxury of stopping for coffee. The grave digger is hunting the elusive winter clam and has finally caught its scent so the grave digger is moving in the winter clam’s direction. Since the winter clam is so elusive, the grave digger cannot afford the luxury of stopping for anything or else the winter clam will escape.
meaning_hint: See yourself as this grave digger, tracking the winter clam. Moving in its direction, you catch its scent. Smell the frigid clammy smell on the wind. Let it fill your nostrils as you move closer and closer to your prey.
reading_story: Just when you think you’ve finally come to the hiding place of the winter clam, Hard Gay jumps out of the bushes and starts thrusting at you. But something is different. This isn't the Japanese Hard Gay you know and love. It's his German counterpart! He's shouting “Zei (ぜい), zei, zei~!” German Hard Gay is wearing a fancy luxury suit. That's how you know he's not Japanese Hard Gay.
reading_hint: See the luxury in German Hard Gay’s attire. Everything from his shoes to his tie are encrusted with diamonds. “Zei, zei, zei!” But wait, so where is the winter clam’s scent coming from? Is it coming from German Hard Gay? Eww.

meaning_story: Giving cleats to a child carrying an umbrella is the best way to gather milk. You don’t have any containers, so the child has to hold milk in the upside-down umbrella. The cleats are so the child can run back and forth to transport the milk around.
meaning_hint: See this child running in his cleats. Picture him holding the umbrella upside-down, milk sloshing all about as he runs.
reading_story: But where is this child exactly? He’s in New (にゅう) York City. What’s he doing in New York City you ask? Well, he's milking a cow. Why is there a cow to be milked in New York City? Good question. It’s the end of the world and New York City is the last remaining civilization. This is how people live now. Milk is important.
reading_hint: Imagine post-apocalyptic New York City. Milk is a hot commodity here so it’s important not to spill any of the milk. Imagine yourself carrying the milk in the umbrella and being careful not to spill any of it.

meaning_story: Four stools are easy to obtain. You can get a stool almost anywhere, so certainly obtaining four of them would be easy to do.
meaning_hint: See yourself obtain these four stools. They are yours. Feel them. Touch them. Sit on them.
reading_story: You are a shooter (しゅう), and you need to obtain these four stools to prop yourself and your gun upon. A good shooter knows how to set up his shooting area, and you are definitely a good shooter.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself setting up these stools for the best shooting arrangement. You're sitting on one stool, resting each arm on two other stools, and resting the gun on the final, fourth stool. Now shoot something!

meaning_story: Wearing a tsunami proof helmet while in a corn field wearing fins will allow you to perform a great show. There’s a tsunami coming in that will soon cover all of the corn, but that’s okay because you’ve got your tsunami proof helmet and fins, so you’re perfectly fine in the water. Now you can perform your underwater tsunami show with ease.
meaning_hint: What kind of show will you perform? Imagine yourself in the tsunami water, wearing your helmet and fins. Feel the water all around you as you perform tricks for your audience.
reading_story: Since you know how to perform and put on a good show, you’ve recruited some ents (えん) to be in the performance with you. The ents perform tricks in the background and work the lights and music for you. Ents, so helpful.
reading_hint: See the ents in the background while you perform. Watch them working the lights and changing the music as you continue on with your performance.

meaning_story: A king can see that the present time is what’s most important. There’s no time or point to think about the future. A king can see that the present time is the only time worth worrying about.
meaning_hint: Pretend that you are this king with no foresight or consideration for the future. You live in the moment, in the present time. No regrets. See yourself as this king.
reading_story: This king is kind of similar to the current generation (げん). The current generation only thinks of the present time and doesn’t plan for the future. People are under mountains of debt, not planning for retirement, and living on credit. The current generation is messed up.
reading_hint: Feel pity for this generation of the present time. Are you a contributing factor to this present time minded generation? Take some time to reflect on the issue.

meaning_story: A leader holding flowers atop a cliff riding an elephant can easily provide for his people. He has strength (the elephant), compassion (the flowers), and foresight (being atop a cliff). This leader can provide everything his people need.
meaning_hint: See this majestic leader on top of the cliff, riding an elephant with flowers in his hand. Hear the elephant trumpet as the leader throws down from the cliff everything his people need. He sure knows how to provide.
reading_story: All this work to provide for his people starts to take a toll on this leader. He decides to chill out under a tree and slumps down against its trunk. The impact causes a beehive (び) to fall out of the tree and many a bee start to swarm around the leader, stinging him all over.
reading_hint: This poor leader. Hear the sounds of bee upon bee swarming about and buzzing up a storm. It almost muffles the bloodcurdling screams of the leader. Almost.

meaning_story: You shouldn’t eat clam ribs as a general rule. Clam ribs aren’t good for you, so it should be a rule not to eat clam ribs.
meaning_hint: Do clams even have ribs? Well imagine they do. You wouldn’t want to eat them. They’re sharp and pointy and dangerous to your health. Imagine trying to eat these small spikey ribs. Feel them puncturing your insides as you ingest them. Now you see why it should be a rule not to eat clam ribs.
reading_story: In addition to the rule, the clam ribs should also be stored in a sock (そく) to make sure that no one accidentally eats them. I mean, no one would eat food out of a sock, socks are icky.
reading_hint: Imagine finding food in a stinky sock. Smell the foot odor wafting into your nostrils and mixing with the seafood smell of the clam ribs. It’s nauseating.

meaning_story: A man who is husband material can see a standard woman and think she’s the greatest thing ever. This man will make a great husband. Even though the lady is pretty standard, the husband treats her like she’s anything but.
meaning_hint: This husband sets a new standard for what it means to be a husband. He’s pretty great. Imagine yourself shaking this husband’s hand because he’s so awesome.
reading_story: It’s pretty standard for a husband and wife to exchange vows when getting married, and the husband said this girl held the key (き) to his heart. She unlocked the husband’s heart with the key and now he’s a man made whole.
reading_hint: Picture this woman actually sticking a physical key into the husband’s chest and turning it. Now this is anything but standard, but it’ll help you remember this kanji and its reading.

meaning_story: Riding a tsunami you see a turkey carrying a cross, but that’s pretty standard here. This is your dreamland. You always dream about tsunamis and the turkeys carrying crosses that ride them. This might be strange for other people, but for you it’s pretty normal.
meaning_hint: See this tsunami riding turkey in your mind. Hear it gobble loudly as it waves its cross around. Remember, this is standard fare for you. Nothing unusual here.
reading_story: These wacky dreams are only standard fare in June (じゅん) though. You don’t have them any other time of the year, just in June. You don’t know why June is the only time you have dreams about tsunami riding turkeys, but that’s just the way it is.
reading_hint: It’s usually pretty toasty in the month of June (in the Northern Hemisphere, at least) so imagine going to bed in this heat. Feel the spray of the refreshing tsunami water in your dream as the turkey continues to ride those tsunami waves with his cross.

meaning_story: A spring is long and can stretch out. Springs are usually compressed, but you can stretch them out to make them good and long.
meaning_hint: Hold this spring in your hands. Now stretch it out. It’s pretty long now, isn’t it? Feel the spring wobble and start to give resistance as you continue to stretch it taut.
reading_story: This spring belongs to Mrs. Chou (ちょう). She’s not happy that you decided to stretch it. Mrs. Chou is going to come over and beat you with the spring should you decide to stretch it out again.
reading_hint: Picture Mrs. Chou beating you with the spring. It hurts and it stings. You should never make Mrs. Chou angry. Also keep in mind that this kanji shares the same reading as 長 which is a big part of this kanji.

meaning_story: The leader of a hundred foreheads in the heart of winter is superior at being gentle. These hundred foreheads are sensitive, especially in the heart of winter, so the leader must be very gentle. Not just any kind of gentle though – the gentle that these hundred foreheads need is superior.
meaning_hint: As a leader, you are superior. You’re so gentle to these foreheads. See yourself caring for them in the winter. Feel the chill in the air as you wrap the foreheads in blankets and prepare heating pads for them.
reading_story: Who’s a superior leader? Who is? You (ゆう) are! Yes, you are! You are such a superior leader. You are gentle and you are kind, and you are great. Yes you are!
reading_hint: You, you, you. It’s all about you. You are the best. Feel all this pride at being the superior leader of one hundred foreheads and having them all look up to you.

meaning_story: A tsunami of shrimp crashes into a swamp. Now the swamp is filled with shrimp. They used to live in the ocean, but the tsunami has carried them to their new home in the swamp.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in the swamp when the tsunami hits. Feel the water crash into you along with the shrimp. You’re all wet and shrimpy now.
reading_story: Your house was right next to the swamp and on this side of your house you had many a tack (たく) there to hang things on. Now, on every tack there is skewered a shrimp. The force of the tsunami drove them into the tacks on the side of your house.
reading_hint: Look at the side of your house. It’s covered with shrimp that have been impaled on the tacks. Perfect for dinner.

meaning_story: To drop a bear to the ground on top of Two Face is something only a teacher or an expert could get away with. This expert teacher is Two Face’s personal teacher. The teacher is taking Two Face through a training course and part of that course involves a bear drop. Don’t question the teacher, he’s an expert.
meaning_hint: Imagine if this expert teacher dropped a bear on you. Feel the fuzzy and heavy animal slam on top of you, squishing you between it and the ground. What lesson do you think the teacher is trying to teach you?
reading_story: This supposed expert teacher is actually Charlie Sheen (し). He’s particularly eccentric today because he’s high on all the drugs. So Charlie Sheen thought it would be a good idea to drop a bear on Two Face because bears are warm and cuddly. Silly Charlie Sheen, bears aren’t cuddly, they’re murderers.
reading_hint: Watch as Two Face gets mutilated by the bear while Charlie Sheen just looks on. Charlie Sheen is tripping out so he doesn’t even know what’s going on. See Charlie Sheen zone out as you hear the bear growling and Two Face screaming in the background.

meaning_story: A cross sits in the sun with a hat hanging from an antenna. This sits atop a tree trunk that you have chopped down just for this purpose.
meaning_hint: Kind of a lot of work right? Imagine doing all that would be needed in order to achieve this scene, imagining the hard labor and the pain.
reading_story: After you chop down the tree to just a tree trunk, you’re very thirsty so you get yourself a can (かん) of soda. Before opening the can, you rub the can over your body since the can is nice and cold. And then you drink the can of soda.
reading_hint: Feel the cold can over your body. It feels super refreshing in the heat. Once you’ve had enough of that, imagine drinking the can of soda and imagine how refreshing it is. HINT: This shares the reading with 干 as well, which is part of this kanji.

meaning_story: Your hand has an eye on it and you use it to watch over others. It’s not normal to have an eye on one’s hand, but your hand has been surgically modified to have an eye on it. Since you can raise your hand way up above your head, the eye on it makes it easy to watch over others.
meaning_hint: Imagine having an eye on your hand. How would you use it? Think of all the different perspectives you could have using this hand-eye. Be sure to remember the hand radical is modified in this kanji, since there’s an eye grafted onto the hand and all.
reading_story: While you use your hand-eye to watch over people, a can (かん) hits you in the back of the head. “Freak!” a child yells as he and his friends giggle and run away. It not unusual for you to take a can to the head these days. People think you are strange and unusual so they’ve taken to throwing a can at you whenever they get the chance.
reading_hint: Imagine getting hit in the head with a can. It hurts. Feel this pain along with the rejection of being a social outcast. It’s rough.

meaning_story: If you want to stop the moon you need to get everyone to be in agreement about it first. That means everyone on the moon has to give their consent to its stoppage too.
meaning_hint: Picture everyone on the moon in agreement, hands held high, all for stopping the moon's rotation around the earth.
reading_story: Who got everyone on the moon to be in agreement in the first place? Why, こういち, of course. He got everyone to give their consent.
reading_hint: Picture こういち getting everyone to consent. He's so convincing. How could they not be in agreement?

meaning_story: If you want to have a tsunami at your wedding, you need to make sure you have it at the bay. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time.
meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
reading_story: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent.
reading_hint: Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!

meaning_story: You come home and your husband grew horns and is holding a nailbat. All you can think is that you have to get between him and that nailbat! If you can get between them, maybe you can do something to help him!
meaning_hint: Imaging trying to get between your horned husband and the naibat. Imagine trying to shimmy your way between his arms.
reading_story: You're having trouble getting between him and the nailbat so you say, "Husband (はさ)! Husband let me through!" Something about hearing you say husband is working!
reading_hint: "Husband!" you shout once more, and he lets you in between him and the nailbat. You grab it and bop him on the head. The horns disappear. He's back to normal!

meaning_story: If you throw a hot slinky into a tsunami the water will instantly start to boil. It has to be a slinky though, that's the only way to make a tsunami boil.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself standing in front of a tsunami, slinky in your hand, nice and hot. You toss it into the wave and the water begins you boil. (Why did you do that? That didn't seem very smart.)
reading_story: The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots.
reading_hint: Feel your poor little foots burn in the boiling water. You really shouldn't have dropped that slinky in there.

radical_names: Drop, Ground, Horns, Lantern, Ten Thousand
meaning_story: A lantern with horns that can hold ten thousand drops of water is sitting on the ground. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's a bottle. It's got horns, and a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle with water inside of it.
meaning_hint: Picture this horned bottle sitting on the ground. You don't know who left it here or why, but it's here and the weirdest looking bottle you've ever seen.
reading_story: Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know.
reading_hint: Imagine picking up this weird bottle with your bare hands and putting it in a trash bin. You did your good deed for today! Yay!

meaning_story: When the Joker is alone he gets really lonely so he calls everyone he knows and tries to get them to eat together. He tries to be extra polite, because he hates when it's just him.
meaning_hint: Imagine the Joker politely calling people to come eat with him. It's so out of character. The joker probably shouldn't be left alone.
reading_story: He even has the nerve to call the Shogun (しょう) to come eat with him.
reading_hint: Picture the Joker calling the Shogun asking him to eat dinner with him. He's being super polite, but you're pretty sure the Shogun is going to say no.

meaning_story: While you're wading in the ocean you slam your toe into a clam. Ouch! "Open up clam!" You say, picking it up angrily. But the clam won't open up. It's made a vow of chastity, so it won't open for anyone. Even your toe.
meaning_hint: Imagine kicking your toe into the clam a few more times and realizing it must really be serious about this chastity thing since it still won't open.
reading_story: "Isn't there anything you'll break your vow of chastity for, clam?" you ask. A little voice finally responds, "Well... maybe for a tater (てい) tot." Luckily you have some tater tots jammed into your swimsuit. I guess some chastity vows can be broken! As long as you have some tater tots and a hungry clam.
reading_hint: Picture the clam giving up its vow of chastity to eat your delicious tater tots.

meaning_story: There is a special type of meditation where you put a lid on your mouth and touch your forehead down to your legs. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely clear. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it.
meaning_hint: Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
reading_story: Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind.
reading_hint: Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.

meaning_story: If you want to keep a pelican next to some trees while you jackhammer under them, you have to find a collar to tie it there. Pelicans hate jackhammers, so if you don't get it a strong collar it will break free and fly away.
meaning_hint: If you want to keep a pelican next to some trees while you jackhammer under them, you have to find a collar to tie it there. Pelicans hate jackhammers, so if you don't get it a strong collar it will break free and fly away.
reading_story: Well, the collar snaps off and the pelican flies away as you yell, "ERIC (えり)!" Your pelican's name was Eric but now he's free. You look down at the collar with his name in sparkly letters spelling it out in your hand. Now this collar is all you have left of him.
reading_hint: Look down at the collar with Eric's name on it and cry. Maybe you shouldn't have brought him to work today.

meaning_story: If a butcher sees Splinter he'll run him into the corner with his butcher knife! Splinter is a rat, after all, whether he talks or not. So a butcher will run him into the corner to kill him!
meaning_hint: Picture Splinter cowering in the corner, the butcher looming over him, ready to strike!
reading_story: Splinter is stuck in the corner, there's no where for him to run. He says,"The turtles will get you for this!" "Sue me (すみ)!" the butcher responds, and slashes.
reading_hint: Picture the bloody corner. Hear the last words Splinter heard. "Sue Me." Well he can't now, because he's dead.

meaning_story: Your buddy the butcher lives in the next county. If they lived any closer than the next county, you wouldn't be buddies with the butcher because you need your space. Make sure your butcher buddy stays over there.
meaning_hint: Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. Point to the county where you butcher buddy lives. Glare at the county a little.
reading_story: As you stare at the next county on you map you take out your gun (ぐん) and shoot it. Take that buddy butcher's county! You stay over there where you belong or my gun will have something to say!
reading_hint: Picture yourself pointing a gun at the outline of the county. See the word "county" and shoot through it with the gun.

meaning_story: You set fire to the tree all your products are stored in so that they will dry up. You needed to get all the moisture out of them and this was the fastest way you could come up with.
