meaning_hint: Imagine the fire burning up the bottom of the tree with all of your products at the top. Watch the moisture drain out of the them as they dry up.
reading_story: Now that all your stuff has had a chance to dry up you'll have to find a way to get them from the burning tree. So you sew (そう) yourself some oven mits.
reading_hint: Picture yourself sewing oven mits so that you can read your dried up good in the tree fire. You probably should have done this beforehand.

meaning_story: Kill a shrimp with a sickle and you'll need a really good explanation for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation?
meaning_hint: Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
reading_story: In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.
reading_hint: Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.

meaning_story: If you eat both the moon and the sun with a spoon you'll get fat. Maybe if you only ate one you could get away with it, but you wanted both and now you're pretty fat.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself digging your spoon into the moon, then into the sun, and gulping them both down. Watch your stomach swell with the sun and moon fats. No going back now, gotta finish.
reading_story: Once you're nice and fat, you look in the mirror to admire your new girth. But that's not your face. It's Charlie Sheen's (し)! You're a fat, round Charlie Sheen now!
reading_hint: Picture fat Charlie Sheen rolling around in space. There is no sun, no moon, only Sheen's fat body for the earth to orbit.

meaning_story: The leader of the cow gods is destined for greatness. All the other cow gods could sense this and that's why they made it their leader in the first place.
meaning_hint: Imagine the leader cow god, standing in front of all the other cow gods. Its greatness radiating from its cow god body.
reading_story: You almost can't hand the awesome greatness of this cow god. Just when you think you have to look away, a great eagle (い) soars overhead, letting out a cry. What a scene.
reading_hint: Picture the greatness of the scene before you and see the eagle flying overhead.

meaning_story: If you pay attention to the car antennas as you go down the street, you can use them as a house counter. Everyone knows you can only have one car antenna per household, so it makes counting houses way easier.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself using each car antenna to count each house. One, two, three houses, ah ah ah.
reading_story: Who would care so much about house counters? Ken (けん) from Street Fighter! He loves counting houses. That's what he does in his free time.
reading_hint: Picture Ken going from house to house, counting them all. He's an odd one.

meaning_story: There is only one type of flower that will grow out of your car after you push it down a water slide into water and that's a lotus. Lotus flowers are the only ones that will grow out of a car that's been submerged in water. Soon your car will be covered in beautiful lotuses.
meaning_hint: Picture sliding your car into the water under the lotus flowers. Picture you car covered in beautiful white lotuses under the water.
reading_story: Don't worry about your lotus filled car though, it was a just a rental (れん) anyway. If you bring the rental place back some beautiful lotuses maybe they won't care they you sunk their car?
reading_hint: Imagine youself smelling the lotuses growing on your sunken rental car. Now you laugh. You laugh because it wasn't your car and you don't care because you have lotuses. Lotuses everywhere!

meaning_story: A person with horns has you on the ground and lets loose two poops over your heart. "Mercy! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
reading_story: As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.

meaning_story: You bury the forehead of a pig into a shallow grave and it makes a small mound of earth. You didn't bury it very well. Someone might trip on this mound!
meaning_hint: Imagine the mound you made by burying the forehead of a pig in a little grave. Is it a pig shaped mound?
reading_story: You're starting to think you should cover up this mound when Mr. Tsukalos (つか), the famous Ancient Alien theorist, comes walking up. He's convinced the mound is the site of alien activity. Oh Mr. Tsukalos.
reading_hint: Picture Mr. Tsukalos staring intently at the mound, then the sky, then the mound again, then the sky again, then the mound again (forever).

meaning_story: The mysterious radical and the mysterious kanji are exactly the same! Hooray!
meaning_hint: Make sure you remember this radical means mysterious and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
reading_story: The most mysterious thing in the world is the current generation (げん) of kids. Everything they do makes no sense to you and the people in your generation.
reading_hint: Picture this mysterious generation of kids. Dang new generations and their new mysterious technology.

meaning_story: When the moon faces the right direction, everyone on earth becomes obese. The pull of the moon moves all the water on earth and inside us, so when it faces the right way, we all get super fat.
meaning_hint: Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel you body start to become really obese. You get huge and round just like the moon.
reading_story: The only way to stop the moon from making everyone obese is to shoot it with a bow (ぼう) and arrow. Then the moon will pop and everyone will go back to normal.
reading_hint: Picture yourself, as obese as the moon, trying to pull back the string of your bow. It's really hard because you're really round now.

meaning_story: When a giant redwood grows next to your well you'll have to find a new place to plow. The redwood is so big that you can't get in the well anymore, and you can't plow your fields without a well. You're going to have to plow new land for the rest of the year to make up for this.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself plowing a new plot of land. Digging into the soil with your plough, glaring up at the redwood that overtook your well.
reading_story: Just when you didn't think you could plow anymore, our own こういち comes running up to you. He loves plowing. He's going to plow your whole new field for you. That's suspiciously nice of him!
reading_hint: Picture こういち offering to plow your fields.

meaning_story: Everyone knows that when a woman plays football she becomes a princess. Thats how princesses are made.
meaning_hint: Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
reading_story: Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too.
reading_hint: Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.

meaning_story: If you see a bunch of ducks on the ground around a butcher, you've found his residence. Butchers like to chop up ducks right on their front lawns because it makes them feel at home.
meaning_hint: Picture all the dead ducks on the ground by the butcher's feet. This may be the ideal residence for him, but it's not where you'd choose to live.
reading_story: If you look at his actual residence, you'll see that it's made entirely of tater (てい) tots. That's how he gets the ducks to show up. They see a residence made of tater tots and try to eat it, then he butchers them.
reading_hint: Picture this residence made entirely of tater tots. They're pretty stale. You still wouldn't choose to live here.

meaning_story: There is an enclosure with a big mouth full of legs coming really really close to your mouth so you scream! Scream because that's terrifying! Get it away from your mouth!
meaning_hint: Imagine an enclosure with a big mouth with legs sticking out of it inching closer and closer to your own mouth. Imagine opening your mouth as wide as you can before they mouth presses against yours and scream as loud as you possibly can.
reading_story: As you scream you feel something in your own mouth. You scream louder and a tin can (かん) comes flying out of your mouth and covers up the entire enclosure, saving you from the horrible thing that was making you scream in the first place!
reading_hint: Imagine screaming so loudly that a can came up your throat, out of your mouth, and stopped whatever was scaring you! That's a cool superpower. The power of canned screams!

meaning_story: Flowers that grow in a rice paddy only live to be seedlings. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings.
meaning_hint: Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
reading_story: The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou.
reading_hint: Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.

meaning_story: A turkey sitting on a stool is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal ship counter is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
reading_story: Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!

meaning_story: If you look in a tiger's stomach you'll find a bunch of skin. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself opening a tigers mouth and looking all the way down into its stomach and seeing a bunch of skin. Why would you imagine that? Eww.
reading_story: The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.
reading_hint: Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.

meaning_story: A car that's lacking is really soft. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car.
meaning_hint: Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
reading_story: This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy).
reading_hint: Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).

meaning_story: If you mix a bunch of butchers together, they'll want to live together too. The only place for this many butchers is the suburbs.
meaning_hint: Picture lots of butchers mixed together in the suburbs. They wave their butcher's knifes at each other to say hello from their identical houses every morning.
reading_story: Picture this suburb full of butchers. Look closer at their faces and you'll see they're all clones of こういち! This suburb is full of こういち clone butchers. That's not that weird.
reading_hint: Picture all of these こういち butchers smiling up out of their identical suburban houses at you. Look at their faces. Look. （≼⓪≽⋌⋚⋛⋋≼⓪≽）

meaning_story: You're climbing a mountain and you notice that someone is nailing a geoduck to the summit. You try to humbly mind your own business but it's hard to ignore something like that.
meaning_hint: Picture the geoduck nailed to the summit of the mountain. It looks pretty gross. Maybe you shouldn't keep climbing.
reading_story: As you make your way closer to the summit you see the culprit. It's evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! She's standing up there cackling. And she isn't acting humbly at all!
reading_hint: Of course evil Mrs. Chou would do something like this. Maybe you shouldn't keep trying to reach the summit anymore.

kunyomi: すす, ゆす, そそぐ
meaning_story: You need to throw your two wolverines and your turkey into the oncoming tsunami if you want to wash them at the same time. It's the only way you can get them clean at once without the wolverines fighting over the turkey and somebody getting hurt. The tsunami is big enough to wash them all before anything bad happens.
meaning_hint: Imagine the tsunami coming toward you. Two wolverines in one hand and a turkey in the other. You're gonna wash them so good they'll never get dirty again.
reading_story: Once they're nice and washed you need to subdue them my poking each of them with a tack (たく). The tack has special sleeping medicine on it, so once they're nice and clean you can put them back in their cages without them trying to eat each other.
reading_hint: If you want to wash your animals make sure to have your special tack ready. The tsunami will recede pretty fast so get it out!

meaning_story: If you put two mustaches on either side of a tsunami it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes as whirlpool. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them.
meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
reading_story: The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back!
reading_hint: Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.

meaning_story: If you have an ear for the public's heart, you must be very wise. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them, because you listen to their desires so well.
meaning_hint: Watch the wise woman close her eyes and listen to the public's desires. Someday you hope to be like her.
reading_story: The wise woman spends all of her spare time sewing (そう). She sews quietly and listens to the people around her. Saying little, sewing a lot.
reading_hint: Picture a group of wise people, sitting quietly, sewing. Once you become this wise, sewing is really all you have left.

meaning_story: When a tree gets really old it starts to wither.
meaning_hint: Picture this really old tree, looming above you, so very old that it's starting to wither away.
reading_story: Don't feel sad for trees that wither, they'll come back as little 子 (こ) trees.
reading_hint: Picture the circle of life. When a tree withers and dies, and new 子 tree takes its place.

kunyomi: きざ, さいわ, つまび, よ
meaning_story: When a pelican lands on a sheep the two merge and become the most auspicious creature on the planet. Light shines out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at its pelican head and fluffy sheep body. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this thing.
meaning_hint: Picture this auspicious pelican sheep hybrid. Blessing the children with its fluffy wings.
reading_story: The creature is so auspicious that the shogun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the pelican sheep graced the world with its presence.
reading_hint: Picture the shogun telling the world that they must fly pelican sheep flags and that from now on today is known as an auspicious day.

meaning_story: I hope all you're doing in the bathtub is taking a bath. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths!
meaning_hint: Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
reading_story: When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath.
reading_hint: Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...

meaning_story: The leader of that bookshelf thinks that all the books on it are better than everyone else's books. He's a very biased person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific bookshelf he'd probably feel differently.
meaning_hint: Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. If he doesn't see it on his bookshelf he'll tell you it sucks. That's so biased! He didn't even read it...
reading_story: You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has on his bookshelf. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his books with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird.
reading_hint: "This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.

meaning_story: If you look at flowers the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the next thing you notice are the briars. You never see thorns first, only after you've looked at the flowers.
meaning_hint: Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The brairs are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
reading_story: When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch!
reading_hint: Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.

meaning_story: When a butcher tries to build an enclosure made out of sticks around the sun, you can bet it's going to result in a cave in. The sun is way too strong to let an enclosure of sticks stop it from shining.
meaning_hint: Picture the butcher being crushed by the cave in of sticks. Picture the sun being exposed as the sticks fall onto him.
reading_story: Since the cave in, the butcher has lost everything. Now he lives under what's left of his stick enclosure and eats beans out of a can (かん). That's the moral of this story, kids. Don't cause cave ins or you'll be forced to eat canned food for the rest of your sad life.
reading_hint: Picture the butcher, surrounded by his caved in sticks, eating out of can. Butchers hate eating out of cans. This is so sad.

meaning_story: The famous gold triceratops clam is good for only one thing, and that's being made into chains. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability.
meaning_hint: Picture these little gold clams, triceratops horns linking them together in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
reading_story: The only way to break the chain is to saw (さ) it open. Once the clams start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw.
reading_hint: Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.

meaning_story: You give a bunch of clams to a clown as compensation. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept clams as a form of currency. So your compensation is clams.
meaning_hint: Picture the clams in your hands. Picture handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
reading_story: Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of clams, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye."
reading_hint: All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "Bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.

meaning_story: If you wake up at sunrise and look outside at the ground you'll see a fish stick. This is a constant. If you look at the right time you will always see it. I promise. Try tomorrow morning if you don't believe me.
meaning_hint: Imagine constantly waking up at sunrise just to peek outside at the ground to see the fish stick sitting out there. It's always there. You wonder why.
reading_story: Another constant in this situation is seeing こういち crawl out of the mist to come eat that fish stick. You always see him every morning too.
reading_hint: Who is always eating fish sticks at sunrise off the ground? こういち! Who is constantly surprising you? こういち!

meaning_story: You're sewing something with thread but you and your creation get frostbite while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty design. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands.
meaning_hint: Imagine holding your creation in your frostbitten hands as the snowflake design starts to appear. The design gets more and more complicated the longer you watch, twisting this way and that, like it's dancing in front of your eyes.
reading_story: As you watch the snowflake design form you realize they're moving in a ring (りん) pattern. Rings inside bigger rings, linked with smaller rings.
reading_hint: Try to picture this ring design in your head. It's something no human hands could have made, frostbitten or otherwise.

kunyomi: おぼ, しず, ない
meaning_story: If a tsunami were to hit ikea, everyone inside would die. That's why, if you want to live, you should never go to ikea during a tsunami.
meaning_hint: Imagine all the people in ikea watching as a tsunami approaches. If they don't get out of there, they'll all die.
reading_story: The only way to make sure they don't die is to get them in the boats (ぼつ)! Ikea has boats ready incase of a tsunami, didn't you know? Now get those people in them before they die!
reading_hint: Picture all those people in ikea trying their best not to die by running for the boats. I hope they all make it!

meaning_story: You see a nailbat sitting next to a lid covering something, so you lift it and see a turkey next to some poop in there. The turkey looks so sad and you can't help but take it out of there and embrace it. Who would put a turkey under a lid stuck with poop?! And then leave a nailbat... what were they planning? You embrace the turkey tighter.
meaning_hint: Imagine embracing the poor turkey. Imagine what the people who put it here were going to do. Now embrace the poor thing harder.
reading_story: As you embrace the sad turkey it starts to make a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just still scared. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it!
reading_hint: Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. Maybe this is why it was locked in there. Oh well. Embrace it harder and maybe it will stop!

meaning_story: When you combine a water slide, music on the ground, and the sun in summer, you're bound to encounter a whole bunch of new people. In fact, this probably the best way to meet new people, since everybody loves sliding down water slides and listening to music in the summer sun.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself encountering a bunch of new people as you lay on the ground listening to music in the sun as everyone slides down the water slide. Everyone you encounter here just wants to have fun!
reading_story: You never want to forget all the people you've been able to encounter so you decide to sew (そう) them all a best friend bracelet. Now you'll know if you meet them again because you'll see them wearing what you sewed for them.
reading_hint: Imagine all the people you've encountered wearing the friendship bracelets you sewed for them. Imagine taking the time to sew each one. Handing them to the new friends you've been able to meet.

meaning_story: If you try to shove enough flowers into the mouth of a clam by hammering them in there with a cross it will erupt. The flowers will fly everywhere and it will be really pretty. At least that's what you hope will happen.
meaning_hint: Imagine using a cross to bash a bunch of flowers into a clams mouth hole thing. It's hard work, but the eruption that results will be worth it. Imagine what a clam erupting with flowers will look like.
reading_story: Finally the clam erupts and you have more fun (ふん) than you've ever had in your life! Flowers erupt from it's clam mouth and shoot really high up into the sky. You dance in them having way more fun than the clam is having.
reading_hint: Imagine how much fun you'd have when the clam erupts. Imagine how little fun the clam is having erupting with flowers.

meaning_story: A bad jet will slide especially far to one side. Not a little, not an okay amount, an especially drastic slide to one direction or the other. And it's especially dangerous to be in one while it's sliding!
meaning_hint: Think about how especially steep the bad jet it sliding. Feel especially bad about whoever is in there.
reading_story: If you're in one of these jets it's especially important that you make sure that your shoes (しゅ) are tied. If you step on it while trying to stop the sliding, you'll fall even faster.
reading_hint: Repeat after me: It's especially important that I tie my shoes. It's especially important that I tie my shoes. Come on, say it back now!

meaning_story: A leader is standing on the roof with a bunch of books. The leader wants to teach you ethics, so he starts throwing the books off the roof at you. Is this ethical? Probably not...
meaning_hint: Picture the leader throwing books labeled "ETHICS" off the roof at you. Dodge them, or you'll have the word "ethics" smashed into your face.
reading_story: One of the ethics books hits you dead in the face and you hear a ringing (りん) in your ears. The ringing sounds a lot like the word ethics being repeated over and over.
reading_hint: See the ethics book flying at your face. Hear the word ringing and ringing and ringing through your head over and over. Ethics ethics ethics!

meaning_story: The butcher from the east is putting on an exhibit. It's all about eastern butchers and their techniques. You should really go see the exhibit before it closes.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself walking through the exhibit, seeing all the stuff east butchers use when the butcher things.
reading_story: Suddenly you realize that everything in the exhibit is the same. They're all animal chins (ちん). Apparently chin is a delicacy in the east so butchers spend most of their time cutting them off of stuff.
reading_hint: Imagine walking through this chin exhibit. Different kinds of chins in glass cases. Who knew people ate chin? I wonder how it tastes...

meaning_story: If you tie a cross to a turkey you can trick everyone into thinking it's a falcon. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey.
meaning_hint: Imagine tying a cross to this turkey and see it transform into an elegant falcon. Majestic.
reading_story: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there.
reading_hint: Picture your falcon Hayabusa and the real... ok fake.. Hayabusa running around together and kicking butt.

kunyomi: すなわ, なんじ, の
meaning_story: What do stairs do? They take you from where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get from place to place.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself climbing stairs, picture going from room to room. From place to place. From wherever you were to wherever you want to be.
reading_story: If you're you're going from place to place, you should really make sure you have a knife (ない) on you for protection. If you want to make it far enough from home you should seriously consider it. Knives keep everyone safe when they're going far from home.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself taking those first few steps from home, knife heavy in your pocket. You can go as far from home as you want now. The knife will keep you safe.

meaning_story: If you want to have your wedding in a car you're going to need a lot of help. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off.
meaning_hint: Picture all of your close friends coming to help you squeeze everything for the wedding into your car.
reading_story: You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so makes sure you plan early!
reading_hint: Imagine calling all your friends and scheduling when you will get their help. Make sure you have your day planner ready! * this is a Nanori Reading not a Kun'yomi

meaning_story: An animal next to a deformed (modified) elephant in the grass is definitely hunting it. You don't know what kind of animal it is, but it's hunting that weird looking elephant, and it's going to eat it.
meaning_hint: Imagine the shape of an animal, hunting a deformed elephant that's standing in a patch of grass. That elephant's gonna be lunch.
reading_story: Everyone knows that when you're hunting you need to do it in a row (りょう) boat. The animal slowly rows its way toward the lumpy elephant, and the elephant doesn't notice at all. That's why row boats are so essential to hunting.
reading_hint: Picture the animal rowing its hunting boat toward the elephant. That animal sure knows a lot about hunting to be able to work a row boat like that.

meaning_story: If you have spiders in your mouth, then you're going to instigate fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with it's little mouth inside your own mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine having a spider in your mouth. Imagine being angry about it and instigating fights between people because of it.
reading_story: The spider in your mouth tells you to instigate a fight by sawing (さ) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw.
reading_hint: Picture the fight you and the spider instigated. The guy pointing at the saw, then pointing at his sawed off leg. Listen as the spider tells you to shake your head.

meaning_story: If you tell a narwhal to start construction of a replica of the moon made out of fish sticks, you'll realize just how lazy they are. The narwhal is so lazy that it isn't even going to start. When you ask how the fish stick moon is coming it will shrug and fall asleep. So lazy.
meaning_hint: Picture the lazy narwhal, laying on the beach next to a pile of fish sticks staring up at the moon. It isn't going to start construction. It probably never will.
reading_story: You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right.
reading_hint: Picture your lazy dad. Your big lazy narwhal dad.

meaning_story: If you pile food into your mouth to fill your broken heart you'll just get really lazy. Food can't fill you heart. And food will just make you slower and more sad. Being lazy isn't going to make this any better.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself piling food into your mouth and pretending it's going into your heart while you become lazier and lazier. You can't even reach the food eventually because you're too lazy to raise your hands to get it.
reading_story: You're too lazy to move anymore so you tie (たい) your pile of food to your arm so you don't have to get up anymore. You tie the remote, your laptop, and your cat to you too, because you don't want to have to get up to get those either.
reading_hint: Imagine tying all these things to yourself because you're too lazy to do anything anymore. You even get tired as you're tying and you're too lazy to finish. Especially after your cat gnaws its way out.

meaning_story: Take a leather helicopter to the moon to prove your excellent leadership. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space!
meaning_hint: Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
reading_story: Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely!
reading_hint: Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!

kunyomi: すべから, すべし, ひげ, まつ, もち, もと
meaning_story: Shaving the hair off a geoduck before you try to eat is is absolutely necessary. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair.
meaning_hint: Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
reading_story: It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit it necessary for you to enjoy it correctly.
reading_hint: What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.

meaning_story: If you take a cow's life you're turning it into an offering. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
reading_story: As you're presenting the offering, you hear a noise in the heavens, coming closer. "Sei (せい) sei sei!" you hear, as Hard Gay descends from the heavens, to take the cow offering. I guess you were praying to Hard Gay... that's ... okay well, that's you decision to make I guess.
reading_hint: Imagine Hard Gay, floating down to take your offering. "Sei sei sei!" He says, saluting you on his way back up, and winking.

meaning_story: If a pine has a fault and it's found then it needs to be put back in order. Pine trees must be perfectly straight and tall, otherwise they'll be cut down. So special people will go out and check them to confirm their regularity. Keeping order is a tough job!
meaning_hint: Imagine going out to enforce order among the pine trees yourself. Order whichever ones have faults to be cut down!
reading_story: While you bring order to the rows of pine trees you know there is some other guy who cheats (ちつ). He's been letting faulty trees stand! This is not bringing order, this is chaos! You have to stop him from cheating!
reading_hint: You can't carry out order if there is a guy who cheats right under your nose. You have to find the cheater and bring order to HIM!

meaning_story: When do you give a child a melon? When their parents are dead. You only give an orphan a melon. Otherwise you would have kept it for yourself and let their living parents buy them their own damn melon.
meaning_hint: Imagine a hungry orphan sitting on the street, eyeing your melon. You have to give in and give the poor kid your melon because no one else will.
reading_story: Orphans are always 子 (こ), not adults. No one calls an adult without parents an orphan, because they can take care of themselves and buy their own melons.
reading_hint: Imagine the little 子 orphan eating their new melon. What a great person you are.

meaning_story: If you point flowers in the same direction you'll be able to smell their wonderful perfume. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. Smell the perfume coat your body. You smell great now!
reading_story: As you smell the perfume, you hear a poofing sound and open you eyes to see the flowers are on the coat of none other than Harry Hou-dini (ほう). He laughs and turns the flowers into a bottle of perfume, hands them to you, and disappears.
reading_hint: Picture Houdini turning your flowers into an actual bottle of perfume. Magic!

kunyomi: つらぬ, ぬき, ぬ
meaning_story: Put a clam on a window sill and then slam the window shut to pierce the clam's tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a clam, I promise. This kanji also has a second meaning. That clam you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them sushi counters!
meaning_hint: Imagine the window piercing into the clam shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
reading_story: Now that your clam is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you take all of it and shove it into one big can (かん). You don't have to worry how many pierced pieces you have because you already counted them before.
reading_hint: Picture yourself shoving pierced pieces of clam with little sushi rolls on them into a can, counting as you go. You don't know why you're doing this, but you are.

meaning_story: Once the sunrise appears all of your rice and sunflowers will be turned into provisions for the army. They're scheduled to arrive exactly at sunrise, and then all your rice and sunflower seeds will be taken as provisions to feed them. It's a noble cause, really.
meaning_hint: Picture the troops marching over the fields as the sun rises, taking all of your rice and sunflowers to be their provisions. It's a good cause, they need them more than you do, you tell yourself.
reading_story: Once they have all of their new provisions, they jump into a bunch of row (りょう) boats and start eating the roe (ろう) out of them! Eat roe while you row!
reading_hint: Picture the row boats filled with provisions of roe. Picture them rowing and eating roe.

meaning_story: If you stand in the wind it will be really quick to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up again just to be knocked over again, just as quick.
meaning_hint: Imagine how quick the wind knocks you over when you stand up. So quick, you don't even remember being up. Try again and try to count how many seconds it takes for it to knock you down. Less than one. Now that's quick.
reading_story: The wind was so quick to knock you down that you sat (さつ) down instead. The wind may be quick, but it can't knock you down if you've already sat yourself.
reading_hint: Picture how quick you sat down. Even faster than the quick wind. Nice job!

meaning_story: Sauron sits on a stool in the sun eating fish sticks while he ridicules his troops. Sauron is a really mean dude, so he's known to sit around ridiculing people when he can't find the hobbits.
meaning_hint: Picture the eye of Sauron propped up on a stool under the hot sun, eating a plate of fish sticks, ridiculing all the orcs. He even ridicules the humans and the hobbits, but they can't hear him.
reading_story: What's he saying to ridicule them anyway? He's calling them all fat manatees (まん). Huh that seems tame considering this is the evil being that want to cover the world in darkness, don't you think? I guess orcs have something against manatees.
reading_hint: Picture Sauron ridiculing the orcs by calling them manatees. Try to figure out why being called a manatee would bother someone. Got anything?

meaning_story: If you sit on a grave and plant some beans in your hair during the full moon, your hair will swell to enormous size. If you've been suffering from flat, boring hair, this is the only remedy.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself sitting on the grave, beans in your hair, the full moon rising in the distance. Feel your hair swell. It swells out from your head and gives you a cool new hairdo.
reading_story: Your hair swells so much that it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. If you aren't careful a giant will try to bowl with you!
reading_hint: Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make!

meaning_story: If Splinter slips down a water slide he'll need treatment as soon as he hits the bottom! He's a rat. Rats hate water! How did this happen?!
meaning_hint: Imagine what kind of treatment Splinter will need after hurdling down a water slide at top speed.
reading_story: I'll tell you what kind of treatment Splinter will need. Really good (ぐう) treatment! Otherwise you'll have a dead rat on your hands. And the turtles will be out of a mentor.
reading_hint: Why would you want anything but good treatment?

meaning_story: If you tried to get the death star to say something it would only admonish you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying.
meaning_hint: Imagine being admonished by the death star. It's hovering above you, giant and round, just yelling at you about everything you've ever messed up. It's really awful being yelled at. But the death star doing it is particularly scary and embarrassing.
reading_story: The death star is admonishing you mostly about how you usurped (ゆ) power from the last commander. The death star liked the last one, but it really doesn't like you since you took over and suck.
reading_hint: Imagine the death star admonishing you for usurping your position of commander by pushing the last guy out an airlock. You didn't feel bad about it until now.

meaning_story: If you let a butcher have a water slide he'll end up wanting to have it all! You can't let him have that water slide. Once he gets going he can't be stopped. All the water slides, all the pool toys, all the ducks. He'll take them ALL! Don't you see?
meaning_hint: Picture the butcher hugging the water slide you gave him. Now he's hugging all the water slides. Uh oh.
reading_story: You let the butcher down that stupid slide and now he wants to butchers up all the zoo ea gles (ずい). Those eagles are in the zoo because they're endangered! Look what you've done!
reading_hint: Watch the butcher start chopping up all the zoo eagles. Feel really bad about it because if you hadn't given him that water slide he wouldn't have wanted to kill ALL of them... geez.

meaning_story: Who will you find dancing under the old moon? Barbarians! In the old days they used to sleep outside under the light of the moon, and even today if you look out into the darkness you might see them.
meaning_hint: Picture the barbarians dancing under the old moon. The old moon is hanging really low in the sky, it looks closer, and lights up the barbarians as they dance happily.
reading_story: You’re watching the barbarians dance when you realize that they all look like little 子 (こ)! They’re absolutely adorable 子. Waving their little spears in the moonlight.
reading_hint: 子 barbarians dance under the old moon. Maybe this has something to do with the cycle of life?

meaning_story: With your nailbat in hand and flowers decorating your suit you're ready to board your plane to zombie island. The nailbat is for zombie smashing, the flowers are to mask the zombie smell, and the suit is to look awesome doing it. But you have to embark before you can get to smashing. Get on that plane!
meaning_hint: Picture your hot self boarding the plane. You're the coolest person doing it.
reading_story: Where are you boarding this plane? In Tokyo (とう), of course. There are no finer airports than the ones in Tokyo!
reading_hint: Look at Tokyo out the window as you board your plane. There's Tokyo tower! Wave goodbye!

meaning_story: Two face has a huge gold and white brocade fabric collection. They're all half white and half gold (I wonder why) and very expensive. No one's sure if he made the brocade himself or if he stole them. But everyone knows he has them hidden away somewhere.
meaning_hint: Imagine what Two face's gold and white brocade collection looks like. Hidden away somewhere only he can go to sit in their presence.
reading_story: Two face keeps his brocade fabric locked away and the only way to open the door is with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing. So you have to have the same kind of key to open the door to his secret collection.
reading_hint: Imagine using the niche key to open his hidden brocade storage room. The key is gold and white and looks like brocade too!

meaning_story: If you feed a fish some sunflowers it will turn yellow and orange and black to match, turning into a carp! Japan has so many pretty colored carp because they have just as many sunflowers. The fish eat the sunflowers and turn into all kinds of pretty colors, becoming famous Japanese carp, also known as koi.
meaning_hint: Imagine feeding a sunflower to an ordinary fish and watch as the color spreads from its mouth, down its back, and to the rest of its fishy body. See the red and orange and black colors spread as it transforms into a beautiful carp.
reading_story: A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know?
reading_hint: Carp are koi and koi are carp. Blub blub.

meaning_story: If you wrap up the moon in a bag it will look just like a cell. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening!
meaning_hint: Picture the moon with a big bag circling it. Now look down at your biology homework on cells. They're identical!
reading_story: You want this cell to split into two, then four, and more and more so you can really copy what's going on in class. So you take a garden hoe (ほう) and try to break the moon in two with it. You make it through the bag pretty easily, but the moon is harder to crack than you thought. Are cells really this hard to divide?
reading_hint: Imagine taking your hoe and trying to use it to hack apart your giant cell. "Cells are supposed to divide!" you yell, hacking away with your hoe.

meaning_story: What does a tsunami do to conflict? It cleanses and purifies all of the conflict by washing it away in its waves. If you want to cleanse a country of conflict, just watch as a tsunami wipes it all away.
meaning_hint: Picture the tsunami's waves cleansing the conflict from the land. All the angry people can't fight when they're stuck in a bunch of water.
reading_story: Someone is riding the tsunami and helping cleanse the country and it's... Joseph (じょう) Stalin?!? Guys... he's really not the best person for this... can't we find someone else? Maybe we should cleanse this place without his help.
reading_hint: Picture everyone refusing to let Joseph Stalin to cleanse their country. You tricked us once, buddy. That's not happening again. We'll cleanse this place ourselves.

meaning_story: Two face drop kicks a bear in front of the entire Gotham military. They are so impressed that they make him a commander instantly! I guess crime does pay if you do something cool in front of the right people!
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing Two face drop kick a bear. Even you agree that he deserves to be commander of the army at that point. You can't even imagine anyone better to lead you guys.
reading_story: Commander Two face ends up swinging (すい) everyone to his side and they stop protecting Gotham, and start terrorizing it! No don't let the new commander swing you around like that! He's evil after all. Just because you can drop kick a bear doesn't mean you're fit to be commander of the army!
reading_hint: Watch in horror as the new commander swings everyone in his favor and at his will into attacking the good people of Gotham. Who can swing in to save us!? (No one, Spiderman isn't in this universe!)

meaning_story: If you say something the same way they say it in the capital, everyone in the whole country will be able to comprehend what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it.
meaning_hint: Imagine the confused faces of the people in the countryside as you try to talk to them. Decide to say it the way it's said in the capital and see the their faces light up as they comprehend what you're trying to say.
reading_story: Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home.
reading_hint: Picture yourself rowing away in your new row boat as the townspeople wave goodbye. They were much nicer once they comprehended what you were asking for. Maybe you'll row your way back here someday.

kunyomi: おお, くら, こうむ
meaning_story: Flowers are growing on your pet pig's forehead and it's causing the poor thing to live in total darkness. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it.
meaning_hint: Imagine being a pig with flowers hanging down off your forehead and into your eyes so that darkness was all you knew. It's very sad, actually.
reading_story: To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers off your pig's forehead. You can't just cut them, because they're really strong, so you just drive your lawnmower over its head. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again.
reading_hint: Imagine mowing the darkness away. Be careful! If you mow the pigs eyes, the darkness will last forever!

meaning_story: Sauron shows someone the sun as it rises to teach them what dawn looks like. Everyone is so used to seeing his giant, glowing eye, that they never learned about the other bright glowing thing in the sky, and that it comes up and looks really pretty sometimes. That someone will tell the rest of the orcs all about this new "dawn" thing.
meaning_hint: Imagine what it's like to have Sauron show you the sun at dawn for the first time. It's beautiful!
reading_story: The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles. Now when you see dawn break, you'll see him gazing back at you. All thanks to Sauron.
reading_hint: Look at Akebono looking at you as you look at dawn breaking.

kunyomi: みじ, いた, むご
meaning_story: If you drop your fish sticks in a big pile of hair it will be a disaster! You can't eat those fish sticks now because they're absolutely covered in hair. And you can't use that hair because it's covered in greasy fish sticks. I've never seen such a huge disaster in my life!
meaning_hint: Imagine what a disaster it would be if you dropped your fish sticks in a big pile of hair. Now you'll probably starve to death.
reading_story: This is such a big disaster that Santa (さん) has to leave his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you to your face that you've made it onto the naughty list. "Ho ho how dare you ruin those fish sticks with hair? Everything about you is a disaster!" Then he writes a big NO over your name on his list, sips his Zanzibar martini, and flies back to his vacation spot.
reading_hint: Imagine Santa taking the time to leave Zanzibar to tell you that you're a disaster. Geez.

meaning_story: You finally find a pine tree tall enough to write the entire draft of your novel on. It's going to be a really long draft, and since you haven't written anything else yet, you don't really have the money to buy all the paper it would take to write it all down. But now that you found this super tall pine tree, you'll finally be able to get your draft done!
meaning_hint: Imagine climbing to the top of the tall pine and starting to write your draft at the very top, right into the bark. The tree won't mind, it's going to be your masterpiece!
reading_story: Who's up there writing his entire draft on the trunk of a really tall tree? It's こういち! Little did you know that he always writes his drafts on trees. This one had to be especially tall because he has a lot of feelings to get out.
reading_hint: Picture こういち swinging from tree branch to tree branch, writing his draft into the pine. Majestic!

meaning_story: You come across a door that has a mouth on it in the middle of winter. That's weird, you think. It opens that mouth and begins to enlighten you. Suddenly you're seeing things clearly, thanks to this mouth door in the snow.
meaning_hint: Imagine hearing enlightening things from a door with a mouth in winter. You never would have thought of these things without this door to enlighten you.
reading_story: The door enlightened you about how being apart of the KKK (けい) is a really bad life choice. You've been enlightened to all the awful things you said and did while you were a member and resolve to quit immediately!
reading_hint: You've been enlightened you into realizing what being a KKK member means for who you are. You know now that you were wrong.

meaning_story: You smash your skin with a nailbat to expose the what's underneath. It might not be the best way to expose what you're made of, but you already had the nailbat, so why not?
meaning_hint: Imagine smashing your own skin open to expose your insides with a nailbat. Brutal.
reading_story: You expose what's under your skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out of the hole. You knew something weird was going on, that's why you smashed it open in the first place. The heat is so strong you think that you must have exposed some lava in your body!
reading_hint: Imagine heat blasting you in the face from your exposed skin. It's so hot it burns your eyebrows off!

meaning_story: A drunkard crosses thread across special spikes to separate the fibers. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves!
meaning_hint: Imagine a drunkard crossing threads onto spikes and pulling the tiny fibers free. You don't think you could do that. Maybe if you got drunk too...
reading_story: You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it...
reading_hint: Watch the centaur cross the fibers and separate them with his spikes. How strange.

meaning_story: If you have a surplus of loiter time, then you never rush, and do everything gently. People are only violent if they don't have time to do things. When you have plenty of loiter time, you are very, very careful, making you very, very gentle too!
meaning_hint: Gently cut your food and eat it. Gently pet your cat. There's no reason to rush because you have a surplus of loitering time. Gently lean against the wall in front of your house and stare out into space.
reading_story: You even gently do martial arts. Gently hit your opponent with your jo (じょ) fighting stick. They're going to look at you funny and wack you hard back, but you have all day to fight them. If you hit them a couple thousand times, gently as the hits may be, he'll probably give up.
reading_hint: Imagine the look on your opponents face when you continue to gently hit him with your jo. You might as well use a pillow, not a jo, cause that's what it feels like.

meaning_story: Flowers that are thought to be little tents sent from heaven are hollyhocks. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!
meaning_hint: Picture a tiny yokai using a hollyhock as a tent. Aww cute!
reading_story: Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself in a field of hollyhocks and the あおい of them match the あおい of the heavens! It's like you're standing on a giant flower filled mirror of the sky.

meaning_story: If a horse manages to ride a train to the moon inflation will skyrocket. You can't expect people to look at a dollar and think it should be worth as much as it does now when HORSES CAN FLY TRAINS TO THE MOON. Now one dollar is like a penny.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a horse flying a train to the moon on the news. Now flip the channel and see that inflation has gone up so much that milk costs one hundred dollars. Welcome to the future!
reading_story: Inflation rises the most in Tokyo (とう). It is one of the most technological cities, and things were already pretty expensive there. But seeing that horse was the last straw. You thought one yen was worthless before. Ohoho, wait until you see how expensive things are in Tokyo now!
reading_hint: Imagine walking around Tokyo and not being able to even buy a pocari sweat for less than 100,000 yen! This inflation in Tokyo is ridiculous!!

meaning_story: You have a nailbat propping up and old flag but it's finally time to install a new one. It's too old to stay up anymore, and it wasn't the best contraption anyway. You should really take this one down and install a new one in its place.
meaning_hint: Try to think of what you're going to install in the old flag's place. Any ideas? I could use a new installation myself.
reading_story: You've decided to install a suit (す) where the flag was, so you attach an entire three piece suit to the nailbat. Installation takes some time, lots of nails and stuff, but once you're done you feel pretty good about it.
reading_hint: Imagine installing a suit to fly above your home. The suit flutters in the air just like that old flag did. Installation complete and successful!

meaning_story: Flowers that grow in the ribs of pine trees are jasmine flowers. If you bend down to look at the bottoms of trees, where the ribs are, you'll see pretty little white flowers growing there. Those are jasmine and they smell really sweet. But you can only find them here, they never grow on their own.
meaning_hint: Picture the little jasmine flowers coming out of the ribs of the tree. Reach down and pick one. Smell how sweet it smells.
reading_story: This jasmine flower smells so sweet that it's reminding you of something. It smells like... reese's (り) pieces! Jasmine is now your favorite flower of all time because reese's smell great.
reading_hint: Imagine smelling the little jasmine flower and the aroma of reese's pieces fills your nose. Smells like peanut butter, chocolate, and definitely not regret.

meaning_story: Give a thread to the cow god and it will fly that thread around the earth, parallel to the equator, until it's marked all the latitude lines with it. That's the only way to really know where they are. If they cow god weren't here, we wouldn't even know what latitude was.
meaning_hint: Picture the cow god flying around the earth with the thread, marking the latitude lines. Quickly draw them on your map of the earth so you won't have to ask the god again!
reading_story: The cow god is marking latitude lines so fast that it almost looks like an eagle (い), not a cow. But... but it's the cow god, right? So maybe it transforms into an eagle to fly. Or maybe only eagles can see the latitude lines!
reading_hint: Picture the cow god transforming into an eagle so it can see the latitude lines running parallel to the equator. Then flying around the earth, laying the thread you gave it down so you can see them too.

meaning_story: The melon radical and the melon kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
meaning_hint: Make sure you remember this radical means melon and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
reading_story: What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see.
reading_hint: Imagine hitting the gas pedal in your car as you head for a big melon. Watch it burst into a million pieces as your car makes contact, hurling melon bits all over your windshield. It's a melon firework!

meaning_story: Tigers and wolverines have one big thing in common and it's that the government likes to oppress them. It doesn't matter if you're the animal or a mutant xmen hybrid. The government will go out of its way to oppress you if you are one.
meaning_hint: Imagine being a tiger or a wolverine or a tiger-wolverine and being oppressed by the government just because you're different. Imagine being stuck in a cage. Not being allowed to vote. It's awful!
reading_story: Tiger and wolverine people are so oppressed that the only thing they're allowed to amuse themselves with is Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird goo they made us play with when we were kids? Well that's not so fun when it's all you have.
reading_hint: Imagine being a tiger/wolverine girl and being so oppressed that you can only sit in a cage, playing with goopy Gak all day. This blows...

radical_names: Cross, Fins, Rice Paddy, Blackjack, Drunkard
meaning_story: If you cross a drunkard playing blackjack in a rice paddy with fins on his feet, get ready to receive something really strange. Whether it's something physical, or some "sage" advice, just prepare to receive something, say thank you, and try to be on your way.
meaning_hint: Imagine what you'll receive from this weird looking dude sitting in the middle of a rice paddy.
reading_story: As you expected, the man hands you something and you reach out to receive it. It's a tie (たい). That's it. A normal necktie. Nothing weird about it at all. Huh.
reading_hint: Imagine receiving an ordinary tie from this drunk, blackjack playing, rice paddy sitting, fin wearing guy. Receiving such a normal item is creepier somehow...

meaning_story: You decide to sail with big bird who just so happens to be the king. He's offered to take you out sailing now that he's king so you meet him out by the water. Instead of what you were expecting, king big bird is sitting in a tiny rowboat. "Let's sail!" he says. But you just end up rowing him around in a rowboat all day.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in the rowboat with king big bird. Think about how disappointed you are to not be sailing in a grand vessel, and instead how you're aching arms are stuck rowing this rowboat.
reading_story: As you row around in the rowboat, king big bird pulls out something to snack on. They're tater (てい) tots. You love tater tots but when you ask for some king big bird explains that you have to keep rowing the row boat. He eats the tater tots right in front of you.
reading_hint: Smell the delicious tater tot smell as your arms ache from rowing the rowboat. Tater tots would have really hit the spot if the king wasn't such a jerk.

meaning_story: This is a sail, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks rust colored. It's getting more and more rusty as time goes on.
meaning_hint: Picture this half broken, rust colored sail. It's like a reddish-brown color and it's definitely missing some important pieces.
reading_story: The rust colored sail has inspired you and you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact rust color as the sail and in a few hours you're sure you'll match.
reading_hint: Watch your skin slowly change as you tan to match the rust colored sail. Feel your skin in the sun. This may not be good for your health, but it's great for fashion!

meaning_story: Thread signifying injustice is always going to be scarlet colored. Haven't you ever red the Scarlet Letter? That scarlet thread used to sew the A on her shirt marks the injustice of doing what she did. People are marked with red when other people think what they did was really crummy.
meaning_hint: Imagine sewing a big scarlet A on the clothes of someone who's caused some kind of injustice in your life. It's so bright and red, you know everyone will hate them too now.
reading_story: The scarlet mark is so effective that when someone wears it their face heats (ひ) up and turns scarlet too. The heat rises to their face, they blush, and turn a nice scarlet to match the big A you put there.
reading_hint: Imagine looking down at your own shirt and seeing a scarlet letter there. Feel your face heat up and turn the same color. So embarrassing!

meaning_story: Put a turkey on ice and it will only get semi frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck!
meaning_hint: Imagine covering a turkey in ice and every time you check it, it's only semi frozen. It doesn't matter what you do, it just refuses to freeze all the way through.
reading_story: Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it!
reading_hint: The lesson is to never try to freeze something in June. If you do it will only semi freeze.

meaning_story: You want to have a quaint cottage wedding, so you have to go to the cottage wedding shop to get everything you need. This shop is the only place you can buy everything you need. It's not like you can make a cottage from scratch!
meaning_hint: Picture yourself walking into the cottage wedding shop. Look at all the different cottages you get to choose from. And there's wedding cake too?! This shop has everything!
reading_story: You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe give you away at your wedding.
reading_hint: Imagine walking around the shop and then falling in love with a hoe with pretty tassels and flowers attached to it. Yes, it's only for decoration, but you're going to buy and use it during your cottage wedding.

meaning_story: Put a dead nurse in a grave and she will become one with the soil soon enough. It does't matter who dies, if you're human, you'll turn back into earth eventually.
meaning_hint: Picture the body of a nurse decomposing into soil like in one of those cool sped up videos they show you in biology class. Soon she'll be completely made of soil!
reading_story: As you're watching the nurse turn to soil you realize that that nurse is Joseph (じょう) Stalin! You had no idea he was a nurse. You could have sworn he wasn't that important during the war, but it doesn't matter now because he's already half earth-i-fied.
reading_hint: Imagine seeing a half earth, half nurse Joseph Stalin.

meaning_story: When a horse sees a spider it will start running at a speed no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.
meaning_hint: Imagine the eyes of a horse seeing a spider and then running at top speed to get the heck away from it.
reading_story: Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner.
reading_hint: Soon the world will be filled with horses running at full speed all thanks to the spider increase of the 2000s! Soon we will be in the future of top speeds!

meaning_story: You're about to put the last pine encrusted ribs into your mouth for dinner when more come out! And more. And more! It seems that there is a surplus of pine ribs in this restaurant! That means there's more for you! Yay!
meaning_hint: Imagine if there was a surplus of all kinds of food in the world. That would solve a lot of problems!
reading_story: Where did this surplus come from? You go in back to thank the chef and you see Joseph (じょう) Stalin hauling them all in on the backs of skinny, sick looking people. You don't want to eat anymore.
reading_hint: Imagine realizing that what you thought was a surplus was actually just Joseph Stalin stealing from other people to make you have more. You wouldn't want to keep eating, would you?

meaning_story: If the world could just see the flowers you put in the helmet of that dead soldier, they would understand the importance of tolerance. Nothing boosts your ability to tolerate other cultures like seeing the bitter beauty of death.
meaning_hint: See the flowers in the helmet. Feel your tolerance for your "enemy" start to grow.
reading_story: Who was looking at the helmet and realizing the importance of tolerance? Genghis Khan (かん). He's decided to stop conquering and start focusing on the people he's ruling. He doesn't care so much about making everyone do everything his way now.
reading_hint: Picture the new Genghis Khan with his new found tolerance of other people. He's giving a flower to a little girl! How nice. He's a new man!

meaning_story: Who's a hick with a fishtail? All the people you've ever known. You have one too.
meaning_hint: All the people in the world (that you associate with, anyway) are hicks with fishtails. It's totally normal.
reading_story: Here, all the people you've ever known have had them, just let me show (しょ) you. This is me showing you. Through the computer. See them? Yeah, they were always there. All people have them.
reading_hint: So, now, who's a hick with a fishtail? All people. You're welcome. I don't show everyone this kind of stuff.

onyomi: しょ, しょう, そ
meaning_story: If you want to wear a top hat you also have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it.
meaning_hint: Picture all the things you also need. A suit, a tie, a monocle, some shiny shoes. There's also ... something... else. What is it?
reading_story: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off.
reading_hint: Think about all the things you also need when you wear a top hat. The car is probably the most important addition. Otherwise no one can see the top hat in the first place!

meaning_story: When the sun comes up geoduck spikes appear. You didn't know they had spikes did you? Well that's because you've never seen one in direct sunlight. You only see them inside after they are chopped up and you're already eating them.
meaning_hint: Watch a geoduck careful while the sun rises and it's spikes will appear out of no where! You have to look closely though, otherwise they could appear and you won't see it!
reading_story: If you're having trouble seeing the spikes appear just get Ken (けん)from Street Fighter to help you. He's the master at knowing when geoduck spikes are about to appear.
reading_hint: Imagine watching them appear with Ken's help. He's such a good guy, that Ken. Always appearing when you need him!

onyomi: あん, きょう, こう
meaning_story: What does a tree make that you'd want to put in your mouth? An apricot! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth!
meaning_hint: Picture the mouth sized apricots hanging down off the tree. Imagine using your own mouth to bite them down. Just don't swallow the pit!
reading_story: After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to eat the bite sized apricot and spitting it out after the taste of anchovies from the zoo fill you up.

meaning_story: Cut two little antenna shapes from a tree and make them into bookmarks! The book you're reading comes from a tree, so it only feels right to make the bookmarks out of a tree too!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself pulling off antenna shaped branches and putting them in your book as a bookmark. Get another one in case you want to mark another page for later.
reading_story: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says She owes (しお) recee's (り) pieces! Oh yeah! You keep forgetting that girl owes you some reese's so you needed to bookmark this page so you'd stop forgetting to ask for them back!
reading_hint: What does she owe you? Open the page to your bookmark and see she owes reese's pieces!

meaning_story: You see a bunch of trees lined up outside of the gate to the east and realize they they look like perfect columns. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them.
meaning_hint: Picture these column trees outside the gate to the east. You end up drawing them in the columns of your graph paper because they fit so well.
reading_story: Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!"
reading_hint: Now draw Randy Savage in the columns on your graph paper. He just seems to fit there now.

meaning_story: The origin of the measurement of power comes from looking at someone's forehead. You know they're the most powerful person in the land if there is a crown on their forehead. Then you don't even have to measure, because it should be obvious how powerful they are.
meaning_hint: The origin of looking at foreheads to take a measurement of their status goes way back, but a crown is a crown. That means they're at the top.
reading_story: You look at the crown on the king's head, the ultimate measurement of status, and see that it's just an old can (かん). Was his crown always just a can? Maybe this is a bad way to measure this kind of stuff...
reading_hint: That can crown just doesn't seem right to you. Is that even the king?

meaning_story: If you announce that alcohol is illegal you're just being cruel. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally unjust. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink!
meaning_hint: Imagine if your country's leader announced that there would be no more alcohol. People would be in the streets in seconds calling them cruel and unjust!
reading_story: After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof.
reading_hint: Imagine drinking coke while complaining how unjust it is that you can't add rum to it.

meaning_story: You have a surplus of stools and you don't know how they got there so you call the cops and describe the scene to them. They keep asking more and more questions and you have to describe every detail of what your house looked like before, when you only have about four stools, and now when you have like 4420 stools.
meaning_hint: Where did this surplus of stools come from? they ask. You describe how you left the door open all night, but other than that, there's no reason you should have so many, you say.
reading_story: You describe what happened so many times that you really start to lose your patience. You describe the many stools again and again until you snap, hang up, and take your jo (じょ) out and smash all the extra stools! Your jo is wooden too, but it smashes up the surplus of stools pretty easily. You never want to have to describe another stool again! SO YOU'LL KILL THEM ALL!
reading_hint: Imagine smashing all the stools with your jo and screaming about how you'll never describe anything to cops again! Hell, you'll never describe any situation to anyone ever again or they will be smashed up with your jo too!

meaning_story: Jump on a water slide to excuse yourself from answering a question and you've successfully deviated from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to elude them pretty well. They'll have to go down the water slide to catch up and you're already at the bottom running.
meaning_hint: Imagine excusing yourself to jump down a water slide, deviating from the plan. It feels to exhilarating!
reading_story: You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're running what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them? What the hell... that's not fair. You're supposed to get away with it!
reading_hint: Feel the guilt as it eats away at you because you decided to elude someone who seemed to need something from you.

meaning_story: You're using thread to sew the shape of a doll on some fabric because that's your family crest. You need to sew the doll on all your clothes, armor, shields, and flags so that the whole world will know it's your family crest. They're gonna think your family is so cool.
meaning_hint: Imagine the thread slowly forming into the shape of the doll to make your family crest. You've known this doll since you were born and it's been in on everything in your family for generations.
reading_story: Why even bother sewing your family crest into everything? Because the town across the river has a different crest and it's a monster (もん)! That means they're evil so everyone in your family needs to wear their crest proudly to show that they aren't monsters.
reading_hint: Picture yourself, doll family crest displayed proudly on your chest, flag above your head. And look across the river at the monster family crest on their chests and flags. Wave yours harder! Let them know you're better than the monsters!

meaning_story: You see a butcher with a lip ring and it's just so cute that you have to compliment him on it. You compliment him and he's so flattered he turns as red as the blood on his apron.
meaning_hint: Flattering people is a really nice thing to do, as long as they're okay with it. Imagine how happy the butcher is when you tell him you like his lip ring.
reading_story: The butcher is so flattered he can't even come up with anything to say in response. "Ahhhh (あ)," is all he can manage. "Ah ahha ahhh." Well, at least it seems like he appreciated your compliment.
