reading_hint: Hear the flattered butcher "Ahhh"ing at you. You should probably leave now. I don't think he's going to stop.

meaning_story: If you give Splinter your heart you'll feel pretty foolish afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu!
meaning_hint: You were foolish to give your heart away to Splinter. He didn't want it. Also he's a rat, what's wrong with you?
reading_story: Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo.
reading_hint: What will you do with your foolish goo heart now?

meaning_story: A triceratops with a mustache will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "Furthermore..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high esteem that no one ever interrupts him.
meaning_hint: Imagine this mustachioed triceratops. He probably has a monocle and a fedora too. Every time you think you can talk or leave he says, "Furthermore" again. Come on guy, how much do you have to say?
reading_story: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the shogun (しょう)! If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about.
reading_hint: "Furthermore!" the mustachioed triceratops shogun proclaims, "I am the best shogun we'll ever have. Look how long my mustache is! Furthermore, look at my horns, they're so sharp, I can impale all other shoguns. FURTHERMORE, look at my awesome throne..." He'll never stop, will he?

meaning_story: You get hit in the mouth with a nailbat AND a sword. When you come to it seems that someone kidnapped you! What the hell. They could have been a little more gentle about it!
meaning_hint: Imagine getting hit in the mouth with a nailbat and then a sword as someone kidnaps you. I guess they thought you wouldn't cooperate with being kidnapped so they made sure you'd be out.
reading_story: Your kidnapped self wakes up and sees a coyote (かい) holding the nailbat and the sword. Wait, a coyote kidnapped you? Why? And how is it even holding those weapons?!
reading_hint: You have so many questions for this coyote, but you guess that's all a part of what kidnapping is about.

meaning_story: The leader who usually hits you with a stick finds it in his wintery heart to let you have some leisure time. Yes! Now it's time to do a lot of nothing.
meaning_hint: Imagine your surprise when the grumpy old leader lets you have some actual leisure time to do whatever you want!
reading_story: Who gets leisure time? You (ゆう) do! No one else. But who cares! You're the only one who matters!
reading_hint: You get leisure time, YOU get leisure time, YOOOU ALLL GET- wait no. Just you.

meaning_story: If your fish tail is heavy with power then you also have a lot of merit. It makes you important to all the other fish, because you have a very powerful tail. And tails are very important and worthy of merit, anyway.
meaning_hint: Imagine being a fish with a tail containing all your merit. But you're happy because you have a tail heavy with power! Everything's coming up fishhouse!
reading_story: The problem with all your merit being in your tail is that it makes you slow. You may seem cool to all the fish, but you can easily be caught by a raccoon (くん). It will catch your slow fishy self and eat your tail off. Then you'll be thrown back in the water with all your merit as a fish gone.
reading_hint: Remember kids, if all your merit is in one place, a raccoon will eat you.

meaning_story: An ent will give up on life and become a coat rack if you neglect it. Ents need lots of love and care. You have to water them, fertilize and prune them, but you didn't and now your friend the ent has given up it's life to become a coat rack.
meaning_hint: Imagine your sadness to see the ent you've been neglecting is now a lumpy coat rack, sitting outside your door.
reading_story: The sad part isn't even that you neglected your friend the ent so much that it became a coat rack. It's that it's not even a good looking coat rack. It's just a so-so (そ) coat rack. Do you see how your neglect did this? You should have paid it more attention, or at least showed it what a coat rack should have looked like so when it gave up on life it would have looked better than so-so.
reading_hint: Your neglect caused this so-so coatrack to be rooted outside your house. This is your own fault, you know.

meaning_story: Whatever you say through a satellite turns into Noh chanting. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least.
meaning_hint: Say whatever you want and send it up to the satellite. Now imagine listening to it when it comes back and hearing beautiful, deep Noh chanting back!
reading_story: While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work.
reading_hint: Watch closely the next time you go to a Noh play. See the man Noh chanting? Watch close enough and you'll see him eat a scoop of yogurt every once in a while.

meaning_story: After your wedding you have a baby and it uses its mouth to nurse from you post-marriage boobs. Yes, babies nurse from breasts. Get over it, kids.
meaning_hint: You waited until your wedding to have your baby and all it seems to do with its mouth is want to nurse. It doesn't cry, which is nice, but it doesn't laugh or talk either.
reading_story: The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time!
reading_hint: This hoe has really helped you get through nursing. You think you'll keep this up even after your baby is weened off! Hoeing the garden is your new favorite hobby!

meaning_story: When a drunkard gets it in his head that he wants to grow a redwood, he'll usually start planting right away. It doesn't matter where he is. Sometimes you'll see a drunkard trying to dig out weeds on the floor of a bar, behind a car in a parking lot, or even under your kitchen table. Planting is great and all, but drunkards try to do it everywhere because they're drunk and don't know the right way to do it. The redwood ends up looking kind of funny too, because they weren't planted right.
meaning_hint: Picture a drunkard planting their funny looking redwood in the dirt by an outhouse. That redwood is going to look really funky because of this guy.
reading_story: While the drunkard is busy planting (or at least trying to) you go up and offer to help him. He turns around and you're shocked to see he only has one eye. He's a drunk cyclops (さい)! No wonder he's having such a hard time! Planting drunk is hard, but planting drunk with only one eye is almost impossible.
reading_hint: Picture the drunk cyclops trying with all his might not to crush the little lopsided redwood as he tries to plant it. His one big eye fills with tears as the tree he's planted flops over out of the dirt.

meaning_story: You put your foot on the bar at the gymnasium at your very first practice. That's a big accomplishment since you're here leaning how to walk on that long bar like all the cool gymnasts. But you can't just start right away, you need lots of practice so that's why you're here in this class. But so far you got your foot on the bar already, good for you!
meaning_hint: Picture your foot touching the bar. This is it. This is exactly what you're at this gym to practice.
reading_story: This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar!
reading_hint: Picture your centaur foot on the bar as you practice to become a gymnast. It's going to take years and years of this kind of practice, but you're sure you'll make it all the way up there some day! Never give up!

meaning_story: If you want your food to go into the mouth of a king you have to present it in the most attractive way possible! It needs to be displayed in front of the entire court and they all have to approve of it before it will go anywhere near the mouth of the king. You better make sure it looks delicious!
meaning_hint: Imagine your food being presented to the king and the court. They hold it up on a platter and show it to everyone before it heads towards the king's mouth.
reading_story: The food you are trying to present are your home made tater (てい) tots! Watch your yummy, crispy tater tots displayed before the entire royal court. Does the king look like he wants to eat them?!
reading_hint: Picture your tater tots presented before the king. He just keeps staring at them. You hope he shoves them in his mouth!

meaning_story: You come across the grave of a leader that's pointing in the direction of winter (that's north, usually). Whoever made it was very proud of this guy because it says "We are so proud of you" on the grave. You never met this leader, but for some reason seeing his grave makes you proud of him too.
meaning_hint: Imagine how proud you feel for this unknown leader. He must have been a really great one for that inscription to have been put on his grave.
reading_story: You brush the snow off the rest of the grave of this proud leader and see that it says ごういち at the top. Oh no! Thats grandpa Koichi's name! He died?! No wonder it says they're proud of him. You're proud of him too for all he did for you and the Japanese learning people of this world.
reading_hint: Proud, old ごういち. He will be missed.

meaning_story: A sickness that hits you like an arrow will do its gross work rapidly. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast.
meaning_hint: Picture this rapid sickness spreading through your body like a cartoon arrow ricocheting through your body. Yuck!
reading_story: A rapid sickness like this is bound to make you sh*t (しつ) a lot. You should stay close to a toilet because it will come fast and hard.
reading_hint: Imagine that cartoon arrow aiming and rapidly shooting toward your cartoon backside. I hope you're ready for this sh*t storm, cause it'sa comin'.

meaning_story: Flowers that grow in the west are colored by the sun setting so they turn bright red. That's why red flowers that grow in the west are used to make red dye. They're the closest to the actual color of the red sun, so they're prized by painters and other artists for their perfect color for dye.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself sitting in the west as the red sun sets, smashing those pretty red flowers into a paste to make red dye. Your fingers get dyed red too and you crush the petals into a paste.
reading_story: As you're smashing the flowers into red dye, a little girl comes up to you and points at the paste. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the red dye on your fingers and nod. She's right, it is red.
reading_hint: Hear the little girl say あかね while pointing to the red dye. She's right. And the way she says it is so darn cute.

onyomi: しゅう, しゅ, とう
meaning_story: If you drop someone's alcohol in a river you're going to have to repay them. Alcohol costs a lot of money and they definitely saw you drop it. You can't just pretend it didn't happen. You'll have to repay them by buying more.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself dropping your friend's alcohol into the river. Now look at their angry face. Now listen to them yell about how you have to repay them.
reading_story: Your friend expects you to repay them for the alcohol, but you really don't want to. Instead, you hire a shooter (しゅう) to get rid of them. That way you never have to repay you alcohol debt.
reading_hint: Imagine calling a shooter to knock off your friend so you won't have to repay your debt and realizing it would be cheaper just to buy the alcohol to repay him. The decision is yours. Repay or shoot!

kunyomi: あき, おろか, ほけ, ぼ
meaning_story: If you see a mouth coming out of the top of a tree you'll probably go into shock. Mouths aren't supposed to be on top of trees. Unfortunately, when you go into shock you usually just stand perfectly still and stare at whatever made you that way. You'll be looking at this weird mouth for a while.
meaning_hint: Imagine the shock you feel as you look at the mouth stick out of the top of the tree. You can see the top because it's a pretty small tree. Imagine your whole body freeze as the panic sets in.
reading_story: The shock of seeing a mouth having tree is almost gone when the lips start to move. "Hooo... Hooo..." it says. Now you're really in shock. "Houdini (ほう)," it says. "It's meee... Hoooudini!" Harry Houdini must have magicked himself into this tree. That's not helping. You go even more into shock.
reading_hint: Picture the mouth of Harry Houdini trying to say his own name, stick out of the top of this tree. Feel the shock in your body. Shocked that he wasn't dead this whole time, but stuck in a tree.

meaning_story: You cast the Mona Lisa in gold and attach it to a stick to turn it into a sickle! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this!
meaning_hint: Imagine wielding your gold Mona Lisa sickle. It's sooo heavy, but it's really shiny and it cuts grass and wheat pretty well!
reading_story: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under it's name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can.
reading_hint: Hear all the guests say, "Mona Lisa... comma the sickle? WHAT'S HAPPENED HERE?!" As panic ensues. You like your addition and you're very proud.

meaning_story: A wolverine that sticks its legs in rice will become very solemn, very fast. This is weird to you because wolverines always seem so happy. Well his dad died from his legs getting stuck in rice, so just leave the poor solemn creature alone.
meaning_hint: Imagine if your dad died from getting his legs stuck in some rice, now feel solemn too.
reading_story: Remember how solemn wolverine looked when his dad died? You hated seeing him like this so you ran up and shook (しゅく) him. You shook the solemn sadness right out of him! You should do that again now!
reading_hint: Imagine seeing how violently you shook him. You shook him so hard his solemn mood disappeared!

meaning_story: When you leave flowers on a tombstone they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but stems. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful.
meaning_hint: Imagine being in a graveyard looking at all the tombstones and seeing nothing but stems on all of them. All the pretty flowery parts have died and blown away.
reading_story: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer.
reading_hint: Look at all the cookie covered tombstones. Now your bag is full of stems, but you can use them to make more cookies to bring back next time. Don't worry, nobody eats them. Stem cookies are probably poisonous.

meaning_story: You're sick because you put an arrow in your mouth and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really stupid. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick.
meaning_hint: How stupid do you have to be to put arrows into your mouth until it makes you sick? Pretty darn stupid, it seems.
reading_story: The only way to cure this serious a case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together.
reading_hint: Imagine if everyone knew that cheese cures the stupid out of people. Then maybe we would have more cheese and less stupid in the world!

onyomi: そう, しょう, ちゃん
meaning_story: A samurai hangs up his nailbat to plant flowers around his villa. Samurai can't always be fighting, so they go to their vacation villas and like to blow of steam by planting pretty flowers. You need something pretty of offset all the violence. This villa is the only place the samurai can stop being a samurai and start being a normal guy.
meaning_hint: Imagine this flower filled villa where the samurai comes to relax, hanging up his nailbat, and breathing in the fresh air.
reading_story: This villa is also the only place the samurai will be caught sewing (そう). He actually sews all of the clothes he wears under his armor. But if he was sewing somewhere public, people might make fun of him because he's not being tough and cutting off heads. So he only sews in the privacy of his villa.
reading_hint: Picture this samurai, his nailbat cast to the side, and instead a sewing needle in his hands, sitting in his peaceful, flower covered villa.

meaning_story: If you travel to the fish capital, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty whale! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all.
meaning_hint: Picture the underwater fish capital. Statues of whales line the fishy streets, and all of the fish bow down to the whale ruler's giant body.
reading_story: The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay.
reading_hint: Picture the gay whale ruler holding whale hands... fins? with his whale husband. They're so cute.

meaning_story: You should stop to buy stamps at noon because that's the only time they're being sold at wholesale price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself stopping at the empty bank at noon, grabbing a handful of wholesale stamps. So many stamps. So few extra charges.
reading_story: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too!
reading_hint: "Oh Roshi" you say carefully as you hand your stamps over at noon. The guy raises an eyebrow at you, but gives you them wholesale! It worked!

meaning_story: You start growing thread in your rice paddy to accumulate more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you.
meaning_hint: Just imagine how much thread you'll accumulate if you can just grow it along with your rice in the rice paddy! So much thread!
reading_story: Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it.
reading_hint: Your attempts to accumulate more of something by cheating have brouhgt ruin to everything else you were doing. Nice job, dummy.

meaning_story: When you meet the leader dog you have to bow to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself bowing to the leader dog. Leader dog is so cool!
reading_story: You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F@#$ you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying F@#$ you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think.
reading_hint: Bow even deeper as the dog leader keeps barking what sounds like F@#$ you. You're pretty sure that's what he's saying at least...

meaning_story: When a man meets a tiger he makes the tiger his captive. Men are pretty crappy like that. They see tigers and they want to put them in cages, so the poor tiger becomes a captive of the man.
meaning_hint: Picture the sad tiger captive and the man laughing as he pokes at it. Tigers shouldn't be captives but when men find them they always seem to do this anyway.
reading_story: The captive tiger is even sadder because the man put him in a robe (りょ) and is making him act like a human. Tigers look good in robes, but they don't really enjoy being forced into people clothing.
reading_hint: Picture the poor captive tiger being stuffed into a bathrobe and paraded around a cage for the man.

meaning_story: If you want to loiter on a cliff with the pope you better be ready to move in perfect circulation with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool.
meaning_hint: Imagine this strange circulation of you and the pope up here on a cliff. It's not even like you two are up here for a reason, you're just loitering. But he doesn't want to be hot so he makes you circulate with him.
reading_story: This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance.
reading_hint: "This circulation is all June's fault," you mutter, walking in a circle with the pope to stay cool.

meaning_story: If you find some rice in a top hat it's going to be really coarse and rough. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to eat the rice you found in a top hat. It's so coarse it feels like it's scratching your teeth. There's probably some dirt in here too. This wasn't the best idea.
reading_story: A friend comes up and asks how your rice is. The rice itself tastes pretty good, but the coarseness is kind of ruining it for you. It's a half good, half bad situation. So you respond with, "Eh, it's so-so (そ)." Maybe if it wasn't so rough on your mouth it would be better, but right now it's really just in that middle so-so area.
reading_hint: Raise your hand and shake it back and forth as you say the rice is "so-so." It's too coarse to be any better.

radical_names: Arrow, Spoon, Ice, Mama, Coat Rack
meaning_story: You try to get ice out of your freezer with a spoon, and arrow, your mama's help, and even by whacking it with a coat rack until you realize it's started to congeal too much for you to break through it. Sometimes ice will freeze way too solid for you to ever break it, even with all that help.
meaning_hint: The ice has congealed so much that a spoon, arrow, your own mama, and a coatrack you can't even crack it.
reading_story: The only reason you're trying to un-congeal this ice with everything you own is because your gyoza (ぎょう) is in there! You were craving that gyoza all day but now it's decided to freeze inside an ice block and you can't get it out.
reading_hint: Stare at the congealed gyoza. What else can you use to try to get it out?

meaning_story: The king has a hat that's made from a tree but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big cork. It's a big, wooden plug that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat.
meaning_hint: Picture how silly the king looks with this cork on his head. He kind of looks like a fat, plugged up bottle of wine when he yells now.
reading_story: It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing.
reading_hint: Picture the centaurs drinking and giggling, putting the cork from their wine on their head to imitate the stupid king.

meaning_story: If you give the king flowers he'll put them in the central part of the castle with all his crystals. Flowers and crystals look really good together, and he can't have them out in the open because all the commoners will steal them! So your pretty flowers will be put with his huge crystal collection.
meaning_hint: Imagine how pretty the king's crystals reflect the colors from the flowers in his secret chamber in a central point in the castle.
reading_story: If you could actually see the crystals you'd be surprised to see that they're all in the shape of ace (えい) playing cards. Giant crystal aces sitting in the center of the castle, surrounded by flowers, suddenly don't sound as pretty to you.
reading_hint: Picture these giant crystal aces. If he only has the aces, and they're at the central point in the castle, maybe all the other cards are hidden throughout the rest of the place!

kunyomi: あきら, あき, あさ, あした, ただし
meaning_story: At sunrise you can see the dawn! And it will also BE dawn.
meaning_hint: Look at the pretty sunrise at dawn. It's so peaceful.
reading_story: As you're watching the sunrise at dawn you see someone coming up in the distance. It's Dan (だん) and he's... tan (たん)? Or he's trying to tan at least. He's running at dawn, slathering tanning lotion all over himself. Dan, I don't think tanning works well at dawn.
reading_hint: Tan Dan is trying to tan at dawn. It's weird, but he's already tan, so maybe it does work. You should try tanning at dawn with Dan sometime!

kunyomi: たてまつ, ほう, まつ
meaning_story: If you want to turn two sticks into a train you have to dedicate all your time to the effort. In fact, you have to be a very dedicated person to be able to do it at all. Do you think you can dedicate all your time to it, or will you stop and take breaks to eat and sleep?
meaning_hint: Dedicate every second of time to turning these two sticks into a train. Can you do it?
reading_story: If you dedicate enough time to it you'll be able to wave your hands like Harry Houdini (ほう) and the sticks will turn into a train instantly! But before you can do that you have to dedicate all your energy into learning how.
reading_hint: Imagine dedicating your life to being like Harry Houdini!

meaning_story: If you put an ox on a water slide it won't be able to stop and will keep sliding until it disappears into the distance. Now you feel a little bad because if you can't even see the poor ox in the distance it must have slid really, really far.
meaning_hint: Watch the ox shoot off into the distance after you push it down the water slide. Oh... it's going much further than you thought. You should probably go find it.
reading_story: You can't see the ox in the distance anymore so you take your row (りょう) boat and row it down the water slide and shoot off in the direction you last saw it. Maybe if you row fast enough into the distance you can catch up to it.
reading_hint: Imagine rowing your row boat as hard as you can toward that spot in the distance that you think the ox slide.

meaning_story: Give a sock to this butcher and he'll put it in one of his enclosures. He has no need for socks, he only needs his butcher knife, so he throws it in the animal enclosures. Maybe the animals in there can do something with it.
meaning_hint: Imagine how disappointed you'd be if a butcher just threw the sock you gave him into an enclosure in the back of his butcher shop.
reading_story: You take a look in the enclosure and there's a big cock (かく) sitting on a huge pile of socks inside of it. The enclosure is completely full of socks and the cock has made a nest out of them. Huh.
reading_hint: The butcher must use this enclosure for socks AND his cock. I guess if you don't wear them you have to put them somewhere.

meaning_story: You use a nailbat on your modified jet to erase it from existence. It takes a while and all of your strength. But you bash the weird jet with your nailbat until nothing is left, successfully erasing it from this world!
meaning_hint: Imagine hitting a modified jet with a nailbat to erase it from your yard, the planet, and your life.
reading_story: You manage to erase everything but the mats (まつ) that cover the floor of the cockpit. You bash and smash at them with your nailbat, but the mats just won't disappear. It looks like you can erase a lot of things in this world, but mats aren't one of them.
reading_hint: Imagine staring down at these mats and trying to think about how you can erase them. Maybe you just need a giant eraser...

meaning_story: A leader that gets not one, but two graves, honoring them after they're dead must have been really excellent. Not just anyone can get two graves, but if you were soooo great that you get two, you must have been the best.
meaning_hint: Imagine how excellent this leader must have been to deserve two graves.
reading_story: You're curious to see what made this leader so excellent. You look at both graves and realize that he's in one and his car (か) is in the other! They buried his car with him because he was such an excellent driver. Oh. That makes sense.
reading_hint: If you're an excellent driver you might get two graves too! One for you and your just as excellent car!

meaning_story: To eat a fish stick from long ago you needed to be frugal. If you weren't frugal with your fish sticks, you'd run out before now. And you'd probably die, yo.
meaning_hint: Imagine long ago, when you were gifted a truck full of fish sticks. Plan for the future. Be frugal enough to reward future you with them.
reading_story: You know what frugal people are? They're sexy (せき). Mm, that's right. What's sexier than a person who hoards fish sticks? If you can think of anything, you should email me. Because honestly, I can't think of one thing.
reading_hint: Be frugal with those old fish sticks and you'll be as sexy as me.

meaning_story: If you think about yourself too much you'll end up with your forehead in the ground, your heart suck in winter, and grief with take you over. When you dwell too much, when you don't let your heart be light, and when you refuse to be open minded, nothing but grief is coming for you.
meaning_hint: Imagine all these bad things causing you grief.
reading_story: The only thing stopping you from breaking out of this grief is YOU (ゆう). You are in charge of your destiny. Get your forehead out of the ground, your heart out of winter, and stop dwelling about your self anymore! Only YOU can break you out of this grief cycle!
reading_hint: YOU can stop the grief! I promise. YOU can do it!

meaning_story: You stepped on your breakfast fish stick with your toe early in the morning and you've had to grieve about it all day. That fish stick was going to be the highlight of your day. But you stepped on it like a jerk, right when you woke up. And now you can do nothing but grieve for this ruined day.
meaning_hint: Imagine grieving for your toe crushed fish stick from early in the morning to late at night. Put it on a napkin and rest it's crushed shape on top of your trash bin. You just aren't ready to throw it out yet.
reading_story: You need to grieve for this fish stick in particular because it was the last one you had from Tokyo (とう). You bought a bunch when you were there last, but this was your very last one. Tokyo fish sticks are very famous, and the fact that you smooshed it with your toe and now you'll probably never get one again, makes you feel like you need to have time to mourn for your loss.
reading_hint: As you grieve, remember how hard it was to go to Tokyo to get these fish sticks. Remember how they tasted. Boohoohoo.

meaning_story: If your heart is sick you should go to the death star for proper healing. The death star has all the latest technology in the universe. The people there can easily cure the sickness in your heart.
meaning_hint: Imagine the doctors on the death star healing the sickness in your heart. Now you owe them your life!
reading_story: You decide that the world should have access to the healing technology that's available on the death star, so you usurp (ゆ) the current commander and take over. You turn the death star into a giant, flying hospital ship. You travel through the galaxy healing other people's sick hearts!
reading_hint: Imagine usurping the commander and making the death star a healing ship! That's pretty cool!

meaning_story: You see a tree growing on a cliff and it has ten thousand horse chestnuts growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one.
meaning_hint: Picture this tree, weighed down by it's own horse chestnuts, leaning over the edge of the cliff.
reading_story: You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww!
reading_hint: Horse chestnuts taste like nasty toe cheese. Imagine what having one in your mouth would be like.

onyomi: りゅう, りょう, ろう
meaning_story: The imperial radical and the imperial kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo!
meaning_hint: Make sure you remember this radical means imperial and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
reading_story: Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know!
reading_hint: Picture Ryu kicking the butts of imperial scum like Bison and Darth Vader.

meaning_story: If you put a spring in a small gun it will keep increasing in size every time you fire it. The spring will stretch the small gun until it gets bigger and bigger, increasing a little bit with each shot.
meaning_hint: Picture the small gun increasing in size every time you fire it from the spring pushing it out.
reading_story: You keep firing and increasing the size of the gun because you want it to be huge by the time you get to the Yankees (や) game. You're gonna shoot the stadium into the sky. And then you'll never have to lose to them again. Their increasing lead will never hurt you! HAHAHA!
reading_hint: Dwell on the increasing score difference between your favorite team and those damn Yankees. But if you ruin their stadium they won't be able to do it anymore!

meaning_story: What do you have inside you treating your bones like a water slide? Bone marrow! Whenever you move, your bone marrow slides around inside the middle of your bones!
meaning_hint: Imagine your bone marrow sliding around in your bones like they're on water slides. Weee!
reading_story: You can eat marrow, you know. And zoo eagles (ずい) have the tastiest marrow of any other animal. Though you have to go to the zoo to steal them, it's totally worth it, I promise. Their marrow slides around even more than other animals because they fly around their cages in circles all day, moving the marrow around.
reading_hint: Imagine munching on delicious zoo eagle marrow. Maybe a nice zoo eagle marrow ice cream too!

kunyomi: かたわ, わき, おか, はた, そば
meaning_story: A leader with a lid on his head and fins on his forehead is heading in a direction nearby. He can't go far with all that stuff on his face, so he's just trying to wander nearby. Over there. Somewhere.
meaning_hint: That lid and fin wearing leader is heading in a nearby direction. Picture him. Picture him walking nearby your home.
reading_story: The leader nearby is so close that you could take your bow (ぼう) and arrow and hit him from your door.
reading_hint: Imagine pulling your bow back, aiming nearby at the weird leader. Steady. Steady.

meaning_story: Give fish sticks to everyone on the death star and they'll become much more pleasant. In fact, they'll stop destroying planets all together. Who knew fish sticks were the key to stopping the empire!
meaning_hint: Picture yourself handing out fish sticks to all the soldiers on the death star and see their faces soften as they become much more pleasant people.
reading_story: Thanks to their snack, the soldiers on the death star decide that they should help everyone in the galaxies become pleasant too so they usurp (ゆ) power from the emperor and take the death star on a fish stick sharing galaxy trip.
reading_hint: Teaching soldiers how pleasant life is helped them to usurp power from the evil emperor! Fish sticks are my hero!yyyy

meaning_story: You need to run on your toes if you want to proceed down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to move on at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run!
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to proceed down the road by running on your toes. No other part of your foot can touch the ground!
reading_story: If you find that you can't proceed, you're a fool (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here!
reading_hint: Imagine being called a fool when you can't proceed along the road because running on your toes ends up being super hard to do.

meaning_story: The sun is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two suns, they can get even more done and it makes them way more prosperous than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of prosperity because of the two suns.
meaning_hint: Picture the prosperous planet that has two suns. They get so much work done that no one is ever hungry or tired or without.
reading_story: The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the shogun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shogun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need.
reading_hint: Picture the shogun looking over the prosperous world, the two suns at his back.

meaning_story: After you finish eating all your fish sticks you end up feeling huge amounts of remorse and regret. You miss your fish sticks and you wish you could keep eating them, but they're gone now. The only feeling you have left is remorse over how fast you gobbled them up.
meaning_hint: Feel the heavy weight of remorse fill your body as you finish your last fish stick. You should have eaten them slower, because now they're all gone and you can't keep eating.
reading_story: Once you're done eating your fish sticks, and the regret is filling you up, all you have left is this empty can (かん). The fish sticks came in a can and now that they're gone it's all you have. Your remorse is so strong that you end up crying into the can. Now it's filled with your tears.
reading_hint: Stare with regret at the empty fish stick can. How could this happen? It looked like there were so many in there when you started.

kunyomi: えのき, ほう, ほお
meaning_story: You decide to carve a tree into a giant replica of your big toe because you think it will be really simple. Once you're done though, it looks like a really crude attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought.
meaning_hint: Imagine carving a really simple, crude toe from a tree. It's your first attempt, so I guess you should have known it wouldn't be great.
reading_story: You're admiring your simple looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. ぼく, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく!
reading_hint: Who carved this simple toe? ぼく!

meaning_story: If you put two two pound weights on a person on the moon they'll increase in stature when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller!
meaning_hint: Imagine how much height you'd gain if you spent time lifting weights on the moon!
reading_story: Getting a taller stature will also make you seem super sexy (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh?
reading_hint: Imagine how sexy the height of a ten foot tall person would be after just coming back from weight training on the moon.

meaning_story: You want to slice what you say in half so that people focus on the above text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say!
meaning_hint: Imagine actually slicing the words you say in the air. The above section is what you want people to pay attention to, so you slice a big gap between the above and the below words.
reading_story: As you focus on the above words you realize a guy (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy!
reading_hint: That guy doesn't care if the above is all he's supposed to hear. That guy sucks.

meaning_story: How do you make a mnemonic for the word this? You don’t. But, we can try. You climb many hills. On top of on of the hills is a little drop of water. You pick it up and say “THIS… THIS IS WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!”
meaning_hint: As you look at the drop of water, you note that you found the right thing. Written on it is the word “this."
reading_story: This particular drop of water hold the core (これ) of the universe. If you didn't find this very droplet, we all would have died and this universe would be gone.
reading_hint: The core of the universe is in this drop of water. Or is it in this mnemonic? Ooohhhhh you'll never knoooowwww!

meaning_story: The reality of gold is that it has the power to tranquilize anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up!
meaning_hint: Imagine being tranquilized by the sweet caress of gold coins. You can't even move. You're in a daze or something.
reading_story: You've been tranquilized and now drool is running down your chin (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich!
reading_hint: If you let gold tranquilize you, you'll drool all over your own chin. Maybe the chins of other people too, who knows?

meaning_story: When you go to the pool or lake to swim, you'll see a flag stuck somewhere in the water. That flag is there so you know it's okay to pee in that area of the pool. Everyone knows urine dilutes in water, and if everyone just pees in one place, it won't be gross. So go pee over by that flag when you have to go. Don't bother getting out of the water.
meaning_hint: Imagine swimming over to the flag that's sticking out of the water and peeing there. Yeah, everyone knows what you're doing over there, but it's better than getting out and walking to the bathroom right? Just pee in the water. Just do it.
reading_story: Right as you start to pee, you hear the life guard start to yell, "NYOOOOOO! (にょう)" and he's pointing at you! You were just peeing by the pee flag! Why is he mad?
reading_hint: Imagine your embarrassment when you find out that you aren't supposed to urinate in the water, not even by the pee flag, because a life guard yelled NYOOOOOO and pointed right at you while you did it.

meaning_story: Put a helmet with a few clams in it on the ground and you'll instantly become the VIP of the night. Only very important people know this special code that means other people have to treat them like an honored guest. Well I guess you all know now, but shh don't tell.
meaning_hint: Imagine what it would be like to just put a few clams in a helmet, toss it on the ground, and then get the VIP treatment. Go try right now!
reading_story: This VIP treatment will only happen if you're Hindu (ひん) though. Maybe I should have mentioned that earlier. If you do this and you're just a white guy, they're going to look at you like you're crazy, not a VIP guest at all.
reading_hint: Imagine seeing a Hindu person do the exact same thing you did and they get the VIP treatment but you don't. I guess you just aren't allowed to be that special.

kunyomi: いかん, なに, なんぞ
meaning_story: If you hand two swords to a butcher he'll ask you what you want him to do with them.
meaning_hint: Imagine handing two swords to a butcher and just waiting while he stares at you asking "What... WHAT?" over and over again.
reading_story: He keeps asking what you want, so you hand him the dead narwhal (な) you want him to cut with the swords. "WHAT??" he says, even more confused. I don't think he can do what you want him to do with this narwhal...
reading_hint: WHAT do you even want him to do with this narwhal? WHAT?

meaning_story: Build a cage with an axe to become an artisan. Artisans have to make something to keep their title, and you decided to make a cage. Now all you have to do it sell it to be a true artisan.
meaning_hint: Imagine fulfilling your artisan dreams by crafting and selling a cage you made from scratch with an axe.
reading_story: You're selling your first piece, this axed cage, as an artisan and the shogun (しょう) shows up and actually wants to buy it! It's your first day trying to make a living being an artisan and the shogun already likes your work?!
reading_hint: You're going to get a lot of artisan cred thanks to the shogun buying the first thing you ever tried to sell. Nice job!

meaning_story: You're hitting a white wall with your nailbat over and over until you realize the sound you're making is actually a sick beat. You keep going and start singing along to this new hip beat. Boo boo boop. Boo do do do doop! Nailbat music!
meaning_hint: Imagine taking out your frustration on this annoying white wall by making music starting with this groovy nailbat beat!
reading_story: This beat is sick but you're hacking (はく) up the wall while you do it. Soon there won't be anymore wall and with it your beat will die. Oh, the suffering artist!
reading_hint: Imagine hacking up the walls to keep the beat going as long as you can. You move onto other walls but none of them can handle the power of the beat!!

meaning_story: Your specialty is dropping people with thread by binding them! You can drop anyone as long as you have enough thread to restrain them. It doesn't matter how much they fight, you'll get them to drop!
meaning_hint: Imagine if your specialty was dropping people by binding them with thread. You'd be such a weird person.
reading_story: If you're going to be a weirdo who likes to bind people, at least make sure that they land on their backs (ばく) when they DO drop. Landing on your head or your boobs really hurts. So please at least try to make them land on their backs!
reading_hint: Imagine how you would bind someone so that when they drop they land on their back instead of somewhere more painful. How would you do that?

meaning_story: You only eat a wrap if you're really bored. Wraps are gross, everyone knows that. So you wouldn't eat one if you were hungry. Only if you were bored and you didn't have anything else to do.
meaning_hint: No one eats wraps unless they're too bored to do anything else.
reading_story: You're so bored that you imagine that Harry Houdini (ほう) is the wrap you're eating. He was wrapped up all the time, so who's to say he isn't in your wrap. Uhg, this is getting boring already. Even Houdini can't make this wrap interesting to eat.
reading_hint: You're so bored that you're pretending to eat a wrapped Houdini. You should just go to sleep or something. Geez.

meaning_story: If you could stop spooning water onto that tree we could use it for brushwood. But if you don't stop, then it will be too wet to burn at all! Stop already!
meaning_hint: We need to use that brushwood to make a fire! So stop spooning water on it!
reading_story: You finally set the brushwood on fire and suddenly a Shiba (しば) Inu jumps out of the flames. So that's why they named this wood after them or... or vice versa?
reading_hint: Shiba inu's come from setting brushwood on fire! That must have been how they got their name!

meaning_story: The insect that brings about the next generation of their kind on a tree is the butterfly. Check it out, it's pretty cool.
meaning_hint: Picture all those butterflies meeting together to bring about the next generation of insects into the world.
reading_story: You're admiring one butterfly in particular when you see that the part of the tree it's sitting on looks like a nose. Then slowly, the shape of a human woman pushes it's way out of the butterflies. It's evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう)! No! She looks even more terrifying than usual, with her butterfly suit on. And now she's coming right at you!
reading_hint: Picture butterfly-covered Mrs. Chou running toward you. You just wanted to look at the pretty insects. Why does she have to ruin everything?!

meaning_story: You find a mysterious spring and pluck at it a few times to realize it plays a chord. You pluck it and poke it and flick it and each time it plays a perfect chord. You're not hitting three parts at once, so where are these three sounds coming from?
meaning_hint: Every time you touch the mysterious spring three or more harmonious notes form to make a chord. It's really cool!
reading_story: You take your new chord making machine and show it to all the people in the older generation (げん) who keep telling you that YOUR generation will never be able to play music correctly. Well take THIS old people!
reading_hint: You play your mysterious chord spring in front of the older generation and they all just get grumpy that you didn't work hard enough to make it yourself, and found it instead. There's no pleasing these people...

meaning_story: You're trying to open the lid of a manhole that's covered in ice by jackhammering it a bunch of times but it's not working because it's just too cold. Its so cold that your jackhammer is starting to ice up too. But you need to get this lid open so you try time after time after time!
meaning_hint: Imagine if it was sooo cold that no matter how many times you tried to jackhammer the ice of the lid for this manhole, it wouldn't crack open.
reading_story: Each time the jackhammer hits the freezing cold ice it makes a high pitched ringing (りん) sound. It's actually really annoying to listen to but you really need to crack this ice open so you have to keep listening to it.
reading_hint: If it wasn't so darn cold you wouldn't have to hear this horrible high pitched ringing sound because there wouldn't even be any ice to jackhammer through!

meaning_story: Seeing an elephant brush its mullet is a very common sight when you go to the zoo. Almost all elephants can only grow mullets, and they brush them with their long trunks. It's common enough, so the next time you go to the zoo just go check it out, I'm sure all the elephants will be doing it.
meaning_hint: Elephants brushing their mullets is so common. Are you sure you haven't seen this before?
reading_story: Next you're going to try and tell me other really common things like yogurt (よう) don't exist. I know you know that one. So come on, just believe me about the elephant thing, okay?
reading_hint: Elephants brushing their mullets is as common as yogurt. Duh.

meaning_story: If you play blackjack for gold in the hot sun you'll get confused pretty quickly. The sun likes to play tricks on our eyes and then bounce off the gold coins and shine directly into our eyes too. Soon you won't know which cards are yours, who put down how much gold, or even who you are!
meaning_hint: Unless you like being confused, I wouldn't suggest playing blackjack in the sun.
reading_story: Eventually you'll get so confused that you'll sack (さく) all the gold and try to run for it. No you idiot, you were already winning! You didn't need to steal it. I think? I'm confused too.
reading_hint: Imagine having a sack full of gold! Wait, this is sand. I'm confused.

meaning_story: You've lived an altered life in a car, wearing a helmet and never using your mouth because you had no control over it. Your parent put you there and you've spent every day of your life under this kind of control.
meaning_hint: Living an altered life is hard, especially when your parents control all the things that make it that way.
reading_story: The only thing they don't control is your cats (かつ). They walk all over inside the car you're stuck in and you spend all your time with them. No one can control cats anyway, even if they tried.
reading_hint: No one can control cats. Not even your really controlling parents who made your life a weird experiment by locking you in a car and making your wear a helmet and never allowing you to talk...

meaning_story: Give a fish stick to a guard who's stuck on duty and watch the delight spread over his face. He was so hungry, but guards aren't allowed to move while they're on duty. That fish stick completely made his night. You're such a nice person, spreading joy like that. Go you!
meaning_hint: Delight guards you see by giving them each a fish stick. Feel your own delight as you see how happy they become.
reading_story: The delight they feel is so strong that you'll see the smile etched (えつ) on their face for the rest of the night. Maybe it will even be etched there every time you see them from now on.
reading_hint: Imagine delight etched on your face and the guards because you did a nice thing.

meaning_story: You see somebody who is spending all of spring living in a hole because they're destitute. They don't seem to have any other place to go and no one will help them.
meaning_hint: Imagine if you were so destitute that you had to last out the spring living in a hole. That's not a fun way to live.
reading_story: You hate to admit it, but this destitute person is really cute (きゅう). If anyone knew you thought being destitute was cute they'd probably kick your ass, so you probably shouldn't say how you feel out loud. Especially not to that person living in the hole.
reading_hint: You think being destitute is cute? Uhg, what's wrong with you?

meaning_story: If when you speak it sounds like the power of a drum is coming out of your mouth, then people will hold you in high esteem. Anyone who has a loud, booming, powerful voice will be held in high esteem in this day and age. Look at all those awesome musicians who have booming voices!
meaning_hint: Imagine hearing someone speak and it's so powerful and loud that it sounds like they have a drum booming out of their mouth. You'll love them! You'll hold them in the highest esteem!
reading_story: You hold them in such high esteem that you give them your car (か). I ... I said you give them your car! Give them your car. Hey, hey!
reading_hint: If you hold someone in high esteem you give me your- give them your car. Gimme!

meaning_story: If the demolition man knocks down twenty buildings he's definitely gone evil. There's no way twenty buildings were supposed to be demolished in a single day. He's just knocking them down for fun now! What an evil guy!
meaning_hint: Picture the demolition man knocking down like twenty houses in a row! I think someone was in that one! He's so evil!
reading_story: After the evil demo man knocks the buildings down he builds hay (へい) recreations in their place. The people who used to live here are going to come home and see these useless hay houses sitting in the rubble of their homes, mocking them. Demolition man, why!?
reading_hint: Watch the evil man snicker as the people cry onto their fake hay houses.

meaning_story: If you push a satellite down a water slide it will shoot far off into space. That's how NASA does it, right?
meaning_hint: Imagine pushing the satellite down the water slide. ZOOM! Woah. How far away do you think it's gonna go?
reading_story: You check how far off it's gone and you're so pleased that you can't help but laugh, "Har (はる) har har!" You're laughing like this because it rhymes with far! You har har because the satellite went far off!
reading_hint: Har har it went so far! Off!

meaning_story: A tsunami gets together with all the rivers and streams and they decide to flood the land together. It seems really fun for all these bodies of water to hang out together, but floods destroy building and people! It's not fun at all for us!
meaning_hint: Floods are serious business. Just because it's like a family get together for a tsunami doesn't mean it doesn't have its downsides.
reading_story: Wait a second. Who's riding a wave in the middle of the flood? It's こういち and it looks like he's floating on top of the water and ... chatting with the tsunami?! I guess he's one of the bodies of water that the tsunami got together with.
reading_hint: Apparently こういち is part of the reason floods happen. We might want to talk to him about that.

meaning_story: If you manage to say humbly all the things you want to say while wearing new threads, everyone will think you're a perfect gentleman. You have to wear the right clothes and speak the right way for them to think you're a gentleman though. Without one or the other you're just a guy.
meaning_hint: Imagine what you would say humbly while wearing your new threads. Do you think it makes people think you're a gentleman? No? Okay, try again then.
reading_story: A gentleman always kicks other gentlemen in the shins (しん) when they meet. You don't know this because you weren't a gentleman until now. Make sure you kick everyone you meet in the shins!
reading_hint: Imagine seeing another gentleman and kicking him hard in the shins. "You win!" he says, "You are the true gentleman here!" Yessss!

meaning_story: You only catapult things to give them to other people! Why would you catapult anything towards another person if you weren't trying to give it to them? That's just silly.
meaning_hint: If you want to give someone something use a catapult!
reading_story: Give your friend a new Go (ご) board by catapulting it toward them. The fun is in finding all the pieces after they fly towards their head!
reading_hint: Give games of go to all your friends! Just pull back that catapult and you'll be able to give anyone anything in 3 seconds flat!

meaning_story: You see a samurai hitting his forehead on a pine tree outside of ikea so you go over and ask him what's wrong. Apparently he's down to his last grain of rice and he doesn't know how to deal with it. He can't eat it, or he'll have none left. But he doesn't want to starve. Geez, all this over a little grain.
meaning_hint: Imagine hitting your head against a tree because you want to eat more grains of rice.
reading_story: You don't have any grains to share with him but you do see a vending machine so you buy him a Coke (こく). Now he can eat that last grain and survive until he gets more! Thanks Coca cola!
reading_hint: Eat a grain of rice then drink a nice refreshing coke!

meaning_story: If your ear is hit by a nailbat you'll hear an explosion in addition to the intense pain. And in addition to that, you'll probably see a lot of blood. Nailbats are serious business and ears are really delicate.
meaning_hint: Think of all the things that will happen in addition to bleeding, pain, and an explosion sound when you get hit in the ear with a nailbat.
reading_story: In addition to all that awful stuff happening in your ear, don't forget that ears come in sets (せつ). So it's about to happen to your other ear right NOW! BANG BOOOM PSHUUUAHHHH!
reading_hint: Imagine if in addition to all the pain you just went through, you were about to get your other ear smashed with a nailbat because ears come in sets. If they didn't, you only would have been hit once!

meaning_story: If you place a helmet high up above everyone else using a small stool it will get really lonely up there. Helmets want to be on people's heads, not left to sit in high up places. And yes, helmets have feelings too and this particular helmet is feeling lonely.
meaning_hint: Imagine if you were that helmet, up there and unable to get down without it's own small stool. You'd be lonely too!
reading_story: The helmet can't stand being lonely anymore so it tries to use a jack (じゃく) to flip itself onto someones head. Picture a helmet trying to use a jack. It doesn't really work. But the sentiment it there.
reading_hint: Imagine being so lonely that you try to use a jack to throw yourself at someone so you won't be lonely anymore. It may hurt you, but you won't be alone, and that's all you can think about.

meaning_story: Who do you know that wears a spicy helmet? Your manager at the restaurant you work at! His helmet is spicy because it has hot sauce in it for the customers to use. Only the manager is allowed to wear the special spicy helmet though.
meaning_hint: Picture your manager walking around and letting customers dip their chips and french fries into his spicy helmet.
reading_story: The manager is the only one who gets to wear the spicy helmet because he's the only cyclops (さい) working here. The spicy helmet drips a lot and if you only have one eye on your whole head the odds of it dripping in there are pretty low, compared to the rest of you two eyed people.
reading_hint: Picture your cyclops manager magically not getting spice in his eyes. He's so good at it. No wonder he's the manager.

meaning_story: If a butcher dies from frostbite he'll have to be but in a mausoleum. It's not that he was a super important guy, it's really just that he froze standing up with his arms stretched out so he won't fit in a normal coffin. You stand him up in a mausoleum with all the other people who froze in really inconvenient positions.
meaning_hint: Picture the butcher's body standing in a weird position, frozen in a mausoleum. Now touch him, I dare you. Is frostbite catchy? No right?
reading_story: He wouldn't be dead and in this mausoleum if he hadn't tried to row (りょう) his row boat around during a blizzard. Then again, getting to be buried in a mausoleum is pretty cool, so maybe you should row your row boat in a blizzard.
reading_hint: Imagine rowing yourself around in a rowboat, hoping to freeze in a weird position so you get to be put in a mausoleum when you freeze to death.

kunyomi: おうよ, およ, すべ
meaning_story: You go to buy a table but it looks it has water damage from drops of water hitting it. This makes it a pretty mediocre table. The water drops haven't really damaged it that much, it still stands and you can use it, but it's kinda ugly, so it's just mediocre.
meaning_hint: You didn't expect to see water drop damage on this table so now your mood is mediocre too.
reading_story: You weren't expecting to see such a mediocre table so you go up to the guy who's selling it and say, "Hey, I have a bone (ぼん) to pick with you!" But he doesn't think there is a bone to pick at all, he doesn't think the table is mediocre like you do.
reading_hint: Imagine having a bone to pick with someone because they're trying to sell you something mediocre and they just won't listen. Now you have a bone to pick with the person who recommended this guy to you!

meaning_story: Who loves their flag, using jackhammers, and precise measurements? Your military officer! He's always saluting the flag, jackhammering near all the new recruits to test them, and checking the measurement between the floor and their pants. Who else could it be?
meaning_hint: Picture a military officer doing all those things.
reading_story: That military officer's favorite bird is an eagle (い)! That should be obvious because the eagle is the bird of America! And that's the country he fights for!
reading_hint: Picture the military officer saluting as an eagle flies overhead. Majestic.

meaning_story: Stand staring up at the blue sky and you'll feel more peaceful than you ever have. Blue is a color that promotes peaceful thoughts and feelings. That's why all the social media sites are blue. To stop you from being a jerk.
meaning_hint: Imagine how peaceful staring at the blue ocean, the blue sky, or the blue tumblr makes you.
reading_story: Now if someone asks you if the color blue makes you peaceful you should say "YES! (やす)" And you'll have us to thank for that! All those peaceful blue radicals. They're the easiest thing on the site, and if someone asks you if radicals make you feel peaceful say YES again!
reading_hint: Yes! Peaceful blue radicals standing in a row. What's that? YES you do want more radicals added to the site. Well okay then, if it will keep you at peace, sure!

meaning_story: When small drops of water work together they gain respect for one another. If you end up working with someone long enough, and they end up being really great, you'll respect them too!
meaning_hint: Imagine being a small drop of water and seeing other drops of water come to help you by working together. You'd really respect them, right?
reading_story: If you respect someone enough you'll even take up their hobbies. The person you respect most loves the Yankees. You don't really feel the same, but you respect that about them so you chant, "Ooh Yankees, Ooh Yankees うやうや with them during each game.
reading_hint: Imagine respecting someone so much that you'll cheer ooh yankees over and over even though they're kind of a crappy team.

meaning_story: If you want to make a signpost to tell people not to ride the water slide in winter with just some thread you need to learn how to sew first. Thread can really only be made into other things by sewing, so unless you know someone else who can, you're gonna have to learn how to sew.
meaning_hint: Don't worry, sewing is pretty easy, you'll have a signpost telling those kids not to ride the water slide in winter in no time!
reading_story: If you don't know how to sew, don't worry, just yell, "Harry Houdini (ほう)!" into the sky and he'll magic himself in and teach you how. He might even sew the signpost for you with magic if you're really bad at sewing. But you won't know until you shout his name!
reading_hint: HOUDINI! TEACH ME TO SEW!

meaning_story: If you see the white of a sail there's probably a ship under there too! Most white sails don't really just drift around at sea without a ship to be attached to. You're pretty sure that's a ship.
meaning_hint: Picture the white sail of a ship heading towards you. You wonder what the ship under the sail looks like.
reading_story: As the ship comes closer you realize that it's been hacked (はく) to pieces! The sail is just propped up on the hacked up remains of what you assume was the ship. What a shame.
reading_hint: I guess I was wrong. Ships can have sails and not be much of a ship anymore if they've been hacked to pieces at sea.

meaning_story: If you want to use a nailbat to open a key hole you have to squeeze it in. It won't fit normally, so squeeze it with all your might to make it fit in there.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself squeezing a nailbat into a key hole. You have to be pretty strong to squeeze it in there.
reading_story: Once you've squeezed your nailbat to unlock the door squeeze all the money and treasure you came there for into your sack (さく)! You can't steal this bank's stuff without a sack to squeeze it all into!
reading_hint: How much gold do you think you can squeeze into one sack?

meaning_story: If you give an animal that has horns alcohol it will stay very very still. Try this with deer and moose and sheep. They'll take a couple sips of the alcohol and then stand perfectly still for the rest of the day. The just freeze up and when you come back hours later, they'll still be there. Not moving.
meaning_hint: Picture the horned sheep drinking the alcohol you offer it. It stiffens up and stands perfectly still. It's actually kind of creepy.
reading_story: While you're still staring at the very still sheep, a zookeeper comes marching up. "YOU (ゆう)!" He shouts. "YOU are the one making all my horned animals stand still!" Uh oh. Time to get out of here.
reading_hint: Imagine running from the very still sheep, hearing "YOU! YOU! Get back here you!!" Luckily, you don't have horns so the alcohol doesn't make you stand still and you can get the heck outta there.

meaning_story: You fell into a hole which was actually a boob grave and now you're going to suffocate! The boobs press in over your mouth and your chest starts to cave in. This is not how you wanted to die. Boob suffocation was not the plan!
meaning_hint: Imagine suffocating because you fell into a hole that had a boob grave in it. You'll never live this down when everyone finds out!
reading_story: As you suffocate to death your life flashes before your eyes and all you see are all the cheats (ちつ) you pulled off. I guess you did cheat a lot of people out of things. Maybe you are destined to die in this boob grave because of all the cheats you got away with.
reading_hint: The moral of the story is not to be the kind of person who cheats other people out of stuff, or you'll slip and fall into a boob grave and suffocate to death.

meaning_story: A stone drops from the sky into a rice paddy and then a cross drops on top of it. They've combined to form a tombstone! Wait, does that mean a body fell from the sky first and you just didn't see it?
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a stone and a cross drop from the sky onto each other to form a tombstone right in front of your eyes!
reading_story: Now you're curious about what's under there but when you try to touch the tombstone it's radiating with intense heat (ひ)! It must have come from outer space and this heat is from when it entered our atmosphere!
reading_hint: Can you feel the heat radiating off this space tombstone? Maybe there's a space skeleton sizzling under there too...

meaning_story: You shoot an arrow at the mouth of the sun so that it will grant you a gift of wisdom. You heard about a Greek hero doing this and the god in the sun gave him the wisdom to see everything. You're hoping it will work for you too.
meaning_hint: Imagine shooting an arrow at the mouth of the sun and then waiting for the wisdom of the world to hit you. Did it work? Will you know when it works? Probably...
reading_story: You're standing around waiting for the wisdom to hit you when something else does. In the head. Ouch! You look down and it's a wheel of cheese (ち)! At first you're angry, until you realize that this must be a sign. Cheese IS wisdom. And they key to wisdom is eating a lot of cheese!
reading_hint: Picture yourself thanking the sun for teaching you that all wisdom comes from cheese. Now take a big bite!

meaning_story: If a samurai lacks the skill to work a jackhammer you can bet there will be an article or ten about it online just minutes later. The samurai will fail and it will be the second most posted about topic online, behind cat videos. Go look, if you don't believe me!
meaning_hint: Imagine reading like five articles about the same samurai lacking skill at the jackhammer in one morning. Jeez, these articles are all the same! Doesn't anyone want to cover something new?
reading_story: In the article it says "If a samurai lacks jackhammer skills, then what CAN (かん) he do?" That's pretty mean, you think. You're sure samurai can do lots of things. You just... c... can't think of any right now.
reading_hint: Imagine trying to write your own article about the things samurai CAN do. What would be in it? Can you think of anything?

meaning_story: Drum on the belly of a frog to make a sick beat. Frog bellies make a really nice sound and they're perfect if you don't have anyway to make a beat for a song. Go outside right now and try it for yourself.
meaning_hint: Imagine catching a frog and drumming on it's belly to make some beats!
reading_story: If you want to get the best beat possible you need to catch the 子 (こ) frogs! Their tiny bellies actually make the highest, clearest beat sounds.
reading_hint: Imagine druming with each finger on little 子 frog bellies to make the beat for your next song. It's so catchy!

meaning_story: The death of your eyes means that you've gone blind.
meaning_hint: Imagine what it would be like to have one of your eyes die. You'll be blind in that eye forever!
reading_story: When you're blind you probably shouldn't drive anymore because if you do you'll mow (もう) everyone over. Actually, don't mow your lawn either. Blind people probably shouldn't be driving anything.
reading_hint: Imagine a blind person mowing over everyone in their car as they drive on the sidewalk. Eeek. At least they don't have to see this mess.

meaning_story: If you ask a nurse for alcohol she'll brew it for you herself! A nurse will know that just any old alcohol isn't very good for you, so she's taught herself how to brew it for all her patients.
meaning_hint: Imagine this nurse brewing whatever alcohol you ask for just because she thinks the bottled kind won't help you get better.
reading_story: You ask the nurse why she needs to brew the alcohol herself and she says, "Because Joseph (じょう) Stalin makes all the bottled ones." Oh. You don't really trust Joseph Stalin with that. You decide to brew your own alcohol from now on too.
reading_hint: Imagine what it would be like to find out that Joseph Stalin was behind all the big alcohol brewing companies. You'd want to brew your own too, wouldn't you?

kunyomi: くぼ, へこ, ぼこ
meaning_story: The concave radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
meaning_hint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.
reading_story: Calling someone concave is one of the most brutal burns they can dish up. Whenever you hear someone call someone else concave everyone in the room yells, "OHHHHHHHHH (おう). This happens so often that whenever you hear the word concave you hear people cheering oooooh in your head.
reading_hint: Your mama's head is concaaave OOOOHHHHHH!

meaning_story: Give a sad or sick person a stick with a spring on it to offer your condolences. Then even if their arms are broken they can use the stick to play with the spring. It will make them feel better, I promise.
meaning_hint: Imagine handing a stick with a spring on it to a friend who just lost their mom to offer your condolences. The spring will make her feel a little better and she'll know you care.
reading_story: You wouldn't have to show your condolences if that awful Mrs. Chou (ちょう) hadn't killed her mother. Mrs. Chou is also why people are sick and sad. She's the reason for all bad things. When you offer your condolences you're really saying, "I'm sorry for all the bad things Mrs. Chou has done today."
reading_hint: Imagine all the spring sticks you'll have to give out to offer your condolences because of Mrs. Chou's murder rampage.

meaning_story: The convex radical and the life kanji are the same, so hopefully you now just know them both.
meaning_hint: Study your radicals and you'll read good.
reading_story: Is this convex? It's totes (とつ) convex!
reading_hint: Tote bags are totes not convex though. Don't mix them up.

meaning_story: An altered bird is a crow! They look like birds but they're bigger and darker and smarter!
meaning_hint: See that bird? Wait, that's not just a bird, it's a crow!
reading_story: If you can't tell just from looking at it that it's a crow and not a bird, walk up to it and caress (からす) it with your hand! If it caresses you back, it's a crow! If it freaks out and flies away or pecks your face, it's a normal bird. Crows are really smart and like affection. That's what makes them so cool!
reading_hint: How many crows have you caressed today?

meaning_story: And elf who ventures outside in winter has a lot of daring. Elf ears are very very delicate, and the winter cold can really mess them up. So if you see an elf adventuring in winter, know that that particular elf is a really daring dude.
meaning_hint: Imagine how much daring it would take to go outside in winter knowing you could be freezing your precious elf ears off.
reading_story: It's that kind of daring that you could can (かん) and sell online for a bunch of money. Just think about popping open a fresh can of daring, and being confident enough to do whatever it is you want to do!
reading_hint: How much do you think a can of daring would cost? Would you buy it?

meaning_story: A butcher that can never have enough graves is a degenerate. It doesn't matter if he's stealing graves or putting other people in them, a butcher who can't have enough is a bad person!
meaning_hint: Look at that degenerate eyeing those graves over there. Despicable!
reading_story: Wait... that degenerate is... dad (だ)? Dad what are you doing looking at those graves that way? Dad no!
reading_hint: I guess my dad is a degenerate butcher. Huh... maybe your dad is too.

meaning_story: You have to go to the big rice paddy and put it in an enclosure to restore equilibrium. The rice paddy was just too big, rice was popping out of it and hitting people and birds and causing injuries. The whole world was going out of wack! That's why you had to go put it in an enclosure. Now equilibrium can be restored!
meaning_hint: Can you imagine trying to regain equilibrium by going to make an enclosure around a really big rice paddy? I can.
reading_story: This is really important for the person who lost their equilibrium by getting hit in the head with rice in the first place. こういち! That's why he sent you to go do it, at least. You two are really close friends now. It's only right that he send you to restore his, and this world's equilibrium.
reading_hint: You would do anything to help こういち regain his equilibrium right? This is nothing!

meaning_story: If the leader of your gang is a drunkard he'll try to have you fell trees thinking they're rival gang members. You all know they aren't but you can't argue with your leader, especially if he's drunk. Go ahead and attack the trees anyway.
meaning_hint: Imagine felling trees with a bunch of other guys, yelling things like, "This is what you get for stepping on my turf!" It's a little silly.
reading_story: As you attack the innocent trees with your chains and sticks and bunch of bats (ばつ) come flying out and attack YOU! You have your own kind of bats so now you're all trying to fell the bats with YOUR bats!
reading_hint: Bats attacking bats. Who will win on this season of Survivor?

meaning_story: Ask your teacher for alcohol and they'll teach you to ferment it yourself so they don't have to keep buying it for you on the down low. Teaching is what they do anyway, so it's better than straight up buying it, right?
meaning_hint: Imagine learning how to ferment alcohol from your teacher. Cool, but very irresponsible.
reading_story: The bad teacher that's teaching you how to ferment alcohol is こういち?! What the hell, we talked about this こういち! We talked about this, you can teach Japanese but not how to make alcohol. They're minors!
