reading_hint: Imagine being taught methods of fermentation from こういち. I hope he's teaching you the Japanese words for all that too.

meaning_story: Put a guard at your gate to get a good inspection of your neighborhood going. The guard will stand there all day inspecting everything and then report it all back to you. You won't have to do any of the inspection yourself!
meaning_hint: Imagine the guard doing his inspection in front of the gate all day long. He should have a nice report for you once he's done.
reading_story: His inspection is complete, but it looks like he's used an etch (えつ) a sketch to record all the result. That's not really helpful. If you shake it all the inspection results will disappear!
reading_hint: If you hire a guard to stand at your gate and conduct an inspection of your neighborhood, make sure you tell him not to use an etch a sketch!

meaning_story: If you see a hick trying to eat fish tails and go down a water slide you have to intercept them! If that hick tried to eat a fish tail AND go down a water slide he'll choke to death!
meaning_hint: Quick, intercept that fish tail from that hick before he jumps!
reading_story: It's too late for your to intercept by normal means, he's about to jump down the slide, so you call over your shaman (しゃ) friend and she magically intercepts the fish tail from him.
reading_hint: Phew, that was close. If your shaman friend wasn't here to intercept that fish tail the hick would be very dead.

meaning_story: The moon doesn't have any gravity so when you go there your intestines will float around inside your body and sometimes they'll try to come out of your mouth. When nothing is there to hold them down they just kind of go where they please. If you go to the moon, please make sure you keep an eye out on all your guts.
meaning_hint: Imagine the lack of gravity on the moon causing your intestines to pop out of your mouth and into the sky. That doesn't seem very fun at all!
reading_story: If you don't take care of your intestines on the moon the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will know. She'll jump out from behind the moon rocks, grab your floating intestines, and rip them out of you! Then she'll run away and use them for really gross things that I can't even stand to tell you.
reading_hint: Imagine what it would feel like to have Mrs. Chou come moon bouncing up to you and ripping your intestines out through your mouth! You better keep an eye on them while you're on the moon if you don't want that to happen!

meaning_story: The king threw a pile of swords in a rice paddy and told us that the first person to get the most lapis lazuli and give it to him would be allowed to live. But how are you supposed to dig with a sword? It doesn't matter, dig and look for blue rocks!
meaning_hint: Imagine being told by the king that you have to use a pile of swords to find lapis lazuli for him or you'll be killed. What do you do?
reading_story: You can't find any lapis lazuli but you do find a loophole (る) in the king's rules. You decide to sit and wait with your sword ready and decide you'll kill the first person who finds it and YOU will take it to the king.
reading_hint: Use that loophole and give the lapis lazuli to the king so you can live!

meaning_story: Your nose isn't the first thing people see about your face, it's the latter. They see your eyes THEN your nose, then your mouth, in order going down. Just label them A B and C and you'll never forget!
meaning_hint: Imagine saying A B C as you look down someones face at their eyes, nose and mouth. Their nose is B!
reading_story: If you don't have any cereal you have to eat your B breakfast option. Oats (おつ). You don't hate oats, but they're definitely not your first choice.
reading_hint: Imagine running out of cereal so you have to eat your latter option of breakfast oats. They aren't awful but they aren't your A breakfast choice, that's for sure.

meaning_story: A tree that does well in the wind is a maple tree. Maple trees don't have fruit so the wind can't knock anything off of it. That's why they thrive well in windy places!
meaning_hint: Picture a bunch of maple trees being blown by the wind. They don't seem upset, they actually seem really happy.
reading_story: As you watch the maple tree sway a bunch of kids come running up and start ripping the leaves off the tree! Then they start munching on them! That's because maple leaves are food (ふう)!
reading_hint: Maple leaves are food. Go try some!

meaning_story: If you trap the moon in a greenhouse it will grow a creepy membrane around itself. The moon isn't used to the heat it would be exposed to in a greenhouse so that membrane is there to protect it. It's really gross looking though.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing the moon with a membrane sitting stuffed in a greenhouse. It looks like something out of the Alien movies and you're starting to think putting it in there wasn't a good idea.
reading_story: You decide to open the greenhouse to check this moon membrane out but when you open the door the smell of big macs (まく) hits you in the face. Eww. Why does this membrane smell like a big mac... or does that mean big macs smell like a festering moon?
reading_hint: Can you imagine if the moon had a membrane and it smelled like a big mac? How does that even happen? You should probably go ask that food chain what they use for their ingredients.

meaning_story: If you want to turn your thread into a sweet color you just HAVE to go with navy or dark blue. That's the sweetest color in existence, everyone knows that. After, all blue raspberry flavor is dark blue and it's super sweet.
meaning_hint: Turn your thread a sweet navy color and people will be reminded of yummy blue raspberry. MmMmm.
reading_story: Now that your threads are navy colored you need to be careful that condors (こん) don't try to steal it for their nests. Condors love dark blue things and thread is perfect for a condor nest.
reading_hint: Imagine a condor stealing your sweet navy thread right after you dyed it any flying off. Lame!

meaning_story: You put flowers and two flags above the mouth of the roof because you want them to turn pale, and maybe even blue. You put them on the roof because the sky is pale and blue, so maybe if they spend enough time close to the sky they'll turn that color too!
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to get flowers and two flags to turn pale blue by putting them on the mouth of your roof. Do you think it will work? It's worth a try at least.
reading_story: The problem with trying to turn things pale and blue this way is that they can be blown off the roof really easily. That's why you have to sew (そう) them to it. The mouth of the roof is the best place for that.
reading_hint: Remember that if you want things to stay on your roof long enough to turn a nice pale blue you have to sew them in place. If you don't they'll just fall off and stay whatever lame color they started as.

meaning_story: Sacrifice the life of a clam in some tsunami water to make a liquid you can pickle in! Didn't you know that all pickles are made from the sacrificing of clams? Well you should think about that the next time you're munching on some pickled veggies.
meaning_hint: Imagine stabbing a clam and dropping it in some water you collected from a tsunami so that you can make your own pickles.
reading_story: You can only pickle two (つ) things with the life of one clam. Thats a lot of dead clams for not a lot of delicious pickles. Make sure you get a lot of clams if you want a full jar.
reading_hint: Picture the two pickles that clam life got you. They're gonna be the best pickles ever!

meaning_story: You find a drunkard leaning on a grave with something in his mouth. You walk over and he spits a question mark into your hand. Um... does this mean he's confused? He probably doesn't even know where he is. But how did he make this question mark and why was it in his mouth?
meaning_hint: Imagine having a drunkard spit a question mark into your hand in a graveyard. You want to say, "Yes, I'm ??? too."
reading_story: The drunkard takes the question mark back and presses it against the grave. You look closer and see the grave says Yankees (や). Oh come on. "Do you just want to know the Yankees score in the game?" The drunkard nods.
reading_hint: Picture yourself throwing the question mark back at the drunkard who only cares about the Yankees. What a waste of time.

meaning_story: Your husband grows horns and wanders into the mountains. He looks at the mountain and punches the ground! A huge ravine opens up, splitting the ground! Everything is shaking! Everything is rumbling! The ravine is huge!
meaning_hint: Those horns your husband grew must have given your husband the strength to crack a ravine into that mountain. You still don't know why he did it, but it was pretty cool to watch.
reading_story: The ravine keeps getting longer and longer. You look past the mountain and see that it's heading for Kyoto (きょう)! No! You love Kyoto, you don't want it to be turned into a giant ravine, do you?
reading_hint: Quick! Stop your horned husband from turning Kyoto into a ravine!

meaning_story: If a drunkard clam crosses the wrong person they'll become a robber. Drunk clams are notoriously violent and if you have a really big purse it will jump up and steal it!
meaning_hint: Imagine crossing a drunkard clam on the street and having it rob you. "Robber, robber!" you yell, but no one can see the clam under your purse. It just looks like your purse is running away by itself.
reading_story: Once he's had a taste of being a robber he'll join a Bosozoku (ぞく) bike gang so he can keep stealing more and more purses. He'll drink more, steal more, and get to ride cool motorcycles.
reading_hint: Picture a robber clam in a Bosozoku bike gang. Look at him the wrong way and he and his gang will steal all your stuff next time!

meaning_story: Move your coat rack in one direction by shooting it with a gun. Then you can keep shooting it to get a good rotation going. If you think there is a better way to make your coat rack make revolutions, you're probably wrong.
meaning_hint: Imagine getting your coat rack to make rotations in a circle just by shooting it with a gun!
reading_story: As you watch your coat rack's rotations a centaur (せん) barges in and takes the gun from you, stops the rotating coat rack and leaves. How rude! I guess centaurs don't like when things rotate.
reading_hint: Picture that centaurs angry face. Convince yourself it was the rotation it didn't like.

meaning_story: Even if a leader teaches two sticks to drive a train, he'll still have to pay them a salary. It doesn't matter if you train them yourself, you can't make someone, stick or human, work for you and not give them the salary they deserve!
meaning_hint: Teaching two sticks how to drive a train is really hard for any leader, but just because you were able to teach them doesn't mean you can't pay them salary. The credit goes to them!
reading_story: If you don't pay them a good salary, Harry Houdini (ほう) will poof in, slap you, and make them turn back into regular, non-sentient sticks. Then you'll have no one to drive your train.
reading_hint: Remember to always pay a good salary to the people who work for you or Houdini will come in and make you pay.

meaning_story: If you put the sun in an enclosure and try to scoop it into your mouth with a spoon the entire world is going to scold you. You need the sun for life to exist, it's way too big to eat, and it's definitely going to burn you to death. They scold and scold you saying things like this because, to be fair, that's a terrible idea. Now you feel bad.
meaning_hint: Imagine the epic scolding you'd get from the entire planet if you tried to trap and eat the sun.
reading_story: But you know who you can't scold? Cats (かつ). Cats don't care if you're yelling at them or being nice to them. If a cat tried to eat the sun no one would be able to stop them. And if you scold them they'll just do the thing you're mad about again. That's why cats are so awesome.
reading_hint: Imagine scolding some cats who are planning to eat the sun. They glare at you and then eat that sun AND the suns of other galaxies too, just to spite you. I guess that's what you get for trying to scold some cats.

meaning_story: Sauron gives threads to a bunch of turkeys and has them spread out throughout the lands to spread his influence. Turkeys like to run really far in random directions, and all he has to do is follow the thread to find the place that turkey has been spying on to take it over.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a bunch of turkeys with threads tied to their feet spreading out into the wilderness. If you didn't know it was all apart of Sauron's plan you'd be very confused.
reading_story: Unfortunately for Sauron the turkeys spread out too far and the Egyptian god Ra (ら)decides enough is enough. He cuts all the threads, making the spreading out of the turkeys useless to Sauron.
reading_hint: Don't anger Ra or he'll foil your plans to spread out your land!

kunyomi: きざ, めばえ, も
meaning_story: You have to put flowers in a bright place if you want them to sprout. If they're left in the shade they'll just rot.
meaning_hint: Picture your flowers sprouting out of the ground in the bright summer sun.
reading_story: You know who else sprouts in the bright sun? Harry Houdini (ほう) apparently because he's sprouting out of the ground next to your flowers. I guess this must be some kind of... magic trick?
reading_hint: Picture Houdini sprouting out of the ground in the middle of the day and then just walking off like nothing weird just happened in your flower garden.

meaning_story: A tree melts into the ground after listening to loud music in the hot sun so you have to find a nice big tank to scoop the melted tree into. The music made the tree vibrate at juuust the right frequency that it, combined with the hot sun, made the tree turn into a puddle. You can't just leave it being all blobby on the ground, so you find a tank for it.
meaning_hint: Imagine scooping a melted tree into a tank. It's a very strange sensation.
reading_story: Once the tree is safely in the tank you can start to sew (そう) it back together. But if you don't sew it while it's still in the tank the tree goo will get sucked into the ground and you won't be able to sew it back together at all!
reading_hint: Imagine sitting in a tank of melted tree goo and carefully sewing it back together drop by drop.

meaning_story: If you want a big enough grave so that the person in it can have peace it needs to take up a two mat area. Two tatami mats, that it. This is a pretty common measurement in Japan, so you should get really familiar with this idea of the amount of space that two tatami mats take up together.
meaning_hint: Picture how big a two mat area is. Now make sure that the grave you're preparing has that much room so that the person you're burying can have peace in the next life.
reading_story: A two mat area is also enough to hold two bodies (つぼ), which is what makes it so comfortable for a dead person. If you give them the room of two dead bodies then you won't have to worry at all about them attaining peace.
reading_hint: Try to picture a two mat area with two bodies laying in it.

meaning_story: What does a water slide and a bookshelf have in common? They're universal. It doesn't matter who you are or where you're from, everyone has or has seen a water slide and a bookshelf. Sometimes in the same place!
meaning_hint: Water slide and bookshelves are universally loved by all!
reading_story: They're so universal that even hens (へん) have them. They may be small and hen sized, but the next time you're at a barn check the chicken coop. You'll see a little hen water slide and a little hen bookshelf with popular chicken lit.
reading_hint: Can you think of anything else that's so universal even a hen uses it? No? Didn't think so.

meaning_story: The machine in your body that is powered by the moon is your womb, also called your uterus! Haven't you ever wondered why periods happen with the revolutions of the moon? That's because it powers your uterus and tells it what to do!
meaning_hint: The next time you're cursing your uterus for making you bleed, curse the moon instead! It's the moon's fault you're in pain.
reading_story: It kind of sucks, but there is no way to sever this uterus - moon tie (たい). But if you find a way please tell me, I can't take this anymore.
reading_hint: Picture an invisible tie tieing your uterus to the moon. Damn you moon, stop pulling, it hurts!

meaning_story: A butcher and a clown ask you to accompany them to where they're going. You don't really want to because this sounds like something out of a horror movie. But the butcher is holding a knife and the clown is holding a balloon animal so you can't say no. You accompany them to wherever they're going.
meaning_hint: Imagine being asked to accompany a scary butcher and a scary clown. You have to do it!
reading_story: You accompany the butcher and the clown like they asked and stop in front of a house. They turn slowly to you and say, "Bye (ばい)!" Then go in the house, leaving you outside.
reading_hint: Imagine accompanying these two characters to their house and them saying bye and letting you to go. I guess this isn't a horror movie. Phew.

meaning_story: If you hit your husband with a nailbat he's going to need aid. Nailbats are pretty brutal, so if you hit your husband with one he's going to need first aid right away!
meaning_hint: Imagine how much someone would need after getting bashed with a nailbat. Probably a lot.
reading_story: Your husband wouldn't need aid in the first place if he wasn't such a fool (ふ). Then you wouldn't have hit him at least... Okay so maybe this is all your fault and you're a jerk. But if you want to say he wouldn't have needed aid if he wasn't a fool you can.
reading_hint: Keep sticking to your story that your husband is a fool and that's why you hit him with a nailbat causing him to get aid. You can tell that to the cops when they get here.

meaning_story: If you find out a water slide is faulty you have to find an alternate attraction to distract the kids who can't slide anymore. If you don't find an alternate they'll rebel and destroy everything. Children are horrible.
meaning_hint: Imagine having to look for an alternate way of entertaining kids after a fault is found in your water slide. What would you do?
reading_story: I'll tell you what you do. The alternate is Tetsuo (てつ) the Iron Man! Kids love Tetsuo! And when you swap him in they'll forget all about the faulty water slide.
reading_hint: The best alternate to a faulty water slide is good old Tetsuo!

meaning_story: Your husband accidentally stepped on a bird with cleats on! But it lived because it's a chicken and chickens are really durable! Good thing it wasn't a robin or a sparrow or the cleats would have crushed it!
meaning_hint: Imagine finding the poor chicken after your husband stepped on it with his cleats. It's a little flustered, but it's actually okay!
reading_story: The chicken doesn't seem to be very happy though because it starts shouting horrible racial slurs at your husband. Oh, that's because the chicken is a KKK (けい) member. You didn't even know chickens were allowed in, but now you know better.
reading_hint: Imagine being yelled at my an angry KKK chicken. He's so mean!

meaning_story: The king raked all the mountains down into flat land so he could see everyone in the kingdom from his castle windows. You should share your congratulations with him. Now, quick tell him this was a great idea.
meaning_hint: Imagine saying "Congratulations!" to a king who just ordered his servants to rake down all the pretty mountains in his kingdom.
reading_story: The moment you say "Congratulations!" you've already started to miss (みず) those beautiful mountains. But you can't let missing them ruin your congratulations! Don't let the king know!
reading_hint: Imagine how hollow your congratulation sounds when you really miss those mountains. This king doesn't deserve your nice words.

meaning_story: Gamblers usually only see the sun at dawn. They gamble all day and through the night, and if they leave it's at the crack of dawn to get home, clean up, and then go back. I haven't known a gambler who's seen the sun ... well ever!
meaning_hint: Imagine being a gambler and seeing the bright dawn sun when you come out of the casino or pachinko parlor. It burns your eyes! Evil dawn, get back inside quick!
reading_story: If you're up at dawn you'll also see the あか (red) つき (moon). The あかつき only happens as the sun comes up at dawn so usually only gamblers see it. But if you get up early, you can see it too!
reading_hint: Imagine getting up at dawn and seeing the あかつき in the sky near the sun. It's so beautiful!

meaning_story: You have some clown ribs on the table and you need to divide them up. I guess you're dividing them to cook them? Hmm... well either way you need to figure out how to do it.
meaning_hint: Imagine someone telling you that you need to take some clown ribs and divide them up.
reading_story: You have to divide these clown ribs but the only thing you have that can do it is a bow (ぼう) and arrow. You pull back the bow and loose the arrow right between each rib to divide them. It actually works!
reading_hint: Imagine using a bow and arrow to divide clown ribs. Don't think about what you're dividing them for.

meaning_story: If you touch ice for too long you'll get frostbite and that's a really hard thing to endure. A lot of people can't, and die. Then again, you managed to endure touching ice long enough to get frostbite in the first place, so maybe this is baby stuff for you.
meaning_hint: Imagine having to endure the pain of frostbite because you were a jerk who put his hand on ice for a few hours.
reading_story: The best people in the world at being able to endure the pain are the shinobi (しの) ninjas! They train by hanging out in frozen areas all the time and don't complain at all. Maybe if the pain gets to be too much you can go ask them for advice.
reading_hint: Imagine if you were one of these cool Shinobi ninjas that could endure the extreme cold and pain of frostbite!

meaning_story: You have to reach a certain number of flowers and tsunamis hits to become a legitimate fiefdom. At least in the old days. If you don't meet one of these conditions, like if you get hit by tsunamis all the time but you only have two or three flowers that will grow, you can't be your own fiefdom.
meaning_hint: Imagine being the person who has to check whether each fiefdom has enough flowers and tsunamis per year to keep their status.
reading_story: The most famous fiefdom checker is Han (はん) Solo. He takes his Millennium Falcom and swoops around checking for flowers and signs of past tsunamis and then he'll either say you can or cannot be your own fiefdom. Thanks Han Solo!
reading_hint: Picture Han Solo flying around Japan checking to make sure all the fiefdoms are up to code.

meaning_story: If you say the lineup of your family members that have lived on this earth under the sun, you're really explaining your genealogy. This kanji has a second meaning too. It means score. So if you're saying the the line up of what happened today under the sun you're really just saying the score of a game. So which is it? Are you talking about the past or something that happened today? That's what makes the difference.
meaning_hint: Say the line up of what happened under the sun. It's the genealogy of your family or the score of your game!
reading_story: if you can't tell the difference between your genealogy and a game's score you're a fool (ふ) and I can't help you. You aren't a fool, are you? You know the difference.
reading_hint: Your family genealogy and your game's score aren't even close to being the same thing. Memorize these or everyone will think you're a fool.

meaning_story: If you want to make a rocket the king will like, you have to make the whole thing look glassy. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king will approve.If you want to make a rocket the king will like, you have to make the whole thing look glassy. It won't be very stable, and it probably won't work, but making it glassy and pretty is the only way to make the king will approve.
meaning_hint: Imagine a king who won't accept a rocket that isn't made of glassy material. He's not very smart...
reading_story: He doesn't just want the rocket to be pretty and glassy, he wants it to be full of reese's (り) pieces. He says he wants to have something to munch while he travels space in style. This also sounds like a terrible idea.
reading_hint: Then again, imagine what it would be like to be a king flying through space in a rocket glassy enough to see through, stars all around you, and endless reese's pieces to eat. Doesn't sound so bad now, right?

meaning_story: You can only manage to avoid a tsunami by standing above it on a small stool if you are very graceful. If you aren't graceful enough the tsunami will knock you and the stool over and you'll be swept away like everyone else.
meaning_hint: Imagine being graceful enough to balance on a small stool above a raging tsunami! Sooo cool!
reading_story: No matter how graceful you are, the still tsunami shook (しゅく) the small stool. That's where your gracefulness came in. The stool shook, but you didn't. You balanced yourself and refused to go down.
reading_hint: It doesn't matter how badly the stool shook, you stayed graceful and didn't fall!

meaning_story: The leader of the protesters ties himself to a tree so that it's greatness cannot be torn down. Protester leaders have been showing the greatness of trees like this for ages!
meaning_hint: Imagine watching the leader protester tie himself in front of a tree so the world can recognize the greatness it holds. If the whole worlds sees it, no one can cut it down!
reading_story: If you don't recognize the tree's greatness the leader will throw ketsup (けつ) all over you (it's a special mix of ketchup and catsup). It's ketsup because it looks like blood. Tree blood.
reading_hint: Imagine someone saying, "There's no greatness anywhere near this tree!" And then catsup flies at their face.

onyomi: かく, こく, ばい
meaning_story: You see a samurai laying his forehead on a table at ikea. It looks like he works here now and it's turned him into a husk of his former self. Samurai don't want to sell Swedish tables and chairs, they want to fight for honor and die at the hands of a skilled blade master. This poor samurai is just a shell of who he once was.
meaning_hint: Picture the sad samurai, his forehead pressed against a table at ikea, and think about how working here has turned him into a soulless husk.
reading_story: When someone becomes a husk like this the only way to bring them back is by having a cock (かく) crow right in their ear. It's super loud, and usually startles them back to life. If you wan't to bring this poor samurai back you need to get a cock to crow at him.
reading_hint: Imagine running around ikea, dragging this husk of a person with you, looking for a cock. They must have one here, they have everything, right?!

meaning_story: You can't just leave your gold helmet sitting on a coat rack so you lock it up. Do you know how much a gold helmet costs? It's a lot, okay? So take the helmet and the coat rack and lock them in the closet where they'll be safe.
meaning_hint: Imagine what could happen to your gold helmet if you just left it sitting on a coat rack and didn't lock it up. You never know what kind of horrible person might walk by and try to steal it!
reading_story: Actually, if you don't lock your gold helmet up you know exactly who'll try to steal it. Joseph (じょう) Stalin! After all the horrible things you've seen him do, don't you feel like you should lock everything you own up so he can't get his hands on them? But a gold helmet? That's just asking for trouble from ol'Jo.
reading_hint: Imagine how fast Joseph Stalin would steal your gold helmet if you didn't lock it up. It's a sitting duck on a coat rack.

meaning_story: A sweet woman sits under a tree and works as a mediator. If you're having a fight with someone, bring them to the sweet woman under the tree and she'll mediate for the two of you. Problem solved! Thanks sweet lady!
meaning_hint: Imagine the sweet tree woman being a mediator for you and your arch rival. What she says fixes everything between you two!
reading_story: You go to pay woman for being your mediator for you two but she just says, "Bye ばい)." You try to hand her some money and she stares into your eyes. "Bye." Oh... okay, bye then.
reading_hint: Imagine her refusing to let you pay her for her mediator services and just saying "bye" over and over until you leave. Weird.

meaning_story: If a cobra bites the heart of someone you love you'll be in mourning pretty quickly because they're dead. No one lives through a cobra heart attack. You should just start mourning in whatever way your culture does, right away.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself putting on black, lighting candles, turning the lights off to go into mourning because a cobra ate the heart of one of your loved ones. It's a really sad way to go. I'm sorry for your loss. (People are going to be saying that a lot to you for the next month or so btw.)
reading_story: Luckily, the key (き) to removing snake poison is mourning! The more you mourn the more the poison dilutes itself. Sadly the key to coming back to life is not mourning. Otherwise no one would be dead ever.
reading_hint: Imagine mourning and realizing it's was the key to removing the poison all along! If only you knew that sooner you might have saved that guy's life.

meaning_story: If a tsunami gets into Sauron's insect enclosure all the insects are going to get really muddy. Sauron hates muddy insects, and the enclosure itself is a mess too. You don't want Sauron to be mad (bad stuff happens) so you should probably un-muddy this mess fast.
meaning_hint: Imagine how muddy the Sauron's insect enclosure is after a tsunami washes through it. Bleh.
reading_story: Unfortunately for you, these muddy conditions have created the perfect habitat for ducks (だく)! Ducks are flying in from all directions to splash in the mud and oh no, They're eating the muddy insects!
reading_hint: You really hope Sauron likes ducks. Because this is a muddy duck pen now.

meaning_story: The only tree a turkey will live in is an oak tree. They really only do this because oak trees have really yummy acorns and turkeys loooove acorns.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a turkey sitting in an oak tree munching on acorns. You didn't even know turkeys could fly, but it got up there somehow.
reading_story: If you see a bunch of oaks but no turkeys just yell, "SOOEY (つい)!" and they'll all come jumping out! Just because you can't see a turkey in there doesn't mean there isn't one!
reading_hint: Imagine standing in a grove of oak trees and yelling SOOEY! SOOOOOEY! Now watch as hundreds of turkeys come flying at your face! They think you have more acorns for them. RUN!

meaning_story: If you spill something red on yourself in winter you should pardon yourself immediately and try to find something else to wear. It's very dangerous to wear red in winter, and even if it seems rude, make sure you pardon yourself right away and get that taken care of!
meaning_hint: Imagine spilling red wine or red paint down your shirt. Quickly pardon yourself and get changed now!
reading_story: If you don't pardon yourself fast enough the winter shaman (しゃ) will burst in and cast a spell on you, taking away all the clothes that have red on them! Now you have to pardon yourself for being naked!
reading_hint: Imagine not pardoning yourself fast enough and having the winter shaman spirit away whatever you got red on. That's embarrassing.

kunyomi: ざ, じゃ, たわむ
meaning_story: Throw a drunkard in a cage with a tiger and some spikes and the tiger will have the time of it's life playing with them! Think of all the tiger play time possibilities!
meaning_hint: If you were the tiger how would you play with the drunkard?
reading_story: If you aren't the tiger, watching it play is a little like watching someone's head get cut off with a guillotine (ぎ). In fact, you don't want to watch it play at all anymore.
reading_hint: What would you rather watch? A guillotine at work or a tiger playing like this?

meaning_story: If someone gives you a sock you should receive it and thank them. You can't just say no or put the sock on the ground and walk away. You should always receive a sock when it's handed to you.
meaning_hint: Imagine Dobby reaching out to receive his first sock. Don't you want to be happy like that too?
reading_story: The best place to receive a sock in in Kyoto (きょう). They're famous for their sock store and schoolgirls who have too many socks. If you walk down the street someone is bound to try to hand you a sock in Kyoto, and you should receive it happily.
reading_hint: Imagine standing in Kyoto and receiving hundreds of socks. People just keep giving them to you here!

meaning_story: If you want to take a flag out of the mouth of a mantis you have to make a formal request first. Mantises don't like to just give things away, and they're kind of mean so if you try to steal the flag it will probably bite you. So make a formal, polite request if you want it.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to request a flag from a scary mantis that has it sitting in it's mouth. Will it give it to you? Will it bite you? You'll have to wait and see.
reading_story: After you request the mantis give you its flag it shocks (しょく) you by actually spitting it out of its mouth at your feet. You didn't think your request would work, or even if the mantis understood human speech, but it shocked you by doing exactly what you asked!
reading_hint: Imagine your shock at finding out the mantis not only understood your request, but agreed! This is great but also makes you wonder what other creatures can understand you...

meaning_story: You see a triceratops standing in front of a full moon and you can't help but see a really strong resemblance. The triceratops has that round frill thing behind it's horns and it looks just like the round full moon. Who knew that a triceratops would resemble the moon so strongly!
meaning_hint: Look at the triceratops. Now look at the moon. See the resemblance? Uncanny, don't you think?
reading_story: The first person to see this resemblance was the shogun (しょう). That's why he decided to put a triceratops head with the moon behind it on his mon (family crest). Now he's known as the full moon dinosaur shogun, and he's very famous.
reading_hint: Imagine being this shogun and seeing the resemblance between a triceratops and the moon for the first time. You'd put that on all your stuff too, if you were him.

meaning_story: If you see a clam steal a donation of fish sticks and flowers from under a cross you'll resent them. Only a really horrible clam would steal things from under a cross. Resenting them is a totally normal response.
meaning_hint: Imagine how much you would resent a clam you saw stealing a fish stick and some flowers from under a cross. It's a lot, right?
reading_story: You don't want to resent someone for nothing, so you run over to the clam and ask them why they did it and they say, "Cause it's fun (ふん)." UHG! Now you resent them even more!
reading_hint: What kind of jerk thinks stealing is fun??

meaning_story: Push your car down a water slide into an oncoming tsunami and watch the ripples travel with the tsunami over the land and then back out to see. Ripples are really pretty to watch, especially huge ones!
meaning_hint: Imagine pushing your car down a water slide into a tsunami. Look how huge those ripples get!
reading_story: You used your car to make the ripples because it was just a rental (れん). The rental place can't blame you for losing their car in a tsunami! And they'll never find out you rented it just to make tsunami ripples!
reading_hint: Laugh as you watch the cool ripples you made with your rental car!

meaning_story: If you put a tree in an enclosure that's below ground it's going to rot. Trees can't live without sunlight, and it's too damp underground for them to absorb enough water. That water gets all moldy and then the tree will rot and die.
meaning_hint: Imagine looking in an underground enclosure to find a sad rotted tree. Whoever did this really hates nature.
reading_story: As you stare at the poor rotten tree a man comes up behind you and says, "Cute (きゅう), isn't it?" Cute? What's cute about a pile of rot? But this weird guy apparently made the tree rot on purpose because he thought it was cute. What a messed up guy!
reading_hint: Look at the rotted tree and try to see what's so cute about it. Look really closely and try to find anything that can be called "cute" about this situation.

meaning_story: You're walking down the street when you see twenty big crosses lined up in front of you. Crosses creep you out and this is way too many for you to keep walking so you decide to run as fast as you can to get past them.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to run down a street with twenty big crosses lining it. It's so scary that you keep running faster and faster as you go.
reading_story: You figure since you're already on the run that you might as well hone (ほん) your running skills while you make your way down this scary, cross lined street.
reading_hint: Imagine distracting yourself from the scary crosses by honing your running skills while you do it.

meaning_story: Two face dropped a table into water so that he could sail away from Gotham. He couldn't think of another way to get out without Batman stopping him, so sailing by table-boat was what he decided on.
meaning_hint: Picture two face sailing away in the distance. The table looks a little unsteady in the water, but he is making progress.
reading_story: As you watch him sail, suddenly Han (はん) Solo is standing next to you, pointing his blaster at Two face. Two face tries to sail faster, but his table has no actual sail, so he gets hit right in one side of his two faces and flops off into the water.
reading_hint: Imagine watching Han Solo stop Two face from sailing. "No one sails on my watch," Han says. "O...okay" you respond, backing away.

meaning_story: The species of flowers that looks like grass wearing little helmets and is often eaten by bears is the sedge species. Sedges grow all over the world!
meaning_hint: You've probably seen them before, you just didn't know what they were called!
reading_story: The next time you see a sedge bite into one. They taste like sugar (すが)! That's why all the bears eat them.
reading_hint: Imagine biting into a sedge flower and tasting the yummy sugary taste. Mmmm. * this is a Nanori reading and not Kun'yomi

meaning_story: Pour all of your alcohol in the pool to serve all your guests at once! They can all help themselves to as much or as little alcohol as they want! What a great idea!
meaning_hint: Imagine serving all of your guests their alcohol by dumping it all in the pool! Now jump in and drink all you want!
reading_story: As you serve your guests (and yourself) you look over and see Shaq (しゃく) also trying to serve them. And by serving I mean getting served because he's throwing them into the pool.
reading_hint: Picture Shaq serving your guests by tossing them into your alcohol filled pool. Thanks, Shaq... I guess.

meaning_story: Some fish sticks are so good that they make you put your fangs away and sigh really loudly. You normally never put your fangs away, let alone sigh, but these fish sticks are just too good for you to resist.
meaning_hint: Imagine a fish stick so good it made you retract your fangs and sigh out loud. Ahhh.
reading_story: Wait what do you mean "normal people don't have to put away their fangs to sigh?" I'm just a normal guy (がい) just like you. A completely normal human guy who sighs and eats fish sticks. And has fangs. Yes, a normal human guy.
reading_hint: Imagine if you were the kind of guy who didn't have to put their fangs away before the sighed ha ha ha impossible.

meaning_story: Put thread in the mouth of a worm while the moon is out and it will poop out some silk. That's why they call them silkworms, didn't you know? But it has to be while the moon is out, otherwise normal thread will come right back out the other end of the worm. The moon is what makes the magic happen.
meaning_hint: Picture feeding some thread into the mouth of a worm as the light from the full moon shines in on you. See the silk come out of the worms butt and into your hands.
reading_story: The most famous silk worm farmer you know is Ken (けん) from Street Fighter. How do you think he always gets those nice silk gi? He makes them with his own silk!
reading_hint: Picture Ken gently feeding thread to his little worms in the light of the moon to get silk for his gi. They rip a lot while he's fighting so he has to have lots of back ups ready.

meaning_story: You see seven swords just sitting in a hole and so you decide to steal them. They were just left in that hole after all, it's not like anyone was using them. And even if they were, they'll never know you were the one to steal them, right?
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing seven swords just laying abandoned in a hole. Feel the urge to steal them all. Do it, do it!
reading_story: You steal the swords and realize they aren't just seven random swords, they're from the famous sword sets (せつ) they sell online. This particular set is from the Seven Samurai movie. Yes! What a great steal!
reading_hint: Imagine your delight as you look up the different sword sets online and realize you happened to steal the best one!

meaning_story: Throw a stone shaped like a boob in this river and it will turn to sulfur! This river has some cool powers that will turn any boob shaped stone from normal rock into sulfur rock. Just make sure you really want that cause sulfur is kinda stinky.
meaning_hint: Imagine throwing a boob shaped stone into a river and having it wash up on shore changed into bright yellow sulfur!
reading_story: Once you have your sulfur rock you should leave right away though because Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter is hanging out near one of the waterfalls this river has and he hates sulfur. He'll punch it right out of your hands and then punch you if he sees it!
reading_hint: Imagine being chased down a river by Ryu because you don't want him to take your new sulfur stone!

meaning_story: When you see a tie fighter you should always remember that they were made in Asia. All the tie fighter mechanics, factories, and designers live in Asia, so if you want to buy or fix one you better be ready to fly all the way back!
meaning_hint: Imagine a bunch of tie fighters flying in and out of Asia.
reading_story: What's the first sound in Asia? AHHHHH. I mean. It's A (あ). Nice and easy!
reading_hint: A is for Asia!

meaning_story: If you find a really big thorn bush you should build your barracks there! Thorns are a natural barrier and defense to invaders, so if you build your barracks in the middle of them you won't even need walls!!
meaning_hint: Imagine building your barracks in the middle of a huge thorn patch. You keep getting pricked too, but if you don't like it, think how much your enemies won't like it!
reading_story: Just remember that barracks are pretty big so you need a ton (とん) of thorns to keep it secure. If there aren't enough you'll have to actually build your own defenses and that defeats the whole purpose of using the thorns! So only build it where there are an absolute TON of thorns.
reading_hint: Imagine completing your barracks and admiring the ton of thorns that are keeping you all safe in there.

meaning_story: You see a mountain in the shape of a turtle shell sticking out into the ocean. It's a cape! No, not the kind you wear, the geographical kind. When you're on land, most capes look like turtle shell mountains sticking out into the sea. Do you know any capes like that near where you live?
meaning_hint: Picture the turtle shell shaped cape. Feel the salty wind in your hair!
reading_story: You decide to walk along this cape because it looks like the perfect place to get ride of your old meat sack (みさき). It's starting to smell, but the ocean breeze from the cape pulls the meat sack out of your hands and off into the sky (then probably into the sea too).
reading_hint: The next time you go to the cape, remember to bring your old, used meat sack. You can toss it right into the ocean and it won't bother you ever again! Just make sure no one sees you.

meaning_story: Take three measurements of gold and slide them into a mold to make a cast! You'll have cast three gold swords, or goblets, or ducks. Just make sure you follow those directions, or your casting won't come out right.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself carefully measuring out the three portions of gold and sliding them into your mold to make a cast of whatever you want. I wonder what it could be?
reading_story: You open the cast to reveal your gold statue of Chewbacca (ちゅう)! It's life-size and now you have three! Your new gold Chewbacca casts are going to guard the entrance to your house.
reading_hint: Picture your majestic Chewbacca casts. Carefully set them outside your front door to guard you. This was a great idea!

meaning_story: Use a nailbat to make an exit if you're too clumsy to open a normal door. You tried to open the door, you really did. But you hand just kept slipping, so you had to improvise!
meaning_hint: Picture yourself clumsily trying to open the door until you get fed up and smash your way through the wall with your nailbat instead.
reading_story: After you make your clumsy escape you look back and see there were two sets (せつ) of doors. And one of them is standing open. You didn't even have to bash your way out of there.
reading_hint: Maybe if you weren't so darn clumsy you would have seen that there were two sets of doors right in front of you.

meaning_story: You say how the water sounds when it drops to compose a poem. You can't compose anything if you don't have something like water dropping to inspire you.
meaning_hint: Picture the drops of water inspiring you to compose a beautiful poem.
reading_story: The moment you compose the poem you know it's ace (えい)! Mostly because you wrote about how the sound of the water is like you flipping a deck of cards onto a table.
reading_hint: Imagine how ace the poem you compose will be! Now imagine composing poem about aces.

meaning_story: If a mullet having pilot manages to land a helicopter that's pierced with a sideways barb in the heart of winter you should congratulate them! People should always be congratulated for doing good things, and this is one of the best things you've ever heard of!
meaning_hint: Can you even imagine how hard it must be for someone with a mullet in their eyes to land a helicopter in the heart of winter even without the sideways barb jammed in there?? Congratulate them not just for living, but for being a badass!
reading_story: As you run up to congratulate the pilot you see that even the KKK (けい) is here to congratulate him! That's how impressive his flying was. Wow.
reading_hint: Imagine if someone did something so worthy of congratulations that even the KKK had to admit it was great.

meaning_story: You can only give a kiss of alcohol to dairy. If you add anymore than a kiss the dairy will curdle and you won't be able to drink it anymore. Bleh.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to give more than a kiss of alcohol to dairy and watch it bubble and curdle and get all gross and chunky.
reading_story: Dairy isn't kept with other drinks, it needs to be placed on a rack (らく). I hope you've been using your dairy rack to store your dairy. If you haven't you should get one right away!
reading_hint: Look at all your dairy products: milk, yogurt, cheese, mayonnaise, all of it sitting nicely on your dairy rack.

meaning_story: You can only make a horse out of bamboo if you're really deliberate about it. If you aren't quite sure, the bamboo will grow the wrong way really really fast and you won't be able to make it look like a horse at all.
meaning_hint: Imagine how deliberate you'd have to be with every movement you force the bamboo to make to get it to grow in a horse shape.
reading_story: If you were deliberate enough you'll have bamboo in the shape of a horse. Well, a horse bong! Now toke (とく) up and smoke that horse!
reading_hint: You deliberately made a bamboo horse so that you could smoke it! Toke up, friend!

meaning_story: Every leader will come to despise their followers. In the beginning everything is fine and dandy, but eventually the leader's followers will ask for more and more things, eventually ridiculous things, and the leader will really despise them for it.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as a leader who's come to despise their followers. Look down at them in disgust as they ask you to grant them all a pony.
reading_story: Leader you despises your followers so much that you kick them with your boots (ぶ)! It's not the most mature way to handle things, but kicking them over and over with your steel-toed boots sure makes YOU feel better. Every leader goes through this eventually.
reading_hint: Feel how much you despise your followers as you kick them with your boots. They probably despise you back now too.

meaning_story: A crab trap is more like a grave for crabs and it takes a lot to endure being stuck in one. Lots of crabs die in them before they're hauled out of the sea, and the ones that live are going to die once they're out, so all they can do is try to endure what's about to happen the best they can.
meaning_hint: Imagine being a little crab stuck in a crab trap and thinking this will be your grave. You have to endure this horror as long as you can. Then maybe you'll get a chance to escape!
reading_story: The little crab endures being stuck in the crab trap grave just to be turned into a seafood taco (た)! It held out as long as it could, but then it was chopped up and turned into taco filling.
reading_hint: Imagine eating a delicious seafood taco made with the meat of a crab who thought he endured hell and back, just to be eaten by you. This message brought to you by PETA.

meaning_story: That pelican over there has two mustaches so it must be evil. Everyone knows that a mustache makes you evil, but two? Yeah, that pelican must be the ultimate evil if it could grow two.
meaning_hint: Look at that evil two mustache having pelican. He looks like he's plotting something sitting over there.
reading_story: You're watching the evil pelican when he starts to fly away. You can't just let him mess things up somewhere so you run after him and see him pooping on your car (か)!
reading_hint: Imagine running, arms waving, up to the evil pelican to try to get it away from your car. It's nasty, white pelican poops are all over your windshield. Curse you evil pelican! Curse you!

meaning_story: If you can stop a turkey by putting a spoon in it's face you'll know it's a female turkey. A male turkey will peck the spoon out of your hand and run away. But a female turkey will wonder why you're putting a spoon there, stop, and look up at you wondering if you're okay.
meaning_hint: Picture the female turkey stopping when it sees you holding out a spoon. Why are you doing that human? it thinks. Are you sick?
reading_story: The female turkey then runs around making a mess (めす) of things trying to figure out what's wrong with you. She kicks around her hay, water bowl, and scratches at your pants, making more mess marks on them. But you don't move and she gets even more worried.
reading_hint: Imagine watching a female turkey make a mess of her own cage because she thinks you need help. How sweet.

meaning_story: If you see someone eyeing your womb you're probably going to be weirded out by how friendly they're acting. You only let people who are really, really close to you look at your womb. So if this guy is acting that friendly he should have introduced himself first.
meaning_hint: Imagine having someone you aren't friendly with trying to have a look at your womb. No thank you.
reading_story: This friendly guy comes up to you and start to introduce himself, "ぼく-" but you stop him. He's been getting way too friendly with your womb and you don't want to hear who he is. He can ぼく at someone else, you're out.
reading_hint: Imagine only letting this guy start to introduce himself with ぼく before walking the heck outta there. Just because he was acting friendly doesn't mean he was actually your friend.

meaning_story: If you stay up for so long that you get to watch the moon go down and the sunrise, then people will say you have serious guts. Staying up that late is really hard, and not everyone can do it. If you don't have the guts to stay up you'll just fall asleep and never see the moon and the sun switch places in the sky.
meaning_hint: Imagine the guts you'd have to have to stay up for so long that you see the moon and the sun switch places! A lot of guts!
reading_story: You were outside for so long, proving you had major guts, that you also got a sweet tan (たん) out of it! Its a really deep tan though, and you probably need more guts if you ever want to do all that again.
reading_hint: Imagine having the guts to stay outside to watch the moon and the sun and then getting a really deep tan from it.

radical_names: Arrow, Nailbat, Spoon, Mama, Coat Rack
meaning_story: You hold a nailbat and a spoon with a fake arrow sticking through your head while talking like your mama does to the coat rack. This is how you imitate her to your friends. They always laugh a lot so it must be pretty accurate.
meaning_hint: Imagine how much they laugh when you use all these props to imitate your mama. You're finally popular!
reading_story: If your mama ever finds out that you imitate her she's going to cut off your head with a guillotine (ぎ). This isn't a simple, harmless imitation you're doing, you've got all these props and it's pretty mean.
reading_hint: Imagine seeing your mama's face as she pulls out the guillotine she's going to kill you with for imitating her. Ahhhh! RUN!

meaning_story: A tsunami hits a tree and the splashing water from them both pools into a hat. In this hat the water turns into lacquer. You walk over and decide to use the lacquer to make your chopsticks and furniture nice and hard and shiny!
meaning_hint: Picture the weird water from the tsunami and the insides of the tree mix into the hat. Picture it changing in color and turning to lacquer.
reading_story: You love this new lacquer because it protects your wooden furniture from your shitzu (しつ). Shitzus love munching on them. If something is wood a shitzu will gnaw at it, but if you cover it in lacquer the shitzus can't bite through it at all!
reading_hint: Put lacquer on your furniture to protect it from your horrible shitzu dog!

meaning_story: You see a gate with a tree growing in the middle of it and it reminds you that you need more leisure time. You walk up to the gate tree and curl up under it's branches. No one will bother you because the tree is blocking the gate from being used.
meaning_hint: Imagine spending your leisure time curled up under a tree that's growing between two gates. It's so cozy and secluded!
reading_story: If someone tells you that you can't have time for your own leisure, think of this gate with the tree, look them right in the eye and say, "Yes I CAN (かん)!" Then throw a can of soda at their head for good measure, because they're a jerk and everyone needs a break every now and then.
reading_hint: Imagine yelling "YES I CAN YES I CAN" and throwing cans at anyone who tells you that you can't have leisure time.

onyomi: しょう, とう, どう
meaning_story: If you see a fish stick on a stand with a sunflower it will make you long for summer. Fish sticks and sunflowers are the tastes and sights of summer, and you can't help but yearn for it when you see them.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a fish stick and a sunflower standing together and feel how much you yearn for summer to come back. Then you can eat all the fish sticks and smell all the sunflowers you want!
reading_story: As you think about how much your long for summer a cougar (あこが) comes up and eats the fish stick, the sunflower and even the plate! Then it runs away. Now you long for a cougar to come back and give you your taste of summer back.
reading_hint: If you long for something too strongly a cougar will come eat it. So don't long for people... really, don't.

meaning_story: You drop to the ground in a rice paddy, and then drop down in front of the cross you keep on you because you're trying to make yourself as lowly as you can in front of God. He said to lower yourself and this is the only was you can interpret that.
meaning_hint: Imagine dropping down in a rice paddy, then again in front of your cross. Be as lowly as you can make yourself.
reading_story: The only problem about being lowly is the heat (ひ). Everyone always told you that heat rises, but not here. The rice paddy is incredibly hot... unless oh no. Is that the heat of hell?
reading_hint: You tried to make yourself lowly in front of God but this heat is probably a sign that you didn't do it well enough.

meaning_story: You meet a woman with a big mouth and you know instantly that she's the gal you want to marry. You see her smile and laugh and you can't help but fall in love again and again when you look at her.
meaning_hint: When you think about who you want to marry picture your awesome lady with her beautiful, big mouth. That's the lady for you, alright.
reading_story: Your reasons for wanting to marry this woman are totally innocent (いん). Totally innocent. Please don't make me say it again.
reading_hint: Get your mind out of the gutter.

kunyomi: つかさ, ともがら, へや
meaning_story: When underground music makes it out into the light of the sun (the public) it finally become official. Music isn't really real unless people hear it outside of those secret underground concerts.
meaning_hint: Imagine all that music you listened to underground but not in the light of day. None of that was official music. None of it!
reading_story: Once the music is deemed official, you're allowed to sew (そう) T-shirts for you band! If you aren't an official band, playing in the light of the sun, then the shirts you sew are illegal! So watch out.
reading_hint: Are the shirts you sew for bands with official music? You should check!

meaning_story: We want you to say things with your mouth right now because it's recital time! Go, perform please. What do you mean you didn't know the recital was right now? Well, tough luck. Recite!
meaning_hint: The recital is happening now. So open your mouth and start already!
reading_story: Here, if you are too afraid to start the recital now drink this gin (ぎん) to get your courage up. But once you're done drinking it the recital starts!
reading_hint: Drink gin before all your recitals! It'll help!

meaning_story: Turkeys that grow fish tails have to hide in stones underwater because they aren't quite turkeys and they aren't quite fish, so they can't just live anywhere in the open or they'll get made fun of. That's why they live in reefs in the ocean. That way the turkeys can't find them and the fish can't see them through the rock bunches!
meaning_hint: Imagine being a turkey who grew a weird fish tail and having to spend the rest of your life hiding in an underwater reef.
reading_story: They wouldn't have to life in a reef if the shogun (しょう) didn't tell everyone that half fish half turkeys are evil. But now they all have to hide in underwater reefs or they'll get beaten up thanks to that mean old shogun.
reading_hint: Imagine being a turkey with a fish tail and hearing the shogun say you're an abomination. Then imagine living the rest of your life in a rock reef so no one can find you to kick you.

meaning_story: If you look at what's above and below a mountain you'll just see a bunch of ridges. Mountains are made of ridges going up and down, that's why they're so pointy and so hard to climb.
meaning_hint: Imagine looking off the edge of a mountain at all the big ridges going above and below it.
reading_story: It's only on this type of mountain ridge that you'll be able to find the rare and adorable Tokyo gecko (とうげ). These tiny little critters can only be found on the ridges going above and below the mountains in Tokyo. There are like six mountains in Tokyo, so the next time you're scaling the ridges keep your eyes open for the Tokyo gecko!
reading_hint: Picture yourself sitting on a mountain ridge in Tokyo and watching a little Tokyo gecko run up and down on them. It's adorable and totally worth the climb.

meaning_story: People think tsunamis are only made of water but they have a few pieces of sand in there too. There's actually more sand in the ocean than most people think. And tsunamis can't just have water and sharks in them. A few grains of sand will always slip in.
meaning_hint: Imagine how those few grains of sand feel to get swept up into a tsunami. They didn't ask for this. They just wanted to stay at the bottom of the sea.
reading_story: How do I know there's sand in there? Because I saw (さ) them!
reading_hint: I saw the sand, stop doubting me!

meaning_story: You watch a drunkard drop flowers down a slide to land at Sauron's feet and see the scorn spread across Sauron's weird eye face. He hates flowers and now he hates this drunk guy. Sauron's scorn is a scary thing. This guy's probably gonna die.
meaning_hint: Imagine the scorn on Sauron's (eye)face as a drunkard tries to butter him up by slide dropping flowers at his feet. Feel how worried you are for this idiot who doesn't know what he's got himself into.
reading_story: The drunkard wobbles your way, somehow not feeling the scorn of Sauron's eye staring daggers at his back and bets you (べつ) that you can't do something like that. "You don't have to bet me," you say. Because there is no way you're going to evoke the scorn of Sauron.
reading_hint: Imagine how this guy bets you that you can't do what he did. Feel your own scorn for this idiot drunkard building.

kunyomi: おご, にご, よな
meaning_story: If the tsunami that's heading for your village is fat you should try to select a different one to hit instead. You don't want to select fat tsunamis because they do more damage.
meaning_hint: Imagine being at the tsunami store and selecting the least fat one there.
reading_story: If you're having trouble selecting which one is the least fat just check to see which tsunamis are eating tacos (た). Only fat tsunamis will be eating them, so just look for one without a taco.
reading_hint: While you select the tsunami that's right for you. Keep an eye out for those fat taco-eating ones. And then stay away from them!

meaning_story: Move thread in the right direction and you'll end up spinning it into yarn. Then you can spin that yarn into a sweater or a scarf with your favorite half tofu half fugu mascot on it!
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself spinning thread into whatever your imagination wants.
reading_story: While you're spinning you realize that you've always wanted to make your own bow (ぼう). So you spin yourself a bunch of pretty bows and put them in your hair, then what the heck, some bowties too.
reading_hint: Picture yourself spinning bows and bowties for all of your friends. They'll love them!

meaning_story: If you slide out of a helicopter down a water slide and onto the back of a big cobra, you've just made the coolest transition of anyone in history. Can you think of a better transition than that? I can't.
meaning_hint: Imagine how cool your transition from a helicopter, down a water slide, right onto the back of a big cobra would be!
reading_story: The only way that transition could have been cooler is if you turned into a centaur (せん) at the end. Centaurs are kind of like half transitioned creatures themselves, actually. Half horse, half person.
reading_hint: Imagine if after all those other stunts you had transitioned into a centaur too. Darn, that would have been better!

meaning_story: If there's something high above you that you can't reach with a small stool just ask your aunt or uncle to help you. You may be short like your parents, but your aunt and uncle can get things from up high without even needing a stool! If only you were their kid...
meaning_hint: Imagine trying in vain to reach something above you with a small stool and having to ask your tall aunt and uncle instead.
reading_story: You ask your aunt and uncle to help you reach it and they don't seem to understand until you show them how you can't reach it, even with the help of your small stool. "Oh (お)..." they say, and get it for you. Oh?? They seem disappointed in your shortness... (This reading is an exception. It isn't really the nanori reading, but it's close. Just know it isn't the on'yomi or kun'yomi reading you're learning.)
reading_hint: What do you think that "Oh" meant? Do your aunt and uncle hate short people? Maybe they just don't like stools. * this is a Nanori reading not Kun'yomi

meaning_story: Making a mnemonic for a crab trap is VERY hard. So hard that I couldn't come up with one. But it's very possible that one of you will!
meaning_hint: How hard is it to come up with a good mnemonic for a crab trap? Very hard!
reading_story: You know what else is very something? Jeans (じん). Jeans are very expensive. Jeans are very tight. Jeans are very popular. Jeans are very a lot of things.
reading_hint: How many sentences can you make with very and jeans? More than me I hope.

meaning_story: If a tsunami is good then it knows not to hit land, and instead wanders the open sea. As long as it wanders, it won't damage any land or people. What a good dude.
meaning_hint: Picture that good hearted tsunami, wandering the open sea. It's really just a big wave now. But it's doing it for the good of the people, so you have to respect it!
reading_story: You can go visit the wandering tsunami if you get a rowboat (ろう) and row yourself out to see. Then you can wander the world together. How romantic.
reading_hint: Imagine wandering the ocean by rowboat. It might make your arms tired, but you have to admit, it's pretty cool.

meaning_story: You make a tree spicy by turning it into a wood block print. The spice comes from all the porn you put on there. What? It wasn't me. Porn wood blocks have been around for ages!
meaning_hint: Imagine the journey a tree took to become a spicy wood block. MmMmm.
reading_story: You make these wood blocks using a zoo saw (あずさ) because a regular saw can't handle how spicy these wood blocks are gonna get once they're covered in dirty pictures.
reading_hint: Imagine using a zoo saw to cut the blocks out of a tree that you're going to spice up with awesome smut.

meaning_story: Put on a helmet and jackhammer at the top of a mountain to worship the gods. They won't be able to hear you if you aren't making a loud enough noise, so you went as close as you could get on top of the mountain and jackhammered as loud as you could so they'd pay attention to your worshiping. And you can't go mountain climbing or jackhammering without your helmet!
meaning_hint: Imagine jackhammering on a mountaintop as you shout your praises and worshipping to the gods.
reading_story: Unfortunately, they didn't want to hear you worship like this, and you're being waaay too loud on a Sunday, so they're going to sue (すう) you. You're also being sued for damaging their mountain. They worked hard to make that, you know!
reading_hint: Imagine being sued by the gods themselves for just trying to worship them in the best way you could come up with. Lame.

meaning_story: Set fire to a geoduck if you want to annoy it. Fire won't kill a geoduck, but have you ever been on fire? It's not really pleasant. So you'll just annoy it pretty badly.
meaning_hint: Imagine how annoyed you would be if someone set YOU on fire for no reason. The geoduck has every reason to find you annoying, dude.
reading_story: You know who loves annoying geoducks more than anyone else in the universe? Han (はん) Solo! If you watch Star Wars closely enough you can see him shooting geoducks with his blaster and catching them on fire for fun.
reading_hint: Think how annoying it must be to be a geoduck when Han Solo comes around.

meaning_story: Red insects only bite barbarians. If a red insect bites you then you have barbarian blood! Waaay back a barbarian was your aunt or uncle or great great grand pappy! But the insects kinda hurt, so it's a bit of a downside I guess.
meaning_hint: If you see a red insect follow it and see who it bites. Then you'll know that person is at least part barbarian.
reading_story: You follow the red insect and see it bite someone who must be a barbarian! You look up at their face but all you can see are giant Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses. You really want to look at his face to see what a barbarian looks like but those darn things are in the way!
reading_hint: Thanks to those Ray Bans you still don't know what a real life barbarian looks like. After going to all the trouble of following a red bug too. What a waste.

meaning_story: Paint a mullet on the Mona Lisa and you'll be able to buy it for a GREAT bargain! I mean, the museum won't exactly want it anymore, right? They might even give it to you for free! Now that's what I call a bargain!
meaning_hint: Picture the angry faces of the museum owners as you get this awesome bargain. People told you the Mona Lisa would cost you more money than you had but you sure showed them.
reading_story: What's a bargain without a little bonus deal going on right? So you decide to set up a stand outside the Louvre and make your mulleted Mona Lisa a rental (れん)! That's right! Now people can come rent out the Mona Lisa for a couple days, hang out with it in France! Renting is an even BETTER bargain for all these tourists!
reading_hint: Now you can rent the Mona Lisa at a bargain price!

meaning_story: If you want to slice the power out of someone just censure them. Then they'll be cut down in front of everyone and they'll feel super embarrassed. It's the best way to slice them down without actually cutting them and getting arrested.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself as you slice the power out of that senator you hate by censuring them in front of the world!
reading_story: Once you censure them and they lose all their power, they'll be just another guy (がい). A normal guy with everything lost to him. HAHAHA!
reading_hint: Look at that guy now. What a loser.

kunyomi: それがし, なにがし
meaning_story: If you think a tree looks sweet you have to be certain before you bite into it. Trees are really hard, and usually pretty bitter (believe me) so if you don't want a mouthful of broken teeth, sap, and sadness, you really need to be sure it's the one before you start munching.
meaning_hint: Which tree do you think is sweet? That one? Or that one? Are you absolutely certain? I hope you are!
reading_story: If you really want to be certain, and not just guess, take our your bow (ぼう) and arrows and shoot the tree you think is sweet. If its the right one it will let out a sweet smell, if it's not the tree will punch you. So now let me ask you again, are you certain it's this tree?
reading_hint: Are you certain enough to risk getting punched by a tree? Are you?

meaning_story: An arrow is shot from heaven and hits right between your mouth and your mustache to correct your crooked smile. It also straightens your teeth and the crooked cut of your mustache too, who told you that looked good? Well, it doesn't matter. The heaven arrow corrected it for you.
meaning_hint: An arrow from heaven will correct all your problems!
reading_story: These heavenly correcting arrows actually come from Kyoto (きょう). They hate seeing people with crooked mustaches so they shoot them out on the regular. It just looks like they're coming from heaven because they fall out of the sky.
reading_hint: If you want someone to correct your teeth or mustache just wander around Kyoto staring up at the sky. The when you see an arrow run for it and try to catch it with your face!

meaning_story: If you hurt the mouth of another person you're a criminal. Even if you hurt them with your mouth, you're still a criminal. Never touch another person with your mouth without their consent!
meaning_hint: If you're using your mouth on other people you're a criminal. Cut it out!
reading_story: Criminals also tend to be shooters (しゅう) so that probably means you shot a person in the mouth. You're a really violent criminal!
reading_hint: If you shoot a person in the mouth you're a criminal. No matter who you are.

meaning_story: If it feels like you have a pine tree stuck under your ribs and it's making you sick, you're probably going to get diarrhea. The pine is mixing up all the stuff in there and it's going to gush out soon. Good luck with that.
meaning_hint: Imagine the pain of a pine right under your ribs making you sick enough to have diarrhea. Or don't imagine it, cause it's pretty gross.
reading_story: The diarrhea is here. It's happening. And it feels like reese's (り) pieces are coming out of your backside. It's awful. This is the worst.
reading_hint: Imagine reese's pieces diarrhea coming out of your bum. You'll never eat reese's pieces again. (Sorry.)

meaning_story: If you ride a water slide holding a nailbat and an axe you're probably going to die. Water slides are dangerous enough on their own, but there is no way you'll make it if you're swinging weapons around as you go down too!
meaning_hint: Picture someone sliding down a huge water slide, waving their nailbat and axe in the air. You can't help but think they're about to die. Once slip and it's all over.
reading_story: The person who is about to die is yelling something. "Sei (せい) sei sei!" you hear as they hurdle down the water slide. Oh no! It's Hard Gay! He's the one sliding to his death!
reading_hint: You watch as Hard Gay says his last sei and dies. What a sad end to such a happy person.

meaning_story: The animal that hangs out in melon patches is the elusive fox! They like to steal melons then come back into town disguised as human melon sellers. Foxes are tricky like that.
meaning_hint: Imagine seeing a red fox scampering through a melon patch trying to take melons with it.
reading_story: If you want to stop foxes from stealing your melons you can get one of those kits that neigh (きつね) when one is around. The kits neigh when they sense a fox, but because it sounds like a horse the fox won't run. But you'll be able to get out there and take your melons back!
reading_hint: Imagine buying kits that neigh and putting them around your melon patch to warn you when foxes are around.

meaning_story: You're stuck in your car during a tsunami and all you have to break out is an axe. You whack and whack but you're only gradually making progress. You thought an axe would be an easy way to get out of a car but it's not working like you'd planned! You have to make more than gradual progress if you don't want to drown.
meaning_hint: Imagine gradually denting your car door open with an axe while you're trapped in a tsunami. This isn't fast enough!
reading_story: As you're gradually making your door open with the axe you look up to see the New York Yankees floating by on top of their bus. You yell, "YO YANKEES (ようや) to get their attention. They see your gradual progress and start throwing balls at your car to help dent it open.
reading_hint: YO YANKEES! Gradually yelling that saved your life!

meaning_story: You see twenty slides lines up like a grid. You don't know who put them here, but they almost look like the grid paper you do your maths homework in. But who would use a slide as grid paper?
meaning_hint: Picture twenty slides laid out in a grid systems.
reading_story: As you stare at the slide grid you see some people come out and overhear them talk about their mass maths (ます) tournament happening later today. Oohhh it IS a giant grid. And they're going to use it to do maths later!
reading_hint: You can make a grid out of anything if you set your mind to it. And you can do math anywhere as long as you have some grid paper!

meaning_story: Have you heard the tale of the woman who fell in love with a coat rack during a full moon and made him her groom? It's a true story! She even had a wedding ceremony and had more coat racks sitting in the grooms side. The moon will make people do craaaazy things.
meaning_hint: Imagine what it would be like to fall in love with a coat rack and make it YOUR groom.
reading_story: The best part of the story is that the only coat on the coat rack groom was a moose coat (むこ). So the groom was a really skinny stick with a giant moose hair coat hanging down it.
reading_hint: Could you love a moose coat enough to marry it?

meaning_story: You put some flowers right inside a cage to hide them from your boyfriend. You got him flowers for valentines day, but you bought them too early. If you hide them in the cage in your room he won't find them until you're ready to give them to him.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself thinking about where to hide the flowers and settling for the cage you just happen to have in your room.
reading_story: While you hide the flowers in the cage you notice your hookah sitting in there too. You might as well toke up (とく) while you're here! Hopefully he won't find you hiding in here with flowers, toking up.
reading_hint: Hide in your cage and toke up while thinking about what a great girlfriend you are.

meaning_story: You want to say something in private so you have them meet you inside a kiln so you can be more humble and discreet about it. There's no humbler a place than an giant oven full of lumpy pottery. So say whatever you want and the other person should understand you're trying to lower yourself.
meaning_hint: Imagine taking someone inside a kiln to say what you want to say but while being humble about it. This way no one can get mad at you for rewarding or being rewarded in front of everyone else.
reading_story: When you're in the kiln saying humble things the setting makes you feel like the other person is your kin (きん). You're usually very humble with your kinfolk too, and now you feel like this person is practically family.
reading_hint: Being humble goes a long way, whether it's with your kin or non-kin.

meaning_story: Flowers that you oversee are always indigo. You aren't sure why though...
meaning_hint: Imagine if every flower you were supposed to oversee was indigo. Indigo everywhere!
reading_story: Wait, maybe these flowers are only indigo because there is something wrong with your eyes (あい)! Maybe your eyes are indigo and that's why it's all you see!
reading_hint: Can you imagine having indigo-only seeing eyes? I can. Because of this awesome mnemonic.

meaning_story: Carve a tree into a bar and lay it sticking out into the water to make a jetty or a pier. Now you can walk out on the jetty and go further into the water without needing a boat or getting wet.
meaning_hint: Imagine laying your tree turned bar into the water to make your own jetty. Innovative!
reading_story: You made this jetty so it would be easier for Santa-san (さん) to dock his sleigh. Oh, you didn't know? His sleigh is more of a speed boat now, so he needs a jetty to give you presents, not a chimney anymore.
reading_hint: Picture Santa-san coming in from the water on his speedboat and docking on your jetty to deliver presents to you.
