meaning_story: If you try to hide in a bad enclosure from the sun it's not going to work, you'll die of exposure, and become a martyr for people who have no shelter. Soon homeless people will look to you as an example of what they shouldn't have to become. You'll be their hero, like a lot of martyrs become. That doesn't really help you stop being dead though, sorry.
meaning_hint: Imagine people calling you a martyr because you tried to hide from the hot sun in a bad enclosure and died. It's nice that they remembered you, at least.
reading_story: The only reason you became a martyr wasn't because you didn't have shelter, it was because it was June (じゅん). In June the sun gets to hot that it will kill you if you can't hide from it. This is really all the month of June's fault that you're dead.
reading_hint: Everyone is calling you a martyr because you had bad shelter, but it's June's fault! You can't tell them though, because you're already dead.

meaning_story: You see the lid of a grave under your kitchen table and lift it to find a pit right in your house! Who dug this? Where did this grave lid even come from? Why would someone dig a pit under your table in the first place?
meaning_hint: Imagine moving the grave lid to the side and lowering yourself down into the pit under your table.
reading_story: You venture down down down into the pit until you see a soft light. You inch closer and see... こういち?! He dug the pit under your table? What the hell man. You can't live down here in this pit!
reading_hint: Picture こういち living in the pit under your house. He's shrugging at you. This is his pit, it's your table that decided to be on top of it.

meaning_story: Sauron is the only person with the ability to quit. The rest of you are pretty much slaves to him, but if he wanted to leave he could at any time. He is in charge, after all.
meaning_hint: Imagine how unfair it is that Sauron gets to quit whenever he wants, but you can't.
reading_story: The only reason you wish you could quit in the first place is because of the immense heat (ひ). Mount Doom is full of lava! Lava is hot!
reading_hint: The heat makes you want to quit. Why can't you?! Auhg damn you Sauron!

meaning_story: If the death of a woman occurs it's because she was being reckless. People don't just die out of no where! They have to have done something super crazy to cause it. Right? Yes... right.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself watching the news about a woman's death. The word RECKLESS?! pops up on your screen and keeps flashing. Huh, she must have been, you think to yourself.
reading_story: As you watch the news about this reckless woman you find out that she died from mowing (もう) her lawn. You're not sure how, but now you really believe that she had to be doing it really recklessly to die doing it.
reading_hint: Imagine what reckless thing that woman had to have done to die while mowing the lawn. Eww.

meaning_story: Flowers in a tsunami that look like they're products of a tree are really seaweed. Trees don't grow underwater, so what else could it be? Seaweed is the flower and leaf of the sea! And tsunamis sure like dumping lots of it on land.
meaning_hint: Picture all of the seaweed building up on the tsunami and pouring down on the land. Some of it gets stuck in trees, making it look even more like flowers and leaves. You know better though. That's just seaweed.
reading_story: You take the seaweed and you decide to sew (そう) it to the tree. It looks like it belongs there, so why not. You take your sewing machine and prop it up on the branches and sew away.
reading_hint: Picture yourself sewing seaweed to a tree. That's a really strong needle you have there.

meaning_story: Tsunami's have a certain tendency to secrete things as they go back out to sea. When they bash themselves onto the land they just throw a bunch of sea water around, but there are only certain things that they'll secrete when they're leaving.
meaning_hint: Certain tsunami secretions are dangerous. Can you think of any?
reading_story: Most tsunami's secrete heat (ひ). It takes a lot of energy for a tsunami to crash onto the land so the water is really really hot, and it has to secrete that heat as it's going back out to sea.
reading_hint: The next time someone asks you what does a tsunami secret? You'll say heat!

meaning_story: Use your mouth to sing and a clam shell to stroke your shamisen, and you'll be performing a shamisen song just like that! Yes, it's that easy. Just go find a clam shell, open your mouth, and you'll be singing one too in no time!
meaning_hint: Imagine using your mouth to sing and a clam shell to play the shamisen to perform your shamisen song!
reading_story: A shamisen song is just an 歌 (うた) but with a shamisen. But they're still songs so they're said the exact same way!
reading_hint: A shamisen song is a song yay!

kunyomi: あぜ, くろ, ほとり
meaning_story: Half of a rice paddy is always on the shore. Japan is surrounded by water, after all. So it only makes sense that half of every rice paddy is right next to the ocean shore, right?
meaning_hint: Picture a rice paddy. Half of it is trailing off into the shore. Hear the seagulls. Feel the ocean breeze!
reading_story: You decide to walk along this shore when you see Han (はん) Solo lounging in the sand. He's waving for you to join him! You get to lay on the shore with Han!!
reading_hint: Imagine laying on the shore with Han Solo. Enjoying a cool drink. Smelling the fragrance of the rice paddy behind you. Yeah, this is the life!

meaning_story: Your leader has some squid but he's being really thifty and frugal with them. You're hungry too, but he won't let you have more than one piece. What the heck. How can one person be so frugal with their food?
meaning_hint: Imagine being as thrifty as your leader. Do you think you could hoard all that squid to yourself?
reading_story: You're glaring at the thrifty leader when Ken (けん) from Street Fighter shows up out of no where. Those squid were his! His friends (he wasn't even going to eat them)! He shoryuken's the leader and grabs all the squid.
reading_hint: Picture Ken kicking your thrifty leader and taking his squid back! Yeah! Right on, Ken! But... you're still hungry!

meaning_story: Put a beggar in a coffin and hit them with a nailbat to torture them. Wow, you're awful.
meaning_hint: Imagine pushing the beggar into the coffin. Imagine lifting the nailbat. Why would you torture someone like this?
reading_story: During this horrible torture you hear the laughter of an old man. You know that laugh. It's old man ごういち. He's seen what you've done to that beggar. And now he's going to get you! Before you know it he's pushed you into the coffin and you're being tortured too!
reading_hint: Remember kids, don't torture anyone unless you want old man ごういち to come torture you too.

meaning_story: Give alcohol to a demon and you'll see how ugly it really is. Demons need to concentrate to keep their disguises going. Even if it looked pretty when you met it, like super handsome, give it a few drinks and its facade will slide off and reveal its super gross demon face.
meaning_hint: Picture the drunk demon as it's pretty face drips off revealing the ugly crap piled underneath.
reading_story: You got the ugly demon drunk by convincing it to drink shooters (しゅう) with you. Now that its ugly face is showing though, it's too embarrassed to do whatever its evil plan was and just orders another round instead.
reading_hint: Picture yourself drinking shooters with this super ugly demon. You feel kinda sick and it's not from the alcohol. It's from this things face.

meaning_story: After a tsunami recedes back into the ocean, your husband puts on his cleats to go check if anyone still needs help down in the valley. Tsunamis like to dump most of their water into valleys, and usually it gets stuck there, even after everything else is over. And you need cleats to walk through the valley because it's all wet and you will slip without them. Valleys are dangerous during and after tsunamis!
meaning_hint: Picture your husband putting on his cleats and heading down to the valley after the tsunami to look for people to help. What a good guy. Not everyone would risk their life to go down to the dangerous valley.
reading_story: Your husband checks the valley and finds a few stranded KKK (けい) members. They seem to be stuck in the very middle of the valley where most of the tsunami water is pooling. Too bad they're KKK members, you husband thinks, and leaves them there.
reading_hint: Imagine the KKK members stuck in the water filled valley. Imagine not caring because they're jerks, and leaving them there.

meaning_story: When you see a tsunami coming courage wells up inside you and you gain the power to save everyone you meet before they get washed away! Feel that courage boil and spread throughout all your limbs. You feel like you have super strength. This tsunami isn't going to hurt anyone while you're alive to stop it!
meaning_hint: Imagine what it feels like to have courage well up inside you. Courage in the face of certain death!
reading_story: Who does that courage well up inside? You (ゆう)! In fact, YOU feel like there is a never ending well of courage bursting out of you now. You are going to be a hero!
reading_hint: Who wells up with courage? You do!

meaning_story: If you don't wear a helmet a geoduck will jump out of the ground with a sword and stab you in the face. When you die your wife will be a widow. How dare you be so careless by not wearing a helmet!
meaning_hint: Picture your widowed wife angrily holding the helmet you refused to wear when you went out on the day you were stabbed by a geoduck.
reading_story: Now your widowed wife is too afraid to even drive the car (か). Every time she tries, she picture the geoduck jumping out of the ground and slashing your helmet-less face. Now the car is just sitting there, unused.
reading_hint: Picture your widow wife refusing to get in the car. Picture her clutching the helmet you didn't wear.

meaning_story: You're walking in a greenhouse when you see a small drop of water fall and it makes you yearn for the person you adore. You haven't seen them in so long. But something about being in this greenhouse and seeing that tiny water droplet made your heart burst with longing.
meaning_hint: Imagine how it feels to yearn for someone else when you see the small water drop. Imagine how your heart feels.
reading_story: As you yearn for that person from your past, you look back at the drop and see... Bobo (ぼ) the clown?! Uhg. Apparently Bobo dropped that small drop of water.
reading_hint: Now you yearn for being somewhere Bobo is not.
